description:
It's Friday in October, around 2:00 PM.  The scene is quiet in Chinatown: not many tourists or locals, just a few of us who either have the day off or are done with work already.  After having lunch in North Beach, I was craving an egg tart.  Hoping to win the lottery and catch this place open, I started walking towards the bakery. (Pro tip:  do not attempt to drive directly into Chinatown.  Park in one of the nearby garages or take public transportation.  The streets in this hood are too narrow and too busy with pedestrians to make it worth your while).  

Jackpot!!! Golden Gate Bakery was open AND there were only a handful of customers inside.  I was served right away, with everything at my fingertips.  If I wasn't already full, I probably would have bought out all the goodies (which would not have been smart, since I was walking/bussing around).  The lady at the counter wanted me to get everything, but I chose 4 egg tarts and two sesame balls.  She placed them in a pink box, tied it up with a string, and cut out some holes in the corners (since all the pastries were still warm!).

To say these items were large would be the understatement of the year.  The sesame balls were as big as a baseball and super tasty!  Just one could be a meal in itself.  And the egg tart was as advertised... the best I've ever had.  The crust was flaky, the filling was warm and luscious, somehow both heavy and light at the same time.  

Somehow, I restrained myself from eating the entire order right on the sidewalk and saved some for my wife.  But next time, I might eat them all myself!

Lastly, this place is cash only.  There is an ATM across the street.  And while I was fortunate to not have to deal with the throngs, be ready to wait in line if they happen to be open.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is a small Chinese pastry dessert shop in China Town. Everyone knows they are known for their egg tarts so we decided to try it out this weekend.
There is usually a line out the door but definitely worth it because the egg tarts are so creamy and fluffy. They come out super fresh and hot.. a little too hot so don't burn your tongue. But it is definitely the best egg tarts I've ever had and it is a little bigger than your average. 
They wrap it in a nice pink box for you and cut holes in the box so the egg tarts can breathe. A MUST TRY if you like egg tarts!
author: Katelin N.

description:
The 40 minutes wait was well worth it. Make sure you call the bakery before arriving -- there are some days when they are not open.

Egg Tarts 
- This was the only thing I order, but that's all you need to order. Hands down, these were the best egg tarts I have ever had, and I've tried many many egg tarts throughout my life. The egg tart is truly baked to perfection. The crust is flakey but thick enough to support the egg custard in the middle. The egg custard itself is perfectly sweetened but has some sort of addictive taste to it that makes you just want more of it. Even after leaving it out in the cold for 4 ours it still tasted amazing. It will still taste as amazing even if you reheat it the next day. This place is well worth the hype and I would recommend this to anyone.
author: Eric Q.

description:
OMG! O!M!G!
Their egg tarts! 
Popping hot, freshly made!
I haven't had such a good egg tart for years, and it is definitely THE Best I've had in the US for the past six years. I love love how they have the right amount of sweetness in the egg custard, and the shell is crispy and the layer in between nicely soggy. Just, perfectly made. This is just how an egg tart should be.
I was lucky so that when I arrive, there was only six people in front of me. It took me about 5 min to get my egg tart and black bean moo cake (yet tried). By the time I left the line got really long and there were 30 people already. Would advice come here between 300-430pm in the afternoon to avoid the crowd.
author: Tian G.

description:
I don't usually like egg tarts with a flaky crust, but these egg tarts are amazing. They're super fresh and straight out of the oven so don't burn yourself when you eat it right away (I can never resist)! The crust is crispy and buttery, and the egg custard is mmmmm. These egg tarts are actually a lot thicker than normal egg tarts as well (they're more than an inch in thickness).

$2.50 each! Beware of the line though, and they're often closed for "vacation" so I would call before stopping by. d:
author: Alice C.

description:
Food: 1/5       Price: 1/5      Service: 1/5      Ambience: 1/5

Way overhyped, very very dissapointed. The store didn't have egg tarts due to moon festival, so we were left with mooncakes and some other Chinese sweets. Line was very long and moved extremely slow due to unproductive cashiers. Crowded deli. Food was EXPENSIVE compared to other Chinese places, and not appetizing at all. 

Sweet Rice Pancake ($2.50) - 1/5. Didn't know what this was and the lady was bad at communicating. Greasy soggy piece of mochi cake with no flavor and minimal bean paste filling.

Sesame Seed Ball ($2.50) - 1/5. Wow....probably the worst sesame seed ball I've had. It's pretty big with ok red bean filling, but the ball was fried in cheap oil and not drained properly. It was oily and disgusting.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Typical Chinatown venue serving small bites to go. Quite big in size and not bad in taste, pork buns are especially good. Prices are ok too.
The line took maybe 20 min to make our way through, but I have heard that it can take longer. Well worth the wait. I do believe it is cash only, but do not know for a fact.
author: Quinn S.

description:
So I've been here exactly 6 times now. I think it's time to give my honest opinion. The egg custard tarts are obviously amazing, they have the perfect custard consistency, not too sweet but just enough of the eggy goodness. The crust is my favorite part, it's flaky and buttery and melts with the custard beautifully. Definitely a good bake. Sesame balls, get it if you are a fan of those delightful dim sum treats cause you stood in that line so make it worth it. The almond cookie, skip. The mooncakes pretty darn good, I've only had the pineapple and taro. 

My 4 stars...why?!! It's due to the fact that they don't have everything available even when you go the minute they open. I mean..ok fine maybe the oven just didn't want to work properly or some lack of inventory for the week made some baked goods not available but every single (6 times) time there is one item or two not available. Otherwise great little shop of baked Chinese goods. Take out only!
author: Sammy L.

description:
I always look forward to coming here when I visit San Francisco for the egg tart!  All the other times I have visited here there were no lines but this time it seemed like a good 30-45 minute wait as once the egg tarts come out of the oven, people order them by the dozen and it runs out real quick and the line and wait time gets longer again until the next batch.

My wife got smart and and asked a very kind lady in front of the line to purchase 2 egg tarts for us because we needed to rush to the airport to catch our flight.  She obliged and we bypassed the line and enjoyed our hot, fresh out of the oven egg tarts in less than 5 minutes wait time (LOL, we did get some evil stares from people who were still waiting in line when they realized what my wife did)!

The egg tarts are delicious but this is the first time I am able to compare the egg tarts here and at Lido Restaurant in Richmond, BC when both are still fresh in my mind and palate.  Lido wins as Golden Gate is lacking the egg flavor Lido had in its egg tarts.  Don't get me wrong, Golden Gate egg tarts are still very good and I will continue coming here as it is a lot closer to me than having to cross the Canadian border...but, just saying, Lido is better.
author: Johnny N.

description:
Came here last week and was so happy to see that the bakery was open for once! Proceeded to line up only to learn about 10 mins into waiting that they were NOT selling their famed egg custard tarts, and it turned out they were doing their moon cake special. Ultimately, I decided to stand in line and order some moon cakes to try..I was already there, after all. To be specific, the moon cakes that they sell are the Cantonese variety, not the Taiwanese ones.

Upon getting my foot into the door of the bakery, I could see their extensive moon cake menu. There were so many different fillings and you could choose to have anywhere between 0 to 4 yolks in your mooncake. I ended up getting just two: a white lotus one with 1 yolk and a pineapple one with no yolk.

I definitely like moon cakes and always look forward to the Mid-Autumn Moon Festival, but let's be honest....they're really heavy. Normally, I can maybe eat 1/8th or 1/4th of a moon cake in one sitting and probably be okay for the rest of day. Golden Gate's moon cakes were noticeably lighter than other moon cakes I've eaten. The flavor of the white lotus paste was still sweet, but not cloyingly so. The saltiness of the yolk paired well with it. I especially liked the pineapple moon cake, which is one that I've personally never had until now. The pineapple filling is actually tart and I felt like I could have easily eaten half of it without any regrets.

The egg custard tarts of Golden Gate Bakery are rightfully legendary, but don't pass up on their moon cakes either when that times comes around!
author: Clarice C.

description:
Big thumbs up for Golden Gate Bakery.  GGB's egg tart is indescribably delicious, fluffy, light, egg tart that I ever have!!
I have seen many reviews and recommendations about Golden Gate Bakery in tourist guides
However, Golden Gate Bakery ISN'T a TOURIST TRAP who only knows how to fool tourists. Both San Francisco locals and tourists loveeeee their egg tarts!
Also, you gonna be lucky enough to taste the egg tarts, because the owner lady will close the store A LOT for vocation.
author: Regina W.

description:
The egg tart I had was brought all over SF and shoved into a fridge before my friend reheated it for me and W O W - it was probably one of the best egg tarts I've had to date. 

The first thingI noticed was that this egg tart was a bit bigger than most I've had before. The exterior is thick enough to hold the custard filling and not get soggy but was also buttery & flaky (no cookie type crusts here!!). The filling is also nice and smooth and is not overpoweringly sweet - it's honestly a perfect balance. 

I've passed by golden gate bakery a few times before and have never tried it myself just because the line seemed way too long, but having tried it now, I'll definitely be making a visit for a box or two!
author: Janice L.

description:
This place does seem a bit overhyped.

I got the famous egg tarts, which were good but not noticeably better than any I've had elsewhere. It was nice that they happened to be fresh out of the oven and the crust was buttery, but besides that the filling itself was almost tofu-y and a bit bland in my opinion. At $2.50 a pop, you're paying a premium compared to other spots in Chinatown without an upgrade in quality.
author: Harry X.

description: The egg tarts are now $2.50 a piece, but still so good and irresistible. Make sure you pick up some when you're near the area!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
This place came highly recommended by some coworkers and friends. I stopped in after work to pick up some pastries to bring to my friend's house for dinner. 

Firstly, heads up this place is cash only. I found that out when I got there and had to run across the street to the Citibank to get cash. 

You have to be really aggressive to order here. People just kept jumping in front of me. It was not organized at all. 

Prices were higher than I was expecting. I think their celebrity has led them to increase prices. 

I ordered a taro moon cake and a coconut moon cake. Wanted to try the egg tarts, which were highly recommended but they were sold out. 

The cakes were good if a little dry but not worth the stress of ordering or prices in my opinion.
author: Ashtar B.

description: I came here for the mooncakes. They have decent prices, and excellent mooncakes. It comes in a no-frills paper box, but I prefer it that way. For the holiday season, the rest of their baked goods were abbreviated, which was fine. I came here for the moon cakes anyway. Come, stand on line, make your order, pay cash. It is simple as that. I might come back to try their egg tarts, since that is their other specialty.
author: Jane H.

description:
Yummy! Love Golden Gate Bakery and all of their deliciousness. They have buns and egg tarts and dim sum food and egg tarts..... LOL yes, their most popular item is egg tart. It is flaky on the outside, with a perfect egg custard on the inside.

Located in SF's Chinatown, Golden Gate Bakery is difficult to get to as there is no private parking or even street parking right near it. You'll need to walk your way over, but it could be a fun experience as there are tons of little stores and boutiques to pass by. 

This bakery is notorious for closing on random days, so try to call prior if you can. 

P.S. Their moon cake is absolutely delicious! Perfectly dense and smooth paste... drool
author: Katherine S.

description:
Yes, this place will serve you one of the best egg tarts you've ever had. Just be patient. The line is almost always extended out the door, but it moves quickly!

I went on a peak Saturday afternoon during the summer and the line was maybe 30-people deep. It took about 20-minutes before I made it to the front. The space is tiny (no seats/tables) and there are only two people working the counter at a time.

Each egg tart is $2.50 and it is cash only. If you don't have cash, there is a Chase Bank ATM conveniently located directly across the street.

I ordered two -- one to eat and one to take home -- but I could have easily devoured a couple more... easily. You have been warned.
author: Jordan H.

description:
Finally was able to catch them open. No joke, like many others, whenever I pass by this place, they're always on vacation so it's definitely a win when I finally got my hands on these egg tart. 

The egg tart is $2.50 for a decent size (bigger than normal). It comes out pipping hot from the oven. I swear they're making a new batch every second. If you get it right when they come out, I recommend letting it sit for a bit. I got it right out the oven and obviously it was hard to eat and everything just didn't settle. I had some the next day - the crust was still crispy and flaky and inside was delicious and jiggly! 

Tip: cash only! Call to see if they're open before coming in.
author: Sherluna V.

description:
Golden gate bakery - perhaps one of the most famous parts of the food scene in SF. 

What makes this place so great? Honestly, I think it's the high demand and the allure of catching them when they're open. They take random vacations and a lot of the workers here have worked there for decades (one of ladies told me she's been there for 30+ years!)

Egg tarts is their game and yes, they've pretty much perfected it. Will you stand in a long line waiting to grab some? That's the real question. These egg tarts coming out piping out and fresh out of the oven. That's why you're really waiting in that long line - because the shop is TINY and I'm sure only so many trays can be baked. 

But the end result of all your waiting? Deliciousness. Light flakey but crispy crust that's a little buttery but delicious with a creamy custard that's not too overpowering of egg but delicate and light. And that, is just perfection. 

I'm going to be honest - I'm biased. I grew up in Hong Kong and grew up on egg tarts. So I love them in general, but golden gate's takes me back to those days in my childhood that I can't find in other egg tarts. 

The egg tarts at $2.50 a pop and honestly, just buy what you're planning to eat. Don't buy 4 dozen, don't buy a dozen just because you've been waiting in that line. Heck, don't even buy them to take home or on a plane or whatever. These things are best eaten when they're fresh out of the oven and any other experience will be lackluster. 

Now....the secrets. There's a facebook page that sort of tracks whether the store is open. Use it. Don't call them, don't try to check out their yelp hours. Just look up that facebook. Parking in Chinatown is a hassle so use the facebook! Secondly, if you're planning on ordering a good amount (even like a dozen), you can CALL AHEAD AND SKIP THE LINE! 

What?! Skipping the line?! Yeah. I didn't know about it either until my last experience where a woman came in and told the workers (Hey, I'm here for my pick up order of XYZ). Of course that was all in Cantonese and that's if your phone call gets picked up.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This place is a must go-to whenever you're in the San Francisco Chinatown area. It is home one of the best egg custard tarts in the country. This place often has a line out the door so thats how you know this place is legit. Do not let the long lines fool you because it moves rather quickly. 

At $2.50 per egg tart, they are rather pricey. I remember when they were about $0.60 each in NYC's Chinatown. Oh how time flies. Once you're inside, you have the option of purchasing the egg tarts individually or by the dozen. They also offer other Chinese baked goods such as sesame balls, rice cakes, Chinese "rice crispies" and moon cakes.

The rice cakes had a distinct cooking wine aftertaste to them, somewhat sweet and a chewy, airy texture. I'd say try it out if you haven't had it before, but other than that, skip it. 

The famous egg tarts were warm and straight out of the oven when we purchased them. The crust was buttery and flaky and complemented extremely well with the warm egg custard in the middle. One can easily eat 5-6 of these if they wanted to since they were so delectable. 

Overall, I really enjoyed my first experience here at Golden Gate Bakery. The goodies that they offer here are delicious and would satisfy any sweet tooth. The staff here speak little to no English so keep that in mind when ordering.
author: Henry T.

description:
A must when strolling around SF's Chinatown. I was fortunate to find parking literally a store down from GGB. It was meant to be. Before I walked in, there was probably 3 people on the line but the line goes by pretty quick if you know what you want. Its not hard if you're coming by just to have a taste of their famous and fresh egg tarts. Of course, they sell other pastries and I was tempted to try them, but I ended up getting half dozen egg tarts for $15. They're $2.50 each. More than double the amount of what I pay for in NY. 

It was certainly my lucky day when the egg tarts I got was fresh out of the oven. You bet I had to try one of them as I walked out. So fresh that within the first bite, some of the egg custard fell right onto the box. The crust was perfectly flaky and the filling was hot, springy and sweet. One of the most DELICIOUS, not to mention FRESH egg tarts I've ever had in my life. I even saved some to eat the next day and they were still good! Please come to GGB for egg tarts and then, you can thank me later :)
author: Rita L.

description: I came in expecting to be tricked by the hype, but find myself really enjoying the custard tarts here. There's always a bit of a line, but should pass in about 10-15 min. Each custard egg tart is $2.50. In each piping got bite, you'll get a big mouthful of soft custard and flaky crust that's light but tasty.
author: Will X.

description:
EGG TARTS! First visit here and be prepared to stand in line and wait for your goodies. Cash Only! this is what yummy creamy delicious egg tarts suppose to be like and fresh out of the oven. We waited about an hour 20minutes on a Sunday late afternoon and picked up 2doz of these tasty treats. They also have other items on the menu like coconut macaroons , moon cakes to almond cookies it's a treat! 

try it! 

street parking , $30doz for egg tarts prices may change so make sure you have enough cash with you.
author: Michelle M.

description:
FIRST TIME here.. Serendipitously stumbled upon GGB thru Yelp, while exploring & doing our 7k+ steps.

We had absolutely NO IDEA how deliciously fresh and fluffy these custardy Egg Tarts were gonna be???

I mean the line is INSANE! It's nuts that people wait for several hours for these delectable tarts. 

We had no clue what we were in for, as we stopped by around 1pm. We were 5th in line, & after 45 minutes of waiting around, I was confused... 

No egg tarts available at bakery, so I went inside this tiny cluttered messy hole in the wall bakery to inquire? The ladies said the fresh batch would be ready in approx 45 mins?? But wwwwwwhhhhat? We had naively waited for 45 mins already??? We were too vested to walk away at this point and I HAD TO TRY THESE CUSTARD EGG TARTS after every one around us (whom were also waiting in line) said there's nothing like these in creaminess, fluffiness, custardiness, texture.... Hhhhhhmmm?

After 2 hrs in, we were finally getting our infamous pink box with yellow string. We each burnt our mouths & hands, as we bit into our steamy hot tarts - well exceeded my expectations!!! It's actually better than CRACK.. I ate 3 back to back after burning my tongue & fingers, lol!

But call in advance to pre-order to bypass the insane stand-by line. Lesson learned for our next San Fran trip, hahahaha!
author: Nine S.

description:
You guys, I spontaneously stopped by and they were open!

1. We were aimlessly walking around Chinatown and I remembered Golden Gate Bakery and we decided to walk in the direction to see if they were open. And they were open, on a Friday evening! I was so surprised because I expected them to be closed.
2. When we walked in, no egg tarts to be seen. Then out of nowhere, a lady walks to the counter with a tray of fresh egg tarts and I was next in line!
3. $30/dozen egg tarts, $2.50/egg tart. I got 6 for $15. Pricey for egg tart, which is why -1 star.
4. These are the prettiest egg tarts I've ever seen. They're filled to the brim with custard. The crust is thin, but still flakey, which I love. They had the perfect amount of sweetness. And the cherry on top is that they were still warm after 15 mins.
author: Tammy P.

description:
Honestly, I had never heard of Golden Gate Bakery. A friend of mine said I should try their egg tarts when he found out I was in San Francisco for business.

I wandered into Chinatown after dinner in the Financial District and - according to other Yelp reviewers - was lucky to find that they were open AND there were no lines. I was informed that they were out of egg tarts, but the next batch would come out in fifteen minutes, so I waited.

The store is tiny and consists of a counter where you order and pay, cash only. During my visit, they still had a lot of moon cakes left over from the Mid-Autumn Festival. I probably should have purchased one, after reading the moon cake reviews here on Yelp.

As I waited for the egg tarts, a crowd started forming of people waiting for them. The store owners were cheerful and friendly, making small talk with customers while we waited. Every two minutes, the store owner would call the kitchen and hurry them up to send the egg tarts. After the fifth call, I started feeling really bad for the poor person on the other end of the line.

When I finally managed to get my hands on one of the precious egg tarts, it was way too hot to eat immediately. I took it back to my hotel room, where I was able to enjoy the flaky crust and creamy filling. Damn, I should have purchased more of them!
author: Tom S.

description:
I can't believe they're open for once! I've been flying up to the Bay area from LA quite frequently and they're always conveniently on vacation when I visit. I swear they do it on purpose but I'm glad I got to experience their famous egg tarts for once. Hailing from LA, we've got a lot of Hong Kong dim sum restaurants in the 626 but they can't compare to those up in SF. Historically, Chinese immigrants settled up north for the railroads before coming down to LA and I feel like those ancestors established different Chinese cuisine than those down in LA. Not only does it taste different, the people who make them are different. 

Enough with the history lesson, let's get down to business. The egg tarts here has a flaky crust all around and an extremely hot core when you take your first bite. I have never tasted any egg tart fresh off the oven and straight into my mouth. For a box of 12, $30 may seem steep but it's worth it. I can see why the business owners take so many vacations throughout the year. You must try this place out of your ever in SF and only if they're open, which usually is 50/50.
author: Chris Y.

description:
I'm not sure what the big deal is here.   I'm the famous China Town but the goods weren't as good as many of the newer bakeries imho.

Maybe just me... But seems more for namesake than actual delicious.

Been to quite a few bakeries in my day and... Yeah.  This place was just meh.  So very meh.
author: Ben H.

description:
Best egg custard in SF Chinatown. They're warm and the crust is not as thick as some places I've tried. It's a good size not the minis at dim sum. The taste is more on the eggy side... Will come back to try coconut tart!

I also ordered boxes of moon cake to bring home. White lotus seed with 1 yolk... however, 2-4 yolks are available to pre-order. See photo for complete menu. The line is long here and parking is definitely not easy like everywhere else in SF.
author: Dee P.

description:
Egg tarts were fresh out of the oven because of the high turn over. If it wasn't for the fresh out of the oven hotness effect, i'd prolly give it 2 stars.

To be honest, the tarts at Golden gate bakery were just average, definitely not worth the long wait.

Bakeries like these are a dime a dozen in Los Angeles, prices are competitive if not cheaper.

So come to Golden gate bakery for mediocre egg tarts but are guaranteed fresh because of the high turn over.

OR If you have time to kill and just want to wait in line and tell people you've waited in that line then feel free and go ahead too. Life is short, do what you want.
author: Steven H.

description: One of the best egg tarts you'll ever have! Baked warm and fresh. Be prepared to wait on the line! I've heard some people wait an hour for it. Luckily whenever I go, I only get to wait a couple minutes.
author: Elise L.

description: Been wanting to go here ever since I heard the hype but never actually had the time to wait in line for them until today. We passed by near closing time and saw that the line was more bearable. Wow, they know how to make an egg tart, fresh and warm with a flaky crust! The only downfalls are the long wait and the price. Can't believe I waited 30 mins and paid $10 for 4 egg custard tarts! I didn't even know other items on the menu existed for this place! Not sure when they start to run out but I think they were getting close since they started asking each person in line how many they were going to order. We also passed by the next day to find that the place was closed for the day... so glad we spontaneously stood in line the night before!
author: Monissa W.

description:
Don't get me wrong ... I'm a fan of egg tarts. From bakeries to Dim Sum restaurants, egg tarts are a classic treat! Having bookmarked this place for what seemed years, I happened upon GGB about 15 people deep. First off, what may be surprising is that they're open and second of all there were only 15 people in front where the line usually goes down the entire block.

After a half an hour wait, settled inside the small bakery of strewn boxes and miscellaneous non-bakery related items (Look inside, you'll get what I mean ...) there isn't much-baked goods out in their counter and the egg tarts come out on trays from the back. Decided with a wait, might as well get my money's worth and got 6 egg tarts.

Egg tarts came out piping hot. Smelled delicious and was properly placed in a box and tied. The egg tart smelled and looked beautiful. Nice deep cups, flaky and buttery crust. The egg custard itself, although hot and molten straight out of the oven was not to my liking. I mean, I may have burnt off 50% of my tastebuds by the sheer heat of the damn thing but it was way too water and eggy. I prefer egg tarts that are more set and creamy versus egg and these were exactly the opposite. Nothing against the way they make egg tarts, just personal preference. Ended up eating my egg tart and brought the rest home for the family to consume. They ate the egg tarts but there were no remarks on it being delicious or exponentially better than anything else we've had.

Was lucky enough to happen upon GGB when they were open and with a "short" line. Would I wait in line for these egg tarts? Absolutely not. It did knock off an SF "To Try" off my list, however.

CASH ONLY
author: Janet N.

description:
Foodgasm in your mouth! These egg-tarts should always be a go-to when you're in San Francisco. Fresh out of the oven and piping hot, the custard is so buttery soft that it melts in your mouth. The crust is flaky and crisp, but also thick and layered to hold all that custard without falling apart. It's sweet but not overpowering like warm milk in your mouth. When they're hot out of the oven, they're amazing. When they're cold, they're still freakin' good.

This place is always swarming with a line down the block and around the corner. (Because of its popularity, they're constantly making fresh tarts to keep up.) The wait is 100% worth it. We waited close to an hour for the tarts. However many you think you're going to get, get 2 more. Once you've had one, you'll be glad you did. And after waiting that long, you deserve to treat yourself.
author: Victoria W.

description:
Probably one of the most hyped places in SF Chinatown. There's even a specific fan-made website notifying you if the bakery is open today or not (since the bakery is so popular, the owners tend to go on spontaneous vacations, leaving fans stranded). You'd often find a line out the door with dozens of people waiting at any time but trust me, IT IS SO WORTH IT. 

Though there is usually a line coming out the door, the grandmas are really good at hustling people in and out quickly. I only had to wait around 15 minutes with about 10 people waiting in front of me. 

Speaking of which, the grandmas running the shop ARE SO GOOD AT HUSTLIN' YOU, IT'S ALMOST SCARY. There was a Indian family in front of me who were obviously tourists and was asking me what was good there. One of the grandmas overheard them and before I could reply she said briskly, "Every thing is good". At the end of their visit, she convinced the family to buy nearly every pastry. I was impressed. 

Anyways, back to the food, what they are known for are the heavenly Hong Kong -Style egg tarts. Since this bakery is so popular, you can expect the egg tarts to be fresh any time of the day. It is UH-MAZING. The tart crust is extremely flaky, tender, and buttery. The custard is glassy, smooth as silk, and blow-your-mind good. At $2.25 a pop, these are pretty cheap for the amount of deliciousness you get. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND YOU AT LEAST BUY ONE--- or two --- or 3 -- IF YOU ARE EVER IN THE AREA.
author: Julie D.

description:
From the corner of my eye, I saw a giant line hugging the streets up ahead. I've heard of Golden Gate Bakery from plenty of people but have yet to try it. I decided that this would be the day to embark on a 45 min wait on a Saturday evening to take the chance! 

There's some magic finally walking into the store and seeing the pink bakery boxes, moon cakes and freshly baked egg tarts--like going into a prize show to collect my rewards. Each egg tart was $2.50 and you only get a box if you order 6, otherwise they put 2 in each white paper bag. 
I love sweets and egg tarts aren't new to me, but these are really quite good. And I mean GOOD. You can actually taste the nutty egg, the perfectly balanced crust that's got a good balance of sugar and salt. Try to eat them when they're hot and go when you have a good chunk of free time :)
author: Leona C.

description:
We arrived on a random Tuesday morning and only had to wait twenty minutes in line. Definitely call the store ahead of time since it seems like their operating hours are somewhat random. At first, I was skeptical that the egg tarts here could really be THAT good, but after putting one of these delicious morsels in my mouth, I was made into a true believer.

Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts are amazing! Fresh from the oven, the custard is silky smooth and ever-so-slightly sweet, while the crust is buttery and flaky with an almost lightly fried texture despite it being baked. At the time of this writing, one egg tart will set you back $2.50 in cash ($30 for a dozen), which is a bit expensive, but I chalk it up as a "popularity tax" for being so good. Yes, these really are the best egg tarts you can find on the West Coast!
author: Kevin C.

description:
Wow, this place lives up to the hype, no joke. The vast majority of opinions here seemed to say even though the entire experience getting to the food was terrible it was worth it, and yea it is. Our particular experience wasn't even that bad because we got there around 1pm and it was OPEN!!! If you don't know already there's a website dedicated watch-dogging this place for being open/closed and hours. When we went on Monday they had a sign that they'll open at noon. The line was short but moved slowly, probably took us a good half hour of waiting. 

There is no filming inside the store, and there were two ladies taking orders and wrapping up your food. It's crazy the # of things people buy, I saw a girl walk out with 5 dozen egg tarts! It's pretty reasonably priced since $2.25 each or $27/dozen. We were going to be reasonable and get 6 but decided we'd be stupid not to get a full dozen. We were right, we had a wait a little bit because they were out and we were waiting for the next batch, and it was totally worth it. They also have other items other than egg tarts since they are a bakery, they had amazing looking moon cakes, etc and I ended up getting a sesame ball as well that was filled with red bean paste. The sesame ball was good too just slightly greasy.

The egg tarts are actually pretty big and it's filled WAY up to the flaky crust. I don't know how but every single egg tart is so perfect and it's truly just beautiful to look at. It's also the PERFECT amount of sweetness and the texture is a firm custard. The crust is nearly indescribable, it's flaky, buttery and perfectly complementary to the custard. Hands down the best egg tart I've certainly ever had in my life and it's ruined me for egg tarts at 85 degrees, etc. Each egg tart was also super filling and though the flakiness disappeared by the next day every single one and bite was absolutely amazing. 

So yeah, I would totally do this again, it's btw a very non descript tiny hole in the wall in Chinatown and there is pretty much no parking. Good luck.
author: Amy K.

description: Ok When you first go there and see the line, you'll probably think "really, is it worth it?" the answer is an overwhelming YES. When you get the egg tarts (yes, plural) you'll realize why everyone and their moms waits for this. It's steaming hot (watch out) and the shell is so thin. It's the best egg tart I've ever had in my life and I go there multiple times a week. Best place ever and I'd take anyone visiting SF to go try it too!
author: Connor W.

description:
I've resigned to the fact that this place is one of the biggest disappointments of my travel career. 

Oh don't get me wrong, their super famous, freshly baked egg tarts are absolutely as delicious as everyone says, like, 10 stars... IF you can get some.

In the past 6-7 years, I've made 6 trips to San Francisco from Los Angeles and only during ONE of these trips was the freaking bakery even "officially" open. I've stood in line for hours when they were "unofficially" open - yanno, when they exchange egg tarts and cash through a tiny crack in the door. I've stood in line for an hour in the rain waiting to grab a couple. I've basically seen more "ON VACATION" signs than egg tarts. 

Today, on my current trip from Wisconsin, my honeymoon of all things, again leaves me disappointed because apparently the owners are on vacation for three WEEKS. My husband hasn't been to SF for a couple of decades and he loves egg tarts. I was so, so, so excited to have him try Golden Gate Bakery's that it was one of the first things to do on our list. 

This place is legitimately a highlight of San Francisco if they can manage to honor their business hours and care just a tad more about their customers.
author: Belinda J.

description:
Ever since moving up to the bay, it has been a longtime dream to sink my teeth into an egg tart from Golden Gate Bakery. It is quite a hilly trek to make it out to this area, and I had tried and failed three times. This place is family owned so hours and closure could be quite random and frustrating. There is even a website counting on the community to check to see if its open (http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/)!

We got there around 12:45pm and there was already a massive line even though it had just opened. It took about 45 mins to get through, but it was definitely worth it! The egg itself is more like a creme brulee, with a hard shell on top that crumbles easily to yield to a light and fluffy custard. The crust is perfect, neither undercooked nor burnt. It also was pretty amazing that after 20 mins, the egg tarts were still freshly warm after purchase. 

For $2.50 a pop, the tarts are more on the pricey side. But they are a bit larger than the average ones you would get at dim sum restaurants.
author: Lily C.

description:
Man, I always used to walk by Golden Gate Bakery and thought how ridiculous it was seeing people lined up here all the time. I have always been told that Napoleon Bakery in Oakland Chinatown was comparable and I took people for their word, but they never had that massive line outside. Finally, one day, we noticed that Golden Gate Bakery was open when we were walking somewhat later in the evening and there was barely a line so my boyfriend suggested lining up. There were fresh dan tat right out of the oven at the time and the line was short, so why not?
We ordered two dan tat, which my boyfriend checked with me twice about. He kept suggesting ordering a dozen but I said no. Oh my gosh, worst mistake ever. These dan tat are heavenly and perfectly flaky and sweet. I have never had such good dan tat EVER!  I thought about them all weekend. I think about them whenever I walk by. There is no comparison. Golden Gate Bakery is so much better than Napoleon. Don't talk to me.
Yes, it's cash only and yes, they are expensive for dan tat, but man, you pay more for macarons. Shut up and give them your money because it's freaking worthwhile.
author: Jenn T.

description:
I went.

It was open.

I conquered.

I did it. I finally did it. After years of business trips, ubers to Chinatown only to realize it is closed, I finally went to Golden Gate Bakery when it was open. The line was about 20 minutes or less (an anomaly, my friend says) on a Saturday after lunch (suspicion: everyone was watching the Golden Gate playoff game). I ordered a eggtart and yes, it's delicious. The egg consistency is more on the runny side, then jello like, but is not too watery. The actual pastry part itself was also amazing. I usually don't like the flaky eggtarts as much, but this one was just flaky enough and not dry. Must eat when hot and fresh.

I docked one star for the inconsistency of open hours/no way to tell unless you go there. There is a facebook group and website dedicated to whether or not the Golden Gate Bakery is open (go google it) but they don't always update, so sometimes your're still at the whims of fate.
author: Jade L.

description:
I'm pretty sure the "Gone On Vacation" sign is always on their door, but if they happen to be open GO INSIDE. 

I've never been when there wasn't a line, but it's well worth the wait. Yes the asian ladies inside might abuse you a bit, but it's well worth the amazingness that is their egg tarts. They're massive, and crispy on the outside, custard filling on the inside, AMAZING when they're piping hot, and still so good when they're cold. And all at an awesome price. 

Overall, these are probably the best egg tarts I've had in SF, but is it worth the wait and the erratic schedule? That's for you to decide. I'll probably come back when I have Asian relatives to entertain.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Overall: 4.5/5 stars

After thorough research out of the yelp reviews, we can vouche for a few things...

1) The wait for us on Saturday (3/24) at 12:45 pm was about 40 minutes long so yes, it's a long wait

2) Yelp says the shop opens at 12:30, but their white scratch paper with blue ink says otherwise (12:00) The girl in green is a regular and told us they do open at irregular hours (12-1 pm) as well as the days they open (aka closes for months at a time) 

3) The coveted highly- praised egg tarts are pretty good as well as basically everything else we tried. I broke my veganism streak to try a bit of their desserts and I must shamefully say, it did not dissapoint.

4) At $2.75 a piece for most things, the pricing is a bit steep and since it's my first time here and wanted my family to try some, I spent ~$40 for 8 tarts, 2 moon cakes, 1 bag of almond cookies, and 1 sesame ball. That's pricey for food in China town haha

We got:

Egg tarts - 4.5/5
      It's one of those dishes that's easy to make decent, but hard to make stand out, and upon the first few piping hot bites, the flavor of the egg was too much (remember, I haven't had eggs in a long time) and so I deemed it decent, with potential. The crust was so flakey and was the saving grace at the time. After eating it again, cooled an hour later, the sweetness from the sugar pulled through and the custard had set to a better consistency instead of the jiggly steamed egg appearance. The bf and I both agreed this now was worth the rave. It could be that our poor souls have never tried legitimate, traditional egg tarts, so the former profile is what makes it good and what folks seek out. We don't know, don't stone us XD. 

Coconut tarts - 5/5
         We overheard people in line praising the Coconut tarts so we thought we had to give it a try as well. These were amazing! Very popular amongst my Vietnamese relative. (As a culture, we don't eat egg tarts, so while it's good, these seemed to have a better flavor profile depth-wise)

Sesame Ball (Banh Cam) - 3/5
           The intrigue with these, were that they were huge. Filled with red bean, encased in a rice/tapioca outer layer with a deep fried sesame crust, it's a classic Chinese/viet dessert. It's decent, but nothing you can't find at other bakeries. These guys are always vegan. 

Lotus Moon Cake (Banh Trung Thu) - 4.5/5
           We also over heard these were good from the crowd. The girl in front of us also reccomended it, so you know... Peer pressure.  The skin on these were dried out perfectly, texture - wise, and the filling was sweetened just enough, while the egg yolk was salted perfectly as well. My only critique is that the batch I got might have stayed in the oven a bit too long as I could taste a slight bitterness emitting through the skin. But overall, the quality and taste is the same if not better than Kieng Giang in my opinion ( Socal's popular bakery for moon cakes)

Almond Cookies - 4/5
        Traditional in taste, not overly sweet, and comes in a pack of 6-8 I believe. I'm not particularly fond of these cookies, but they were popular amongst yelpers. 

We unanimously recommend the Egg and Coconut tarts; Moon cakes for the older crowds. Leave the cookies and sesame balls behind unless you're particularly fond of those items.
author: Christine H.

description:
Quick take: Best don tat (egg tart)


Best egg tart ever! After waiting in line for 1 hour 20 minutes we bought 1 dozen ($27). Had 10 of them packed up in the traditional pink Chinese pastry box. We requested 2 to be left out of the box. Going in our bellies immediately!

After a long wait we were up next in line. Waited a few minutes for a fresh batch straight from the oven. Piping hot and fresh....fresh....fresh!!!

We also bought 6 almond cookies. Those look good too.

Back to the egg tarts. Super flaky, light crust. Filling is a creamy egg custard texture. Smooth and just the right amount of sweet. Traditional Hong Kong style dan tats is what I like. So yummy!

Wait in the long line. So yummy. Gotta leave the shop with at least 1 box. CASH ONLY.
author: Nancy H.

description:
A must visit when in SF!

Their egg tarts are sooooooo gooooooooood.
They're huge, warm and flavorful. YUM!
author: Annie H.

description: I had to try this place because of the long wait outside! It was unfortunate that I came close to closing so they ran out of the more popular items, but I ordered the egg tart since I saw the man next to me order four dozen! The workers we very friendly and quick. The egg tarts were freshly out- the egg was jiggly, the flavor was not too sweet, and the crust was super flaky! I will be coming back to try the other items next time!
author: Tammy L.

description:
Closed till June 30,2018. 
No problem, i come to ct often enough where i'll still be satisfied with an egg tart a month. 
The fact that each time i get it, the crust is flaky af like when i used to get them after chinese school back in 2006, the tart is gooey and smooth, it keeps me coming back a decade later. 
Your local asian establishment with some flare. It always looks closed but you just gotta look lol.
author: Amiee C.

description:
I've had my fair share of egg tarts and the ones sold here are up there in terms of taste and authenticity. Especially when you eat them while they're still warm from the oven and the crust is super flakey - an amazing feeling. They have a lot of other Asian desserts, but the egg tarts are definitely what people come here for.

At first glance, this place doesn't really seem like much, just another one of the numerous bakeries in Chinatown, but then you see the perpetual line snaking down the street. Definitely come on an off time if you don't want to wait over an hour to get your food. On a side note, the staff don't speak/speak very little English. $2.50/egg tart is a little on the pricier side for this area, but they're actually pretty decently sized, and the experience of eating one of these pockets of heaven is worth.
author: Lydia S.

description:
This place is insane! I have been lucky with this place and all my trips here I've gotten short lines and been on days where they would randomly be open.

The last trip here I was in SF just for 12 hours and we came and they were only open for that single day in the WHOLE month! 

They definitely don't care and close randomly without notice.

However it's worth a try to stop by in you're in SF and grab a box of these piping hot egg tarts.

I've been to Hong Kong and eaten a lot of delicious egg tarts and these at Golden Gate bakery are still my favorite!!

They trek at $2.25 each now but each tart is large and pretty filling! I got my latest dozen for $27
author: Tammy N.

description:
Ways to check if they're open because the owners are always on vacation: 1) call 2) check http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ or 3) check their Facebook group of the same name. 

Expect at least an hour wait, but it's worth it if you flaky egg tarts! It's hard to find parking so I'd snatch any spot you can find blocks away. 

I tried making egg tarts on my own, and man, it's hard. So $2.25 is worth it.
author: Angela T.

description:
$27 for 12 egg tarts

I no longer see a line at this place because their hours are so infrequent, that and price increases each time I come back.

ehh. The egg tarts are delicious, but not enough to pay a premium price and go all the way there to have the perpetual "We are closed for vacation" sign. 

If I'm in the area, I might stop by, but I will not make a special trip for this bakery.
author: Angelica C.

description: I walked by early this morning (Saturday) to get some of their amazing egg tarts only to see their open sign at 11:30 am instead of what Yelps listed.
author: Van D.

description:
The perfect softness and flakiness!!  If you can get these egg tarts when they come right out of the oven, you will experience happiness in your mouth.

Sometimes you're lucky and there's only a few people in line, other times you have to wait over an hour, and the worst is when they're on "vacation" aka they can open and close whenever they want because they are that popular.  It's always a gamble when you try to come here.

Each dan tat is $2.25 and it's CASH only!  Not that cheap, but worth the money!  You'll kind of forget how much you spent on them when you're eating it, then realize later your wallet is empty :(  They're a good size and so so delicious!  Check out their other items as well, such as their huge red bean sesame ball.  But you definitely have to try the infamous egg tart here at Golden Gate Bakery!
author: Stephanie Z.

description: Ok yes the egg tarts are out of this world but you can't believe how many times we've attempted to come here only to find out they were either closed or had run out. I mean the hype is well deserved but I wish they were more reliable about being open.
author: Julia L.

description:
This place is a must-visit stop if you've never been to SF Chinatown. First came here when I was a kid, so several decades ago! 

The ladies behind the counter are the same, and they have gotten saucier now that they have learned english. Overhearing how I told a tourist that the egg tarts are the best thing here, one of the counter ladies drily feigned hurt feelings and said in pretty good English: "hey we have lots of other stuff that is good, ok?!" Gone are the days when they scolded unsuspecting tourists from around the world in rapid fire Cantonese ....these ladies reign in terror now that they are bilingual!

Seriously do not expect any customer service here. Be prepared to stand in line for 45 minutes for the privilege of being a customer. Do not tell them that you want egg tarts that are less burnt bc you will be ignored or told to leave. Be prepared to hand them cash quickly (they have no patience here) and to be treated brusquely. Also do not be surprised if they disappear for months at a time (handwritten sign on cardboard will read: on vacation) ... if you try to call ahead you will get yelled at and possibly hung up on.

But also be prepared to eat the most delicious egg tarts, fresh out of the oven, with their molten egg custard centers still tender nestled in their flaky, buttery pastry shells. Eat these hot, standing on the sidewalk. You've officially been initiated into the club of those-who-know locals who enjoy such delicacies in SF Chinatown daily. 

Then walk across the street and find the alley with Bruce Lee's face and take a photo of yourself.  Congratulations for finding the real SF Chinatown experience.  I always bring friends here if they want something authentic and unique.

And don't believe the egg tart ladies.  There is one item on the menu that people come here for. Egg tarts. So buy yourself a dozen (they'll cut a little hole to let the steam escape). Enjoy as many fresh out of the oven, standing on the sidewalk and then bring home the rest.  Don't worry, there will be a long line of people doing the same thing. Be prepared to feel self conscious because the tourists who don't know about GG bakery will be looking at your egg tart trying to figure out what the big deal is. 

Everything else at this store is ordinary and can be gotten elsewhere without a sour attitude lol. But their egg tarts are the best.
author: Joyce M.

description:
Walking down Chinatown on a Friday afternoon, my family and I saw a short line forming. We looked this place up and saw great reviews, so we stopped. The line got longer quick. Line doesn't move very fast, but 2 ladies working and everyone ordering big box/ boxes.

Everyone in line was talking about how great the egg tart was and this place isn't open everyday. 

We got egg tart, coconut tart, coconut macaroons, and some other stuff I can't remember. These were the best out of what we ordered.

Egg tart - what they're known for. It was great strong egg taste but sweet with a crust. Came out piping hot. Could see the steam coming from it. I personally liked it better, once it cooled than when it was warm.

Coconut tart - looks kinda like corn bread muffin. It was light, soft, buttery, with a coconut taste. I don't even like coconut like that. This was better than the egg tart to me.

Coconut macaroon - crunch on the outside, soft inside. Soft, sweet, crunchy, and buttery taste. Wish I had ordered more.

It was nice to stop by and try something different. Egg tart was good but the coconut tart and macaroon were better. If in the area and they're open, I'd probably stop again if I had time. I wouldn't go out my way to get here though.
author: Ashlyn K.

description:
Nothing you haven't already read - these are the best Chinese egg tarts I've ever had.

I'm rarely in the area let alone during non-peak times for the best chances of trying one, but I made the trek on a weekday in the early evening hoping I could try at least one. To my surprise they had ~5 left in the case and I guess more in the back because people after me ordered a bunch.

Lady gave a pause when I asked for only one, but these guys are good size. One or two per person is plenty, best eaten outside the shop while it's fresh.

Whether you're a local or visiting SF, make a stop. Bring cash.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
Possibly the best egg tarts I've had in the states so far! To be frank, I really haven't tried that many places so my standards could be low, but everyone I know/don't know Love their egg tarts so hopefully that says something. 

The irregular hours though...... it's quite frustrating. They never announce when they'll be operating and very frequently close down for MONTHS. If anyone has any clue about their operating hours/system, I will be eternally grateful!!
author: Mandy H.

description:
I am so, sooo torn about this place. I really want to like this place. Like, I want to like this place so badly, but am I wrong for not seeing the hype? YESSSS the tart crust is the bomb diggity. Buttery, flaking, soft, cooked perfectly and you can taste the sugar they coated the tins with...but am I wrong for not caring about the egg tart filling?? I am sorry, does egg tart usually taste like eggs with a jello- tofu texture where it's that firm??? Maybe I have been too tainted with new egg tarts like 85 degree bakery...but I didn't care too much for the custard. I didn't think it was rich or creamy so I was bummed. I was really looking forward to this. It just tasted eggs, but nothing else really. It was semi-sweet which was nice, but the crust was richer to me.

The line wasn't too bad when I got there. I only waited 30 minutes. The creme horn looking cannoli was good though. I really liked the filling b/c it had walnuts and raisins, but the dough was just okay to me. Overall, very fast-paced. Know what you want because they take orders fast and people will try to order before you even though they're after you in line. Cash only! $27 for a dozen. Pretty big tarts though so 1 was enough for me. Random hours and EVERYONE comes here. A lot of locals, people even driving 1 hour or 2 away to just come here, and tourists. I think it was worth trying though. LOVE that they bake everything fresh. so it is piping HOT when you order. Appreciate their service and quality.
author: Tan Lo S.

description:
I've come here twice already and they were closed! But third times the charm and they were opened and yes as usual a line. The line was only 25 minutes so not too bad. People literally go crazy for this stuff!!! I only wanted half a dozen egg tarts but the guy in front of me got TWO DOZEN and the guy behind me got EIGHT DOZEN! and there was still a long line. They must have fairies in the kitchen working hard or have made hundreds in advance. But it was everything people said it would be. Tasted very eggy and real. The crust was yummy too. Even my husband who doesn't like egg tarts loves this too. 

I would go back again.
author: Marlana Y.

description:
CASH ONLY

I only get the egg custard here. Flakey, lightly buttered crust yummmm

Right in the heart of China town you will find a line in the morning with hoomen egg custard lovers. This bakery definitely lives up to their hype!!

Only down fall is that they occasionally close whenever they want due to whatever reason. BUT GUESS WHATTT there's actually a fan based group facebook that tells you when they are closed hahaha. Love it!!

Will be coming back soon.

Pro tip: Either walk of uber, lyft, bike, bird etc. here if you can. If youre trying to find parking, GG
author: Dorian C.

description:
The BEST egg tarts I've ever had. Slightly pricey on the higher end (at $2.50 each/$30 per dozen), but totally worth every penny.

Golden Gate Bakery specializes in pastries, more specifically, the amazing egg custards, moon cakes, and other baked goods. The egg tarts contain a fluffy egg filling that melts in your mouth and a flaky crust that texturizes the taste. Highly recommend for those who want something light or have a sweet tooth!

I've also had the coconut macaroons which were very chewy and crunchy in texture. A pretty solid pastry, but not as outstanding as the egg tarts and very comparable to other coconut macaroons made at other bakeries.

Lastly, I just wanted to emphasize that they're almost always on "vacation" (i.e. closed). Make sure to call in to see if they're open for the day. Expect a long line, but a relatively normal (15 - 30 min) wait. Parking will be difficult; I suggest public transit, Uber/Lyft, or walking.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Finally got to try this today after a few failed attempts at figuring out when they would be back from vacation. One egg tart is $2.25, a dozen for $27, and I also purchased a sesame ball (which is HUGE) for $1.75. The sesame ball has some red bean paste in it and was delicious, though for the size that it was, there wasn't a whole lot of red bean paste. The egg tarts were delicious and relatively big too!

Overall, delicious! I would come back but not often because it is so difficult to figure out when they will be open and it's also more expensive than other places.
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
These egg tarts are bomb.com. I can vouch for them as I've already eaten 3 in the last 12 hours and I'm still not sick of them. Anyway it's impossible to be since they're that good!! 

They're flaky on the outside, and the custard is soft and had a tofu-like texture. Tofu might be gross but I'm telling you the custard is just pure yumminess. The best part about these tarts are that they're no where near being sickeningly sweet. They're perfect. Everything is perfect about them!! 

Get a dozen of hot piping tarts for $27 or $2.25 for each of them... But why would you just buy less than a dozen? You're gonna have to wait in a long line anyway so might as well make it worth it.
author: Ivy C.

description:
They have the BEST egg tarts!!! I heard stories about long lines during the weekend (1+ hour wait) so if don't want to wait in that long line, my advise to you is to come on a weekday and you will have the egg tarts in your stomach in no time! 

You should eat the egg tarts right away when they are still hot and fresh, the egg custard is super soft and jiggly with the perfect sweetness. The puff pastry is done perfectly, you can tell the time and effort they put in to create the puff with so many layers!

The shops opens and closes whenever they want and they do sell out from time to time to so you might have to come here a few times before you can successfully buy it.
author: Katie M.

description:
After 5 tries, I was finally able to buy the infamous egg custard tarts, and they didn't disappoint.  Fresh out of the ovens, so these were warm, crispy, flaky, and the custard just melts in your mouth.   There was just the right amount of sweetness to the custard.  At $2.25 per tart (or $27 for a dozen), it was worth every penny.

I picked up one of their giant deep fried sesame balls filled with red bean paste, and it was delicious as well.  Nice and crispy.  This one giant ball certainly filled me up.
author: Sklar T.

description:
We called to see if they were open since they're notorious for randomly closing shop and taking long vacations.  Some mean lady with the nastiest attitude answered and immediately started yelling that she was busy blah blah blah (Cantonese) and lectured us for calling them.  Like, how dare you call us during our busy business hours.  They really have that "I DGAF about your business (money)" type of stink attitude.  They really couldn't care less.  I guess the popularity got to their heads way too much.

Uh, first off.. we are not from around here.  We are visiting and don't know "your phoning rules".  I was actually very polite.  If you hate answering the phone that much, then DON'T answer the damn phone!!!!!!!  To go off on your customers over the phone like that just leaves such a bad disgusting taste in our mouths.  We would rather fly directly to Macau to have THE WORLD's BEST EGG TARTS!  Yours is average compared to the ones sold in Macau.  You people need to be more humble and realize your customers "made you" as popular as you are today.  But you treat them like they're bothering "YOU"?  That was exactly how they made us feel.  EXACTLY.  Well, we're not sorry for "bothering" you.  We're sorry for giving you our "business" (money).  You are overhyped, overpriced, and over-rated.  

The custards are $2.50 each, a dozen for $30.  They're small and gone in about 2-3 bites.  Their prices went up and they only accept cash but there is a Chase ATM across the street.  They are located in the busy bustling area of China Town.  It's chaotic driving around that area and good luck with parking.  You'll be wasting a lot of gas just driving around looking for one.  You'd have to be super patient and super desperate for egg custard, otherwise, just go... just go.  It's highly stressful and frustrating to maneuver around the area as there are pedestrians EVERYWHERE!  Some don't even abide by the traffic signals, like they're on a suicidal mission or something.  Reminds me of China, literally.

There are other less popular bakery shops nearby which sells pretty decent egg custard tarts for way less.  The lines aren't as crazy either and the workers won't treat you like you don't matter.  I love egg tarts but no egg tart in this world can make me stand in line for more than 30 minutes max.  Well, maybe Macau's egg tarts... hahaha
author: Kelly O.

description:
Best egg tarts in the United States. I use to love egg tarts as a kid growing up but all the bakeries in New York City has compromised the quality of egg tarts. It's cheaply made and doesn't even have flakey crusts. So when I heard that Golden Gate Bakery makes them the authentic way, we drive 4 hours from Reno to San Fran during our vacation. 

We arrived 15 min before opening because I anticipated a line after reading reviews. There was still a short line ahead of us. The ladies that worked there were very nice and friendly. I explained to her that I'm from NYC and wanted to bring a dozen home to my family and she let me pick it up before I left San Fran later that day. 

Now the egg tarts... It was warm, gooey, and the crust with light, airy, and crispy. It was literally perfect. I haven't had egg tart this good since my trip to Hong Kong back in 2012. We also got the banana roll, rice cake with peanuts, and Portuguese egg tarts. Everything was fresh and delicious!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
There's always a line for this place out the door. Well, that's because their custard egg tarts are so delicious and also because their bakery is super small without any seating areas. They have other pastries too but their egg tarts are the #1 seller. The egg tarts cost $2.25 each so $4.50 for 2, or you can buy an entire box around $28. This place is CASH ONLY which is typical of most places in Chinatown.

Two older grandma-type ladies run the shop and can be a bit impatient and mean with you if you don't know what you want or if you don't have your money in your hand. They said they don't have the time and have other things to do. I learned that today-it was my first time there. However, they really do have tons of customers and their egg tarts are delicious so I know they're busy dealing with customers.

So, let's talk about them egg tarts. The crust of the egg tarts is made with layers and layers of hand-rolled (most likely since this looks like a traditional Chinese pastry) flaky dough. Perfectly crispy. The interior of it contains a perfectly baked egg custard filling: bouncy, smooth, and delicious. It's the consistency and taste similar to that of of creme brûlée- rich and sweet. Also, I find 1 egg tart quite filling. It's a bit bigger than ones served in other places like dim sum restaurants.

I think I waited around 15+ minutes for this and the line can get pretty long but I highly recommend this place if you're in San Fran!
author: Cindy N.

description:
Love the tarts, but I think the only reason they are any good is because they are coming out hot due to the mass of people. When they are cooled down, they taste like any other tarts. 

I'm primarily giving them a 2 star rating because they really don't care about their customers and are just trying to milk it due to the unwarranted hype. I don't live too far away so it's not necessary for me to go out of the way to get, however they are constantly closed on random days with just a sign that says it's their day off. They do not operate with a regular schedule and I'm sure this frustrates many people trying to get some due to the hype. 

Lastly, I challenge anyone that says their cooled down version is substantially better than others. Hot food always tastes better than cold food. So you can't compare apples to apples.
author: Drew R.

description:
Last year, I weary to San Francisco and saw that bakery people line up miles away for the egg tarts I didn't try it. So this year I went back and put myself in line.  OGM!!!  The best egg tarts I ever had.  The crusts was so crispy and delicious, the egg cluster was so smooth and perfect.   It's worthy to stay in line for that. 
I will definitely go back if I'm in n San Francisco again.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Despite the erratic business hours, Golden Gate's egg tarts are the BEST! I stopped by around noon, and the shop hadn't opened yet; by the end of the day touring SF, I stumbled back to the shop to find the bakery open with NO lines at 8pm. Hooray! The egg tarts are rich and creamy, yet they don't feel heavy. It was hard NOT to gulf them up. They're still delicious the day after.

If you're lucky enough to get the the egg tarts. Buy MORE than you think you need!  You won't regret it, and your friends/loved ones will thank you!
author: Maggie C.

description:
EXPECT A LONG LINE

NOT OPEN EVERYDAY

NOT OPEN ALL DAY

NOT ALLOWED TO TAKE PICTURES, without the ladies permission (Chinese superstition) 

But the egg tarts are FVCKING MAGICAL!!! They are so delicious & crispy, buttery crust!!!! *drooool* 

Definitely over priced, but you get what you pay for when you magical egg tarts made of gold (not really, but you know what I mean)
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Everyone told me Golden Gate is a staple for making egg tarts in SF Chinatown. It truly is and an unassuming one too. It is so easily overlooked when you walk by due to its simple and outdated store front. You can say they keep it real and I honestly think they just don't bother updating or spending money. Whatever the real reason is, they draw a long time among tourists and locals alike. 

They sell a selection of Chinese bakery goods including egg tart, coconut tarts, fried sesame balls, walnut sponge cakes as well as seasonal moon cakes. I have never tried the other items here but I did see people buying them. I haven't been here for over 2 years and I just came by last week to find out that each egg tart is now $2.25. I think it is overpriced for lack of visible reinvestment into the business. If you pimp up the space, come up with new flavors, adjust to inflations or open additional stores, I feel it makes sense to increase the price. However, when other places sell them at the same price over the years and they raise it to over $2, it just seems like greed to me. Then again, I am no business person and this is just my silly opinion. 

If you really crave warm fresh out of the oven egg tarts when you visit SF, you should certainly look up their odd store hours and wait in line. Otherwise, I would say seek other alternatives.
author: Athena C.

description:
Tucked away deep in Chinatown is Golden Gate Bakery. A bakery that has managed to establish themselves as a premier egg tart producer, despite being surrounded by numerous Asian bakeries.

Let me start off by saying, this is the best place to get egg tarts. No other place compares. There's just something about this recipe that tastes so heavenly. The custard is the right amount of sweetness and the crust is flaky and soft. What I really like about these egg tarts too is that they are not too oily. I don't feel completely greasy after stuffing my face. And, the custard to crust ratio is perfect (not too much crust and they don't skimp on the custard).

I do have to knock off one star because of the number of times that I have been disappointed by Golden Gate Bakery. It has nothing to do with their egg tarts, but solely because every time I come here, they are closed, contrary to what their Yelp page says. I've attempted to come here probably 6-7 times, but was only able to catch them when they are open twice. I highly recommend calling ahead of time before making the trip here to avoid any disappointment. 

Aside from egg tarts, they do sell other Asian goods.
author: Yennhu N.

description: Update your business information on social media if you're not here.  Thanks. Also, two weeks starting from when?
author: Andy L.

description: Stopped by the bakery! There was a line outside the door! saw all the options and decided to stay in line! there was a woman behind us who helped us to make selections! The women Inside notified they took only cash!Luckily there was an ATM across the street. They have a smaller menu on the counter for you to use to see the pricing. a few things they were out of, but we Made our selection and it was tied up in a nice box!
author: Cienna G.

description:
I don't claim to know much about egg tarts, but this is definitely the best I've ever had! You need to eat it when it's fresh and warm! The egg custard is perfectly creamy and custard-y. It's not stiff like most others that I've tried and the crust is so flaky and buttery. I'm getting hungrier thinking about it. 

As other yelpers have mentioned, the business hours are quite sporadic so I'd call in before you make the trek out, but if you're in the area and happen to pass by when they are open, I'd recommend going in and ordering an egg tart or five. You won't regret it. This place is super hyped up, but for good reason. You won't find a better place for the the egg tarts than here.
author: Christina C.

description: Mooncake is a Chinese bakery product traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival, this was the best one ever!
author: Jay R.

description:
Best San Fran Trip ever!! After lunch at The House, we walked to check out the Lunar New Year celebration in Chinatown and Golden Gate Bakery was recommend by cousin. I heard all the scoops on Golden Gate Bakery, that they usually close early, not opened during their business hours, closed when sold out, and closed for vacation. Besides the very LONG lines. As we were getting close to the bakery, I see and noticed the lines out the door. I had to do it, I stood in line while my cousin shopped and then vice versa. I was so happy as the line moved closer, & closer, & closer, then BINGO! We placed our orders, 2.25 a piece, cash only, packaged nicely in a pink box, and tied nicely. We received the precious tarts fresh & hot and I couldn't wait to pop them in my mouth. Actually we all couldn't wait!! My cousin's husband drove around (due to the festival & the crowd) and we met him after we got our precious tarts. 

The plan were to eat them when we got to our destination but we all couldn't wait, so we ate them in the car, all of us!!  

OM-goodness, super wow!! Those custard tarts are so yummy, fresh, hot, creamy, it was the best egg custard tarts I've ever had. Can't even compare those precious tarts we have here in Hawaii, Size, price, & taste wise. 

Tip, Best to call ahead to see if they are open, there is a Facebook page titled "Is the Golden Gate Bakery Open Today?" check the page for info. on if they are open, before you go. 

Overall, This is sure the best San Fran trip ever... super happy & grateful that I get to try the precious custard tart from Golden Gate Bakery, What a treat!! 

A must to stop here at Golden Gate Bakery, don't know when I will be back at San Fran but I can't wait to be back again!!
author: Judy C.

description:
One of the most staple food items in San Francisco is the GGB egg tarts. Everyone knows about it and everyone knows what a rarity it is to get some. You never know when it's open, but there's literally an entire website dedicated to whether or not this place is opened: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ 

GGB has pretty damn good egg tarts, but not worth the wait. This was probably my first physical visit to the store and I waited a good half an hour before their opening. The line inched by, but we were in no rush. I ended up only ordering two egg tarts ($2.25 each) and a bag of their "Cow Ear Cookies" ($5.50). The egg tarts are delicious, yes. But I also find it to be quite pricey, but they can afford to make their prized egg tarts as much as they want and people would still be lining up for them! As for the cow ear cookies, they were very pricey from what I remember at other Chinese shops. This traditional biscuit snack is one of my childhood favorites, so I did splurge a bit on myself to reminisce over.

Overall, this place is some serious hype. Unless you're here by request from someone out of town or trying to bring some souvenirs, I wouldn't waste my time waiting here.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Be prepared to wait quite a bit for these tarts, I think I waited like half an hour. The egg tarts take some time to come out and there are only two ladies selling them so it takes some time. That being said I really enjoyed the egg tarts.

The egg tarts themselves aren't amazing special in some way, it's just that usually when you get egg tarts they've been sitting around for some time and kept warm, so they just taste mediocre. 

Here because the line is so long and there are so many people coming in, you can pretty much be sure they are pipping hot when you get them, which adds to their deliciousness. That and the fact that you've waited in line so long for them make them extra good.

They are good though, the crust was flaky and the egg was creamy, but as I said, the freshness from the oven are what make these so good.
author: Tyler T.

description: Showed up and waited in line for the fresh batch of egg tarts and man were they good. I wish I would have bought more than 2 when I did because they were well worth the wait. Soft and creamy inside with a crispy and flaky crust, great taste overall. I had no idea what to expect but this is definitely a must try when in Chinatown.
author: Taylor N.

description:
Stay on track and just stick to egg tart!   Omg, we have been trolling them for egg tart and was never successful because they're always closed.  I thought they're closed for good.

So I chance it again and cold call them today...so surprise when I hear a voice on the other line telling me they're closed by 8pm.


They have haphazard hours and unreliable.  Just call them before heading there.  


Don't trust the hours posted on yelp (those hours are as good as Christmas decorations)
author: Phg T.

description:
I came on a Monday which I had the day off. There was still a line which isn't so bad compared to the weekends. The bakery only had fresh egg tarts, sesame roll, and red bean pastry. I ordered 8 egg tarts and one sesame roll since they were expensive and hard to come by since waiting in line can take up to 1-1/2 hrs on a weekend. A dozen egg tarts costed $27!

After dinner, I ate the egg tarts, and they were fresh and sweet. The tarts didn't soggy up the crust. The tart wasn't heavy on the stomach like before so I can finish 1/2 my egg tart at ease. I sampled the large sesame roll; regardless, of its large size, it was a good as the sesame rolls I've eaten at my local bakery.

It's still worth waiting in line for as long as they don't run out.  This was my 2nd trip to Golden Gate bakery for the year. If I had to go again, I'd come on the weekday for a shorter line.
author: Miriam T.

description:
I admittedly only came to see what the hype was all about, had never even had an egg tart in my life. Unfortunately the entire ordering process was so stressful that after waiting in line for 45 minutes we finally got to the counter & nearly just left without ordering. 

After seeing dozens of customers leaving the store clutching their prized pastry boxes we finally reached the counter only to be totally ignored. Several customers behind us spoke to the ladies in their native language, had their goods boxed up, paid & left before we were even acknowledged. While waiting at the counter 3-4 people walked in, skipping the entire line, had dozens of items boxed, paid and left. A customer in front of us could see my agitation, explained they were waiting for more egg tarts to be brought up but to be honest we could have done without if we had even been acknowledged. Incredibly frustrating so for that we'll never revisit.

The egg tart had a delicious golden crust, the custard was lightly sweetened and perfectly rich. The almond cookie was very hard tho I'm sure would have been delicious with a nice cup of morning tea. The winner for me was the coconut macaroon, golden on the outside with a sweet chewy center.
author: Kymberly C.

description:
My bf and I were on the hunt for these elusive egg-tarts. Legend has it that they open  whenever they want and close whenever they want, but that didn't deter us from trying. We went midday on a Sunday and luckily they were open! Even more lucky for us that the line wasn't too long. There were 3 people ahead of us but we waited maybe 15-20 min for fresh egg-tarts. The store looks messy but that didn't seem to bother the two ladies working that day. Fresh pastries are brought out from God knows where every 10-15 min. 

Don't let all these quirks deter you! The egg-tarts are heavenly! They're ginormous (bigger price tag at $2.15 ea)! The outside is light and flaky and the inside is fluffy and not too sweet.
