It melts in your mouth! Sooo good when fresh but still good the day after. Usually the outside becomes a little stale the next day but these stayed crispy the next morning when we had them for breakfast. 

If the line isn't too long then I highly recommend waiting for these delicious egg-tarts.
author: Nancy D.

description:
$23.95 for a dozen custard tarts. The BEST egg tarts on this side of the earth.
Yes, there is some insane wait times, especially on weekends and mornings.
Yes, they bring up the tarts from a little hole which I assume is the basement and it's weird and creepy.
Yes, you cannot take pictures in the store.
Yes, they take cash only.

Despite all this, I'd still line up again to get my egg tart fix. 
Yes, it's worth it.
author: Elle L.

description:
Yehey, I finally set foot on this bakery because I want to try their signature& most coveted egg tart made in SF Chinatown. Most people said these are the best ones in the world. So I ordered 6 of these morsels. It cost $2.50 each. So it rose in price. This is probably the most expensive in the country by far.
The ratio of egg custard and puff pastry are just right. The crunchy, flaky puff pastry is excellent. The egg custard is perhaps made with whole eggs, milk, water & sugar. It is jiggly soft so it may have gelatin, & it is brushed lightly with a vanilla syrup. To my standards the egg custard wasn't really good. So it was 3/5. Pretty half disappointed on the egg custard, and half phenomenal on the pastry. I am going to try their lotus with 1 yolk mooncake later tonight.
Customer service is organized here.
The way they packaged is special, they cut the box corners to make sure the puff pastry is crunchy & flaky. So it is an art.
The egg tart is way too overpriced like $2.50. In my opinion, the Hong Kong & Guandong makes the best dan tat. Way too overhyped.
But most people think this is the best dan tat. I had tasted & eaten a lot delicious egg tarts. But this not the "Chosen One".
Few bakeries in Oakland Chinatown use a rich, velvety smooth egg tart but crust is either puff pastry or shortbread.
Dan tat is a matter of preferred sweetness, balanced taste & the right rstio of custard & pastry shell.
author: Jade M.

description:
GGB is a staple of the community in Chinatown. Everyone always walks by it and exclaims "wow what's this line for!?" You can go ahead and take your business elsewhere if waiting in line is not your thang but you will miss out on fresh baked egg custard tarts. 

It's so funny to hear so many people try to describe to their friends while waiting in line, mainly just off hand comments from passerbys like "It's some type of chinese egg pastry thing" or "it's a pastry with yellow stuff in it" or "i don't even know what it is, but it's good!" In the age of technology, it's pretty entertaining to hear comments like this ... 

Anyway, bookmark this place if you intend to visit SF and do touristy things. They are always so packed and churning out continuous tarts that you won't and shouldn't be disappointed ... unless you happen to be there on a day where the bakery is super busy and the line is extra long. then you're SOL lol
author: Misty M.

description:
When my friends come visit SF, I usually like to take them here.

I love that Golden Gate Bakery has hot, fresh, flaky, creamy, and simply delicious egg tarts. They sell other goods too, but I only really come here for egg tarts. 

However, there's almost always a line unless you swing by later at night. Also, they're closed/on vacation seriously all the time... but if you get the chance to try it, I highly recommend!

It costs $2.25 each & cash only!
author: Melody W.

description:
I have waited an embarrassing amount of my life at Golden Gate Bakery. Yes, their egg tarts are divine: perfectly flaky crust and flan-like egg that is neither loaded with sugar nor grease.

It used to be the highlight of my visits to SF, but they were closed both today and 363 days ago for weeks at a time. I understand that everyone deserves time off, but also expect businesses to be consistent with operating hours. Too many times, they close early or are not open at all.

Visit Golden Gate Bakery if you are willing to gamble your happiness on their unpredictable schedule and have lots of time to kill. Otherwise, consider supporting worthy alternates within a few blocks walk.
author: Chris L.

description: These are the best egg tarts I have eaten. In taste they are balanced by a mellow sweet and soft egg custard and a nice crisp slightly salty tart. My friends and I came around 20 minutes after it opened on a Saturday and there was still a line that extended to two shops down. The wait wasn't too bad though and the tarts were worth it. They are $2.25 a tart and a dozen for $27. I highly recommend coming here. I think my only qualm is that it is so popular that only thing it offers is egg tarts because of such a high demand. I was not able to see any other items they sell but saw the labels and was sad I could not buy a nice variety of sweets.
author: Liangcheng R.

description: I'm not really a fan of egg tarts so I think that makes me a really good person to write a review about this place actually. I thought egg tarts were absolutely gross and tasted like salmonella. However when I came across this place and saw the long lines, I just had to give them another chance. The egg tarts here were better than any I've tried. I know now I was just having the wrong tarts. They weren't phenomenal (but this is coming from someone who hated them) but they did taste good. I have to wait 25mins to get one. Happy I did because I won't be coming back. Always nice to try the popular things in a city.
author: Angela L.

description:
Sometimes I find myself questioning what's worth the wait. Well, let me tell you that these egg tarts are definitely one of those things. 

This bakery is quite elusive. Google will give you a certain opening time, Yelp will tell you another but ultimately it's the sign on their door that will dictate if you will leave happily with egg tarts in hand. I found out the hard way about the time as I arrived at 10am on a Friday ready to receive these deliciously egg-y, palm-sized treats but read the hand-written sign on the door that said "noon". I wandered around for a bit but returned by 11:30am. I was already 10th in line at this time and patiently waited for noontime. At noon, slowly but surely the line moved and I approached the counter where three older women were bustling around selling "cash only" Chinese pastries, but most of them were egg tarts being bought by the dozen. 

Totally worth the wait. Fare warning: I've never had anything like them and I crave them constantly.
author: Jonnathan B.

description:
This is a must visit bakery shop if nearby this area and also sometimes depends on luck whether they open their business. The line might be a little long and have to be patience. We have lined for 1 hour. 

I would recommended their egg tarts. The egg tarts were so good and delicious even you have it on second day. They are all freshly made when you buy it. Their egg tarts made of real ingredients especially they're willing to have enough eggs make the egg tart. So when I bite it, I can taste it so good and so real! One dozen egg tarts cost around $26, might be a little pricey, but it's fine once in a while to pamper yourself.

The lotus paste pastry was using real lotus paste and taste so fragrance. And not too sweet. I would recommended this too if they are selling. 

They have lots of other pastries that can try.
author: Jaane F.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery makes THE BEST EGG TARTS I have ever tasted in my entire life. Creamy, not too sweet, not too eggy, and just the right aroma of vanilla smoothness on the tongue. Yes, they're expensive ($2.25 each), but they're worth the price (and the 15min-1hr wait).

They also make fantastic moon cakes. Nobody makes better moon cakes than Golden Gate in SF.
author: Michelle E.

description:
This famous bakery is not what it once was.

Their signature egg custard is very small and cost $2.50  each.

In Chinatown,  there are plenty of good bakeries for much less.

Don't be fooled by the reviews which may be written years ago when they were good.
author: Doris A.

description:
Notorious for never being open, this place makes the most sought after and hard to get egg tarts in the city.

Operating hours are usually written on a piece of paper and is taped to the door and is usually only good for about a day. If you happen to walk by and they're closed but someone's inside, they might tell you the next time they're open for business.

In addition to the egg tarts, they also make other baked goods and pastries, but everyone flocks here in droves specifically for the egg tarts. Expect to wait at least an hour in a line that could stretch half a block down the street before you're able to get in to order. You don't have to worry about them running out because it appears like they constantly bake new batches, and if you're REALLY lucky, you'll end up with some tarts that are fresh out of the oven.

The tarts themselves are definitely worth the wait. They're definitely on the larger side, and at $2.15 each, it's also a bit pricy. There's no discount for buying a dozen, but there's a sign to let you know how much a dozen is. The custard has an eggy texture, is very soft and fluffy. The top of the custard has an amazing and perfectly smooth finish to it. The crust is light and airy, with a satisfying crunch to it. It's very flaky, buttery and almost melts in your mouth. The tarts are piping hot, so exercise some caution before biting into one. The workers will cut ventilation holes in the box to let heat escape as a way to prevent the tarts from getting soggy.

If you're fortunate enough to be in town when this place is open, change whatever plans you have to get here. The tarts live up to the hype and you don't get many chances to snag one.
author: Khoi T.

description:
GREAT HOT FRESH Classic Chinese Egg Tarts.  Great only if you like sweetened condensed milk flavor (aka Tres Leches flavor).  As other reviews mention, frequently a long line.  

And they must be raking it in since they are frequently "Closed on Vacation", 2 out of the 3 times we visited.  Check the "Is the Golden Gate Bakery Open Today?" Facebook page to check if they are open.
https://www.facebook.com/isthegoldengatebakeryopentoday/
author: Michael Y.

description:
This bakery probably has one of the most intense cult followings comparable to the mobs on Black Friday. I walked past a pretty long queue (~40 mins wait) at 6 PM on Saturday on my way to dinner.

Once my mom, my friend, and I wrapped up our dinner at 7:50 nearby, we found that the queue was much shorter so we opted to stick it out and try their egg tarts. We waited a whole 10 mins (one customer at the front was giving the shop owners a hard time and slowing down the process) but were able to score the last two of the night. If you do go late, it's a bit of a gamble as to whether or not they'll have any left or if they'll even serve you. 
 

As for the egg tarts themselves: they came out piping hot and had a rich egg-y flavor! If you've ever been to Hong Kong, I would say they're pretty comparable to the ones at the infamous Tai Cheong Bakery (just minus the turquoise storefront;))
author: Melissa V.

description:
Just take all my cash right now, Golden Gate Bakery.

Yes it's ACTUALLY worth the hype, yes it's worth the wait, yes it's worth the uncertainty of not knowing if and when they will actually be open or on an extended vacation spending the cash that is thrown at them on the daily for the best egg custards in the universe. :)

Things to know for newbies:
1. Be prepared to wait, usually 30mins but longest has been 1.5hrs Chinese New Year weekend (ashamed to admit it but I, along with a block of other people, waited and bonded and waited together)

2. Get the EGG CUSTARDS aka Dan Tats. They are famous for this. They are huge. They are hot and fresh out of the oven, creamy, eggy, and not overly sweet on the inside, with a toasty hot and flaky crust.  They are worth it, and I can confidently say they are THE best dan tats I've EVER had. Bold but true statement. Don't settle for small, dry, hard custards. Oh, and eat them hot right when you buy them- like standing outside the door (in front of all he other people waiting in line ;)

3. They are $2.25 each, $27 for a dozen.

4. Pro tip: Check on the "isgoldengatebakeryopentoday" Facebook page to see if they're actually open! Warning: they go on vacations or randomly close certain days. Seriously. It's not always updated but better than nothing. U can call too.

5. If you must get something else, the moon cakes are really good quality
and they have diff kinds like standard black bean, lotus, lotus w/1 yoke, lotus w/ 2 yoke, etc. 

Enjoy!!!
author: Jen K.

description:
This place became so popular with tourists, it's so hard to get an egg tart now! I have to say, they do have ridiculously delicious egg tarts. The inside custard so smooth and perfectly sweetened. Outside crust perfectly crisp/flaky. Price is a little under $2 each - not cheap but if you've ever tried making egg tarts at home from sctatch, you would know that $2 each is not that bad. 

Only reason they don't get 5 stars is because their hours and days of operation is so unpredictable!! They sometimes leave for weeks on end and I never know until I make my way out to Chinatown full of ambitious to buy two dozens of egg tarts, only to be slapped in the face with an "on vacation" sign posted on the gate. I've seen so many sad tourists take photos of the sign, and walking away with a even more sad tummy. At least I live in the city and can keep trying every time I go to Chinatown.
author: Susanna C.

description: BEST. EGG. TARTS. EVER. They were crispy and light and so thick and creamy and fluffy. The wait however is ridiculous and so are their hours. Make sure you call before you go because often times they wont be open or wont have egg tarts on certain days. Each egg tart is $2.50 and $30 for a dozen, there is no discount for buying more. They are currently selling moon cakes for about $10-11. Beware that the wait is very long because they are pretty inefficient. The employees making the egg tarts will make a batch and youll have to wait another 15-30 minutes for the next batch...It was worth it to try it but I dont know if i would wait another 2-3 hours again. I dont know if they do not have enough equipment or if they can only make a certain amount each time but they definitely need to find a more efficient way because their customers are waiting too long. CASH ONLY. Beware parking around the area is limited to 30 mins.
author: Brenda H.

description: I love their moon cakes and egg tarts! However, their business hours are always so inconsistent.  Couple times I have been, this place has always been closed! (They were always away on vacation)
author: Sunny S.

description:
On Grant street in between Jackson and Pacific is that bakery where. Let me save you some time reading reviews: $2.25 for one egg tart , $27 for a dozen .
1) They have an irregular schedule. Call and ask if they are open that day , they picked up when I called (surprisingly). This after I came here one day previously and saw the "today we're off" sign much to my dismay. 
2) They have a long line. Yes, even before they open. Tourists who are passing by frequently ask those in line "what's so good about this place". 
3) Why a long line you might ask? Because the egg tarts are good and when people get to the front of the line they figure, I might as well buy a couple dozen.  That's how I felt at least ....which I admit I was influenced by the many many people walking out with multiple pink boxes. 
4) CASH ONLY
5) Know what you want 
6) Moon pies aren't that good, at least in my eyes, stick to the EGG TART. 

Now why isn't it five stars Mr Rod you might ask???

1) I don't think it's that much better than another local establishment and definitely not if you also factor in the wait time and the price 
2) Was it good? Yes...for sure but I don't think I'd wait a long time for it again which I would for other 5 star venues which is kind of a barometer/measuring stick for me.

I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank places that sell Egg Tart...yes Egg Tart. Obviously given the nature of the food most of these places are in SF or Oakland Chinatown. 

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?).  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 

1 Mr.Bread
2 Golden Gate Bakery
3 Yummy Bakery 
4 New Hollywood Bakery
5 Ruby King Bakery
6 Napolean Super Bakery
7 Sheng Kee Bakery 
8 Wonder Food Bakery 
9 Sum Yee Pastry
10 Grand Mission Donuts and Bakery
author: Rod M.

description:
I absolutely LOVE the egg tarts here. If you're looking for quality egg tarts, you've found the right yelp page, but prepare yourself because there will for sure be a wait. This bakery has amassed a large following and grown in popularity over the years so prices and wait times have increased but quality, the most important ingredient, has remained the same. To order anything here, you can expect to wait a minimum of 30 minutes but it won't disappoint. The egg tarts (蛋撻) were priced at $2.25 each when I was last here in April 2018. I also ordered the fried sesame ball (煎堆)! 

The fluffy egg texture and perfectly flaky crust was absolutely heavenly and I wish I was back in line anticipating my next order. Each egg tart is pretty big, about 2x the size you'd find at dim sum, so eating one is already quite filling... but why stop there. Of course I had two!
author: Carrie M.

description:
Holy moly. I've finally made it!

I have known about Golden Gate Bakery for a long time, but I always seem to visit San Francisco when Golden Gate is closed. 

I finally got a chance to try these famous egg tarts last weekend. The line was out the door, but the wait wasn't too bad. The ladies are speedy and have a pretty speedy system for getting customers in and out of their tiny store. I tried the egg tarts, of course, and the fried sesame balls. 

The fried sesame ball was nothing to write home about. It was good, but nothing special. I certainly didn't blow me away-unlike the egg tarts did. The egg tarts are definitely worth the wait. The crust is so flaky and buttery. The custard is super smooth and literally melts in your mouth.  At $2.25 for each egg tart,the price is a little steep, but the quality of the egg tarts at Golden Gate are totally worth the price!
author: Emily C.

description:
Not much to be said here! Out of the 8 times I've tried coming, they were only open about 4 times.

Golden Gate Bakery is a famous hole-in-the-wall bakery (no seats. Just grab and go).

They are indeed the best egg tarts out there. Because they're not open daily, when they do open, everything is made fresh just a few hours (if not 20 minutes) prior so they are still warm when you take the home! The tart is also flaky and buttery - such a great combination with the egg center.

Save yourself the pain of going into Chinatown and getting disappointed by checking this page ahead of time... sometimes there are updates on whether they're closed/open - http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/
author: Veronica S.

description: This bakery has the strangest operating hours ever. It doesn't matter because their egg tarts are so good that you'll be at their mercy anyway! The best you can do is to give them a call before going. At $2.25 for one egg tart and $27 for a dozen, I'd say prices are pretty fair given the quality and taste. One piece of helpful advice, rather than to struggle to find parking in SF's notoriously crowded small streets, have one person get dropped off to wait in line. It's pretty typical to see a long line in front of the bakery. I remember circling the block a few times and double parking on numerous occasions (with emergency lights on) while waiting for my friend to obtain the prized goods.
author: Justin F.

description:
CHECK THE WEBSITE BEFORE GOING TO SEE IF ITS OPEN! 

I love egg tarts, and I have heard of this place many times from friends. I also hear the stories of long lines similar to Black Friday and the unpredictable hours. Every time I find myself in SF, I always call to check to see if it would be my lucky day. One time, someone picked up (*excitement begins*) only to tell me they were closed (*disappointment*).

However, one Christmas day, I found myself in the area. Would they possibly be open on Christmas day?! No... right? But alas, my fiance called, and lo and behold, it was our lucky day. =)

Parking is a pain, but it's SF. We spotted the line, and it didn't look TOOO long, so we thought it'd be a quick wait. Well, looks are deceiving, because it took an hour. However, well worth the wait, because every batch is fresh out of the oven. Once we finally got inside the small bakery, we ordered two dozen and enjoyed some in the car. Warm, custardy goodness that made me forget about the long, cold wait in the night.

I've only been here twice, and each time, I've enjoyed the goodies immensely. :) Now.. is it worth the wait? Hard to say, because I'm always distracted by the divine flaky crust and custard once the pink box is in my hands. But it's probably worth at least one try in your life, if you're in the area and egg tarts are your thing. Especially since I haven't been able to find any egg tarts that are as delicious around here. (And if you know a place, help a girl out!)

tldr; Come with comfy shoes and the patience to wait.. and you will leave with a happy belly full of egg tarts.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Had one of the best and biggest sesame balls of all time. Delicious and fresh. Red bean was great flavor. Not too oily. Crunchy and soft. Quality stuff here!
author: Sage S.

description:
CASH ONLY. CASH ONLY. CASH ONLY. CASH ONLY. 

I've had many egg tarts in the past, this place by far has one of the better ones. On it's own, the egg tarts will get 3.5 stars. The crust is super thin and flakey, and the egg filling has the perfect consistency. The rating here is for the overall customer service. 

Hours of operation. You will never know whether they're open or not unless you google. I work not far from this place, and for two-years, when I walk past this location for my after-lunch stroll, 95% of the time it is closed. Because of its inconsistent schedule, there is always a long line. 

Customer Service. I do feel that if you speak the native tongue of the employees (Cantonese), service is slightly better. However, this is not absolute. The two times I came for egg tarts, my order was put on hold, because "someone outside" had placed an order. That individual was immediately served first, while the rest of the individuals in line waited. Also, the lady who handles the cash, will sometimes handle the food as well. Talk about sanitary issues. 

Price. The price of an egg tart is now $2.15. Is this egg tart worth that price? Absolutely not.

Don't get me wrong. The egg tarts here are good, but not worth the price, the wait, and the sometimes decent not all the time customer service. If you haven't been here before, then sure, give it a try. But for those who can go with or without it, no need to wait.
author: Teresa C.

description:
I've been here several times over the years and there's a reason I continue to come back, the egg tarts.  You typically will find a line has formed outside, but it's normally around a 15 minute wait.  The egg tarts here are larger than most other bakeries in SF Chinatown.  They are almost always served warm and the crust is nice and flakey.  

Their sesame balls with red beans are another item I really enjoy.  These are some of the larger ones you'll ever find.  However, they aren't just big, they are very good as well.  There's a good amount of red bean inside.  

They also have apple, pineapple, blueberry and custard pies.  These little gems are flakey and filled with the right amount of filling.  These little pies are a nice dessert option at any time.  

Every now and then I've been lucky enough where they've had Baked BBQ Pork buns but they didn't have any when I visited yesterday.  

This bakery has been known to close for periods of time throughout the year, so before going, make sure to see that they're open.  The prices for their egg tarts continue to rise in price.  As of yesterday, they are now $2.15 each.
author: Lon H.

description: Did it need another 5 star review. Yes yes it did. Worth the wait in line for the egg tarts. Plus, you can make new friends while you wait!
author: Brooklyn D.

description:
Horrible customer service. Yelp said they open at 8am and I got here at 9am. They had customers in the shop and the open sign on the door. However, I was kicked out. The lady said they were closed and because I was taking too long to decide what I want, she said I was wasting her and my time. 

Should treat customers way better.
author: Lien H.

description:
This was my first time coming here. Came here for Dan Tat at about 7 PM on a Monday night.  Line was super long. We waited about an hour 

There were two older ladies working there. One was really nice and came down the line to ask each party how many Dan Tat they wanted. 

The Dan Tat came out piping hot every few minutes. So hot that I burned my tongue a little trying to scarf one down before I got into the Uber. This stuff should savored and not eaten in a rush. 

Now for how the Dan Tat tasted. The crust was super flaky and tasty. Best Dan Tat crust I've ever had. The egg custard seemed a little bland to me. I am used to it tasting sweeter. I don't think that I would wait in line so long again for this again.
author: Sean A.

description:
After waiting for a couple month , finally!! I got it !! I have passed the store for several time but they were on (longgg)vacay lol . 

I would say that their egg tart are precisely authentic favor and reminded me the taste i used to try in Hong Kong. You can taste the natural sweetness from an egg and the dough tart is not thick at all 

Coconut macaron and red bean pie are wonderful wonder as well , truly natural sweetness 

Overall, here is worth your time and every single penny!
author: Tiratiwan L.

description: The egg tarts here is the best that I've ever had - this is from someone who is Asian and has spent significant amount of time in China and Chinese bakery shops. I heard about this shop from my husband who grew up in the San Francisco area and said this bakery exist when he was a kid! The shop is ran by a few old Chinese ladies and is very small. Their egg tarts are freshly cooked, crispy, warm, and deep dish with eggs! If you have ever had deep dish pizza in Chicago, that's the same idea in the egg tarts world. Definitely worth the wait!
author: Nancy M.

description: Delicious egg custard tarts...compares to what I had in HK. Long line ups but well worth the wait...you will not be disappointed if you like egg tarts.
author: Mark Y.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to randomly check this place out. I think we waited about 30-40 minutes, but the wait was sure worth it! 

The egg tarts were fresh out of the oven and let me tell you, they were soooo good!!! The crust is so flaky and buttery and the egg in the middle tastes like pudding and was the right amount of sweet. What a treat! Egg tarts are $2.15 each. We also got the coconut tart which was also yummy, but not as good as the egg tarts. The big sesame balls were just as good as any sesame ball, so nothing spectacular there.

I recommend to eat the egg tarts while they're fresh and warm out of the oven because it just tastes magical and so delicious. I ate one later for dinner and it just didn't taste as good anymore. The magic was gone.

There were three ladies working there and while they are quick, I don't think they are so fluent in English. Be prepared to know what you want to order and point to the goodies you want if needed. CASH ONLY. 

Definitely a must try if you're in Chinatown.
author: Lin S.

description:
Great egg tarts and a great crust! This place was on the list of most recommended places to visit when in SF Chinatown. The day I went, it said online that they open up at 12 noon, but when I went there was a sign on the door that says they open up at 12:30pm. I decided to walk to Dragon gate and to kill some time and walk back, and by the time I came back at 12:20pm, there was already a line in front of the door. I waited an hour to get 7 egg tarts.... They were delicious, don't get me wrong, but the customer service isn't that great. The ladies really take their sweet time giving you the egg tarts and often spend time conversing with customers or on the phone so that's what makes the wait so damn long... 

The prices were 1 egg tart $2.25 and a dozen for $27.... honestly it's kind of a rip off if you ask me coming from a native New Yorker that can gets delicious egg tarts in NY Chinatown without having to wait in an hour line, nor spend that much. I guess it's all part of the experience.... My aunt said they used to be $1.50, but they just keep jacking up the price since they know the demand is high for their egg tarts. This was a once in a lifetime place for me to visit.
author: Stephen E.

description: The egg custard is soooooooooo good, especially when it is warm - just out of the oven.  The sesame ball is good too.  Definitely going back and stay in that line.
author: John S.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?

Hmm...

Well, first off be prepared for some tourist or nosy ABC azn to ask you why you're standing in line. Extra points if you use the phrases "strip club", "irish mafia", "egg porn" or "Guantanamo Bay".

Second, bring a portable charger.

Third, bring a face mask if you're one of those clean freaks cuz the street is dirtier than the mind of a 40 year old virgin. 

Fourth, if you're reading this, please go home. These are the best egg tarts NA and if you weren't here, the line would be so much shorter and I wouldn't have to wait an hour plus for my egg porn fix.
author: Joshua F.

description: They're always closed. Ok maybe not always but very often...but you just deal w it bec they have the best egg tarts in the Bay Area.  Cash only, folks!  And please respect that they don't want any photos taken in the store.  It didn't say No Videos so...
author: Margaret W.

description: Meh... it was good but nothing really to write home about, I'm sure if this was the type of food you grew up with it would be more appealing on a sentimental level but with their lack luster location and not even knowing what the symbols on their moon cakes even mean I would say this seems like a lot of hype for custer and pastries.... btw Mexican Flan is still better :P
author: Javier R.

description: Just tried their moon cake and I must say, even if they're on the pricey side it's definitely worth it! Not sure why they have to only offer moon cake when it's moon cake festival season - they should at least offer egg tarts too! Not a fan of them going on vacation for weeks but you just have to keep checking online if they're open.
author: Ly L.

description:
Single File Line Out The Door Along Grant Ave With An Average 1 Hour Wait Time. 

Single Form Of Payment Accepted - "Straight Cash Homie." 

Single Item On The Menu - Egg Tarts!!! Just Kidding On This One. The bakery has other items, too. However, the egg tarts are all you need. I order by the dozen and eat them ASAP out of the box while they are piping hot.
author: Steven L.

description:
First time here. Came at 11:40, and there was a couple waiting. We waited for almost 40 min. They didn't open at 12 sharp. It was close to 12:20 when they let us in.

The lady behind us raved about everything: the moon cakes, the pies, the mochi, the sesame ball, etc.

The current price of the egg tarts is $2.15. We got egg tarts, a pineapple pie, a white sugar cake?, 2 sesame balls, some flat pancake thingee, and one coconut tart.

They didn't have much else.

The egg tarts were good. Fresh out of the oven, the flaky crust balanced well with the semi sweet custard. 

The sesame balls were the size of oranges. The chewy texture of the dough was to die for. 

The pineapple pie had raisins. I liked the crust and it wasn't too sweet.

I'm not sure if it's worth an hour wait...
author: Jenny L.

description: The custard tarts are absolute amazing!!   When they come out warm sooo good!   Expect a line but it moves quick.   The sesame ball thing was also pretty unique and good!
author: Mark R.

description:
There is definitely a long wait and in some cases standstill because the egg tarts ran out and it takes 10-12 minutes for new egg tarts to come out. 

The reason why their egg tarts are worth the wait is because the shells are deeper than average egg tarts. That means more egg custard filling. Also, because of the demand, the egg tarts are always hot and fresh, therefore the shell is crisp and crunchy. 

I also tried their custard pie. It was very good. There are actually raisins and walnuts inside. The crust is very similar to the egg tart, crisp and crunchy.

Overall worth the wait!
author: Ann M.

description: Best egg tart I've ever had. Worth the wait. Eat it while it is still warm. Very flaky..
author: Steven C.

description:
A must-go to place whenever one is in Chinatown. Their long lines always make people passing by question what the wait is for, but once you walk past the entrance and smell the sweet aroma of baked goods, you can't help but also wait in line. I came here on a Saturday at 1:00pm and waited about 30 minutes, but the wait is definitely worth it to get those freshly made egg tarts. This place is cash only but there's an ATM right across the street if you forget. 

*FOOD* 
The egg tarts are their most popular item. The price is gradually increasing being $2.15/piece as of today, but the egg tarts are bigger and more fresh compared to the ones that are $1/piece. The egg tarts are delicious and served warm from just coming out of the oven. I love how flaky and buttery the crust is, but as for the filling, I wasn't a huge fan of how eggy some of mine tasted. It seemed like they were from the same batch, but some of them had the perfect filling consistency while a few were more runny/eggy. Regardless, they were still tasty and not overly sweet. 

*LOCATION*
Very small store just to allow the people ordering inside. There's only street parking since it's SF, but there's a parking garage (Portsmouth Square Plaza Garage) just a few blocks down (~5 min walking!) that's $4/hour. 

*SERVICE* 
Service has been pretty good the few times I've gone. If you're just ordering egg tarts, they have your order ready in less than a minute unless they're waiting on a new batch, which probably takes an extra 5 minutes since they're constantly being made.
author: Christine V.

description:
There are two things that are consistent about Golden Gate Bakery. First that there is always a long line and second is that there is no way to know when they will be open. I've passed by Golden Gate Bakery many times while walking through Chinatown and each time it's either closed because they are on "Vacation" or there is a long wait due to the slow moving line of people waiting outside, so I've given it a skip. This changes a couple of days ago. Around 8 pm there was absolutely no line so I decided to give it a try.

I got 3 of their custard tarts ($1.95 each). Even at 8 pm which is their closing time they were fresh out of the oven and piping hot. These were literally the best egg tarts that I've had period. The crust was flaky and the filling light. I wished that the filling was a little sweeter but that's more of a personal choice rather than the norm. Egg tarts from other bakeries in Chinatown range from $1.10 to $1.40 a pop so these are definitely a lot more expensive. I guess the additional cost is what is paying for their frequent vacations and arbitrary opening times. Golden Gate Bakery is a tourist trap no doubt as it is on the must visit place for people visiting San Francisco. The product is excellent but when you factor in the high price, long wait and not knowing if they will actually be open, I can at best give them an A-OK grade.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
Warning: they have random times. They basically open and closed when they feel like it...I guess they can since people just come and line up even when they don't know what the line is for . 
Price of one egg tart is $2.15. So these are special because of the warm custard and the crust is buttery and flaky, which means they probably use lard . 
We also got sesame balls that have red beans in them. Those are definitely to share. Husband had the eggs tarts for the first time and liked them- he wouldn't wait in line for them again though. 
If you are in the area and they are opened, definitely check them out.
author: Pascale C.

description:
I waver between how many stars I want to give this place but I'm honestly obsessed. It's luck of the draw whether it's open or not. Your best bet is to call and see whether someone picks up the phone and ask if they're open. 

Their egg tarts is the best I've ever had. The crust is thin and flaky but doesn't fall apart and get crumbly like many others do. The custard is rich, eggy, but not overly sweet. It is best when it's fresh out of the oven, and when you buy it, it is always fresh out of the oven because there's generally a huge line and you have to wait a bit for the next batch.

The shop closes and goes on vacations for weeks at a time whenever the  chef decides to. Every time they open shop again, the prices go up. The last time I went in around October, the price was $2.10 per... which adds up to $25.20 a dozen. Yikes. It's double the price of every other store in the area but ugh, it's worth it. 

I've tried some of the other things they offer but they're nothing special compared to the egg tarts.
author: Judy H.

description:
I wanted to give this place five stars cuz those egg tarts deserve it, however if you put up a sign that says "open @ 12" and not the time stated on Yelp which was 8am, but then still DON'T open up @ noon, but actually 20 mins later...(actually, whenever you feel like it, basically) Yeah...You lost half a star for that. 

The next reason why they lost the other half of the star is when my BF and I got into the store, there was one girl ahead of us, so one lady was helping her, but there were two other ladies behind the counter doing their own thing. One was just opening up bags, while the other was rearranging pastries. Ummm...Hello? You clearly see there is a line, but you STILL make us wait? I lost all my patience. And even said to myself "yup, lost a whole star already, and I haven't even tried their egg tarts. These egg tarts better be worth it!"

We ordered a dozen egg tarts and almond cookies. The almond cookies were yummy! The egg tarts, yes, they made me happy. It was worth standing outside for 35 mins before the store opened. Second in line too. They're fresh, the crust is super flaky, the main part is soft and makes you wanting more. So I do understand why people line up for them. They are five star!

This place is CASH ONLY. They do sell other pastries besides the egg tarts and almond cookies. They're just known for having really good egg tarts.

I would be here a lot if I lived here lol. Those egg tarts got me.
author: Akemi H.

description: Believe the hype. It's very good. Don't let the line dissuade you. Most folks are there to grab the dan tats and run. So line moves fast. You know. That is when they're open.
author: Gordon A.

description: Came here because of all the hype around their egg tarts. We'd also heard that this place randomly closes sometimes (which I find HILARIOUS), so we were lucky that they decided to open when we went :') the line was definitely very VERY line - I'm not sure exactly how long we waited, but it was definitely a long time. One egg tart is $2.50, which in my opinion, is WAY too expensive. And while their egg tart is pretty big and pretty good, I wouldn't say it was worth the long wait or the $2.50. I'm glad I went but I probably won't be back!
author: Angela L.

description:
These are the BEST Dan tat (Chinese egg tarts) in SF. There is almost always a line regardless of weekday or weekend. The people that own the place seem to know that they are popular so they don't care to rush service. So make sure you have a sweater/jacket/scarf/personal heater and some good company. You will see many people walking out with little pink boxes with vents cut in them, but don't despair, they have plenty of egg tarts for everyone. 

Btw, the absolute worst time to visit this place is in September during the moon festival because they also happen to have the best moon cakes in the city.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Definitely long line. The shop looks like a rundown star in Chinatown. When it comes to the egg custard, I felt like it was OK and not screaming amazing. I had better custard in house where it was more flaky crust and the egg was not too thick and way too creamy
author: Eric E.

description:
Finally made it!! Went few times and they were closed for vacation. We got there and they were hot & fresh, Egg tarts custard was really good, crust was just okay. The crust at 85* bakery in Serramonte was actually better. We also had sesame bun: good but lacked filling. Purchase almond cookies but haven't tried them yet. I will update after doing so.  

Overall I feel like if I'm in the neighborhood I would go back but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there. It deserves 4 stars because it is good just not as good as it's hyped to be.
author: Rio J.

description:
$23.40/dozen and a little under $2 for a single egg tart. Tack on a 45 minute long wait, and that's the experience you'll get at this bakery.

We all know egg tarts or dan ta's are the name of the game here at GG Bakery. Sold by OG grannies, who offer zero smiles and lots of delicious warm pastries instead...this place is a staple of Chinatown SF. Although most people walk out with the big pink boxes of a dozen egg tarts, they also offer fresh baked goods from sesame balls to moon cakes. There aren't descriptive cards to indicate what you're eating, so if you're a vegetarian or have allergies to certain baking ingredients, I'd stick with egg tarts because it's just dough, egg, dairy, and no meat.

I highly recommend calling them before you head over to check and see if they're open. Yup, although Google Maps says they're open everyday from a certain time to close, it's usually wrong. Every time I'm in the area and decide to wait in line for some egg tarts, the place is usually closed. CALL. It'll save you disappointment and time. Parking here is rare, unless you get some random street parking on one of the hilly side streets...so take public transport or Lyft.

After coming here a few times over the course of my lifetime, I think local bakeries offer more delicious and less expensive egg tarts. I wouldn't wait in line to get their dan ta's which aren't as flaky in crust (it's more crumbly like shortbread texture) and less like flan in the eggy center. I have my favorite asian bakeries I frequent to get egg tarts, and I don't have to wait in line for it! This is definitely a great touristy spot.
author: Jodi H.

description:
We got lucky: 1) It opened on the day we went; 2) There was no line at all.
The egg tart is definitely a solid 4.5+! Best egg tart I have had in the US so far. The crust is so crispy, would recommend!
author: Lily Z.

description: Very disappointed did not live up to the hype. They didn't sell the custard pastries when we went so I got a coconut pastry and it was way too dry I had to get water because I starting choking on the pastry. The people working there kept ignoring us. Very frustrating considering how popular the place is.
author: Kelly W.

description:
I can't be eating this anymore! They seem to close the bakery whenever they feel like it and I am tired of going there and see a sign at the door stating that they are closed for vacation!

It was good while it lasted!!!
author: Brenda K.

description: The hype is real!! The line is long and the heat/cold can get you... but once you're here and got your hands on those hot out steamy oven, is so so so so good and not too sweet.
author: Hannle P.

description: Best bakery in Chinatown. Literally waiting almost 40 minutes standing in line just to get some pastries. We ordered egg custard tarts, rice cake, egg custard pie/cake, and sesame balls. I can say the egg custard tart is a MUST! The outside if the try is delicious but once it cools down the inside is even better. Rice cakes were a little too sweet but the other pastries made up for it. The bakery is small and they only take cash. We spent about $50. I can say the service was quick and the wait was worth it. I'll definitely recommend coming to this bakery.
author: Veronique V.

description: Egg Custard Tarts worth the wait! Some of the best pastry I've had for these type of tarts. Plus, the women who work here are so charming.
author: holly c.

description: Yup the custard tarts are pretty yummy! I guess this won't be the last time that we stand in line outside of the Golden Gate Bakery in China Town!
author: Pleiades M.

description:
What is there to say that hasn't already been said?

Lines can be long - but move quite fast.

Buy a lot, somehow they disappear in your mouth and you're regretting only buying one box by the end of the day.

Prices are fair.

Yum.
author: Byron L.

description:
I've been coming to SF to work for the past 4 years and I've tried to visit Golden Gate without luck ever since. Like clockwork- I walk over at lunch and see the old worn out "on vacation" sign. Honestly- I must have tried 25 times.  Somehow the egg tart god finally showed favor on me and the shop was open last night. I almost couldn't believe my eyes. 

I happily got a box of 4 egg tarts-- which were still warm at 7pm.  They were pretty good- maybe close to the best I've had in the US.  Worth the 4 year wait? Not sure.    As I left I asked the the old lady behind the counter if she'd be open tomorrow- "不一定" she said.  Translation- not sure. Haha.
author: Brian P.

description: Good but overpriced. The greqt thing is that at times its difficult to find warm egg tarts, and these are directly out of the oven. If you have time during your SFO visit, go wait in line. But one can be more than enough.
author: H F.

description: We made a special stop in Chinatown SF just to try their pastries, but we were greeted with a closed bakery even though Yelp and store sign indicates they are open.
author: Lieu S.

description:
My family has been going here for the longest that I could remember. Their egg tarts are seriously to die for! All that egg custard in the center of a flaky crust MMM MMM!! 

Parking could be a pain around the area. My family usually likes to park in the parking structure close to the park area of Chinatown and then walk a couple blocks to get to this location. I believe the parking garage is called Plymouth Square? Don't quote me on that.

The wait for these egg tarts could be anywhere from an hour to 1.5 hours on a good day. All egg tarts are made so frequently, so it's always a fresh batch. Once you get a dozen (or two), open the box and try one for yourself!! It tastes best when it's fresh. They also have other pastries such as mooncakes when in season, Asian Rice Krispies, and coconut or red bean mochi. Honestly, I only go for the egg tarts. Pricing increased over the years but I believe a dozen egg tarts go for $27 right now. 

I've also heard you can call in to pre-order and then arrive there to pick up if the line is too long for you. They only honor this if there is a long line. 

Overall, do try to go here if you're in town. I know it's too good to pass up and it's totally worth the wait. Heads up: since they have business all the time, they do NOT hesitate to take a vacation when they need one. I suggest calling in first to see if they're open before heading there. And also, you can't miss it. It's the shop with a long noticeable line outside.
author: Sandy T.

description: Dan tat is hands down one of the main attractions at the end of every dim sum meal. Kids love them and so do the adults. These egg tarts are always seemingly in demand. But did I expect to ever to see a line form outside a small store front for them?! Never. I tried a sliver of the day old dan tat my brother's and it was still very moist, flaky and yummy. I passed by the grant ave shop in hopes to pick up a dozen or two for a dinner party at my cousins but due to time restraints we did not stop to wait. GGB has quite the devoted following. I observed locals waiting along with tourists. I would definitely try to make time for this on my next visit. I'm sure my kids will love it!!
author: Jane Y.

description:
Hands down best dan tat ever. Well worth the wait. It's crazy everytime I've been to SF for the past few years, they've been closed for vacation. For the past two years, I've always caught them when they were open. I was graced the first time with a 10 minute wait. The last time I went it was at least half an hour. 

Wau that first bite I took though, sent me to heaven. The crust is perfect, flaky, but not too flaky. Filling was piping hot, fresh, perfect texture. Size was the PERFECT size. Not too big, not too small. Took it home to San Diego the next day, and it still tasted amazing, even cold. My coworkers thoroughly enjoyed it too. 10/10.
author: Sam V.

description:
Was planning on stopping by Golden Gate Bakery one morning while staying in SF.  Yelp and the website say that the bakery opens at 8 am.  However, as we arrived at 8 am, we saw a note on the door that they open at 11.  That was a bit frustrating as we made a far journey to get there.

The weird part is that as we walked up to the door an old Asian grandma walked up from the outside and just stood there looking at us.  She wouldn't move, and just kept starting.  Her at us, and us at her.  A delivery guy then came up to the door to drop stuff off, and she also just stared at him.  He made a comment about wanting to deliver, and she remained motionless.

This all got too creepy for me (especially for 8 am before coffee), so we walked away and tried to find another bakery.  I really wanted to go to this place because of all the reviews, but I guess it wasn't meant to be. :-(
author: Patrick M.

description:
Third time's the charm! I would walk by this place and it never seemed to be open. But I finally got to try the coveted egg tart - and it was fresh from the oven!  
Highlights
- $2.25 for a big tart
- cash only
- always has a line
- I got there 10 minutes before they opened and ended up waiting 30 minutes in total
- They seem to open in the afternoons lately (12:30pm or 1pm)
author: Shannon B.

description: Delicious egg tarts. Very flaky pastry and oh so warm. There was a wait and we happened to catch them when they were open. We've swung by a few times when we've visited and they have been closed every time since our first visit. I'd be interested in checking out their moon cake offerings since it looks like they have fun flavors. Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area and like egg tarts. They're the best I've ever had
author: Lea B.

description: The best egg tarts I've come across in the states.  Not a personal fan of HK egg tarts because I love portugués egg tarts the best which hails from Macau, but this one here is an exception.  And you'll know it's true when you pass by it and find there will always be a perpetual queue extending from outside the store.  People literally will buy in the dozens of half dozens.  That's testimony my friends.  It's seriously good that I will but at least a dozen just to bring it back to Iowa and ration it through the rest of the week kind of thing.
author: Kaverne A J L.

description:
This rating reflects not the quality of the food (i.e. egg tart, which was great) but the extremely long wait and general negligence for the customer. The line itself was not long (it should have taken 30 mins to 45 mins tops), but we somehow waited 1 and a half hours. The line stopped moving all together for about 30 mins, with no explanation. They allowed people to order unlimited amounts of egg tarts when they should have capped it at 4-5 per party. Not once did any employee come out to check on the customers who were in line and to let them know of the wait time and what they were getting themselves into. We finally made it to the door, and there was no "apologies for the long wait," nothing like that. The egg tart was good, but it was not worth an hour and a half wait. 

If I was a resident of San Francisco, I would feel compelled to further protest their business model, but since I'm a tourist (like most of their clientele), the only thing I can do is leave a Yelp review which probably further emboldens them to continue this practice.
author: Travis H.

description:
Tarts so good, they make up their hours on the daily. Our first day, they opened at noon and the next day they opened at 3 sooo really, they call
the shots because they know they'll have business anyways. I'd play it safe and call before you make the trek to wait in the guaranteed line formed outside. 

Definitely get the egg tart! We also tried this flat white pancake looking thing that has the texture of mochi; it was also good! 

The ladies behind the counter seem to know a few languages, so don't be intimidated by them! They were sweet and patient.
author: Kathy D.

description:
I'm using the last of my battery to tell you that this place is RIDICULOUSLY dysfunctional. There is no order and you're literally stressed out about getting dessert. Really not worth standing in a tiny ass place for an egg tart that is $2.25. 

IF YOU SEE A LINE, DON'T DO IT! NOT WORTH THE STRESS, WAIT AND PRICE.
author: Heather P.

description:
So glad I was finally able to try out Golden Gate Bakery for myself to settle once and for all if their egg tarts really are the best in the US. I've tried to visit them on 3 prior and separate occasions, each time leaving San Francisco disappointed after finding out that Golden Gate Bakery was on yet another break. I actually had been able to try their egg tarts once many years ago after my dad had brought them back down from an SF trip. Even though the egg tarts were no longer fresh, they still tasted way better than any bakery I've had around the 626 area. That sealed it for me - I had to visit them one day in the flesh. 

My family and I were actually heading to Fisherman's Wharf for lunch when we somehow passed by Chinatown. We spontaneously drove by Golden Gate Bakery (because why not) and saw that it was OPEN and even better, there was no line! What the heck?! I immediately tore out of the car (more like wandered in a confused daze) toward the store. There were only maybe 5 people or so in front of me in line. I seriously had a deja vu moment because I've never set foot into their store and yet I clearly remember ordering egg tarts for myself in that store before! 

The egg tarts had JUST come out of the oven, and yet the customers in front of me weren't even buying them! More for me right? We bought half a dozen ($1.95 each), some strawberry pies, and a sticky rice cake. The prices of pastries here are actually not cheap. Each item seems to be more than $1.50, and buying them by the dozen doesn't result in any discounted price either. 

So was that egg tart worth the three disappointed visits? The answer is a solid YES. I ate it right away when it was still warm and fresh, and it was amazing. I wouldn't say the egg tarts are as good as the ones I've had in Hong Kong (where they're even cheaper!), but they would give the HK bakeries a run for their money. These egg tarts are filled deep with custard and bigger than most SGV bakeries' egg tarts. Custard had the right amount of sweetness, and the crust was a warm, delicious, and flaky piece of goodness. The smoothness of the custard definitely contrasts well with the flakiness of the crust, making each bite THAT amazing. I usually like to scoop out the egg tart's custard like a crème brulee before eating the crust separately, but no can do. I had to eat it all at once. Amazing! I ended up consuming three egg tarts that day and ... not even sorry. 

The strawberry pies - we saw people buying it, but they were a major disappointment. I think this is geared towards their American customers/foreigners. If you're a fan of Asian pastries and baked goods, don't try this. Very strong taste of persevered jelly mixed with walnuts and canned strawberries. The crust was not too bad, especially when eaten warm, but not something I would try again. 

We also got a sticky rice cake - not what we were expecting when we ordered the "sew bang." This was very similar to the sweetened Taiwanese rice cakes; not a fan as this was quite tasteless. 

tl;dr - YES an absolute must-try if you're in the San Francisco area. Don't be disheartened by the number of times they're on vacation. Try again if you have to! Or visit the is the golden gate bakery open today website. Workers were really fast and efficient. We were in and out within 5-10 minutes with our delicious egg tarts. Now that I've had them, I don't feel like I'm in any rush to go back, especially since they're so hard to catch while open. But I'll definitely make a trip and stop by to see if I can get more egg tarts the next time I'm in SF!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
BEST
EGG
CUSTARD
TART
EVER
!!!!!!!!!!

The wait and crazy hours are definitely worth it. If you have the chance, try it. You will fall in love with their egg custard tarts too.
author: Allyson L.

description:
This place is the reason as to why I made it back into my hometown so late. The line had a wait of about 90 minutes, shout out to Sunday street parking though.

Tasting the egg tarts is an experience. Warm, toasty outside. Warm, sweet, gooey middle. I should really say HOT if you decide to eat one within the first 5 minutes.

Their other items are okay. I loved their strawberry pies. they don't have an upscale bakery taste but they're baked and prepared to the perfect degree of average bakery, that you can't help but enjoy them. 

I expected the ladies working the bakery to be rude (insert your own reason as to why), but they flashed some smiles. Even if they would of been rude, I really wouldn't of cared, just leggo my eggo and we're good.

Golden Gate Bakery is worth the wait if your day's agenda is more flexible than Gabby Douglas. Amazing egg tarts, surprising strawberry pies. All in a day's work around here.
author: Javier J.

description: Very long lines, with only two ladies working in the front.  The egg custards were good, but overpriced.  A lot of tourists standing in line.
author: Mark K.

description: Honestly, I'm not the biggest fan of egg tarts, but I can appreciate a good one and definitely understand that the egg tart from golden gate is probably the best I've had. Custard is super fluffy and really has an eggy flavor. The whole pastry is light, not dense at all. Was in line on weekday around 2pm with about 15 people in front of me. Line moved relatively fast, about 15 minutes to the front. Cash only!
author: Lexi R.

description: Got some fresh Dan tats, made me feel like a fresh dan tat!
author: Andy L.

description:
This was my first time ever having an egg tart and hopefully last time waiting in a line 45-minutes for one, but it was pretty good. 

Definitely not the kind of thing I'd ever go out of my for or crave, but it's interesting and unlike any pastry I've ever had before. 

Also ordered 2 of their Moon Pies since I saw so many reviews raving about them but wasn't as impressed. The egg tarts are under $2 each and priced pretty fairly while the moon tarts are $8 each and not at all my taste. Also there was some confusion about what flavor moon pies they had among the employees so I'm still not really sure what kind we got. 

The line moves slowly but mainly because most people buy the tarts by the dozen so they run out after just 2-3 people get through the line and can't bake them fast enough. It seems like with such a long line and history that they could work on a more efficient way to produce more, but maybe that's part of the draw. 

Inside was pretty janky. Not gonna lie- the cleanliness of the place seemed pretty questionable. There's a hand-written cardboard sign that asks customers not to take photos or video inside and I have to wonder if that's in part to the mess of boxes and miscellaneous piled up everywhere. For real, they have both a door and a door mat made out of leftover cardboard. It was just kind of strange to see a business that has upwards of an hour-long line from open to close that won't spend $10 on a doormat that isn't made out of garbage.
author: Candice G.

description:
Get the egg tarts!!

Get two dozens of egg tarts.  They were fresh, warm, soft, tasty.  Anyway, it's just simply awesome.  ;-)
author: Mike Y.

description: Can I give this more than 5 stars?! Yes, there is a line for a damn good reason and worth every minute waiting. I grew up eating custard tarts since it was gmas favorite dessert and this is hands down the best one I've ever had. They cut the sides open to make sure the crust doesn't get soggy and it was delicious for lunch and dinner. I had skeptics in my group who thought they could just have 1/4 of one and they went back for more and agreed... best custard ever. This line doesn't move fast so be patient and just remind yourself you're lucky they are actually open that day. You will receive them piping hot from the oven and that's worth the wait.
author: Kai T.

description:
Five stars for the most delicious egg tarts!  If you can get your hands on them that is.  

The bakery is famous for being on vacation so I wasn't holding my breath when we showed up at the shop on a Friday morning.  Yelp listed opening at 8am, but they were still closed at 8:30am.  We were trying to figure out what to do next as a lady tried getting into the bakery and then a second lady showed up to open the doors.  We took the opp to ask when they would be open and she told us to come back at 12pm.  

We were able to come back about 4pm and got in the line that had already formed out the door.  We waited about 30 minutes in anticipation.  We just didn't know how many egg tarts were left.  But luckily tray after tray arrived even with customers ordering dozens at a time.  

Once we got our mitts on them, we ate one right outside the door.  They were amazing and sooooo good hot.  They are also really good cold.  Each tart sells for only $1.95.  They also offer jin dui, rice cakes, and other Chinese pastries.
author: Nadia K.

description: Golden Gate specializes in pastries that are time consuming, beautiful, and totally worth the cost! Get the egg tart or moon cake (with at least one egg!) and you'll feel like you've traveled across the ocean. 10/10 would recommend.
author: Shelbi S.

description: Was looking forward to getting some egg tarts and the sign said closed for three weeks vacation but doesn't say from what date they began or when they will return.  When they are open they have the best egg tarts and I was so looking forward to some.
author: Corliss V.

description:
What you need to know: 
- The owners have no desire of being in business. I have heard a number of reasons why their hours of operation are so erratic: they have health problems, they are on long travels, etc. 
- Because of their loathsome and unpredictable hours, there is a Facebook page where people report if they are open or not, on a daily basis. 
- They are famous for their egg tarts, which I have to admit are the BEST egg tarts I have had in the States. I'm Lines can be long, but if you see a line, at least that means they are open! 
- Their egg tarts deserve 10 stars, but I am giving 4 stars because of my intense love and hate I have for golden gate bakery. 

What I always order: 
- Egg tart $1.95 - these are best eaten hot right outside their bakery - do not wait to eat them! The crust is the flaky type and is gloriously buttery, crispy and flaky. The bottom crust is unbelievably paper thin without being soggy from the egg tart. The egg custard part is more like the Chinese dessert steamed egg (dunn daan) and is fabulously tender and silky.
author: Karen L.

description:
Real tasty egg tarts but leans to the expensive side at 2.25 each compared to other places in Chinatown. Definitely better but is it worth nearly double the price...some can debate it. I took a star off for price. The lines can be long but worth the wait. The ladies speak the various Chinese dialects Toisan, Cantonese, Madarin and obviously in English. I like how they customarily cut vents for the boxes to keep the fresh baked goodies from not steaming.

Would I buy them again? Yes, sure. But I'd look to find a comparable at a lower cost. Just say that I wouldn't pay that much for it with all the places that make them on Mott, Bayard, Canal St in New York City.
author: Clarence E.

description:
Egg. Freakin'. Tarts. 

Ugh, these suckers are so damn good!!! They are worth the 40 minutes of waiting we always do when in SF Chinatown. Although it is extremely tempting to eat one once you get your hands on them, they're piping hot & not as enjoyable as when you let the crust harden a bit (in my opinion). 

Aside from the amazing egg tarts, the coconut tarts are also delicious! We were curious about the "black bean" mochi so we asked one of the ladies if they meant red bean & she said yes, it's red bean. Lady, I suggest you change your descriptions because black bean and red bean are completely different and you're probably missing out on potential customers!! The red bean mochi was so bomb! I don't know if it was the coconut flakes on the outside or if the mochi was infused with something but it was so fragrant! That with the smooth red bean filling made it a great surprise!

Golden Gate Bakery is cash only!! I highly discourage parking in Chinatown because people are always walking in the streets and there's almost never any parking. Save yourself the trouble and Uber or walk. Buy the egg tarts in bulk. Trust me, you're going to want more later.
author: Ly D.

description:
It's one of most unpredictable shops I've ever been to...but if you are lucky, definitely give it a try!

Tips:
1.They don't have a regular schedule, so I highly recommend calling before your visit. 
2.Lines on weekdays are probably not long just bc sometimes the shop hasn't opened yet...like me, the actual time I spent on waiting after their open was about 10 mins.
3. The egg tarts are always served warm, so be aware of the hot filling!

Egg tart costs $2.15/ea. but it's bigger than a regular egg tart. The flaky but sturdy crust and the smooth egg custard are to die for...
author: Jui Han Y.

description: I have heard about the legendary egg custard tarts from Golden Gate Bakery, so knew I needed to stop in on my trip to San Francisco last week.  The bakery is non-descript, but don't let that fool you...there is deliciousness that abounds inside these doors.  Don't forget...cash only, so bring enough to enjoy the $2.25 tasty egg custard tarts.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The best HK-style egg tarts I've ever had in the states! It's best when it comes out hot and fresh. There's usually a long line, so go early so you don't have to wait. We didn't encounter a line when we last went, but it was in the morning. Luckily they were open during our trip, because they're notorious for being randomly closed and "away on vacation." There's even a website dedicated to whether they're open or not. I suggest calling first, so you don't waste your time trying to get there. As much as we love GGB, we wouldn't wait no more than 20-30 minutes for it, if that.
author: Sherry V.

description: It's good but not a must try, you gotta be outta your mind to line up AND pay $2.25 for 1 egg tart. Don't fall for the hype. Hit up AA Bakery on Stockton and they're just as good if not, better.
author: Hui L.

description:
This place is not how it used to be. First visit in a looonnnng time since. Golden Gate used to carry a variety of pastries, but this past weekend visit was disappointing. I waited 35min just to get TWO :( egg tarts and sure they taste great, but ain't worth the wait. Egg tart is the only thing they sell. I love their cocktail buns and pork buns when they did carry it.

I spoke to grandma and asked her why she's not making it anymore, she replied the baker only makes it when they want. I can't believe how much Golden Gate has changed since I was kid. This place isn't worth visiting anymore because sometimes they're not even open! 

Golden Gate is notorious for closing for a few months as they visit the homeland. Sometimes you won't even know when they will be back. Personally, I feel like they close for 9 months and open for 3 months intermittently. 

If it's your first time, then go for it to check it off your bucket list. However, if you've been a regular then go take stroll up the street to Good Mong Bakery for some egg tarts. They're just as good and I bet you can't tell the difference.
author: Hang E.

description:
I really wanted to like this place; especially after waiting in line for an hour. We got the "famous" egg tart. We didn't like it. The Apple pie was pretty good. However, the macaroons were the winner for me; they were tasty.  

So sad we didn't thoroughly enjoy this place since it was so highly reviewed on Yelp. It was definitely NOT worth the wait. I wish all of their goods were as good as their macaroons were.
author: Erin J.

description:
Don't let the line out the door scare you away! While people may take a while to order the staff inside work quickly to get every person their order as quickly as possible. Golden Gate Bakery is renowned for their egg tarts that are around $2 each, but you can also buy them by the dozen. 

As we waited outside I noticed that they sell a ton of other goodies in the window, but by the time we got there most things were already sold out. 

My previous experiences with egg tarts are having them cold so I was ecstatic to find that these were warm. I was worried at first since the tray of egg tarts went empty after the people in front of me bought their batch but luckily they brought another tray out of the oven. And let me tell you about these egg tarts. Because I was so excited to eat them I didn't even wait for them to cool down. The crust was oh so thick and flaky and held the warm egg custard perfectly. The custard inside was the right amount of sweet and basically melted in your mouth. Unlike the tarts you would get at a bakery where you pull them out of the containers these were huge and so filling - and I only had 1!

Wait in the line and you won't be disappointed.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
IF you like egg custard that tasted like scrambled eggs than this is your post. If you equally enjoy waiting in long lines for upwards of 30 minutes and inhaling wafts of pee smell then this is your spot. 
You can have it.
author: Erica U.

description:
I don't really remember when I first had an egg tart (dan tat) from Golden Gate Bakery. I only remember the it being flaky, silky, and oh so delicious! Imagine my surprise when a friend took some dan tats out of her fridge last Friday, December 23rd!

A group of friends from out of town went up to SF to explore the city. Of course Golden Gate Bakery was on their list. From the story they told me, they walked by and it looked like they were all sold out. After they called an Uber, they saw a tray of dan tats being brought out and ran across the street to buy a box. They were so ecstatic they got a box of fresh, warm dan tats. And all before their Uber arrived.

Luckily for me, they bought too many and I had part of one the next day. Even the next day, these were still good. That silky, eggy filling is so comforting to me. Reminds me of eating dan tats as a little girl. It actually made me want to go up to SF to get a warm one.

So are the dan tats worth it?! You betcha! If you love these little desserts like I do, you have to try one from Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Elena N.

description:
For 24$ a dozen egg tarts and an average wait time
Of 90 minutes on a weekday, 120 minutes on a weekend -- you can treat yourself to mouthwatering baked goods with recipes only stored in bank safety deposit boxes. This place does not take call-in orders, you have to be in person to place an order.  After 20 minutes you can place your order and come back at your given time to collect your food. It's straight up the best egg tart I've eaten even better than Asia so obviously worth the wait if you even enjoy egg tarts (I don't). I came because my aunt made me. She comes all time when we visit SF. But even though I don't enjoy egg tarts I can appreciate these because they actual custard is made perfectly and the crust compliments nicely. 

I was told by a customer outside that the bakery is closed half the year because they go on vacation and make all their money in only half the year. So if you catch the bakery open, consider yourself  lucky.
author: Matt C.

description: The egg tarts here make it all worth it. The tart pastry itself is so flakey and yummy and the custard itself is so creamy and ours were even warm. The sesame ball was also great. My boyfriend got the white lotus moon cake with one egg yolk and we hated it. While it was very beautiful the whole dried egg yolk thing wasn't really for us. It was a savory salty mixture that even I, an adventurous eater, couldn't stomach. Other than that, the egg tarts make the wait worth while (which we arrived 10 min before it opened and were still in line) and I recommend getting more than 1, they're amazing. The ladies working inside were very polite and very thorough so the line moved quickly. A must visit in China town.
author: Natalie G.

description:
Yeah i know cash only is standard in china towns but..... yeah i'm just lazy

Golden Gate Bakery has the reputation of best egg tarts in SF... i was expecting a long line but i was lucky enough to snag fresh egg tarts without any wait :-)

Egg Tarts - I'm always partial to Portuguese style egg tarts but i will say that these tarts had the best crust i've ever had... extremely flaky with a nice crunch that emulates a croissant... the filling was a little too eggy for me but nonetheless i devoured probably 6 on my way to the wharf

As your former state Governor once said... I'll be back
author: Peter H.

description:
This is a place that has either a crazy long wait, or just is straight up closed, so I wasn't surprised to have to wait 1+ hours to finally try the esteemed egg tart (also didn't help that I went on Chinese New Year parade day). 

I wouldn't say that it was 100% worth the wait, but I definitely would say that the egg tart is top notch. When we finally got to the front of the line, we were lucky enough to get egg tarts fresh from the oven! When we stepped out to try one, it was still warm! 
Crust was flaky and perfect golden brown, and the egg filling was absolutely silky and delicious! Knocking it down for being $1.95 per egg tart, a little pricey for an egg tart in Chinatown... but worth a try! 

We also tried some of their macaroons, and those were tasty as well! Solid small bites, and nice balance of coconut. I appreciated the balance in texture as well, playing with the crispier exterior and the softer inner portion. 

If you're ever in the area and have a couple of hours to spare, I would totally recommend!
author: Tina T.

description:
If it wasn't for Yelp, this place would be definitely be one of those famous hole in the walls that you could only hear from the locals. Golden Gate Bakery hands down, makes some of the best egg tarts in the bay area, if not the best. 

First off, this place is not open every day, not really sure how people find out of their store hours but I guess you can go by every day to see if they're open. If you do get lucky to find that they are open, I hope you have the patience to wait in line for at least 45-1 hour for their delicious baked goods.

My group waited for 1 hour 45 minutes for some delicious egg tarts, as we went during a popular time of the year, Lunar New Year. People were buying these things by the dozens, at one point we saw a lady leave with 6 dozens of these bad boys. However, despite the wait, I thought they were very efficient and the two ladies manning the front lines were experts at their craft. 

When it was finally our turn my group each ordered a dozen, and the tarts were pipping hot as they come out fresh every 2 minutes, seriously. A dozen cost about 24$ and if you buy them as singles they are roughly $2 each (CASH ONLY). Seems pretty steep for some egg tarts right? Trust me they are so worth, the egg tarts are pretty generous in size and so is the egg filling. The tart crust was so flaky and fresh (my personal favorite part of the desert). 

I brought some home to share with my family, and even though it wasn't fresh by that time, after re-heating in the toaster for a few minutes, it tasted just as it would when it first came out of the oven. 

Is it worth the wait? Most definitely!! Something worth trying at least once. The bakery also sells a variety of different goods, haven't personally tried them but they all look delicious as well. 

5/5
author: Thy B.

description:
This place is notorious for always being closed due to vacation, but when you do have a chance please please do yourself a huge favor and try out their egg tarts (Dan tat). I have been a fan of this place since 2002. 
The size of each dan tat isn't your typical dim sum small size. I would say it is equivalent to two.
I can't even explain how good and authentic this place is. But recently I did notice their custard isn't as creamy as before. Their dough tart is not thick at all, I hate when the dough is super thick and overwhelming.
author: Selina L.

description:
Server: Virginia

She was so helpful in helping my friends and me choose our food! She was so friendly and made a lot of conversation with us. Usually when we go to China Town, people are rude, probably due to culture, but Virginia was just the sweetest! Glad we came.
 The bakery has such fresh food!
author: Chris B.

description:
Now I understand the long lines...

Each time I visit San Francisco Chinatown it never fails that there is always a long line in front of this bakery that wraps a few feet to the other side of the sidewalk making room in between for other pedestrians. Two Christmases in a row I happen to catch the bakery open as I was told that they are notorious for closing down at any given time without warning? and that they usually have no set schedule when they're open... well, I have not seen that happen to me yet and maybe it's true what they say or not but I'll just consider myself fortunate that they were open the times I visit.
