Last Christmas [2015] I didn't stop here because the line was ridiculously long! This year, though, I made it a point to check it out. Stood in line and it was nice that the line, although a bit long, went pretty quick and before we knew it we were already inside (we were having a nice conversation with another patron from out of town)! I thought we were already coming from pretty far (Roseville) but this guy we were in line with came from Chicago! (and he said he just found this place through Yelp) LoL! WTG, Yelp! 

The selection was pretty much low at around 6:30p but I really just wanted to try some of the recommended goodies from my other Yelp friends which was the egg tarts and moon cake. I bought a few egg tarts, they were freshly made still very warm and soft. They are $1.95 each. I thought it had a somewhat similar taste to our Filipino custard pie dessert from Goldilocks. Am I right, kababayans? Also, I bought one moon cake, I'm not sure which flavor we got but it was yummy also. I thought it had a similar taste to one of our Filipino pastries as well but I can't seem to pinpoint what it is. I would've loved it if they didn't ran out of the sesame balls. That is one of my faves... and, yes, we have that in a Filipino bakery too. 

I'm glad I got a chance to experience this bakery's treats. Now I understand why they always have such a long line every time I come here but this is a one time visit for me. I'm sure there are more Chinese bakeries offering just as good treats for cheaper (heck, Filipino bakeries offer similar baked goods also) but now I can say that I've tried this bakery. No seating inside, once you get inside it is immediately the display windows of their baked treats (or what's left of it for the day) and you just tell the ladies behind the counter what you want. Oh, and one more thing! CASH ONLY! Lucky for me, I bank with Chase and there is a Chase bank across the street. 

P.S. Read some of the Not Recommended reviews. Most of them use one common word... can you guess what the word is?

Review #0630 (and 2,657th review for the business)
author: May A.

description: This bakery is located in Chinatown in SF and there is ALWAYS a line out the door no matter what day or time. I have read other reviews saying that this place is rarely open as well but both times I've been here, it's been open. The interior layout of this bakery is really small and inefficient; the back area looks super messy w huge piles of boxes, papers, etc. It sort of makes me wonder how they manage to keep everything in order or if they even do, as their cash register is super old and there's a huge mess around the register as well -- do they even count all the money & make sure everything balances along with their inventory? They don't even really have receipts or anything. Aside from that, the baked goods are pretty good. Many people say that the egg tarts here are to die for; I wouldn't necessarily agree that they're the best egg tarts out there, but they're pretty damn good. The crust is super flaky and they give a generous amount of filling -- they definitely don't skimp. I also tried the sesame balls with red bean paste filling and that was pretty good as well. I would definitely be back if I'm ever in the area again and craving egg tarts but it's not something that I would HAVE to have every time I'm in SF.
author: Victoria Y.
Miko B.

description:
FYI this is Cash only! 

Honestly the best egg tart ever! We stood in line thinking that it was gonna take forever but I think we were super lucky because it took about 25 minutes until it was our turn to get egg tart. The line started to build up a lot after we got in the line. 

So the wait wasn't bad and when it was finally our turn, we found out why it was taking a shit ton of time. People ordered boxes and dozens of these and it takes time for them to pack all of the egg tarts. The ladies here were super nice and cute. They were friendly and quick with the service. We ordered 4 egg tarts and we wanted to order something else since we were in line so long already. We then got the white sponge cake (the literal Chinese English translation of this cake is "white sugar cake"). 

Eggtart was just AMAZING!!! Now I know why I was really never into egg tarts at dim sum restaurants. I just never had the good one! The crust was super flaky and crispy and the egg custard was super soft and smooth. I loved how it was still warm because it was fresh out of the oven. I had to have another one after the first one. Now I regretted not getting more for myself! So the one bad thing about this place was the "white sugar cake" that I got was bad. It turned sour within 2 hours of purchase. I am not sure about the other bakery items there but I would definitely come back and stand in line just for egg custards
author: Tran N.

description: We got here just after dinner at around 7 and there was a short line. The egg tarts are $2.25 each and came out fresh and extremely hot. They're delicious because they're not too sweet and have a nice flaky buttery crust. I would highly recommend you try this place if you're around Chinatown.
author: Chris S.

description:
Thing is, there's no actual need to report/review this place. There's not much advice that can be given or suggestions to be made. If Chinese baked desserts interest you, you would already know or have heard about it.

Gold Gate Bakery has had a solid following in the local Asian-American community since for-fucking-ever. On one end of Chinatown, they are going to have lines out their doors no matter what happens. I live in San Jose, and there is a solid community here of people who specifically love Golden Gate Bakery's egg custard tarts. The goddamn Cult of Golden Gate Bakery Egg Tarts is a real thing here. Whenever we stop by San Francisco, no matter what group I'm with, we ALWAYS STOP HERE. I get LOOKS if I so much as insinuate we do otherwise. At this point, their slitted, pink donut boxes are pretty recognizable. Even if you don't know WHEN they're open, if you're walking down Chinatown, you know IF they're open because there is a smattering of people walking down the street with one or four of those boxes. This is convenient when you need an impressive mooncake for the Mid-Autumn/Chinese Moon Festival. They sell those too, and it always impresses the traditional, Chines families.

The process entails this: Get in line, wait anywhere from 45 to 65 minutes (an hour and five minutes has happened to us before), order at the counter, they'll box it up for you and slit them so that the heat doesn't make the tarts or pastries soggy, pay in cash, and shoulder your way back out on the sidewalk.

I know this routine as well as anybody else. When my family goes to San Francisco, we're expected to buy 2 to 3 dozen egg tarts to bring back and redistribute among friends and family in San Jose. We have being doing this for as long as I can remember, which means at least over a decade . From these experience, I can only give you one piece of advice...:

Send the dispensable family members/friends. Give them some money, go about your business, and have that one or two friends/family wait in that hour long line. It's brutal and selfish, but only one truly needs to be sacrificed (and in my family, it's me or my brother).

......

This has got to be one of the shortest reviews I've ever written, and it's about sacrificing family members and friends to your food cravings. The world is a beautiful, beautiful place.
author: Christine L.

description:
I bought a ticket to SF for this.  Yes... flight sale... thought to myself... it's been too long since I've had a food orgasm.

What you need to know is... this is not just any egg tart... no!  You cannot categorize this with all the plebeian tarts of the world.  This tart is in a league of its own.  It is the supreme epitome... if this were the bar... no other tart deserves to be called a tart.  You will not be able to imagine the ecstasy that is this egg tart unless you commit yourself to the 45 minute line that is always in front of that door... you must bite into a piping hot tart right out of the oven to understand why people are willing to withstand that long line for a $1.95 egg tart?

This could become a dangerous addiction if the recipe got out.  The owners of the bakery mysteriously disappear for months at a time every year.  Are they going on vacation to enjoy the fruits of their yearlong labor?  I don't think so... I think they are traveling to the deepest highest mountain temple of China... to train... to meditate... to practice the ancient art... of tart.  Yes, and probably harvest some rare herbal endorphin that makes us all crazy for this tart.  

So... to all of you out there who don't live in San Francisco... book your ticket now.  Come for the tart... stay for the bay.
author: Hanh P.

description:
Hands down the best custards I have ever had in my life as a 22 year old Asian American. I have had my fare share of custard adventures in NYC and Boston, and none has ever been as good as the ones at Golden Gate Bakery. The custard here was very fresh and warm with the perfect sweetness. In proportion to the crust, it had there was so much filling! Some places are skimpy on the filling, but this place is very generous on that. However, it is $2 each custard which is much more expensive than the usual custard ($0.75-$1.25), but still worth the money!!

TIP: there is usually a line and they are open whenever they please. So definitely check out Yelp before you go to see if anyone says it's open. My first time trying, it was closed. You just gotta be lucky sometimes.
author: Shirley G.

description:
Open open open! I was jumping for joy to see that it was open- figuratively. I've tried coming here multiple times in the past, but they were always on vacation. When you can't have something, it makes you want it more. The line was long, but it didn't look too bad. It was deceiving though, as I waited over an hour for the egg tarts. The egg tarts sell out quickly, so it was mostly due to waiting for the next batch to come out. 

I ended up buying a dozen. It was $1.95 for one, which is pricy. Once I got my box, I couldn't wait to try an egg tart and scarfed one down. The crust was thin and flaky while the custard was smooth and creamy. I also bought a mooncake (lotus seed paste), just one as it was about $8. I never really cared for mooncakes, but I might as well since I was there. It was one of the better mooncakes I've had.

Cash only. Thankfully there was a Chase across the street. I feel like I should've pulled out more money though as I wish I could have another egg tart right now.
author: Helen H.

description: My favorite place to get egg tarts! The crust has great texture and very buttery, while the filling is silky and flavorful! The best thing is that you get to eat it very fresh here, where it is very hot. The wait is ridiculous but was well worth it. I'd be coming back here for sure!
author: Anthony L.

description: Every time I come to visit SF, I dread coming to this bakery because of the long line! But it is worth the wait. The egg tarts are what you need to order here. They are freaking huge too!  I always order at least a dozen because why wait in a long line just to order 2?  The breading is flakey and the egg custard in the middle is just right, not too sweet.  The bakery is small inside but the ladies in the back are really husselling for those egg tarts orders! You won't be disappointed waiting in that line if you're an egg tart fan!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I FINALLY got to try golden gate bakery after 4 attempts! Golden Gate Bakery is constantly on vacation.. which makes it nearly impossible for tourists like me to get to try their bakery. 

I recommend checking this website: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ and calling ahead of time prior to making a trip all the way down to downtown San Francisco. Parking is extremely difficult.. and it's more frustrating when they're not even opened. 

So tonight was the first time in 2 years that i've been able to go inside the store! you can imagine the excitement i felt when i realized it was opened. Luckily the line was not too long for a sunday evening. We waited in line for 15 minutes and got a fresh batch of egg tarts. 

The egg tarts are very tasty and creamy compared to the other egg tarts i've had before. Probably one of the best egg tarts i've had in my life! The wait is totally worth it and would definitely come back! 

Minus one star for their irregular hours and constant vacations.
author: Shelly S.

description: The ear cracker is the wrost crackers I have ever eaten!!!! The egg tart is good even though it is expensive!
author: Vincent Y.

description:
Definitely a must try if you're in SF. We came here on a weekend and waiting for 1 hour to get their egg tarts. The lady told us that we were lucky because the wait is usually 2 hours on the weekend. Bring cash because it's cash only! Also, call in ahead to check if the place is open. I hear that it closes randomly a lot of the time and it opens at random times of the day. The first day we came, it said it opened at noon. Today they opened at 10:30am.

We bought a dozen egg tarts for $25. They run out of egg tarts so fast that they always come out hot and fresh and delicious. The crust is buttery and flaky and there's so much egg filling. I honestly prefer my egg tarts a little sweeter, but other than that these egg tarts are nearly perfect.

Overall, many people will tell you that this place is a must try if you're visiting SF. I definitely agree. However, would I come here and wait 1 hour again for the egg tarts? Probably not.
author: Ashley D.

description:
yess! known throughout chinatown for their pink boxes, this is one of the best egg tarts i've had. definitely on par with the egg tarts in hong kong. 

egg tart ($2.15 each) - what they're popular for. custard part is very soufflé-like and the crust is crispy. the line is totally worth it especially when you bite into the tart and it's piping hot. 

apple pie - got talked into buying this but didn't regret it. i think they add nuts inside. so good and not overly sweet.

wife cake ($4.25) - my god this is the biggest wife cake i've ever eaten. pretty good. filling has seeds in it too which is different but i do wish there was more filling! 

i also got this other pancake looking pastry that i forgot the name of. 

interior is small and the line went out the door and down a few buildings. there's a display in the window and more inside. totally recommend coming here!!!
author: Yan L.

description:
Guess I'm lucky, because I've heard stories about them closing on random days and having long lines. But, I went twice, once on a Sunday and another on a Thursday and waited a max of 5 minutes for these marvelous egg tarts.

Eat them fresh, cause that's when they're at their best!! So GOOD, and I DO NOT LIKE EGG TARTS generally. But these are so cutard-y, melt-in-your-mouth amazing. I even at the crust, and I HATE crust! These don't taste as good the next day, not even with the help of a toaster oven. So, eat them asap!

Ordering is easy, and they speak english/cantonese/mandarin. Cash only. And I think, it's $2.25 a tart. I would assume their other pastries are good too--but that's for another visit!
author: Kelsey C.

description: Wow the egg tarts are SO photogenic. You look at the pictures & they makes you salivate. I didn't post a picture because there's tons of them already I was never an egg tart person but this place got me and I am happy to convert
author: Ako W.

description:
There are very few times in my life where I will wait long for things, THIS PLACE IS A TOTAL EXCEPTION, not kidding this place is the REAL DEAL when it comes to custard Egg Tarts.. I'm literally drooling thinking about biting into the fluffy deliciousness 

Came here on a Saturday around noon and waited about 30 min (the line got longer after lunch time so avoid if you're going to go around 1ish!). It was my first time so I was like uhhh why is this line so ridiculous but then I realized why after biting into their hot, fresh custard egg tarts. The crust is flakey, buttery and just the perfect amount of crunchy and softness-literally just melts in your mouth (or it feels like it because I was savoring every bite). The actual egg custard filling is ON FLEEK; perfectly fluffy and not too sweet. Eating it right after buying it while it's still warm is literal heaven highlyyy recommended. 

Bottom line: go hereee& if you see a long line & second guess coming here to get one of their custard egg tarts, don't think just DO IT & you'll thank me later 

NOTE: CASH ONLY
author: Lilly N.

description: One star for the tart and another one for the mochi desserts. They are not able to keep up with the demand--and Im starting to think if this is on purpose. Youd think the line should move faster since they just back your orders in boxes. The wait is because there's not enough tarts. With the money they've amassed from thousands of customers daily, they need to invest on production cost. But because of their unique customary business principles....it'll be a while until we see some change, if not never.
author: Chari G.

description: I was lucky to see this store actually open during my trip to SF. Waited for almost an hr thinking how good can an egg tart be.. Egg tarts are just egg tarts.. but after the first bite I was amazed. I am not a big fan of egg tarts, but definitely the best I've tasted and now I am a fan of egg tarts! I can actually taste the eggs in it, soo fresh, not too sweet, pefectly blended with the custard. It was definitely worth the wait. The size is bigger than other egg tarts making $2.25 worth the money.
author: Jeanne W.

description: Finally I was able to catch this and the line was moving pretty fast. Yes, they do speak English and yes, they only accept cash and better bring at least a$100 if u plan to buy more than just a box. Do buy the egg tart and the sesame balls. The balls are really crunchy n very big.
author: Joana D.

description: Finally getting some egg tarts and they aren't closed this time I'm here! Can we say the egg tarts are just delicious though? Melts in your mouth especially when they are out from the oven! OMMMMMMMG! Definitely worth the wait in line for these yummy goodness! I would totally recommend if you're ever in the Chinatown area! These are a MUST!
author: Sally S.

description: Way too overhyped. Not worth the wait OR the $2.50 price tag for their custard tarts. Don't waste your time. I have had better.
author: Eddy X.

description:
Had to give this place a try given the hype about their egg tarts. The ladies who run the shop are so accustomed to the orders and prices that they'll tell you exactly how much it is without any calculators lol the egg tarts are made very fresh, and given the volume of people that goes through, you'll almost always be getting a fresh batch, which is the main reason the wait can be long.

That being said, I thought the egg tarts were good, but I didn't like the crust too much. It wasn't as flakey as I hoped, and there wasn't much to the flavor. The egg custard itself was very eggy-tasting, and not too sweet. Personally, I like Portuguese egg tarts better. 

They also have other pastries too, like macaroons and apricot and walnut pastries. Those aren't made as frequently as the egg tarts, and whatever they have in display is what they have for that day.
author: Cindy H.

description:
Didn't have to wait for our 2 dozen egg custards. Perhaps it didn't taste as good to warrant a 5 stars since we didn't "earned" it by waiting for hours in line. 
Crust: extreme flaky as it should 5/5
Custard: Well balanced, not too sweet 5/5
Custard firmness: A bit too soft as I like mine a bit firmer. This is a personal preference. 4/5

This is a solid 4.5 stars
author: Sean T.

description: Egg tart and peanut mochi. Say no more!!! Be ready to wait in line but it is worth the wait.
author: roderick s.

description: Simply amazing egg tarts ( aka dan tat).  Buttery and flaky crust surrounds a rich custard. There seems to be a line out the door at all times of the day which only means fresh egg tarts constantly being made. Dont wait to get home, take a bite while the egg tarts are still warm.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I've been looking for egg tarts after having some in Lisbon, Portugal.  These hit the spot, but they're not quite up there.  The treats displayed at this bakery all look delicious.  We picked up some tarts, almond cookies, and a sesame ball with the bean paste and they were all good.  You know this place has to be good with the line that's constantly outside. I would recommend this place to anyone visiting the Chinatown area.
author: Angelo L.

description:
I've been meaning to try Golden Gate Bakery, but when i go there, the line is either too long or it's closed. The thing about this place is that the hours are so unpredictable. I called that morning to see when they would be open and when we got there, we found that the bakery was open one hour later than expected. We were 40 minutes early for the opening and found that the line was already getting very long as the opening time approached. 

We got both the egg tarts and the coconut tarts. I personally prefer Portuguese egg tarts, but this egg tarts were the best I've had (among this kind)! It was smooth and creamy and I loved how delicious the bakery smelled. I only got one coconut tart and I regretted it! They were SO good. 

You should definitely check out this bakery if you're in the area (pray that they're open!!)
author: Arianna B.

description:
Ok- best egg tarts I have ever had in my life and I've had a lot of egg tarts in my life as a Taiwanese-American. But this place is hands down the best that I've ever had. I've always been fortunate enough to have other people bring me some because this place is also notorious for having bizarre open hours. 

Decided to swing by the place after getting dim sum in Chinatown and they were open! They are cash only, so prepare for that. There will also always be a line out the door as it's a pretty small establishment. 

Onto the egg tarts; they're wrapped up in a cake box for you, just out of the oven. I personally like them after they've had some time to chill in the fridge, but you should definitely try them hot and cold to see what you like best. 

If you're ever in SF Chinatown, you have to get these egg tarts if they're open; otherwise you're definitely missing out!
author: Isabel C.

description:
Is it the best egg tart in the city? So far without a doubt Yes
Is it worth $2? Yup
Is it worth waiting in line upwards of 2 hours? Hell to the...No

Overall Thoughts

Anyone who waits in line for these egg tarts and brings it to you is someone you should thank profusely
author: Eddie W.

description:
My friend was a fan of this bakery and when we had our trip to San Francisco, this bakery is in one of the top places to visit. Located in the Chinatown of SF but the first thing I noticed was this shop is the only one that has a long line outside the door. I went to the line while my friend was shopping something else, and it was not long at all I would say around 20-25 minutes.
Bought a couple of dozens for $27/ each dozen and per piece was $2.25 and left home. When I got home and tried I CAN NOT STOP, it was so good. The filling is not too sweet, moist, I can taste the egg but not too "eggy", the crust is crusty and perfect. A man behind me waited for the same time and only ordered 1 egg tart, he must have lived nearby and just craving for it. If I live closeby I'd do the same thing too.
Yummmm!
author: Stephany S.

description: Not many places I know can afford and have the "we open whenever the f#ck we want" mentality, but this place can because of what everyone is raving about on these reviews.  The product is pretty stunning.
author: Patrick C.

description: Golden Gate Bakery is a must have if you find your self near the area.  When I went there i really didn't know what was about to happen.  In my mind I believe that is was just going to a place with some good custard that was really hyped for nothing.  But when I bit into it for the first time I could not believe how undeniably delicious it was.  I can try to explain how good it truly is but I think you got to make your own first impression on it first or else if might keep your up at night thinking about what you missed out on.
author: Russell G.

description:
Why I haven't reviewed this place yet? No idea how to even answer that question. This place has been here for years. I remember stopping by with my parents when I was a kid every time we would visit SF for the day. I never ate it as a kid and I deeply regretted that decision as an adult. These golden beautiful yellow delicious egg tarts are heaven sent.  The line you see wrapping around the block. Don't sweat it just get in line. You'll thank me later after you inhale 4 or 5 walking back to your car. Everything is piping hot and fresh out the oven.  I'm don't eat egg tarts anywhere else because nothing matches up to the taste of these. They are perfect mix of creamy, sweet and eggy with a flaky golden crust. They are kind of expensive now from back then but SF in general is an expensive place. I believe each runs for about 2.50 each. Only downfall about this place is they randomly are closed for weeks at a time, my only suggestion before hitting up Chinatown and trying to find parking just to walk over there to find it close and your heart broken is to just call them first. If they don't pick up once call again. If they don't pick up the second time. They are probably closed and on vacation. But seriously no trip to SF Chinatown will be complete without making a trip here and buying at least a dozen to bring home.

Pro tip: refrigerate when you get home. Pop one into a small oven for 10 minutes at 350 degrees, comes out perfectly warmed as if it came fresh out of the bakery
author: Janice P.

description: The egg tart was pretty good and fresh.  It is a bit over rated and expensive.  Had many egg tarts in nyc and non off them cost $2.50 and was equally as good. I also tried their banana cake.  It was chewy and soft.  Their rice cake with peanut was good. It had a banana taste to it.
author: Ariel E.

description:
HELLO EGG TART! Curious about the long line on this "bakery" I yelped to see what is the hassle all about. All yelpers raved about this bakery's egg tart. As a true fan of egg tarts, I had to try it. We waited in line for 30 minutes and we were literally the 60th or so people from the front of the line and hundreds more after us. Egg tarts practically all tastes the same (seriously, i have ordered them from Paris Baguette, 85 Bakery, Shengkee, you name it!) but GGB is A-perfection! Fresh out of the over (burnt my tongue - I was so excited to taste it), their egg tarts so smooth and slightly sweet with perfect crust - so flaky and crips! I also had it the next day and still tasted so fresh and delicious - unlike other egg tarts (the next day, it's eeeeehhh, OK). I noticed people ordered by the dozens so they kept bringing out new fresh batches of egg tarts one tray after the other. It's the best one I've ever had. If you have had egg tarts from different places like I have, you will know the difference. 

Other great bakery goods that I highly recommend: Coconut Muffins (SO GOOD!!) and their Lotos pancakes (well, that's what I call it.) It so delicious. It has lotus filling inside. Let's just put it this way: If you love Chinese baked goods, GGB is the place for you! 

We were fortunate to be in the area while this place was open because from the chatter amongst the people standing in line, this Bakery has weird hours. They are only open maybe 3-4 a week and on random hours too. It's a hit or miss. Business hours is unreliable! Also, be prepared to order right away - know what you want because the staff will rush you to order to keep the line going fast. HAHA. Just smile through it.
author: Rodalyn C.

description:
Finally I came here and they were not on vacation. I think it was because it was Chinese New Year month because they blocked off a lot of the street so you have to park outside of chinatown and walk in. Waited an hour in line because so many people before ordered dozens of egg tarts which was annoying but when I finally got it. That bite into the egg tart reminded me how heavenly these bad boys were. What I like about these egg tarts is that the crust is light and flakey but not too flakey where it falls apart and the custard is creamy yet firm and it doesn't taste too eggy.

I also like getting their coconut macaroons, I really wanted only one but you are required to buy at least 6. The coconut tart is also good, it's different from the macaroon as the tart has grounded coconut to where as the macaroons are shredded.  Delicious goodies and I usually leave with all 3 and you should to.
author: Andrew T.

description: Waited an hour for egg tarts on a Wednesday afternoon. The egg tarts were warm and flakey with soft and silky egg/butter/milk filling. I agree that it's probably the best in Chinatown because it's fresh and warm. However I gave 4 stars because as a Chinese who had a lot of different egg tarts, I wouldn't say it's impressive enough to justify the 1-hour wait. It's good but not outstanding. The filling can be less sugary and more natural.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Amazinggggg egg tarts! Worth the wait and drive every time we're in the area. The egg tarts are like no other- flaky crust on the outside and smooth creamy custard in the inside. It always comes out fresh and warm from the oven they don't serve you cold ones! It's the place where you know it's recipes passed on from your mama's Mama so it's all hidden and they also say no pictures so it's a bit sketch but you know Asian mamas don't trust anyone in their business. 

Service is what you expect at any other mom and pop Asian places in Chinatown. A whole lot of yelling and get in and out of my place. Ran by old ladies you know like your moms that just wanna get things rolling. The wait is shorter on weekdays than weekends and it's always s at least half an hour. 

Do not skip on a gem like this!! Oh and it's cash only!!
author: Anni N.

description:
I had heard about Golden gate from some locals and it's really an interesting experience. The egg tarts were way less sweet and way more eggy than I expected, but it really was an interesting treat. They did open about 30 minutes later than the sign said, and a few people who had waited in line with us for 40 minutes left because they didn't have cash! (Bring cash!!) 
I also tried a pineapple dessert that was kind of like a Mcdonald's apple pie, but with pineapple and nut filling... yum!
author: Christin J.

description: Amazing egg tarts! We waited for almost two hours! Worth every single bite! Our egg tart was steaming hot! So good!
author: Junie H.

description: Simply delicious egg tarts!!! Warm eggy center with a hint of sweetness!! I'm back in Hong Kong!!!
author: Anna L.

description: Waited for 45 minutes. Egg tarts are 2.25 a piece. The crust is absolutely amazing and the filling was ok. Definitely try it once if you never had their egg tarts before.
author: Zi C.

description: I've heard many people rave about this place and I'm glad that I actually got to try it for myself. Luckily the wait wasn't that long and I got it within a few minutes in line. Personally I like my egg tarts crusts more on the soft side but golden gates bakery egg tarts have really good flavor and a flakey crust. I also got one of the red bean sesame balls and those were delicious, the outside was crispy and good and not too drenched in oil. A con of that was that the red bean filling barely existed but it was good. A pro is that when you get it they are still warm and that makes the experience more mouth watering. This is one of the places you must try if you like dimsum pastries.
author: Christina S.

description:
Other than the constant closure of the bakery even though you would think it is open during regular business hours, the dan tats are extremely well-known and worth a visit or an attempted visit to the shop in Chinatown. The place is a small little shop so you may have to wait outside. In addition the dan tat, they also sell other Chinese pastries that I would say are also great. There is no discount for purchasing more unfortunately.

So here's the deal, you have to have them when they are piping hot. Like literally buy the dan tat, walk outside and start eating. That is the best way and I want to say the only say you should do it. If you do buy more, I would risk microwaving it to get the custard hot but be careful not to cook the egg...

In terms of service, they are super quick and ready to pack your box/bag with pastries. They have learned enough English to help you but it might help to know Cantonese or have a buddy with you that knows Cantonese.

BUT a must when coming to SF. Them dan tats tho...

P.S. I would've added a pic but no pics inside the shop and I ate my dan tats before I could take a pic...
author: Kevin L.

description:
Alright so call me a skeptic, but I was not down to pay $2 for an egg tart esp since all of the ones I've had growing up had never been something I looked forward to eating. The insides were always too eggy and the texture bothered me. The only saving grace was the crust and even then I was only meh about it. But guys, absolutely 100% would come here again even with the hour long mid weekday line. The egg tarts were phenomenal. I've never had anything like it! The egg custard was less eggy and more like a pudding texture and since it was freshly baked it was still warm and creamy. The crust was thicker than a typical dim sum egg tart but was also flaky and buttery and reminded me of a thicker and more crusty version of a croissant. We ordered a dozen for our coworkers but man I wish I had ordered more. 

Cash only and be wary of coming up here during holidays and the summer since they shut down for months at a time it seems like. Make sure you google "isgoldengatebakeryopen" to find the website and Facebook that will tell you if it is open!
author: Sam L.

description: Line was long as usual, but this seems more like a tourist trap. Egg custards here were not the best I've had... they lacked taste and dimension, and there wasn't anything to savor.
author: Lucy T.

description: Yes the egg tarts are better than some nearby BUT I give em 2starsvfor the $2.50 price and for it's size!   And making me wait 35 mins!!  I believe the reason why there's daily long lines is bcoz the tourists look for best Yelp ratings and willing to spend money for em.   To the locals that's way to much for an egg tart!!
author: Jun S.

description:
This review is based on their EGG TARTS! 

EGG TARTS STORY
I never liked egg tarts. It was always either too sweet or too egg-y. Like why. When I came to SF this was raved about, but me and my sister just kind of shrugged it off. We both love food but didn't like egg tarts. While getting dimsum at another store we happened to be in the area. There was no line (which was a freak of nature) and I think it so was the world's way of luring us in otherwise we wouldn't have bothered. So yes we went in and bought two. We each took a bite and our eyes widened and we both said "wow". 

By the time we finished our two egg tarts, we knew we wanted to buy more... alot more. When you watch other people they buy these tarts by the BOXFULL. We thought it was weird till we ate it and wanted to do the exact same thing. In those couple of minutes a line had formed so we did go right back in but had to wait in line, which normally there always is a line or so I've read. We bought a ton more and enjoyed it the rest of our stay in SF. We ate a ton of new and awesome food while we visited but these egg tarts stick out the most in my mind. 

So, moral of this story is to try these egg tarts no matter what. It's a Must! 

EXPERIENCE
After the first time we went there was always a line so be prepared to stand in one. But the line does move fast.

I'm Asian but not Chinese so it's always a little intimidating going to a full on Chinatown establishment. But it wasn't too bad here. Just know what you want (egg tarts) and enjoy!!!
author: Liz L.

description: This was at the top of my sf bucket list! I was checking yelp religiously to see when it was opening back up because they were closed for the month of June for vacation. The line was down the block but goes by quickly and I actually like it better because most bakeries don't have lines and you have to shove your way to the front. Egg tart was warm and crust was browned. Overall very delicious  but I prefer aa bakery around the corner. The tarts are a little sweeter and half the price ;)
author: Mandy P.

description:
Best egg tarts but only when they're eaten day of (and ideally 5 minutes out of the oven). I took off a star because they really taste normal to bad the day after. It's a very thin crust with a custardy egg filling. Golden Gate Bakery is a Chinatown staple. Although normal hours are noted on Yelp, make sure to google "Is Golden Gate Bakery Open?" to get the latest on whether the owners are on vacation. They often can leave for weeks on end. I haven't tried any of the other dishes but I've heard they're popular for moon cakes as well.

=Wait Time History=
Waited 1 hour on a Saturday afternoon
Waited 15 minutes on a Saturday evening (an hour before closing)
author: Tammy T.

description:
Minus one star for the whole cash only thing.

Most people come in ordering a dozen egg tarts and one one dozen is 27 dollars. There is no reason why it should be cash only. If anything have a minimum purchase.

Other than that they egg tarts are so worth the wait. We always get two doses when we go only because we drive all the was from South Bay and then we have to wait in that line, so not worth all that trouble if you're only grabbing 2 or 3.

Our last batch was fresh out of the oven, so good, by my little man was so excited he couldn't wait and burned his mouth. He refused to spit it out even though it was hot because it was so good. The whole moment was hilarious but shows how obviously good this place is that someone would risk injury just to consume it. Hahaha.

All in all we always go back. Just FYI their vacation time for 2018 is April 2018 they will be gone for 3 weeks so they whole establishment will be closed. I will be back in May :)
author: Alexandra G.

description:
I've probably been to San Francisco 5 times over the past 2 years and FINALLY had a chance to try it during my most recent trip. I was walking by around 7:30 on a Sunday evening and noticed the shop was actually open. I stopped by and there was a short line out the door. Turns out they were making a fresh batch of egg tarts! Not 15 minutes later, I got my hands on this little heavenly pastry. It was still warm and toasty and smelled amazing!

I've had my fair share of egg tarts in my lifetime, but if you can get your hands on these egg tarts, and actually eat them fresh, you will not regret it!
author: Calvin L.

description:
I've come by this bakery at least three times and 2/3 times I've been here, they were "closed, on vacation"... and as I read that sign, I saw a whole bunch of people in there. Yeah, you got it right, they seem like they make enough business they can close shop whenever they want and still have enough money to pay for rent/vacation whenever they feel like it. 

Anyways, on the very third time I came here, they were finally open!! I waited in line for at least 30 mins before I was able to order... but I've gotta say, these are these are some pretty gooooood egg tarts!! My sister and I bought 20 egg tarts plus like two other baked goods for almost $45(around that price). Yep, coming from LA, with an abundance of delicious, inexpensive food, these egg tarts were pretty darn expensive. They are almost $2 each but I'd say it's worth it for egg tart lovers out there. 

Would I come back again? Probably only if my friends want to go.. but I don't think I would deliberately come here or go out of my way to make plans to go here. 

One thing I really base my reviews on is service. Their service can definitely use some work... I speak Cantonese so I jokingly asked if I can be an apprentice (tou-dai) there and the lady packaging the egg tarts said she didn't have time for my nonsense and that they were busy! Like who in the world treats their customers like that? Oh well, seeing how busy they were, I wasn't expecting superb service and small talk anyways. 

One small advice, EAT THE EGG TART RIGHT AWAY WHEN IT IS FRESH. You can also reheat it in the oven but it kinda loses its freshness. 

That is all. Happy eating!
author: Amy L.

description: Is this one of the best egg tarts I've had? YES. I'm from the San Gabriel Valley in LA, which is FILLED with delicious Asian food. I've had my fair share of egg tarts from both LA and China and Hong Kong. Golden Gate probably makes the best egg tarts in the Bay - flaky, smooth custard, could probably eat a whole box in one sitting. They also sell other Chinese snacks - one thing my mom loves from here are their "elephant ears" as we call it, which are slightly sweet crackers with a swirl design. Worth a purchase if you decide to stand in the insanely long line. Their hours can also be quite iffy. I always call the morning of to check if they're open.
author: Jacqueline T.

description: This place has no business ethics. I've flown up to sf four times this year and each time this piece of shit place is closed. Shut down for vacation. Now if I did that for my business, my ass would be boycotted. Don't get me wrong, their tarts are good. But it would take a miracle for one to see them open.
author: Patrick W.

description: Heavenly egg tarts!: delicate pastry with flaky crust and jiggly egg custard. Stumbled by this non-conspicuous bakery as we were exploring SF Chinatown. Living in NYC, bakeries in the Chinatowns are "dime a dozen". However the line outside (consisting of Asian and Caucasian and others) made me check Yelp. Damn all these rave Yelp reviews (as they spoke the truth), and enslaving my palate once I tasted these egg tarts! Waited 20 minutes around 3pm (makeshift sign on door stated that they opened at 12pm - consider meself very lucky as many reported that the bakery keeps unpredictable hours and may run out of the cherished tarts). Once inside: to my horror they were selling the last egg tarts on the counter. I wanted 18 and one of the 2 ladies told me that more are being baked in the kitchen. She spoke English and Cantonese, and was the nicer and chattier of the 2, as the other lady behaved more like the egg tart version of Seinfeld's Soup Nazi. Finally a fresh batch came out and we got what we wanted. Coconut macaroons were also very good. Price was $2.50/egg tart compared to $ 1.95 a year ago (25% hike).
author: Ed P.

description:
So I seem to have lucked out with this one. From what I understand from the locals, this place has
no regular schedule and you never know when they're open. However, when they open the line is around the block and it's worth the wait. The egg custard tarts are potentially the best pastry I've ever eaten. I would definitely call before you go. It's a small space, the service is a little slow, it's cash only and it still worth it.
author: Debra S.

description: Walking down Chinatown on our visit in San Fran and saw the lineup so we got in line. On Monday, holiday it was open at 11am and only opened around 11:10am. The line moved slowly as two older Asian ladies were packing the egg tarts.  Finally got half dozen egg tarts and tried 2 and I must say it was the best egg tart I've had. I love the flakiness of the crust, I love the amount of filling in it. It wasn't overly sweet, but the filling was amazing!  So smooth!  It was worth the wait.  Definitely eat it when it is warm!!!
author: Cynthia C.

description: There's a reason why I stand in line for 45 minutes and come back every time I'm in Chinatown. These egg tarts are definitely the best I've ever tried. From the crust to the egg, nothing is overly sweet and everything is flavorful. They're so addicting that I have to remind myself that it's probably not a good idea to eat 3+ in one sitting. Other egg tarts always pale in comparison to these. The only downside is the hours! You might be disappointed when you go all the way down to SF and are greeted with a "Closed" sign. I recommend checking the "Is the Golden Gate Bakery Open Today' location on Instagram to see if they are open.
author: Sophie S.

description:
Took a trip to Chinatown on a Saturday and it was just so crowded. This place is known for their egg tarts and I had never tried so I decided to wait. 

1 hour and 30 minutes. 

I don't know about you but nothing tastes good after 1.5 hour of wait. I am fine with egg tarts at my usual dim sum places. 

The egg tarts are very good though. Do stop by when there's no line.
author: Yuesquared H.

description: Extremely overrated. It was our first time here based on word of mouth.  We waited an hour and it was not worth it. Cannot understand the demand for the egg tarts. While placing our order the owner/employee answered the phone but quickly grew tired of answering questions about store hours or if they'd be open tomorrow.  The owner/employee literally said "I'm too busy to talk" and then hung up on the person. It was comical at the same time rude customer service. At least we experienced it once and know not to bother coming back again.  The custard of the egg tart was too sweet and nothing extraordinary. The only notable difference in their egg tarts is that the crust is evenly baked. So not worth it, even without a wait.
author: Nhan H.

description:
Baked to perfection with the seriously most perfect ingredients.

The egg tart is delicious but it's very expensive at about $2~ each. Considering you can get 'em for around $1~ at other stores nearby, it's literally double the price. You get what you pay for....right? Haha, this place really has me salivating all the time.

They're so popular and well known they open whenever they want...whenever they feel like. They also choose to sell however much they want..and however much they feel like. LOL. One time they only sold 1-2 tarts per person and one time they were opened on Friday starting at like 4pm. They do what they want!

I've asked the owners when they are usually open, and she just gave me a random day and time. Whenever I catch them open, I always run in and grab one.
author: Melanie T.

description: It is all about supply and demand.  Very smart method to keep the hype up and the word on the street for others to know about.  This is probably the reason why their hours of operation is never consistent and they say they are closed for vacation.  I would only get the egg custard.  Everything else in there seems just okay.
author: G R.

description:
The ladies here are the Chinese, egg tart equivalent of soup nazis. "Three pieces only! 

I don't love the egg tarts here because I find the filling too egg-y as opposed to creamy like the original egg tarts back in Macau. 

The lines are pretty ridiculous and it's unfortunate that the bakery is right next to where homeless people seem to pee but when you're craving egg tarts in SF this is the place to go. 

3.5 stars. Cash only. $2.15 per egg tart. And they will only give you the box if you buy 1/2 a dozen.
author: Eunah T.

description:
If you love eggtarts, this is definitely the place to get it! Came here last week to wait in line. Normally I wouldn't wait but hadn't had it in so long and we had visitors in town which justified it. Otherwise expect a long line no matter what. If you need Asian foods or fresh veggies, go with someone and you can go shopping around there while one person waits in line. 

The place is tiny with few people working which is probably why the line doesn't move faster. They come in pink boxes like you get at the donut store and they also tie ribbon around it which is probably why it takes longer

Anyway, the egg tarts are soft, flaky, and ooh so good. The middle is wiggly and nice to eat, not stiff like some places.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Quality of the Dan Ta is always on point. It was just the line and the wait this time was ridiculous. Usually the wait is short no matter what time I've gone. So when I planned this spot, I didn't leave enough time. We waited for almost 50 mins in the urine smelling streets of SF. No one in the party has ever experience this drastic wait. 

Parking is SF. So don't expect a spot. Just circle around the world a few times.

Once again though, the pastries are on point.
author: Aaron H.

description: This is the best don tart place so far beside the one I ate in Hong Kong ... it's always a long line but it's worth it for the wait cause it's  so yummy....
author: Vivian H.

description: O M G  this place definitely has the best tarts in the whole Bay Area  if you don't mind waiting in line for more than 1/2 hr. I recommend getting the whole dozen but also don't forget to try the muffins. It is conveniently located around the corner from our favorite Chinese restaurant! Everything is perfect even the way the pastries are packed
author: K L.

description: Waited in line for almost and hour, expected the tart to be more custard consistency (however very tasty). The hoarder mentality of the actual shop itself is kind of worrisome - it makes you wonder about the cleanliness.
author: Hannah P.

description: Their egg tarts are to die for! Long lines unless you go towards closing on Friday nights!
author: Keepme A.

description:
Really nice baked goods at this Chinatown location.
Service was friendly and even recommended what was the hot items.
The line can be a bit slow, but the food is worth the wait.
I recommend you give this place a try.
author: Douglas F.

description: This bakery is known for their delicious egg tarts!! Served warm as the crust is not crumbly (like most egg tarts)- and creamy egg in the middle! The only downside is that they open whenever they feel like it and the lines are long (the last time I went here, I had to wait 20mins!!)
author: Jenn N.

description:
My husband and I have passed by this bakery a couple of times and always wondered what all the hype was about (aka the line). A guy on the street told us they have the best egg tarts in all of San Francisco. So we decided to stop and wait on line the other day.

To start off, we aren't familiar with this delicacy - so to be fair, we have nothing to compare to. Also, we were born and raised in the US so I suppose we are accustomed to sweeter treats. 

That all being said, we found the Golden Gate egg tart to be pretty nasty. We got one to share RIGHT out of the oven (scorched my tongue) and all we tasted was scrambled egg with an extremely small hint of sweetness from the crust. If that is what they are supposed to taste like then you will love them. Judging by all of the positive reviews, it might be.

I also bought a banana rice roll. The texture (from the rice flour) was gum-like and mushy. I found it to be oddly satisfying. Although, the flavor was extremely artificial. I can assure you that no real bananas were used to make this dessert. It tasted like candy.

Overall, the prices seemed fair, the customer service was pretty good, the place seemed like it was in violation of some health codes, the wait was probably about a half hour long, and the baked goods were terrible. We will not be returning to this bakery.
author: Danielle P.

description: Awesome place for dim sum ! The food is cooked fresh  and ready to go for order. Although the line is long, it goes by quick. Don't mind the look of the place, the food is delicious! Great price and would definitely come back for more.
author: Michael W.

description:
Rude service if speak to them in Chinese. But when you speak English thank you this and that. 
.
Known for egg tarts. They have a crazy line which is usually 30 mins to 1 hr wait or more. The egg tart is good when it is served piping hot. Suppposingly best in SF.  But doesn't leave me wanting more, if short line i will wait if long line i pass. 
.
Curry turn overs is my fav here. The curry is not too strong has corn and bellpepper inside. Moist and juicy in the inside. Flakey on the outside. 
.
Moon cake is like 10 bucks each. My fav is the white lotus seed with egg yolk. But to figure out the egg yolk is not really great. Why? When you had better ones, where the eggyolk leaks out oil those are the good ones. This egg yolk was dry. But the lotus seed really taste quality. Overall i think i will pass next time on the moon cakes. Just surprises me how people buy 6 boxes with 4 inside basically 40 bucks a box. Wow.... making bank! 
.
Overall prepare to wait. If your visiting come visit and just say you have been to a known place. Take a selfie, eat a hot piping fresh outta oven egg tart, pair with your own coffee or strong tea in you tumbler. Just some hints i would do. Thanks for reading and egg it up!
author: Alex T.

description:
There are lots of Chinese bakeries in SF Chinatown, but only one is well known to all tourist and locals, it's the Golden Gate Bakery.  Yes, it also has the best name for an establishment.  It has become so popular that it became a tourist attraction.  All for what?  Yes, an egg tart!  
The crust is soft and crispy and totally melts in your mouth.  The egg tart is not too sweet and when it just comes out of the oven, it just broke the mouth good!
author: Cindy L.

description:
GGB has and always will be my favorite bakery for egg tarts. Wait isn't bad if you're going at the right time. Right before they open and sometimes the line dies in between 4pm - closing. But once people line up, everyone follows. 

The shop is small, I think maybe enough for 5 people at a time and usually 2 - 3 ladies to help with orders. CASH ONLY. If you're gonna complain, go somewhere else. The ladies are quick, don't expect them to treat you like you're super important. They'll take your order and give you what you ordered as fast as they can because they have a ton of people to get through. They don't have time to ask how your day is, have you been here before, etc. So be ready with your order once they call for you. Prices have been increasing, but guess what, so has their rent I'm sure and ingredients to make all their wonderful pastries. SF is extremely expensive, and to me their egg tarts are worth it.

Now the egg tarts themselves. Perfect. The egg custard is amazing. Super soft, blended really well and still tastes fresh the next day (put in a toaster oven to warm back up). The "crust" is very flakey and crisp, but moist in the middle. Again, perfect. Believe me, I've tried many different egg tarts. Even did a blind taste test because people didn't believe it was that good. I always choose GGB. Nothing comes close. 

**Just a warning to those who don't know, the shop to the right of the bakery is VERY irritated by the bakery's customers blocking their shop so watch where you line up. Either line up to the left or split the line once it ends at bakery end and continue the line where the meters are for parking.
author: Lucy N.

description:
Anyone that knows me knows that I hate waiting in line for pretty much anything.The dreadful hour and half wait sure made me one hungry and grumpy camper. I can't believe I'm saying this but man, the wait was totally worth it. Their egg tarts(priced at $2.25 each) was the best I've ever had and the buttery coconut macarons melted my soul.
Waiting with so many people also made place for some great conversations and really is apart of the SF culture. So maybe I should not be so impatient after all :)
author: Hanyu Q.

description:
What makes a good egg tart you ask? Why are these better than others you may have had? What makes them worth $2.25 each? Here goes (not in any particular order):

1) these actually are about 1.5x larger than others I've had in the Bay Area. 
2) the crust... super flaky, almost like a croissant. This is not your average Safeway store bought crust. I've never experienced crust like this except perhaps my grandmas pie crust from back in the day. This actually is I think possibly even better.
3) the egg filling... not too sweet. Super fresh. A simple taste that is only possible when you use just a few ingredients and no preservatives. When you bite, you first taste egg, almost like an omelette. But keep tasting and you taste a milky/cream taste. Don't swallow yet. Swirl it one last time over the tongue and you will barely taste a hint, just a slight hint of sugar. In a world full of overly sweetened baked goods I am a huge fan of bakeries that  are capable of exercising some self control when it comes to adding this nearly toxic ingredient (sugar). It's needed for sure to complete the flavor profile of these, but I'm very thankful this bakery has determined the exact quantity required for this recipe.

We got our 18 tarts warm... really actually hot and slightly jiggly in the center. We ate  one of them immediately nearly burning our mouth. I recommend eating them this way whenever possible, but they were still quite yummy several hours later once they had completely cooled. Do yourself a favor. Stand in the line. Try it for once in your life! Then you be the judge.
author: Chrys K.

description: A bit on the pricey side for bakery goods, especially in the heart of Chinatown where competition is high in the same niche market. $2 for a seasame ball, $8.75-$13 for moon cakes. Limited bakery offerings, basically what's in the window, and today was just the two above mentions and some thick brick-like rice krispie treat. Swung by here a few times in the past and they were randomly closed. Also, although famous for their egg tarts, they do not have them every day. In general, coming here on a whim results in inconsistent availability of pastry offerings and you risk them not being open. Best to always call in advance the day of to ensure it's opened and that they have the selection of goods you are looking to buy.
author: Alison A.

description: Is this what a real egg tart is supposed to taste like? Excuse me while I go wipe my tears away... I am being super dramatic, but it was seriously a great egg tart. The store owners are fickle. They close and open the store whenever they want, which is understandable..especially if the egg tarts are that tasty. If they're not selling at the time you go, explore Chinatown a bit and then stop by again! You just might be pleasantly surprised.
author: Erika P.

description: We were so lucky that it was opened on the day we arrived SF. We basically ordered small quantity of everything to share, except for the egg tarts. We had to have one for each person as it was very good. We finished everything outside the shop, no leftovers whatever for later :)
author: Karen L.

description: I've tried going to this place every time I visit San Francisco but it always seems to be closed for vacation or something. I've been 0 for 5 over the past couple of years. Is this place ever open?
author: Bruce-Cindy B.

description: Thank goodness it was raining and we didn't have to wait in a line because I personally do not think these are THAT amazing. They're good but I've had better in Alhambra, CA at various dim sum houses. The crust here is not flaky like a pastry. It tastes more deep fried, which I know isn't the case so I don't know what to say.
author: Nicole J.

description:
You see a long line?  Yeah it's that good.  Everyone comes here for the egg tarts.  It's expensive just for one egg tarts.  

But it is delicious, the best one I've ever had.  If you have had you know, if you haven't it's worth the try.

If you are lucky the line is short, worst would be they are closed for vacation.
author: Lyman C.

description:
If you like your tarts fresh, I would highly recommend stopping by!

Dozen for ~$24.. pretty pricey for egg tarts, but you can't beat how great they are! They're so creamy,and will melt in your mouth. The flakey crust is also an amazing treat. I love flakey crust anything! Note: I'm not one to ever want egg tarts, but when in SF this is definitely one of my must have pit stops. *Drooolssss

Also, I've been here on a couple occasions and both, they had a "closed on vacation" sign...Reading through reviews, it looks like they've been on vacation for ages. However, I think if you see goodies in the window gawking at you, then you just have to stand there looking like a beggar...And maybe someone will come and bless you with these divine treats!
author: Yannie S.

description:
Finally, I had the chance to try one of the most reputable and elusive places in San Francisco, California. How about that!

For those of you who do not know, Golden Gate Bakery is known for their famous egg tarts. People in the food and Yelp community will rave about how good their egg tarts are. At the same time, they'll also cry over how impossible it is to actually try the stuff at Golden Gate Bakery. For this shop is only open once in a blue moon - there's a website devoted to notifying you when it's open here http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com (doesn't work anymore though?)! And, if you do catch this place while it's open, be prepared to wait a LONG TIME. 

I decided to drag my girlfriend to Chinatown in hopes of being the lucky few that catch Golden Gate Bakery while it is open. I had a good feeling, since some of my good Yelp friends spotted it open for business weeks ago. And low and behold! On Sunday, April 2nd, Golden Gate Bakery was open, alive, and well. After finally finding parking at a parking structure (I gave up...), we made it to the end of the line. 

To be honest, I thought there would be an insane line that wrapped around the street for these egg tarts, but there was a much smaller line out the door. Don't be deceived though because customers will take FOREVER to order. Since this place is only open once in a lifetime, people will try to buy everything. It took us maybe 30-40 minutes to finally reach the front. And although we were scared they'd run out of egg tarts, we ordered two fresh ones. 

And how were these egg tarts? Let's just end my review here and say that they were "Omg, I'd drive two hours for this" good! For $1.95 each, you get a GIANT piece of egg tart that is smoking hot. Have some napkins/gloves ready because these things are hot, hot, hot. After letting it cool a bit, we chomped down into a delicious, flaky, and soft egg tart. It was definitely the best egg tart I have ever had. Unlike most egg tarts you get at Chinese togo shops or at dim sum restaurants, this one wasn't stale, it wasn't cold, nor was it rough to the taste. This was one smooth and soft. I loved it, and the only regrets I had were that we ate them too fast and that we didn't order more/anything else.

Golden Gate Bakery is a must, even if it might take several tries to get in and wait in line. 

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
I've gone most of my life without having tried an egg tart. In fact, I tried my first one just last year and it was from a small forgettable bakery. I couldn't say if I liked it or not at the time so I simply forgot that egg tarts even existed. Fast forward a few months and we found ourselves in San Francisco. It was only by chance that we had just eaten lunch at a restaurant right across from Golden Gate Bakery and sheer luck that they were open at this time. The line intrigued us enough to walk over and wait for these little custard filled treats. Now, the line does move somewhat slow. The bakery is tiny and everyone is ordering these egg tarts and it looked like by the dozen. We waited about 45 minutes for our dozen. 

We got them hot and tried one right away. This was my husband's first egg tart and he didn't really like the flavor of the tarts (no fault to the bakery, he just didn't like tasting eggs in a dessert form). I also admit that when I tried it hot, I didn't like it all that much. However, I tried it again after it had cooled down and I found the tart to be absolutely delightful. It was so soft, and the tart was just so flaky and it was absolutely delicious. The right amount of sweetness also and that custard was just so smooth and divine. I loved them. My only gripe with Golden Gate Bakery is the price. They're pricey at almost $2 each! Still, if you really enjoy egg tarts I think it might be worth it to try Golden Gate Bakery. They certainly were worth the wait for me. 4/5
author: Michelle L.

description:
A hit-or miss bakery. When I say hit-or-miss, I mean it literally - either it's open or not. I never heard of a place that opens whenever it wants. This bakery is known to go on vacations for an indefinite amount of time, and no one really knows when this "vacation" ends. For me, the chance they will open is 20%; I have been here 5 times and they opened only once. In addition, on days when they are open, you really don't know exactly when they open. Their official opening time is at 8am, but it could be any time. I got 10:30am two times, one for Chinese New Year Parade and one on 4/7/17. That is the store. 

The food. I only had the egg custards, and they are pretty good. They are the best I ever had, especially when it's out of the oven (really early or late afternoon). They have flakey crusts and they just melt in your mouth. Kinda pricey ($2) but it's okay (store hours not okay). 

The service. They are typical rude Chinese. Enough said. 

I might have given this place five stars, but this business is not dependable in terms of store hours. I always get disappointed when I go up the hill in Chinatown to find that the store is not open or they changed their hours. I had these egg tarts once two years ago, and I really wanted to try them again before I leave the Bay Area. I succeeded finally (success rate was 20%). Now I can forget about this bakery. 

Everyone should try this place at least once.
author: Jessica C.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Are the egg tarts good? Yes. Are they out of this world, must try, delicious??? Meh.

I've eaten my fair share of egg tarts and used to visit Golden Gate Bakery as a kid, walking out of the store with handfuls of pink boxes.

My biggest gripe with this place is their lack of consistency in when they open. They literally open when they feel like it. 

The egg tarts are 1.95 each, $23.40 for a dozen. You will not get a discount for buying more.

They come out piping hot and the crust is my favorite part. So flakey and delicious. I prefer eating mine while they're a bit cooled down, as you can get a better taste of the custard without burning your mouth.

Overall, I'd come and get an egg tart or two if I'm in the area, but I won't come to SF Chinatown just for them (50% of the time, they will be closed).
author: Shirley H.

description: Best place for egg tarts! Check the website to see if it's open before going and expect to wait in line
author: Sarafina S.

description: Every time I come to San Francisco I attempt to stop by but they must have been closed for a while. Very good bakery, the egg tarts are delicious. The only thing is the bakery items are mostly in the window so if you're ordering on the farther side of the counter it's a little hard to order if you don't know the names of some of the items. It would be nice if the items were displayed in front of you instead & more clearly labeled.
author: Buenafe S.

description: Went there a month ago after the San Francisco marathon.   The wait was a little long but live their custard and the sesame balls
author: Gil M.

description:
The best egg custard that I've ever tasted ! Although it's pricey it's $25.80 per dozen . I guess because it's too butter on the custard but anyway it's the best so far!

I bought a Mochi ( red bean inside ) it's good too , it's a little bit pricey $2.15 each. 
Overall it's so good ! Ill recommend this place for sure.
author: Nicaida C.

description:
I hate to be /that/ person, but this place was just okay.

Came here on the recommendation of a friend who said its a must stop in SF on a Sunday afternoon. We got in line, while the rest of our group went on to the daunting task of finding parking. It took 30 minutes for them to find parking, and we were in line for 1 hour total.

When we were finally served, we ordered 1 dozen egg tarts. Cash only. The tarts were nice and warm, the crust was flaky, and the custard was creamy.

Was it good? Yeah. Was it worth the wait? Hell no.

Personally, I think this place is all hype. I don't think it would have been such a long wait if they were well-staffed and had a more efficient system in place. I guess if you took an uber and you came early it wouldn't be so bad, but I mean, it's just a dang egg tart. I just don't think it's worth the trouble.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Almost a hour on a Saturday!!!!! I've never waited this long for egg tarts. I have, however, waited for Portuguese egg tarts from 85 for 15 minutes. But this was suppose to be life changing egg tarts from this part of the world. So I left my kids with my husband and was determined to have my life changed. 

No lives were changed in this story. Even my kids who can eat an egg tart by themselves, took a bite and wanted nothing to do with it but to throw it back in my face and said, "No, thank you, mama!" Now, I have to give them credit, the egg tart was fresh out of the oven. This was demonstrated by how hot my lap got after just 5 minutes of having the box of egg tarts sit on top of it. But the crust was burnt, and the egg itself just okay. I find myself, chewing, and waiting for the "ah-ha! There it is." moment to justify the time I spent waiting in line. But in the end, I was banging my head on my car door window, wishing that I had listened to my SF Native friend, who told me that it is just a hype.

Also, I am used to Cantonese ladies yelling at each other in solidarity. But these ladies were actually fighting when I was there. They put all their stuff down and was NOT helping customers while yelling about who was supposed to help who. I was hoping to catch a scene where the ladies start throwing egg tarts at each other but the bossman came and told them to go back to helping customers. 1 star for the OK egg tarts and 1 star for the awesome drama.
author: Yuen Tung P.

description: The line sucks and it seems like they choose to be open when they want... cash only but those damn egg tarts are delicious.  Try Mr. Tetsu are a replacement.
author: BENADICK F.

description:
I clearly think this place is OVERHYPED of their egg tarts. 

The first day we decided to explore SF it was closed on vacation. I have heard that they do close whenever they FEEL LIKE IT. 
Then on the 2nd to last day we decided to check the place out and it was opened, however they didn't let ANY customers inside the bakery. All the customers were lined outside the bakery and only the workers were allowed to go in. I heard we were only allowed to buy a dozen of egg tarts since they were limited in supply. So we waited around 15-20 minutes and we finally got it. 

After we found out my sister found like those metal things that they scrub with to wash dishes on the egg tarts. NOT HYGIENIC once again.. 

As for the egg tarts, it just tasted like any other egg tart to me.. It is big, but I don't see the hype to it..
author: Susan L.

description:
The first time I went to SF, I stumbled upon this place on accident. There was a line but it was a bakery so i thought, why not? Welp...Best egg tarts, always worth the wait. Come back every time I've been to SF.

**CASH ONLY**
author: Perla G.

description: The few times I've been here, there has been massive lines. But they are worth the wait, the egg tarts are bomb! So wear your comfortable shoes.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Deducting a star because this place is so unpredictable. Between my roommates and I, there have been too many occasions in which we've shown up only to be greeted by a small "closed" sign or a line out the door and news that they didn't have any egg tarts that day.

So when you finally show up on a lucky day when they're both open and selling egg tarts, there is already a reason to celebrate. And there is only more rejoicing after you bite into the egg tarts-- the crust is fresh and soooo flaky, and the egg is sweetened with just the right amount of sugar. At around $2 each it is a bit pricey for Asian desserts, but compared to what I get at coffee shops and other bakeries around the city, I'd say it's still a steal.
author: Amy C.

description: DONT READ THE REVIEW, go line up and try it. It's amazing!!! There's a reason all these years there's a line out there and it only gets longer and longer. I haven't travel the whole world yet, but as of now it's the best egg tart I ever had in my life and in the lives of everyone I bought for. Took one star off due to its price, I know I said it's he best ever, but could be cheaper. That's just the Asian in me being cheap. MUST GO MUST TRY MUST HAVE!!
author: J W.

description: Front parking and fresh out of the oven egg tarts!!!!! Must try when you're in the area.
author: Camille D.

description:
The last time I had eggtarts from this place was 10 years ago. Back then, I did not have much of a tasting pallet so i thought everything tasted good. I didn't think this place had better eggtarts than other places especially if it is double the price.

A decade has passed and I have been wanting to revisit to see if it really lives off the hype and I have been admiring food a lot more. I pass by this place pretty often whenever I visit my grandparents but there is always a line or they are closed for vacation. 

Today I walked by around 4:30pm on a rainy day and not only was it open, there was no line!! I walked in and there is a huge sign that says Eggtarts are $1.95/each since most people order that. I was so happy and I ordered 4 eggtarts and brought it with me to eat at my grandparents. It was piping hot when I ate it about 20 mins later. Honestly, the crust was so flaky and the custard was soft and a tad bit creamy. The flake doesn't fall off and creates a mess.

I noticed they sell a few selected items such as mooncake, cha siew tarts, eggtarts, and a few more but options for other items is definitely not huge.

I can now say I know how eggtarts from Golden Gate Bakery finally tastes like! It really is good, but still I would not wait in line for it since I can get eggtarts from other bakeries in Chinatown for much cheaper.
author: Allie Y.

description:
Have to say their egg tarts are the best I have ever tasted, either in states or in china. Minus one star given it's always closed.
My advice always call the place before you go! And when you do go, order only egg tarts! In my opinion sesame ball and coconut tarts are only mediocre.
author: Feifei X.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS!!!!

They are always closed when I come (I'm from out of state). Finally, by the fifth time they are opened...with a long line. The egg tarts are freshly baked, one batch at a time, that's why the line moves a little slow. I tried the other pastries and they were pretty bad. I guess I don't recommend anything else but the egg tarts. 5 stars for the egg tarts and egg tarts only. 

Cash only!!
author: Nga N.

description:
They are back and the line is long as usual! Waited 20 minutes but well worth it. $1.95 per egg tart now. Cash only. They give you a box if you order enough (I got 6). The silkiest egg tart in the US. Not too sweet. Join the line and you won't regret it.

They also have other items like sesame balls and sweet rice pancakes but I have not tried them.
author: Norases V.

description:
This is as tasty and as fresh as you are ever gonna get for egg tarts. This bakery is manned by a woman who would open the door, take your order, and then arrives back 15 mins or so...and this is before waiting in line for 1 hour and 30 mins (that's how long we waited for). Times will vary though. The whole experience is unique and some may question if it's all worth it for an egg tart and I would say, "do you have anything better to do?"

Go for: perfect egg tarts

Don't go for: if you have a life and can't wait around for egg tarts
author: John V.

description: I waited in line for about 30 minutes to get their freshly baked egg tart. It was worth it. The crust was perfectly flaky and the warm cream just melted in your mouth. It was heavenly
author: Sana M.

description: As a native in SF, they've always made the best egg custard tarts. They deliver the same hot, fresh product as it was made back then. They go on weeks long vacation between July and August and some occasional days that they just don't need to be open for business. Expect to wait for a long time, expect at least 1 hour or more to get into the store. The reason why they're 4 stars is that their prices have surged so high now.. $2.25 each making that a whopping $27 for 1 dozen. Quite a splurge for these little gems.. enjoy!
author: Lauren L.

description:
What a fun experience! Waited in the rain for an hour. They opened at 10 am (although Yelp and the sign said 8 am). Glad I didn't jog from our hotel that am! 

2 elderly Chinese ladies. Fresh, hot, amazing, flakey custard tarts. $1.95 each. The real deal! The guy in front of us ordered 6 doz to take to LA. Most of the other customers were from So Cal, a few locals. Fun atmosphere and super fresh. 

The coconut tarts were good too! Order more than you think you'll eat. Why? Cause you waited in line! Truly something that makes SF special... 

Cash only.
author: Lisa B.

description:
So this place was rockin' on a weekend with the line out the door and plenty more lining up. The lemming effect? Quite possibly. But with Yelp reviews this good, it was worth a try!

The 20ft line overall takes about 30-40min, so holding a bike in that time is rather awkward while old Asian ladies allure you to get a few extra egg tarts for them so they don't have to wait in line. I call it good karma, they probably call it "young sucker who had to wait in line but I convinced him to get me my order for free". Flip a coin, right?

So while waiting in line, there is a window display that shows off some other pastries, and by the halo effect, if their egg tarts are that good, then everything they make should be amazing too right? 

Of course, I have no idea what they're called other than "sesame seed covered ball" and "crispy looking thing." I'm sure when you get there, you'll know exactly what I'm referring to.

(Except if you're legit Asian. Then you probably know the actual names to these delicacies and are shaking your head in shame. Sorry I call it as it is.)

In the end, bring your cash and at least try the egg tarts! They are definitely really really good - just the right amount of sweetness and egg-iness to combine into a delectable treat! I don't know if I'd stand in line for 30-40 min again with a bike, but if there isn't a line and I feel like ruining my diet for a week, this is the perfect place to be!
author: Greg G.

description:
After trying to come here 3 separate times when I'm up in SF, I saw that this place had a sign that says "open tomorrow at 10:30". I went back the next morning and waited there an hour before open. Guess what? It was totally worth it! Egg tarts were so delicious when they're warm!
