The lady who sold me told me to start eating it right as I paid. Very nice lady that was excited to have me try it. She looks very Chinese but spoke english just fine! They're not cheap but since it's kind of hard to get, I got a dozen for friends/family.

Huge line though behind me. And I walked by this place a few times during this particular stay and the lines were always long. So be prepared to wait. But also just do it at least once. With coffee is also amazing.
author: Ming C.

description:
This place is home to the best egg tarts in San Francisco! My family has been getting egg tarts from here for as long as I can remember. What makes the egg tarts here so amazing is the perfect balance of soft egg-iness and sweetness in the center custard and the perfect flaky crust of the outside. The crust on the outside is like a croissant but still sturdy enough to hold the tart together. The egg tarts are a good size, about the size of my palm or maybe the diameter of a normal sized wine bottle. While $2.25 may seem expensive for an egg tart, it is definitely worth it. 

I came in recently while showing some of my SoCal friends around San Francisco on a Monday night. Even though it was about 6pm on a Monday night there was still a 15 minute wait - but don't be deterred the egg tarts are worth the wait. They make them continuously throughout the day so they're as fresh as can be. If you are making a big order, they may make you leave and come back to pick it up a little later (we came back in 30 minutes) but you can just leave and walk around Grant St while you wait. The two ladies running the shop are very nice and speak Cantonese and English. When ordering a whole box, they will cut out the corners of the top box to let out the steam from the fresh tarts to prevent the flaky crust from getting soggy. I usually order a box at a time and eat them as snacks over a day or two. As long as you keep them in air tight containers once cooled, they'll still be good to eat the next day. My friends that were visiting definitely loved this place and found themselves even craving the egg tarts from here towards the end of the trip.
author: Evelyn L.

description:
Came here last night around 8:30PM just as they were closing. One of my buddies was visiting and he told me he always wanted to go to Golden Gate Bakery (GGB) but could never go since GGB would always be on vacation. We had been walking along Grant Avenue, and by luck, the lights were on inside with just a few people waiting in line (all waiting for egg tarts, which were baking in the oven).

Since my last review, egg tarts have gone up in price, from $1.60 to $1.95 per egg tart. Years ago, these egg tarts were less than a dollar each! Inflation? Tourist prices? Go figure. 

Is it worth the high price tag and wait? Sort of. The line can be pretty annoying but honestly, I haven't had egg tarts as good as the ones here elsewhere in San Francisco. The egg tart's crust is flakey and not too thick -- while the custard has a soft, milky, buttery, melt-in-your mouth texture that is absolutely amazing! I would probably recommend visiting GGB at off hours (like close to closing) than during peak hours (such as around lunch time). Visiting GGB during off hours to purchase your egg tarts will make your experience much more pleasant.

Even though GGB is a tourist hot spot, it's also popular among locals like myself. If you haven't been here before, it's definitely worth a try. Come sooner than later, before they hike up the prices again.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I've been here many times and have never been disappointed. I love egg custards, and nothing beats burning your tongue on piping hot custard! Due to its popularity and turn over, you can count on your custard being only a few minutes out of the oven. After waiting in line for 20+ minutes, you'll want to order at least a dozen. I've also had their mochi, sesame balls, and macaroons. All equally delicious! 

Tip: don't close your plastic bag - the custards are so hot their steam will cause significant condensation!

My only complaint is that the line is always long and you can never count on them to be open.
author: Vivian N.

description:
Whenever i'm in the neighborhood (which is not much lol), I make an effort to come here. I would be fearful coming to Chinatown JUST for these because the workers are known to go "on vacation" a lot.. Aka they just put the sign up and have the day off LOL. 

The most recent time i've come here, they had the vacation sign up, but they were still inside, taking orders one by one, going down the line outside, and fulfilling those orders one by one. It actually wasn't too bad of a wait because no one knew they were open!

Now onto those famous dan tats... They are amazing! They come out hot, the inside perfectly creamy and sweet, and the outside perfectly flakey. They are a bit expensive (around $1.50 each), but are a really good treat if you're around the area.
author: Tara A.

description:
NOT WORTH THE WAIT. The custard tart has strong egg flavor/taste.
The shop is not very clean. 
Workers are very slow.
NOT IMPRESSED.
author: M A.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery, the home of the famous egg tart that comes with a one hour wait in line. Is it really worth the one hour wait? Sure, its actually very good. But you know what, you best not go around 6pm on a weekend. You know why? Because they have a fear of running out of the egg tarts, and they start rationing the egg tarts, as in only two per customer,as in I was deprived of this golden goodness.

I give a 4 because of the wait, and this rationing, otherwise the egg tart would justify a 5 by itself.
author: Raymond H.

description: Reputation for best egg custard tarts is well earned. Wow, these were fantastic. Give yourself the treat of time to really savor these. The delicate and delicious filling, the buttery flaky pastry shell. I also love sesame balls and the ones here are enormous and excellent. Wonderful texture and flavor (and I assume high calorie count!). Expect to wait 15-30min even on a weekday, but it is worth it and the counter ladies do speak English and you can chat in line with other patrons.
author: Amy B.

description:
The really good thing about this place is they have fresh egg tarts.  95% of the time the egg tarts come straight out of the oven. 

* $1.95 for an egg tart.  No discount if you order one dozen (Now you don't need to do the math and figure that out. =P )  . 
* Really limited selection of bakeries. But everything they have is good.  I tried their coconut cookies, coconut pie, banana sticky cake and more.
* They don't have fixed business hours.  There were times that I went there and they were closed.
author: Rachael C.

description:
Wow! What a line...While we went on the day of Chinese New Year Festival celebrations in the city, we thought the line looked pretty short. We realized it wrapped around the block, but figured it wouldn't take more than 30-40 minutes. It took us 1 hr 15 min to get in! I expected that to be the case but was still pretty surprised it took so long. 

Wait aside, the egg tarts were delicious and definitely worth trying! They edge on the sugary sweet side but are delicious when warm. I probably won't wait another 1+ hr for them again, but I did enjoy having them that day. I'd recommend giving it a try if the line looks reasonably short!
author: Cindy S.

description:
Some people call them "Don Tot" or "dahn taht" in Chinese. For today and for this place, I will call them DARN TART !

We drove by and saw a long line. My gal pal, Yuri, waited in her car, acting like she was going to pull into a space on the street around the corner. I ran to the shop to stand in line and made sure that I was in the correct line on the right side of the door. The people in front of me had called in their order, so I immediately called to place my order. The lady who answered the phone seemed preoccupied. I looked in the window and saw them boxing up some of the goods. Listening to the people in line, I learned that the shop is actually on vacation and they came in today to do a large special order. We were lucky that they were answering the phone and taking names. The lady at the door told us that they don't usually do this and not to tell others....so, shhhh... mum's the word!  (Wink, wink)  ;)

Somehow, my phone call to her ended,  so I called again. I told her that my name was "Luk" and used the best Chinese accent that I had. I told her I just spoke with her and she had asked me how many I wanted. She asked me for what time. When I said, "now", she said that I would have to wait. I said. "Yeah, yeah! (Using my assertive Chinese accent)". She agreed to a 1:30pm pick up. (20 minutes). (I win)

She came to the door and filled a couple of orders then pointed to me.  I knew what she wanted.  I told her that I just spoke to her. She said, "I told you wait"!  I replied, "I am!"  Then she nodded (understanding that she is speaking to another Chinese woman) and directed me to the other line on the left side of the door. (I win)

I'm not the rudest Chinese woman on this earth, but I know that game.  When you try to cut in line and speak Chinese... hey!  I'm not deaf!  So I had to speak (in my loud Chinese accent) that I was here first.  That woman behind me was smart. ..she backed off!  (I win)  Plus, the lady at the door saw my $21 cash in my hand so she took it. (That's a good sign that I'm getting closer to my goal!)

Finally, she came back with a pink box!  It was tied with white plastic string and 2 corners of the box were cut open to vent the steam. ..nice!  She placed the box in my hands and I carried my trophy to the car!  We brought our gift to my cousin's house where we relayed this tale of victory and glory!  (We win!)

Conclusion: is it worth all of the hassle? Definitely! The crust is on the thinner, crisper side. The custard is moist and "just right" sweet. These egg tarts are on the larger side and better quality, so they cost a bit more. However, it's better to consume them while they are fresh and warm...  So good!  

If you need help,  just bring me with you...hahaha!  It's fun!  I promise not to hurt anyone. .. LOL!
author: Nadine C.

description: This place is amazing.....if you're able to catch them when their open.  I've been to Macau and I've had the Portuguese egg tarts from lord stow's and Margaret's cafe e Nata and the egg tarts at golden bakery are a little different but delicious none the less.  Unfortunately it seems like their always closed whenever I make it down to SF.  If you're ever in SF definitely make a trip to see if their open.  They are so worth it.  The custard is flavored just right.  You can't get good egg tarts like this other than in Macau.
author: Cristina N.

description:
- CASH ONLY-

OMG, the food gods have finally graced me with an OPEN sign in the front window. Granted I always assumed this place was a tourist trap, but the curiosity in me urged me to give this a shot anyways. 

Stopping by on a Saturday afternoon around 2pm, I saw a semi-long line wrapping around the front of the store. 30 minutes later, I was wondering why it was moving so slow so I peaked inside to see that there were only 2 people working, a grandma and grandpa (i'm just assuming this) who were constantly churning out egg tarts because they keep selling out immediately. By the way, these suckers aren't cheap - they come at about $2 per tart so that's pretty much double the average cost of one, but whatever.

I ended up getting about 5 egg tarts and one coconut one just to try and omfg these were easily the best egg tarts that i've ever had. EAT IT WHILE IT'S HOT, I promise that you won't regret it (unless you burn yourself, but that's not my problem). The crust is super flakey and warm while the custard is still soft and creamy. 

I need more...
author: Wiseley F.

description: I came here one day to see the line about two sections long folding in on itself but looking to be about 15-20 people. It didn't look too bad. But I overheard people in line saying they waited an hour. That's legit how long it took to order $1.95 egg tarts. Were they life-changing? No. They were really good. Baked fresh, I got the first of a fresh batch and they slit open the box to air out the tarts. Pro tip: let them rest for a while because they solidify and the flavor intensifies. While piping hot, it kinda tastes like steamed egg, more eggy and less sweet. Would I get this again? Only if I didn't have to wait in line. While they're good, they're definitely not the best I've tried.
author: Sarina J.

description:
Can't beat a hot and fresh Dan Tat. When visiting SF i guess its a must to visit SF's chinatown and head down to the golden gate bakery for the most delicious egg tart on the west coast. Now when you get here the line will be down the block and you don't just order one or two egg tarts, people here order them by the dozen.  

I came here with SO with the intention of just getting 2 egg tarts to try but realized that it might be kinda annoying to wait so long just for two egg tarts... so we decided to ask those who bought a dozen to see if they could sell us two. Luckily we found someone and they were very nice to sell us two!

For the egg tart: perfectly golden crust that doesn't fall apart or flake easily. The egg custard itself is perfect. Slight eggy taste but the perfect sweetness and creamy texture. Its so fresh and hot that once you bite it the egg filling will melt and the crust mixes perfectly with it. We were almost angry that we didn't get a dozen. 

If you come to SF, get to chinatown, wait in line, and get your self a dozen of these egg tarts. you won't find this kinda of egg tart else where.
author: Vincent T.

description: The line is very long but the wait is worth it if you are a fan of egg tarts....the food is very...the egg tarts were a little thick for me but very tastey
author: Amar W.

description: Post Chinatown dim sum, I happened to pass Golden Gate Bakery right after it opened. There was already a line. I waited 30 minutes. With people who don't give personal space. But the egg tarts were -so- -good-. Delicate, not to sweet, freshly baked flakiness. I wish I bought more. The ladies at the counter will talk up some of their other baked goods while you wait, and you'll probably order some of those, too. Just do it. Don't forget your cash.
author: Angela C.

description:
It was Chinese New Years and what better way to celebrate than to go to Chinatown and see if the legendary Golden Gate Bakery was open for us to snag some egg tarts? They're known to close and go on vacation pretty often so we were hoping for a miracle haha. Walking through Chinatown on Chinese New Years felt a lot like walking through a war zone, with firecrackers going off left and right, but when we finally got to the bakery it was open!!! And then we wait....for a hour. 

BUT, definitely the best egg tart I've ever had. The reason it takes so long is cause they keep making fresh batches and so good when its hot and right out of the oven! The inside is so soft and sweet and the outside is so flakey, it's the perfect combination!

Also, cash-only and each egg tart is $1.95. They also sell other Asian sweets and pastries inside!
author: Jingxi Z.

description: Came back for a revisit because my friends and I crave them on a regular basis. They are closed for 3 weeks for vacation from 5/3.
author: Xi K.

description: My boyfriend and I came here on a Saturday afternoon. The wait was pretty long but the egg tarts are most definitely worth it. They're buttery, crispy, and the egg filling is light and fluffy. Contrary to what I read in some reviews, the two ladies working were super nice. I have yet to try their other desserts, but I'll be back soon anyway!
author: Steph W.

description: I've heard that the previous owner was apparently better.  I wish I could have tried that because if it was better I can't really imagine how good it must have been.  As it is, we bought 8 for the 4 of us thinking 2 each should be more than enough.  Big mistake.  We went right back and got in line and bought 12 more
author: John C.

description: Come here for the egg tarts, and be prepared to wait in line and pay with cash. Authentic, a bit pricy but so worth!
author: Chelsea W.

description: WTF came here back to back Saturday and Sunday and no egg tarts both days because they were too busy making moon cakes for moon festival -.-
author: Majes W.

description: Considered myself bless because my friend and I only waited in line for less than 5 minutes. First time trying Golden Gate Bakery and they sold me. Trays of egg tarts came warm from downstairs and the lady put it in a pink box and cut it up to let the air out. Once we left the shop, I couldn't resist and popped one of these egg tarts in my mouth. The most delectable delicious things I've tasted in the name of egg tarts!!
author: William T.

description:
Yes the hype is worth the wait and unusual hours. My fellow yelper commented that only other place can compete is from Macau/Hong Kong. 

Do call them ahead to confirm their hour and to reserve yourself come Egg Tart. I was lucky to call ahead because coming half and hour later the restaurant owner told everyone else in line that they were out of luck. In addition their hours can vary so its definitely important to call ahead. 

Waiting in line kind of remind me of an episode of Seinfeld with the Soup Nazi. People line down the street just to be told in the end that they ran out. When you get to the front (Ignore the sign "We are closed for Vacation") they would just crack open the door, ask for your name, then bring your order then close the door again.  

Just getting my two Golden Egg Tarts felt like winning the Golden Ticket. And the taste was awesome. Nothing better than piping hot Egg Tart that has the flakiness and sweetness.
author: Bryant N.

description: Best egg tarts I've had in North America!  We had it hot and fresh right out of the oven and they were to die for!
author: Winnie L.

description: Drove by two days in a row in hopes they would open and they did! I had a friend stand in line for me while I double parked (not recommended!) but the wait wasn't too bad (10min). Our egg tarts were fresh out the oven and looked perfect. With just one bite, I knew the egg tart would be life changing. The crust was flaky but not to the point where it will just crumble all over your clothes and slightly sweetened. But the most amazing part was the egg custard. It was soft and sweet and consistent in texture all throughout; it was jiggly and light, not dense like some places, and it had the right egg taste balanced with the perfect amount of sugar. These egg tarts were hands down the best egg tarts I've ever had in my life!!!
author: Judy M.

description:
JUST A-OK. I don't understand the hype. The egg tarts are good but not worth waiting in line for. I came here because my SoCal friends wanted to go. Luckily there wasn't a line when we went. They are often closed at random times of the year for vacation so I recommend calling before you go!

Egg tarts are $1.95 each (kind of pricey) It's really fresh and steamy. Custard was moist but a little too liquidly. Could be better. Honestly, any fresh out of the oven egg tarts would taste good.

This place is not very clean or hygienic. When I first took a bite into my egg tart, it had this smelly towel scent, which made me gag... I would not be coming back
author: Angelyn S.

description:
We picked up a fried mochi ball with black bean paste, a moon cake and an egg tart. The egg tart came right out of the oven. We literally left the store, and right outside we took our first bite. They let off steam. 

I don't particularly care for egg tarts. These are well made, and are fairly large. The wobbly center is very delicate and light. It was fun to eat, but I only ate a third of it, had my boyfriend take two bites, and then gave it to my friend who scarfed it down relatively quickly. 

The egg custard just isn't my thing. I'm glad I went to try it, but I don't think I'll wait 30+ minutes in the rain for this again. Not any time soon. 

Now that giant fried mochi ball. :D I thoroughly enjoyed. It was chewy, had just enough black bean paste to make it interesting (I don't really like too much) and was so big, it didn't leave me wishing I got a second one.
author: Tiffany W.

description: Super yummy egg tarts!!  Especially good when it comes out fresh and hot!  Finally made it here and line was not too long - it's a long line because they bake them in small batches and don't mass produce to cheapen quality.  I can't believe the 2 guys in front of me ordered 3 dozens each!! That's what held up the line and it's that good!  The ladies (owners) are egg tart nazis haha - not so pleasant but who cares!
author: Kate C.

description:
With the way people line up for this place, you'd think you were lining up for gold. Or a Powerball lottery ticket. 
 
But to be honest - yes. Yes, these egg tarts are just as good as gold. When they hit your taste buds, you'll understand why. 

As a tourist in San Francisco, I arrived on a Saturday around 5:00 PM and the lineup was pretty long. I ended up waiting around 40 minutes until I finally reached the front of the line. Not a bad wait - people-watching in Chinatown isn't the worst exercise in the world. I ordered a dozen of their famous egg tarts and a couple of moon cakes, as that was all they had left. Honestly, best egg tarts I've ever had. Buttery, flaky, sweet (but not overtly), and not too eggy (I hate eggy egg tarts). Overall, the perfect formulation. The moon cakes were additionally super flavourful, flaky, with just the right amount of sweetness. I can't tell you how glad I was to have had the chance to come by this place and sample their products - affordable, freshly baked, and highly recommended.

For a dozen egg tarts and a couple of moon cakes, my total came to a little less than $20.00.
author: Barbara D.

description: I have to say they have the best egg custards, however, they are never open for us to get them. We called on Weds to see if they would be open the next day. They said they should be open. We called the next morning but they didn't pick up,which was our mistake. We drove 50 Minutes to get there, And arrived at 10 am, the sign on the door stated they would open at 12. They are suppose to open at 8am. Not sure they ever opened that day. This is the third time we have tried getting their egg custards. It has been so long since we have eaten them, so we are not sure if they are still as good as we remember!
author: Janis M.

description:
What can I say? After numerous visits so far since the 1990s, I'm totally in awe for this local Chinese bakery located at Chinatown in San Francisco. Golden Gate Bakery delivers some amazing, authentic baked goods that it's fresh from the oven! Of course, it's the most popular spot for residents and tourists alike despite the long lines by waiting for this popular signature item: the Egg Tart! The concept is much smaller, but it has the natural, classic modern design inside despite the plain blue background.

The employees and bakers are doing an excellent job here for making the customers like me especially my parents a friendly service! No cons at all!

As I mentioned earlier for the Egg Tart, that Tart as I ate tasted outstandingly good! It's flaky and eatable to chew! Much flavorful than any Chinese bakeries here! Besides the Egg Tart, I tasted the plain buns too, and it tasted not bad after my first bite! What a great dessert or snack meal!

Parking can be difficult to park, you can park at the nearest surface street parking nor the garage if it's available. Otherwise, you can ride a bike, walk, or use public transportation easier without the hassles.

Sometimes, this bakery has vacation offs during the spring break, summer break, Thanksgiving break, and Christmas break especially Chinese New Years, so be aware to avoid these holiday peek by going to non holiday peek times as possible.

In the end, Golden Gate Bakery is the most outstanding local Chinese bakery right in the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown. A well, worthy visit! My rating: 4 solid stars!
author: William L.

description:
It was good, not great. These are not the Portuguese (charred-creme brûlée like) egg tarts. They were not open til 12:10pm on a Saturday, not sure why their hours say 7am. Strange!

What's good is that it's served fresh out of the oven with the yolk being moist and the tart being crisp. For $2 each tart, it better be above average, which it is. If you really love egg tarts go here, but if they're not your fave, you can bypass this pitstop. I wish they had half the size egg tarts and I'd pay $1 for those.
author: Kristen Q.

description:
The Egg Tarts from Golden Gate Bakery is a gift from the heavens. For only $1.75, these fresh from the oven Egg Tarts is something to die for. I'm serious. I would take a bullet for these little bastards. Shit, I even burnt my mouth eating these the second I left the store. I regret nothing and would do it again.

I'm used to eating Egg Tarts with stale pastry crusts and tasteless custard tart from those Dim Sum carts in OC so you can only imagine the look on my reaction when I bit into GGB's Egg Tart. Both my GF and I were silent on our walk to the Pier as we enjoyed the state of serenity that was washing over us. It was 2 minutes of complete bliss. 

We also had the almond cookies but who cares about that. No one wakes up in the morning thinking "Oh man, you know what I'm craving today from GGB? Some Almond Cookies!". No, get out of here with that. Do yourself a favor treat yourself to a little piece of nirvana. Just don't forget to bring cash!
author: Larry T.

description:
So this is what an egg tart is supposed to taste like!

To be honest, I have never been a huge fan of egg tarts. But that was before I tried the egg tart at the Golden Gate Bakery! The egg tarts here are so fresh! They come out nice and hot and taste like they were just baked from the oven. I only tried the egg tart but they also have all kinds of moon cakes and other pastries.
author: Jenny B.

description:
The pastries are inexpesive and they are delicious. You need to get there early for the pastries. Only thing I didn't like was this place had flies. 

Egg tarts are the best here.
author: Ashi C.

description:
The egg tarts here are a must-try when in SF!!! MAKE SURE TO CALL IN AHEAD to make sure the place is open because they aren't open daily.

They make and serve the tarts fresh and it was really worth the wait (~40 min for us). What's different about them compared to other dim sum places? Well...
- the tarts are extremely fresh, as in they came right out of the oven 
- the egg is 90% of the tart and has a good height 
- they actually taste like EGG!! 
- the crusts are crispy, flaky, and rolled to the perfect thickness 
- the tart is bigger than the ones you get in restaurants 

Tips:
- CASH ONLY
- Call in to make sure the shop is open
- you can place an order IN PERSON and pick it up IN PERSON later (so you don't have to wait in line) 
- a bit pricey ($1.75) but definitely worth it!!! 
- if you are coming on a weekday, come around 5pm
- any other time, be ready to stand in line for 10-30 minutes
author: Wendy F.

description: These eggs tarts definitely cause a lot of hype. I  went on Tuesday and there wasn't a long line. The ladies inside are very nice. The pastry on the tart is nice and flaky but was not a fan of the filling. I  live in Boston and I have my favorite egg tarts there - the ones at Golden gate have a strong eggy taste which I wasn't fond of.  Overall glad I went for the experience but it may not be everyone's favorite
author: Lily Z.

description:
You know when a former hip hop artist turned reality TV subject gives advice that's useful, it's not a good sign.

"Don't, don't, don't, don't, don't
Don't believe da hype!"

That advice should've been taken into consideration before giving up 40 minutes of waiting and $2.15 for each egg custard tart. (aka: "duntats")

Two years ago I would've crowned GGB the "Duntats King," but now they're only an eggshell of itself.  They USED TO have that perfect balance of crust, creamyness, and egg. Nowadays I can only alude the fact that only their crust is perfect, and a perfect crust no matter how perfect, doesn't justify a 40 minute wait AND a $2.15 price tag. On top of that, that "perfect crust" is only applicable when they're fresh out of the oven. In other words, they've become a victim of the Krispy Kreme effect: good when fresh outta the oven or conveyor belt, but later on, "Meeehhh."

My wife who finally tried the duntats here for the first time did say that the duntats were good but not worth the wait. Then she saw the posted price for them. 

"Naw, just try it once and go back to ________ for the duntats. It's not $2.15 each and half hour wait good."

Thank you Golden Gate Bakery for taking all those vacations causing me to look for alternatives. Now that I've found some comparable duntats, I can take a permanent vacation from you!
author: Terrence P.

description: EGG TART - BOMB!!! But be careful when consuming fresh outta the oven - you will burn your mouth. Trust me. I speak from experience. I know it's gonna be hard to wait, but give it a min to cool down before you inhale the tart in one bite :)
author: Brax Z.

description:
Damn, these egg tarts lived up to their expectations. My friend and I were taking pictures around downtown and stopped by to see if they had any egg tarts left and luckily they had plenty! One of the workers warned us that the egg custard is piping hot (even though it didn't look like it in our eyes). Being the idiot that my friend is, he decided to stuff half of it into his mouth. You already know the rest. 

These tarts were large in size while being rich and sweet in custard flavor along with a flakey and buttery exterior. MUST COME BACK FOR MORE.
author: David H.

description:
I love asian bakeries and this one is exceptional. The only reason I can't give it 5 stars is because the line to wait usually insane, there's no parking, the interior is tiny, and their opening days and hours are incredibly random. I've had random ladies in Mountain View come up to me asking about whether the bakery was open today because they saw me holding a Golden Gate Bakery box, and then tell me that I was really lucky.

They're hands down known for their great egg tarts. The custard part is perfect and smooth, the crust is just the right flakiness and it's always baked fresh because they run out. The first time I got these, I had to wait in line for over an hour because some lady in front of me bought 2-3 dozen egg tarts. CRAZY.

They also have a bunch of other pastries, which seem to get bought out at lightning speed too. Honestly, if you can make it to the cash register, just buy whatever your heart desires and stock up for a bit so you can make the wait worth it. 

Everything I've tried tasted good so I don't think there's really anything bad. If so, I'll update my review with what I don't recommend.
author: Wendy D.

description: Cash only and get here early. Worth the wait in line. Seasame balls are huge but decent. The real winner here is the egg custard!
author: Nick C.

description: Dan Tat!!! Egg tarts!! Always a long line even if it short it takes them awhile to freshly bake egg tarts. I want to say they bring up about 30 at a time every 10/15 minutes. I've been there in the weekends, weekdays as they are opening, I've waited from nearly 45 minutes to nearly two hours. You can always ask to have a couple of fresh, hot egg tart before they box them up. Cash only. And they vary in times they open day even month. I've called a few times and sometimes they would only be making mooncakes and no egg tarts.
author: Vanessa T.

description: We came here for an egg tart and waited a good 45 minutes for them.  The line is long and sometimes gets held up by one person buying 10 dozens of eggtarts (no joke). But they are made fresh and the workers are sincere, quick, and hardworking. We tried a raspberry pie too which we equally enjoyed.  The egg tarts are close to $2 and delicious, especially because they are so fresh and warm out the oven!  Go early if you want to beat the line.
author: Dana O.

description: I won't lie the egg tart has a nice flaky texture and an interestingly good custard. It was my first time trying it after passing by it many times whenever I'm in Chinatown. Would I go back? Definitely no because the price does not seem reasonable for worth going back and the lines are way too long. I rather go back to my regular since childhood egg tart bakery in Chinatown (Garden Bakery) even though it isn't as good as GG but filling to egg tart cravings.
author: M W.

description: I waited in line for over an hour just to even get in the store. Then, they apparently ran out of the famous tarts and so they would only allow one tart per person for the rest of the line. After I was finally able to get my food I tried it and I honestly did not think it was anything special.  The tart was decent at best so I'm actually happy I was only able to get one. The cookie was very doughy and not impressive. However, the ham roll was delicious. They do have friendly and funny customer service, I think I may have just been there on an unlucky day.
author: Michael C.

description:
The egg tart tastes amazing when it just get out of oven.  However if you take the 2nd or 3rd one again, it tastes a bit rich.  When it get cold, then it is just ok.  That is why I don't understand why some people in front of me want to buy 20 or 30 of them to bring home.  The long line is due to those people buy 2 whole boxes of them, and the remains people has to wait for the next batch from the oven.

Is it worthy to wait 40 min in line?  Maybe yes for the first time just for my curiosity.  However I would not waste my time again if the wait is this long.
author: Jon W.

description:
At 4pm on a random Monday, the line was still very long.  Bring some entertainment or a friend so time can pass by more quickly.

I got to say, though I was getting frustrated with standing, the egg tarts were absolutely worth it.  Fresh out of the oven and piping hot, I even burned my tongue eating it...but it was one of the best egg tarts I've ever had.  It had an incredibly flaky crust and the egg custard itself was glorious.

Also had the white sugar cake and a blueberry pie, they were good too but the egg tart definitely takes the cake!
author: Diana C.

description: Their egg tarts are not as good as they USED to be. I've found some place else in the city that's even better and cheaper. It's a total rip off here.
author: Annie H.

description:
The five star rating is purely for the egg tarts. I still remember the first time I tried a golden gate bakery dan tat. The crust is so flakey and the egg part of it is just the right amount of sweetness.. man I really miss having them. Probably the best dan tat of my life! 

Unfortunately, I'd have to give the actual business one star only because they're NEVER open. On yelp they have daily operating hours and they never never never stick to them. I get that they're such a popular business and that nothing compares to their egg tarts, but at least have regular business hours so your patrons don't make a trip all the way out to Chinatown just to be disappointed =[  really wish they were more consistent with their hours... guess you just have to be lucky.
author: Kelly S.

description:
I love the egg custard tarts from this bakery...they are just the right amount sweet and the pastry is good and tasty too..I usually buy a dozen whenever I'm here because of two reasons really: a) they are so freakin good and b) this place is open very rarely.
Like I dunno why they are closed so often..sometimes they are closed for like 2 months (last summer), there was a note against the glass saying they will be closed for the next two months and then very often when I'm in the city I have found them to be closed..u have to really be lucky to find them open.
I have trekked their lotus sweet with black bean stuffing and like it too. Also tried but didn't like their sesame fried sweet ball!
author: Roxane V.

description:
Yelp 2017 100 Challenge:
2017 Review 4/100

Eggtarts are definitely good but I'm not sure if they are good enough for the amount of time and effort you will have to put in. 

The wait in the line was about 1hr30mins. (As the other reviews will state) BUT this was after a third attempt. 

I understand that the business is going well and they are making good money, but it is really irresponsible to open and close whenever you feel like it. Even though the closing time says 8pm, our group took an Uber to the shop around 5pm and found it closed. The second day, we called and was told that they would not open at all the next day. The third day, we called and was told that they would open at 10:30am. But when we arrived around then (with the line already formed), the staff said that they would "maybe" open at 11:00am.

It's up to you if you think the hassle is worth it, but for me it is not. Be prepared to wait and attempt more than once.

Tip: Always call before actually going. DONT TRUST THE BUSINESS HOURS ON YELP!
author: Linda S.

description:
Worst thing besides the street parking, is that the schedule is a bit spotty since they don't really have one posted up at the front window, so people are usually left guessing.  Due to the kindness of a old school Chinese stranger they my friend and I know that they were actually taking some small orders today!

SO after all these years living near SF I've finally tried their famous custard tarts and they're definitely very good!  The tarts are a bit pricey at nearly $2 a piece but so far it's one of the best custard to crust ratio I've had yet on this side of the Bay Area!
author: Eric T.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery... Good luck actually getting your egg tarts! I've tried 3 times in the past, two times to find that it's closed, and one time to see a two hour wait and have to leave. I had to wait for almost 1.5 hours this time, but I was determined to try it at least once.

For $2 each, they're honestly reasonably priced egg tarts, and genuinely good. If you are visiting SF and your time here is limited, it might not be a great idea to spend 2 hours here waiting, but should you find yourself some time, you won't regret it!

EGG TARTS: I personally don't like super flakey tart crusts, but these are great. They're flakey without having dozens of layers, and don't get too messy. The egg pudding in the middle is just a perfect level of sweetness, and super soft and tender. It's rich, eggy and has a great texture.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I've waited my entire adult life for this moment...

AND IT WAS WORTH IT.

All the pain (of never having tried),
the anticipation,
the jealousy (when I saw photos of others eating)
the anxiety (will they be closed when I go?!)...

All of it culminated into one giant egg tart-shaped cloud of doubt and determination. Will I ever get to try these famed egg tarts? I MUST.

And I did. We waited in line for a mere 15 minutes and ordered a dozen for the 4 of us. It looked so unassuming but the moment I took a bite, a kaleidoscope of taste burst in my mouth like the culinary equivalent of being on acid...Crispy outside, hot piping creamy inside, slightly sweet egg custard flavor, generous waves of umami rushing into your body, overwhelming your senses...

After three I was done, though. It got a little too much.

Service was actually pretty good, considering it was chinatown. They were actually nice! Price is reasonable as well. Will come back!
author: Pim Y.

description:
BEST egg tarts!! 

Waited in line for 40 minutes to try their famous egg tart. So worth it. Since their egg tarts are so popular, they keep baking trays and trays, so the egg tarts are steaming hot and fresh. The crust was amazingly crispy. The texture was like layers of thin paper, distributed evenly all around, unlike some other egg tart that has a graham cracker/ tart-like crust. The egg was smooth and every bite is so soft, it is heavenly!

I overheard the owner telling some customers that they usually open very late during weekdays, like late afternoon, but they open 'earlier' on weekends. Still, this is not much info to their irregular hours... I really understand why people would wait 30 mins+ for their egg tarts and some people get a few dozens at a time. $1.75 for an egg tart is not cheap, but it is so worth it. I will come back for sure for these egg tarts!!
author: Karen C.

description:
Line can get long. Be prepare to wait in line! They can also be close randomly. 

The egg tart is so good. $2/each. Full of egg! Thin crust. I brought some back to southern cali and had them the next day. Hear it up with and airfryer. Omg! Bomb!
author: Winky L.

description: What more can I say than this place is so Yummy that it's worth the long wait in line for their moon pies!
author: Mike K.

description:
Long wait. Good egg tarts. It's a treat if you're able to get a fresh batch. 

Legend has it that it was even better 10 years ago, but the recipe was lost and the family was able to almost recreate it.
author: Anthony T.

description:
So after coming here for years and years. I decided to repeat the long wait for dahn tat on New Year's day this past weekend.  We waited for 3 long hours with a bunch of annoying and loud kids (college age) behind us.  

I ended up with 6 dahn tat, 2 banana rice rolls, and 6 coconut macaroons. $22.00. 

Well, turns out those dahn tat were tainted, as in very bad.  I had one, and was sick all day on Sunday, on the toilet for most of the day until 5 p.m.  I didn't make the association until later so I ate another one on Sunday, and my friend tried one on Sunday too, and we both ended up having the porcelain god visits on Monday. 

Sorry, but I've got to avoid this place during the holiday seasons... just not worth it.  Ever.
author: Fannie S.

description: Great value egg tart and other Asian pastries in Chinatown.  Due to the popularity, be prepared for long lines and limited food supply.
author: Alfred C.

description:
The egg tarts are the BEST here, you can't find any better tasting one in Chinatown. Generally there is a long line, but it is well worth the wait. 

They tend to go on vacations quite often because they make so much money, so I miss them when they aren't there. 

I haven't really tried anything else but their egg tart except for the macron that is that swirly coconut thing, and it wasn't bad. But it was a little sweet for my preference. 

I generally park at the Plymouth Garage because I walk around Chinatown, but there is also a couple of street parking spots out in front as well. 

Also I'm pretty sure they only take CASH
author: Jean T.

description:
I've been to Golden Gate almost every time we actually manage to make our way up to the City, and there is ALWAYS a line! Are the egg tarts good? Yes...but are they really worth waiting in that super crazy line? I'm not so sure...

I have tried to venture out and get other items since they sell a lot more than just egg tarts, but nothing really jumps out at me. I do agree that they sell some of the best egg tarts in town, but I still am not convinced that it's worth the wait!
author: Cathy W.

description:
Seriously theeee best dan tats, EVER. 

I've tried so, so, many times to come here but they've always been closed. When I saw that they were open yesterday, I sprinted through the streets of Chinatown to the end of the line where I proceeded to wait 20 minutes for my dan tats baked for the gods. 

I tried one right away and it was warm, flakey, custard-y, just perfection. I had a day-old one, room temperature, just now and it was STILL delicious. 

$1.75 for one or $21 for a dozen, it's not actually cheaper if you buy a dozen so don't get confused by the sign. Oh, and their almond cookies are good as well!
author: Laverne N.

description:
5 stars for the egg tarts!!!!!!!

I swear they used to be $1 but now they raised the price to $2 per piece? I could be wrong but thats what the menu said.

Forget all the other baked goods. ONLY GET THE EGG TART IT'S SOOO DELICIOUS.

Don't expect fancy decor and bring yo ca$h. Also, uber/bus to Chinatown cus everywhere is hella cramped!
author: Denise H.

description:
Waiting in line took almost an hour because they kept running out of dan tats but mmm it was so worth it. Their business hours are pretty wonky. I know some days they close at 6 pm but today they closed at 8. Tomorrow I think they said they were closing at 9 pm. The owners are always on vacation; the only thing you can do is visit and pray that it's open. I always see the line out of the door at this place whenever it's open.
The egg tarts themselves are pretty pricey at $1.95 for one and around $24 for a dozen. I got around 18 dan tat, 4 lotus rice cakes, and 2 bags of the striped cookies. Whew RIP wallet. 
Definitely eat the dan tat immediately after you buy it. It's pretty thick(tall? fat?) and filled with custardy goodness. I bit into it when it was still piping hot and it tasted so fresh and amazing. The best dan tat I've ever had. I'm usually not a big fan of the dan tat crust but it was very buttery and flakey. 
I remember a tourist behind me commenting that they had been to the bakery every day for the dan tats. Yes, they're just that good. The two ladies in the front are also friendly, especially if you speak canto.
author: Flora C.

description: We made fortune cookies here and had a blast watching the process. I would recommend going to experience this first hand. It's really cool
author: Ryan M.

description:
As far as egg tarts go, this is as good as it gets!

Yesterday, my friend E sent me a picture of a dozen egg tarts she got from GGB. That picture made the ones I got in Oakland Chinatown look inferior! As if that was not bad enough, she didn't drop any off at my house!! Truthfully, I was jealous, but also happy for her at the same time. Getting one's hands on egg tarts from GGB is like winning the lottery, as the owner goes on vacation and closes the shop often.

It just so happened that I was meeting a couple old friends for dinner tonight in SF Chinatown and I decided to try my luck on scoring me some egg tarts at GGB. I arrived at around 6:00pm and lo and behold, they were opened! I walked in and asked one of the ladies if they still had egg tarts available. She looked around, asked another co-worker, and then looked around some more. I thought to myself that there's no way they would still have egg tarts available at that time. But to my surprise, she was able to fine one last one on a sheet tray! At the same time, a young couple walked in and they also asked for egg tarts. Fearing they would take the last one away from me, I quickly whipped out a $20 bill and handed it to the lady. Had the young couple took that away from me, that would be classified as a robbery and I would have to place them both under arrest!

The egg tart was EXCELLENT! The crust was warm and flaky and the custard was perfect both in taste and texture. The egg tart cost $1.75. For perfection, that's cheap.

And yes, I fired a picture back at E. She was so jealous!!
author: Harvey K.

description: The best egg tarts ever! The crust is SO flaky and the inside is so creamy and soft. Definitely haven't tasted any better ones. You can really tell that they take the time to make the outside so flaky. Definitely worth the wait in line.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
Must call this bakery before making a visit! Sometimes they like to open for business and sometimes they don't. I waited in line for about 20 mins around 1pm on a Friday. 

The egg tarts were fresh and warm. I'm usually not a fan of flaky crusts because they get all over my clothes but their thin and flaky crust held together nicely. The custard was light, creamy, not too egg-y and not too sweet. It was perfect :)
author: Margery W.

description:
Our last stop on our way out of SF was to stop and get some moon cakes at this bakery. The line had been down the block all day but by the time we passed them on the way to our car, it was only a few people deep.

Of course, that also meant they were sold out of many of the flavors that I wanted to try. So we got the lotus with egg yolk and Vicky & Dorothy loved them. I was more ...umm what am I eating. They were tasty but maybe just too exotic for me. 

Would love to try those egg tarts. And I appreciated that the brief descriptions were both in Chinese and English.
author: Jen L.

description: After about a 45 minute wait in line my husband and I were lucky to get our hands on a few fresh out of the oven egg custard tarts on our first try. While they did have a strong egg taste at first, they were also creamy and slightly sweet. The crust was sweet and flaky. We liked them! We also tried a coconut and nut mochi, the texture was a little strange, but the taste was nice.
author: Michelle M.

description: Place is always closed. Have been to SF 3 times in the last year and have tried going all 3 times, and place is always closed. Heard egg tarts are good though.
author: Rose L.

description: Came here 20min after they opened and waited about an hr to get our eggtarts. They are freshly made and brought out in batches, so thats why the wait was long. Personally I dont think it was that special, I feel like I could get the same type of eggtarts in LA(where I live), but dont get me wrong the eggtarts were decent but I probably wouldn't wait in this line again the next time I am in SF
author: Sandy C.

description:
Uh, so I finally tried this place after handful of failed attempts (owners were on long vacation, line was ridiculously long, etc.), and oh my gawd. 

For those who thought this place was just okay, try to get some in their fresh batch when the egg friggn' tart is warm and moist. That's all, and you will change your opinion, I promise. 

I don't even have a pic because I stuffed them all into my face with all four as soon as I got them. 

How do I know this? Because I got two old and two (hot n fresh) ones, and from one to the other, it changed my opinion on them. 

And I is it just me or is the egg/custard tart the best out of the pastries they offer? I nibbled on some of their other offerings, and thought it was all right. Maybe I need to get those pippin hot too... Hmmm
author: Sung Hee P.

description: This was the best place for egg tarts.  With a flagrant coconut aroma and flavor.  Want to give it a try after not having been here in a while, however found the egg tart not that unique anymore.  With the rush of fusion bakery in the Bay Area, this place does not stand out like it used to.  With the line and wait, it might be more of a tourist place now.  At least you get it hot.
author: Tony C.

description:
Best egg tarts I've ever had. First time here, but I've had plenty of egg tarts in the past, and none comes close in comparison. This is basically a commentary of the journey to the egg tart, so skip everything and scroll to the bottom for the actual food review haha. But I feel like the journey is the important part to the destination, so read on if you please XD

We came here on a Saturday night around 6:15pm and spent over an hour waiting in line for these famed egg tarts. Made it just in time before they closed!I mean, we had to see what all the fuss was about XD It was kind of funny (but not really) because the egg tarts came out and semi-constant intervals (i.e. 10-15 minutes for a batch of a few dozen), and so this was the rate and frequency at which the line moved. And then when the person at the front of the line bought like all of them (a few dozen), everybody in the line would stare down the person coming out and be like, "What is that girl/guy gonna do with 2 boxes of egg tarts??" Of course there is no system where 1 person can only buy max 1 dozen - it's a group of Chinese grandmas running the show, I'm thinking probably cash only? At least I assume so (and the grandpa sitting in the chair behind the counter snoring haha).

There felt like some kind of camaraderie while waiting in line haha. Sadly, the people in front of us waited just under an hour and then ended up leaving (why??) and we got our egg tarts soon after. Also another sadly is that one guy with his wife (and baby) who was near the back of the line asked another lady 1-2 people in front of us to buy egg tarts for him. We should have given him a bigger death stare down or like really smh because dude, we're all waiting here. If everybody tries to get somebody in front of them to pay for them to get egg tarts, then there's no point of a line, and nobody lining up will ever get egg tarts! Gotta think Kantian ethics and categorical imperatives here. Actually if I cared enough (or had big enough balls) I might have said something just to prove a point/teach a lesson, but oh wells we were so close to getting our egg tarts that I was like EGG TARTSSSSS more than anything haha.

Anyways, on to happier times. If you look at the face of whoever is at the front, there's always a huge grin on their faces, with excitement at the golden treasures that lie within the pink boxes, and that's precisely how we felt when we placed our order :D

Enough with the commentary. On to the food review. I could honestly just leave it as the egg tarts were darn good.

- Egg tarts: so delicious, you really need to try them for yourself!! I've never had an egg tart with such perfect balance: gooey egg filling (plus it was hot/warm, having just come out of the oven) and a flaky but not super oily crust. I'm definitely coming back again :D 10/10 would wait again. Ok well, waiting always kind of sucks, but it was totally worth it hehe.
author: Joanna C.

description:
Best egg tart I've ever had!

I tried a couple of egg tarts from other places in the area and I was even skeptic myself because the line was so long. I'm so GLAD we waited in line! It was so good!

The only thing is if you come here during the day, the line is soooooo long. I also heard that they're not always open- that you pretty much have to keep checking every day. We got lucky because we came here late at night and didn't wait a long time.

So my advise is try to get here either really early or really late. But then they might not be open (lol). The day we came, yelp hours says they open at 830 but there was a written sign that said, "open today at 10:30 am".
author: Kristie A.

description: My fav Chinese bakery shop in the bay area. Nice people and great bakery...... worth the wait in line.
author: CH C.

description:
I yelped the egg tarts here before we went to SF since I knew we were going to Chinatown. The line is crazy in the morning or maybe it's like that in general it's 1.75 a egg tart. 

I wasn't too much of a fan of the egg tart here since it's too eggy for me I'm more into Portuguese egg tarts but my boyfriend loved them since they were the traditional hong kong style egg tarts. It was nice, flaky, a pretty big size for a egg tart but I'm not a fan of the consistency of egg ratio. 

I would recommend this to people who like the traditional style egg tart.
author: Annie N.

description:
There's always a long line waiting outside, and sometimes they closed for day off or vacation. 
-it's by luck to find a parking in China town. The tiny street is always full of cars. 
-waiting: it's a proximity about 30 minutes waiting. 
-there ladies were inside taking their time to help the customers. 
-there's not much bakery to choose from. But we got the famous egg tarts. It's a palm size egg tart, it's better to eat it hot. But we put it into the oven to heat it up for a minute or two. It's nice and creamy inside. This Cantonese egg tarts are the famous food in San Francisco. 
It's a must try egg tarts from this
author: Karmen S.

description: When I had this for the first time in my first visit to sf. I was thoroughly impressed. I've never tried egg tarts before and these were delicious! Had to buy a box to go!
author: Hoang V.

description:
Okay, I have the wildest story to tell about this place.

Since it was our first time in San Fran, I of course, HAD to check out Chinatown and compare it to what I know back home in NYC. We yelped the highest rated dessert places and this came up and we head over - ONLY to realize the line is halfway down the block! We debated waiting but we had 15 mins to kill so we waited....

The guy behind us was a nice young man from San Bruno, who said a bunch of friends recommended their egg tarts and mooncakes. Both of which, i basically grew up on! 

Another 10 mins roll by and we get anxious. We need to catch a shuttle back to the hotel... so we decide to call an uber and try our luck. Finally we make it inside the store but there is at least 10 people in front of us. It starts to get crazy because they can't make the egg tarts fast enough and they were waiting for a fresh batch. People outside get angry. It gets chaotic. Our uber arrives and my group tries to stall. The uber driver says he'd wait if we got him one. 

More time passes and the ladies up front are yelling to the guys baking it. It's hectic. I finally say, ok just give me some moon cakes and let me get the heck out of here! I mention we came all the way from the  east coast and the woman's like "and you don't want to try our tarts?!" And I'm like "no i do! But my ubers literally about to leave me!" And she screams, "they're ready!!!" And i'm like what?? And she asks how many I need and hands me half a dozen in front of angry customers. I feel reallllllly bad, but also couldn't say no. I paid whatever price she throws at me and dash into the uber. 

Now about these egg tarts...
I've grown up eating millions of these after summer school in NY. My uncles even own a chain of famous bakeries in NY. But wow! Golden gate bakery's tarts changed my life. I was a hero in my group for bringing these back... they melt in your mouth and taste like heaven.

Worth the wait and madness!
author: Lisa C.

description:
I think this place is all hype. LOL 

I bought a dozen egg tarts for $23.40 ? Which it outrageously expensive in my opinion... And for it to have such long lines is kind of ridiculous. I don't think the egg tarts are any special. Keep in mind, I had these egg tarts fresh out the oven. Super hot when I bought them, but I don't think the flavor is anything worth the price or the waiting in line. 

There is also only street parking soo my recommendation is to go with someone and have them drop you off.. since you most likely will be standing in line. 

Overall, don't think they should be charging so much for an egg tart...
author: Christina T.

description: We finally tried this place after all the hoopla surrounding their famous egg tarts. We waited in the line (actually my awesome hubby did) while the kids & I window shopped at the surrounding shops. I think we waited got about 45mins seriously. Ordered a mochi like pancake (it looked good) and 6 egg tarts. Egg tarts are $1.95 each. Ouch! I thought to myself it better be damned good! The verdict?! Damn it was good. It is the best egg tart I've ever had! The crust is flakey almost croissant like and the perfect thickness. The custard divine, perfectly made. It's the bomb. Don't think I'll order another egg tart anywhere else. The wait sucks & it's pricey but delicious! Must try if you're in the area & they're open & the line is not too deep.
author: Jules K.

description:
I was supposed to come here for the infamous egg tarts, but they didn't have any. Instead, they had MOON CAKES! And OMG, they were amazing. I only like the lotus with egg yolk  it was dense, and delicious. It was delicious with coffee or tea, a decadent breakfast. My go to place to buy every year now. 

Reminder to self, go back for the egg tarts. - I've still never had any.

Pro-tip CASH ONLY!
author: Vicky L.

description: This place is CASH ONLY. The egg custard tart tasted like sweetened scrambled eggs to me, but maybe this is only me. It tastes nice but I wished if the egg taste was no that strong. I liked more sweet rice cake (Mochi) and coconut tart. The store from inside is a big mess. I guess that's why they have no photos sign.
author: Mo M.

description: Waited in line for the egg tarts -- and was so worth it. Got sesame roll just to try something else. Wasn't my cup of tea - if you like fried foods - you'll probably like it. I do t eat much fried food so didn't really enjoy. However tarts were remarkable. Lived up to the reviews!
author: Joanne G.

description: Golden gate bakery makes me feel so nostalgic & brings back childhood memories of the dan tat my grandma would make me. The egg tart is crispy, flaky, sweet but not overly sweet, just over all freaking delicious. The lines here seem intimidating but it honestly isn't as bad as it seems. Make sure you eat it right when you get it, it's best when it's still hot. Around $20ish for a dozen which isn't bad, price is reasonable considering the ingredients you have to use to make egg tarts aren't cheap.
author: teresa c.

description: Came here the other day to get egg tarts (obviously).  The opening times on all websites say 8am, but when I got there at 8:30am they wouldn't let me in and said they only opened at noon thirty.  Someone change the availability hours to accurately depict the hours.
author: Craig V.

description:
Get ready to stand in line. Watch out for those who will blatantly cut in line because they do not want to wait in line for 30 minutes or so!

The women at the front work as fast as they can packaging dozens of pastries at a time and processing transactions. Cash only location despite how much you pay for (the mooncakes are shockingly very expensive). Unlike other pastries, they don't really have signs or give you time to take a look what to order. To the right of the right front counter are the different types of mooncakes. The more yolks in the mooncake, the more $$$ you will need.

The mooncakes are great for sharing. One mooncake will be good for two people. The mooncakes are amazingly good, rightly sweetened, and very fresh. It's hard to choose which one to get!!!

The women in the counter will help you as best as they can. Don't get discouraged if you feel you are being rushed, they simply want the line to keep moving I supposed.
author: Romer C.

description:
I have no doubt that these egg tarts are delicious.  I would probably wait an hour for a dozen of them again.  However, I think their poor service and lack of customer appreciation is a big stinker.  During my visit to SF earlier this year, I came here only to be disappointed with the big sign on the door that they're on vacation.  I've read on numerous Yelp reviews that they randomly close and are on "vacation".   Throughout my stay, I did call them and no one picked up so I didn't bother going again.  On my most recent trip to SF, I called them as soon as we landed and they picked up.  I asked what time they're open till and the lady promptly said 8 PM.  She didn't say anything else.  They were our first stop from the airport and guess what?!  They were closed!!!  I saw staff working in the shop but the sign on the door said they wouldn't open until 2 PM.  I was so pissed off.  Was it too much to ask for her to have told me they're open from 2-8 PM that day while we were on the phone?  Uggggh.  

I honestly didn't think we were going to get any egg tarts but the hubs reminded me that we were in the city and we should try one more time.  Off we went and of course there was an insane line.  Damn, why do they have to be so good???  Flaky buttery crust that kinda falls apart when you eat them.  Or maybe it's because I'm a fattie and couldn't wait for them to cool down a bit.  The custard is light yellow, jiggly, not overly sweet and melts in your mouth!  I scarfed down three in an hour.  

The staff isn't the most helpful/friendly but I'm sure it helped that I spoke chinese.  I believe they allow you to order a certain amount of egg tarts due to the high demand.  When it was my turn to order, the lady asked me how many people was in my party.  Since it was me and the hubby, she allowed me to order a dozen.  

Tips:
-Call in advance and ask them what time they're open and what time they're closed!
-Pretty sure it's only a dozen per person.  If you need two dozens, make sure you bring a friend!
-CASH ONLY
author: Tiffany C.

description: We were so surprised it was open, considering that it was Lunar New Years weekend, but so glad it was! I happily waited for 1+ hour in the cold  for this. I got in line to wait, and my sister gave me all the cash she had before going to meet up with her husband and kids at our hotel. We scrounged up $45 cash, and decided to buy all the egg tarts we could with it (20). The hotel was a good 0.5 mile away or so, and my sister debated on whether or not to run me more cash so we could buy even MORE to take home! Yes, they're THAT good!! Probably the only thing we did all weekend that was actually worth waiting for!
author: Kristie T.

description: Egg-tarts! Enough said. Parking is an adventure, then waiting in line. Well worth the wait.
author: Cody T.

description:
actually they closed the whole morning today.....these grandmas never post a sign or give a damn... Hahaha, good luck for ur egg tarts hunting.

PS: one grandma told me that she would open the store around 2-3pm... But not sure :p that's what u call a hunger marketing
author: Sidong H.

description:
Pros: Quite possibly the tastiest egg tart/蛋挞 I have eaten in my life. The egg tarts are large and the crust is perfectly baked/very soft. I liked them so much, I purchased a dozen and brought them with me on my flight back to Saint Louis. 

Cons: Their hours are unpredictable. There is a 50/50 chance the bakery is closed when you show up at the door. I think the bakery was closed (the sign read that the owners were on vacation) the first 3 times I tried to purchase egg tarts here. Luckily, I decided to swing by for a 4th time and saw a long line of customers out the door. This site may come in handy:
http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/
author: Helen P.

description:
I was honestly never a huge fan of egg tarts until Golden Gate Bakery.

It was the week of mid-autumn festival, and my boyfriend strongly insisted that we try this place despite the super long line, over the DOZENS of other places in the area selling egg tarts and moon cakes. My boyfriend is Chinese and grew up with these treats. I'm Korean and never completely understood the appeal of them, so I wasn't super enthusiastic with waiting so long.

45 minutes later, we walked out with a big box filled with $40 worth of egg tarts and moon cakes, and after having a taste...I actually wasn't bitter at all about waiting so long.

The egg tarts were fresh and still warm, the crust was perfectly flaky without being greasy, and the custard (which was what set it apart for me from all the other egg tarts I've had in the past) was creamy and flavorful while being light. 

Highly recommend!
author: Sara L.

description:
Hands down, the best dan tat! I've grown up eating these gems and they never disappoint - always hot & soft on the inside and crisp & flakey on the out - it's amazing. 

They've up-ed their prices a lot and I think the last time I got it, it was up to $1.95 - but doesn't seem to have effected their customers since there's always a line outside. Definitely give it a try if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Carrie L.

description:
I love egg tarts!! I'm always on the hunt for them, and I think I found one of the best I've ever tried. Since there's barely any space inside the store, the line here is out the door passing two stores. I brought my boyfriend here on our San Francisco visit and we waited around 30 minutes just to order. Their egg tarts ($1.25) are SUPER fresh and right out of the oven. I couldn't even eat them right away because they were burning hot. 

BE CAREFUL! Even after waiting a few minutes to eat it, I almost burned myself. The inside has butter and keeps the heat in longer.
author: Annie W.

description: Probably the best egg tarts in the WORLD!! They were creamy and soft, I couldn't stop eating it. And we went on a good time, as there was no line. But it did formed a long one after we left.
author: Tan D.

description:
Still the BEST "EGG TART" in the states! I would never wait in line because I think its crazy long. The best feeling is when you walk by Chinatown and there is no line. You order your egg tart and always fresh of the oven. That bite is simply amazing. ha! Hot and flaky. So freaken delicious. It's now $1.75 each. But I feel like its still worth it. YUM!!

Also recommend their walnut pound cake. They come out later in the day. After 3pm. One other cool thing is their GIANT sesame ball. It's as big as an orange. So awesome.
author: Sandy B.

description: This was the best egg tart I've ever had. The line was long and moved slowly but it was worth it for the egg tart. Definitely lives up to the hype!
author: Courtney L.

description:
Honestly, I've grown up eating a lot of egg tarts and they've all tasted the same. But this place was definitely the best! During my trip up to San Fran, many friends told me I had to try this place out. So we went and the line was LONG. BRING A SWEATER ! It got pretty cold waiting in line. I don't remember what time we got there, but my boyfriend and I ended up waiting 2 HOURS ! Yes, 2 hours in that line and we weren't the only ones who waited that long.

Since it was labor day weekend, they limited each person to 2 egg tarts each... It made me so sad but still the 4 we got was DELICIOUS. 

Upon taking a bit, the crust was flaky rather than hard! The egg tart itself was so creamy and just melted into my mouth. After that bite, I understood why people were so crazy about this place ! We made sure those 4 egg tarts lasted and once we finished we wished we had more...

So if you're looking for places to eat in San Fran or places to try, add this to your list of things to do !
author: Diana L.

description:
White guy here.

I've never considered Chinese cuisine as being in possession of good desserts. Italian, French, sure. Mexican and Chinese, not so much. But this place changed my mind (about Chinese cuisine; sorry Mexican, I'm still waiting to be impressed by your bakeries).

My wife visited once on a recommendation and raved about their egg tarts. So the next time we went to Chinatown she insisted we visit Golden Gate. Sadly, there was a line and a sign on the door saying that they'd open in two hours. But as we shuffled our feet indecisively, we saw one of the owners open the door a crack, and quickly hand a bag to the first person in line. Money was exchanged just as furtively. Intrigued, we got in line and discovered that the owner was serving one person at a time.

Why? I have no idea. We peeked through a gap in the window and could see a man asleep at a desk in the back. Maybe it was nap time? I don't know, but I do know that the owner tries very hard to please her customers, and she is exceedingly nice. Some people complain that they're on vacation a lot, or that they're closed often. It's like visiting Europe for the first time in August; Americans are aghast that their desires will not be instantly gratified like they are in the U.S. Get over yourself. 

Oh, and their stuff is great. The egg tarts are delicious, and I really enjoyed the moonpie as well. And both are beautiful, in addition to being delicious.

You can get decent dim sum at a dozen places in Chinatown, but this is the only Chinese bakery that truly impressed me.
author: Jeff R.

description:
The Golden Gate Bakery is a legend among locals and non locals like myself for a reason. My family and I have been visiting the Golden Gate Bakery for 20+ years now and the baked goods have always been absolutely heavenly. 
The Dan tats are something to reckon with. Golden custard and crispy and buttery crusts melt in your mouth after every bite and before you know it you'll have had 3 in one sitting.
The size of these bad puppies hasn't changed since it's opening which is note worthy in itself. While other bakeries' dan tats in Chinatown have become minuscule over the years, Golden Gate has stayed consistent large and in charge. Roughly the size of coasters, these dan tats will fill you up.
While the wait (10-15 mins) can be a bit daunting sometimes, know that the bakery isn't consistently open seasonally and that the wait is beyond worth it! 
As an Angeleno that has pilgrimaged up to this Bakery on an annual basis for my entire life, I hope to bring my own kids one day! 
Thank you Golden Gate Bakery!!
author: Kelli W.

description:
A hidden gem in the city.

They're always so busy. The line can get quite long. However, that also means you always get fresh batches of egg tarts coming out. I have gone here many times and every time my egg tarts are still warm and crunchy. 

Parking around the area is a nightmare for sure. If you find a street parking spot around the area, QUADRUPLE check all the signs to make sure that it is legal to park there. And of course, HIDE all your belongings. It is not the greatest area of the city...
author: Chris H.

description: I asked for 1.5 dozens of egg tarts in 3 boxes but they said one box must be a bozen so they forced me to buy 3 dozens.
author: Charlotte T.

description: Damn. It's 1.95 now!! But long line still exists and the crust is still flakey. Inside is gooey and I preferred a more cooled down solid egg custard.
author: Amy H.

description:
I've grown up going to Chinatown every week. I would never end up going to this bakery. I asked a couple of my friends who live in Chinatown or SF, and they don't actually go here either. When I went to college and met some friends not from the area, they all seem to know this place and are crazy about going here. Why?

Who knows?

I really don't understand the hype about this place. If you haven't grown up eating egg tarts, there's a good chance you'll like these. If you have, imagine an egg tart with double the sugar. That's basically what the egg tarts here taste like. I suppose it satisfies the sweet tooths of tourists.

Who knows?

And this place is always closed whenever they feel like closing down. It seems like they are always on vacation possibly due to the amount of money they earn from the mysterious and ridiculous amount of hype they get. Why else are they closed for seemingly random periods of time?

Who knows?

So are the bakery items here bad? no.
Are they necessarily good compared to other bakeries in the area? no.
Would I recommend this place? no.
Would I recommend against this place? no.

So what's my verdict on Golden Gate Bakery?

A resounding.... Who knows? ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
author: Joshua M.

description:
Best egg tart of my life (or in recent memory).

You'll be lucky if you can get your hands on one. They're hit or miss in terms of opening hours (they are open when they want to be). 

One of the must-hit places on your SF-bucket list. 

$2 each (yes prices have increased).

Still worth every penny.

Eat it hot and fresh.

Nice ladies.
author: Cindy W.

description: The wait was kind of long, but it was the day of the Chinese New Year parade and it's so famous. They've never been open whenever I am passing by, so I had to wait to see if their egg/custard tarts are as good as everyone says. They are! I highly recommend eating the tart as soon as you buy it, while it's warm. Also, they only accept cash!
author: Wicia F.

description: They don't open all the time but they have the worlds best egg tart!!! Trust me they are the best!!!!
author: Susan Z.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place yet. I learned about this place from my BIL who lives in the city. He had brought it one time, can't recall when, but let me tell you. One bite from their egg custard tarte.. OMG. You won't want to get egg custard tartes from anywhere else.

The crust isn't dry like some places and the custard consistency... just right. 

I always request for my BIL to bring these down to SJ whenever he heads over. Definitely worth getting a box full whenever exploring The City.
author: Kristal J.

description:
Best. Eggtarts. Ever.

It doesn't matter if:
1. There's always a line: sometimes, the line folds into two lines (~30 minute wait)
2. They aren't open randomly: check the facebook page for updates!

People will still keep coming back for more. The crust is light and flaky, and the custard is creamy and buttery. Basically, you're eating a little piece of heaven. 

Take out your Andrew Jackson because each dozen is $19.80 (@$1.65/piece). Worth it, I promise! 

Tip: Trying to get a mouthgasm? Eat it when it comes right out of the oven. Amazeballs!
author: Christine S.

description:
It's a cash only place so plan ahead. I've heard that the timings are irregular, but the place has always been open when I've visited (a handful of times).

There's always a long line here because their egg tarts are that good! I've waited about 30-40 minutes every time. But a warm tart from a fresh batch makes your day all the better.
author: Nimeela D.

description:
This place was recommended by the BF. It's located in Chinatown and its hard to find parking. He dropped me off to get in line/pick up some egg tarts that he loves and talked about a few times since we started dating. I was so confused and When I walked to the place with a sign on the door "we will be closed for 2 days" there were 3 people standing by the door so I asked them if they're really closed; luckily the lady told me to just wait in line and they'll take my order. 

Finally, I got the six egg tarts for a little over $10; the egg tarts were fresh! I had one fresh and another one cold from the fridge the next day. Boy, both hot and cold the tarts were delish! The best egg tarts I've tried - so far...

Yay, didn't have to wait in the long line! :)
author: Keycee D.

description: I waited for at least an hour to try their fresh egg tarts and I have to say that it was worth the wait! The egg tarts came right out of the oven and they were still hot when I ate it&it was one of the best I have ever had :)
author: Tiffany W.

description: The best darn coconut tart I've ever had! I got here at 7:30pm on a weekday so there was no line. Definitely a must try if you're close by!
author: Lam L.

description: Helpful for me, the staff speaks Mandarin fluently. :-)
author: Anthony W.

description:
I've been coming to this bakery since I was a little boy with the family for a long time.  I don't want to outdate myself, but I would say 25+ years ago whenever we made a family trip up to the Bay Area. This particular bakery is located in the old Chinatown of San Francisco.

I have never known until the last time I came here that there was such a long line of people outside waiting to buy their pastries.  We must have waiting a hour before we finally got in to order the pastries.

I must admit that they make delicious "Don Tats" or egg custards. It's basically battered egg poured and  baked in a small round crust which is simply delicious! The concept seems simple, but I'm quite sure there's a lot of work behind it.  

They also make delicious coconut puffs... which is similar to the American rice crispies. It's the same simple concept, and the preparation is also similar to rice crispies. Again, delicious!
