They sell other baked goods such as pound cakes, bread buns, and baos.  Whatever is purchased depends on the quantity will either be bagged or boxed in the traditional pink Dim Sum box and tied. It brings back so many childhood memories just by looking at the pink box reminiscing how I use to open up the boxes and just smell the aroma when my parents use to buy dim sum.

This bakery has been around for a long time. As you peak in the store, everything looks the same... the floors, walls, display cases, etc. Only the strings used to tie the boxes has changed into the more flimsy kind instead of using red string. 

I like this place, but never realized it has become so popular. The Chinese ladies working inside are nice, especially when you speak the same Chinese dialect. Yes, you'll get shoved a few times by an older lady who does not believe in lines. But nobody in line waiting complains knowing that they're elders.

Anyhow, great memories here and I wish Golden Gate Bakery the best.
author: ED L.

description:
Without a doubt, a MUST-visit whenever possible.  
1.  Egg Tarts:  I have never been a fan of egg tarts.  Until I tried these.  Fresh and hot out of the oven.  The tart is soft and custardy, not too sweet but not too eggy.  The crust is flaky, buttery, tender, and melts in your mouth.  
2.  Coconut Macaroons:  I love a good macaroon.  And these are the BEST anywhere ever.  Again, hot out of the oven:  perfectly browned and crunchy on the outside.  on the inside, chewy perfection.  ADDICTION.
3.  Service:  super friendly, funny, patient.  The line can get insane, everyone is vying for the goods.  But they ensure to assist everyone.
4.  FYI:  tarts and macaroons are still perfection when taken home:  toast up in the oven and they are fabulous!  Cash only.
author: C P.

description:
Bookmarked for ages, but on my last visit to San Francisco they were closed which was closed for vacation. On this trip, we were so excited to see that not only was Golden Gate Bakery open, they had just opened back up recently so we rushed over to try as many delicious goodies as we could. 

We of course had to try the famous egg tarts but we also ordered a bunch of other options to take with us to sample throughout the day. Every morsel we sampled was delicious. The egg tarts lived up to all the rave reviews. 

It's worth the wait and make sure you have exact change to keep the line moving.
author: Emily R.

description: I love egg tarts and have eaten them all over the world (including in Asia). This place is THE best, but the line is also really long (30-60min). Worth the wait though :)
author: Catherine W.

description:
Egg Tart " Dan Tart" is one of my favorite of all desert!  

The best, the freshest, the most satisfying egg tart I had.  Call them before you come to make sure they didn't run out.  

Don't be selfish!  Treat yourself to the best!
author: Ly L.

description:
Took me forever to try this place out, I was a bit frustrated when I saw the long line I had to stand in... which meant even longer to try out the egg tarts. 

Pastries: The crust is amazingly flaky, crisp and just well rounded in texture and flavor. The custard was extremely tasty, not too sweet, but just right. However, the texture of it was a bit thicker than I'd like and on the egg-y side. Overall, the egg tart was great. Warm and tasty, but I wouldn't stand in the long line for just one. I also had the vanilla sponge cake, which to be completely honest, I loved a lot more than the egg tart, but that is just personal preference. The texture was exactly what a sponge cake should be like... soft and spongy, melts on your tongue delicious-ness! The vanilla filling is buttery, sweet and naturally tasty. If you're going to stand in line, buy a few dozen egg tarts or try out some of the other items on the menu, everything is pretty tasty. 

Customer Service: Fast, friendly and efficient. The woman that helped me clearly knew I was new to the establishment and she made some recommendations right off the bat.  I will mention the weird vacation sign that I posted a photo of, which apparently isn't uncommon. Their business model is quite confusing, but it is after all their business. I'd recommend that you give them a ring before investing your precious time in coming here and then having to go home empty handed.

Ambiance: Very busy, long lines, crowded storefront. Nowhere to eat your pastries, maybe that's what the corner opening in the box is for... on-the-go consumption!

Price: Reasonable, but on a steady incline from what I've read.


Overall: Good egg tarts and other pastries, prices are okay, but the wait isn't too pretty. Call ahead if you're worried about them being on vacation!
author: Astrid Z.

description: Finally tried the egg tarts here after trying 3 times! (Note: you should call beforehand because it seems like they're closed more often than they are open.) It was super worth the wait though! The egg tarts are a bit larger than I'm used to, and the crust is super buttery and flaky. Definitely one of the best I've tried.
author: Alice S.

description: Disappointed!! We attempted to go 11/8/2017 evening and they were closed. We wasted an Uber ride. The sign on the door stated they were closed for vacation 3 weeks but there was no start date or end date. I recommend to call first to confirm they are open.
author: Lisa S.

description: Known spot for egg tarts! The crusts are so soft and buttery! I would buy a bunch when I am here.
author: Yennie L.

description: The wait is bonkers and the egg tarts are good but I'd say because its a hot sweet treat its probably just as good as any other egg custard you can get that is hot out of the oven (versus sitting for a while). If the line is short, its worth getting a half dozen for two people as a nice sweet treat, but otherwise...I'd be wary going back again.
author: Jon H.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is absolutely magical. I don't know what luck dawned on me that wondrous day I road-tripped to SF during finals week from San Diego. It was my first time going to GG Bakery, and to my surprise, it was OPEN and there was NO LINE. Sorcery, right? I could barely believe my eyes as I squealed and entered the bakery. I kid you not, my hands were shaking from excitement. 

These egg tarts are a bit pricey and it was ~20$ for a dozen, but IT IS SO WORTH IT. And I would do it again.

What makes these egg tarts different from all the other SF egg tarts? Every. thing. First of all, they're warm. So warm, it's like they literally just came out of the oven. Secondly, they're so flaky and crispy, but just so enough that it doesn't taste like you're eating a slice of butter. Thirdly, the filling to crust proportion is perfection. When I buy an egg tart, I want the eggy part! I don't want to be eating a bunch of crust! Lastly, and probably most importantly, the egg tart itself. It's creamy, yet firm. Almost flan-like, but solid enough to not be pudding. 

These egg tarts are literally melt-in-your-mouth deliciousness. 10/10 would go back again. (and I'd probably buy like 2 dozen next time :D)
author: Andrea K.

description:
Pretty good! The egg tarts did live up to the hype. I waited 20 minutes at noon on a Saturday. The store layout looks very cramped and inefficient. They really need to clean the place out to make room for a better bakery and maximize profits. I'm sure they lose some business from the long wait.

But the dan tas are the best you'll get in the U.S. I love how they're always hot when you first get them. And the egg custard to crust ratio is 9:1. Not very standard for most egg tarts and very difficult to make since the crust will most likely fall apart. Although it's thin, the crust is probably the best part! It's always perfectly flakey and baked to a nice dark brown color.

I would definitely go back on a weekday when it's not as crowded.
author: Jia-Wen H.

description: WARNING: This is definitely not a traditional Chinese flaky crust egg tart.  This might be considered by some as the best egg tart in SF, but it's far from the best I've ever had.  I liked that it was served warm, but you'll never find an egg tart like this in HK. In my opinion, not worth the 30min+ wait at all.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Had to wait several months for these guys to get back from vacation. Even joined the facebook group IsGoldenGateBakeryOpen just to keep track. Finally opened up in early June.

Egg Custard Tart - 5/5 - Lived up to the hype. Best egg custard tart of all the ones I've tried in the city. Flaky, creamy, tasty. Deserves its spot on the 7x7 list. Order again.

Overall, on the rare occasion that they're not on vacation, stop in at Golden Gate because their tarts are "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
One of the best egg tarts in SF.
They also have traditional Chinese cookies and all were good
author: David H.

description: I heard that the bakery was opened today so I made the trek in the rain for those beautiful egg tarts. There wasn't a huge line so I was super thankful. Every single penny spent at this bakery is well spent. The egg tarts are creamy with the right amount of buttery and crumbly crust. Do yourself a favor and buy more than a dozen when you come because I bought a dozen and I promise that the box is going to be empty by tonight!
author: Yolande H.

description:
THEAE EGG TARTS ARE SO GOOD. Trust, I love egg tarts! I've had them in NY, Boston,
NC, etc. This place trumps them all. Located in a little shop in china town, this bakery sells egg tarts and moon cakes. 

The egg tarts are the big sellers. They are about $2 (little pricey), but completely worth. My favorite part of the tarts are the shells. They are larger than most and very crispy and fresh! I can't comment much on the mooncakes, but they had a variety of flavors. They're a bit expensive though so be prepared to spend some cash here.
author: Denise K.

description:
I have waited for years to be able to try the famous Egg Tarts from Golden Gate Bakery, and as luck would have it, GGB was open this weekend when I was visiting San Francisco.

Many patrons have pronounced these Egg Tarts as "life changing", or "best egg tarts in the world". I have to agree that they are fantastic, however, "life changing" may be taking it a little far. The crust is very thin, but exceptionally flaky, and the custard (which was piping hot when I tried it) is extremely light and not overly sweet. It was really good, and I really loved the "aunties" that were working inside. They were really sweet and kind.

Definitely worth the trouble of doing a drive by to see if they are open. Don't be alarmed by the line as it moves fairly quickly.
author: Margaret L.

description:
Looking at various reviews saying they are randomly closed a lot, I think my friends and I got lucky during our trip to SF. We visited the shop around 6pm, and it was still open, plus no line. Wasn't able to make it in time for most of their baked goods (they ran out), but was able to try their egg tart! SOOO GOOD. They also had a bunch of various mooncakes left too. The egg tart was still fresh and warm when we got it, and the crust was very flaky and so well-made. They are pricier than I'm use to, but also one of the best egg tarts I've had. Definitely try it if you're in the area!

NOTE: CASH ONLY!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
There was a huge line in front and went to try the egg tarts, mooncake and rolls. OK, I've never eaten any of this to be honest. Not a fan of the egg tarts because I do not like eggs to much or more runny like tarts. But many were crazy for it and were buying it like crazy. So I just had to try it. The white lotus mooncake was excellent never tried anything like it and would recommend it to anyone.The Apple roll was OK. The raspberry roll was excellent. The line was 30-40 mins long. The portion was large and the price was right. 
If you are going here and aren't sure what to try, the mooncakes are a must.
For me it was not worth the wait, since I liked the food but wasn't super impressed. Also inside the place isn't quite neat, it packed with boxes and stuff.
author: Rita S.

description:
I'm from Toronto where there are amazing egg tarts and now I live here and hands down these are hella good if not arguably better. The egg custard to tart ratio is freaking perfect. Not too sweet or too buttery. 

Worth the wait and the constantly disappointment that they're on vacation. Get a dozen because you'll finish them eventually. 

Eat here.
author: Janice K.

description: Just a hype....Good egg tarts but it's always closed! It's been 4 years since we first tried their egg tart. Yes, they are good but 2 out of 3 times we want to GG bakery, they were closed for whatever reasons. Sick of all the disappointments and finally found another replacement. Goodbye GG bakery. See my other review for the replacement.
author: Ping T.

description:
My family has been coming to this bakery for over a decade and this place never disappoints. Their egg tarts always fresh and crust is super flaky. Don't hesitate to come near closing because they must have fresh egg tarts at all times. Customers come in here purchased and DOZENS at a time and they would be screwed if it's not a constant baking process. 

The women at the front work as fast as They can packaging dozens of pastries at a time and processing transactions. Note that this is a cash only location despite how much you pay for. Unlike other pastries, they don't really have signs or give you time to take a look around the area. The expect all their customers to know exactly what they want or do the research prior to the visit. Nobody really walks. in there and ask what's good for the day. They just say I want a certain amount of this pastry and what not.

Perhaps some of you get lucky and don't wait for long but I have never waited for less than an hour. But I guarantee you that it's worth it. Egg tarts here are truly exceptional compared to the ones you had dim sum whether it's mayflower or Koi. 

I have no idea how parking works and have no input since I'm always the one who jumps out of the car and stand in line. But just from a glance at the meters nearby, it is $3.50 per hour.

They currently sell a dozen egg tarts at $23.40.

Another side note is they randomly comes for a couple days just to go on vacation. I would not recommend coming all the way here just for the bakery around Christmas or New Year's. I would also think twice before coming around Chinese new year unless, of course you have other plans in the area.?
author: Danae L.

description: This place makes the best custard hands down. The only problem is that they are always closed. This makes me want them even more, because when you finally get your hands on them it is like a reward. It is best to eat them fresh when they just come out of the oven.
author: Marty M.

description: You will need to call in to check the hours of operation and also get there 10-20minutes early if you don't want to wait. But this place is one of the best egg tarts, even my area (socal) does not have any good tarts there! Recommended if your around the area!!
author: Bobby L.

description:
There seems to be something very wrong with this place. They've had a "VACATION" sign on the door for what feels like weeks in a row. And looking through the window, it's filled with shelves of random stuff and just loads of boxes everywhere. Very odd.

Edit July 5. Just walked past again. Still "vacation". And given the huge mess through the window. Definitely doesn't seem like just a vacation
author: Grapes T.

description:
People come near and far for these egg tarts. If you've tasted it, then you know why..
that warm, flakey, buttery crust and perfect balance of egg and sweet custard in the middle will make you savor each bite! Its a must try!! 

Lines are horrendous, especially on the weekends but it does go fast and is worth the wait. And, don't even get me started on parking and customer service. Its Chinatown, enough said.

The prices of these egg tarts keep rising. As of today, they are $1.95 each. Is it worth it? Again, YES!

Oh, and just a tip - make sure you check if the shop is open first before heading over. Owners like to close shop when they please so be prepared!
author: Liza L.

description:
THE BEST EGG TART I'VE EVER HAD IN MY LIFE.

Keep in mind that this place takes vacations whenever they want (BALLN I say). I tried going here two times and they were on vacation those both two times. But I finally got lucky the last time I went. Chinatown was basically closed at around 6p.m., but luckily this place was opened. There was still a line when I got there and they were baking some fresh egg tarts (yay!) My friend and I got six egg tarts because come on! We never know when they're going on vacation again?! But oh wow oohhh were they deliciousss. Can't wait to go back to SF and get some more egg tarts from here!
author: Sera K.

description: OMG egg custard tarts (don tots) are so....good! Some of the best I eaten. Just &1.95 each. They just came out of the oven. Crust is very flaky!
author: Sandra L.

description: Golden Gate Bakery is almost ALWAYS closed for vacation (at least when I pass by here). But when I was walking through Chinatown recently, it was open (and had a long line out the door), so I just had to jump on the chance to get some pastries! After waiting a good 45 minutes (and getting lots of questions about the line from curious tourists), we finally stepped out with a box of fresh, hot egg tarts along with a few other things (but let's be honest--the egg tarts are the reason to come!). They were still warm as we took them out of the store (and the nice ladies even cut a hole in the corner of the classic pink box to let the steam out--the signature mark of a box of pastries from Golden Gate!). I couldn't help but take a bite right away and nearly got burned! But these were delicious egg tarts--some of the best I've tried! The custard mixture is lightly sweet, creamy, and moist, and the tart is particularly flaky and crispy. Delicious and definitely worth a try! Just be prepared to wait and pay up--the tarts don't come cheap at $1.95 a pop.
author: David K.

description:
WHY IS THERE A HYPE FOR THIS??!!!!

My friend swore by this place. $2 an egg tart. WUT. We came on a weekday around 7pm and there was a short line. They move very slowly as egg tarts come out fresh from the oven. The egg custard is very hot when you bite into it. 

But come on...I've had the same quality egg tarts all over LA bakeries. What is so special about this place? Honestly if you venture out to other bakeries and get them when its fresh it's the same idea. 

Plus, the business is so good that they can open and close whenever they want without notice. I rather go to a local bakery with reliable business hours. 

I just don't see the hype. I've had same egg tarts in LA piping hot and had some in San Leandro when they make it fresh. 

Next.
author: Sarah I.

description:
If you're looking for a silky, crispy crusted egg tart, come to Golden Gate & be prepared to wait in line. The line will vary, if you're lucky- there may be no line at all!
Unfortunately, they have raised their prices of the egg tarts, $1.70 a pop and a total of 5 big boy bites to finish. I think this place is just hyped up & VERY touristy spot. I wouldn't go out of my way & drive to Chinatown to pick up these eggies nor would I wait in a 30 min line, but if I'm in the area & the line is just right...
author: Maria C.

description:
If Golden Gate Bakery were a car. It will be Lamborghini Countach. It's Finicky ( unpredictable closing and availability of Egg Tart), yet thrilling and fast ( buy your dan tart in dozens!! and it has one of the flakiest crust and creamiest custard on west coast), yet the car can kill you if you oversteer, or incorrectly refill the oil aka burning car ( well It's creamy, eggy and sweets , as long as you ate in moderation, it will be fine! Overate, then you will see your blood sugar up and health will deteriorate) 
So this dan tart will drive your taste bud from 0-60 in 4 seconds!

Moon cakes from this shop will be the 911 GT2 (Widow maker) of car. It's not finicky ( widely more available when the shop are open, and mooncake season is up) Has lots of flavour that you can choose. Overate this morsels, your head will get chopped right away.....
author: Dan A.

description: Too much hype for this place. What makes it good is just the use of a lot of butter. Other than that, not a special custard/egg taste. Couple with the unexpected openings and long lines, you can get better value elsewhere.
author: Jaymon H.

description: They have by far the best custard tart in the Bay Area.  However, they are not always open.  It's hard to catch them and when they are open, the line is out the door.  Probably a good idea to call them first before coming.
author: Jonathan W.

description: They are inexcusably slow and don't have the good sense to serve other customers while some wait for baking.  No custard is worth hours of waiting.
author: Crystal G.

description: This is my favorite and I love there egg tarts. Every time when I have friend come visit me I want to bring them there but line always too long when they open cause there egg tarts n moon cake r good.
author: gloria y.

description:
CASH ONLY!!!

Got a coconut cupcake, some coconut macaroons, and a dozen egg tarts. 

I admit, these Dan Tat (Egg Tarts) are good. I don't know if it's worth the wait though. 

The coconut macaroons were okay too, not a big fan of coconut, so I don't know if you should trust me on them. Just try them out, it's pretty cheap. $1 for 6 coconut macaroons & $1.60 for an egg tart. 

Was going to get some on Saturday afternoon, but the line was HELLA LONG. It wrapped around the place. So my cousin and I decided not to get it that day. 

We did get it the next day, Sunday before we left to Sacramento. The line wasn't as long as yesterday, but it was still a 30 min wait. 

Once you get in, you have one of the ladies take your order, they get your goods, and you are out of there. The ladies speak enough English to take your order. From what I saw that day, they seem to treat you nicer if you spoke Chinese ( which I did ^^V). 

Overall, if I was in the area and there wasn't a long wait, I would come back again.
author: Shelley G.

description:
Very few things make me as happy as a good egg custard tart, so when I read the reviews of this place, I knew I had to go.

The line was out the door, and there were only really two things on the menu: moon cakes (in a bunch of different flavors), and, of course, egg tarts.

The egg tarts are so popular here that they were literally rationing them - max. 3/person - so they wouldn't run out before the next batch was ready (which was estimated to be in about half an hour). This caused some consternation among some of the patrons. I did manage to get one, though, and I can totally see why there was a long line - it was delicious! Warm, flakey, and everything you want an egg tart to be.

I also tried a coconut almond moon cake with egg yolk - by FAR the best moon cake I've ever had (though admittedly it's not a large sample size). 

Absolutely worth the wait.
author: Liz F.

description:
Best egg tarts I've had! Filling is cooked JUST right and sweetness is perfect! The shell is flakey but not oily on the bottom.

Line was down the street and it is definitely worth the wait.

They can be more efficient so the wait wouldn't be so long though.
author: Jen L.

description: The hype is real, the dan tats were on fire. The Dan tats were really fresh and straight from the oven. Since there was such a long line they are constantly poppin out a fresh batch. The gf decided to take some home but they are not the same when you try it straight from the oven to your pie hole.
author: Dak L.

description: One of the best authentic egg custard tarts I've ever tasted - located at the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown. I guess the owners are always on vacation but when this place is open, there's usually always a long line and by long, I mean around 30-40 minutes. The egg tarts are $1.75 each, which is pretty pricey, but the filling is absolutely divine as the egg yolk is soft and sweet - melts right in your mouth with the outer crispy crust to balance out the texture of the pastry. Highly recommend you to try this place out at least once if you're ever in the area!
author: Jacqueline K.

description:
Totally worth waiting in line for! I'm a huge egg tart fan, so my friends brought me here during my visit to SF. :)

We were really lucky that it was open and that the line was pretty short (it only extended to the shop next door). I've heard the line gets really crazy and wraps around the block sometimes. 

When I bit into that warm egg tart, I felt like I was in heaven. The custard is slightly sweet, rich, and soft. The crust was crispy, flaky, and buttery. So simple but so delicious. I'd say it was the best egg tart I've had in my life, even compared to some that I tried in Taiwan! We saw a ton of people buying dozens at a time (presumably as gifts), but I think you gotta eat them fresh to really appreciate them.

I'm going to have to hit this place up during every future visit to SF!
author: Stacy Y.

description:
Egg Tarts so good make me wanna slap your momma!?!

I've passed by this place a few times when visiting Chinatown and noticed how long the line always is and I've have never had the guts to wait in that ridiculous line.  I heard the hype of how good their egg tarts are so I finally decided to bite the bullet and give this place a try on a Saturday evening.  To my amazement there was no line, probably because there was less tourists in Chinatown as the Golden Gate bridge was closed for construction that weekend.  Enter this small bakery which look so appealing from the outside but the smell of baked goods had me hooked and they did not disappoint that's for sure...

Egg Tarts - picked up two dozen of these suckers, and they were damn goodz! I ate them throughout the week and it is a perfect thing to bring back for family/co-workers as you can purchase by the dozen and they all loved them.  Best way to eat these are when they are warm, o so good!!!

Coconut Cake - this was actually my favorite from here, even better than the Egg Tarts but that's just my opinion!?!

Lotus Mooncake - all looks, tasted disgusting!?! 

I don't know if I would wait 45mins to an hour to get Egg Tarts at this place, but if the line is short I would definitely be back.  They also might think about opening another location as it is really hard to get parking around Chinatown and this places gets extremely crowded especially on the weekends :(
author: Deep S.

description:
Believe the hype!!! 

Before I tried Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts, I couldn't help but think, "Come on. How good can an egg tart really be? And to wait in line for? Eh...must be hype." 

But then I tried one. OH MY GOODNESS. And if you get one fresh?! Game over. 

Just do yourself a favor and go here. Wait in line. Order some egg tarts. And enjoy. 

It's worth it!! 

CASH ONLY.
author: Noelle H.

description:
4 stars purely for the egg tarts. Look for the long line outside and you will have found your destination. Coming from NYC where our Chinatown and Flushing pop out some bomb egg tarts, the standards were set pretty high. After waiting about 15 minutes on line, I finally got to  bite into a perfectly warm, flaky, sweet egg tart that was definitely worth the wait for me (to be honest, there isn't too much going on in Chinatown). 

Service is quick and efficient and they usually have reserves of egg tarts in the ovens so do not fret if the person in front of you purchases what seems to be the last one!
author: Matthew L.

description:
Came here and there was a line out the door but it went pretty quickly, i don't think i waited more than 20 minutes.  I got a few egg tarts (Dan Tat) and a order of rice cakes.  The egg tarts are perhaps the best i have had or can remember having in a very long time.  They are on par with the ones i've had in Hong Kong and Macau.  The crust is so flaky and yet crisp, while the custard is soft and creamy and still warm!  SO GOOD!

Many reviews speak of long lines and wait times, i went on the day after the Chinese new year parade, when there was a street festival, can't be more crowded than that?!  i waited less than 20 minutes.  Maybe i got lucky, or maybe you just have to be there before 11, i really don't know.  Either way get there early and get yourself one of these, they are awesome!

At $1.75 each they were a bit steep but totally worth it!  A bit cheaper if you order them by the dozen.  You'll want at least 2 for yourself immediately and 2 more for later, so make sure you order enough!  You won't want to stand in that line again right?!
author: Ryan M.

description:
As a SoCal native, I had heard many of my NorCal friend rave about this place for years. And whenever I tried to visit in the past, they were always closed. So imagine my excitement when I found myself in SF again and realized they were open! So, I got in line with some of my friends and waited in line for 2 hours. I watched the line grow longer and longer, because everyone ordered at least a dozen or two. I also watched people angrily accuse others of cutting in line. People get really serious when their egg tarts are threatened. 

Because I prefer my egg tarts fresh, I just ordered one hot one to eat. And... it was nothing special. Yeah, it's huge (which is why it's so expensive), but I would not line up again for it. The custard wasn't too sweet, but it was a bit watery. Also, the crust wasn't quite as flaky and buttery/lardy as I prefer. Pretty meh. I've had much better egg tarts from other places. Don't waste your time here.
author: Meagan S.

description:
Yes, the custard tarts really are that good.  And fresh ones are constantly being made, open to close.  Almost had a heart attack when I went 30 minutes before 8pm and thought one of the ladies said they were all gone.  But then they pulled out a tray full of fresh ones, as good as it gets!  Creamy, thick, and smooth middle, light and flaky crust.  $1.60 each, $19.20 for 12.  

I've heard the stories that they close and open whenever they want, guess I've lucked out since they've been open every time I've been in the area.  Early on a Saturday, 30 minutes before close on a Sunday, lucky me!  At night probability is the line will be nonexistent.  

I wouldn't make the trek all the way to Chinatown just for the tarts, but when in Chinatown...I'm definitely getting the tarts. 

P.S. Cash only folks
author: Emmeline C.

description:
5 stars for the egg tarts.  I despised them growing up but it's probably because they were not as delicious as the ones from Golden Gate Bakery.  The custard has the perfect consistency.  The incredible demand for them probably helps since this place keeps churning out fresh egg tarts from the time they open to the time they close.  I score a warm/hot egg tart every time I managed to snag one.  The crust is out of this world.  It's flaky and not dense.  They must use real butter or lard.

4 stars for the lao po bing (wife cake).  I was not a big fan of the filling but that might be due to the difference between the Cantonese version and the Taiwanese version that I'm used to.  It was fresh, just not what I anticipated.
author: Amy J.

description:
Ok, so I know this stuff is amazeballs with it's fresh, warm, silky smooth custard and their perfect textured thin crust BUT...

I'm all about the crust.  I use to purchase $5 apple pies from Safeway ONLY to eat the crust.  I use to take other people's unwanted crust from pizzas and eat it.  Yeah, I'm that person.  So for my egg custards, I like the thick flaky crust.  Don't get me wrong, this was good and all, and I would give it 5 stars if I weren't such a snob... I just like my crust.
author: Linda N.

description: Melt in your mouth, hot and delicately crispy egg tarts that are far superior to any others I've tasted in the U.S.  Well worth the wait - eat one immediately if it's warm when you get it in your hands - you'll likely swoon, shove the whole thing in your mouth, high-five whoever is next to you and reach for another one. The macaroons are good too but they pale by a lot to the star of the show, the egg tarts. Be warned - the place is often closed for vacation so call ahead first.
author: SK L.

description: This Golden Gare Bakery doesn't offer one of best egg tarts in Bat Area because they offer the best.  None of other egg tarts is nearly even half good as their egg tarts.  And the time you need to wait in line is also much longer and the price is also much more than other egg tarts.  Is an egg tart worth 1.85 dollar when you can find other egg tarts cost less than 1 dollar?  Well,it took me 45 mins to wait in line for these little yellow dudes.  Guess you already know the answer.
author: Jerry W.

description: If you go by this place and the line is less than 10 people, you must come in to get some of their world famous Custard Tarts. They sell them by the dozen for $21 currently. Since there is always a line, the tarts are always hot and yummy. Perfect for the walk around Chinatown. Cash only!
author: Gregg R.

description: YES, these infamous babies are indeed worth the hype. Flaky crust, smooth custard, nice/warm/fresh out of the oven. They are amazing! If you are lucky to catch them when they're open (rare) and not on vacation (often), you MUST go in and buy as many as you can! That's my strategy at least!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
This place is strange bc they think they can do whatever they want - like be closed on April fools day/ the entire month of April. The strange part was that someone answered my call on a day they were closed. ?_? 

I can't get over their egg tarts though. The 5 star goes to the egg tart, not their business model or location/decor. The place looks pretty dingy and the rest of the pastries do not look appetizing at all. The egg tart, however, is always really warm and fresh with perfect filling concentration and crust flakiness. Remember - CA$H only!
author: Juliana P.

description:
If you're really lucky, you might be able to catch them when their line is on the shorter end. I am a local to SF and have walked by this bakery line so many times; I have only ever waited in line when it seems reasonable enough of a wait. That being said, my experience with the long wait hasn't been too bad. 

The egg tarts themselves are nothing short of amazing. From the first bite, the warm egg custard melts in your mouth while the crust is perfectly buttery and soft. The ratio of crust to egg is perfect. I think this place holds the best egg tarts in the city and if you aren't here all too often, I would make a stop if time permits in your schedule. 

TIP: Bring cash for payment! Call in to check their opening time and hours
author: Grace Z.

description: The line is worth the wait! Delicious egg tarts. Does not take credit cards - be sure to bring cash!
author: Heidi W.

description:
Drove all the way to Chinatown from fishermen's wharf for this bakery because we wanted dessert! 

I was so excited because so many people yelped about this bakery and it was 4.5 stars!!

Unfortunately when I went they were closed!!!! I was so sad!!! They were closed because they were on vacation!! What!!!

I will definitely have to try this place whenever I go to San Fran again. It's such a shame that I didn't get to try this bakery out instead I had to settle for some dim sum/bakery place because I wanted egg tarts... Sigh...
author: Kathlyn D.

description: Me and my friends were in Chinatown area and we wanted to get some yummy egg tarts and moon cake. I been here in the past and it been a long time since I came back here. The line was really long. We finally got into the store after an hour wait. It a really small bakery. It a mom and pop shop so this place is unique and rare. There wasn't much left of stuffs to choose from since it the end of the year. I got two egg tarts and lotus seed moon cake. The egg tarts were hot and fresh out of the oven. It was very good. The moon cake was okay not as good as the egg tarts. I think maybe the other moon cake flavor would be better. Parking is hard since it condense in Chinatown so best to park a little  further and it will be easier to get out later on. The services was alright. I will be back again if I'm in the area for yummy egg tarts. I need to try the other items as well. This place at times doesn't open so it best to call before heading over there.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Here's the deal: they make awesome egg custard tarts (dan tat). I personally have not tried any of their other pastries, so these 5 stars belong to the dan tats alone.

There is almost always a queue here. And this place is not always open or hours are inconsistent. Luckily, all but one time, this place has been open when I've stumbled through.

The storefront is pretty small and can only fit a handful of people inside. You need to know what you want to order before you get in because this is a hustle and bustle type of place. Don't hold up the line by trying to figure out what you want and asking hella questions. Also, if its the end of the night and theyre taking orders for how many dan tats you want, don't argue with the ladies saying you want more than what they can offer to make sure everyone has enough. I'm sure they don't care how far you drove for it (no offense).

For all the reviews complaining about customer service (which are the only negatives you'll see in the non 5-star reviews other than the inconsistent hours), you need to understand the kind of establishment this is. This is not their priority and even if you try to knock 'em on yelp, they have a loyal enough fan base that this will not affect them or compel them to change their ways. It really is good enough to forgive the service.

The egg tarts are always piping hot out of the oven when you go in. They are best served that way IMO. Exterior is perfectly flaky and the filling is sweet and creamy. To me, it's perfect. I would happily wait for these, especially if i'm especially craving. They are $1.75 each (and I believe $21 for a dozen).
author: Josephine T.

description:
Got a fresh a straight out of the oven egg tart. So worth the wait! 

A must stop in Chinatown!

You will not be disappointed.
author: Crystal B.

description: I don't get it. Rarely open, long lines, rushed and rude service, and very underwhelming pastries. I just don't get it. It tastes like egg whites with a sprinkle of sugar. I expected it to be creamy and sweet but instead it tasted like breakfast. They should have the menus posted on the windows so you can decide before you're at the register.
author: Chris B.

description:
Many have come from near and afar and failed to gain hold of the legendary egg tart of Golden Gate Bakery, while others have fortunately obtained its delicious pleasures. After years of hearing so much about this holy grail of a tart, I set out on a serious mission in search of it in the midst of Chinatown. 

I call this: Operation Egg Tart

Now, from many people, I've heard so many stories of how Golden Gate Bakery is always closed or the hideous lines that snake around the block. So, in order for me to combat some of these perils, I decided to do a bit of research to ensure my mission. 

Google, duh. 

I Googled their location and hours which stated that they were open every day from 8am to 8pm. I thought to myself, "Why was everyone having such a hard time?" These are like prime hours, even for those who have to rush after work to get these coveted bites. 

So I drove to Chinatown to attempt my first bite of these famous tarts. Anyone who has been to Chinatown definitely knows that parking anywhere in or near this area can be a beast. BUT, I did manage to find a discreet metered spot just around the corner. 

The stage was set... A cold, gloomy day, a tad windy with a slight drizzle of rain throughout. The streets were crowded with people with open umbrellas. I slipped through the streets with strong intention. Even in the dampened air, I caught a whiff of sweet smelling breads baking. As I looked up, I suddenly caught sight of the storefront. 

As I hurried to the doors, I noticed that the bakery itself had gated windows, door shut, lights dim. There was even a sign out front that said they were out for vacation. I began to hang my head thinking that I too have failed this mission. 

I kept my eye on the store with a longing heart as I stood under a canopy of another store. Then ever so carefully, a man dressed in a suit approached the door and knocked. An older Chinese woman appeared at the door and stuck her head out. The man stated something in Cantonese and handed her money. She then closed the door and soon reappeared with a few pink boxes. 

Oh M Gee

I sprang to the door before she was able to close it. She then looked at me and simply stated, "How many would you like?"

So excited, I could hardly get the words out. "I would like a dozen egg tarts, please." She then replied, "OK, $21 cash only."

Cash? Noooooo! I only had my credit card in hand. I have come too far to fail now. I quickly looked around in a panic and noticed Chase Bank ATMs directly across the street. Oh how the stars have aligned for me that day.

Eureka!

In ninja like action, I was at the ATM and back across the street in an instant. Thankfully I had an extra dollar in my pocket and happily forked over the $21 bucks.

I couldn't wait another minute. I quickly opened the box, snapped a quick photo (you guys know what's up), and bit right into the prized tart. 

Sweet mother of dandelions! It was everything I had hoped for and more. Soft, flaky crust, warm gooey, eggy center, with a kiss of sweetness. 

Operation Egg Tart was a complete success.
author: Ann S.

description: My family and I have been patronizing this place for years. We still wait in line for an hour for the custard tarts and moon cakes. This place now opens whenever they feel like it and after waiting patiently to order, the old Chinese lady who handles the money yells at you for whatever she feels like. It felt like she could care less whether or not you return to give them business. This is not the first time I've seen her be disrespectful and after over 30 years of giving her business I will not be returning again. Very disappointing.
author: Darah D.

description:
Yum yum I like.

Having heard the hype about GGB for a long, long time, I was pretty thrilled to stumble upon it actually open for once this past Saturday. I've learned to take a zen approach to this--never seek out GGB, let it seek you. Rather than making the mistake of going to Chinatown in search of their delicious egg tarts and expecting it to be open, this time I stumbled into Chinatown with no purpose but to explore and was greeted by a big crowd of people right after I passed Jackson St. 

I waited in the line for maybe about half an hour? It wasn't too bad. It was pretty fun getting to chat with the people around me to hear about best practices in the egg tart acquisition industry. Anyways, time flew by and I was soon at the counter. So one tricky thing that I noticed about ordering at this place is that you need a nice repertoire  of your Asian pastries before you get in. Unlike other bakeries where the goods are out for display, these goods are hidden away in baking pans in the back or covered away in sheets, so you better study up and be ready to request. 

This process made me realize that I do not know any Chinese pastries in English. I got 9 egg tarts, 2 buo luo bao (bread with sweet flaky topping), 4 sa qi ma (sweet rice cake thing), and one of those vanilla flavored roll cakes. Total was only 25.50! I love how cheap Chinatown is. 

The rundown:

egg tarts--sweet buttery flakes of deliciousness. They come out hot and the sides melt in your mouth and are so delicious!! They're also pretty big and filling. pro tip you can leave them in the fridge for a few days. just turn your oven on to 250 and bake them a bit to warm them up

buo luo bao--yum, pretty good. loved how soft the bread was, though not sure if it's super amazing

sa qi ma--pretty good, though I'm no connoisseur of this--this was for mama Xu

vanilla cake--yummy as well!

Basically. The wait is worth it if you like good Asian pastries, though if you aren't picky you probably wouldn't be able to tell the difference I do think this place caters much better to people who speak Chinese obv or know their Chinese pastries since ordering is a lot easier that way. They do have English menus taped on the counters but my Chinese upbringing didn't prepare me to try to buy pastries in English. 

tldr; super cheap delicious yummy pastries! they're never open though.. so pro tip is to definitely always call ahead
author: Jasmine X.

description:
It's been ages since I've been here! I recently moved to the East Bay so I shall be visiting this place more often now that I am close by. It's been probably more than 3 years since I've had the egg custard tarts here and they still are just as delicious. It's always pipping hot and just came out of the over. It definitely hit the spot!

Each piece is $1.75 and a dozen is $21.00. They also have other items but most people come here for the egg custard tart. There was a long line today and the wait was definitely not short, but it was worth it once you bite into that hot delicious tart. 

The front of the shop is run by 3 ladies who are all very friendly and nice. This is the go to place if you want egg custard tarts in San Francisco. Be patience and you will be rewarded with something delicious.
author: Sheila K.

description:
I refuse to hop on this golden gate bandwagon!!. There are endless flaws to this bakery and I'll tell you why.

-Inconsistent hours of operation. Opens late, closes early, closed half day, closed all day, closed all week. Strange, there was even a weekday when they were opened 4p-8p. Call ahead of time! Don't assume it's open the day after it's closed. Swear they stay on vacation year-round.

-Inconsistent menu. Call ahead of time and ask for product availability. I finally came on a day as soon as the hour and minute of opening. All they had were egg tarts (still baking in the oven) and moon cakes collecting dust on the nearly empty shelves. Where my walnut pound cakes at tho... Why open if you have nothing to offer..?!? 

-Limited quantity of purchase. You never know when they'll refuse the right to sell you more than one of anything, or anything at all. Even if you've waited in a half hour line.
 
-Terrible location. Little to no chance you'll find parking in the alleyways of SF Chinatown. The trek up this place via public transport is not worth it either. The bakery itself is so tiny that they may not even let you inside. They'll take your order from the door depending on their mood.

-Worst customer service. If they don't have change, they'll waive their hands up say thank you and move on to the next customer. 

-Overpriced. AND IT'S NOT THAT GOOD. Why in the world would I pay $1.75 for a mediocre egg tart?? Yes it may be due to the fact that they're always piping hot out of the oven. But if you intend to bring a dozen home for your family n friends (for a whopping $21...) then I suggest you not. The egg tarts taste terrible once you've journeyed back home till they're cold and soggy. Even worse when you try to toast them back up in a convection oven. Just go to your local Chinese bakery or dim sum restaurant for egg tarts. Please.

**I do enjoy their walnut pound cake. It's super crumby and the perfect flavor. For almost $7 a loaf that you can't get elsewhere, I'd take a few if I was already in the area.**
author: Mandy L.

description:
Sunday June 21, 2015 at 8am OPEN!!!!

Third time is the charm. Came here two other times. First time, June 17th, saw the closed for 2 days sign. Second time, June 18th at 8am, the cashier yelled from inside, "open at 3pm". Finally, today at 8:10am, i was the first to get my egg tarts!!! Cashier said the closed sign is for their convenience. 

Crispy crust all around and creamy custard filling. Very good! I would say the crust is the best, never a crust so crispy, but the filling, I've had similar. Together, they make a great egg tart!
author: Ellen C.

description: Anyone who has been here should love their DonTots. Anyone who hasn't, needs to come by. Look for the line out the door and get into it. The shop is small and it'll take anywhere from 20 to 40 minutes to get inside. Once you're in, order a dozen and don't be too shy to try some of the others yummies too!
author: Dexter D.

description: Egg tarts are orgasmic, as long as you don't mind waiting in line for an avg of 20 min.
author: Daniel V.

description: To be honest I was sooo hyped up over getting the egg tarts here but came out with a bit of disappointment. It was about a 1.5hr wait in line and turned out the custards are suuuuper expensive. Idk I love egg tarts, but because of the wait and price I thought these would be OUT OF THIS WORLD.. They were okay. They were freshly made and all which was nice. But man I was so excited to get that foodgasm but it just didn't happen for me. Maybe my expectations were too high and hyped up. But yeah, I guess I'm glad I experienced it, but probably not gonna be coming back again
author: Dana D.

description: This is our second time here, first time they were closed and this time they were open, in San Fransisco you can't tell if stores here are open or closed because they go on vacation a lot. Got here around 12:30 and waited at least an hour in line. I could totally tell the egg tarts were fresh, because they would constantly bake new egg tarts, so people would wait even when they are inside the store. I heard that they only make 2000 egg tarts a day, and people would buy at most 2 dozens. We got a dozen egg tarts and yup they were good, they were the best I've tried in the US so far. The egg custard was soft and not too sweet, the way I like it. The crust was really good, not too flaky and just right. Would definitely recommend to try at least once.
author: Rachel L.

description:
YES the egg tarts here really ARE that good!!

Both times I've tried to come here, the place was unfortunately closed. I guess they aren't always open even though Yelp says they're open 8am - 8pm everyday. But I FINALLY got to try these legendary egg tarts when a coworker brought a bunch to work one day, and they were legit the best egg tarts I've had. The crust is perfectly thin, buttery, crispy and flaky, and the custard filling is smooth and silky with just the right amount of sweetness. The egg tarts are pretty big too. They taste light and delicate, but unfortunately, that doesn't mean they're any healthier than other egg tarts..

I haven't tried any of their other pastries but their egg tarts are a MUST. That is, if you can catch them while they're actually open.
author: Jessie L.

description:
We tried to go to several other bakeries, but everything was closed. We saw a big line outside of this one and figured we'd try it.

The line moves very slowly. Everyone is there for egg tarts. They cook two big trays at a time and it takes about 8-10min for each batch. Some people come in and order several dozen and slow it way down. However, this means the egg tarts are hot and fresh.

The egg tarts ($1.95) were fantastic. I didn't know what they were, but I figured they must be worth the hype. We were there late in the day (7pm), so everything else was sold out. 

Cash only. 4 stars because of how slow the line is (40+ min).
author: Will C.

description:
This place is getting extremely over rated, and I felt gypped!

Do not believe their Yelp hours. They make so much money that they open whenever they want. Call ahead and if you're lucky, they might pick up and tell you what time they're open. And even if they do tell you, they might be lying...true story! They told me they're opening at 11:00 a.m. on a Sunday morning. Waited outside at 10:45 a.m., line started appearing behind us soon after, but they didn't open till 11:30 a.m.

And guess what? They don't let people in! They literally open the door, ask what you want, tell you the price, go inside, pack your order, take your money and give you your order. There's really no time for any other questions or browsing. You either know what you want, or tough luck. There's also the pressure of all the people behind you who makes you feel rushed.

Egg tarts are $1.75 and walnut pound cake is roughly $7. I'm just estimating because I initially ordered 6 egg tarts and the lady said, "$10 something!", and ran back inside. Added 3 walnut pound cake and she came out and said, "$30.10!". We gave her $31 and she went to the next customer and asked for their order. Not that we expected 90 cents back, but what? Lol okay Golden Gate Bakery, I see you.

The egg tarts are tasty when they're fresh; I usually put them in the oven the next day but the outside doesn't get crispy anymore. Walnut pound cake use to taste better; it's kind of crumbly now, but still soft/fluffy. I like how it's not too sweet. I don't know if they're worth all this trouble, but I guess I would recommend if it you've never had it or you're not from the area.
author: Michelle L.

description:
3.5 

Egg tarts. Apparently that is what Golden Gate Bakery got really famous for.

I wasn't exactly sure how big or how far their popularity has gotten until all of my friends started to talk about it when I mention "San Francisco." Being born in San Francisco and being raised a good portion of it within Chinatown, I could definitely tell you that "Golden Gate Bakery" does not ring as loud when I was younger. 

The only other memory of having egg tarts from Golden Gate Bakery was about four years back. That is assuming that I haven't had it as a kid or maybe I did but didn't know it was from there. They didn't have a long line and I was just passing by. I've heard about it but the scale of their popularity never hit me at the time. I decided to get some egg tarts since the lady told me that it was fresh from the oven. At the time, I paid about $1.25 for each egg tart. Even then, according to my grandmother, their prices have raised drastically. 

On a recent trip back to San Francisco to pay my grandmother a visit, I decided to try Golden Gate Bakery again. I wasn't sure if they were going to be opened because they have this habit of just going on vacation whenever they desire. Due to a helpful tip on Facebook, we found out that they were opened. We went straight there. There was a line (go figure). The line definitely attracted people. Tourists that didn't even know about the bakery decided to stand in line because there were so many people there. He said, "I'm not sure what I'm standing in line for but I just have to since it looks so popular here." Of course I had to tell him that he had to get the egg tart since that's what they are known for. Haha. 

It was probably a 20 minute wait for me. A dozen of egg tarts will run you $21.00 while if you bought them separately, they were $1.75 each. Wow. Holy price raise. It probably doesn't seem like a high raise but for egg tarts? For a bakery? Yes, it is quite the increase. 

I ate one, boyfriend ate one, gave my friend two of them, and gave the rest to my grandmother and her friends. Her friends also made a comment on how much the egg tarts were. I can't say I'm mind blown. I can say that they were done well and the custard is not overly sweet, which is very much appreciated. A plus is that they are fresh but how can they not be? With the amount of business and turn over rate, they better be fresh! However, I can't say that I'm in love and I can't say that I would do that again. On top of it, they were rushing out orders like mad so I'm not sure how careful they are with the actual product. The egg tart that I had was a little overdone so it was a little more cooked on the edges, which led to a small burnt flavor to it. I do believe that I liked the ones I got four years ago versus the ones I got this year. Plus, I like mini egg tarts more than full sized ones :P 

Oh, CASH ONLY. Don't get in line without it. But no worries. There is a Chase across the street, like a five second walk, and there is a Citibank down the street or something.
author: Doriee D.

description: Would you wait 1.5 hours for a wild tastebud ride? I did. The wait is actually agonizing as you watch people walk out with the famous pink pastry boxes. You'll frequently question what could possibly be taking so long. It should only be an in and out kind of ordeal right? Well I can tell you that the reason the line exists is because they are literally bringing up fresh egg tarts that have just finished baking, tray by tray, every 15 minutes or so. These are the real attraction and the sole cause for the line. There are a bunch of other offerings like mochis and rice cakes but you can't leave without picking up an egg tart. Walking out with warm egg tarts is honestly one of the best feelings in the world...obviously second to actually putting one in your mouth. The crust is perfect - it isn't insanely flaky (a symptom that often accompanies dryness), it's buttery, and slightly chewy. The custard is smooth and sweet without being overbearing. They were even good room temp or heated up the next day.
author: Emily L.

description:
Amazing egg tarts :D They are fresh and hot when you get them. The crust is flaky and the custard is perfectly cooked. 

The lo poh bing (wife's pastry) is pretty good and popular (I kept seeing the tray get replaced while standing in line). It was a bit too flaky for my liking and I wished there was a higher filling to pastry ratio.

Line varies. I've been here when it took only 5 mins, and when it's taken over 30 mins. Just depends on the people in front of you and how much they order lol :)
author: Jessica Y.

description: Pretty good egg tarts-not sure if i would wait over an hour for them again. I think the fun of it was in not knowing when they were going to open, but that flame quickly faded.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I love this bakery, but I hate that it seems like every time I come here, either there will be no wait, they are randomly closed, or the line is ridiculously long (and I never know which it's going to be!!).

The bakery is very popular so there tend to be long lines. They also seem to take random vacations and post a little paper on the door, so you don't find out until you get there.

Other than that, the baked goods are delicious! They're a little on the pricey side compared to other bakeries close by, but delicious really good. Here are some of my favorites / must-haves each time:
* Egg Tart: the egg tarts here are really delicious, especially right when they come out fresh and hot. The crust is flaky and delicious, and the custard is so warm and creamy. They can run out near the end of the night though!
* Banana Mochi/Cake (?): This is like a round stick of banana flavored mochi, about the size of your finger. Worth trying if you like banana and mochi!
* Mochi: They have mochi with different fillings, and it's super chewy and yummy!
* Baked custard buns: Nothing super special about them at this particular place, but very delicious.
* Spongecake Cupcakes: fluffy and yummy
author: Tiffany J.

description:
Born and raised in SF.  I have always visited this place when I was a little Marshal and wanted some quality food.  ..   It is a "no thrill, No chills" place. They just serve high quality food.

Quality of Egg Tart [ Dan Tat]:   5++ out of 5
Perfect heating and superb crust
Perfect balance of egg and custard
The egg tart melts in your mouth, not in your hand.

The custard is tasty and the shell holds the custard up and stand up well on its own from a "taste and crispiness" perspective.
Best bang for the buck ($2.00) .

Quality of Sponge Cake: 5++ out of 5
Perfect cake (soft and tender)
Best bang for the buck.

Quality of Mooncake: 5++ out of 5
Best bang for the buck.

Some one asked me what are the secrets behind their quality.  I believed that their ingredients and their baking process are the two parts of their secret sauce that makes their food superb.

The wait is long.  Get there early.  The quality of good is worth the time and the price..

Their food goes well with some green tea from Red Blossom Tea (They are also located at Grant Avenue.),
author: Marshal L.

description:
Went at 430 on Saturday and waited in line for 20 minutes. Heads up, they only take cash! 

We got egg custards and one sesame ball.  To be honest I'm not the biggest fan of egg tarts, but this was really good - fresh out of the oven, crust perfectly flaky, egg custard piping hot with the right amount of subtle sweetness and the egg flavor, was there but wasn't overwhelming. The sesame ball was also fresh and had that great glutinous rice sticky texture with a crunchy toasted sesame seed coating. There was also the typical red bean? Lotus seed? Filling inside as well. I thought it was worth the 20 min wait, though if I had to wait much longer might not have been willing to.  But overall was really good :)
author: june k.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery - the most famous egg tart and wife cakes in San Francisco Chinatown. There are other places that have the same things... but somehow people just love waiting in line to get their $1.75 egg tarts.... yup, the price went up!! Ridiculously expensive as heck!!! There are a lot of tourists lining up there. 

The last time I went there, I waited in line for an hour and even met a husband, wife, and their 4 month old baby. It was a really, really cold night too. 

The are rumors that they use pig lard or pig oil and that is why it tastes so good. I don't know if that's true... but all I know is everytime I go, they're CLOSED. 

YES. CLOSED!!!! But they've been opened for a few days already and not sure why the line is still SOOOOOOOO long. 

Their banana roll cakes are really good too... if you like that stuff.. it's very chewy and soft, it's not hard like in some of the places in Chinatown. 

Back to the egg tarts - the outside of the tart is very flakey.. and the inside is very soft. If you don't finish your egg tart, you can always stick it in the oven and it'll be like you just got it. 

I believe it's cash only...........
author: Eugenia W.

description: Calling ahead is a must since they don't follow the hours on their yelp page. Just called today (Nov 13, 2017) and they said their on vacation until December :(
author: Alma E.

description:
Dear Golden Gate Bakery Jerks,

Thank you for absolutely ruining other egg tarts for me.  I've hesitantly tried other egg tarts from places closer to home, and because your egg tarts are so flaky and custardy, nothing else can compare.  You have effectively ruined other egg tart establishments for me - so thanks.  

Is your pastry dry and tasteless? No.  is your custard too eggy or over-cooked? No.  Why do you do it? Why must your egg tarts be so goddamned perfect? I went to my local dim sum joint last weekend, and the waiter asks me and I want something sweet to finish the meal, "Maybe the egg tarts?", he suggests.  Nope, couldn't do it.  I already knew that everything would fail in comparison.

And you want to know the worst thing about Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts? They're so freaking good, that one day you'll be like, "Hmm, maybe I should try other stuff here?"

Salted Egg Yolk Moon Cake? Delicious! 

Red bean-filled Gluten Balls? Delicious!

Curry Beef Bun? Delicious!

Sesame Balls? Also delicious! 

All kidding aside, this place is pretty great.  I wanna take away stars because parking is an absolute nightmare here (virtually non-existent - don't bother driving. Actually, have someone drive you and circle the block) and more often than not, you need to queue.  

Lastly, everyone who's been here can see that their receipts tend to be written on loose scratch paper and with Chinese characters.  Can you imagine a tax auditor coming in and trying to make sense of these every April?  Pretty hilarious to think about, especially given that this place is cash only.  -- But I suppose it's for the best that this place is cash only.  If they take credit card, I'd probably order more delicious pasties with  reckless abandon!
author: David D.

description:
I am in a love-hate relationship with this place. Of the six times which I have visited, I succeeded in conquering some delicious egg tarts twice. Consistency? Non existent.

After waiting in line for 40mins amongst a cluster of hungry pastry lovers, we finally managed to walk away with half a dozen egg tarts. They have done the contrasting texture well. Sinking my teeth into some soft, cloudy-like wibbly wobbliness, delicate, creamy and warm (a little too warm that my tongue protested in pain) filling, which is juxtaposed against the buttery, flakey, slightly crispy crust was pure indulgence. My only complaint about the dan tat is that the bottom should be lightly toasted, in this case it was not (probably due to the ridiculous high demands.) 

The reason why this I am only offering three stars is the lack (or rather, barely existent) of customer service. Three ladies hustle and bustle their way behind the counter, yelling "NEEEEXT." It was my turn. As I was about to order, one of the ladies snarled at the other (in Cantonese), "are these people all deaf?! What is wrong with them?!" I stood in shock and turned. Behind me stood a Mandarin speaking couple happily chatting away and behind them, a cheery caucasian family. They had absolute no idea that the comment was directed at them. "You!" The same lady shot a word at me and I suppose that was my indication to order. My initial excitement plunged. I quickly placed my orders and escaped the crowd. 

Although the egg tarts were divine, I will probably not return for a long time - until the hours are more predictable; until the poor customer service episode eventually rust in my mind.
author: Vega N.

description: I don't usually eat Egg Tarts, but this bakery changed the game and made the most divine tarts I've ever tried. It's probably due to the buttery flaky crust, but the tart cream itself doesn't reek of egg like usual egg tarts. I'd rate this 5/5 stars if they accepted card. Other than that, it's a wonderful bakery.
author: Jamaica P.

description:
golden gate is always a conundrum, either they are randomly not open or the wait is RIDICULOUS, hence i've only tried it once after knowing about it for 5 plus years!

the wait today was only 20 minutes score! egg tarts were $18 per dozen or $1.50 each (for those of you who hate math, nope no discount if you buy more)
---egg tarts: HOT out of the oven! i actually tried one fresh and one a few hours later and i prefer the egg tarts after a few hours of cooling since the custard becomes creamier and you can enjoy the flakiness of the crust

they also sell other bakery items but i didn't try anything else

NOTE: Cash only
author: Jenny S.

description:
Food: if you're a fan for egg-tart, this will be a heaven treat for you. This place makes the BEST and I mean the BEST egg-tart ever. Sweet, hot, creamy that melt in your mouth. You can always guarantee there will be a line but don't worry, it goes by fast.
Atmosphere: small shop, there's no place to sit and chill. This is a grab and go sort of place. Cash over, no card.
Overall: best egg tart ever!
author: Dyala N.

description: Egg tarts are amazing,  Service is poor and the place is not as clean as it can be.  No dim sum and BBQ buns either.  So we ended up getting a dozen egg tarts for $27.00.  Egg tarts are very over priced yet very nice and warm too.
author: M L.

description:
If I could give them 3.5 stars I would only because the service is sooo slllooowwww... I want to get my hands on them delicious flakey egg tarts as soon as I can damn it!

If you're in Chinatown San Francisco and are debating whether Golden Gate Bakery is worth waiting in line to try, the answer is yes.  Do it.
author: Tien L.

description:
So the legend is true - these egg tarts are truly the BEST egg tarts in California, if not the best in America.

Golden Gate Bakery is hidden in the middle of San Francisco Chinatown. The legend also has it that the line is incredibly long. Luckily, there was absolutely no line when we came here around 3 PM on Saturday. Oh, cash only!

Egg tarts were fresh out of oven and its flaky crust was out of this world - how can an egg tart be this flaky and did not crumble apart at all??? Trust me, $1.50 for a such beautiful egg tart is a real steal. 

A must visit San Francisco destination.

P.S. (IMPORTANT) - There's a Facebook page called "Is the Golden Gate Bakery Open Today?" (https://www.facebook.com/pages/Is-the-Golden-Gate-Bakery-Open-Today/394882013908745) because the bakery owners constantly close the store for 3~6 months of vacations.
author: Luke L.

description: Been here three times, and two times they were open, Yay!  Yesterday was Christmas eve so when we got there the line into the Bakery snaked around the front of the entrance.  It was about a 30 minute wait. You have to wait because they bake in small batches. At least you know you will have hit fresh egg tarts. Be nice to the ladies, they can only sell you what is available.
author: Garry Y.

description: Egg tarts are truly amazing, there's a reason why this place is famous for it. Hours are on/off, they can randomly be on vacation. It's a small little shop, but they surely are cranking out those egg tarts along with other sweets. If you ever get the chance, I do recommend coming here!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
We saw the numerous Yelp reviews and decided that this is a must visit for the Dan Tat's. 

These Dan tat's should be called bomb tat's because they're so freaken good!!! They're by far the best I've ever tasted. The crust is crisp, flaky, and buttery. The custard is rich, sweet, and there is plentiful to create a perfect custard to crust ratio. And one of the most important factors is that they are not dry! Other cheap Dan tat's don't even compare. The hype is real!!! 

Side story - The only thing that I was able to try was the Dan Tat's only because my girlfriend pre-ordered and called in at around 9am the morning we wanted to pick them up. The man on the phone was friendly and asked how many we wanted so we told him 7. They were kind and charged us $1.75 for each, totaling $12.25. The man told us to get there at around 2-4 pm but to call at around 1 pm to confirm that we would for sure be there. We called back at 1 pm to confirm our order and then went to the store at 2 like they said and they gave us the Dan Tat's.

The funny thing is that they have a sign saying "we are closed for vacation," although they really aren't. The owners are just chilling inside. I even saw one lady go inside (probably a friend/good customer) after knocking several times and speaking Chinese. Also, after we got our order of Dan Tat's a whole bunch of people started to crowd and line up to get some as well because they saw it was open. 

TLDR: good dan tat's, call in advance to pre order the morning before, eat them to your satisfaction!
author: Allen Y.

description:
I have tried several times in recent year to get egg tarts and their door is always closed.  One customer was found staring at their doorway and remarked to another customer that "they open when they want to."  Jr. Yelper was in the area and brought home a box of the egg tarts or the family because the shop happened to be open on a week night. 

I have a friend who told me she knows the owner and that they travel a lot.  Guess business is so good that they don't need to be open for business on a regular basis. 
The custard in their egg tarts is good, but not as good as the ones served at Yank Sing Restaurant. However, it's a better price at $2.80 for a large tart.  The inside is silky, smooth and jello-like. The crust is flaky and flavorful.  If not for the inconsistent days of business and long waits, I'd give it 4 stars.
author: Ry T.

description: Ahhh my fAvorite place in all of San Francisco! The best tourist spot out of all the places. The egg tarts are soooooo good here. They come out warm and taste custardy. The consistency is somewhat of flan with  taste of vanilla cheesecake?! Anyway I still have dreams about eating their egg tarts again. They are the best!
author: Lily K.

description: 3/5 we came here, they are always close /on vacation . Definitely the best egg tart (very crusty shell and less sweet egg custard). Getting 12 every time we are here. Share the happiness cause why not ?!
author: Hester D.

description: Met some very nice people in line while waiting for fresh egg tarts, and you will wait. Came by the bakery probably 2-3 times while in San Francisco and there was always a line waiting to get in. The group in front of us drive into the city for the entire extended family, buy 6-8 dozen at a time, then distribute them when they get home. Not a connoisseur of egg tarts, by any means, as this was the first time that I had them, but it was very good fresh out of the ovens. Crust was super flaky and the custard was just hot enough to make you want to take in some cold air with each bite, but not so hot as to where you wanted to wait for it to cool down before eating it. Worth a stop when you are in China Town.
author: Ed M.

description:
Their egg tart is pretty famous in NorCal, and we got so lucky that they were open on Black Friday because they take random vacations or just close for no reason quite often, as stated by the locals. 
The line was not that long and moved fairly quickly.
Make sure to bring cash and some extra cash because they rose their prices to $1.75~ 
I was extremely displeased with the shop's attitude towards my group.
We ordered all together at a total of 10 to 12 and asked for separate boxes because we are gifting them and the lady working there gave us a glare and said "who gifts this small amount of egg tarts to anyone?" and kept insisting that we order more and she would not split the tarts into separate boxes.
Excuse me? Who the heck are you to be lecturing us about how many and how much we should be gifting to people. It wasn't even a joke, the worker was literally ridiculing us about how little we are gifting and still refused to give us an extra box. I did not understand Mandarin but I could just tell from the look that she was giving my friend that she was extremely grumpy and bring rude to my friend.
 I really did not enjoy my egg tarts that much because of the sour attitude we got from the lady working there. Yah the egg tarts taste more like a real egg and has a decent crust. But eating those egg tarts just reminds me of my experience there. Maybe I'll have to give this place another shot one day.
author: Judy L.

description:
Jerks.  

Their sign said open at 10 am. A long line had formed in front of the bakery. We saw activity inside so figured a few more minutes. 10:15 a person called on the phone and was told maybe we open at 11:00. Waited till 10:30 and gone. 

Other locals said the owners were always gone or closed.

Too many other great bakeries in san francisco. 

This bakery is 100% miss!
author: Loly H.

description:
This place is ahhhh-mazing!!! I really didn't think a bakery could have this many reviews about egg tarts, but these reviews are no lie. 

This bakery has been open for about 40 freakin' years.

They make their egg tarts fresh so that's why there's usually a wait. We bought a dozen for $21 and holy moly they were pipin' hot and fresh. 

The crust was so crispy and flaky. The egg custard filling was steamy and fluffy. They actually tasted like egg and there's a generous amount of filling. They don't skimp out!!! These golden egg tarts are a must have in Chinatown.
author: Maggie C.

description: Completely worth the 45 min wait for dan tat (egg custard tart). Every time I come to SF I make sure to visit! You won't be disappointed, I promise!!  Enjoy!
author: Cynthia K.

description: We have been here a few times.  You must try this place.  There is usually along line because the selections are amazing.   If you don't try the egg custard you will be sorry.  We had them right out of the oven.  Heaven!   I should have bought more.   They were insanely amazing.  The apple pie was great.  My advice - go wait in line and buy more than you think you should.   You won't be sorry.
author: David W.

description: Waited in line for about 20 mins before they opened to get the famous egg custard tart and was not disappointed! They were perfect and also the black bean moon cake was divine!!! I would recommend this place to anybody visiting the city we em if there is a line it totally worth it!
author: Cassandra T.

description: Waited 30mins on the 2nd day after they reopen from long vacation. A bit pricey $2.15 for their egg tarts, but super tasty.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Everything about this place is slightly comical. From the weird/gross (take a peek in the store and realize that it looks like an absolute dump) storefront to too-busy Asian ladies trying to get everyone their egg tarts, it's an interesting scene to say the least. 

After eating nearby, we decided to walk past Golden Gate Bakery after multiple attempts to catch it open in the past few months. After waiting in line for 30 minutes, I ordered half a dozen egg tarts. I didn't really know what to expect, as I've been to Hong Kong and have had "famous" egg tarts there multiple times. But these completely exceeded my expectations. What everyone says is true - these egg tarts are amazing. The crust is perfectly flaky, they're generous with the egg filling, and the entire pastry is just so well made. I can't get over how good these are; I'm just sad they open randomly whenever they want to. I feel silly gushing over egg tarts of all things, but these are next level egg tarts.

Keep in mind that they do run out of pastries, so to be safe you should get in line earlier than not (we went around 1pm which seemed to still be okay). I really want to try their "wife cake" next which they didn't have that day.

If you're still on the fence on whether you should wait in line for 1.75 egg tarts (yes, overpriced), stop deliberating and GO NOW.
author: Claudia C.

description:
Really? We got here at 8:00 am to see this sign and the lady opens the door As I asked her what time will you close 8:00? She said no maybe early don't know when.  I asked what time they will open Sunday tomorrow she couldn't tell me.  Wow very hit and miss here. 
Even with all the good reviews...I wait the line but they a either on vacation or not opened.
author: Toma C.

description:
Egg tarts on Egg tarts on egg tarts. This review is for the most recent visit.

30 min wait crammed outside the crowded streets which is filled with tourists curious on the hype. Smooth interactions with the cashiers as speaking the same language does help a lot when ordering. 

Egg tarts are excellent especially when it first comes out of the oven. Probably the best egg tart i've had in a while because the tart layers are so crisp and thick. You know its a GREAT egg tart when you eat one. The egg yolk part is thicker than most id say which makes a great balance tart to egg ratio.
