1.75 each with no discount if a dozen is bought because they know they're going to sell regardless. I'd say it's worth the wait once in a while because the location is chinatown is just away from most people. Overall, recommended to all egg tart lovers. Probably the best in SF.
author: Auden W.

description:
YELP 365 CHALLENGE 2014-(273/365) "The Gold Standard Of Egg Tarts?"

EGG TART SCRAMBLE-Stop # 3

You've read about the long lines and the random vacations that the Golden Gate Bakery takes every once in a while, right? Luckily for us, and thanks to the bride and groom, after our 10-course Chinese feast at R&G Lounge, a plate of Golden Gate Bakery's famous Egg Tarts were brought to each table!

No having to see if they were open for business or not, no standing in long lines, none of that!, just take one and pass it down. SWEET! I finally got to see  and taste what all the rave was about. So how was it? Well, to me, these were the best looking tarts by far with a nice flaky crust, BUT they had a more eggy taste than the other two we tried earlier(Anna, Eastern) which was fine by me. As I looked over at the lazy susan, I noticed that there were extra tarts, and before I could even consider getting another one, a couple of people on our table had already asked the waiter for take out boxes to box up the extras. NOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!

Oh well, at least I got to try them, I thought...When the reception was over and everyone else was heading to a nearby lounge to continue the festivities, no one wanted to take any leftovers home, so we became the designated leftover takers of about 10-15 pounds of Chicken, Peking Duck, Lobster, and Black Cod! There was also a pink box all by itself , full, and untouched of EGG TARTS which we gladly took home as well. Boy, was my frown turned upside down in seconds!  ALOHA!!!

Shaka Meter:  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  4
author: Nelson Q.

description:
This bakery has legit egg tarts - that was already been established by the thousands of reviews on here.

So I'm not going to talk about that. Instead I'm going to focus on my experience procuring these golden egg tarts, since it was a little bit unusual...

Before you visit, visit the FB page (https://www.facebook.com/pages/Is-the-Golden-Gate-Bakery-Open-Today/394882013908745) and make sure there aren't any posts about it being closed. It doesn't hurt to call them and check either.

Before I went on a Wed afternoon around 1:30, I did my homework and checked the FB page. According to that, it seemed to be open, so I headed over. 

However, when I got there, there was a "Sorry we are closed for vacation" sign and the door was closed. I was pretty crushed, understandably.

BUT as my friends and I were standing around mulling in our disappointment for a minute or so, an old lady opened the door and proceeded to hand someone else an order of egg tarts. She then took our order and told us it'd be about a 10 minute wait.

We ended up waiting about 30 minutes, but we walked away with 16 shiny egg tarts for $1.60 each!!

Moral of the story is - don't give up just because there is a closed sign out in front. They might still be taking secret orders if you wait for a little bit ^_^
author: Dianna H.

description:
*Sings* It's all about dan tat, about dan tat, about dan tat!

Shoot... I will never forget the love at first bite indulging myself with my first egg tart at Golden Gate Bakery. It was fun watching other pedestrians glare at my pastry with envy while I made approving facial expressions of how delicious it was. It was a glorious super cheat day moment, and taking all those high carbs had me at "YOLO!" I can't get enough of those savory eggy beautifully crusted fresh dan tats (also known as the egg tart.) Just thinking about them makes me want to do naughty sinful, gluttonous, and impulsive types of eating... IN THE DARK! (That way I won't feel so guilty for being super gluttonous...)

The line can be pretty long. It seems like the average customer waits about 5-15 minutes to order something fresh. However, I can promise you that wait will be worth all that time! A thing to keep in mind is that there is no picture taking or video recording allowed inside the bakery. (Probably they don't want someone stealing something? I don't know...) However, if you want to Yelp or Instagram that sexy little pastry, you will have to do it outside of the shop. 

Overall, this is a pretty neat shop, but you better get there before the clock strikes at 6 PM!
author: Aubrey D.

description: Excellent pastry and always a line down the street to get some, I always get custard cakes to go :)
author: Bobby P.

description: After seeing long queues and Yelp reviews we decided to give a try. We were neither impressed with the taste nor the customer service. Thier service is dead slow, that's the main reason for the long queues waiting outside. Also, we felt the mooncakes were overpriced and not impressed with the taste. This was the first time we tasted the mooncakes. Maybe the mooncake lovers might love the place. The place is little cramped and messy.
author: Baskaran D.

description:
Went there on a Sunday and the place was closed even tho it should have been opened. I even called the place and a person answered the phone and said sorry we are not open and wont be until Tuesday!  Like what the other folks said this place is hit and miss when it comes to time that its open. 

We asked the owner of the gift shop next door as to why the odd hours and they explained to us that it's always like that and surprisingly -- that they actually don't make the Yellow Custard's actually at that location and thats brought in from another source!! Imagine that!
author: John S.

description:
Finally!!!! After 3 attempts, GGB was actually OPEN. I was disappointed all of the other times I craved egg tarts and arrived only to see a "we're on vacation" note on the door. Just so we're clear, they're never really on vacation. They're just lazy AF!!!

Alas, it was open... Thank you, Buddha!

Waited in line at 11:30am... 20mins later, it was my turn. Let me just say, the lady who took my order was a smart-mouthed little b*tch. Pardon my french, but I speak cantonese and she was definitely a SNARKY old lady. 

After snapping back and forth, I finally get my egg tarts, quickly got my ass out of stinky Chinatown, whipped out an egg tart, put it in my mouth, and YES..... the rumors are true.... it was DELICIOUS! 

Although the experience was frustrating, I can say with confidence that I'll be back for more. Damn, it be like that sometimes...
author: Frances T.

description: What a bad experience! After I stand on line for 45 minutes, only to be told when I get to the end of the line that I can only buy one of the much talked about custard tarts, (i wanted a dozen) when I said "Ok, I'll buy one and my husband will buy another one." After an exchange in Chinese between two ladies at the counter, I was suddenly told I couldn't buy any. I was told "better luck tomorrow" sure, like that will happen. I felt like the soup Nazi episode from Seinfeld ... NO TART FOR YOU!!
author: Tairyn A.

description:
FINALLY it's open just in time for Thanksgiving! Woke up early (but not early enough) and called first to make sure it's open. It's only 10:15am and there's a line already  (and it's cold). This feels like a Black Friday...They say Patience is a Virtue... For the craving and love of Egg Tart! Lol
Originally going to buy a dozen only but heck if I'm staying in line waiting I'm getting 2 dozens!! 
They have other goodies too that I don't know the name but if you ask what's in it and sound delicious, buy it! I know I get "panic buying" lol.
The last time I bought the tart it was $16/dozen, the new price now is $21/dozen or $1.75 each. Tarts are fresh out of the oven every 3-5 mins and this lady brings out a tray each time only that's why I'm still in line and it's already 10:50am.
Finally got my 2 dozens of tart, 6 coconut mochi, 3 moon cakes, and 2 sesame balls (now you see what I meant of panic buying) lol and it's 11:00am...yes it took 45 mins waiting....was it worth it? Depends you you ask...for now...YES!!!
author: CJ B.

description: Other than egg tarts, the "wife cake" and the mooncakes, nothing else tastes good here. And it's pretty pricey too. Their hour of operations are according to their mood. Every time I come to visit SF, they are either on vacation or they are on vacation. Attempting to come to this place as a tourist is like trying to catch a rare Pokémon, it all depends on luck. Otherwise the egg tart is pretty good tho.
author: Berry P.

description: Egg tarts will never be the same again, these babies are sooooo delicious!! My parents, who are picky Chinese eaters, even said they were the best they've had, and this was after they made the trek through my flight back home. On top of it, all of the staff are super sweet and friendly.
author: Jenny C.

description: My buddy was in SF this past weeknd and brought back some of their famous Egg Tart pastries. Wow! Never had anything like it... Thanks Jon you wierdo!
author: Bryan M.

description: Get in line for the best egg tarts of your life. It is definitely a long wait, but it a worthwhile experience. The egg tarts are all fresh out of the oven. The crust is flaky, buttery and delicious. The creamy custard melts in your mouth as soon as you take a bite into it. No wonder why everyone falls in love with them. They also have a coconut egg tart, rolls and other baked goods available. You will never have an egg tart as good as from this bakery.
author: Camellia P.

description: Delicious egg tarts, but I haven't tried anything else here. I've been here a few times, sometimes with no line and sometimes with a huge line. It seems really variable, but worth the wait if the line isn't too crazy!
author: Cynthia M.

description: Each time I come here, no matter what time of day, if they are open, there is a line.  Fortunately the line moves so we wait an average 30 minutes.  We get the custard tarts which is what they are known for.  You can buy custard tarts (also called egg tarts) at many places.  What sets these apart is the crust.  It is still crispy, even at the bottom.  Tarts at other places tend to be mushy on the bottom.  Also, these have just the right amount of sweetness.  They are more expensive than other places but these are very good.  It is cash only.
author: Lily L.

description:
The egg tarts here are probably the best I've ever had. They were fresh hot from the oven - the egg custard was still oozing when we were eating them further down the block. I would love to give them five stars, except for 2 issues: 

- Unpredictable store hours. They are supposed to be open at 8am, but when we arrived at 10:45am they were still closed and a small handwritten note on the front door said it would open at 11am instead. Apparently they are notorious for this and for taking random days/weeks off. Understandable since they are a small family business but it's inconvenient for customers who make the commute to their storefront only to find it closed. I can't recommend calling in advance since they often don't answer

- High prices. The egg tarts were $2.25 APIECE. That's 2-3x the price from other restaurants and bakeries!! I can order a full 3-piece egg tart dish in a dim sum restaurant for that amount of money...
author: Constance C.

description:
TL;DR: Fresh egg tarts. Large. Delicious. 

Finally got to visit this place after many a times walking by and giving up due to the long lines. For a Sunday afternoon, it was surprisingly not crowded at all. Each dan tat (egg tart) is $1.75 I believe.

I gotta hand it to em, their egg tarts have something about them that makes them better than any other tart I've had. The custard had the right amount of sweetness and the exterior was flaky and delicate. It was also considerably taller than other ones I've had. Room for more custard!
author: Steven L.

description:
I've come here two years in a row all the way from Texas. And they have been closed for "vacation" both times. Enough said. 

Make that three years in a row and they are still closed for vacation. Pathetic. Will not try again.
author: Armanius M.

description:
Highlights of the 1.5 hour wait on Chinese New Year's Eve:

1) Shocking firecrackers being lit by inconsiderate vendors on Grant as people are walking by (yes I know it's tradition but it's just outright scary)
2) People getting excited when it's finally their turn and spent 20 mins deciding what else to buy in addition to egg tarts when you're anxiously waiting in the ever-increasing line
3) Relief of a successful order and sufficient fund for 3 dozens of egg tarts after 1.5 hours of wait
4) Slightly regret of not having one immediately as these gorgeousness were intended for a party the next day. 
5) Happiness the next day as these egg tarts are still DELICIOUS nearly 18 hours after

Lesson to self: never come on an Asian holiday
author: Nina T.

description:
I love the egg tarts here. Always call ahead just to make sure they're open. I'm not sure if the times on Yelp is wrong or if it's because of the holiday, but Golden Gate Bakery opened at 11 am over Lunar New Year weekend (and the following Monday). There's a minimal late if you come around 2 or 3 from my experience.

The egg tarts here are delicious and extremely rich! Super flaky and sweet. My mom is a fan of AA Bakery's more since she thinks it's too rich here, but I'm solidly in the GGB camp!
author: Amy B.

description:
My brother and I were in SF on Monday enjoying the great weather and unique eats.  Per several of my Yelp friends, we made sure to stop at Golden Bakery for their famous Egg Tarts.  I have to be honest.  I was really skeptical because I don't usually care for Asian sweets but I think it's because I never know what to order. 

We arrived around 2:30 and there was a line ... a pretty long line which we were prepared for. The wait wasn't to bad, maybe 20 minutes and while we waited we got to really take in the area and do some people watching. China Town is super colorful and filled with great restaurants, unique shops and LOTS OF PEOPLE!.
As we were standing there in line we couldn't help but notice we were the only Caucasians in line. Hmmm another good sign that this place is not only authentic but pretty tasty.  We watched the constant flow of people leaving carrying perfectly packaged pink boxes.  I'm talking 3 or 4 at a time!  And from what I could see, inside were those infamous little egg tarts.  Mouth watering ....

When it was our turn to order, I almost felt back only asking for two tarts when everyone else got boxes of them.  But since I haven't had great experiences in the past, I figured 2 was a good number to start with on this trip.  The nice lady at the counter packaged my tarts up in a little paper bag and out the door we went.  Um .... I'm not sure why I was so surprised but when I felt the bottom of the bag and realized these little handfuls of goodness were WARM I couldn't wait to eat them.  So I reached in and gently pulled out the little cup of warm goodness.

The crust was light and flaky.  The filling was bright yellow and OH SO GOOD!  Creamy, warm, sweet deliciousness. I'd compare it to a Cream Brule and warm vanilla pudding.  Now I understand the hype, the line and the desire to make this a permanent stop when we're in China town for sure.
 
The women at the counter are friendly and fast.  Bring cash because I didn't see anyone using credit cards nor a machine in sight. Don't get intimidated by the line outside or the lack of items on the trays in the window.  The line moves fast and there are plenty of delicious bites once you step inside this tiny little shop.  It's a bucket list stop for sure.
author: Christie B.

description: First off, I'd like to say that I am a pastry addict. I want to walk into every pastry shop I see. I love pastries! And I've had a lot of pastries! Golden gate bakery has the best egg tarts I have ever had in my life! Had to wait in line for 2 hours but it was sooooo worth it. Also, I really liked the custard twist bun? I think they called it a custard tart in Chinese even though it's not a tart. I was expecting the wife cookie to be "to die for" since it was $4 for one, but it was not that great, not even better than a mediocre Chinese bakery. I would not recommend it.
author: Kimmy H.

description:
It was mooncake season when I stopped by here early September. The line wasn't long, but the wait was still 20-25 minutes. Normally, I'm the type of gal to turn around and go home if I see a long wait time anywhere. Costco check outs? Yep, not waiting. Theme park rides, uhh fast pass please. DMV? Online renewal stat!!! You get the picture! So, why the heck would I wait in line for this place? Truth be told, I wanted the best mooncakes to take back home in order to serve at a family dinner. Thankfully, yelp steered me in the right direction and found me the right spot. Thanks yelpers!     

While in line, I was waiting outside wondering why the heck the line was moving was so slow. I erroneously equated old ladies to slow service that led to long lines. Well, when I finally entered the shop, I realized that I was so OFF! It's because all the people in front of me kept on ordering 5-10 boxes of mooncakes or 40 egg tarts. I didn't realize how serious this mooncake business was until the woman in front of me pulled out stacks of hundreds, WOW! Those grandmas were seriously wheeling and dealing!  I don't even know how they were able to work together in that cramped storefront. You had 2 ladies constantly restocking items, 1 lady taking care of to-go orders, and 2 taking care of the line. 

Anyway, when it was finally my turn the lady who helped me was very patient and kind. She answered any questions that I had and quickly packed up my items. I left with 4 mooncakes and 3 egg tarts(just to see what the hype was all about). I chose the mix nuts one with ham, 2 lotus one, and one with coconut, almonds, and melon(my fav choice!). All the flavors were delicious, even the ham one! At first I was like wtf am I buying and why did I get this crazy flavor? But it all made sense when I eventually tried a small piece. It really was a perfect balance of salt, sweet, and savory!  

I didn't get to eat my egg tarts until I got to the airport, but when I did I understood. It was like that silent bond you share with your bff; you just know. The funny thing is, I don't even like egg tarts that much! It turns out, I just haven't had the right ones yet. The crust was moist yet flaky, while the egg custard had a light flan texture with the right amount of sweetness. MMM! 

In the end, the wait was worth it because all my family members enjoyed the cakes. It was a perfect dessert for our family celebration!
author: Kady W.

description:
How good an egg tart can be?
This bakery's egg tart is the king of all egg tarts!!!
It is that good that I don't mind dealing with the busy Chinatown and the problem of trying to find a parking spot. The line is long most of the time, but I usually get 2 boxes minimum.
They only downside though, they often (or at least I feel it's often), they are closed for vacation. I live in Socal now, and the last time I went back to SF, they were closed :(
author: Candice L.

description:
You will never look at egg tarts the same way after you try Golden Gate Bakery's. This family business has been around for decades, and as someone who's grown up with their egg tarts, I am happy to say their quality has never wavered. The crust is crisp and flaky, contrasting nicely with the soft warm custard. It is best when fresh out of the oven, but you can always heat it up at home and it will taste just as flavorful. 

I hear their other pastries are good, although I've only tried the sponge cake, which is light and fluffy and not too sweet. Their hot milk tea is perfect for keeping you warm on a cold day, or any day tbh. 

They are often on vacation (considering how much money they make, I don't blame them) so you may have to visit multiple times before you catch them open, and when they are open, the line snakes down the block, BUT it is worth the wait! Many tourists are deterred by the long wait, deciding to come back "when there's no line." This only happens when they run out of egg tarts at the end of the day or when they're closed. So be patient and you will be rewarded :)
author: KC W.

description:
This is my 4th time in SF and the last 3 times I was here this bakery was closed (for vacation). I can't believe they're open this time I am here! Came here on a rainy Sunday at around 5p; the shop is small and very old school. I only got one egg tart and, luckily, it was fresh out of the oven. The lady asked if I was gonna eat it now, I said yes. She warned that its really hot and it will burn your mouth if you try to eat it immediately.

She's right. BUT IT WAS SO GOOD! The crust and the filling are perfect. Growing up I've always hated eating the crust, but this place's egg tart crust is phenomenal. The egg filling isn't too sweet and is very silky. I am so glad I got to eat this heavenly pastry .
author: ChingWa C.

description: Egg tarts! The freshest yet! Beware of the long lines that move rather slow but could be worth the wait. Nice, piping hot... Gotta eat them right away to experience the fresh warm egg custard along with the buttery crisp crust!
author: Tramy V.

description: Ok so I have to admit that this place does have the best egg tarts I've had, and I'm Chinese so I've had a ton of egg tarts from everywhere imaginable.  But since we've eaten everything this place as a whole, not just the egg tarts, I have to say everything else is just pretty average to be honest.  Their rolls are comparable to just about every other bakery, as is their wive's cookies (I think that's what it's translated to), banana rice rolls, and moon cakes.  So why only three stars?  Well, they're always on vacation, which is fine, but they should kind of have a schedule up on when they leave or are planning to, instead of just closing up abruptly.  I can only be a patron of an establishment if they're open for business so availability is kind of hit and miss.  If you're coming only for egg tarts, I think it's definitely worthwhile assuming they're open and the lines isn't 45 minutes long (which it usually is).
author: Charles H.

description:
We stumbled upon Golden Gate Bakery while walking through Chinatown. We were stopped in our steps by a giant line that had overtaken the sidewalk. When we saw that the line was for Golden Gate Bakery, we immediately joined the line. The bakery has unreliable business hours so to find that they were open, it was just good luck. I recommend calling the shop before making a trip out here. 

We, like many others, got the egg tart ($1.75). It's what the bakery is known for and it is tasty. It's served warm so be sure to enjoy it soon after you purchase it. There are other pastries and bites that are available, such as sesame balls and pineapple buns, if egg tarts aren't your thing.
author: Katie C.

description:
"Best I ever had" -Drake. He was clearly singing/rapping about GGB's dan tat. Literally though. Best egg tarts I have ever had. I have been a customer since I was a kid. This was my snack after the dentist (probably not the best for my newly cleaned teeth). But if I was going to be in Chinatown, I would not leave without one (or twelve). The price has certainly gone up over the years, but the quality and consistency have never faltered. Still so flaky, still so buttery (because lard-y does not sound very good), and so so so good. 

Yes, there will be some sort of line (or a very long one). But it's oh so worth it! 

Yes, they set their own hours and are always on "holiday." But it's oh so worth it!
author: Anna Z.

description: There was a little bit of a line coming here. The egg tarts were amazing! So fluffy, eggy and perfectly custardy... The egg tarts were nicely sized as well.
author: Stephanie F.

description: The hype is real!! I just ate two egg tarts for the first time here. Could go for one more lol the crust is perfect and flaky and the custard is really flavorful.
author: Diane L.

description: I would love to try this place, but it seems that fate is preventing it from happening. I came here twice to a closed bakery. The first time was back in July and today, I saw that a sign was on the door saying that they were closed for vacation.
author: Faye S.

description:
1 star for always being closed (on vacations)!  Most likely to open on Saturdays.
5 stars for not oily flaky crust, even after a few days.
3 stars for egg custard filling - too sweet and too watery.  Taste better after drying up for 2 days.
Being coming here for several times over the last 3+ years, I've finally able to buy the egg tarts here last Thursday.  The store was closed, but I was able to reach a woman and ordered a pickup after calling for one whole afternoon.  She told me to come back to pick up after 45 minutes, although it took an hour, which I wasn't complaining as it's better than going home empty handed again :)
Anyway, it's overrated.  The flaky crust was the only good thing.  Will I buy again?  I may even have to think about it, even if there's NO LINE.
author: Eric T.

description: I have been to SF only twice and have heard so much about the egg tarts at this bakery. Last time I came here, the bakery was closed and I was not able to try the famous desserts. The second time I went the bakery was open, so we made sure to go! The line was not super bad, but was the longest I have seen for a bakery. The egg tarts were a good size, and were very very fresh. The crust was very crispy and flaky, and the egg part was not too sweet or bland. The egg tarts are constantly being made and freshly packed for the person ordering, so we got to have them warm. I would definitely go back again to get more if the line isn't super long!
author: Rusteen H.

description: I promise you that you can't find better egg tarts than this bakery. I was pretty upset when I came there a second time, only to find out they were on a 2 week vacation.
author: Demi N.

description: Best Egg Tarts in San Francisco! Warm, buttery, flakey, & yummy! It's always busy here but definitely worth the wait!
author: Trang Ashley P.

description: As expected from all the other review prior to mine. It is definitely amazing egg tarts!! I came here cause it was one of the places that was highly recommended on my first trip to San Francisco and lucky enough it was open even when everyone said the chances of it being open is low due to there inconsistent schedule of being open when they want to, But lucky enough for me i had a chance to try it and as everyone else describe it is as truthful as how i will describe it as well. With its thin flaky crust and creme-y middle filling. It is definitely the best egg tart I've had thus far.
author: William N.

description:
Egg tarts are $1.75 now?! Whaaaat. If they weren't so good I wouldn't get them. But dude. They're so good that I just can't help it. They make their pastries all day so you can guarantee getting fresh ones! 
To avoid standing in long lines, come here in the morning at around 11! 
Cash only, so be prepared.
author: Christina W.

description: I literally waited 45 mins to get a dozen of egg tarts in the chilly weather of SF.But it's worth the wait time.If it's your first time here please carry cash.Worth eating those hot tarts
author: Kirupa G.

description:
If you ever plan on coming to Chinatown in San Francisco, this is a MUST TRY! I guarantee you won't be disappointed. 

Just going to keep it short and sweet. Since they've raised the prices to about $2.15 an egg tart, I recommend bringing $26 CASH to buy a dozen! It is so worth the money, but beware of lines when you go! Also, minus one star for always being inconsistent with their hours and always being on 'vacation' :(

Tip:
-Call before you go to see if they're open and have egg tarts available!
-The fresh pineapple buns are really good as well!
author: Elisa S.

description:
Best Egg Tarts EVER! You must eat them fresh out of the oven, where they're piping hot and the crust is still a rich flaky delicious bomb waiting to explode your tastebuds. They also have a generous gelatinous not overly sweet egg custard filling, yumms.

Downside, they're located in Chinatown where parking is not only a b**** but the pedestrians that decide to cross whenever they feel like it makes you want to pull your hair out. 

Not only does driving through Chinatown deter you from coming, but they're closed half the time. I recommend calling in to make sure they're open before you actually drive down there just to find out they're closed making you want to burn the place down.

A dozen of these eggs tarts are now a whopping $20! They've increased their price incrementally over the years. And cash only.

But what can I say? They still have a line all the time and they're able to survive even being closed for half the year. That speaks a lot.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
$1.75 for an egg tart, people will pay butt loads for these delicious eggy delights. The crust is buttery and thin, while the egg custard (bought around 12:30pm on a Sunday) was still warm and in between eggy and smooth. The egg tarts here are done very well because you can taste everything that went in to it and leave you content. 

The red bean sesame balls were fresh from the fryer too but it would have been even more amazing had there been more red bean filling. 

The line goes quick and they typically don't open until the afternoon. Check the tips section in Yelp mobile for real time updates of the bakery. Yelpers typically announce the going on of this bakery there.
author: Nancy H.

description:
finally got to try this place after waiting over one hour in line.
sadly, i was not amazed. the egg tart was okay but nothing i'd ever stand 1+ hours in line for at all. the custard part wasn't really creamy and there was too much custard to crust for my liking.
author: Priscilla P.

description: Best Dan tant I've ever had and let me tell you... I've had them all over the world.  Get them warm if you can... prepare to wait in line.
author: Trevor B.

description:
After coming twice before and finding the closed for vacation signs, today they were open during the Lunar New Year Street Fair. Waited about 40 mins in line for egg tarts. At $1.95 each, they are pricier than the ones I usually buy in Oakland Chinatown. No discount for buying by the dozen. 

It was delicious! So flakey and the filling was delicious too. Would definitely come back if I had time to wait in line. P.S. the line separates into two so people walking by can still get past.

Wish their schedule was more consistent though since it looks like they're on "vacation" a lot.
author: Jo L.

description:
Okay. What the blazes. I waited in line for 1 hour for a dozen egg tarts. I came here with my girlfriend and we wanted to each bring a dozen back for our families. First they said we can only get TWO. What the blazes! Two egg tarts for waiting more than hour?? Nei mo gaau co?? 

I get it. It was Mid Autumn Festival season and everyone was buying Moon cakes... But I wanted egg tarts! Give me the dan tats man! Not like they're cheap. Actually the opposite. These are some pricey dan tats. 

Anyways, we almost got played and only get two egg tarts if it wasn't for the fact that one of the ladies was about to give the person behind the person behind us two dozen. Ooo man. My girlfriend was pissed. Eventually they gave us one of the two dozens they were about to give away. But man... We were first in line and you were about to give some other lady our egg tarts? Shades...

But aside from my ranting, I do like the egg tarts here. They're delicious. ^___^ worth the wait? No. Lol.
author: Brandon L.

description: Delicious egg tarts!! Very crispy and not too sweet. However I feel like their price has gone up over the years. $21/dozen, literally almost $2 per egg tart! Worth a try though, if you haven't been
author: Nancy H.

description:
Dr. Dre: Dan tat-tat-tat, dan ta-tat like that.
Snoop: Never had an egg tart ever good as that!
Dr. Dre: Dan tat-tat-tat, dan ta-tat like that.
Snoop: Never had an egg tart ever good as that!

No Chinese bakery or dim sum experience will ever be the same, since Golden Gate's legendary and delectable dan tats changed my life. While indulging in the snap-those-fingers hallelujah-sexy crust and warm and loving (almost Mother Teresa-like) eggy center, at one point, I'm pretty sure I ...  I... saw a bright yellow/ orange glow around my face. My aura, I saw it... (Cue Rick James aura gif: http://bit.ly/1iwq5hL) Or, it could have been the 10 am sun hitting my face exactly at the same time as I bit into this palatable pastry... I will go with the former.

Was it worth the $1.40 per egg tart that's about twice as much as other bakeries? Yes! Was the detour to Chinatown with Michael T (reppin' Reno) worth the time? Absolutely! Will I visit Golden Gate Bakery the next time I'm in San Francisco? No question.

However, while, as you can tell from this review, that I love their dan tats, I wasn't too fond of their curry beef and bbq pork puff pastries. While the fillings  were wonderful, the crusts were way too overcooked. Nonetheless, I think my exceptional egg tart experience makes up for these small blips.

Can't wait to return!
author: Jonathan T.

description: This is probably the best place in San Fran for egg custard tarts. Long wait to get them but kind of adds to the excitement.  Wasn't hugely impressed with their other baked items though. Granted we just came from a bakery in South Korea
author: Chris F.

description:
I usually don't eat egg tarts because I don't really like them.  However, Golden Gate Bakery is the only place in which I will eat egg tarts from.  These are literally the best egg tarts I've ever had.  Why?  Because of the DELICIOUS and big eggy center of the egg tart.  The shell is also cripsy, yet not too thick or crunchy.  The egg tart melts wonderfully in your mouth with each bite.  Plus, because there are always people waiting for egg tarts, all the egg tarts are extremely fresh and warm!  

One egg tart costs $1.50 and a dozen costs $18.00.  Also, they accept CASH ONLY.  Don't expect to be able to walk in and buy egg tarts, as usually, the line is at least a 30 minute wait.  But, it is WORTH IT, just make sure you plan accordingly for time or bring someone to keep you company.  Also, I've heard that the Bakery closes randomly for holidays.  However, I've been 3 for 3 so far.  

If you like egg tarts, then this place has to be a stop for you when you visit San Francisco.
author: Janine M.

description:
I think Golden Gate Bakery is a must when you come to SF. It is located in Chinatown so there are a lot of other places to get pastries but trust me this is worth the wait.

I believe I was here on a Wednesday night, so the line was not that bad it actually went by pretty fast. 

I ordered a dozen egg tarts which literally just came out of the oven they were steaming hot! The ladies helping us were so nice they cut the boxes so it wouldn't get soggy and gave us napkins so we could eat them fresh!

These egg tarts are so big! And the egg custard part is definitely worth your money they do not skim out on this part of the egg tart like some other places.
author: Kathy N.

description: $23.40 for a dozen of egg tarts as of July 18, 2016.
author: Jackie T.

description:
5 stars for the amazing egg tarts!!! These are the best egg tarts that I've ever had. The crust is flaky and layered and has a delicious baked flavor. The center custard is smooth and silky on the surface, but beneath it lies a soft custard. These are the best when they've just come out of the oven, and considering how popular they are, they're baked fresh throughout the day and your chances of getting a warm one are high. Also love the buns with pineapple topping.

Over the years, the bakery has become more and more popular. Two bad things; first: the opening times of the bakery are highly unpredictable. As they have become more popular, it seems that they've had a tendency to take more and more unannounced breaks. Sometimes they'll put signs up stating how long they'll be closed for, other times they'll just say they're closed indefinitely (meaning I have no idea when I'll get to eat my next egg tart!!). Guess they can afford to take as much impromptu vacation as they want. The second bad thing is that there's often a wait because of how popular they've become. The lines will go outside the store, but usually move quickly enough. Usually the wait is around 15-20 minutes on a very busy day.

Favorites: Egg tarts and pineapple buns
Tips: Be prepared to wait in line and bring cash!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Yep the wait is worth it! I'm not crazy about egg tarts but these taste like heaven...not even kidding.
My mom's a professional baker and I'm pretty picky about my sweets. These egg tarts really are something. 
This was on top of my SF list and when I got there around noonish on a Tuesday....of course it was close "for vacation" which I got pretty sad but then after another hour or so, my friend passed it and there were people lining up. The line was not long but did waited for about an hour and finally got our egg tarts. 
Fresh one out are soooo good! The eggy part literally melts once you have your bite and the crust is fluffy and crispy not too thick which I love!
I regard only getting a dozen...even after couple days, it still tastes good but you have to heat it up in the oven!
author: Amy C.

description: Wow! Amazing and super delicious pastries. Egg tarts were the best I have ever had. So flaky and fresh! The ladies weren't fluent in English, but we're all very cute and helpful. They really tried to move as fast as they could to make the wait time not as bad!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I love my egg tart with lots of fillings and this one truly hits the spot. We were lucky the wait was not too long and they were actually opened!

Our friends tried 3x to go and every time they went they were closed. Business must be good for them to close at random days.
author: Janet L.

description: Seriously, we saw the line and we thought it must be amazing! They charged double than other places and really, they are just regular egg tart may be sweeter- which isn't a good thing. I say it doesn't worth the price or the wait! 3 stars for the egg tart. 2 stars for the wait, 1 start for the price!
author: jackie t.

description: If u stop by and they're actually open and not on vacation, then wait in the line and order the egg tarts. Best I've had.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Egg Custard Tarts! 

 - Flaky
 - Buttery
 - Light
 - Creamy
 - Warm
 - Sweet

The warm, sweet, light, creamy, flaky, and buttery Egg Custard Tarts are the sole reason to trek down Grant Avenue and wait in line at Golden Gate Bakery. If you want one, you'll have to wait cause the line moves s-l-o-w ... When we went, the line was about 25 minutes. When we left, it was twice as long ... 

The Egg Custard Tarts at Golden Gate Bakery are good. They may not be worth 45 minutes of your life, but they are worth the $1.60. We got a dozen Egg Custard Tarts for $16 and added three Red Bean Sesame Gluten Balls. Jam the warm Tarts in your mouth as soon as possible for maximum joy and then save a few for later.

Golden Gate Bakery is not fancy. It's actually cramped and dingy (almost dirty) inside. The older ladies helping customers have been doing this for a long time so it seems wise to not make things more complicated than they should be. Just get your tarts, pay, and go outside to enjoy them. 

There are really only three words you need to remember from this review: 

Egg Custard Tarts.
author: Michael S.

description: Expect a wait since this place is sooooo good! Egg tarts are a must! Recommend eating it fresh!
author: Eva L.

description: Waited 40 minutes in line for the dan tats. I've never had such horrible and rude service before. Won't be coming back here for a very long time. Sad
author: Sophie L.

description:
I give this place 5 STARS for being consistently closed without courtesy notice of when the heck they will be open. 

I think its opportunity for a rival egg tart business - since this one is becoming the infamous Ghost TART.
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description:
Since there are too many reviews regarding the egg tart, I will review based on waiting time.

Waiting report: if you are waiting outside the door, your waiting time is 5 minutes.

If the end of line is at the edge of neighbor store, your waiting time is 25-30 minutes.

If the end of line is the at the end of the other store, your waiting time is one hour.
author: Kyle C.

description:
Jeez, is this freakin' place ever open????  I still have yet to try these infamous egg tarts because we went there again yesterday and they were on vacation AGAIN!!  Again, is this place ever open???  I guess they only open when they feel like it.  Or they only open if they know you.  

So we headed over to Good Mon Kok bakery on Stockton St. and got some there and they were pretty darn good!  Also kind of expensive though but I think a little cheaper, and maybe even better, than Golden Gate!!!!  If you happen to go there and it's closed yet again, just try one of the MANY little bakeries in Chinatown that all have egg tarts and some are just as good!!
author: Jimmy W.

description: The egg custard tarts that they're so famous for are pretty 'meh'.  There was NO LINE the day we went, so we figured we'd better take the plunge.  We got 3 of them and a giant sesame ball.  We ate one of the tarts right outside the store because we knew how famous they were.  The crust is nice and flaky around the edges, but soggy on the bottom.  It's baaaaarely sweet and REALLY eggy tasting...like absurdly eggy, not egg-custard-eggy.  If you're looking for a sweet custard tart, this is not the place.  The sesame ball was ok too...it was a GIANT sesame ball with barely any red bean.  Oh, yeah...one of the tarts went in the fridge and we ate it a couple days later and it was significantly better than day 1, but still super soggy on the bottom.
author: Tara S.

description:
Those Egg Tarts are well worth the wait. I usually eat egg tarts from places in the sunset district, but these here were especially good. It felt like there was more egg/custard than most places and the crust wasn't overwhelming. And the taste of these egg tarts? Sooooo good. Well worth the price too.

The line will most likely be out the door (cause it's small inside) and it's popular as eff seemingly with locals and tourists alike. I wasn't expecting much service wise, but surprisingly the lady serving us was super nice.
author: Micki H.

description:
I do admit, their Egg Custard Tarts are bomb. But I don't know if they're twice as good as other bakeries in the area to match the price point ratio... ($1.65 each). The one good thing about the constant line is that those Egg Tarts are constantly being churned out so you'll probably get them fresh out of the oven, which is the best time to enjoy their fluffy, flaky goodness! 

Something Golden Gate Bakery also seems to be known for is the erratic business hours. Luckily, some devoted fans have created a web and Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/pages/Is-the-Golden-Gate-Bakery-Open-Today/394882013908745). It's not always updated, but usually keeps track of when the ladies are away on vacation.

They have a nice selection of other classic goodies like Pineapple Buns, Mooncake, Black Bean Cakes, and the Swirl Cakes. The Lemon Napoleon seemed to be quite popular too. Come armed with cash, but you can leave the Chinese-English dictionary at home since they have signs in English and Chinese. :)
author: Helen S.

description:
OVERRATED!!!

Street parking is tough in Chinatown. 

Look for the small shop with the long slow line.

Cash only.

I feel bad but this is the score it deserves.

Dan Tat - $1.40 each
The egg tart is huge. The egg custard was creamy but very loose compared to normal dimsum dan tats. The tart was very soggy, probably caused by the loose custard. I like a soft but crispy tart, this was to soggy for me.

I wish I liked it but was not worth the wait in line. 

I would try it again if I am there and there is no line but I still perfer my dimsum dan tats.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Review of egg tart only! Bc again that's all I could have after lunch.

I've heard of this place (hella reviews, supposed to be good, long wait), but when I went in a rando weekday around noon, it was pretty quiet. It's not a fancy bakery. The egg tart was $1.50. Not as sweet as the ones I'm used to - more Asian palette I guess? The crust was very thin and had a lot more of the egg custard to crust ratio than I'm used to. Which is a good thing because I mostly like the egg custard part. It was a bit hard to hold up because the crust was so thin. I would get it again, but I don't think it's bomb enough to wait in line for/go out of my way to get to. I didn't get anything else too also bc nothing looked amazing I must try. Maybe also because it's not fancily displayed.
author: Kathleen C.

description: The egg tart was good and inexpensive, but the tart probably has more hype than deserved. There is a line but it moves quickly. If you're in China Town you might as well stop by and get the egg tart since people rave about it!
author: Susannah H.

description:
The most expensive egg tart you will ever eat, but it is so worth every penny. The custard is what makes Golden Gate so unique because it is so smooth, fluffy, and thick so you really get a good taste of the custard. Also, they're warm when you purchase them! Warm egg tarts are a great little snack after walking around Chinatown.  

Lines are long because people buy boxes and boxes of the baked goodies and I do not blame them. If you're going to wait in such a long line, make your waiting worth while! Also, the location is deep into Chinatown so it's smart if you get your cravings satisfied by buying in bulk! They're THAT good, trust me and the other 2000+ yelp reviewers!
author: Veda T.

description:
An egg tart (dan tat) from Golden Gate Bakery is like the Taj Mahal of egg tarts.  All egg tarts that came to pass before GGB are nothing.  All egg tarts to come after my visit to GGB shall be from GGB.  My mouth no longer accepts any other egg tart.  Sorry.

Simply put, these egg tarts are unparalleled in quality, taste, and texture.  The crust is incredibly flaky and the egg-y filling is silky smooth and creamy.  At $1.40 per egg tart, you really can't go wrong with ordering multiples!  Their bak tong gou, a sweet white sponge cake, is also quite delicious, but not mind-blowing like the dan tat.  Bak tong gou is a childhood favorite, though, so I had to get a pack of three slices for $2.25.

As other reviewers have mentioned, be prepared for a line.  I was fortunate in that I only had to wait about 20-25 minutes around 11am on a Saturday.  Nonetheless, I would advise arriving early to avoid the crowds, and to use this handy website to avoid those dreaded "we're on vacation" signs that often adorn their storefront:  http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/.  Cash only.  There is a slight discount per dan tat if you order 12+!  

Gung hay fat choy!
author: Brittany N.

description: Omg it was so delicious. I have never tried warm egg tart. They were so delicious and perfect sweetness. Must go place if you are visiting China town in San Francisco. Amazing love it.
author: Food L.

description:
YASSS, finally opened right before Lunar New Years! 

They are notorious for being close unannounced, but it also makes me happy to see that they aren't money driven and open 7 days a week like most businesses. They are successful, so why not and enjoy that success right? Enjoy your days off ladies because making thousands of delicious egg tarts must be pretty exhausting.

They have a permanent "Closed for Vacation" sign affixed to the door, which is a good reminder that it's worth the wait. If you hate lines like me, then get a boyfriend/husband and have them wait while you shop. :) 

We have gotten other pastries, but the egg tarts is what we come back for.... 1 dozen for $21. Just give them your money!! The egg tarts are fresh (even at 4:30 pm) with a nice flaky crust and a perfect custard filling. But watch out while you eat a fresh one. I took a bite and some of the juices from the egg custard dripped on my top. Hahaha ew... 

I'm eating my day old egg tart while typing this review and its still better compared to other bakeries I've been to.
author: Mimi N.

description:
I've grew up in Chinatown as a kid and I never had that fresh of an egg-tart until now. 

I've finally decided to try this out when my friend was visiting SF. I've waited ~40 minutes for these egg tarts, and they definitely worth the ~$2/each. Not too oily, not too sweet. Do eat them right away when they are still piping hot. Cash only. The two Asian ladies inside speak a good amount of English. Bare with the wait as they are super patient and friendly, and deal with hundreds of people a day! 

Do not trust their Yelp hours as they may be close anytime for vacation. They post their hours and days open (or to be open) on the door.
author: Alan Z.

description:
The egg tarts are magical and out of this world. They are made fresh and at a constant pace with how busy they are on a regular basis but in my opinion it is definitely worth the wait!

The crust was crispy but soft and the middle was creamy but also the perfect consistency so that it just melts in your mouth. I would definitely recommend this place if you are in the area! 

Though I hear that they close whenever they feel like it so you can either take your bets on them being open or check online on a website/fb page that reports on it. We got lucky enough to come on a day where they happened to be open.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Without fail, Golden Gate Bakery will have a line of at least fifteen people, and there is a pretty solid reason for that: their dan tats (egg tarts) are the best in the city. And it's amazing how a long line will attract even MORE people to stand in line- the people who joined the line after me decided to join the line without even knowing what Golden Gate Bakery was.
What makes Golden Gate Bakery's dan tats better than every other one on Grant Avenue? The dan tats here are very fresh and hearty. They are served hot and the crust is flaky and delicious. At $1.40 each, it's easy to buy more than just one. Their red bean sesame balls are also tasty. Remember: cash only.
author: Grace L.

description:
The egg tarts were good, but definitely overhyped. They've inflated the price due to their popularity and the lines can get pretty long. There are so many other chinese bakeries in the area where you can get just as delicious egg tarts without all the fuss. 

Oh and it's cash only.
author: Derrick W.

description:
After seeing masses of locals hopping in line, I decided to throw my hat in as well.  Turning to yelp, I learned that the piece de resistance here is the egg custard tart.  Despite being only 8 or so people back in line (a very long line developed behind me), it still took 20-30 minutes to get my coveted tart.  People in front of me ordered by the dozen, and the ladies behind the counter were pulling them out of the oven as fast as possible but not keeping up with the demand.  The tarts are $1.80 each, which is a steal for how filling they are.  The flaky, crispy crust is delicious.  Where the custard started to set up and cool around the edges, I thought it was good.  Eggy, but slightly sweet.  For me, the hot jiggly center wasn't ideal, but I'm happy I tried it and got the GG Bakery experience.  

I also ordered COCONUT MACAROONS, which can only be ordered in half dozen amounts.  While I didn't think I needed that many, I was later SOOOO glad I got them.  By far the best coconut macaroon I've ever eaten.  It was carmelized and buttery and crunchy on the outside with a nice, sweet, soft, coconut bite in the middle.  I left the bakery to bike around the City for the day, and I was so thankful to have these gems in my bag to stave off starvation.
author: Sasha R.

description:
1.) http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/#!

You should refer to this website before a trip to SF! You will either be overjoyed (because you get to consume their famous dan tat) or you will be disappointed because these little old ladies are on "vacation" most of peak times for traveling! They have been open 2/3 times I have visited SF!

2.) Bring cash. $16.80 for a delectable dozen.

3.) Hot. Fresh. Best egg tart I've ever had, bar none.

4.) Thinking about taking these home? The little ladies told me they last up to three days as long as they are not placed in the heat. I tried them up to three days, but after the first day you can taste the difference in freshness.

5.) Drool.
author: Jacqueline D.

description: It was worth waiting in line for an hour. Their egg tarts were magnificent. I never liked egg tart before but these were able to change my mind.
author: Khoi C.

description: Best egg custard tart I've ever had.  I wanted to drop a star due to the staff's erratic schedule (randomly closing for months at a time), but the pastries are just too good.  Their schedule has even turned into a running joke and has spawned websites like http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/.
author: John E.

description: One of the best custards in the world! It's best to eat it fresh and the line is definitely worth it. It's expensive but the custard just melts in your mouth and it's so good. I recommend this place to all my friends.
author: Kyle C.

description:
I give them 5 stars because they make the best egg custard in the bay area. Their sesame red bean balls are great too. The only problem this place has is that
They close for a month at a time for vacation so I'm only giving them 4 stars. It seems that almost every time I come here they are closed for vacation.
author: James F.

description: We stopped by Golden Gate Bakery during our visit to Chinatown. The Don Tots were delicious. We went close to their closing time and they were still hot and fresh. The ladies that worked inside were very sweet and allowed us to take pictures of the pasties inside. I would highly recommend going here. We got lucky and there wasn't any line.
author: Veronica H.

description:
As I was heading to dinner with my friend, we see several people walk by with boxes from Golden Gate Bakery. She exclaimed, "OMG, they're open??"  She then began to rave about how amazing these egg tarts were and how popular they are, with always a long line stretching out front. 

We decided to make a pit stop at the bakery because I had to see what the hype was about, and lucky for us, there was no line! It was $2 each, which is definitely higher than the standard pricing for egg tarts you get at other bakeries. It was delicious and had the right amount of sweetness, a nice, flakey crust, and a tender custard center. I would return again but I don't think it's something that I would wait an hour for.
author: Sharon I.

description:
Dragged myself up the hills 5 times on different days and time before I finally get their egg tarts. Yes, I was that dedicated. The lady behind the counter told me to come either in the morning or around 3pm for best chance of getting it.
5th times was the charm (coincidentally, it was around 3pm). But honestly, it was a bit anticlimactic. Don't get me wrong, the egg tart was amazing with their buttery crust and light custard. Especially when they were still hot from the oven. But, hmm, somehow it kinda lack a punch.
Not the kind of egg tart I would gladly wait in the long line or repeatedly check the place again.
However, I'll still recommend people to try it, at least once. If not for the taste, probably for the curiosity.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I was recommended this bakery from a local when I was visiting from Seattle. Upon arrival, I saw this massive line that began to cover the next storefront. Everyone comes to this bakery for the egg-tarts which are made by the tray and run out almost instantly, so the line becomes long and slow-moving. 

After 30 something minutes, I finally make it to the front of the line and what happens? The cashier completely ignores me and asks the girl behind me (and several others) what she wants to to order. What kind of egg-tart induced hate crime was I being subjected to? Of course, the nice young girl buys enough egg-tarts to feed a small army and leaves me with none. I had to ask the cashier to take my order so I can get some of my own egg tarts before she dished them out to everyone else in San Francisco. She apologized and said I would be the first one to get some of the next batch. How did she know that my favorite thing was waiting in line? Super rude and unprofessional staff.

That being said, the egg-tarts were super good. 10/10, would definitely wait in line and get ignored again for some egg-tarty goodness.
author: Lam P.

description: The BEST egg tarts! It may seem like they're always on vacation or the line is long when they're not, but either way, the wait is worth it. The thin but flaky crust. The perfect consistency of the egg. Yum~~!!
author: M T.

description: Giving it 4 stars but I didn't get to try it. :( I want to give everyone a heads up that they are out until 9/12/2015. We got here today and saw this sign :(. Yelp said they were open, but they aren't.
author: Sherica L.

description:
There was a bit of a line going out the door, but the space is pretty tiny anyway, only enough room for a single file line of 10 people to go in. But dear lord if I wasn't already stuffed when I got here, I would've bought a whole box of these for myself! I've always loved "Dahn Tat," basically egg custard tarts, and this place has done the best version of the traditional kind. I've had the Portuguese tarts from a famous place in Lisbon which were better, but it's a bit different from these. 

When I took it out of the bag, it was at an optimal warm temperature, and it smelled amazing. I may have stuffed my face back in the bag to smell the other ones I got, but who's judging? I proceeded to bite into it, and it was like this perfect harmony of flaky, buttery crust, and melt in your mouth custard going on. The egg tarts I usually get in NYC have a pretty dry and hard crust, which isn't bad as there's a bit of a crunch to it, but it pales in comparison to the smooth perfection of Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Matthew L.

description:
If I could give negative stars, I would. I don't think there is a review scathing enough to capture the absolute ridiculousness of their business model and service. 

This bakery is famed for their egg tarts just as much as their fickle business hours. We just so happened by their store front, where a group of customers were waiting outside the door. Shocked that they might be open for business, we checked it out. After heading over to investigate, I found out that the people who were waiting had pre-ordered egg tarts.

The lady working inside kept the door shut, only opening it to take additional orders or to collect money. There was no order to their line or even a distinction between those adding on orders versus those who had pre-ordered. Adding to the confusion was a sign on their door stating they were closed for vacation. 

When asked about the wait time, she told us that she still had a list of pre-orders to go through, but refused to estimate how long until they would be able to serve the add-ons.

From the glimpses I caught of the store, it appeared very unkempt inside with papers and boxes strewn about. The disorganization did not boost my faith in their ability to keep track of their orders.

Perhaps their egg tarts are the best in the city.  Perhaps they are cheapest priced egg tarts. Perhaps this was enough to attract customers decades ago. But the blatant disregard to their customers' time and unprofessional service marks them as a dinosaur in modern times. Unevolved.

As someone who frequents Asian restaurants where service is expected to lack, I was still appalled. Clearly, Golden Gate Bakery relies on its outdated reputation.
author: A T.

description:
If you've never had an egg tart (Dan Tot) before, it's a Hong Kong delicacy that resembles a hot creme brûlée with a crust. But it's no easy task finding a good Dan Tot in the streets of SF. Luckily, Golden Gate Bakery has masterfully recreated the sweet experiences that Hong Kong natives have of the Dan Tot. Though all these experiences are guaranteed delicious, they can vary between different types of Dan Tot eaters.

1. The Big Biter
Possibly the most prevalent of all Dan Tot eaters, the Big Biter looks to finish their treat in around 3 bites. A satisfying way to enjoy one's Dan Tot, as each bite brilliantly contrasts the crispy crust with the soft yellow custard. 

2. The Nibbler
Precision. Attention to Detail. The Nibbler employ a solid set of tasting skills to enjoy every last intricacy of the Dan Tot. Yes, they're the ones that will tell you about the multi-layer crust that flakes off like a buttery croissant after every nibble.

3. The Boss
The Boss eats the Dan Tot with a spoon. They simply scoop up the sweet custard and leave the crust untouched. Quite unorthodox, but it certainly maximizes the sweetness in each bite. Plus, it looks super boss.

At a little over a dollar for each Dan Tot, you can definitely try out all three ways of eating the Dan Tot for under five dollars. Just cross your fingers and hope Golden Gate is open when you swing by!
author: Ringo M.

description: Don't believe the hype. It's not that great and definitely not worth the line. Ladies running it are rude on top of everything. So you wait for 40 minutes for sub-par pastries and then get treated like you're a nuisance? Yeah, I'll pass. Never going back.
author: I S.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE.  Great egg tarts, great coconut tarts, all super cheap and delicious, and so often freshly baked and warm and delicious!

Beware, cash only, and the owners have the MOST RIDICULOUS BUSINESS MODEL, as in they pretend they're on vacation all the time and act bothered when there's business.  

A lot of times there's a super long line, but if you manage the wait you're in for a treat!

I've been twice, and once we had to wait in a line for over an hour.  The second time I went, we walked by right as the woman was locking up.  They had the on vacation sign up but they were clearly just going on a lunch break or something similar.  We asked what time they'd be open again and she said either 3:30 or 4, so we came back around 4 and were lucky enough to grab some egg tarts and coconut tarts fresh out of the oven and with no wait at all.
author: Ruby Y.

description:
Yes, the egg tarts are good. If you could get them. And that's a big IF. The owners close the place down whenever they go on vacation. So many a time we walked to that store only to find out they're closed. Their sign doesn't even say how long they'll be gone. What kind of a business is that?

But on those occasions you'd catch the rare chance they're open, you're still not guaranteed to snag some egg custards. They run out of the damn product if you're not in line early enough. Yes, there's always a line of mostly tourists who are more than happy to waste half a day of their three day trip to San Francisco just to get a selfie with these fabled custards. 

In my opinion, they're not worth the trouble. There are many other places in the city with egg custards just as good, if not better.
author: Glenn D.

description: Best egg tarts in the US, hands down. Also the lady that runs the store is really sweet.
author: Ryan A.

description:
Best egg tarts in the city? Probably. Filling is on par with other nearby bakeries, and the crust is a little more buttery. But having tried other places nearby, it's really not by much. The waiting time to get them narrows the gap even further.

The way I see it, waiting is worth it if you have time... especially if it's your first time.  But if not, grabbing some egg tarts super fast from another quality bakery nearby and going on with your day will likely be just as, if not more rewarding.
author: Matthew D.

description: Price per eggtart 2.15 （no tax). Opened at 1030 today. Long lines but moves fairly quickly
author: H H.

description:
Everyone knows this place has 5 star egg tarts when they are open.

I've called too many times for them to tell me they are on vacation without an expected open date. "Call back in a few weeks!" 

I rather see them open for two hours a day instead of all day but open on a set schedule or something. It is too frustrating and I am in search of my next favorite egg tart place.

Not worth all the waiting and calling.
author: Lily V.

description: Kind of a disappointment. As I understood, this place is well known and popular. With the long wait times the employees act with apathy. If they feel like helping you they will, if they don't they make you wait longer. We waited for over 45 minutes just to buy three items. It also felt like a slap in the face cause certain customers were able to bypass the line even though many people waited quite long.  To me the food is very pricey considering this is in the middle of Chinatown and there are many other places. The inside does not seem too sanitary. The employees touch both the money and food without any gloves. The employees also came across very rude not just to me but to the people in front of me. They also short changed me and when I asked they kind of acted like I didn't know how to do math. Whatever, keep my change, I won't be coming back.
author: Michele C.

description:
Even though their sign in the front says "closed for vacation"... I saw people inside the bakery moving mooncakes around.  Are they back?? Do they just not want to open for the public?? I drove all the way from LA for some of these egg tarts and they're gone AGAIN??? 

I just headed over to AA bakery for some flakey egg tarts that has the right amount of sweetness to it. 

Life is hard. I'll go to http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ next time to see if they're open :/
author: Jasmine L.

description: Egg tarts!!  It was definitely worth standing in line to get the fresh and warm egg tarts that were very light and airy with just the right amount of sweetness and a flaky crust.  I'm not sure how the women at the counter are able to bake enough for everyone but it seems like everything there is fantastic--I'm really hoping I'll get to try more pastries from here later on!
author: Jenny L.

description:
When we were there, they were closed for vacation. 

We talked to a few of our friends, all have the same experience on different date different time of the year.

So are they in business of what?
author: D L.

description: Best bakery!! Worth standing in line!! Bring cash, lots of it because you will want to buy everything. It is so hard to choose just one or two. You cannot choose wrong, but that custard pie is the stuff of culinary dreams!!!
author: Ann K.

description:
Just picked up a couple of dozen egg tarts, you gotta get them when you can.

They have been closed for months and are currently only open for special holidays like Chinese New Year. There have been about 20 people in line constantly for the last 2 days.

I did not ask, but I assume they have been closed because they are caring for family member. They did say they plan to open again for regular business in April or May. I hope whoever was ill is better. I can't wait till the Egg Tart famine is over.

They simply make the best egg tarts on the planet.. These egg tarts are a national asset, let's hope they keep that recipe safe and keep churning out egg tarts.
author: David T.

description:
If you're ever in San Francisco, put them egg tarts on your bucket list.  There's a sticker on the window advertising "The Best In Town", and in this case, they're probably correct.  The place is so awesome, someone even graffitied the canopy up top.

Parking is available on the street in front.

If you can't find the store, look for the big pink canopy with the giant line-up outside.  Wow, word gets around.  Thank goodness the line does move quickly.  I was in and out in 20 minutes or so.

The egg tarts here are definitely some of the best I've ever had.  About 50% larger than anything you'd find at dimsum, with that nice gooey custard in the middle.  Get yourself a dozen (some $16), and gorge with your friends for the rest of the day.  Tip: you want to eat these while they're HOT.  Oh yes.

They do sell other stuff, and I'm sure those other items are decent too, but wouldn't know for sure.

Being an authentic Asian place, they're cash only.

Yes. they're that good.  Just thinking of them brings a smile to my face.
author: Edward L.

description: Worth the line up, so hot they maintain their temperature for a long time. Best ever custard tarts, trust me , I've tried many .
author: Lilifird J.

description:
Their egg custard tart (dan tat) is 39/100 of the famous 7x7's list of "100 things to eat in SF before you die", 2013 version - BUT I only knew of this after the fact.

---
Aside from doing hospital tours around the Bay Area, I am also finding time to squeeze in trying out the gastronomic essentials - the Bay Area is one of the premier foodie destinations in the US. In this particular case I had 3 hours between a hospital in Antioch and the SF VA, so for lunch I decided on a quick dim sum run. This was the second of three stops. (An afterthought: DO NOT do this. Couldn't eat the tarts right away so I had to store them in my purse. I could faintly smell the tarts during the lab tour)

You'll notice this place because there will be a line out the front - not surprising in part due to the 4 1/2 star average, 1900+ reviews here and other accolades. Supposedly they close at random times; there's an actual website AND FB fan page JUST to track this (http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/)

I went close to 1pm and surprisingly there wasn't much of a line at all. Within 5 minutes I was at the counter placing my order for 2 tarts ($1.40 each). One tart fits the palm of my hand. Yolk was a pale yellow and the outside had a crust of puff pastry.

I have several considerations of the most ideal definition of "foodgasm" - this is one of them. A GOOD puff pastry crust is quite buttery that the crust falls apart when you eat it, this is definitely something you do NOT want to munch on if you plan on keeping your clothes clean. The custard has creme brûlée consistency and not that of an undercooked scrambled egg. If I add a little cinnamon and broil the pastry, this would then turn into my ideal pasteis de nata. 

Cons that it's a messy eat and it loses a bit of deliciousness when it's not fresh off the oven - those I blame myself for doing this within a super tight timeframe. Next time I'll have to try their mooncakes.

UPDATE 1/4/2014: I tried their coconut tart. The closest to what I can describe is "coconut-flavored cornbread". I'm not super fond of coconut, but there was enough to detect it yet I appreciated how warm and fluffy the pastry is. Makes a very good morning pastry and costs the same as the custard tart in individuals and in a dozen.

Like any Chinatown business, cash only.
author: Isabella B.

description:
Is this the best egg tart I've ever had?

Yeah, I guess so, but there's plenty of good egg tarts at the dim sum restaurants back home in the 626.

Would I wait again (even though I only waited 30 minutes this time) ? Probably not
author: Anthony C.

description:
We came on a Sunday the weekend before Chinese New Year. The streets were closed off for Chinese New Years and they were having some sort of street market so it was pretty packed. The bakery itself is really small. There's actually no room for your to browse. The only people inside were the people that were being helped. 

The line formed outside and one thing that bothered me is that we couldn't see what they had from the outside. Most people knew what they wanted, but I didn't even know what they had...except for egg tarts. I ended up taking a little longer when I got in, but still felt rushed because the lady is just staring at you waiting for you to tell her what you want. 

Besides that, I did get the famous egg tarts. I don't really eat egg tarts that often, but boy were these egg tarts delicious. I didn't know how expensive moon cakes were until I bought some here. They got up to like $12/cake, but they were definitely better than any moon cakes I have ever tried. If you're visiting a fan of egg tarts then you should definitely come. But if you don't care for it then save your time because there will probably be a line and parking ain't easy.
author: Christina T.

description:
Two Words: EGG TARTS

I've been eating egg tarts from Golden Gate Bakery from as far back as I can remember and it always brings back happy childhood memories whenever I eat an egg tart from here. This place has grown in popularity over the years and has become quite the tourist spot. The lines are always insanely long but be patient, this place has the best egg tarts you will ever eat. The egg custard is sweet and melts in your mouth and the crust is a perfectly flakey. It also has the perfect crust to egg ratio. (Don't you just hate it when there's more crust than the egg or vice versa?)

If you manage to have leftovers, the egg tarts reheat nicely in the toaster oven so bring a dozen or two back to share... especially if you had to wait in long line for them. Prices are currently $1.40 per egg tart or $16.80 a dozen. 

Note: CASH ONLY. Also, don't forget they also sell fresh moon cakes for the Mid-Autumn Festival.
author: Steph F.

description:
This place is my routine stop each and every time I travel to SFO. The first few times are for the famous egg tarts and coconut tarts. But after my 3rd time, I started getting tired of them (and of course the infamous 30-minute-long queue).

Given the freshness and hotness (temperature duh) of the egg tarts, plus the amazingly egged eggness (I haven't checked the dictionary but what other adjectives can I use to describe the delicious egg part), it's a 5! But wait, I haven't mentioned the crust: it is a little too soft for me. When you try to hold the egg tart by one hand, it starts to fall apart. But well, it's still a 5 because the egg part is so good.

So why am I giving 4 stars?
 1. No official hours - You never know when they are closed for "Vacation". I was there during a normal weekday and the golden gate is closed.
 2. The QUEUE - It just never ends. If you trying it for the first time, yes you must wait. But after a few times, the egg tarts are just another snack. I would only wait in line if it is short.

My alternative egg tart place is the "Red House Bakery" at Bayshore. No line and you have a real bakery, including pineapple buns, to choose from. Take the 8X bus (which is another must-have Chinatown experience) and get off one block from it. They serve breakfast and lunch too!
author: Hoki T.

description: Well just to let you know they going on vacation again no more Egg thing so sad lot of people just standing by making sure they were not on vacation but because I don't know so you know not to come I'm going to miss this place just for a little while but when they open back up it'll be busy well take care be safe have a good afternoon
author: Miko A.

description:
EGG TARTS.

Wow. I don't even like custard all that much, but this blew my mind! Went there at about 9AM & there were no lines at all. My friend & I got 1 each and I was totally regretting not buying a dozen.  They were fresh out of the oven & oh my... THAT CRUST! So flaky. Shortly after devouring our egg tarts we were left craving more throughout the rest of our trip.  Unfortunately, we left SF that same morning.  

I can't wait to go to SF again & have this! I will buy 2 dozen next time.
author: Maria P.

description:
Ive been comming here for over 30 years and the quality has changed recently, it use to be the best place in SF to get the Egg Custard tarts, but something happened within the last couple of years? the quality just isnt like it use to be the crust has gotten thinner and the size has gotten smaller, I think maybe they changed owners or bakers? I can tell it's not the same as the original after comming here for so  many years,

the crust use to have more layers and it was better, now they make them thinner and the crust isnt as good as before? They also raised the prices

I havent been back in more than a year but the last time the egg tarts were $1.69 each, I was disappointed because they raised the price and it wasnt as good. WOW, I just heard Egg tarts cost $1.95 each now! 

It's not even worth waiting in line anymore because they changed

During the summers this place is a very popular "Tourist Trap" I think they raise prices on purpose during the busiest times because they know only a tourist would pay those prices.

the egg tarts are over-rated and over priced
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
If you haven't guess by now, Golden Gate Bakery is known for their egg tarts and coconut tarts (which is very hard to find in LA). Expect a crazy wait during the weekend that'll start from the end of the block. You would think the line will move fast as you order they pack and then you're on your way. But nope, instead you get customers who buy a life savings worth of egg tarts and then everyone waits as they a new pan of tarts comes out. The coconut tart is a must unless you're allergic to coconut. It is delicious!

The tarts run for $1.40 each now ($16.80 for a dozen). They have moon cake also but I have never tried. They speak Chinese and somewhat broken English. So if you cannot speak Cantonese or Mandarin and are trying to order something aside from egg tarts, good luck. 

I would also suggest calling ahead of time to make sure they're open. They like to close on random days and take week long vacation days. This past weekend was my 2nd time here and thank gosh it was open. CASH ONLY.
author: Binh T.

description:
Might call me crazy, but I've never been a huge fan of egg tarts... But, geezzz this place totally got me... and I can't even say NO! HELP I CAN'T STOP EATING!!!!

EGG TARTS - that's all. Crispy of fluff breading, and OMG sweet, creamy egg tarty tarts

*MUST GET: Egg tarts

**OVERALL: you won't be disappointed... and you'll be craving for egg tarts for dayyyyysss.. helppp!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Long ass line.  Egg tarts are good when fresh.  Coconut  tarts and macaroons not bad.  

Really not sure if it's worth the (20-90min) wait though.  

The line just adds to the mystique.  "There is a long line.  It must be good."  The ones who waited in the line would feel like suckers to admit what they waited for is "just okay".  The cycle is perpetuated.
author: Tommy C.

description:
1. They are always on vacation. 
2. Taste not as good as before
3. Raise price almost every time after their vacation.
4. Not that special and not worth the wait
5. Mainly for tourists
author: B B.

description:
The BEST egg tarts you will ever taste!
