Almost every single Norcal person I met during my SF trip have pointed out to me that if I make it to Chinatown I have to try Golden Gate Bakery for their delicious egg tarts. At one point I was beginning to think that if i didn't make it my personal goal to try the egg tarts then I would be messing out. 

Lucky for me during my last day in SF my friends decided to drive us to Chinatown to try these delicious golden treats. We found parking close by and walked about a block to the bakery. I heard they are notorious for closing randomly but on this particular day they were open and the line was pretty short as well (i heard people wait up to 1 hr around the block at times). Once we made it in the tiny store I noticed that people actually order dozens of the egg tarts at one time. Since I didn't have too much room in my carry on bag we only ordered a dozen to share with our friends. We also got the chance to taste the curry meat pies and those were pretty amazing as well! 

Tip* Call ahead or check the "Is the Golden Gate Bakery open today?" facebook page to make sure they are indeed open prior to visiting. Cash only and its about $16/dozen for the egg tarts.
author: Shanon Y.

description: I'm not a custard person, but I can be if Golden Gate Bakery's egg custard tarts are on the menu.  In my wanderings around Chinatown today, I found myself waiting in what was a surprisingly short line for Golden Gate Bakery and treated myself to an egg custard tart.  I had read a lot about this place, and having had Chinese egg custard tarts at various establishments before, I was ready to be blown away. That first bite into the tart was warm, eggy, and sweet.  I think I even let out a small "WOW!" after eating it.  It was definitely very rich and also very eggy, so if you don't like either of those things, then I'd save the effort of trying these. Like most places in Chinatown, it's cash only and is serviced by ladies who are all about business and no nonsense.
author: Lisa I.

description:
You won't miss this shop walking through Chinatown because you'll instantly smell that delicious, sweet smell of their custard a couple shops down with people waiting anxiously in line outside. Egg tarts are now $1.40 each and there is no additional discount if you buy a dozen. But considering how big the egg tarts are, they're definitely worth the price! Their egg tarts are perfectly creamy and just so goood. We ordered a dozen and I lugged a box of 6 all the way back to LA. They're just that good! They're amazing fresh. Don't be ashamed to steal a bite once you walk out of the shop because you'll see other people standing on the sidewalk doing it too! They're also just as good rebaked the next day or two later. 

We also ordered a couple of their Sachimas which is basically an Asian version of a rice krispy. Theirs are a little on the stickier side. My boyfriend tried wrapping a piece around a napkin and the napkin got stuck all over it! But, they're pretty good as well because they're made fresh compared to the ones you buy prepackaged in supermarkets. We also noticed that they were still selling mooncakes even though it was already over a week past Mid-Autumn Festival (probably to cater to all the tourists).
author: Charlene L.

description:
Just another yelper singing the praises of the best egg custard tart ( Dan Tat) in the bay area.  Yes, they sell other bakery items, yes, the lines can sometimes seem daunting, but yes, it is WORTH it.  

They are open from 8 to 8 or until they run out ( which I have never seen happen).

When in the city, Golden Gate Bakery is a must- don't disappoint yourself.
author: Ric C.

description: very long lines...about an 1 hr long wait for fresh egg tarts. buy a box of pastry instead of just one to try if you're gonna wait that long. note: cash only.
author: Raquel K.

description:
Their egg tarts are definitely the freshest I have ever had. Tasted like the Chinese lady dropped them straight from the oven into my bag! That said, growing up in a Portuguese family, I went through boxes and boxes of delicious pastéis de nata (Portuguese custard cups) so I'm partial to that style, and am actually not a huge fan of Chinese style egg tarts. 

My favorite item from my first trip here was the beef curry pie - a savory empanada filled with a spicy beef curry. Their cream bread disappointed me a bit, but that may be because I have recently enjoyed awesome cream bread at bakeries in Seoul. The bread's outer shell was a bit too rubbery in texture and the cream inside was not anything special.

The lines get long here, but the workers are not only efficient at fulfilling orders, but also really friendly. This place is also cash-only so don't waste your time standing in line if you don't have cash!

I love steamed pork buns and was looking forward to giving theirs a try. Unfortunately they were totally out and I didn't want to wait 20 minutes for the next batch. I'm definitely coming back to see if I can grab some delicious meat-filled buns!
author: Mark C.

description:
The line is long and also the hours are unpredictable.  There is a permanent sign stuck to the door that says "Closed for vacation" which means at any time they can decide to close or open.  Buuuutttt, the egg tarts are worth the wait!

Egg tarts have a super flaky crust and come straight from the oven.  The custard is very light and flavorful...very fluffy texture compared to some of the other egg tarts that I have had.

We tried a few other baked goods.  They were okay, but nothing compared to the fresh flaky egg tart.  The coconut tart was pretty good, but still the egg tart wins in my book.  I would not recommend the coconut mochi with peanut/sugar inside--the glutinous rice dough had a strange aftertaste reminiscent of bananas.
author: Jess Y.

description:
So, we were on our way to a bar on a Monday night...

We passed this small bakery with a line out the door.  Color me intrigued. 

After downing a Mai Tai, I checked yelp and found out this place is famous for their egg tarts - which I have never had.  

Fuck it, we are going.

We waited about 20 minutes, paid $6.40 cash for four.  
We ate one right away - fresh out the oven. IT WAS TOO HOT!! lol
We waited a few minutes and tried the second one.  Wow.  So delicious!

I was so happy to have stumbled upon this place (and lucky apparently as the reviews mention that they are on vacation a lot) and even happier that I saved the last two tarts for breakfast before my flight home!
author: Libby R.

description:
After a few visits to SF, I was beginning to think that Golden Gate Bakery was a mirage smack in the middle of the city. These ladies sure know how to yolo, closing shop on random weekends. Ain't gonna hate on that.

Finally able to try the elusive egg tarts after many visits, here are my observations:

1. Delicious fresh out of GG's oven (if you like it hot and soft)
2. Delicious reheated with an oven at home (if you like it hot and hard)
3. Delicious at room temperature at home (if you like it hard)

TLDR: Get your mind out of the gutter and eat some delicious egg tarts.

Is it worth an hour wait? No, but if you happen to be one of the lucky ones to find the line short enough to bear, your taste buds will thank you for it. $1.50 for 1, $18 for a dozen.

PS It's only fitting that my first review as a GOLD Elite is GOLDen Gate Bakery!
author: Yvette T.

description:
I don't eat egg custard tart from any other places, literally, except here. This says a lot since I live in SoCal, which means the only time I get to eat these delicacy is when I am in town. I was recommended by a coworker to try out this little gem two years ago and has been hooked ever since. I am not kidding when I say this place makes THE BEST EGG CUSTARD TARTS! The crust are always perfectly flakey and the egg custard has the perfect amount of sweetness to it. Together this little tasty creation makes my heart sing when I take bite. I also like their meat pies. The dough, one again, has a great flakey texture to it and the meat inside are well seasoned. I have not tried the moon cakes but I've heard good things.

The only pros that I have about this place is (1) their store are always closed so I would recommend to call ahead before you head over, (2) it can get pack! The last time I came I waited an hour for them ( which I believe is worth it), and lastly (3) it's CASH ONLY. 

If you are ever in China Town I recommend coming here and try out some great Chinese pastries, I promise you won't regret it.
author: Nikki N.

description:
Best egg tarts ever!!!! If you're Asian, you probably know about this place. They're famous for their egg tarts and also for being closed almost half of the year. But when they're open and you get their egg tarts fresh out of the oven, it's heaven.

First off, it's hard to know when they're open so I suggest to call ahead and see if they'll pick up. If they do, ask them when they open! I've called on a few occasions and were told they open at 3pm. You'll know they're open if you see a long line out the door and down the street. 

Onto the egg tarts, they're seriously the most delicious egg tarts I've ever had, and this is coming from a person who grew up in Hong Kong. I may have had better ones when I was a kid (that I don't remember), but these are so good! The crust is so flakey and crusty! The egg custard, oh my goodness, is the best! So soft, so flavorful. It's especially the bestest when it's fresh out of the oven! But it's pretty good even if it's cold. 

Golden Gate Bakery is definitely worth the hype, worth the wait, worth the cash (yes, cash only place). It's probably the best in the Bay Area. I can't wait to get my hands on some more the next time I'm in the area!
author: Wendy Y.

description:
Cash only.

What's something mouthwatering, flaky, delicious, and makes you crave for more? Egg tarts!!! 

This is officially now my favorite egg tart place EVER! It's SOO GOOD! Thanks to this place, I think now I need to go to therapy for egg tart addiction. I've tried hundreds of egg tarts, from socal to norcal, from east coast to west coast, and I can say this place has the best egg tarts I've ever had.

They're not cheap, $1.50 for just one egg tart? But it's worth every single penny! And oh, that long line you see when you get there? Yeah, it's wait the wait too!

One downside to this place is that they seem to randomly close pretty often. Luckily there's a facebook fan page and a website (google it, "is golden gate bakery open?") that lets you know the days that it's closed
author: Xin W.

description: I give a 5 for the egg tarts and a 1 for the service. So it averages out to a 3 star! So I called in the morning at 8am to make sure they were open and they answered and said yes. After my 40 minute drive, I find that they are still closed at 11am. I trusted the business hours listed on Yelp which said they were open at 8am. Anyway, since they were closed at 11, we were forced to find a place nearby to eat so that we could get in line at 12. I wish they would have told me over the phone what time they were going to open that day instead of just saying yes we are open today and then hanging up on me. The egg tarts are still yummy and unfortunately for me, I will be going back again!
author: Gloria S.

description:
I thought the egg tart and bbq pork pastry were absolutely delicious WHEN EATEN FRESH. After a couple hours, they started getting a little soggy...

I personally think it's not worth all the hype. Really annoying how GGB is not even open half the year!
author: Betty T.

description: Their egg custard tarts are the best!  There is nowhere that can compete with their egg tarts in he Bay Area.  There is always a long line and the egg is light while the crust is crispy.  This is a must try if you are ever in Chinatown.  I have not had anything like it in any Chinese restaurant or bakery.
author: FG L.

description:
We walked over the Golden Gate Bakery after dinner.  Thank goodness it was still open.  All we wanted was the don tat or the egg custard tarts.

They followed through - a friend waited for them so when we ate them - it was still warm and yummy and delicious!  Our new dessert spot.  Now I know what the hype is all about!!
author: Donna L.

description: Wanted to try this place's egg tarts but on two occasions that I went once at 9am and the other time in the afternoon at 2pm they did not have egg tarts!!! Its mooncake season and people were lining up to buy mooncakes. Their taro mooncake $8.95, doesnt really taste like mooncake but was still pretty good. Though on the pricey side. I would not travel all the way here as  they are not consistent with their egg tarts.
author: Prima Z.

description:
Dem egg tarts doe.

So good. So good. So good. 

They cost more than your average egg tart but it's worth it. For what you pay, you DON'T get an overly fake yellow custard center. Your flakey crust is neither too thick, nor too thin. Just right. A light touch of sweetness. I have to eat 2-3 each time to be satisfied....1 egg tart is never enough! They're the best I've ever had in the Bay Area!

When I want to come here, I will actually call the bakery to make sure they're open before heading over. They're closed a lot!
author: Lisa Z.

description: Speaking as a HK-Chinese-American who has eaten a lot of egg tarts in his lifetime, these custard tarts were pretty amazing.  The ridiculously long line is almost worth it.  Its popularity ensures that the tarts you get are fresh and hot, doubling its awesomeness.  The other items were pretty good as well, but you go there for the egg tarts.
author: L S.

description: I came in for a conference and was not planning to stop by but I'm glad I did! I did not know how popular this place was. I only heard it from my cousin who's around the area. It is a bit pricy, $1.95 i think per egg tart but you know you are paying for quality. I bought two dozen and my friend who doesn't even like them said she would buy it after tasting mine. My brother stole the majority of the box after bringing them home (~ a day after I bought them)... Imagine him devouring them after they're fresh! He blames me for him being disappointed in LA egg tarts now :( it's very flakey and eggy and they were big! Thank goodness they were open. If you can, stop by and try it at least once!
author: Heather L.

description:
Okay, I finally tried one of their "famous" egg tart and...frankly, I don't get the hoopla!  If I was counting the gruffless of the old lady, I would have docked a star, but since I've grew up traditional Chinese, I "sorta get" her and I've read all the Yelp reviews. Because of that, I was prepared for her and I didn't take the point off.  

Don't get me wrong!!  It's pretty decent egg tart.  Crust was flaky and warm, but  the egg custard filling was just okay!!!  I wouldn't wait 40 minutes for them.  The egg tart around the corner at New Hollywood Bakery is much better (filling wise.)

The way to get around the long line is to get a Cantonese speaking person to call them.   If they really aren't on vacation, they will pick up.  You then put in your order for your half dozen to a dozen (or more) egg tarts and set a time to pick up the egg tart and it's just warm from the oven!!!  Don't mind the "On Vacation" sign and the mostly closed gate!  Just peek or knock on the glass door and have your CASH ready for her.  (Also don't mind the gruffness of the old lady at the shop.  It's an old Chinese woman thing...  ;) )

Yes, it had the "Speakeasy" type of feel, but if you really want their egg tarts, this is THE way to go. (You're welcome!)
author: Joanna R.

description:
One of the few lines in SF worth the wait. Of course they go on vacation whenever they d*mn please too, so don't get too excited, but once you have that pink box of heaven you will never go astray. Egg tarts. Done. 

Need something else besides that heavenly tarts? Can't go wrong with some good coconut tarts, macaroons, or even almond cookies. Otherwise get on them egg tarts and just get a box or two and walk around with them to the envy of all. Get them warm and in your belly. It is amazing!
author: Joseph L.

description:
While walking around Chinatown, the bf saw that they finally opened and we ran to get in the line. We both had only one thing in mind: EGG CUSTARD. Luckily for us, when it was our turn to order, the egg custards were fresh out of the oven, steaming hot and ready to be devoured. 

Holy moly. I reached egg custard enlightenment at the first bite.

I must have tried egg custards from 5+ different bakeries previously, and none can even come close to the deliciousness of Golden Gate Bakery. Every time I think about their egg custard, my mouth begins to water...

Notes:
- 1 egg custard = $1.35. 
- Why are they on vacation so often?! Makes me sad.
author: Nari C.

description:
(Review based solely on the egg tart.)

After living in SF for all my life, I finally decided to try the famous Golden Gate Bakery egg tarts. For $1.35 a pop, it better be some good egg tart. To my surprise, it was... Alright. 

The egg tart was fresh but not as flakey as I had imagined. It were as if there weren't enough layers in the shell for it to be that flakey to begin with. In addition, it was so greasy. The custard was tasty but slightly underdone. It didn't give me that satisfaction, like my brain wasn't registering I was downing a delicious tart. 

In comparison to other egg tarts, it's not much better than the average bakery. I definitely prefer Lung Fung Bakery's egg tarts (in the Richmond District) over Golden Gate's any day and it's cheaper too. I would not make the trip out to Chinatown for their egg tarts, but if I'm passing by and craving them, I'll drop in.
author: Angie Y.

description: Tried coming here 3 or 4 times. They were closed very single time. Other friends/family have tried more often than me and still failed. Hate the disappointment... but still so curious. Lol
author: Maria T.

description:
If they are open and they are not out of egg tart, i will end up eating half dozen of them. Glad that they are "vacation" most of the time, or else my health will be in a must worst shape than it is now. Those damn delicious, silky smooth, and sweet custard paired flaky crust is deadly. The price increased to $1.75 each, no longer $0.75. Still, i would eat this over any of those fancy macaroon.

Just a thought, i don't remember any food service establishment ever go on vacation that often.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Fabulous freshly baked eggs tarts!!!  12 Pc for under $24 - a bit expensive. But freshly baked - priceless! Almond cookies are good too! 
Foods - 5 stars
Getting yell at by a middle aged Chinese woman... Omg! So authentic! Remind me off my childhood in HK! Also priceless! So guys be prepared to get yelled at!
author: Peggy W.

description: Fabulous Moon Cakes and incredible Lemon Tarts
author: m j.

description: how good is this place? let me put it this way: when my friends from hong kong visit me here in sf, they bring a box of the dan tarts from this bakery back to hong kong!
author: Randy M.

description: Hands down the best egg tarts ever !!! When ever I come to SF I have to come here to get a couple dozens of egg tarts. Although coming here is based on luck it's still worth it mainly this is because they aren't always open or you run into them being on vacation but when you do come and it open your like yes hallelujah but it's a long line. Even with the line it's worth it especially because of the egg tarts and the banana thing ...oh and the the cupcakes !!
author: Maybeline C.

description:
On the rare occasion they're not on a vacation from all the money they make, it is a must to stop by for their egg tarts when they're actually open for business! I've stopped by here multiple times when I was in SF but today was finally the day where it was actually opened. The line was super long and I waited over 30 minutes for some freshly baked egg tarts. It tasted really yummy and the egg tart stayed hot as I ate and walked around Chinatown. Egg tarts sell for $1.75 each which is the most expensive egg tart I've had but it's definitely one of my top 3 egg tarts. You can also buy a dozen for $21. 

Finding parking will be a struggle in this area. One way streets, only parking on one side of the street and you got pedestrians crossing even when they're not suppose to will make finding parking a challenge. I noticed a lot of people just got dropped off or some people double parked right outside of the bakery.
author: Anne H.

description:
Anyone that tells you that the tarts are anything short of culinary nirvana needs to seriously reevaluate their core values in life. It's useless to wax poetic trying to describe them, you just have to try them for yourself. 

Drove down to SF a few times over the last few months to visit family but really the main motivation was nabbing a box full of coconut tarts. Definitely my favorite bite from Chinatown and the Bay Area and possibly even life.

In writing this, I don't think I'm building hype so much as spreading gospel. You need these tarts in your life.
author: Rei R.

description:
I can't believe this place is finally open from being on vacation for months!!! I've gone past Golden Gate Bakery 5 times within several months and every single time, the "on vacation" sign has been up. 

My boyfriend and I were in Chinatown during Chinese New Year weekend and I decided to try my luck. I was so lucky! This place was open and the line wasn't too long! :) My boyfriend and I waited for maybe 20 minutes, but it was so totally worth it. I actually enjoyed the wait because it allowed me to look at their different bakery varieties and think about what I wanted. By the time I reached the front of the line, I ordered 2 egg tarts and 2 other Chinese new year desserts. 

I wish I ordered more than 2 egg tarts, like half a dozen or a dozen!!! I am totally serious. They were soooo good. Just writing about it right now is making me drool....sigh. Anyways, the egg tarts were cheap and delicious. The egg tarts are big in size. Bigger than the ones at dim sum restaurants. However, they taste 100% better than dim sum restaurants. They are fresh and creamy. You know its fresh by the way it smells and looking at the yolk part of the egg tart. If the yolk part of the egg tart is not dry, darkened, or thick/hardened, its definitely fresh. I ate 2 egg tarts in less than 10minutes. It was that good! The other two desserts I ordered were good as well. 

I am coming back, very soon, Golden Gate Bakery. Please be open and not on vacation again! :)
author: Jenifer L.

description: If you're reading these reviews then you should stop. This place is fantastic, just go! It's a small little hole in the wall so don't think it is a sit down place. But everything they have is top notch! Custard pies are what theyre famous for I think, really really great.
author: Tom R.

description:
I want to like this place.  I try to stop by whenever I visit Chinatown.  It may be my bad luck but this place is closed more often than it is open.  They just post a sign that they are on vacation with no return date.

They ought to post on Yelp if they are going to be away for an extend period of time or update their website, which I just found.  This is not the right way to operate a business.

Their egg custards are quite good but I am going to find another bakery that is more reliable.  Any suggestions?
author: William L.

description:
YO IMMA LET YOU FINISH BUT GOLDEN GATE BAKERY HAS THE BEST EGG TARTS OF ALL TIME!!!!!!!!!!

Now that my Kanye rant is over, I'd like to call out that this place has some bomb pastries as well.  They offer very competitive prices, but the vibe can be a little 'touristy' at times due to long lines.
author: David C.

description: At first, we drove by and saw that it was closed even though the hours on Yelp says otherwise. People were trying to peak in to see if they'd open. After searching for parking, we walked by again to see if it was still closed just to see a long line that had formed. Everyone was getting the egg tart so we got it too. The breading was very buttery and crunchy. We also got half a dozen of coconut macaroons. The macaroons are buttery and crunchy. It's probably one of the best I've had. I actually liked it over the egg tart.
author: Nina S.

description:
Having grown up loving egg tarts (or anything egg related), I couldn't pass off the opportunity to try these famed egg tarts on a visit to SF. Luckily, I only had to wait about 20 minutes to get my hands on these delicious tarts on a Thursday evening. It's a bakery after all so they do have other items but I didn't see anyone order anything other than the tarts while I was there. I ordered 15 tarts from a fresh batch and ate them right away in my car. Caution: VERY HOT!

I believe these tarts lived up to their hype. I did wish there were a little less filling and a little more crust but these were still the best egg tarts I've ever had. If these were made in Texas, I would have gotten them for my wedding.
author: Aron Y.

description: Best egg tarts I ever had in my life! Hot and fresh out of the oven and melts in your mouth!
author: Andy N.

description:
I came here around 3pm on a Saturday and ended up waiting about 45 minutes. We ordered a dozen egg tarts, but I really wish we had ordered more. For only $1.35, they aren't too expensive for being the best egg tarts I have ever had. Every batch seems to be fresh from the oven, which is why the line is so long and everyone seems to love it. 

The egg tart has a flaky crust and a soft inside. I've had fresh ones before, but it has NEVER tasted this good. This is certainly worth the wait, but make sure to check the facebook page to see if it's open before heading over.
author: Edward W.

description:
I stopped by Chinatown to grab afternoon tea with a friend and were on a mission to find good eats. She suggested we stop by Golden Gate Bakery to see if they were open, I confusingly followed her. Apparently, they have a PERMANENT sign on their door saying closed for vacation so they can open their shop at different hours of the day. It was around 3PM on a Monday when we stopped by and saw a Chinese woman glancing out the door. My friend knocked on the door to check if they were open and she cracked the door open momentarily to inform my friend they were opening at 4PM. 

We walked around and returned around 3:45PM to find a line forming outside the establishment. It was around 4:05PM when the doors were finally open, the line consisted of a mixture of regulars and tourists. It felt like we were at the blackmarket for egg tarts. One of the women at the front of the line was antsy from the waiting and kept pestering the workers. She really needed her fix. We had to stay outside the establishment and tell them our orders and pass cash through the door. It was CRAZY. I have never seen people so eager for egg tarts.

I got half a dozen ($10.50) HOT EGG TARTS for my family. My friend got two ($1.75 each) to share and ate them outside the store. The custard was perfection. The balance of eggy-goodness with the splash of sweetness was amazing. The crust was flaky and everything was still hot!

It was definitely worth the experience!! I would recommend to go if you are in the area, although they are on the pricey side! I'm used to egg tarts being 90 cents in the Bay but let's be real. It was bomb. I would definitely go back. 

Tips:
-Cash only
-Unpredictable hours
-Try to call ahead and place an order! I saw someone cut the whole line and they had everything already packaged!
-Worth
author: Elena L.

description:
UPDATE (9/1/13): Price increase to $1.40 each, say whaaaaaa. But, they still taste herra good.

The hype is legit.

On a Monday afternoon, I finally had the opportunity to wait in line for the famous GGB dan tats (resident of the SF Big Eat 2013 list: http://www.7x7.com/big-eat-2013#/38). Fortunately, the wait to the counter was only 15 minutes, as I was already in a 45-minute wait for the Obama-graced Great Eastern dimsum restaurant. At $1.35 each ($16.20 for a dozen, http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/SYsV4RFMkPwjqgbeq0VcIg/l.jpg), these are some pricey pastries, but they are worth every pretty penny.

Dan tats, or egg custard tarts, are denser than most other custard desserts (flan, pot de cremes, puddings). Alongside the custard filling, the crust is another judgment factor, which is typically a shortcrust pastry made of a combination of butter and lard to achieve the pinnacle multi-layer flakiness. Seriously, when a dan tat tastes that good, it's probably made with some good ol' lard because that's what is holding all those flaky layers together.

Their crust is perfect. A perfect crust is not only flaky but also thin so that it complements, not overpowers, the custard filling. This is the thinnest crust I've ever had on a dan tat: crispy and airy without a hint of sogginess. Seriously, how the ultra-thin bottom layer resists moisture absorption is beyond my comprehension. And the multiple vertical layers of pastry in the crust bring me to tears (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/20qxofAo0tiOCy2GGYoAgQ/l.jpg). It's a work of art, it really is.

Having baked my own n00b version of dan tats, I can say that the crust takes the most effort. But the custard cannot be underestimated because if you don't bake the tart to the right consistency, you can dry out the filling or have it too wet. They bake it with just the right amount of firmness on top and light mushiness inside, creating a silky-smooth, vanilla-sweet experience. They lean more on the flavor of vanilla rather than on the flavor of egg yolk, which lends more toward texture.

I would also agree with Lawrence E. that dan tats taste better after a bit of cooling rather than fresh out of the oven. The waiting allows the custard to solidify in texture and flavor so that you can focus more on the taste, not on temperature. But warm dan tats are better than cold ones! That being said...

I've read that dan tats are good for next-day consumption, but try to avoid sticking them in the fridge (crust gets soggy) or the microwave (crust gets hard). Rule of thumb for warm dan tats seems to be sticking them for a few seconds in an oven or toaster oven.

A bit expensive at $1.35 a piece, but damn, this stuff is good, especially if you're craving lard! ;)

Experimental results UPDATE: The crust definitely hardens when the dan tats are stored in the fridge, but a minute or so in the toaster oven will soften things up (flakiness is lost, inevitably). The custard filling stayed consistently delicious even after 3 days in the fridge, but the crust on the bottom got a bit soggy from the custard. Condensation doesn't seem to be a problem, thank goodness. These are some good egg tarts!
author: Adele F.

description: As always busy with line for 30 minutes for non holiday period.  The egg tart is big and can be share with one other.  I am not giving fit h star because no moon cake is available.
author: Hungry D.

description:
FRESHEST egg tarts you'll (likely) ever have. When I arrived at the front of the inevitable long line, the egg tarts in the display had run out and a fresh batch from the oven was brought out. The egg tart was so hot that I had to wait a couple minutes before starting on it. To this day I haven't had a better one, simply because of how fresh this one was. Hot, creamy egg custard inside a crispy and oily tart. They time freshness really well with demand and that's a huge differentiator when it comes to egg tarts!

They're often on "vacation", probably because they're so successful (the minute they open there's a line) so check online before you go.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Go here if you like SWEET SCRAMBLED EGGS.

I lined up for half an hour for these egg tarts and I guess I was expecting an egg custard but instead it tasted like a watery sweet egg omelette sitting inside a pastry shell. It wasn't custard-like at all! Goddamn I wasted all that time expecting something else. The coconut muffin thing was a little better. F*** you and your soggy sugar omelettes Golden Gate Bakery! :(

Update: I threw up. Sweet Scrambled Eggs.
author: Bhavi A.

description:
can I just eat egg tarts all day everyday for the rest of my life? I love my Dan Tat.

this small little bakery in Chinatown puts out some of the freshest and most delicious egg tarts I've ever had. I walked about 15 minutes from the financial district after work. not really too much of a line... maybe 3 or 4 people in front of me and a couple showed up after. we were all waiting for fresh egg tarts straight from the oven. worth the wait!

compared to other egg tarts I've had, these ones seemed bigger and actually a little sturdier. they didn't just fall apart on you, which is good. 

at $1.60 each ($19.20/dozen) these are definitely pricier so I wouldn't go here on the regular. my boyfriend usually gets me egg tarts from somewhere in Oakland Chinatown for less than half the price (65 or 70 cents!), and they satisfy that egg tart craving just the same.
author: Evelyn S.

description: I was expecting a line and did have to wait for almost an hour. Have cash handy. I got an egg tart, two moon cakes and a giant sesame ball. The moon cakes were very pricey (approx $8) and in my opinion not that good. The egg yolk in the middle tasted like it had gone bad so I barely ate them. The egg custard was good, but the stand out for me was the sesame ball. I would go back just for those.
author: Julia W.

description: BEST EGG TARTS EVER. Every bite was Crisp, flaky, not overly sweet, and so, so memorable. What's amazing is that the bottom never turned soggy, even after refrigerating and reheating. The line is long, but you won't regret it.
author: Victor N.

description: Biggest regret of my trip was not buying a dozen of these egg tarts. My bestie and I spontaneously decided to get some egg tarts to go and to our surprise, they were WAY BETTER than expected. I'm obsessed.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Disclaimer that I'm new to SF and even with this accounted for - hence the 3 and not 2 or possibly 1 rating - I am not understanding the hype.

I tried the egg tart ($1.60) and double yolk lotus mooncake (~$8-9) - egg tart tasted normal and the mooncake was not great; the lotus paste wasn't smooth and the eggs were a tad runny.

Key takeaway: paying steep premiums for subpar taste blows.
author: Amy G.

description:
APPARENTLY THIS IS THE SPOT TO GO IN CHINA TOWN IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR EGG TARTS.

I am not a big fan of egg tarts, but when I visited San Francisco my girlfriend recommended to come here to get egg tarts. The shop is small and there was a huge line, we ended up waiting 25 minutes to get our egg tarts. The egg tarts cost $1.75 each, and we ordered a dozen. 

The egg tarts were cooked perfectly, and the crust is nice and flaky and just falls apart in your mouth when you take a bite. The egg also taste really fresh, and there is a good thick layer of it, which is in good proportion to the amount of crust. 

If you're looking for a place with good egg tarts, this is your place to go. Just be prepared to wait for about 20 minutes and pay $1.75 per egg tart. The price is definitely worth it, as you'll fall in love after one bite.
author: Gregory L.

description: Is it worth the wait for these delicious egg tarts?  Yes yes yes.  Love it. Fresh out of the oven. So soft and tasty.
author: Seeja N.

description:
FIVE STARS FOR THE BEST EGG TARTS I HAVE EVER EATEN! 

I am not a big egg tart person.. In fact, I generally don't scarf down any other egg tarts aside from this places. They're just so gosh darn deelish here!!! Freshly baked with a line constantly out the door! The women inside are consistently moving to provide the world with egg tarts! 

On the down side, these women also take vacations whenever they feel like it. So if you are going to SF specifically for these egg tarts, I would recommend calling first to make sure they're open rather than driving here through the hectic ChinaTown to see a paper sign saying "We on vacation." without even a date when they will be back... Haha... Prices are on the higher end for egg tarts too! But hey! These egg tarts are no joke! Definitely worth the price!
author: Kim N.

description: I was fortunate this trip to San Francisco to experience Golden Gate Bakery.  It's usually a hit or miss because they pretty much open whenever they would like to.  The egg tarts are good with thin crust and the egg is nice and smooth but there's nothing special about it.  I would say give it a try.
author: Alice T.

description: BEST EGG TARTS I'VE EVER EATEN...and I've eaten a lot of egg tarts in my lifetime. This egg tart stands out because of the hot gooey custard and the firm and flaky crust. A great snack to munch on as you explore chinatown SF. The only downside is the long line.
author: Jacob T.

description: Went there just before closing, the price of the egg custard tarts are $1.95 each.  It tasted really nice, but I also went to New Hollywood Bakery and Restaurant and it was $1.75 for 3, tastes just as good.
author: A F.

description:
I love egg tarts and when I asked around about places to go in San Francisco, Golden Gate Bakery was suggested to me.  I was able to get to Chinatown via cable car from Union Square.  The walk was short and I found myself out front.  They don't allow photos inside so I took a photo of the storefront.  The line was short when I arrived but quickly lengthened as I put my order in.  I ordered 2 egg tarts and 2 BBQ pork rolls.  I didn't see any egg tarts in the display case but the lady behind the counter assured me there were some in the back.  All for $6.16!  The place didn't look like it had a credit card machine so I paid with cash.  

As I made my way down the block, I inhaled a pork roll and an egg tart.  It was so very good.  The BBQ pork roll was perfectly cooked with just a little sauce inside a pastry crust.  It was flaky, golden, and buttery.  The egg tart wasn't too sweet and the crust was flaky too.  I didn't care how many calories it was because I knew I'd burn it off walking around the neighborhood.  I saved the other 2 pastries for my cousin and she gratefully ate the pork roll before we headed out for lunch.
author: Trina D.

description:
A lot of hype, but definitely worth a try. A lot of people are saying that these egg tarts are amazing. Admittedly. they are very well done. However, it should be noted that everyone has different preferences for egg tarts. These are not rich, buttery egg tarts which can be found at 85ºC. These are sweet, lighter, eggy, and excellent. TBH they taste like childhood. Would recommend. 

Also, because everyone talks about their egg tarts -- there's another pastry which is like banana rice cake or something like that. It's like really soft mochi with banana flavoring. Very aromatic, light, and a really great texture. Don't just buy egg tarts!!! Show the other pastries some love
author: Alex L.

description: I bought moon cake yesterday! it was pretty good ! so yummy but the price was a little bit expensive..I wish I can try egg tarts next time!!!
author: Michelle W.

description: The egg tarts were worth it. Long wait in the cold. This is also cash only. Best to get at least a dozen for 20$ total. Freshly made.
author: Arjan N.

description: Waited 2 hours for tye fresh out of the oven egg tart that did not disappointbut you have to have it fresh. If the eat it the next day, a few seconds in the microwave will make it good again.
author: Suzie Y.

description: The egg tarts are a must get!!! Whenever I'm in the city, I try to make a trip to Chinatown just to get these addicting desserts. The shop is like most shops in Chinatown with an unattractive exterior to match its interior. There is only a small cramped space in front of the counter for you to place your order. The egg tarts are now $1.50 each (Cash only), which is a pricey. However, considering how I've very had egg tarts this delicious, the price is justified. The egg tarts are larger than your average egg tart and are always hot and fresh when I have ordered them. People say that there's always a long wait, but I've never experienced this since I probably come during off times. On the downside, Golden Gate Bakery often closes randomly for no reason, so I would suggest calling ahead of time to see if they are open.
author: Melanie H.

description:
I was never a big fan of egg tarts in general cause I don't like crusty stuff. But GG Bakery totally changed my mind!!! My friend wanted to get some and this was my opportunity to try some.

Its located right smack in the middle of Chinatown on Grant and Jackson I believe? Just find a Chase or the long line and you'll find it. 

I'm not sure how much is each but one dozen is about $16? $17 or so! Kinda pricey for egg tarts but alllll worth it!!! 

The crust is different than most places. It's not too crusty where you have crumbs. I like that!!! And the creamy egg was soo delicious! You could barely taste the egg. I definitely will come back to this place forsho.
author: Phung D.

description:
Does Golden Gate Bakery really need another review of their amazing egg tarts? Probably not, but I'll add my two cents anyways along with other pastries I tried.

Custard Tart aka the egg tart -  I've had many good egg tarts in the past, but this bakery churns out some really delectable ones.  Since so many people waiting in line usually walk away with a dozen of these little golden cups, chances are you will receive some fresh from the oven as well. The sweet egg custard filling is steamy, the crust is flakey, and they ready to be enjoyed by your taste buds.

Sesame Ball with Bean Paste - My second favorite item from the bakery.  The outside crust is nice and crispy, while the inside is chewy mochi with bean paste filling.  Yummy!

With that being said, whenever I am in SF (which is rare cause I hate SF traffic), I make sure to stop by Golden Gate Bakery. They have the oddest hours though... It's more like, "We're open whenever we want" type of deal.  There's a website/facebook page dedicated to letting the public know if they are open or not, so be sure to check it or call them to confirm.
author: Kathy N.

description: Wooow just wow! Most amazing egg tarts Ive had! Could be compared to macau's potats! Soo flaky and buttery! A melt in your mouth goodness!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
The best egg tarts you will ever have in your life probably! I made sure to call ahead and came here the day after New Years when they said they would open at 11. Got there a few minutes before 11 and there was already a line! The bakery didn't even open yet... I guess everyone knows to call ahead nowadays.

A dozen egg tarts are $21 or $1.75 each. There's no discount for buying more because it is THAT good! Although the price increased, it is still cheaper than say B. Patisserie's Kouign Amaan which has the same flakey taste with no egg custard. 

I wish they still sell the French bread they had years ago. That was my childhood :( Oh well, broken dreams... I guess the Mexican bun is close enough.

CASH ONLY
author: Karmen T.

description:
This place has the best egg custard tart I've ever had. The crust is slightly sweet and doesnt crumble when you hold it up. The egg custard is simply heavenly and melts in your mouth. 

There is always a LONG line for the bakery, but I'd be happy to queue for an hour just to get my hands on the egg tarts. There was once, I even saw a cop waiting in line behind me to get his hands on those egg tarts too.
author: Christina N.

description: The egg tarts are as amazing as everyone says. They are warm, delicious and some might say life changing. The price is $2 each and the line is long and moves slowly but completely worth it!
author: Steven T.

description: Asked my friend to order a dozen since he's was one of the first ones in line.  The egg tarts was still very warm and fresh.  Great creamy texture in the middle and flaky crust.  Would I wait 1-2 hours in line for this? Heck no. This is not the best egg tart in the world but it's still pretty on top of the list.
author: Wayne L.

description:
Four words: go for egg tarts!!!

Flaky hot crust, custard-y interior.  Cash-only.  Awesome 5-minute experience.
author: Sandee T.

description:
Finally ..... They back from long vacation!!! 
Everything just pretty good as usual. The egg tart is  still the must have in China Town!
author: Chou t.

description:
Well... can't believe that I've never written a review about this landmark institution.
In my childhood days, this bakery was less than memorable other than being "that place" next to Sun Sing movie theater, watching the Shaw Bros.' classics of Wang Yu and Cheng Pei Pei (Q. Tarantino often touts the influence of this movie genre on his filmmaking skills).  The movie house was my weekly Mandarin class (between age 9 to 12), listening to shrieks, grunts, and groans from swordfighting films.
About ten years ago, this bakery started getting a reputation for their now legendary egg custard tarts (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  A rumor spread about four years ago that the tart maestro passed away, spurring rumors that "it's not as good anymore."  Well, it certainly hasn't deterred anyone about lining up here.
With the moon cake festival fast approaching, they finally reopened about ten days ago, much to the delight of the tart lovers and mooncake givers like myself.  I ordered several boxes for friends and business contacts comprising of a mix of four different varieties:  pineapple with egg, red bean, lotus paste with egg, and mixed nuts (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=NhE3W_qkSccBcjaoDdmF-w).  
Mooncakes are a plenty now as the week counts down to 9/8 Harvest Moon night.  The Chinatown stores are setting up tables OUTSIDE their stores to clear their inventory, Costco has them, but my friends seem to enjoy this one the best.  So get there early if you need the tart fix or have a mooncake shopping list to fill.  The only reason this isn't a five star review is no one can predict when they are open or closed.  And, by the way, if you make it here this week, no, the screaming that you hear won't be from the kung fu movies; more likely, it'll be from those harsh words, "Sold out!"
author: Mike C.

description:
When I was little, I never understood why my mom insisted we had to stand in this GIANT line everytime we were in San Francisco. They're just dan tat right? Now that I'm not as naive, I learned that not all dan tats are made equal. 

Their tarts are wonderfully eggy and not super sweet like most other bakeries. The tart is so flaky, I'm afraid to know what they use to get it so. Yes the line is long, yes sometimes it's frustrating that they're closed (you know there's a website to check http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ you're welcome) but I don't think any other dan tat compares to theirs. Once I was in SF and the website said they were closed, and a SF native friend recommended AA bakery. I brought them home and my mom took one bite and she said "These aren't the Golden Gate ones" that's how distinctive they are. For egg-cellent dan tats in Chinatown, this is the only place you should go!
author: Teresa N.

description:
Pros

Egg custard tart.   These are the Steph Curry of custard tarts.  Possibly best in the world

Cons

Expensive.  These tarts make max money.  Franchise player money. 
Line too dang long, like opening night for Star Wars movie 
Too many people come here
Closed for vacation a lot.  They make too much money by overcharging for custard tarts

They may put crack in the tarts cuz peoples keep lining up for it like needing a fix
author: John L.

description:
When they're open and not on vacation, this place serves up the best Dan Tat that I've ever had especially when they're fresh and warm (not hot because I've actually burned my mouth).

I used to come to the City when traveling from NYC and each time these guys were on vacation. Didn't matter what time of year I visited, they were always closed for vacation. I wonder how they survive only being open 3-4 weeks out of the year?!?!

I've actually tasted these little beauties maybe, 4-5 times and they are delicious! Sometimes there's a line but well worth the wait, well worth the commute.

Don't trust Yelp with the hours because one time Yelp said they were open and when I got there, CLOSED for vacation of course.
author: Scott L.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is an old style Chinese bakery that has some items that are harder to find in the newer, trendier bakeries.  People line up here for one thing and it is the dan tart.  What is a dan tart?  It is an egg custard pastry.  Dan tarts are supposed to have an eggy custardy center and a flaky pastry, though some places have modified the flaky crust to make more of a cookie crust.  I much prefer the flaky crust over the cookie crust.  Also, I find bakeries tend to either make a good custard and bad crust or a good crust and bad custard.  It's rare to find a bakery that can do both. Over the years, dan tarts have also suffered from poor quality and the custard has deteriorated from having a real eggy taste to some that have no custard taste or creaminess at all. Some are so brightly yellow that they actually have a neon glow and can light your way through darkness.

Not so here, the dan tart custard is soft, custardy, warm, super creamy and utterly delicious. The crust is stark contrast to the sweetened center.  The crust tends to be salty and I must have gone later in the day, but my crust was not flaky.  There is though, a nice contrast between sweet custard and salty crust.  If you cannot get both components of a dan tart perfect, at least one should be superior and Golden Gate Bakery excels in the custard, so don't miss out.  Go where all the locals are lining up because they know where to get a good dan tart. One dan tart will set you back $1.50.

On another day, I tested out their banana rolls and not as good as others I have tasted.  It seems like I was eating just a mass of glutinous sweet rice flour with a splash of banana flavoring. These banana rolls are $.80 a piece.  Better off adding $.70 and going straight for the dan tart, where your money will be better spent.

They also have these really hot pink pastry boxes, so if you have a quantity of dan tarts, you too could be walking out in hard not to spot box.  Just don't let anyone snatch your dan tarts away!

The four stars is for the dan tart!
author: Lin Y.

description:
DESPITE the fact that this place is poorly organized...

DESPITE the fact that I felt like I only minimally knew when egg tarts were coming out because I spoke Cantonese and overheard the worker ladies talking to each other...

and DESPITE the fact that my group of 15+ people and I waited 30-45 minutes for 2 dozen egg tarts to come out...

5 stars. The dan tats are straight up the best I've ever had in America, probably only to be topped by the Portuguese egg tarts I've had in Macau on the OTHER SIDE of the freaking world. I would wait in confusion again, and I'd definitely get more than 1 for myself the next time (still slapping myself over that). Boom. Not much more I can say.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This bakery, without a doubt, has the best egg tarts I've ever had!

The custard portion of the egg tart was soft and sweet.  The crust, flaky and buttery.  Simply delicious!  I can normally stuff down 3 egg tarts in one sitting, no joke, and these babies ain't small :P

Another favorite of mine is their custard Napoleon with coconut flakes.  A much sweeter pastry than the egg custards, but tastes amazing as well!  

Definitely worth the crazy long lines to get them since the egg tarts I've had elsewhere were nowhere near as good!
author: Veronica C.

description: Awful customer service. Called to ask what time they were open until and they asked "what do you want to buy?" And then when I answered that we wanted to come look at what they had she literally said "we only have one cake, okay bye." And hung up on me. WILL NEVER get my business. Ever.
author: Julie L.

description:
If I'm in San Fran this is one of my favorite stops. Their egg tarts are huge and so delicious, I can eat five and still want to eat more. I've been lucky the times that I've stopped by since the lines weren't too long but I've seen the line out the door for this place.
I haven't tried anything else besides the egg tarts here but that alone is enough to bring me back again and again.
author: Allison S.

description:
The last two times I was in SF, they were closed.  But this time, I was determined to get my egg tarts!  So determined in fact that I waited 2 hours in line.  Yeah, definitely won't be doing that again.  Words of advice: Don't go to Golden Gate Bakery during the Harvest Moon Festival.

Was it worth the wait?  Heck no.  I would wait maybe 30 minutes.  Maybe.  The egg tarts are pretty good, but I've had better at dim sum restaurants.  Elite Restaurant in Monterey Park, CA is currently home to my favorite egg tarts.

Note: Egg tarts are $1.35 each and they even taste great rewarmed in the oven!
author: Peter P.

description:
Hmmm nothing beats burning the roof of my mouth while I am stuffing myself with fresh out-of-the-oven egg tarts! 

Every time I visit SF, I'd always have to stop here. I can still recall my first experience here. I never cared for this pastry but by the overwhelming popularity, I had to give it a try. Though, I must admit, I was a bit intimidated by the size of this thing--it's the size of my palm!! That first taste was so good. I've never had an egg tart that had a delicious egg flavor and wasn't overloaded with sweetness. 

They have increased in price and I've read other yelp reviews that recommend other local places. I have yet to try those places but until I do, Golden Gate will forever hold a special place in my taste buds.
author: Krissy D.

description: On vacation...seems like they're ALWAYS  on vacation.  Egg tarts are good and yes the wait is worth it; however, I think the owners are taking advantage of their popularity.  Someday, people will find other places that are comparable and maybe even closer than taking a trek out to Chinatown.  I will be boycotting them.
author: Emme L.

description: Fantastic egg tart. We couldn't even wait to have it. Freshly baked every box. Love it! Long long lines. We waited for 1 hour. But definitely worth it
author: Michelle C.

description:
Large flaky warm custardy egg tarts.....
but you can only get them once in a blue moon because the owners are always vacationing! When they actually ARE open, you'll know where they are based on the long line on Grant Ave.

I've probably come to this place 6 times but only actually caught them open twice because they were away for vacation. Fortunately, I chit chatted with them the last time I was there and they told me that they vacation in LA and that next time they're down there, they're going to bring me egg tarts! WOOO. I'm holding em to it!
author: Krystle T.

description:
I was very skeptical that these dan ta were worth the price, especially since I love love love the Portuguese-style dan ta over at Napoleon Bakery in Oakland, Chinatown.  I stand corrected.  I went on a random Wednesday afternoon and there was hardly a line.  The Cantonese ladies were pleasant and I got my dan ta's piping hot (they don't put them in the shelves with the other pastries, they're always being warmed up in the back)!  I didn't get a chance to try them until a few hours later, but oh my goodness, dat custard!  It's good stuff!  The crust was good but nothing mind blowing (I think Oakland's Napoleon might have a slight edge here), but the filling really impressed me.  It wasn't too sweet and tasted thick, buttery, and eggy.  

The perfect dan ta.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
The egg tarts are really as good as everyone claims them to be. I knew I had to check this place out when I was in SF after hearing people rave about this place. Unknowingly, I went during the Mid-Autumn Festival weekend and Chinatown was PACKED. The shop was on the street where they blocked off to set up street vendors. But because it was this special weekend, the bakery was OPEN! By the time we got our goodies and left the shop, the line was even longer. 

I stood in line for almost 1.5 hours. But 1 bite into those fresh and piping hot egg tarts, all the wait was forgotten. This was so delicious! I ended up buying a dozen to take back to LA to share with family and friends! 

Since it was during Mid-Autumn Festival, I knew i had to try some of their mooncakes. I opted for a less traditional one since I can get those anywhere, so I got the almond with egg yolk. The almond was so fragrant and the flavors were great! 

I will definitely be coming back the next time I come to SF.
author: Vickie C.

description:
5 amazing, delicious, and-I-don't-even-like-egg tarts stars for the egg tarts. Flaky crust, and yummy but not too sweet custard. 

2 stars for the customer interaction (using "service" would be a falsehood)...
Bakery: "What do you want?"

Me: "1 dozen please!" (while placing 21 bucks firmly on the counter with a huge smile)

Bakery: (gestures an order for 1 dozen over to the gal prepacking them in the boxes) Then talks past me to the girl sitting to the side and says to her "2 boxes of 6 almost ready" 

Me: (light bulb goes on in my head-this girl is a genius) "Is 2 boxes of 6 still a dozen for $21?" (asked like I cant properly do math)

Bakery: "Yes." (queue enlightened music)

Me: "Can I please change my order to 2 boxes of 6?"

Bakery: (no sign of acknowledgement and proceeds to take the orders of those behind me in line)

Me: (makes eye contact with her, while looking confused)

Bakery: "You made wrong order so I have to help other people first."

Me: "Sorry"
(while still standing there and continuing to look sad and very sorry/apologetic...fearful of the potential dreaded words "NO TART FOR YOU", and praying for her to have pity on me)

Bakery: (helps a couple more people behind me) (time passes) Gal finally turns to me and says "Your order coming up". (handed me the boxes)

Me: (got the dozen tarts and left quietly while looking ever so thankful for granting me the privilege to purchase it)

LOL-Soup Nazi experience! While leaving, I was laughing so hard inside.

TIP: If ordering a dozen, ask for 2 boxes of 6. They cant pack these things fast enough. So they are packed steaming hot. Each box fits a layer of 6. Packing the dozen in two boxes allows for the tarts to vent/set, else the tarts will be stacked as two layers in 1 box...which would probably leave you with a soggy mess bottom layer.

10 cents extra if you want a plastic bag for the boxes

The reviews on extended, random vacations are true. 3 out of the last 5 times I've stopped by they were on vacation. This was the first time I waited in line because I wanted it bad enough.

5 stars for the taste, -1 for service, - 1 for price. 3 stars.
author: Jen Z.

description:
Another win from the 7x7 list: the egg custard tarts are indeed delicious. The women working the bakery were very polite, especially for Chinatown, and gave us a tart straight out of the oven. It's a delicious combination of sweet and savory, with the hot runny egg custard, and the buttery tart.

Highly recommended, but I'm not so sure it's worth waiting on the notorious lines, especially if you don't get one fresh out of the oven like we got. We were lucky to be there when it was empty, and it was an excellent experience.
author: Mike C.

description: Stood in line on new years day for 30 mins for this egg custard from heaven. I was freezing while i was waiting but once it was my turn and i got them it was totally worth it. 12 for 21 dollar, soft on the outside and it melts once its in ur mouth. Best consumed right out the store. Pure heaven
author: Rudy S.

description:
Great food, crowded but I guess that means they're popular.

Getting into Chinatown can be a pain, but worth for the pork buns.
author: Andrew M.

description: My favorite egg tart place. Although there is usually a line. Parking on the street is tricky but there are parking lots near by. I once parked in yellow zone thinking I am just stopping for 5 minutes and for a ticket that made the egg tarts super super expensive that day.... but the moment I bite into that one Egg Tart everything is worth it!!!
author: Gaia W.

description: I've been eating these egg tarts since I was young! I wish the lines wouldn't get so long, but I still wait :) When they're hot, they're worth it. I would call ahead of time to see if they're open before you make the trek to Chinatown, but other than that--go and enjoy that buttery, flaky, custard pie when you can! They're amazing!
author: K L.

description: Get here early because there will be a long line. The egg tart is delicious but it has a strong egg taste. It is a bit pricey for a egg tart  in chinatown but its a must try if you are in town.
author: Joanna C.

description: My husband was lucky enough to happen upon Golden Gate when it was actually open. He snagged me a few egg tarts to go. Aaaah-mazing. Delicious, flaky crust. Never soggy. Perfect consistency in the filling. Bomb.com
author: Sarah B.

description:
After a year and a half of semi-stalking Golden Gate Bakery, which has a way of running out of egg tarts early or arbitrarily closing for the day at the whim of its owner, I finally managed to catch Golden Gate--at 8:40 a.m. on a Monday holiday. Since I happened to be meeting a friend in the area anyway, I decided to try my luck at Golden Gate, though to be safe, I called first to make sure they were open and serving egg tarts that day. 

To my surprise, Golden Gate already boasted a line when I arrived at 8:40, and I was #5. The egg tarts were being made at the moment, so my fellow egg tart aspirants and I spent a good 15-20 minutes waiting for the morning's first batch. 

Having spent more time than I have ever spent elsewhere for egg tarts, you can bet I got more than one, and I made sure to eat them hot. And yes, the egg tarts were hot, tasty and good. However, I am not exactly sure what all the rage is about. Nothing about the texture or taste stood out to me. Maybe I'm just a terribly impatient person, but next time, I think I'll stick with a quick dash in to one of the competing bakeries around the corner when I'm craving egg tarts.
author: Ada W.

description: Honestly...it's good. Yes, it's buttery. Yes, it's flakey; and yes it's freaking delicious. But factoring in the time waiting in line, is it really that much better than the dozen or so bakeries in SF Chinatown? Probably not. If you don't have time to wait, I would recommend visiting another bakery. Also, I surmise that they are purposely not as efficient to create a wait and buzz.
author: Jie S.

description:
Never open. No return date posted. 

Their egg tarts are ok. Quite pricey for a dozen - almost $20.

The rest of the items aren't as tasty. BBQ pork buns have a slightly curry (?) taste to it. Not cheap either. Coconut tarts are meh. The "ma jai" is hard.
author: Julie L.

description:
Boy better get to the back of that line. No not behind the person standing by the window front, behind the person on the opposite end a few yards back... No, keep going. Yup, there. Haha just kidding its not THAT bad but do expect at least a fifteen minute wait more or less depending on how badly the people in front of you wanna buy out the whole bakery. 

Parking- don't count on finding any 

SESAME BALLS - they should be called AMAZE BALLS. Fresh out da oven. My opinion, they're way better than the egg tart. The sesame seeds on the outside are ever so crispy and nicely toasted, when you bite into it your friend will audibly notice the unexpected crisp. Your teeth will then sink into the soft and chewy rice cake and then you reach the sweet red beans inside. Mmmmm my friend easily concluded it was a life changing moment. 

EGG TART - the crust is actually flaky and the filling really soft and eggy. Sweet and eggy.
author: Jane K.

description:
Egg tarts anyone? Although I'm not a huge fan of egg tarts, I can say that these were pretty good. They tasted more like eggs instead of sugar. I loved the crust. It was perfectly flaky and melted in my mouth. I would definitely go back here if I found myself in the area! They serve a variety of other baked goods which also looked as equally delicious! Must-try the moon cakes the next time I'm there!

The shop is a little on the small side - no seating, etc. It seems a bit disorganized at first when you buy, but they do get your order correctly. There was a short line that was pretty much constant throughout our time there! Definitely worth the wait!
author: Berna T.

description:
I tried their egg custard, banana mochi cake and apple roll.

Egg custard is good, the crust is flaky and thin(and the crust on the salty side), the custard is so soft and can't keep the shape if you don't hold it carefully. What I don't really like is the flavor of the custard which taste too eggy for me. I prefer the sweeter ones with rich caramel flavor. 

Banana mochi cake: ... I've had a better banana mochi cake at other bakeries just on the next street.... I don't like the flavor of the banana mochi cake here.

Apple roll:  It looks good, but I realized I would rather have a apple pie from Safeway upon the first bite. The apple filling inside the roll is on the sour side. And the roll cake is a little bland. 

Btw, they really have lots of vacation. I found them closed for vacation twice before I finally completed my first adventure here. You might want to check out if they open or not before coming. There is a website telling you if they open or not. It's convenient and can keep you from wasting time.
author: Jia-Ying X.

description:
Im drolling just thinking about GGB's Dan Ta....UGH. Fresh, hot, perfectly cooked. These babies are TO DIE FOR. Worth waiting in line for as long as they have Dan Ta left.

I'm also not sure why yelp says these are vegetarian?? Almost all of the places I have gotten Dan Ta from use some kind of lard in their crust who knows maybe that is what makes GGB different. I would ask but I think I might get turned out for asking about the recipe TT_TT. Anyways the crust isn't even the best part IMO. GGB'S perfect egg custard is one of those things that seems too good to be true.
author: Christine G.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS HANDS DOWN!
This review is just for their amazing egg tarts.
The wait for this bakery is looooong. The wait in the morning is quite long. However, if you go during the afternoon the line dies down. But there are always customers here. As you wait in line, you will see most customers walk out of the store with boxes and boxes. And what's in them?! 
Freshly made, out of the oven, egg tarts! You should probably get a dozen or two because if you just get a few, you just might regret it. The egg tarts are crispy on the outside and soft and warm on the inside. It has the perfect texture for an egg tart. Once you take a bite into one of these, you'll probably stuff the rest in your mouth as soon as you could. I know that's what I did! 

Btw they charge 10 cents per bag.
author: Crystal V.

description:
Finally came to this Chinatown institution. I had the chance to try their egg custard and seasme balls with red bean inside.

First, the egg custard is delicious and I give them credit for a really solid and tasty custard. What sets this place apart for the egg custard is the fact that the custard is larger than your standard fare at a dim sum restaurant. 

The sesame balls are equally awesome and only slightly less than a four star rating from me because they had been sitting out for a bit. In this aforementioned regard, a dim sum restaurant has them beat assuming they are making or heating up the item to order. Warm and soft with a slight crunch is how I like them and these were lukewarm and chewy.

All in all, is this place worth your time and the potential insanely long line? Yes, if you love egg custard and one of their specialty desserts. However, if you just want a three layer cake or sesame ball then your favorite dim sum place will do just fine.

I will definitely return when I need a quality fresh baked egg custard fix.
author: Corey H.

description:
Sporadic and random opening times and always closed on holidays. 
They're known for their egg tarts so we decided to try. 

It was a 45 minute wait ... to get egg tarts. 
Ok, so they were fresh, flakey, and melt in your egg tart, but honestly didn't think this + the wait really merit it 4 stars. You need to eat this thing fresh and hot, we ordered quite a few and just didn't have that same goodness hours later.

but you know what? you're in chinatown, and you have nothing else to do... so what's 45 minutes anyway right? ;)
author: Mimi C.

description: It's obvious from the first bite why this bakery is known for their egg custard. They constantly pull them from the oven, ensuring that each one is fresh and warm upon sale. My boyfriend and I stood in line for almost 30 minutes waiting to get a few of them! The time was 100% worth it, too!!! Check out their other pastries as well - the sesame rolls and black bean and lotus cakes and exceptional. The only complaint I would have is that it is the most expensive bakery of its kind I have ever been to - the ones in Chicago I am used to are much cheaper; but that's what you get for wanting the best in the city, and it is definitely worth every penny!
author: Kari C.

description:
Got lucky with them actually being opened AND with barely anyone in line. The wait was actually just waiting for the egg tarts to come out of the oven, yumm. 

The egg tarts are very good but it's still just an egg tart. The crust is flaky and not too thick, the custard ratio to crust is huuuuge! I had it piping hot and later when it cooled down more. Cooled down more actually tasted a lot better because you can actually taste the custard without it burning your tongue.

My advice is definitively come get some eggtarts when there's no much of a wait but if there's a 2+ hour wait = not worth it
author: Diana J.

description:
Had to check this place out myself because I've heard so many great things about their egg tarts and egg tarts are one of my favorite things!!  Busted a mission to get out here and walked from the BART station all the way to this bakery but it was so worth it!!

I really wouldn't know where you would park if you drove here yourself. Most likely street parking that's all full...but walking would probably be best.  

I got here around 7pm so NO LINE!! WOO HOO!!  

The chinese women were so kind and funny!!  

Egg tarts were fresh out of the oven and so hot and flakey.  It's the only thing I tried and I had to leave and bring back a box to SoCal. Everyone at the airport wanted some...so if you plan to bring some back, sneak it inside your bag! (lol)
author: Jennifer C.

description:
! Hands down the best egg tarts(dan tats)I have ever eaten in the world and in S.F., and could never be beat!
Pros: 
-Only had their Dan Tats here and you can buy as many as you want and it always comes out warm,sweet and oh so flaky
Cons:
-Since this place is famous for their dan tats, they always go by quick and people strip them off of the shelf or in this case, a warming rack so quickly as some people buy one to try it 
out,while others buy 6 or more of them
-another problem I have with them is they have a sporadic opening as you would need to harass them on the phone or stalk their Facebook/Twitter to see if they're open because if not and you are a tourist or someone in the mood for some egg tarts, you might not be in luck as they are not always open
-also the prices for the egg tarts are a bit to pricey, they are around 2 bucks each but are definitely worth it ! 
overall: This PLACE IS HEAVENLY AND THE ONLY NEGATIVE THING I HAVE TO SAY ABOUT THEM IS THAT THEY NEED TO CHANGE THEIR OPENING DAYS LIKE HAVE A CALENDAR ON THEIR DOOR SAYING WHEN THEY'RE OPEN OR HAVE SET OFF DAYS LIKE WEDNESDAY OR SATURDAYS(JUST AN EXAMPLE)
9.5/10 (the only thing holding this score back was the sporadic opening/closing,besides that then it would be a 10 definitely)
author: Food F.

description:
BEST. EGG. TART. EVER!!!
I couldn't believe it was open. Waited in line for an hour but it was worth it. I got 18 of these beautiful lovely babies (my wallet hurt. They are almost $2 each!!) to share and they were gone in no time. My first bite of these famous egg tarts was while walking up the streets of China town. It is extremely flakey on the outside and perfectly eggy and firm but soft and perfectly sweet on the inside. They're also crazy fresh! It was so piping hot it burned my tongue but it was so good that I made some weird gurgly noise "GAH SOO GOOD" and a man walking by laughed at me and asked in canto if it was good so with my mouth full of beautiful egg tart I answered "hooooo sik" meaning soooo tasty 
Tip: check for the bakery's geotag and hashtag on Instagram to see if it's open for the day! People will post pictures of their egg tarts when they get them! so it'll save you the time and trouble of running to China town just to discover they're closed! :)
author: Victoria C.

description: Don't get me wrong... I love yummy food and this bakery fulfilled my dessert cravings..... but I must say... it is not worth the wait. I waited about 30 minutes in the rain and the egg tart was pretty 8 out of 10. It tastes pretty egg-y and I'm not 100% if I'm into that..... O_O
author: Saemyi J.

description: This place was the highlight of our adventures in Chinatown. We got a Chinese donut, a custard tart and a sweet coconut bun. It was very affordable for what you got. This was such a good place I hope we can go back one more time before we leave. Just about anything in this place I would try at least once.
author: Leslie H.

description: Egg tart is the best, really better than other bakeries.  Worth waiting.
author: Richard L.

description:
Hands down the best egg tarts around.  I die when people bring these to potlucks.

I don't know what else is good here, and I don't care!
author: Lyn C.

description:
Yes, the egg custard tarts (dan tat) are very good, worth 4 stars or maybe - just maybe - 4.5 stars. They're generously thick, have the right level of eggy density, just the right hint of sweetness, and a good balance between flakiness and soft chewiness in the crust. The ladies who work this shop are also sweet, upbeat, and always on top of their game given the constantly long lines and endless barrage of questions from clueless non-Chinese customers and even more clueless tourists.

In my book, however, a Chinese bakery should be strong across the board to merit a stellar overall rating. I do like my custard buns, "pineapple" buns, and roast pork buns, for example. I tried all three, and they were just average (forgettable in the case of the custard bun), which was a bit underwhelming given how good the aforementioned egg custard tart was.

Nevertheless, the egg custard tart is totally worth the $1.25, and all the other items, despite being merely average, are much cheaper. While it's the best bakery in Chinatown, there may be other bakeries in suburban Asian enclaves that are stronger all around.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The best egg tarts I've had and deserving of the praise. 

The bakery itself has that great Chinatown feel.  There is absolutely no seating and the older Chinese ladies behind the counter are efficient and old school, doing all calculations on paper and wrapping boxes with plastic string. 

Prices are great, only $1.25 for egg tarts, and the many other items they serve ate similarly priced. 

But the star of course is the egg tarts.  The crust is unbelievably light and flavor and the egg tart has a light taste as well. 

Highly recommended and great for a quick visit, even with lines. 

Golden Gate Bakery is cash only.
author: Randy F.

description:
I must've been extremely lucky when I decided to buy some egg tarts, because when I came in there were less than 5 people waiting in line. This it took about only 20 minutes to get the delicious egg tarts that I drive from LA to see. 

Yes the egg tarts are worth the hype, like other reviews it is super flaky and the custard is so soft and flavorful it reminds me of flan. 

They are made super fresh and straight from the oven; how do I know? I burned my tongue eating one that just came out. 

There is a sign that says closed on vacation, therefore it really is a hit or miss coming here. 

After tasting the egg tarts it will definitely be worth the gamble.
author: Kyle S.

description: Went on a rainy day and the line was still 20-30 minutes long, but so worth it! The custard egg tarts are a little pricy at $2 each, but they're pretty big with lots of filling and made fresh so they're very flakey and gooey
author: Hai V.

description:
They always seem to be on vacation.. and when you just happen to have the luckiest of lucky days that they're open, the wait is suuuper ridiculous!! But then you finally get your foot in the door and impatiently patiently wait for the next lady to take your order and mannn.. the dan tats are ahhhhmaazeballlz!! Piping hot, extremely flaky crust (so yes, it's going to get EVERYWHERE when you eat it), and the custard inside is juuust egg-y enough. I'm salivating just thinking about it. I hate lines and I hate waiting, but damn.. these dan tats are WORTH THE WAIT.

Ca$h only!! CT problems. Seriously.
author: Leslie C.

description:
Given that the San Francisco Chinatown is the biggest out there, we had to make a pit stop during our long weekend trip.  And the only place I wanted to find was this Golden Gate Bakery - just to see why and how good the egg custards are!

Luckily for us, the bakery was open and there were about 4-5 egg custards left.  Since it was later in the evening, these were not the fresh out of the oven batch.  However, we paid and stepped out - I proceeded to dive straight in and see what it's all about.  The custard itself was not special (and perhaps it's because it wasn't fresh) but the egg part - wow!  It's been a while since I've had some good quality egg custard.  It took me a while to appreciate it.  After that, I slowed down and slowly savoured it.

The bakery did not look glamorous or stand out in anyway.  With this high of a review on yelp, it's nice to see they let the baked goods speak for themselves.  I was just slightly worried at first - not sure it it's the right place.  But point proven, the egg custards are pretty damn good!
author: Carrie L.

description: At 2pm, I called to check if they open. They said they open in 30mins, but I see this sight when I get there, I call again and they said they in vacation. Even the egg custard is good, but I have to remove this store out of my bookmark.
author: Linh N.

description:
JUST GET THE EGG TARTS!  

Locals, tourists and other types of people come here solely for their egg tarts.  This includes me as well.

I never bothered to order or to try anything else because their egg tarts are the most amazing, freshest egg tarts I have ever eaten in San Francisco/Bay Area!  Why spend money on something else that is made average?

I love how the crust is so flaky and the egg tart is warm, buttery and baked fresh from the oven.
