There is often a line out the door, but the servers are quick on getting your order. 

FYI the owners always take an annual mini vacation and closes the store so make sure they are opened before visiting this place!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Many many visits

Golden Gate Bakery is probably the best Chinese bakery in town. It's an establishment dated back to the 1940s. Here you will find traditional Chinese pastries like "wife cake", the signature "dat taat"---egg custard tart, pineapple bun, Swiss roll, puffy brioche, and macaroon (NOT macaron, I'm so frustrated many people think macaroon and macaron are the same things).

*Wife Cake: also known as sweetheart cake, the Golden Gate wife cake is very flaky with a thin skin. The crushed winter melon and almond paste filling is not too sweet. It's the only place in town you can find the "orthodox" candied mash of winter melon mixing with white sesame seed. I love it!

*Egg Custard Tart: is the store's signature item. Usually you'll have to wait as their supply cannot meet the demand. Unlike many other bakeries, Golden Gate uses only eggs and not the egg powder. Custard has a velvety, silky texture with a hint of vanilla. The crust is a pure decadence---a buttery and flaky crust holding together the throbbing egg custard. Worth every penny of $1.40 (for this price you can get 3 at nearby bakeries).

*Pineapple Bun: the point of eating pineapple bun is the top, which is made of a dough similar to that used to make sugar cookies, which consists of sugar, eggs, flour, and lard. This top appears to be like pineapple. It's crunchy, flaky and good.

*Curry Puff: it's like an empanada filled with shredded chicken marinated with five-spice powder and curry. It's another popular item among the locals.

*Pound Cake by the Loaf: is like eating egg and butter. The pound cake here doesn't have lemon or vanilla extract, just pure butter and eggs, mixing with enough flour to give some sort of a stiff texture. Usually pound cake tends to get moist over time but here the cake stays dry.

The ladies who work here would get very chatty with locals and regulars. They can be a bit Nazi so don't touch the cake container or dish. Be ready when your turn is called. The line can be ridiculously long on weekends. 

Golden Gate Bakery does take unannounced breaks at least twice a year for about a month each. Usually they will close about a month before the Moon Festival for moon cake preparation.
author: Matt Y.

description: td;lr: long lines but worth the wait. Egg tart is delicious. Coconut macaroons are also very good.
author: Sherry L.

description:
I've never really been a fan of egg tarts but this place was pretty good. My friend and I stood in line for about half an hour for just one. It's a sweet (but not too sweet) eggy custard with a flaky buttery crust served warm - probably because the workers are making them nonstop but they're still getting sold faster.

If this wasn't one of our first stops, I would've bought more than one egg tart to devour!
author: Kat C.

description:
A chinese bakery located in the hearts of Chinatown in San Francisco. They are famous for their egg tarts and probably one of the better ones I had in the States. You can hardly miss this place if you walk by Grant Ave as there's always a long line. Trust me. As long as they are open, the traffic never ends. However, they are frequently out on vacation or they are just not open. It doesn't help that the service is like that of a classic asian place but what do you expect in Chinatown right?

My first encounter with their egg tarts were when my aunt bought home a dozen of them. She refused to eat them unless she just got them at the bakery. They tasted pretty good even when its cold. So I had to make a trip down to Chinatown to check them out myself. Obviously it did taste better when it was freshly baked. Definitely get a dozen for 15 bucks when you happen to be in the area. Oh one last note, as usual Chinatown = Cash Only.
author: Terence L.

description: EGG TARTS!! DEFINITE YES!! Every time I come to Chinatown, this is a definite place that I hit for the delicious egg tarts. These egg tarts just melt in your mouth.. YUM. $1.80 each is a definite steal but get a dozen of them because they're not always open! There was a time when they weren't open for a whole month! Everyone, especially me gets so happy whenever they are open. Remember that it's CASH ONLY. Also, have fun waiting in line cause the line can go from a block away! But definitely worth the wait!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
These guys are always on vacation thank goodness for: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/

Egg tarts can't be beat in the city, nicely toasty on the rim and nothing but perfection in the middle
author: Peter N.

description:
The Chinese people go crazy for their egg tarts. Sure they are good but I think the wait and utter disappointment of this place being frequently and randomly closed outweighs the pros. The egg tarts are also pricy but I guess that is what happens when people are willing to stand in line for almost an hour just for them.

I really do not have much to say since I have only been there twice and it is closed 95% of the times I visit SF.

I rate this place three stars for being A-OK... WHEN THEY ARE ACTUALLY OPEN. Their egg tarts are good and I am willing to try out their other baked goods if I ever get the chance. Oh well, at least there are a couple other decent bakeries on Stockton St to fulfill my carb cravings...
author: Liana F.

description: I have tried to visit this place several times when I've been in Chinatown but it's always closed. I checked the website http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ and it was open so I decided stop by after getting breakfast in Washington Square. I ordered two dahn tats for $3 and they were the best egg tarts I've ever had! I think the secret ingredient is sugar because the egg tarts were a little sweeter than I'm used to. I highly recommend trying one if they're open!
author: Karen L.

description:
My fellow yelpers w/ over 2k reviews for this place I don't think my review matters, but YES THE EGG TARTS ARE THE BEST HERE!!

I had this place bookmarked to try during my vacation in SF. At first I thought maybe it's just hyped up, but even our hotel maid suggested to try this place. That's when you KNOW it's legit!

After eating at so many dim sum places and bakeries in the LA area & NY. I have to say these egg tarts are #1. It's like their main specialty item and they make each one perfectly. The buttery rich and flaky crust held the creamy sweet egg fillings really well. I wished I ordered extras to take back on the flight home! The ladies working here speak cantonese so it was nice carrying a convo w/ them. They're very friendly and welcoming.
author: Tracie L.

description: Idk what everyone is saying about these egg tarts... Maybe I came on an "off" day. Waited in line for 15-20 to get a couple egg tarts (which I normally love and always get at dim sum) and was disappointed. The egg custard and the pastry ratio was so off. All I could taste was egg. Not a sweet custard with a hint of egg like it's suppose to. And the custard was like jello! I'm not sure if it was because they just came out of the oven and maybe I was suppose to let it cool? Idk but I threw the rest away...
author: Monica H.

description:
I've never have a good vibe wiith Egg tarts (cantonese is "DAN TAT")  but THIS PLACE IS THE BOMB!

Fresh from the OVEN!

Always a line to order this, (Trust me it'll never run out).

Prices are $ 15.00 for 12 Egg tarts.

Other selections are Pies, Mooncakes (they are famous for that too).

Wish they have one in NYC, I will eat one a day with NO REGRETS!
author: Helena H.

description: Hands down this bakery has the best egg tarts in the Bay Area! It's totally worth 1.5 hours of queuing in a line longer than highway 66. That being said, one does not simply just bought a couple of egg tarts. One will definitely buy at least a dozen per visit because their pastries are heaven-sent!!!!!
author: Vi B.

description:
The most delicious egg tarts you will have in your life!

If you see a long line on Grant, it is most likely for these delicious treats. Delicate flaky layers with creamy and smooth egg custard. Since there is almost always a line  here, they are always piping hot as they are baking new batches around the clock.

Take some to go as well as they toast up quite nicely!
author: Schelly Y.

description: So, so, so buttery and yummy! We got here and surprisingly, there was no line. Egg custards are very reminiscent of my childhood, "egg pie" days. These little buttery cups of goodness come warm when you order them.
author: Shela D.

description: The egg tart was famous for a reason.  I had one leftover for the next day, and the crust was still flaky and the egg custard springy.
author: Yvonne J.

description:
This place deserves 5 STARS for it's EGG TARTS!!! To die for!!!!!!!!! 

Flakey and buttery crust that holds the sweet (but not overly sweet) and soft egg custard in the middle!!! O.M.G.

But, I minus-ed 1 star because IT'S ALWAYS CLOSED ON RANDOM DAYS.  I no longer live or visit SF that frequent (especially chinatown), but when I do, it's always closed?  WHYYY!? sadness.
author: Esther A.

description:
Protip: Don't go to a Chinese bakery at 5 PM, because everything tastes like regret.

I'm going to have to give this place a second shot, because the food I had was really subpar. East Asian bakeries are great in the morning, but the later you go the worse your food ends up. As a night owl I roll in past when I should.

Anyways, I had 2 things, an egg yolk pastry and a pineapple/red bean bun. The Pineapple/red bean bun is my go-to favorite at most Chinese bakeries, and this place does it well in a way that holds up nicely throughout the day. The pineapple crust on top was crusty without being crumbly, and the red bean paste was of a good consistency.

The egg yolk, on the other hand, was beyond awful. Now, eat a pastry past the prime of its life, without reheating it? Yes. That was a mistake, but nothing prepared me for the salty, horrible mess that this ended up being.

Again, I might consider going here again, but only because I came here at a time when most bakeries wouldn't even be open.
author: Roger F.

description: Seriously, it was just OK!  I really don't think it's worth the wait for egg tart!  I had better elsewhere!
author: J C.

description: delicious delicious egg tart.  One of the best if not the best I've had.  It was nice and hot and almost burned my lips.
author: Lawrence Y.

description:
OHMYWORD!! Yes, please. give me more. Give me more. I love the taste of these DANTATS. So delicious, whether you're a local or visiting SF for the first time, Golden Gate is a must!

Cash Only!
Lines can get long
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Delicious egg starts... if they're open (which is never).

I have eaten a lot of egg tarts in my life -- so many that I'm starting to look like one.  Admittedly, Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts are the best I have ever had.  The custard is soft and fluffy, and if you're lucky enough to get one fresh and warm from the oven, they are absolutely sublime.

My only complaint is that Golden Gate Bakery must be run by the laziest Chinese people ever -- they are always closed, or "on vacation!"  So, you never know until you get there whether you'll be able to score a delicious baked treat that day.
author: N H.

description:
Yeah, I did it, I came, bought one egg custard tart and then scarfed it down standing in front of the shop. It was tasty, and it was worth the stares from white people who probably thought I was yet another uncouth Chinese person. (I'm yet another uncouth Chinese-American person, good sir!)

Perfectly flaky crust, well adjusted custard middle, Golden Gate Bakery makes a solid tart. More points for the "don't give a crap" attitude of the workers. They know you'll give them money regardless of how long you wait or how surly they are.
author: Michael C.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is known for their egg tarts and people are even willing to drive pretty far for this so I'm not going to complain that it's located in Chinatown and I can't find parking... 

After waiting so long outside in the cold, I was super excited to finally get some egg tarts and I guess I was a bit too excited that I burned the roof of my mouth eating it. 

The egg tarts are $1.65 each and it's nice and hot when you order probably because of the huge quantity they are able to sell so none of them actually sit there in the display case waiting for customers. People walking by wonder what the huge deal is about these egg tarts, but they actually have to try it to find out. 

The store next door gets a bit anal about people lining up at Golden Gate bakery blocking their storefront, but truthfully it might help their business since people in line will actually look at their items since they don't seem to get much business anyways.
author: Maybo L.

description:
In business, you either luck out, or you get your MBA!  In real estate, it's location, location, location!  In Asian culture, it's all about the "Feng Shui." 

Golden Gate Bakery draws crowd in the thousands everyday from everywhere around the world.  There is a buzz that they make the best EGG CUSTARDS.  So good in fact that my friends from Taiwan, Shanghai, Hunan, Beijing, Shenzhen, Hong Kong and Macau whenever they come for a visit, this is their final "pitstop."  It's like going around the world and winning "The Amazing Race."  Their EGG CUSTARDS are especially good that the crust is thin and crispy and brings out the bursting flavor of the custard filling.  Don't take my word for it, go there and experience it for yourself!  

Cheers!
author: Edwin R.

description:
OHHH boy Golden Gate makes some amazing egg tarts. They are HUGE and thick and the custard is so smooth and silky... I could just float away to egg tart heaven and stay there forever.  The crust is flaky and tender too. The very best part of all of this is that my boyfriend and I were lucky enough to get warm tarts straight from the oven.  

After a 30 minute wait, we ordered a dozen tarts (we were sharing...) carried our box around the corner, opened it up and crammed our faces.  The crust crumbled onto my shirt and into my hair, but I totally did not care about the strangers staring at my primal feasting demonstration because these tarts are really that good.  Totally worth the wait, if there is one! I happened to come during the Chinese New Year festival and waited for 30 minutes... but I would have waited an hour to have these!
author: Melissah L.

description:
Stunned. Just floored by how good these are. I've never liked egg tarts but just, I can't even ....begin to describe these. Buttery flaky crust, so delicate, slight crisp. Egg custard eggy with a subtle kiss of sweetness that would make anyone blush. This is a true San Francisco treasure and anyone who hasn't had one hasn't really lived. I work not too far from here and came in a bit after opening. No lines, walked out with half a dozen. Everyone at work loved them. I'm already thinking of life events that would be egg tart appropriate so i have a reason to come back and buy more. 

Oh just, fyi, they taste too good to be healthy and the richness probably means 1 per person.
author: Huy V.

description: My friend and I cannot think of a better egg tart than the ones we had here. The crust had enough salt to balance the sweet egg custard center. We also got a piping hot melon cake aka wife cake. It was delicious !we waited about twenty mins in the afternoon on a Friday .
author: Kaycee C.

description: Once in a blue moon, if you're lucky enough you'll catch them when they're NOT on vacation. My advice is to always call them ahead of time, and they will ask how many egg tarts you would like. This will prevent you from wasting your time heading over just to be disappointed. These egg tarts are the best I have ever had, especially when they're warm and fresh. Make sure you have cash!
author: Karen C.

description:
Custard egg tarts !!!

$1.60 each
CASH ONLY

Light, flaky, perfect amount of sweetness. THE best custard egg tarts EVER. 
I loved it so much I came back the next day for a dozen to take back to LA.

The baker goes to Taiwan often so be sure to call ahead if you live 300+ miles away.
author: Christine T.

description: As a tourist, I was walking around Chinatown for good places to eat and saw that many locals were lined up infront of this bakery. So I joined in, not really knowing what they are famouse for, and ordered egg custards. My goodness, super good. The custards seem to have just come out of the oven, crispy on the outside, warm and moist in the inside, not too sweet, just perfect. Would definitly come back for more.
author: JiEun L.

description:
I visited SF for the first time and trying these egg tarts were of course on my to-do list.

It is definitely good. BUT.... I didn't get the same "wow" reaction as many others. I mean... people waiting 40+ minutes and giving them out-of-this-world reviews? Drinking that Hype Kool-Aid.

I've had better here in 626 area of LA. However, it is still good and deserving of 4 stars.
author: Vinh C.

description: This is my childhood place... Where everytime my parents takes me to SF china town, this place is a must. The egg tarts here are out of this world. So fresh and delicious when I bite into it... The creamy texture of the eggtart melts in my mouth. This place does not only have egg tart but they have like curry pot pies and chicken pot pie which are pretty bomb also and many other goodies that I have yet to try. This place will get crowded on  a weekday & packed on a weekend! And make sure to call before to see if they're open because they're always on vacation.
author: Johnny L.

description:
Typed in "bakery" on yelp while in Chinatown, and found a crazy number of reviews on this one, so I knew I had to make a stop to try these egg tarts that people were raving about. 

I've been to many Asian bakeries & have tried soooo many egg tarts, but hands down, these are the best I've ever tasted. I was walking around Chinatown & thought that this bakery would be difficult to find, but there was a long line out of the door & I instantly knew that I found it! Lol. We were in line outside of the shop for about 10 minutes until we reached the door. Not too bad considering the line was hella long. We got inside & the lady asked how many tarts we wanted, and then we had to wait another 5-10 minutes until we got our box of tarts. They were super fresh, steaming hot, & super flaky. The custard part of the tart had a strong vanilla flavor, and I really liked that! The ladies inside were really nice, and made my first time here memorable. If you're thinking about buying 1 tart, buy 2. Trust me, you're going to want more than 1 after that first bite.
author: Nikki S.

description: I waited 30 minutes for their famous egg tarts. I passed by this place so many times and it was either they had run out or was closed. When I got to the front, there was a fresh batch straight out of the oven and I was like OMG I'm so lucky today cause I caught them when they were opened and piping fresh hot egg tarts. Egg tarts are not cheap, $2.25 in SF compared to $0.75 in Oakland. I took one bite and was totally DISAPPOINTED!!! The egg custard was watery and had no egg flavor at all. The appearance was a light yellow color, so not much egg or not so much food coloring. It had a weird after taste like banana extract was added. WTF, I thought I came motherland of egg tarts. I just to stick to Oakland cause all the bakeries are all decent.
author: Eve H.

description:
Instead of telling people I'm worth my weight in gold, instead I tell them I'm worth my weight in egg tarts.

Their custard and egg tarts are better or as good as Hong Kong. I should know because I've been to HK over a dozen times.

These are my favorite egg tarts in the United States that I've tried so far.

Their other baked goods are just as good too. Hence the line at this bakery.
author: Jack R.

description:
There's a reason that Golden Gate Bakery's Egg Tarts make it on every list for must-try things in SF! They're DELICIOUS!

I'm a sucker for egg tarts, in general, but I've had plenty of bad ones in my time.  Sometimes the crust is too soggy or the ratio of crust to filling isn't appropriate or the taste of the filling isn't good.  But Golden Gate's are perfect!

I stopped by on Tuesday afternoon, and there was no line to get in.  At first, because it was late afternoon, I thought that they had run out of egg tarts, since I didn't see any in the glass.  Then an old lady working there motion signaled for me to go in, and I asked if they had any more egg tarts.  She nodded yes.  So I purchased 4, and was well on my way. When I got to my car, I decided that I had to snack on one immediately. (In my experience, if I waited until I got home an hour later, the egg tart may not be as good because of varying factors).  So I inhaled the tart as soon as I sat down.  The first thing I noticed in my first bite, was that the egg tart was WARM! I didn't realize that the egg tarts weren't in the glass case because they were in a warmer.  What a delightful surprise!  This made eating the egg tart immediately, that much better! Since it was fresh out of  the oven, the crust was perfectly crispy!  The filling was also soft, custardy with a touch of sweetness.

Why did I like this egg tart?  
1. The crispy, flaky crust
2. The delicious, slightly sweet, custardy filling
3. The fact that it was served warm

The rest that I bought were still delicious by the time I got home, but nothing can replace that fresh out of the oven goodness.

After having a Golden Gate egg tart, it'll be hard to find another one that's just as good, and at the same price point. $1.40 each.
author: Audrey C.

description:
They should rename this place to Wait in line for 90 Minutes to Get Some Kick Butt Egg Tarts Bakery.

Fluffy custard. Buttery flakey crust.  Just enough vanilla and almond flavor. The best I've had outside of Macau after my egg tart crawl across Macau.  Story for another day. 

So get in line!  Please note, they are very awesome when fresh and warm. They aren't nearly as good the next day. 

--- my theory on why the line is so long ------
After waiting for 90 mins, here's my theory in the reason for the length of the line.  Most folks really only need to buy one or two per person to eat that day.  However after waiting in line for a little bit, they decide that what the heck, I'll get a dozen. Now a bunch of people make the same decision and the bakers are now trying to keep up with the demand. So the line gets longer. And folks in line are waiting longer and when it's their turn, they buy more than they can possibly eat in a day. So the line gets even longer!  How did I come to this theory?  Listening to people say they only want a few and walking out with a box or two.  Ugh, we do this to ourselves!  The tarts are good but in moderation.  Trust me. After the third, it's not going to be as pleasurable as the first bite of the first one!  Macau is different because on a crawl, you try different bakeries and some have funky flavor a that keep things interesting.
author: S F.

description: So we just got into town and saw lots of folks walking around with pink bakery boxes.  We asked where they were from...and we ended up in line.  What an experience (fiasco?).  Of course the sign on the door says they are on vacation, but they are selling out of the door.  We were all told they were running low, so we were limited to 6 egg tarts. We got 4 and they were fresh out of the oven, still warm and pure deliciousness.   One of the friends we made in line recommended we also get some moon pies.  We have yet to try those.  It was certainly a unique experience we will tell stories about!
author: Lori M.

description:
So many reviews written about this place, so I'll try to make this review as distinct as possible. 

Are you willing to wait for a long time to get possibly the tastiest 蛋撻 (dan taat in Cantonese Chinese), or Chinese style egg tarts in San Francisco and possibly the USA? When I waited on a Monday afternoon at this place, it took me 50+ minutes just to get inside this Chinese bakery. It might have been unprecedented for me, but as the queue got longer and longer, I then realized that I did not want to give up my spot. Plus, it was my last day in San Francisco, so I did not want to miss out. I decided to order eight of them for my family. 

This place is a simple, "low-tech" place, with a lot of clutter and I think there's a small "hidden production facility" behind the counter that makes the 蛋撻. The description of the 蛋撻 might sound a little exaggerated, but I am going to be as truthful as I can.  

The crust was not brittle, was not too hard but just right. It had the right amount of flakiness, and a nice tiny crisp, making it an almost flawless crust that I would look for in an egg tart. The custard itself was not too sweet but not too bland with a nice rich softness. It was one of the most delicious egg tarts I have eaten in years, but eating it fresh right out of the oven was even better, with the warmness still there. 

Coming from a somewhat decent city like Boston, this bakery succeeds in their 蛋撻 where all other Chinese bakeries in Boston fall short. That's how good it is. I think they understand English, but it's easier to communicate with them if you know some Cantonese Chinese and make sure you have plenty of cash. A 蛋撻 is kind of pricey at $1.60 a piece, but you're paying for quality. 

Overall, I thought I had not only the best 蛋撻 in San Francisco, but possibly the best 蛋撻 in the USA, and could be a legitimate contender to compete against other 蛋撻 from Toronto or Vancouver. I really hated the wait, but it was rewarding to finally get that box of 蛋撻 in my hands, as if I got a box filled with gold. Would I wait here again? Probably not, unless the queue is shorter, I play a really addicting game on my phone, or I have an interesting companion to have a nice conversation with for more than 45 minutes. It's much more worthwhile to order large quantities rather than wait for just for one 蛋撻.
author: Ambrose C.

description: Gave this place another try June 2017 to find that they are closed for vacation again.  Yowza I give up.  My advice for you is be smarter than me...call to make sure they aren't on vacation before you wade through the busy crowd while amping yourself up for an egg tart.
author: Shelley L.

description:
Since I'm currently unemployed I thought it would be a perfect time to hit up Golden Gate Bakery for the World's Best Egg Custard Tarts (no quotation marks because there's no question about it) when there might not be line. However, the bakery has been closed since November! Argh! After months of waiting they finally reopened on Jan 18 and I couldn't resist stopping by the next day when I was the area. Possibly a big mistake because though I was so happy to have the egg custard tarts again it was a 30 min wait. Not sure if it was because they were closed for so long or because it's crazy on weekends (lots of families walking out with boxes and boxes of pastry). 

Yes, it's $1.40 per tart but given that most pastry shops sell a chocolate chip cookie for $2 and other pastries for $3+ you should really stop complaining. Even if you can get them cheaper, really are you going to argue over 50¢ difference?

Especially when these are the World's Best Egg Custard Tarts. Super Eggy soft custard filling. Perfectly baked crispy, flakey, golden crust. It's really the crust that differentiates this place.

I'll note that during weekend lunch the curry empanadas seemed very popular as well. I also recommend the melon cakes while you're here.

Note: I just discovered this site through another yelp review and thought I'd repost it. Check to see if they're open before you go!  http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/
author: Jean K.

description: You guys are joking right? The tarts taste like somebody dumped a boatload of sugar onto scrambled eggs.  I thought it would be more like a custard.  At least the crust was flaky.  Waited forever, sign said it would open at 12pm but they didn't open the door until around 12:40.
author: Chris B.

description: Great service, egg tart was fresh from the oven and the crust was thin and flaky. Not super sweet and you could tell is was made from scratch. 20 minute plus wait today and at 1.75 each it's not a bad price. I honestly had never had an egg tart before, not sure if it is really my cup of tea but if it is I can see why this place is the best.
author: Ethan W.

description: Egg tarts are worth the wait. Cash only. It's a very small establishment with usually 3-4 ladies behind the counter. Service is friendly.
author: Umer M.

description:
Well I have a new obsession, and unfortunately GG Bakery is probably as good as it gets. I bookmarked this place as I knew I would be in the area. While walking around China Town I saw the line and instantly knew we were in the right spot. This line is NO JOKE, and it is pretty damn slow. Twenty minutes later, we had our tarts and some almond cookies. 

The egg tarts are unbelievable! Fresh out of the oven, creamy, loaded with flavor and a crispy, flaky crust. I want to drive all the way to SF RIGHT NOW! 

Almond cookies were also very very delicious. Four tarts, and a bag of almond cookies came to 8 bucks and some change. Awesome prices for awesome desserts!
author: Liana H.

description: Simply put, this is my go to spot for the steamed pork buns, sesame balls and egg tarts.  Typical Chinatown fare- no frills Chinese bakery with long lines.  Be patient, the wait is worth it!  GO NOW!
author: Rey D.

description:
Yummy! I stumbled upon this place walking through Chinatown and saw it was the only bakery in sight so I stopped in. The shop is super tiny but I was immediately told by a fellow customer this place is famous. 

I tried the recommended egg tarts and they were fresh, warm and not too sweet. I wasn't a fan but I am not a person that enjoys eating eggs (unless they're scrambled) so I don't think my opinion is a fair vote. 

But we can talk about those macaroons any day of the week. Oh my! They were incredible. And the pricing here is out of this world. I bought a dozen of them for $6.50!! I anticipated way higher pricing being San Fran but I guess not all businesses here are out to rip you off. 

I wish I had stayed in town longer to try more, but I couldn't justify buying all the goodies with only having a day left in the area. 

Don't expect superb service here. They definitely know they have a good thing going and don't have to live up to customer service standards like other places would. 

And they are cash only!
author: Melanie R.

description:
As you've probably heard, this is THE place to get egg tarts in Chinatown. The egg tarts are $1.75 and the line was down the street, but I knew I had to get it. The past couple of times I've walked past, they've always been closed.

The egg tart itself was better than other ones I've tried. The crust was very thin and flaky. The egg part was very soft and not too sweet. Overall I would have liked a higher crust to filling ratio but it was really good nevertheless and worth the wait!
author: Aimee Z.

description:
Okay, so I finally arrived in Chinatown, SF... Aha!! Golden Gate Bakery is open! Ha! They're not on vacay this time! Now's the chance I've been waiting for, for a long time. Gotta snag some of those elusive, famous egg tarts that they're so well known for! Alright, so we stand, and stand, and stand in line for what seems like forever, moving scant inches at a time (or so it seems)! Finally at the counter! Bust out the trusty iPhone to snap a few pics to remember the place by and all of a sudden I see the dreaded "no picture taking inside"! Drats! But hey, I'm in no mood to get scolded by one of those ladies behind the counter and risk being embarrassed to death in front of all those people! Nope, not me!!!  

Being that it was just a week or so away from moon festival, the moon cakes were hot items! Old ladies with literally boxes and boxes of them walking out of the shop through the crowd of anxious people! We reach the counter and get our order of tarts. While outside, I see in the showcase, piles of coconut macaroons. I order some of them (four to be exact) and they, IMHO, win me over, not the tarts!! I know my friends will hate on me for saying that, but hey, it's my money! Haha! For those of you who haven't tried them before, get some next time! I really enjoyed them and if you are staying in a hotel like me, the macaroons will definitely last longer than the tarts! I only wish I had gotten more of them... So pick up a dozen or so to take back to your room with you or even to take home. My journey to GG Bakery to have the egg tarts actually got me liking the macaroons a lot more. Don't get me wrong, the tarts are okay, but I found a new reason to come here next time... and I WILL get more of those macaroons, even if I have to fight that line and risk being scolded by those ladies! :) note: Buy minimum of six macaroons... we asked for four, BIG mistake! "I GIVE YOU SIX"!!!, in a very firm tone was the response.. Yikes...Six it is!
author: Dave F.

description:
My friend and i got 8 dozens of custard tarts... crazy right.???  It took us 40 mins to get those . Many of my friends were talking about their custard tarts frequently so I was extremely curious about their custard tarts. Today before I went , I called ahead to make sure if they were opened. Fortunately, someone picked the phone and told me that they were opening. 
There wasn't a long line so I was kinda of surprised about that, and I though I could get it very fast and if I found out that the line wasn't moving.... we stood at the same spot for about 20 mins..  
Those were yum. I shared 3 dozons with friends, they also enjoyed them. 
Will we be back?  Yes... but probably when there is a very short line...
author: Rila C.

description:
I was told this is a must do/see thing in SF Chinatown.  I think we were lucky as we only had to wait 45 minutes in line......the line was excruciatingly slow but we were entertained in conversation by a local couple and their two sons.  Nice to know both the local Chinese, local non Chinese as well as the flock of tourists like ourselves frequent this place.

We ordered $75 bucks worth of stuff.  12 egg custards, sesame balls,  moon pies and some other things.  I thought I'd better make the 45 minute wait with it cause I wasn't gonna wait in line again.  I was Amazed that a Chinese American college student only ordered 1 item.  I discovered why the line is slow..........their were only two sweet elderly Chinese ladies working the crowd.  Not only did they pick your order, they carefully tied each pink box up with string making sure the corners were torn open to allow heat escape as the egg custards were still warm.

This place is CASH only, so come prepared.  The egg custards were very good, I gave this place only 4 stars because.....

On the way home we stopped at my wife's relatives' home in Oakland and they went to their Chinatown, and served us egg custard tarts from their Chinese bakery......the ones in Oakland tasted better despite not still being warm!
author: Geo P.

description:
I was in SF for a weekend getaway and met up with some friends that were locals, both recommended that we tried the egg tarts from Golden Gate Bakery in Chinatown. 

Once we arrived, I had to try!! I waited in line for about 15 minutes behind many people buying it by the case! I only bought 1 for a taste. They're a bit pricey at $1.35 each, but the tart was larger than most. They're not overly sweet which is usually why I dislike egg tarts.

Next time I'm in SF, I'm going to buy a dozen to take home to SoCal!
author: Tiffany V.

description: Fresh out of the oven egg tarts are the best. Maybe it was the long lines we waited in made them taste better or just the way their crust is flaky. You might think eh it's just another egg tart. You might be right but it's their crust that separates them from the others. Their crust tastes like a buttery puff pastry and the egg custard part was just the right about of sweetness. For a right out of the oven dessert that isn't too sweet.. A little line isn't too bad.
author: Lynn H.

description:
Honestly, yes these were the best egg tarts I've ever had. They were a pretty decent size, Super fluffy and custardy and not to eggy on the inside, and deliciously flakey and buttery (almost croissant like) on the outside. However, there are many other egg tarts that can do the job as well. Definitely a place to try but after you've had it once, I don't see why you should have to wait in a ridiculous line when you can get practically a similar quality egg tart elsewhere.

If there isn't a ridiculous line, I'll be back
author: Careese K.

description:
There's nothing more I can say that hasn't already been said among the 2013 reviews. I'm just excited that i'm the 2014 reviewee! 

I get grumpy about paying a lot more for the egg tarts and Chinese pastries here compare to the many other Chinese bakeries around the area. But you know what, people pay $2.50 & upward for a tiny macaron, $2.00 for a skimpy piece of chocolate truffle (I'm guilty...). Why should I complain about paying $1.35 for Golden Gate egg tart? Asian egg tarts can be gourmet like Chantal Guillon and Godiva! This is the type conversation I have in my head. I will come back for you, Golden Beauty dan tat.
author: Anh L.

description:
The first time I came here, my friends and I happened to visit SF during Chinese New Year. BIG MISTAKE. Traffic was awful and the line to Golden Gate Bakery was ridiculously long. So, this visit to SF, we got smart about it, we decided to come here the last day we were in SF (on a Saturday) and during an odd hour (around 2pm). We either got lucky or we planned it well, because the 1) the line into Golden Gate was small and 2) traffic around the area wasn't horrendous. My friends dropped me off and just kind of waited for me. I went in and ordered 6 egg tarts and 2 coconut tarts ($12 total). It's such a small shop, so just have 1-2 people go in to order a bunch for the group. Don't do what the group in front of me did and hog up space with 6 people while 1 person ordered. 

To quote one of my two non-Asian friends, "I've had egg tarts at dimsum, and those aren't nearly as good as this. There is sufficient filling and the crust is real crispy and not so thick. I really like it". I fully agree with everything he said. The egg tarts are good. If you like coconut, you'll like the coconut tart. This bakery has really mastered the art of a nice think flaky crust and lots of filling. The filling also isn't too sweet, and there's just so much. Although I have to say, for egg tarts and coconut tarts, I wouldn't wait more than 30 minutes for this, but if you go at an off time when the line is short, it is definitely worth the extra buck and change. Also, cash only (tip: always carry cash when going to Chinatown, whether it be in SF, LA or wherever. Chinese people love cash! lol jk, but really, bring cash!)
author: Angela H.

description:
The bf and I came here for the egg tarts. Totally on point :) 

My best friend said that there is a long line.. but hehe we arrived 10 minutes before closing time so didn't even have to wait! So if you don't want to wait in line.. come close to closing time.. but who knows? Maybe that might be a horrible idea since they could possible run out by then? (Not sure since I don't live in SF)

$1.50 for an egg tart. So goood! Reminds me of the one I used to eat in china!

Would totally reccomend to others :)
author: Eunice K.

description:
My roommate and I were wandering around Chinatown when we stumbled upon this bakery. I insisted that we get egg tarts because I remember them being really amazing the first time I had them.

The ladies take no time in asking you what you want. They kind of rush you a bit. Make haste! Good thing we knew what we wanted. 

Egg tarts here cost more than egg tarts from other places, but somehow I don't mind paying the extra few cents. The egg tarts at that time just came out of the oven so they were super fresh and hot to eat. 

Favorite egg tart place for sure.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Best egg tarts I've had outside of Hong Kong. Yes, there is always a line when they're open but its well worth the wait.

Con: They tend to close randomly during the summertime since the staff tends to be on vacation.
author: Tina L.

description:
OMG GGB just made my Friday. We ordered a ton of various Chinese New Years treats - dan ta (of course), sesame balls with red bean paste, moon cake, and two types of nian gao, to ring in the new year at work. 

The dan ta pastry was buttery, flaky, and had just the right toasted consistency, the filling was warm, eggy, custardy, and had a hint of sweet vanilla. 

The sesame balls were HUGE, chewy, crunchy from the toasted sesame seeds, and filled with delicious sweet red bean paste. 

The moon cake was DELISH. One would not know that pork fat was involved. I can't recall what flavor we ordered because I literally inhaled it because it was so good. 

The first type of nian gao was red bean - and super chewy/sticky with a hint of coconut and studded with red beans. I can't recall exactly what flavor the second one was but it was STICKY as hell and white - and so good nonetheless. 

Just writing about it makes my mouth water.
author: Peter C.

description:
Items selected:

Black Bean Moon Cake
Egg Custard Tart

I really have no excuse as to why I'd omitted Golden Gate Bakery from my Bay Area dining itinerary in the past but for the sake of saving face I'll pretend it was because of the rumored long lines and random unannounced closures, neither of which was present when I arrived to find hot egg custard tarts emerging from the kitchen just after noon on a Monday.  Warm and jiggly I quickly ate the first before more slowly enjoying the second, the pastry crisp and intensely buttery when sampled alone while the custard was sweeter than my past experiences yet still pronouncedly eggy - a great achievement, no doubt.  Happily taking my server's advice as other warm items were just coming out of the oven I also ordered a dense Moon Cake, my first experience with this pastry, and loaded with sweetened black bean paste my only regret is that I did not try the taro or lotus options as well.
author: Michael U.

description: So,I guess I was a tourist and only got the egg tart :/ but it was a pretty darn good one. Maybe it was cause I didn't wait in a stupid long line since I came rather early in the day, or maybe it was cause it was fresh out of the oven, but it was nice and light. Guess I'll have to come back to try other stuff!
author: Nina S.

description:
Egg tarts are to die for here, excellent taste and great filling and crust. Lines are long (as usual with anything worth getting), prices are high (1.75 per tart) but it's all worth it in the end. 

They have bizarre open hours, but if you catch them at the right time lines can be short quick and you'll be away with your egg tarts before long. 

Other treats like the red bean sesame ball is good, the real star of the show is the egg tarts.
author: Quentin L.

description:
When I'm feeling fat, I eat. Blame it on the pretty face boy who decided to play switcharoo and add-a-roo with his work schedule so he became semi-nonexistent for awhile. Leaving me to fend for myself, I called up my skinny bitch friend for brunch. 

This is the last place you want to take a girl with fat chick syndrome. The skinny bitch friend insisted on stopping by here after eating a gigantic brunch because "Omg there's no line outside!" I argued otherwise, but my mind tells me that she makes a really good point... there's no line outside!

After a few minutes, I found myself screaming and blabbering away in Chinese, tryna get my daan tat's (egg tarts!) and paper sponge cakes without going into a full on sobbing rage. So skinny bitch just gets one egg tart and stares at me. She's fucking beautiful, you know? But did I mention I was feeling fat?! LE SIGH. My excuse: they're for my parents, for the boy, and for the boy's mother. More like we'll see how many is left after I bart my sorry guilty ass home. 

So we're sitting at Union Square chowing away and Skinny bitch friend just watches me devour my pink pastry box of goods. She tried to take one of my egg tarts and I nearly ripped her arm from her socket. I wanted a dozen for a reason. STAY SKINNY, BITCH. 

I don't know what else to say besides that I love their egg tarts. I like them fresh out the oven, I liked them toasted, I like them icey cold from the fridge, and I like them creme brulee style (try it)! 

And their paper sponge cakes... I've always wanted to see how many I could stuff in my mouth...but that wouldn't be very pleasant to watch.
author: Nadeen H.

description:
Me and my boy pounded our lunch in 30 minutes, so he insisted we walk over to Golden Gate Bakery to get the "best" dan tat (egg tarts) EVER. I can't remember the last time I walked around SF Chinatown, maybe not since I was a wee lad. I have no emotional attachment to SF Chinatown, probably because I grew up with LA Chinatown, which still exists, but not in the way I remember.

He tells me that this place is only open three months out of the year, and there is usually a line fifty deep. He also claims that the owner of this place has microphones in an underground bakery to make sure that no one is giving away the secret recipe for the egg tarts. Urban myth or hardcore Chinese paranoia? Hard to say, 50% of each?

When we walked up, there were only a dozen people ahead of us, but in short order, the line doubled up behind us. I watched a couple of bakers bring tray after tray of egg tarts up from some unseen bakery. With the exception of a glass bakery case in the front, the rest of the visible work area looks more like my parent's unorganized fire hazard of a garage. There are wire shelves everywhere packed with eight year old newspapers, Kirkland chicken noodle soup from Costco, and other non-bakery related items. 

The ladies that work here like to yell at you, like any Chinese (not ABC) lady. They yell at you in English, Cantonese and Mandarin. WHAT DO YOU WANT??! HOW MANY??! TWELVE DOLLARS! If economy of language is inherent to Chinese culture, these ladies are the equivalent of Adam Smith. 

My buddy ordered a dozen dan tats. That's it. All the other Chinese people ordered dan tats. That's it. I had one and I'm not sure if it was the "best ever", but it was pretty damn good. Right up there. Close to "best ever". The pastry crust is paper thin. The egg custard was warm, soft consistency, and not overly cooked or curdled. 

If you're sad that you waited in line for an hour, or your "cream bun" was underwhelming, well, you went on the wrong day, wrong time, and ordered the wrong thing. Go on a Thursday morning, right before lunch, bring cash, and order a dozen dan tats. Done.
author: .Alan Y.

description:
I have literally traveled the world trekking to identify the best egg tart in existence.  So I have eaten at many of many places...even Hong Kong etc.     

Before even eating a fresh one, a friend brought these back to TX one time and they were impressive after a 4 hour journey and 1 day wait time to deliver.  When I got to San Francisco this was one of the only things on my list I was not going to let anything stop me from getting.

I got to the store about an hour before closing on a Monday evening and there was no long line that many people have told me about luckily, but there was a bit of a crowd.  I waited no more than 5 min to get to the front of the line to order one.  It was fresh out of the oven and man... it was epic.  The balance between crunchy/flaky was impeccable, which made this egg tart number 2 in my book.  I ordered a few more and was told it would only take 25 min to cook up a fresh dozen.  I walked around and came back and BOOM they were ready =]

A few things to note, the storefront can only hold about 8-10 people max so don't be shy if you see a long line.  Also bring cash and if you decide to order a LOT.... be sure to either have a bag or be prepared to pay for a bag to hold your boxes of epic egg tarts!

If you are wondering what's number one in my book.... Egg Custard King which is now known as Natalie Bakery (http://www.yelp.com/biz/natalie-bakery-new-york) .  The only reason why this is number one...there's no other explanation than my first bite stopped me dead in my tracks. Not sure if they're still just as good but I saw somewhere it was the same people etc just different name.
author: Anthony C.

description: Definitely worth the 30 min wait for these hot egg tarts! They tasted so good the day after as well. The tarts would even be better if it was the flaky, buttery crust one!
author: Brenda L.

description:
Chanced upon this place without meaning to. 
Never wanted to try it because did not believe in the hype.
The line was short, so thought, why not? 

I am now a believer...I regret not purchasing another box or egg tart...
author: Nancy P.

description:
Although the prices have continued to go up, this is still my all time favorite egg tart place. Unfortunately, there's almost always a line, and they're not the fastest at packing up these egg tarts to be sold, but it's definitely worth it.

Last I checked, prices are $1.40 for each egg tart, and no discount for purchasing more. There's no spot for you to eat it outside, but it's definitely worth getting a little bit of grease on your fingers to snag one up immediately and eat it while it's hot.
author: Michael L.

description: I have seen the light. Its form is little golden suns masquerading as Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts. The dan tats fresh out of the oven will radiate your gloomy taste buds. Be careful, the tarts are scorching and can burn your mouth.
author: Alexander W.

description:
BEST Dan tat I have tasted in all of California. I literally cannot even eat any other Dan tat now because they ll taste so crappy after you're exposed to these 

They're a teeny bit pricey but worth every penny. They're huge, tasty, rich in flavor and sweetness. Even the feuds is crispy and sweet!! Tastes like heaven in your mouth 

Unfortunately they go on vacation alot which makes getting Dan tat from them is a hit or miss at times. When they are opened, there is constantly a huge line outside that is the hallmark of their place. It's small but that's how you can identity the small bakery. 

They sell other baked yummies too but I would say they're notorious for their Dan tat. The long lines and heir occasional vacations make Dan tat a rate delicacy in my eyes now
author: Cuc N.

description:
I just so happen to be in the area during the San Francisco Gorilla Challenge last year (2011).  I don't live un the area so i thought I take advantage of this opportunity to have my most favorite pastry ever: DAN TAT (egg tart)!!!

It was on a Saturday morning...close to noon when I was surrounded by a lot of tourist.  Luckily there was no long line at such a prestigious bakery known for thier egg tarts! I was able to buy one so quickly!

This is perhaps the best egg tarts outside of hong kong I ever had! I been here twice now...it's amazingly delicious every time. The filling is warm and custards and the crust is flakey and not too thick like other egg tarts I've tried...PERFECT.

I wish I lived closer to just come here everyday...sigh...
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
I was visiting SF and my host friend insisted we wait in line for 20 minutes to get these egg tarts. I was really skeptical and not excited; I've eaten a bajillion egg tarts, how good can they get.

These are different. And A-Mazing. Almost everything they sell were just taken out of the oven and at least still warm. So fresh. So worth the wait.
author: Loretta C.

description: Who doesn't like golden gate bakery? The wait is worth it! A native HKer told me it's the closest authentic egg tart he's had in the US.
author: Annie Z.

description: Open today! Amazing! Long line but so worth the wait! No bakery in northern california can match their egg tarts!
author: Kitty D.

description: My girlfriend loves the egg tarts here. There is usually a long line, but the egg tarts are worth it! The other baked goods are tasty as well. My girlfriend also likes the custard buns and butterfly cookies, but the most special item here is definitely the egg tarts.
author: Bill G.

description:
I waited an hour and a half in line for a little egg custard pie thing. I don't like dessert. I really don't. But this I liked. Whenever I go to dim sum I don't get these because they never taste good to me. Golden Gate Bakery does not suck. Period.

Worth it.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Good tasting custard tart, with crispy shell and warm custard filling.  They're the best tarts for these reasons, and I've had my share of custard tarts growing up in SF.  

Are they worth $1.75 each when everyone else is selling for $1.00?  Depends on how much of a tart connoisseur one is.  In my opinion they are marginally better than the competition so definitely try it once to compare.  For me, I'm ok with my $1 tarts
author: Ben S.

description:
I'm still trying to understand what happened. Shanon Y and Sidney T told me to come here to get the egg tarts. So I listened. But when I came here the door was closed and it said "On Vacation." But there was like 30 people waiting in a line. I was like huh?! And then I saw a woman open the door and make an exchange with the next person in the line. Like it was so secretive or something lol. Even the windows had cardboard up from the inside so you couldn't see what they were doing haha. Ok I get it though. Nevermind what they do in there. It's all in the taste maybe?
 An SFPD officer also joined the line and he was asking everyone what the big deal was about this place. He had never been as in my case but everyone had nothing but great things to say. They all agreed it was worth the wait. The officer was really cool, probably one of the friendliest I've ever met. He even recommended a few other places to try while I was in the city. Unfortunately for him by the time we got close to putting in our order at the door his lunch break was about to be over! So I let him go ahead and put in his order before me. I had nothing but time on my hands. I bought a dozen of the egg tarts and the were hot and fresh and amazing I must say. I brought most of then back home to share with people but it was really hard to resist eating all of them on the drive home to LA.  Maybe on my next visit I'll try some other items but the egg tarts for sure are a must
author: Harry M.

description:
MMMM, good egg tarts.  You should eat them right away; that's when they're best.  I don't recommend carrying them in your purse for a few hours, and then catching a flight to So. Cal. then putting them in the fridge and eating them the next day.  It was a soggy mess to say the least.  Though a tasty soggy mess.

The crust is flaky and crispy, more like a phyllo dough than the pie crust type crust that I'm used to on an egg tart.  The custard is smooth and silky and light.  So good!  The combo of the flaky crust and the custard make it hard to pick up though.  They totally fall apart.  It was more of a fork needing tart than a hand held.

I also tried the Raspberry Napoleon and the Chicken Pie.  Both decent.  But unfortunately, those were also carried in my purse and eaten the next day as well.  Those actually held up okay! The day prior they probably would have been phenomenal!  Next time, I will go on an empty stomach...
author: Emily J.

description: Best Egg Tart in the Northern California. Everyone needs to try this once. Only thing I hate about this place is LONG LINES out the door. Even their other bake good are YUMMIE. Moon Cake Festival is around the corner, better head there before you have to wait about 1 1/2 hour!
author: Christina H.

description:
YES, it is definitely worth the wait!

I absolutely LOVE the egg tarts here! It's $1.35 each. Fresh from the oven! :)

I always try egg tarts everywhere I go, but Golden Gate Bakery has the BEST egg tarts in my book. Super deliciouss ~ 

Call ahead to check their hours.. I've been here twice and they were closed randomly :(
author: Christy N.

description:
$15 dozen
$1.25 each

The line here is CRAZY!!! Expect to wait at least a hour or two for it!
author: David W.

description: Unexpectedly passed by an OPEN BAKERY. wowza ....Where do these guys go for "vacation" all the time? They make such bomb tarts I guess they simply open and close as they please. #balla
author: Grace C.

description: This is a Chinese bakery in Chinatown. We passed by it once and the line was very long(out the door). I wasn't hungry at the time so I didn't get anything. However on another day, I made a point to stop by to see and eat some snacks.  I had a muffin and some macaroons. Both were tasty and worth the line (which moved quickly. )
author: Andy S.

description:
Definitely one of the best egg tarts I've tasted. The custard is smooth and creamy and the crust is oh so flaky and buttery! They come straight out the oven. Whenever I get mine, they're still warm! They also sell other baked goods including mochi, red bean sesame balls, moon cakes, etc.

It's a very small store so lines usually go out the door. They often go on vacation and have no set business hours even though they're supposed to be open 8am-8pm. If you're in the area and wondering if the store is open, try http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com
author: Suzy L.

description:
I came here last year and the shop was closed. It was new year eve's last night and my boyfriend and I decided to give it a try again - and guess what, they were open! 

The egg tarts are definitely worth waiting for. Smooth and flavorful egg custard complimented with crunchy crust! I'm an egg tart fan and I would say this is the best egg tart I've ever tried in my life. 

So do not miss out this amazing place when you are visiting SF!
author: Kai Lin T.

description:
Egg tarts priced at twice as much as its neighboring counterparts (1.60 each), there's still an endless amount of people lining up to buy these by the dozens.

Something about these  fresh, right out of the oven, pipin hot, crispy- flaky -buttery- melt in your mouth egg tarts that keep the locals and tourists flocking here. It's hard to pinpoint exactly which aspect of Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts supersede its rivalries, but I have yet to encounter anyone whose denied that these are in deed the best egg tarts in town.

On a side note, prices here have sky rocketed over the years. It is now 19.20 for a dozen egg tarts.

Oh yea, they also close and open at their own discretion. Please DO call in to confirm their working business day and hour before showing up.
author: Ada C.

description: Years later and the egg tarts are still the BEST.  Multiple layers of flaky crust and a jiggly egg middle.   A perfect balance of sweet and egg.  They are very delicate... I threw one into a ziploc bag and after tossing and turning a little in my purse, it almost fell apart completely.  Each one costs $1.35 now.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Um so I frickin' LOVE this place. Capital L-O-V-E, love. If I can marry a pastry or dessert - this would be the one. I think I've actually finished a dozen in two days. That's how much I frickin' LOVE this place and it's Egg Tarts/Dan Tat/Eggy goodness. Whatever you call it.

The first thing I tell people when they say they're going to San Francisco is "Bring me a dozen"!!!! That's all I really want from Golden Gate Bakery.

Honestly, I haven't tried anything else - but why would you get anything else besides the dan tat here? I've burned my mouth in happiness, or when it first comes out of the oven. Note to self - it's still good when it cools to a nice warm temperature, rather than scalding hot when it comes out of the oven. It's good, damn good. 

Lines can be long and they do close a lot. Vacations and random stuff - then again, If we're that good and we're that busy - we're ok closing all the time. GGB deserves it.
author: Mandi T.

description: I used to come to this place as a kid.  The egg tarts are definitely quite delicious but I don't think this place is worth the wait.  Besides being way overpriced ($1.95 for an egg tart) the owners continually go on vacation so you never know when they are open or not.  Furthermore, considering how much money they make it would be nice if they spent some money re-modeling the place; it is a dump inside.  This place feasts on innocent tourists who don't know better.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Love this place but it's always closed. That's tbe reason they get one less star. They should provide a date when they will come back since they are always on vacation. When on three separate occasions and it was closed. 

But the egg tarts are amazing!!!
author: Jaqueline C.

description:
45 min wait. WHHAT??! lol A 626 girl went all the way to S.F and waited in line for egg tarts?!?! Ya..I knoww....-_- I only did that because Yelp said it was the best! I don't think it tasted any different from other egg tart I have tried before. :/ Besides the fact that this place does constantly bake the egg tarts--so it is very fresh.

While in line, all I hear is people talking about how this place is really good--according to Yelp or the internet. So obviously, this place is popular because of Yelp. Right??? lol. I mean I did see a local walking by and saying "Why is this place so popular, it's not even that great". Lol It was coming from an asian grandma too. 

Well, I ordered the obvious--egg tart. They also sell moon cake, bean/lotus cake and other bakery items. I also got pineapple bun. YUCK. It doesn't taste like how it is suppose to. Trust me--I know. Pineapple bun is one of my favorite Chinese bakery item. They seriously skimped out on the main stuff--the filling. It was mostly bread. -.- Doesn't taste great--don't order it. Just get the egg tart and those bean/lotus cake. :)
author: Amy L.

description:
We were in China town today evening and were looking at things to do and where to eat. I have been in and out of SFO For quite a few years but never got time to come down to China Town. The Golden Gate Bakery came up on our list and there was a queue outside of about 30 odd people. Since we had some time on our hands, we stood in the queue, and 60 minutes later we got our hands on 2 Custard Pies, Half a Dozen Macaroons and a Coconut Pie... 

The Custard Pies are served piping hot, and usually packed in a box for you to take away or you can take them in a paper bag, we got 2 units as we did not have the patience to stand in the line, and I can tell you this - that this was one of the best custard pies I have ever had. 

Thank God we got two. The Macaroons are done just the right way, they are crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside with great amount of coconut in it.. 

Will make sure we visit them again before I leave SFO
author: Gagandeep S.

description:
I have been coming here for years and I  just love their the egg tarts. Everytime I come to SF I make it a point to bring a dozen of "Dan Tat"  home with me. When they give it to you...it is so fresh and flakey and just that good. I know people had tried others and people have said it's the same....no..no it's not. You haven't had "Dan Tat" until you have tried theirs. Wonderful taste and just so yummy. 
Their lines here are super long but everytime I do come theres no line. Lucky me...
But one thing for sure..you better catch them when they're in business 'cus it seems they like to go on vacation and when they do they close for weeks.
author: An N.

description:
It's always a good day when:
1. Your favorite place to get a warm, flaky-crusted egg custard tart is actually OPEN during said business hours on Yelp after being on vacation for who knows how long.
2. When there is no line at said favorite location, thus you are in and out in two minutes with your stash of goodies.

That's exactly what happened on Friday afternoon. I highly recommend trying this busy bakery out, but not enough to stand in a long line for it.

Tips: call ahead to see if they are open and if they can accommodate for your orders (in case you plan on buying a lot of baked goods), don't go on a weekend, and bring cash! Eat it on the spot or heat it up at home, the egg tarts are delicious either way!
author: Loriel L.

description: Closed for vacation with no warning whatsoever. They need to publicize some sort of vacation schedule.
author: Aaron W.

description: This 3 star rating only pertains to the my impression of the bakery from the outside.  It looks decent.  It is located in a bustling location, although parking could definitely be difficult.  The glass door and store itself looks very old, dilapidated and it's located in a very old part of Chinatown.  The "Closed, On Vacation" sign written on an old beaten piece of cardboard looks unprofessional.  I rather they had a real sign.  And as for the rating inside the store or the taste of the bake goods they're famous for?  Well, I don't know because each of the 10 time I happen to be there, they were closed 10 of those time.  So hopefully in the near future, I'll be able to give a more comprehensive review of this bakery which should include how the egg tart or the various pastries taste, that is.....if I'm lucky enough to catch it being open one of these days before I die.
author: Hairy Potmaker C.

description: We were walking through China town and the super long line outside caught our attention. We quickly learned that the bakery is known for its famous egg tarts. The line was probably 2 hours long but we just walked right in. The owners kept bringing fresh hot egg tarts to the front and everyone was trying to get them. We got our hands on two egg tarts and they were delicious! They lived up to the expectation! Hot out of the oven, flaky, crunchy, silky, and sweet. We never thought an egg tart would be so good. A few warnings though - the line can get very long, and the owners open and close the bakery whenever they feel like it.
author: Emily G.

description:
I had been wanting to try Golden Gate's egg tart forever!!! Finally after 45 mins in a (short) line. I finally got my egg tart. The reason for the wait because the line moved so slow!!! They basically make a new batch of 40-50 egg tarts every 10 minutes or so. Each customer would likely to buy a dozen. The bakery cannot meet the customer's needs because of its limited capacity. 

Egg Tart - I tried mine the moment it just came out of the oven. Piping hot. It was good but not as good as I anticipated. I was quite disappointed. The custard was a little too sweet and the egg flavor did not really come through. I wish it was more egg-y. The crust was like a puff pastry crust.  The egg tart did not impress me. I had better egg tart in So Cal minus the wait. 

Coconut Macaroon - I like this a little better. It was chewy inside and crunchy outside. That crunch made a different. Again, It was a little too sweet. 

Baked BBQ bun (Lean pork bun) - plently of meat filling inside but lack of flavor.
author: Katie T.

description:
Lived 29 years in the Bay Area without ever trying one of these scrumptious desserts at Golden Gate Bakery.  Thankful the drought ended this past weekend.   The wizardly ladies in this bakery have developed an impeccable egg tart -  good crust to egg ratio is what seals the deal.  There's also an excellent amount of flakiness without completely going limp upon the first bites.  

The egg tarts here are best when hot.  So when you order, make sure you buy some for "on the spot consumption."  I got weird looks when I did this, but I had too much egg to care. Whatever you do, don't be like the person behind me.  She ordered everything in the bakery EXCEPT the egg tarts.  Order a dozen for yourself.  Another dozen for family and friends.
author: Huy D.

description:
EGG TARTS EGG TARTS EGG TARTS!

It's a flaky crust with a warm soft egg filling that just makes you want to be able to consume the whole tart in one bite. Needless to say, I love these :) . This place makes exceptionally well that keeps you wanting for more. Try their egg white filling too!

The line is usually long, but it goes to show you that they are REALLY good. The interior is small, so don't expect to sit inside because there are no seats. Each tart is around $1.30, pricey but worth it! Best eaten when it's still warm. They have other pastries too. They close down some part of the year for vacation, hopefully that won't happen when you go :( TRY IT!
author: Winnie T.

description:
Dan-tats! Dan-tats! Dan-tats! 

If you love them egg tarts - this is the place to get them! Besides the fact that they are always randomly closed for long periods of time (which inspired the Facebook page "Is the Golden Gate Bakery Open Today?" For realz, guys), I have figured out that if you are craving some good and delicious dan-tats from this place, give them a call before you head over. That way, they know you're coming (so they don't randomly shut down) and you can commute over with excitement rather than anxiety.

Now, they do sell other items in the bakery. So, feel free to try them. But the shining star is the egg tart. And if you get them while it's hot, it's totally worth standing outside, ripping open the small vent they cut out for you to let the steam through, and taking the first bite right there on the street. As visiting Friend would say, it was her "best bite" from her entire visit to SF. 

PROS: Deliciousness (promised)
CONS: not always open, but just call beforehand!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Two separate trips to Golden Gate Bakery when they weren't on vacation and there was a very manageable line??? How much luckier can you get.

As has been said by almost everyone else, these are some truly magical dan tats or egg tarts. The asian women who man the counter are brisk and not down for chit chat but do they need to be when they're shilling out delicious Chinese baked goods?

The egg tarts are huge, impossibly flaky with silky smooth custard filings. Definitely get at least 6 so that you can gobble 2 immediately after purchase. Some advice, you may get super excited to get your hands on some and wish to freeze the egg tarts for a rainy day but they don't hold up well in the freezer. They do alright room temperature (and will make your kitchen smell delicious of egg tart) or in the fridge for a couple of days, if they last that long.
author: Teresa T.

description: I'd never heard of Golden Gate Bakery, but my friend insisted that they have the BEST egg tarts so off we went. We arrived a little after 12:30 to a line of about 20 people. The sign on the door said they opened at noon, but despite being half an hour after that time the doors were locked and the lights were out. Still, everyone continued waiting in line so we joined them. Finally, the doors opened around one and the long line moved fairly quickly. I peeked through the window to see what else they had on offer, but nothing really caught my eye, just some muffins and cookies. The egg tarts though? They were legit. Of course I gobbled one up as soon as I received the box! I don't think I've ever had a warm egg tart before and these were fresh out of the oven (is that how you make them?). The crust was crispy, but quite thin and the warm filling was a little sweeter than other egg tarts I've had. They were also pretty big and the price was right at around $1.60/each. I ate another one later on after they cooled off and I felt like they were just okay. For me, these are like Krispy Kreme donuts, best eaten hot off the line, but average after they've cooled. Check them out if you're in the area, but if you're coming from out of town be sure to give them a call to check their hours first!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
My friend: "How can you call yourself a 'Foodie' when you haven't even tried a Dan Tat from Golden Gate Bakery?!?!?"
Me (*embarrassed*): "Ummm, because they're always on 'vacation' and/or the line is ridiculously long?"
My friend: *SMH*

The aforementioned dialogue often occurs when I tell people that I've NEVER tried the infamous Dan Tat from Golden Gate Bakery. However, I guess today was my lucky day! I was getting my taxes filed down the block and decided to pass by GG Bakery to see if they were open and amazingly, they were and there was NO line! *jaw drops* When I was inside I actually had to walk outside to look at the sign again just to make sure I was in the right place and I was...

I bought a dozen of the Dan Tats ($1.15/each or $13.80/dozen) to bring to work and received a nicely bundled pink box with cut outs so the steam from the freshly baked Dan Tats can escape to maintain it's crispiness. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=M3T0ZQ_I7X4lMVjShyyIxg As I was handed my box, the fragrant aroma of the Dan Tats hit me in the face and I couldn't wait to get the office to devour one.

MY FIRST GG BAKERY DAN TAT EXPERIENCE
SUBLIMINAL ECSTASY! Still warm, the Dan Tat's crisp, buttery crust flaked off in layers as I sunk my teeth into the rich, soft custard. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=sUsL9GOUkjJP9iy8COQr6Q The custard was silky smooth (similar to a panna cotta) and had a more milky taste compared to other Dan Tats, which tend to have a more eggey flavor. The simple combo of the buttery crisp, ultra flaky crust and silky smooth custard with a hint of fragrant vanilla sent me to Food Heaven Ecstasy! It's amazing how rich, buttery and decadent, yet light the Dan Tat was. You CANNOT eat just one...

It's no wonder the Dan Tat from Golden Gate Bakery are on 7x7's list of "The Big Sweet SF: 50 Treats to Eat Before You Die". 40 more to go and I can die, very fat BUT happy...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Back in 2007 I'd have written that this place had the best dan tat ever, what with it's super flaky layered crust and tasty warm custard. Nowadays, at $1.40, they are very overpriced for their average quality. Basically they've never been able to match the original head baker's recipe since he passed away back then. Every now and then I try stopping by to see if they've ever found an equivalent baker, but it seems they just keep slipping. My most recent visit today left me sorely disappointed; one glance at the crust and you can tell immediately that this will not rise above the rest. Did they get yet another baker? Because this looks the least appealing of all the times I've visited, with its thin pinched crust edges and overly orange color. Egg custard itself tastes fine though. Better to be on a day when there's high turnover, so you get one that's warm (but not too warm, which tastes less yummy).

I've had wonderful uniformly flaky crusts like the old GGB in mini egg tarts served at a dim sum place, although I forget where (maybe Koi Palace??). Aside from going to the right dim sum restaurant, I've yet to find anything quite like the original I have in my memories. Oh well, the hunt goes on!
author: Linus W.

description:
I'd heard about this place in college, but didn't get a chance to visit since it's always been closed randomly.

I finally got to visit on a weekend trip to SF; there was a line outside but it only took about 15 minutes. I ordered the egg custard tart, as everyone knows that's what's famous.

The egg custard tart was extremely filling. It was also the most egg-y egg custard I've ever had (you could taste the egg). It's pretty much a mini-pie with egg custard in the middle. If I'm ever in SF around this area, I'll come back and visit.
author: Jayo D.

description: YES THE WAIT IS WORTH IT. We waited for a good 45 minutes and there were times when they ran out of tarts so the line was standstill and we were really questioning how we make decisions in life but in the end all is well, and the egg tart was the best tart in the world and it was phenomenal. The pastry is puff pastry (not short pastry) crispy, and the filling was just sweet enough and custardy soft as cloud. Waited for 45 mins, devoured in 1. Would definitely gladly line up again.
author: Thuy T.

description:
I came here because of yelp of course. It was really close to our hotel so I made a trip of it and decided to walk about 2 miles there. I was pleasantly surprised that there weren't too many hills walking there from union square area. I was able to walk by a lot of nicer more Americanized Chinese knick knack stores (more on that later). 

Once I got there the line was about 10 people deep, 5 inside 5 outside. They take cash only so I had to run across the street to the chase ATM. There are plenty of ATMs by this place. I took $20 but after waiting a whole I realized that it wasn't going to be enough. I am from la so I wanted a good sampling of items to take home with me. I thought from the yelp reviews this place was a one trick pony. (Dan tan's mainly) but no! This place has a lot of baked goods that are traditionally found in Hong Kong. They don't have those silly bread with cream inside. This is the really deal. They have the white rice cakes and coconut tarts. They have 6 different flavors of moon cakes white lotus, black bean, red bean, pineapple, ham and nuts. Very exciting!
author: Monica P.

description:
I have never seen so many reviews; it seems a little redundant for me to say anything, but I guess I'll just write here for personal ethos reasons.

The best part about Golden Gate Bakery is that feeling of reaching the front of the super long line and purchasing as many baked goods as you can stuff in your mouth. Maybe even more.

Egg Custard: Usually the main reason people shop here. Scrambled/custard is my favorite way to cook eggs, and compared to those of other tarts these eggs are incredibly fluffy. So I'm a big fan.

Sesame Ball: Much larger than those of other places and not lacking in the sesame and red bean flavor.

Mooncake: Lotus seed paste is especially fine, compared to other chunkier types.
author: Robseth T.

description: CLOSED!!!  Until they can find a new baker.  Apparently, making a flakey crust is very hard for Chinese people, that they need to search the ends of the Earth to find someone that knows how to do this.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I really don't want to repeat everyone here but golden gate is the best.

Aside from their famous egg tart, we also tried their bbq pork flaky bun. Salty and sweet at the same time.

I also observed the line started to get longer after lunch time. Maybe cuz everyone is getting desserts after dim sum.
author: Ruxin H.

description:
My mom dropped me off on the street and went around the block. Strolled in on a weekday morning and got me some Dan Tat (egg tarts). I was so clueless..

While lady was putting a dozen egg tarts into the pink box
Me: "Are these fresh?", I said in Chinese.
Lady: *Dirty look*
Me: Thinking she gave me a dirty look because of my poor Chinese.. "Fresh?"
Lady: "I don't need to tell you that. You can eat it and your question will be answered"
