Walked out with my dozen of egg tarts in hand. Popped one out of the little square flap. HOLY SH*T I AM A FOOL FOR EVEN ASKING. Buttery flaky crust + creamy rich custard, need I say more? Don't go in there and ask if their egg tarts are fresh.

***Call and make sure they're open before planning your journey to the best dan tat of your life. A lot of the times they are closed during store hours.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I was walking through Chinatown one day and stopped by here. I really never walk through Chinatown given the vast amount of tourists that saturate the shops/streets. But I was there during the day just walking through to get to North Beach.

At any rate, this bakery was super busy but it wasn't impossible to get in and order one egg tart to try. It was warm and delicious and I recommend getting it only if you're in the area. It's not really a place to go out of your way for. I mean, you can get good egg tarts in many other non-annoying non-tourist. If you're dying to try this place out though, it's highly advisable to walk from BART or something given the scarcity of parking and scattering pedestrians.
author: Marlon T.

description:
(SEE PHOTOS)

The egg tarts (dan tat) here are absolutely delicious, as plenty of people have already testified to. The other delicacies are really yummy as well! Give them some love~

- Coconut tart (yeh tat): Flaky crust (similar to egg tart) with soft, moist coconut filling.
- Custard Napoleon!: From the outside, it looks just like a mini yellow cake with coconut flakes on the outside and puff pastry on top, dusted with powdered sugar. Sounds delicious already right? Well, there's also custard inside; it's a bit like the cream rolls at Asian supermarkets. And it tastes like the egg tart and coconut tart combined! Definitely try this, you will not regret it. (And it's cheaper than an egg tart!)
- Wife pastry (lo po bang): flat, circular pastry with winter melon filling and thin flaky skin. Mildly sweet.
- Chicken pie: half-circle pastry with the same yummy flaky crust and pieces of chicken, bell pepper and corn inside. I thought it tasted a bit like beef, but anyway, it was savory and delicious!

I recommend lightly toasting the pastries (if you aren't eating them fresh out of the oven). Yum~

Cons:
- Long lines (sometimes). But the food is definitely worth the wait!
- Service isn't too great. But I think if the ladies weren't so brisk, the line would be moving muchhh slower. If you speak Cantonese, you can chat with them (though they'll probably still be very abrupt with you). Oh well, we're there for the food, not for socializing!
- The bakery is very crowded, messy, and loud
- All of the food is really unhealthy (how else would the crust be so flaky, without tons of egg + butter + cream?)

But honestly, if you don't try Golden Gate Bakery for any of the above cons, you are missing out on some really awesome food. :)
author: Ivonnie S.

description:
I gotta say, the egg tarts almost living up to the hype! I only have 2 complaints. First, I'm not crazy about the price, to add such a premium on their egg tarts over everyone else in town. Secondly, we only purchased 2. Keep in mind they're piping hot, and the store decides to drop them in a plastic bag so the heat and steam off the tarts condense in the bag, not great for take home. 

But the positives...they're slightly bigger than conventional egg tarts, with almost 3/4inch of filling. And they do a great job with the filling and crust. And the crust is super flaky!
author: Kit L.

description:
I mean, everyone's gonna tell you this, but it's kind of on the pricey side ($1.65/per) but I mean they give you no choice but to line up and buy a dozen of their egg tarts. I mean sure you can go and get some of the other stuff that they bake, but c'mon we know everyone isn't lining up for the other stuff. 

These are honestly the best egg tarts I've ever had. You take a bite into a nice, fresh, warm, just out of the oven egg tart and you get two parts. One part buttery, flaky crunch and one part soft, sweet egg. 

Unfortunately if you're not a local and have to make a trip out, they take random and week(s) long vacations, which could be problematic.
author: Chuan C.

description:
i take back everything i said about golden gate bakery...  but the only legit way to eat the egg tarts is to eat it on the spot fresh out of the oven :)

don't:
1.  take the egg tarts home
2.  eat the egg tarts cold
3.  visit ggb when they are on random unannounced vacations

other than that, i love the egg tarts so much, totally worth the walk to china town :)
author: Alice C.

description: This place already has enough reviews. But I had to add this. I bought two of the famous don tats. One for me and one for my sister. She's staffed in San Francisco for a project so she's at work while I'm exploring the city on my own. I figured that I would be a good sister and surprise her with some sweets. I took one bite of my mine - and then proceeded to gobble it up as I was walking down the street. It was delicious! It was still slightly warm. And the crust! I normally hate the crust. But this was different. Flaky and delicious. I was sad that mine was one...Then I reached into the bag again and took a bite of my sister's... Oops? She'll never notice!
author: Anne W.

description: The egg tarts are delicious. The shell is buttery and flaky. The egg custard was soft, silky and warm. The best of the best!
author: Donna Y.

description:
This little hole in the wall has been around for decades. It lacks decor, it lacks seating, it lacks room to move, but it definitely does not lack the customers lined up outside waiting to sample their fresh Chinese pastries.

They are known for the egg custard tarts. Always fresh, the crust is flaky and the filling is light compared to all other places I've tried. For all the times I've been there, the egg tarts were always hot out of the oven. 

Also tried their lemon and rasberry Napoleons. Both were light, fresh and have a thin layer of fruit spread. Again, not heavy so I don't feel sick after eating a couple of slices. 

If you're visiting SF, take a stroll through Chinatown and check this place out. About a 10-15 min. walk from Union Sq. (depending on how many shops you stop at along the way, could be longer)
author: James L.

description: Same! went there wanting to try what everyone claims on here and nope it was closed. I guess until next time in Cali!
author: Hanlly S.

description: I was told to come here for their egg tarts. There was a short wait for their next batch of egg tarts when I got there, but it was worth it. The egg tarts weren't too sweet and had a nice flaky crust. I enjoyed them, and this review is for their egg tarts only. I might try their other sweets next time.
author: Kosmo Z.

description:
I came here on New Year's Eve for the first time in at least 10 years, and even though I waited an hour for egg tarts I was glad I came. The Chinese tourists from Shenzhen in front of me commented that the egg tarts in Shenzhen were comparable, but really, why would you bother going to Chinatown if you're FROM China? And why bother waiting for egg tarts? That was a mystery to me. 

Anyway, these are best enjoyed warm but I'd still eat them if they're cold.
author: Ted W.

description:
This place is definitely worth it to try if you haven't already, just to see what the hype is about, just don't come here when there is a line longer than 10-20 people max, or if there is a line, do yourself a favor and walk away and come back later. Or have a rotation with some friends. Or try and ask/bribe someone to buy the goods for you ^_^ FYI, custard tarts are $1.40 each ($16.80/dozen) and the moon cakes are around $7-8 based on the flavor and filling type.

It was a total mistake to come here during the Moon Festival. We ended up waiting 2 hours just to get inside and get our custard tarts and moon cakes. And in reality, they weren't that much different than normal custard tarts and moon cakes I can buy within 5 minutes at a local SOGO, Marina Foods, or Ranch 99.

The issue (or good part when there is no line) is that they make everything fresh. And with batches of 24 custard tarts and most people buying boxes of 6 or 12, you can see how the line can get long and stagnant. Each batch takes around ~5-10 minutes. 

Personally, I prefer custard tarts chilled, so tasting the freshly made hot ones wasn't my thing. It was good, but just not my style, so keep that in mind. 

Also, the place itself is really small. It can fit only a few customers inside at a time, and there are no seats or anything. A very buy-and-go type of place. Not much decoration or sight seeing to do inside the store, but in case you wanted to snap the photos, just beware, they have a sign that says no photos or camera recording inside. They are so famous they probably want to avoid all the paparazzi :P
author: Eric S.

description:
It's gotta be some 2000 year old recipe from the Ming dynasty that Golden Gate uses to make these egg tarts so freakin' good.

Add a warm, velvety, creamy custard to a super flaky crisp crust and 
you have yourself the best egg tart in the city. It's like they crammed the flavor of a thousand and one egg tarts into one. 

Definitely well worth the $1.15. Knock this off your 7x7 list!  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=o4OHTGddsNRdQYcESwLvJg)
author: Earl G.

description:
Ask me this: Would you book a flight to SFO solely for half a dozen dan tats from Golden Gate Bakery? Um, it's only practically a rhetorical question...

The last time I had me some Golden Gate was quite a number of years ago. Why, you ask? Well, they have been galavanting the world (I'm assuming) the last two times I've been to their storefront (read: closed without annoucement). No other store in Chinatown would dare do such a thing, save for Lunar New Year or the like. However, Golden Gate has earned the rights to do so...but since they are Chinese you won't find out until you see an empty store on Grant Ave (true story). 

The line literally zig zags out the small space of the bakery and snakes around the sidewalk. Tourists walk by muttering to themselves, "This must be a good bakery." Is it worth the 15-30 minute wait? Six dan tats and a gigantic sesame ball later, I can wipe the bread crumbs off my fat kid face and say with certainty, "Nom yes nom nom." I'm also unashamed (and quite proud) to say that I even brought extra dan tats through TSA and back to LA with me. They taste just as good, if not better, 2-3 days later and I'm pretty sure that's not normal (a feat, really). So yes, Golden Gate Bakery has the best damn dan tats in SF's Chinatown - and dare I say, California. 

Dan tat tat tat tat tat tat tat...
author: Phoebe C.

description: Pathetic place..NVR open!!! Drove by 3 times and didn't even have a vacation sign up. At less have the courtesy to put up a sign.
author: J L.

description:
it's rare for my chinatown visits and the bakery's actual operating hours to coincide, but they did late yesterday afternoon. it was a bit of a wait, since we had to stand around while THEY WERE STILL BEING BAKED. meaning when we finally got ours (four, because we only had $8 and they're $1.65 each), they were piping hot and we could feel the warmth through the white paper pastry bag. unghhh. this and the debauchery immediately in our line of sight, where a group was devouring a dozen right outside the door, as if they couldn't possibly wait another moment, was too much for us. we stopped a couple hundred feet away in front of a closed store and shared a half.

the pastry was so crisp and flaky, so fresh that the custard's moisture hadn't had a chance to seep into it yet. the custard was so pale yellow that i was kind of thinking that there was more cream than egg in there, but mostly just marveling at how rich and just barely sweet it was. and the texture- it was barely set, almost like chawan mushi or steamed egg, and not stupidly jiggly like jello or something with way too much gelatin. my mouth hurt from burning it in so many places; no matter, it's worth it.

i had another bite after dinner, and it was even better- the custard was slightly more set, but still not too dense or firm. crust was impeccably crisp, still. they were a little banged up; who cares when you have fresh dan tat. and maybe you somehow have extra's the next day. if you do, toast it a little (toaster oven only please, not toaster. that's a bad way for the custard to die). or if you're into the cold leftover thing, it's really nice straight from the fridge.

get other stuff here if you want, but if you don't get the dan tat, you're an idiot.
author: Heather F.

description:
After being next to it and reading all the hype and good reviews about this place, we had to give a try. There was quite a line but it moved relatively fast. 

We read a lot of good reviews about the egg tarte so we had to try one. To our luck they were just right out of the oven. We also had a lotus moon cake and some kind of a mochi like cake. 

Unfortunately, the egg tarte wasn't to our taste. It is exactly like it sounds like, egg in a crust. I guess were were expecting something a little less eggy and more sweet (tart-y). But that's only my hubby and I opinion. 

The mochi thingy was blend not much flavor... As for the moon cake it was really good !
author: Tamara S.

description: This is the second year in the row (in two different times of the year btw) that my boyfriend and I have attempted to come here when we visit SF. We've read so many great reviews on their "popular" egg tarts but every time we go there.. It's always closed saying "Sorry.. On vacation." Oh well.. Maybe next year again...
author: Lyn M.

description: I never liked egg tarts until my co worker brought me here to try, It was sweet and delicious. All the previous egg tarts i tried tasted like sweet scrambled eggs, but not this one. We got a dozen fresh out the oven, and when we got back to the office there was 2 left. I also had a good baked pork bun, it was worth the walk from our office.
author: Sean M.

description:
I waited almost 30 minutes for the famous egg tart. When it was my time to order the woman with the longer hair of the crew there was so rude to me I was embarrassed. It was like what do you want? I'm sorry, does the fact that I'm the only African American in this long line of people bother you? Shame on you! My money is just as green as everyone else's. And get a freakin clue, this is San Francisco - land of diversity. Just because you're in Chinatown doesn't change that. I am absolutely appalled at the level if service I received. I don't care how famous your damn egg tarts are, when people are kind enough to stand in line for 30-45 minutes at your establishment, the least that you can do is be kind and say thank you.

I will never return!
author: Dee M.

description:
#82 on SF Foodie's countdown for this year!

I'm so with the last reviewer..... 

Today
about 1220
fresh piping hot
larger than life (ok...just than your ave one)
Dan taat/Dan ta/egg tart paradise

Jiggly, sexy, perfectly baked shimmering pool of creamy, sweet, smooth, luscious custard.

Flaky, golden, rich, marvelous tart crust with umpteenth thinly laid layers.

O
H

M
Y
author: Jana C.

description:
My greatest weakness when I'm in SF. Golden Gate Bakery. IF THEY ARE EVER OPEN! This bakery is usually close most months of the year. 

If open you will find a long line, but definatly worth the wait. These egg tarts sold freshly cooked sold HOT in the box. Tasty egg tarts so extraordinarily made with this amazing light creamy custard filling so smooth and velvety inside this perfect sensational buttery, flaky crust that just melts in your mouth. 

I would give 5 stars but disappointing they're never open:( 
CASH ONLY
author: Shannon A.

description:
The most amazing egg tarts ever and I've been fortunate enough to grow up with them. This little hole in the wall bakery made it onto the SF 7x7 list so for a gem hidden in the non-touristy side of Chinatown that's impressive.

If you don't know Chinese pastries, this is a must try and will put all the other versions you've ever tried to same. Their egg tarts are always fresh and a huge reason why often time there is a line out front.

The ladies know exactly what to do when they pack everything in for you so just trust them, even if if does look odd at the time. They have some weird system worked out on who takes orders and who does the cashiering but just go with it. Confusing them has only caused more problems for the steady lines. 

Egg Tarts aren't the only delicious items at Golden Gate Bakery. During the Moon Festival, their moon cakes are always a must have in my household. My mom would rather shell out the extra money to purchase these for our relatives than buy the prepackaged moon cakes. The freshness and taste do come at a higher price than the tin boxes you'll see all over the streets. Depending on fillings, a box of 4 moon cakes can run you up to at least $30.

The cakes, buns and other baked goods they offer are pretty good as well. I'm pretty sure over the years, I've tried everything they've had to offer and till today, I've had no complaints. Well maybe other than the line.. but we always try to go when it's not as busy.

- Jenn
author: Jenn Y.

description:
The best place for egg custard tarts!!! Went during my lunch break and score!!! Only 3 people in front of me! The bakery is really small but there are numerous baked goods. Some I've seen before and some I haven't. There was only one thing I already knew what to get- egg custard tarts!!!
I had read the most of the reviews from here so I knew to only bring cash, be prepared to wait in line and of course, eat freshly bought! The crust is buttery and flaky. The custard is not too sweet and the consistency is really silky. I loved it!!
author: Mimie L.

description:
Everyone's already mentioned it.. BUT this place has the BEST Dan Tat (Egg Custard) I have ever had. I haven't had it at too many places nor am I on the mission to find the best Dan Tat, but this place does an awesome job.

It's located right in the middle of Chinatown. It's a very small bakery that sells other Chinese/Asian sweets as well. Me and my gf new exactly what we wanted. At first, we were afraid that they didn't have any left as it was in the middle of afternoon but we came at the PERFECT time b/c they just finish making a fresh batch straight from the magical Asian oven!

You get 12 for 16 bucks which is actually really expensive, to me at least. I am sure you can buy in smaller quantities but i'm not sure how much. The crust is perfectly flaky and light, the egg custard itself is soft, mouth watering and delicious. Ours was still extremely hot but it was worth getting our tongues burnt do put these delicious pastries in our mouth. The egg custard itself is a pretty good size, definitely not small by any means. Go HERE if you want Dan Tat!!
author: Timmy T.

description: In the last two years I've traveled to San Francisco on 4 separate occasions and each time I've seen the sign on the door that they are on vacation. Does anyone know if this place has closed down?
author: Mitzi D.

description:
I ended up waiting 35-45 minutes just for a half dozen dan tats, but it was kind of a nice experience.  The egg tarts were warm when I got them.  As you've probably already read from previous reviews, the egg tarts are really delicious.  The crust is nice and flaky and holds up really well even after a few hours or overnight!  The egg was sweet and smooth, just as expected.  I still prefer the Portugese style egg tarts from other places, but GGB's HK style egg tarts are pretty good.  I'm not sure I'd want to wait in line more than once or twice a year for their stuff though.  

The entire place was run by middle-aged Chinese ladies.  One of them had been working at GGB for at least 15-20 years.  Such dedication!

Parking can be a headache, but if you want to try your luck, they are all metered.
author: May W.

description:
Long Lines = Check

Rainy & Cold Outside = Check

Awesome Selection of Tasty Pastries = Check

Feeling of Euphoria When Eating the Amazing Custard Pies = Triple Check!!!

Happy Eats!
author: Kent D.

description:
This is the place to get egg tarts in sf. There was a line when we went, but we probably only waited 20-30 minutes, which is not bad at all compared to the horror stories I've heard. So pick the right times and you'll be safe :) 

They had a pastry with preserved egg inside. It was no good,  I wouldn't recommend getting it.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Yummmmm egg custard, egg custard, egg custard. Golden Gate Bakery sells a variety of goodies but nothing measures up to the deliciousness of their egg tarts.

Beware: the line is always long and they always go on vacation without warning.
author: Courtney C.

description:
This place was my No. 1 Chinese bakery in North American in my mind. I was so happy to find out that they sell banana rice cake with very reasonable price. The taste was awesome, remind me of my childhood. The decor was completely old school style.

I am from NY, there may be some old Chinese bakeries in Chinatown Manhattan, but they don't have banana rice cake.
author: Spencer L.

description:
Luck was on our side when visiting SF! 

On our last day, we made it a point to stop by Chinatown to try these "heavenly" tarts. It was a miracle that there was no wait when we arrived, so we pounced. 

Ordered some egg tarts and sesame balls filled with red beans. The egg tarts is essentially the blueprint of what an egg tart should be. The eggy part wasn't too hard nor artificially tasting. It was smooth and had  the perfect egg sweetness balanced with the flaky, non oily crust. I can understand the hype. 

The sesame balls were a nice surprise! LARGE balls of crispy fried goodness. I liked it because it was still crispy and the sweetness of the red bean filling was perfect. Trust me this is not some dank sesame ball that you find at dim sum places. 

Overall, good products but not sure if I would wait for it though. Service was quick and efficient!


-Give it a try! 


P.s. I think it is cash only, so have cash on you just in case.
author: Jocelyn V.

description:
I have heard great things about the egg tarts here. I didn't want to get my hopes up too high mainly because a friend of mine, who visited San Francisco a few months ago, told me that she didn't like it as much as the egg tarts in Houston. 

It was close to 7 (closing time) when my friends and I got here. The line wasn't too bad and we probably waited for 20 minutes. The entire time, we were looking into the crowded shop and praying they don't run out of egg tarts before we reach the counter. Luckily, they didn't and I finally got to try this egg tart all the Californians talk so highly about.

My friend back at home was right. They're good but definitely not as good as the ones in Houston. So if you're ever in town, go try ECK Bakery! You will not be disappointed.
author: Jessica C.

description: The egg tart tastes like steak and eggs. It has a salty, buttery crust and the custard is very rich.
author: Gabriel D.

description:
a San Francisco Chinatown institution.

they are famous for their egg custard tarts.
but I have a different idea.
I love their BBQ Pork Buns even more!
that's what I usually get when I'm around.

the best time to come here is after 5 pm when there is no line.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Call ahead to see if they're open! Someone might just pick up. I called on a Thursday afternoon at 2pm. A lady picked up and told me their hours were going to be from 4pm - 8pm. I arrived at 3:55 pm and there was already a line! 

Someone in front of me ordered 10 boxes....so I had to wait another 15 minutes for fresh ones. $18 for a dozen or else it'll be $1.50 each. The egg tarts come fresh out of the oven! These egg tarts taste amazing! They are ESPECIALLY amazing when they're still hot! 

Tip: I overheard the lady telling a customer that the egg tarts will last up to 3 days in the fridge
author: Fanny H.

description:
I remember my father bringing me here as a kid- Back then when the lines were not crazy long...he used to always buy pastries here in boxes and bring them home! 

BEST PASTRIES EVER!!!! Their "Dahn Taht" aka EGG tarts are the best i've ever had.
their wife cake=THE BEST i've ever had!!!!!!
their moon cake.. you get the point!!

TOO bad they were closed for a month while we were here -_-

from speaking with the elderly locals, they close once a year for a month. Yes, that's how much monnnay they make!
author: S-Goddess V.

description:
Nom, nom, nom, nom, nom... the scrumptious warm egg tarts.

Now $1.15 (I think I paid $1.10 in January), and I always go for the dozen. Costs more if u only buy one.

Cash only.
author: Luis C.

description:
I never liked egg tarts until I've had egg tarts from this place!
There's always a long line here but it's well worth it! They have such good business here that majority of the time, they are closed for vacation, so make sure you catch them when they're not on vacation!!

Egg Tarts: Tart shell is buttery and flaky, egg part is delicate and silky & fills your mouth with sweet eggy goodness. They're best eaten warm!!
Banana Roll: Mochi rolls coated with shaved coconut with a banana filling. They are my second favorite thing here!! 
Cow ear snacks: I know they sound weird but the name is more for the shape of these snacks, not entirely sure what they are made of but they are these thin beige and brown swirled crisps that I can't get enough of! I can literally eat a whole bag of them! 

I love this place, I just wished they wouldn't go on so many vacations!!!
author: Kelly L.

description:
A Chinatown treasure. 

Small, crowded storefront. Hard at work Chinese women. A delicious selection of Chinatown treats. Egg tarts, moon cakes, macaroons, custard bread, Mexican bread, and lots of other amazing glutinous treats. 

If you are a tourist or a local, make sure to visit this San Francisco treat. So, go on. Stop by. Grab a few baked good. It will not disappoint. 

Prices: Super affordable! Most breads $1-2. Specialty baked goods, such as moon cakes are $6 and up. 

Location: Close to Little Italy and Union Square.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Best egg tarts ever. Though by no means an expert, I've had my share over the years and have often been disappointed - soggy crust, unnaturally bright yellow color, thick skin on top, too sweet, not sweet enough... But these are special. Even my mother, who generally has no interest in egg tarts, could not stop raving about these. The pastry shell is flaky almost like a croissant, and the custard is so smooth. 

Fortunately, we only had to wait in line for about 30 minutes on a Thursday afternoon during the holidays. At one point, we got really worried because the line stopped moving and it appeared that there were no more egg tarts, but about 5-10 minutes later another batch came out of the oven, piping hot. People smile at you when you walk around the City with vents cut in your Golden Gate Bakery box because they know you got lucky that day.
author: Sharon Y.

description:
I am going to review their curry chicken pastries. No one reviews those and they are simply DIVINE. And I am sad I only bought 1 to try, I should've bought at least 5 for myself.

(1) I have never had a curry puff pastry filled to the brim with contents. And the filling is so good-- did I mention it's full of corn? My own personal favorite, but the curry paste and the chicken filling is also there. 

(2) crust is nicely flaky but not too much. I hate it when it's super dry but this one wasn't at all

(3) Price was around $2.50? So kind of pricy. But worth it.

For tips on lines and egg tarts read everyone else's reviews.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
I love egg tarts.
So, when I was in SF for the day I was Yelping on my phone for good places to eat. After seeing the 4.5 stars by 1800+ Yelpers, I decided I would try it out. BUT - made the mistake of not actually reading any of the reviews (very not like me)...
After dinner, we found the bakery - there was a line. But, I looked at my BF and shrugged, "this line should go quickly.. don't worry... we'll be home right after I get a dozen!".... Right. (Please see my awesome drawing/photo of what the line REALLY looked like... lol)

I'm not from Frisco, so this was my first time at this bakery. The line I was able to see from 5'6, on tip toes, looked like a cake walk! 45 minutes in, we had only moved up the line by about 4 people... the only reason, was because the 4 people before us, got sick of waiting and left (harhar). To make a long story short - 1.5 hours later, and 10 slots up later, we were able to see the line formation. The only words out of my mouth was "OH - MY - F*CK!!". I don't know if the bakery asked people to form the line this way, or it just happened, but the line snaked around like the shape of a question mark. THREE HOURS AND FIFTEEN MINUTES LATER - we finally made it to the entrance of the bakery. Cold, tired, hungry, irritated, and stressed we made our order. A dozen egg tarts, 4 moon cakes. 

I don't know if the line is this ridiculous usually... But I'm thinking maybe it was like this because they make thousands of moon cakes, flavors from lotus seed, to coconut & nuts, to pineapple - with yolk, without yolk. I happened to be there the week of Chinese moon festival... Sooo, maybe? 

THE EGG TARTS - were really amazingly delicious. Worth 3 hours of standing in line for? In the cold? Not really. $16.80 for a dozen or $1.40 a piece. Good size. Creamy and eggy in the middle. Had the perfect amount of jiggle in the center. Egg was not too sweet - just perfect. Amazing flaky crust. 
My irritation of it was the way they boxed up my tarts. Small box - 2 layers. The tarts were just right out of the oven, with only a few minutes of cooling time, before boxed. Now, while they cut 2 holes on the corners of the box to allow steam to escape... that just isn't enough to work. The steam rising from the bottom tarts, sogged up the top layer tarts. And, as pictured, the tarts ALL looked like that. Squished. Bottom and sides of crusts were slightly soggy and top of crusts were still golden brown, flaky, goodness. They really should allow them to cool before boxing them! I understand that they are so popular that they are making egg tarts every 5-10 minutes, ALL day... But, as a business, they should consider expanding, hiring bakers to bake. The reason it took so long, was because they didn't have enough tarts to supply EVERY person in line... So, they would make people wait for tarts to finish... which is why it takes them about 20 minutes to serve 2 customers. 

BUT I must give credit where it is due. The bakery closes @ 8pm, and the staff stayed until 10pm to make sure that everyone who stood in line, was able to leave with what they came for. There was still about 20 people @ 9pm (an hour AFTER they were suppose to close). But instead of limiting the last few of us to only 6 tarts max, they decided to stay for as long as needed and continued to bake up tarts until the last of us! Now THAT is awesome customer service. And plus, the staff were all very very sweet and smiled through the chaos. 

So, last thoughts: egg tarts tasted as good as everyone says. They could use some help in the boxing department. So if you would like to try the tarts, I would walk by and check out the line: if there are more than 10 people outside the door, it might take 15-20 minutes. If the line begins to wrap around the side walk - come back another day OR bring a book, and a fold up chair to sit on.. It sure was a crazy experience but here I am 24 hours after the fact, and I have no tarts left.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Despite their amazing egg tarts, you have to try their big walnut cookie (super crunchy and tasty) and and wife pastry (sweet winter melon filling). Everything is $$ so beware! I walk out spending over $40 every time! 

-1 star because they are always closed for holidays/Chinese new year/vacations etc. I have family that visits from LA and every time they are closed!
author: Yen Yen C.

description:
There's always a line here. We were lucky to come when they were open and not on vacation. The egg custards are pretty good. 
Line is long.
author: Maria M.

description:
Still the best Hong Kong style custard tart, aka dan tat, on this side of the hemisphere. Yes, they are expensive here, but one can argue that we pay that kind of pricing for a lesser quality pastry in non-Asian bakeries or for a cup of coffee.

Sales ladies are sooooo nice. They stayed late to help me with the last order of the day, and with a big smile, too.

Still irksome that they close without notice, and we never know when to expect to pick up some of these delicious heavenly tasting dan tats. And still irksome that they won't take pre-orders for these.
author: Lil D.

description: One of our first stops in Chinatown. Never tasted the tarts and found they're great. Worth the line. Cultural experience as a matter of fact.
author: Rafael B.

description: Pretty much the best Chinese bakery in town. Egg custard and cocktail buns are my favorites. It's worth spending the time to find a place to park. Yum.
author: Big E.

description:
oh GG Bakery, your egg tarts are bites of heaven.  So fresh, no weird after eggy taste like some other egg tarts.  Each bite is perfection.  The egg custard center is warm, not too sweet and the perfect consistency.  The flaky pastry shell compliments the egg custard perfectly.  Goes great with a hot cup of tea to wash it down with.

I really love the egg tars here but yesterday I also tried their curry beef pastry and it is da bomb dot com.  Wife cake is very fresh and flavorful too.

Gotta take my family here soon when they visit so they can try it too.
author: Yue L.

description: Wondering why there is always a long line on Grant between Jackson and Pacific? It is the line to the best egg tarts you can buy. The texture is perfect with the crust perfectly layered. I would always recommend Golden Gate to tourists when they ask me about good food in Chinatown. They are also known for their moon cakes during the Autumn Moon Festival where the line gets worse and stretches to the intersection of Pacific. I usually get four of the lotus seed paste with double yolks. I also like their Pineapple and BBQ Pork Buns for the texture. If you have the time to wait, I would definitely recommend giving them a try. A thing to note is that they go on vacation a lot throughout the year so it can be a hit or miss if your not from the area. But other than that it is a sign that business is good if you are capable in taking weeks off.
author: Peter C.

description:
I was really curios to try the egg tart that supposed to be the best in Chinatown. I'm not impressed at all. We waited for an hour started at 9 am and made a conclusion that the wait mostly caused by inefficiency and lack of organization.
There's no line up system, you have to yell or speak out louder than people around you to get attention that is after you made it to the store, while lining up if you don't pay attention somebody can or at least will try to skip the line and sneak in front of you. 
Finally, the egg tart, it was eggy, the texture was watery, nothing special about the pastry, just blah. To be honest I tasted so many better egg tarts that I can say that this one just a waste of time.
author: Hermine W.

description: I'm not a fan of egg tarts to begin with but I had visitors here.. so we went to wait in line and honestly they were worth it. Comes out fresh and probably one of the best egg tarts ever. The coconut macaroons are also great too!
author: Christine T.

description:
Amazing egg tarts! They're well-priced, huge, and are usually fresh out of the oven. Definitely a place you must try if you like egg tarts. Also, for those that don't speak Chinese, ordering is as easy as just holding up a number of fingers and they'll get the hint.

Oh, and don't forget that it's cash only, which is always a bother for me.
author: Johanna T.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery gets 4 stars for marketing, not good eats. why?
-poor customer service
-products unlabeled, mostly unpriced. (tourists wasting time asking, being answered).
-opening whenever they need $$/feel like it.
-not much buns, egg tarts on hand-runs out easily, causes waiting=delays.
-waited 1/2 hour to get in, about 8 people ahead on me.

eats: 
-egg custard @1.35
still warm from oven, nice crust, liquid center, buttery/eggy taste, 
lots of sugar/sweetener in custard, limited egg taste.
definitely overrated. needs some grass to mellow out the sweetnes..

-curry beef turnover@1.30?
spicy curry, chewy beef, nice crust, nearly the best i've had.

* custards@1.35 + beef turnover@1.30 =$6?

ok, not a math miz, but my figure is 5.35
-maybe tax?  new employee? not knowin g price? whatever. just blew it off

crumbs:
-not the best egg custsrd eaten. 3 stars.
-store's limited spcae only alllovs 5 to get into shop, thus creating a line
-most of shop is racks with boxes in them
-fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice? you can't fool me again!
author: Victor G.

description:
Everyone around me talk about how good this egg tart is and always ask me to buy it for them cuz my office is near the store. Finally I bought six egg tarts to celebrate Moon Festival with my friends and to me, it's a tad overrated hype. 

Let's start from the taste first. It was good even though I bought it in the morning and ate it at night. You just need to put it into oven then it will taste exactly the same. The crust was flaky and thin and with nice gooey egg custard in the middle. And I have to say, this egg tart is probably with the most flaky and the most gooey custard I've ever had in this area.  

However, I would expect more based on reviews and rating from Yelp. Custard was good, but suppose to have more flavor rather than just egg yolk. In other words, the custard was a little bit too eggy and did not match well with their buttery crust. 

Next, the earlier you go, the less time you will spend waiting in the line. At least you need to wait for 30 mins generally in the afternoon. Try to visit there as earlier as you can so that you won't waste too much time prob for just one or two egg tarts. 

Therefore, they won't tell you when are they on vacation until you actually visit the place. Just cross your finger and pray when you decide to visit and hope they do open at that time. 

Lastly, I think this egg tarts is a tad overrated hype, and don't worth to wait for 30mins or longer.
author: Jing Y.

description: Waited an hour for these egg tarts because of the slow service but seriously the best egg tarts ever!!!! They were piping hot and the crust was perfectly crunchy and buttery! Sooo good!
author: Linh T.

description: This bakery is so so yummy ..!! But couldn't buy anything cuz they still closed for vacation ... Been a month already still not open ..!!
author: Crisy G.

description:
THE BEST egg custard tarts ever!

Big, flaky crust, filled with egg custard. It's my favorite Chinese pastry/dessert.

Probably the most expensive place to get an egg tart, $1.35 each, but it just melts in your mouth and is always hot & fresh!

They also sell baked BBQ pork buns (I haven't tried them yet but heard they were good), sesame balls filled with red bean, cookies, and other Chinese pastries.

I always stop by here when I am in SF!

FYI, always a long line, about 15 min wait, but SOO WORTH IT! :D

Con - They go on vacation a lot so there are times where they are closed for weeks (unannounced).
author: Lily Y.

description: The best egg custard tarts in America. To have the best experience you have to eat it fresh. The crust is flaky and the custard is warm and creamy. Like any place that is good there is a line. I always stop by when in Chinatown. The macaroons are not bad either.
author: Steven L.

description:
My sisters and I have been to this bakery several times in the past.  The bakery is small and probably only 5 to 6 people can stand inside, while the lines of people are waiting outside for the fresh egg custard tart (dahn tot).

We were in SF Chinatown to do a little browsing and shopping for lop yuk for my mom and, of course, a stop at this bakery for their specialty, the egg custard tart.  My sister was also looking for another type of pastry; she calls them "flying saucer" (they're white and glutinous and they're shaped like a little saucer).  They didn't have any.  However, she did buy my mom her favorite cookies...the coconut cookies (sort of look like them coconut macaroons).    

I am fortunate that I have an older sister to treat my younger sister and me to these egg custards.  I have to concede that they are the best.  The crust is probably made with a whole lotta butter for the melt-in-the-mouth taste.  The egg custard is also delish...so velvety smooth and sweet.  It doesn't have a lot of eggy taste, but still it's all good.  More like, excellent and they are the "bomb".

Many moons ago (and they have moon cakes, too), these egg custards were 50 cents each, but now they're $1.35 each.  I wouldn't doubt when and if these people go on vacation and they come back, they will raise the price to $1.50 each.  It's a business and they know what they're doing.  

Finally, there is a saying..."what's worth waiting is worth getting".  These egg custard tarts are no exception and they are worth the wait, even in the rain (and nope, I wasn't "singing in the rain"...lol).
author: Carol C.

description:
This was the first place we came to on the morning after our arrival - my brother's coworker also suggested him to this place for the best egg tarts in town....and true to his words it was the most delicious egg tarts I have ever had. 

We thought that there would be a long line and wait - but we got there around 9ish and luckily - I guess it was because it was a Friday morning that there wasn't a long line yet - and we got to try the egg tarts fresh out of the oven. 

The thing I like about these egg tarts is that it's a whole lot of egg custard - piping steaming hot egg custard in the center with a thin and flaky crust....it was perfect for me. that's the part of the egg tart I love the most and this place made it perfectly. 

My parents and brother all agree this place was THE PLACE for egg tarts and we all loved it so much that my brother went there early on the morning before we left to get a dozen of it to take home.

If you like egg tarts and don't mind taking a trip to Chinatown - then this bakery is a must try!

Also their cream cake slices are also very good too!
author: Joanna L.

description:
The egg tarts. Oh, dear goodness, the egg tarts.

I don't care if they're $1.35 each or $16.20 a dozen. I don't care that I usually don't even seek egg tarts. I don't care that I have to wait in line and that I'm not allowed to photograph the bakery. I don't care that I have to drive 400+ miles to get to this place just to get these egg tarts.

My only regret is that I didn't eat them right away. Still, they were delicious two hours later. Still, they were delicious 24 hours later (I recommend that you don't refrigerate or microwave them--otherwise, the crust will get soggy!). 
Oh, wait. I have one more regret--that I didn't get a full dozen! Sigh.

They're just so good. And the size of the egg tart is more than satisfactory. It isn't enormous, but it isn't those cheap-sized ones you get at dim sum places. They're generous with the custard part, which makes for seriously the best egg tarts ever.
author: Wendy C.

description: We wandered in here after dim sum and shopping in Chinatown. Three little tables and a counter full of amazing baked goods. We ordered several different things to share. My favorite was the coffee flavored cream cone. Very friendly counter staff. Cash only!
author: Susan F.

description:
There are only 3 people in the family who like egg tarts and we were originally going to purchase exactly 3 egg tarts.  After waiting in line though (45 min today), and seeing ALL the people coming out with multiple dozens, we quickly reassessed.  Once we got in the bakery, we loaded up and ordered: a dozen egg tarts, a few coconut tarts, a roll cake, a slice of chocolate roll cake, some egg custard cakes and an apple roll.

And though our original plan of 3 egg tarts for $4 ($1.35 each or $16 per dozen) turned into a $40 bakery fix, all concerns were melted away once we took our first taste of an egg tart.  I've had many an egg tart (from NY, Chicago, SF, LA, HK, etc.) and this ranks among the best. Ever.  Flaky, buttery crust with golden brown, crispy edges and jiggly, sweet but not too sweet, eggy filling (the consistency of panna cotta).  It is perfection.  Worth the wait in line and worth the price.

The other cakes we ordered are very good - light, fluffy consistency and beautifully made, but the star of the show is definitely the egg tart.  Go get one (or several dozen) now!
author: Sheila C.

description: Hubby and I noticed the long long long line at the bakery and were intrigued to check it out. Someone in line recommended the Egg Tarts. They were hot and fresh and super amazing. The crust is light and flakey and I he tart is not to sweet. Next time we are in Frisco it's a must.
author: Lydia S.

description:
What luck!! We decided to take a shot and walk 6 mins over while our friend held the spot in line at Mama's. It was OPEN! OMG! :D We walked right in. Ordered a dozen egg tarts, packed it in a big pink box, paid our CASH, and strolled right out merrily! Haha! What JOY!! :D

[[ Egg Tarts ]]-- Light, and crispy with a fluffy flaky crust. The filling is soft, warm, and egg-y with a slightly sweet aftertaste. BEST EGG TART EVER! 

Note: as we ordered, the last told us their closing in 2 weeks of August. So heads up for you food travelers! ;)
author: Linda D.

description: The egg tarts taste gross.  Overhyped.  Also a lady in a motorized wheelchair ran over us and cut in line.  I guess it was a cool experience.
author: Arun M.

description:
Review is strictly for the egg tarts here. 
My mother is the most picky, typical Asian lady around. Anything she tries, she says she can make better. And she does. 

She sends me out to San Francisco to this specific bakery to pick up dozens -yes, plural- of egg tarts when she's craving them or for family parties. She raves about them and I don't personally eat them but just based off of her squeal of excitement the when I get home with three dozen and the happy smile after each bite, I just know they are delectable. 

I do have to mention she's requested the addition of a few of the coconut pastries now. She must love those too. Give them a try!
author: Tammy T.

description:
I would give this place a 5 stars if I didn't have to wait 30 minutes in the long line. 

The Egg Tarts everyone is raving about is also a 4/5. I am not being a party pooper here but I have had better ones elsewhere. 

The staffs were super nice old Chinese ladies. They didn't rush us and they gave us plenty of time to order our yummies. So that was super awesome.

Try their Mochi with redbean filling. I saw them laying on a tray and I got one. I like them much better than the eggtarts!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Really good egg tarts, not too sweet, and really nice when right out of the oven.  There is always a line here, so get there early.  I always feel rushed when I get inside the bakery, which kind of sucks, but really good egg tarts makes it worth it.
author: Nina H.

description:
Best Egg Custard ever. Hands down.

This place will ALWAYS have a line. So be prepared to at least stand in line for half an hour. I have not tried any of the other bakery, so strictly, my review is on their egg custards!! :D
author: Leena N.

description:
Every single time I am in the city, this place is always closed for some random vacation but I finally get to buy some!

My friends and I took a chance of finding out if they were open and walked for about almost about a mile and almost closing time. As soon as we come approaching to the store, we see the line and hallelujah they were open!! :) 

We stood in line, which was not too bad. Heard lots of stories how sometimes the lines are crazy long. Closing time was approaching and as soon as it was our turn, found out that they are still making the egg tarts. We were so happy that we ended up buying 2 1/2 dozens :) 

As soon as we got our boxes, we couldn't wait to taste and eat them tarts! Center was moist and creamy, and crust is flaky and crispy. Well worth the walk and waiting in line!!!
author: Herbert R.

description:
Well, I had never had an egg tart so I didnt know what to expect. It was fun though, the whole line thing. Didnt wait too long, about 15-20 minutes. Everything in there looked amazing. We bought 6 tarts and got out of there, SO TINY!

They were really good. I loved the pastry itself, the filling, not my favorite flavor or texture, but that was just personal preference.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Terrific hole in the wall bakery for fresh and yummy egg tarts! We waited in a line that went out the door in the rain for these delicious desserts. It was quite amazing actually. We realized the reason for the hold up was that we were waiting for the next fresh batch of egg tarts to come out... and when they did, all the ladies behind the counter scurried to fill each box with amazingness. I have to say that you can't beat fresh egg tarts right out of the oven. The crust was really flaky and warm, and there was a good amount of custard in the middle. They really filled that little guy up. 

Definitely worth the visit... perhaps the best bakery in the bay!
author: Joyce H.

description:
My dearest GG,

Your dan tats are to die for. So much so, that I can look past the fact that I will always wait a minimum of 30 minutes in line, and that you are closed for vacation 3/4 of the times I try to go.

xo, much love.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Best darn egg tart this side of the Mississip!

**look in the window before you head in so you are ready to order when you step up.  Those ladies mean business, don't hold up the line.**
author: Kelly S.

description:
Happy 1000th review, Golden Gate Bakery!  You should give 1000 free egg tarts out to celebrate! ;)

Golden Gate Bakery is FAMOUS for their egg tarts because they're seriously the BEST.  Buy a dozen.  Just do it.  After waiting in a long line in the cold SF weather, you're going to want more than one deliciously flaky egg tart to satisfy your taste buds.
author: Francesca L.

description:
I guess Golden Gate Bakery doesn't really need my help in recommending them, but I have to say that their egg tarts are really good. You MUST eat them fresh to enjoy their flaky, eggy goodness. Otherwise, they get exponentially worse with every minute you wait to eat them. 

That said, a fresh GGB egg tart has a delicate, flaky crust. Each layer is really thin and provides a very enjoyable light crisp as your teeth sink into it. The custard is smooth with a semi-gelatinous jiggly texture, and its flavor is pleasantly eggy and sweet but not overtly buttery or rich.  I like that it's not too rich, buttery, or heavy as the crust's relative lightness compliments the sweet egg custard perfectly! These delectable treats are the only reasons you need to take a trip to Chinatown. Yes, reasons, because you won't just eat one.

I also want to add that I only find these lighter, sweeter egg tarts around here. Whenever I've been to Hong Kong or Macau, they tend to be richer and heavier but still very delicious. If you want to try an egg tart that resembles that kind of style, order the Portuguese Tarts (Po Tat) from Koi Palace. They have a thicker, richer crust while the egg custard is more buttery and heavier. They're much more decadent if that's your thing. I can't get enough of either!
author: Nei N.

description:
Be ready to brave a 45 minute wait.  If you can get past that, it's $16.50 for a dozen egg tarts (cash only).   I thought the egg tarts would be more custardy, but it tasted more eggy fresh out of the oven.  I enjoyed it more the day after.  

The cute little ladies behind the counter have worked here for 30 years.  When we asked them if they're all friends or family, one of them laughed and said, "We are all children of God."  They seemed to be having a good time.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Oh boy. I've had many egg tarts and make my own, but the ones at Golden Gate Bakery are phenomenal. 

The egg tarts are not shown in the display case because they're inside busy packing it straight from the ovens into boxes. Do not let the other items on the display case lead you astray as it did for me.  Get only the egg tarts and order more than you think you'll want because you'll want another one.

These yellow delights are delivered to you warm in the box. The custard is milky, smooth, and (just right!) sweet. The crust, however, is a bit flimsy.  Other reviewers say that the crust is flaky, but as an avid pie baker, I would disagree. Though not flaky, this egg tart crust has layers, has a crunch, and is very delicious even the day after when it isn't warm.

For the best results the day after, I recommend keeping it in the fridge and eating it cold.  Putting it in the microwave (no matter how short), makes the crust soggy. Again, do not get the other pastries. I had the pineapple cake, char siu bao, and cream buns, and they were all not very good. Stick to the egg tarts.
author: Ze Lin X.

description:
All of Golden Gate Bakery's reviewers rave about the egg tarts. Seriously, who wouldn't? They're so fresh and delicious here! Very crispy, flaky crust and smooth, melt in your mouth custard. The best ones I've had!

Besides their egg tarts, I also really enjoy their "fot gaw bao". I don't know the English translation. They're only made on the weekends, and they're baseball-sized buns that kind of look like a butt. They're moist and have a thin layer of sweet topping. (Shown on very left: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=CjJeD3TQ78Fb4eZz8lcydg) I definitely recommend them if you think Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts are over-hyped.
author: Priscilla W.

description: This place is has the best custards and there's no need to say more. No need for any more praise of the custards.  Not like they care since they are selling like "hot cakes" but this place can easily improve efficiency.  I can't get enough and either can all of you!  The lines are getting out of hand like we're in Disneyland!
author: Keith W.

description:
Best egg tart I've ever had: soft, flaky crust with a sweet, warm, & custardy filling...makes your tummy happy!!!

Perhaps the best baked bao (monapua) I've had, too: the bun is golden brown with a shiny glaze.  Inside is the best with QUALITY cubes of pork (not tons of fat like most others) in a nice chinese bbq sauce.  I can see the sauce being a little too sweet for some, but I found it delicious!

Add to that their fantastic coconut macaroons, coconut pies, and moon cakes (best eaten around the time of Moon Festival), and I can totally understand why people make a point of coming here if they're anywhere remotely close to SF/Chinatown.

If you come to SF without visiting GGB, you're doing yourself a disservice!!!  Come, get in line, get an eggtart and bao, and thank me later :-)
author: Bryan I.

description:
Finally, I got to try this place. The last time I was in SF, this store was closed, so I never got to try their infamous egg tarts. This time I went with a friend to Chinatown just to try their egg tarts. At 3pm on a Saturday afternoon, the line was just 30 min long, so the wait time wasn't that bad.  We got 2 egg custard tarts, 1 coconut tart and 1 gooey dough for just $5.30. Really reasonable price!

The egg tart was actually quite good. It was not as sweet as the egg custard tarts from other places. This one tasted felt a little more savory than dessert like than egg tarts that I had elsewhere and seemed to be more filling (e.g. more custard portion). The shell was flaky, which made it more delicious in my mind. Their coconut tart and the gooey dough (I don't know what the name was..but it's a circular-shaped white dough) were good but nothing much to rave about. Overall, the egg tart was good and better than those I had elsewhere, but being someone who doesn't and never really cares much for egg tart, I probably wouldn't want to get in such a long wait line here again unless my friend wants to try some of these tarts.

Note: no pictures allowed inside the store. My friend didn't see their handwritten sign and got yelled at big time by the lady there for taking pictures inside the store.
author: Joop V.

description:
YUMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM.

Okay, so I've ALWAYS loved egg tarts but I have never had egg tarts like this before! They're the best and unfortunately raised my expectations for egg tarts...There's always a line when I come but it's not too long of a wait, they move rather quickly and the batches of egg tarts come out fast! The egg tart just has the best texture. It's smooth and light. The crust is just flakey enough and the texture is awesome. The perfect balance. Mmmmmmm. I'm craving some now, writing this review. Haha.

The only bad thing about this place is that they randomly close sometimes, but luckily they've always been open when I went! :) That's how good they are though! They can open and close whenever they please because people will always be coming and checking. Oh, I guess the price is rather high too. Almost $17 for 12 egg tarts. :\ Pretty pricey, but worth it if you only go every so often!
author: Ivy L.

description: The best egg tart I have ever had. Expect a long line when this place open. I minus a star in the rating because this place closes for a long period of time whether it's for a holiday or just because it's summer. The chance of this place opening when you come to SF is 50%. You can always call ahead to see whether they'll be open.
author: Carissa M.

description:
If you're looking for the best egg tarts made, you ought to try this place! Golden Gate Bakery by far sells the BEST egg tarts!  I've tried egg tarts from Seattle, Portland, Sacramento down to Los Angeles -- none comparable to this mom & pop bakery located in the heart of Chinatown, San Francisco. The crust is soft & flaky with an egg custard filling that is not too sweet -- exactly how a perfect egg tart should be made! 

As soon as I walk into the bakery, I immediately gain 5 pounds just from the aroma of fresh egg tarts baking! :) It's not a surprise to see a line tailing out the door; so do expect to wait in line. I would say it is a bit pricey than most other bakeries, but definitely worth it. If you're venturing in the area, I would highly recommend you stop by for an irresistible treat!
author: Mei W.

description:
This is a must-go whenever I happen to be in the neighborhood. The Dan Tat has perfectly flaky crust, the egg custard is light-tasting and not too sweet. Prices just went up AGAIN to $1.35 - BOO!

But the tummy wants what the tummy wants. Even my grandmother told me to take my Canadian cousin to Golden Gate when she came into town. Her exact words (in Chinese) were "So expensive, but really the best. Go." And my grandmother is never wrong.


I always go at random times - sometimes there's a line, sometimes there's not. Of course it's busier on weekends, but props to the ladies who just toot and boot all the customers out there. My mom said they close for one whole month out of the year for vacation because it just gets too cray cray to handle 365 days out of the year!
author: Bonnie S.

description:
I had heard about the famous egg custard tarts here and after confirming on yelp, I just had to try it. I waited in line for about 7 minutes at noon on a Friday, building up the anticipation of this wonderful tart while staring in through the window at the various pastries and options. 

Once inside I decided to order two tarts and a custard cream puff to share. The tarts came out completely fresh and warm from the oven so I was very excited...until I tried it. I think the tart just wasn't for me. The custard had a heavy egg taste, too heavy for me, and was just a jello like texture in a small flaky shell. I didn't even think it was worth finishing so I had my boyfriend polish it off. 

I had more hope for the custard filled cream puff but that also lacked flavor or at least good flavor. Again, I think this dessert just wasn't for me.
author: Roxanne G.

description: The queue was very long. I probably was not hungry enough to rate it higher. The egg tart was warm and delicious, but slightly too sweet. Other than that, it was fine.
author: Zoey A.

description: I had been dying to try this place for a while now and every time we've gone by, they have been on vacation. I finally got to try it today and i have to say, this was THE best egg tart I've ever had. The line was long, but we made our way into the bakery pretty quickly. I who's recommend this place to everyone!
author: Amanda N.

description: If you want delicious egg tarts, this is the place to go! I guess you just have to be lucky with the line, because I came during the off hours and still ended up waiting 30+ minutes for egg tarts. They were still hot, presumably right out of the oven. The egg tarts are SOO GOOD and totally worth the wait. The outside crust is flaky, with just the right amount of crust. The inside custard has a smooth and soft, with just the right amount of sweetness. I was also surprised at how big these egg tarts are, bigger than the ones you find in the usual bakery. It was totally worth the hype and I hope to drop by Chinatown sometime soon to try their egg tarts again!
author: Jason C.

description: Egg tarts are always good but they are getting more expensive now. $1.95 each! I waited for about 20 mins on a Sunday afternoon at around 5pm. Most of their other goodies are gone but you can still get the egg tarts at around this time. They closed at 8pm on Sunday.
author: I C.

description:
They're finally open!!! Being from out of state, the last 2x I've visited this bakery, they were closed for vacation. Guess they're doing that well they can take vacation days randomly! 

Although lines are long, it goes by pretty swiftly. I usually get the egg tarts and sesame balls. The egg tarts when warm and fresh are absolutely delicious but after editing a few back to back, you start feeling sick. Haha so beware of eating too many.
author: Jeena L.

description:
This is the king of egg custards.

It is literally a hole in the wall.  There will be a line from the time it opens the door until when it runs out of things about mid-afternoon.  There is a counter, two or three people filling orders, and that's pretty much it.  As you wait, you see people walking out with amazing number of boxes, all filled with their egg custards.  Tourists wonder what's going on and walk away shaking heads at these crazy Chinese.  Friend receiving a box will recognize the box, strangely cut open at two corners for venting, and exclaim in delight.

Is it worth your while getting one of these?  That depends on the value of small delights in your life.  It probably wouldn't end up on anyone's bucket list, but will sure bring smiles to you and someone close to you.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: When in Chinatown San Francisco, must grab some egg tarts from this little bakery. Delicious pastry! Remember to bring cash.
author: Hillary T.

description:
EGG TARTS are all you need to get.  It's worth the line!!!  Moves really fast anyways.

And no matter how full you are, if you get the dan tat HOT, you must try it outside on the street while there's still steam coming from the egg pudding!!  SOOO good.
author: Cal C.

description: Either you love this place or you're meh about it. I'm the latter. If you've ever been to Lord Stow's Bakery & Café at The Venetian in Macao, you will know that those are the best egg tarts in the world. Golden Gate Bakery is good, but not worth the wait.
author: Austin W.

description: I would come here just for the egg tart because of the way the make it.  The custard to crust ratio is perfect in my opinion since I love having more custard.  I waited in line for a good half an hour and the line never died down during that time.  In my opinion the egg tarts taste the best when they are still warm out of the oven, but they are still good when you bring like 2 dozen home to share with everyone.  I've also had their other pastries such as the BBQ pork buns, curry pastry, sesame ball, and pineapple bun.  They were also very delicious, but the egg tart is definitely the main attraction here.
author: Richard L.

description:
Came only for the egg tarts.  Found the filling to be very eggy and much too runny.  Crust was okay- pretty flaky.  I seriously had the best ever Portugese style egg tart in Macau so I'm definitely biased.
Good for a snack or breakfast stop!
author: Alexandra C.

description: They open when they want but the tarts are good. Five stars for the baked goods but the service is lacking because it just doesn't matter so don't expect to be treated like a human being. Just have your cash ready.
author: Emmeline L.

description: It's a miracle, they're open. We have stopped by three times over the past year and they were closed.  Traveling from Ohio this place is always a treat. The price has gone up to $1.95 for one egg tart and there isn't a price break if you purchase a dozen.  We waited for about 30 minutes but it was well worth the wait. If you're going to splurge might as well be yummy egg tarts.
author: Peggy T.

description:
Just get the dan tat (egg tarts) from Golden Gate Bakery and you will be GOLDEN. They are delicious - flaky, fluffy deliciousness. Double the price compared to other bakeries I saw in Chinatown ($1.35 each) but totally worth it.

We went on an off time on Monday and there was no line! Score. We tried a few other treats (pineapple bun and some other stuff) but just stick with the egg tarts and you'll be one happy human being.
author: Jonny M.

description:
Food-gasm at first bite. 

It's hot out of the oven!
It's buttery flaky crust, ever so slightly crumbles against your mouth as you bite into it!
It's warm creamy eggy sweet tart filling creates endorphin's you never knew existed.

Oh yes!  Oh yes!  Oh yes! 

One is all you'll need to be satisfied.  

NOTES: They close down shop whenever the heck they want to.  Be prepared to be disappointed if there's a hand written sign on the door that says, 'vacation' with no return date.  Lines are long, if there's only 5 people waiting outside, jump in QUICK, that's considered empty.  Every tart is hot out of the oven fresh.  $1.35 each

TRUE STORY - a tourist offered a guy that walked out with a box of tarts and offered $5 for 1 egg tart.  Be prepared to make a fortune for passer-bys that don't want to endure the wait...
author: Jenny T.

description:
So I walked in with my camera and took a few pictures before noticing the no pictures sign.. But they were nice about it because they didn't say anything.

My aunt and cousins comes here all the time. I remember my cousins telling me when they were growin up, they would have egg tarts for breakfast before school everyday and now I am able to finally try them!

The egg tarts were very fresh, HOT and yummy! We bought a whole box and came back a few days later to get another before having to go home.

I also tried the BBQ pork pastry was pretty good but I felt the outside was too dry.

My aunt still comes here all the time and I will be back when I'm back in San Fran!

There is also a gift shop to the right (if you're facing the store) that has really cute everything!

---
[Grabbing this idea from my friend!]
Recommend: Egg tart
author: Jo L.

description:
Finally they are open cause every time I come by this place, they are always on vacation. Got here at the perfect time! I just waited about 5 mins until the new and hot batch of steaming egg tarts goodness to come out of the oven. There wasn't a line when I was there around 6pm. 

As I waited and waited for those little pies.....behold -- out they come from the oven that is piping steamy hot with the eggy custard and flaky crust. It was a pretty good size for their price ($1.65/each) considering they weren't stingy with the filling like other places that's all crust and hardly any filling let alone the size of them. But I am so glad I had bought a dozen to share with the family--that's if there is any leftovers. ;)

Although the egg tarts are on the pricey side, it is well worth it and now I understand why there is always a long line. If you haven't try what is egg tarts or what it taste like, this is def the place to try it out!!!
author: Cindy L.

description: I was walking down the street of Chinatown when I notice a huge line across the street, of course I had to check it out. I found out the line was to a bakery, so I thought this place must have many great treats to have a line this long. As I stood in line an old Chinese lady told me that this bakery is famous for egg tarts and it was they only thing they were selling today. This huge line for just egg tarts??? When I finally got to the front of the line I found out why. The owner hands me an egg tart fresh out of the oven. That first bite was magical!!! The crust was so perfectly flaky and the egg flavor was just right. This place has ruined me, I can never eat an egg tart and not compare it to this bakery. I would gladly wait in this line again and again!!!
author: Liem N.

description:
Been coming here for years and the only time it's ever disappointed is when it's not open. 

There's usually a line outside of this place, and they take random unannounced lengthy vacations, but even then it's still worth it to stop by this place. No other asian bakery comes close to this place!

If you don't live in the city (I don't - but thankfully work within walking distance ;-)), then you should definitely buy a box or two of any of their pastries because you won't be able to stop eating after you try just one. The pork buns and eggtarts (see picture!) are incredibly fresh, and consistently amazing. The egg tarts are flaky, soft, warm, and they're not too sweet or too bland. The pork buns are the perfect texture and have the perfect balance between bread and meat. There's no giant air pocket and dry meat, which I've experienced multiple times at other bakeries.

Parking's crazy but it's worth it.
author: Cassie C.

description:
Best egg tarts in town! Fluffy custard and crispy crust. They still taste good the next day!

Always a long wait, so by the time it's finally your turn, make sure you know what you want to order! The staff is rude and don't have time to tend to your many questions. But they don't care.... they know you'll be back for more!

Beware of their unannounced vacations, this seems to be a frequent problem. Their sign doesn't ever mention when they left and when they'll be back. Sit tight, folks.
author: Sidney T.

description:
I've got mixed feelings about this place. GG Bakery has been a staple of SF Chinatown for YEARS. I remember having the delicious egg tarts from here when I was a kid. Now that I'm older and have slightly more developed taste buds, the magical idea of amazing GG Bakery egg tarts disappeared. 

After trying their egg tarts again, I'm kinda stumped. The egg is very smooth and tender as I expected it to be but it was weirdly sweet. It had a bizarre sweetness to it, as if it was sweetened with Splenda or Stevia. The crust was okay, I expected it to be more layered and flaky. It was still good.

We overheard some stranger saying that their mochis were amazing. So we bought a few. They were pretty disgusting. The ratio of of filling to rice flour were way off. I felt like I was eating solid rice cake with a dash of filling. It also had an artificial banana flavor aftertaste to it. Bizarre. They were rather pricey too.

I think GG Bakery is rather overhyped but I understand the craze. It definitely still can't compare to the amazing egg tarts you can get in Hong Kong and China.
author: Vinky I.

description: These are the best egg tarts in the City. The crust is flakey and the custard delicious!  Worth waiting in line for. The moon cakes said to be excellent also.
author: dennis a.

description:
2nd best egg tart in SF (and possibly in the U.S that I've had) - after Yank Sing. There I said it. But they are half as expensive, 30% larger, and strangely, taste better at room temperature and day old than when fresh. 

Really really wanted to hate it because this place is NEVER open - you need to check this web site to see if it is open: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ - seriously, how ridiculous is that when there needs to be a web site to tell you if a bakery is open or not. I walked 2 miles to get here 3 times on a weekend and checked the web site every 2 weeks for 6 months and it was closed every single time.

Genius though to make it so unavailable - that's why people wait in line for 20+ minutes and go into hoarder mode, buying up whole trays of these bad boys, because you just don't know when the next time you can get your hands on them will be.
author: Snuffles B.

description: I love their egg tarts. Why didn't I give 5 stars you ask? Every time I recommend my friends to this bakery, they were always closed. Wish they had a better system of informing their customers when they are closed. The egg tarts here are great. The crust is flaky but doesn't have the butter or oily taste when it comes to good crusts. The filling is gooey and just the perfect amount of sweetness. I would definitely return when I'm in SF
author: Man Chi N.

description: This place never updates when the are on vacation!!! So disappointing after driving a long ways for nothing
author: Rebecca F.

description:
A few times when my husband and I visited, they were always on vacation.  This time we were lucky they are open!

Their stuff get snatched up quick so go early.  My parents ordered about 3 dozens and they had to wait 2 hours for them to fulfill the order.  Thank god we were staying in Chinatown and we were able to walk back to get our order.

Their eggtarts and lo-poh-peng (wife cake) are the best!  They are pretty pricey but very tasty!
author: Abbe W.

description:
Shut up about the egg tarts. Seriously. They're not that good. They're too sweet, the custard is too heavy for the shell, and it could use a deeper custard flavor. Needs more egg yolks to compensate for the sugar content. 

Since the turnover rate is way too high they're not brought to their full potential with at least 10-20 minutes of setting. Your box of delicate egg tarts will woefully be misshapen as you drive off into chinatown traffic where people don't realize that little street has two lanes. 

The crust is nice and flaky though and I will still eat half a dozen of these in a sitting if no one's looking. 

Please don't rate an entire bakery based on a single item. Please stop posting pictures of the same egg tart over and over again. We know how it looks like. 

Please try the other goods here. It is so good. And they actually have weekend specials! The best being the fat gok bao (French bun), a light fluffy bun in a cupcake wrapper topped with lightly sweetened crust. 

If you're from LA, you'll be accustomed to eating Taiwanese style treats. Believe me, the bread down there is nothing compared to the bread at GGB. 

They are FINALLY open with their full bakery today. I am going to get enough goodies to eat for days. I have been preparing myself for this day for months. This is what I'm going to order:

- pineapple bun
- banana mochi roll
- lemon cake roll (try a slice if you're wary of not finishing it. the vanilla is also rly good)
- cocktail bun
- vanilla cream bun
- baked bbq pork bun
- bbq pork tart..thing (these things are seriously well made. best flaky crust but filling could use some work just like the egg tarts)
- chicken curry pie (now that I'm older, I prefer a deeper curry taste though)
- coconut macaroons (not french macarons. all leftover egg whites from dan tats in these)

I might order more depending on how I feel. 

I so long for the days when I strolled in here after Chinese school to get a couple of buns to snack on. Now I have to load up on a couple boxes because some doofus that's never had an egg tart in their life ever overhyped them. You are a jerk. You are a big fat jerk. Jerk, jerk, jerk. 

/cry
author: Margaret S.

description:
Ever since I heard that Golden Gate Bakery has THE best egg tarts in SF, I've been dying to go here!

Cue a few weeks later.. Autumn Moon Festival in SF Chinatown? I guess it's fate! (;

Me and a group of friends waited around 40 minutes in line (ridiculous, right?) but let me tell you, it was COMPLETELY worth it! The egg tart was incredibly warm and although not as sweet as a Portuguese egg tart, it had a really nice lightness and creamy texture. We ended up buying 6 egg tarts for ~$1.35 each and got a cute little box to go with it!

I'm definitely planning on coming back sometime, but something to keep in mind- clear up a HEFTY amount of time if you want to drop by! You'll be waiting for a while!
author: Lucy C.

description:
Been coming here for many years - never once have I seen this place without a line. Okay, maybe once.. but that was because they were closed for vacation / holidays (rarely happens). There is a good reason for that - this is probably the best egg tart you're going to have, counting Asia. They are the best fresh so my recommendation is to eat right after you get it while they are still hot. They have other stuff as well (wife cakes, lotus seed buns, etc) but those are definitely less amazing than the egg tarts.

PSA: This place is cash only. Make sure you have some!
author: Gary Y.

description:
So glad the place is open after almost 3 months vacation period! The long line is there as always.
The egg tart crust got thinner and more flaky than ever before, also it's not as sweet as before which is a good news for those who couldn't eat too much sugar.
author: Peter S.

description:
If there was ever a legendary Chinese bakery, Golden Gate Bakery has got to be it.  Known the world around for their amazing egg custard tarts, my visiting friend and I had to drop in for some of the tasty treats.  Parking is a nightmare in the area and after a solid 45 minutes of searching I managed to finally nab one.

The line outside the bakery was modest since it was only the early afternoon and the smells of fresh pastries wafted into the streets.  I decided to share the love with my entire family and ordered a full dozen of the egg custard tarts to take home, along with some of the sweet rice cakes.  There was nowhere to enjoy their fresh, piping hot goodness in the rain so we ducked into Ten Ren Tea and found a dry quiet spot in back.  Ok, I usually try not to buy the hype but these tarts were unbelievable and just as good as the legend tells.  The custard was so creamy and had perfect texture and flavor that paired with the flaky puff pastry so well.  Unquestionably, there's nowhere in San Francisco that serves up better stuff and at $1.15 each, they're a total bargain.  The rice cakes were super good as well and were mildly sweet and make a perfect treat for kids.
