The drive though a rainy Chinatown was totally worth it to cap off an otherwise not so good food day.  Even though we paid the premium for parking and in gas, I was glad to finally sample some of the good stuff.  This is an absolute must visit for anybody living in or visiting SF!

Food: 10/10

Service: 9/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 8/10
author: Joe M.

description:
As you can see on my profile picture, I finally, FINALLY got to taste the world's best egg tart. Hubbs and I were walking around Chinatown killing time before we were meeting a friend for dinner. I have only heard amazing things about this place and was excited to get a pre-dinner treat. To our delight, there wasn't a large line out the door. And to our even greater delight, they did not run out of egg tarts for the day.

"What's so great about this egg tart?" I thought, and is probably your thought as well. "What makes it stand apart from all of the other egg tarts I've had?" It has an egg flavor that isn't too "eggy." It has more of a custard consistency that is perfect with the perfectly toasted crust. And even though it's very rich, the small size is the perfect amount to satiate your egg tart craving.

I'm not going to go out of my way to get another egg tart (I'd personally rather have a croissant than an egg tart, anyway), but I'm so glad I am able to check that off of my food bucket list! Check it out!
author: Becky K.

description: They are always "closed for vacation." Second time that this has happened. Make sure you call ahead to check if they're opened before coming here.
author: JK C.

description:
So yeah, I've been coming here since I was a little one.  Sure, that's a few decades ago, but who's counting.  Believe it or not, even before it was on 7X7's list, this was always known as the go to place for dan tat (yeah, i went there with my not so native tongue).  Still as creamy as I remember.

By the way, what lines?  Went in the mid afternoon on a Friday and there were like 5 people in front of me.  Darn it, maybe I shouldn't have said that.

Oh, and you don't need to eat it right then and there like some foodies behind me were saying.  Enjoy it there if you must, but I like to take some home to devour with a nice cup of cha (ha- see, I did it again.  I speak food.)

Dan tat = egg custard
Cha = tea

Enjoy!
author: Maria S.

description: I love egg tarts!  I've never had such as great an egg tart as this though.  It's perfectly flaky on the outside, warm and creamy in the inside.  The best part about it is the freashness.  I didn't taste that artificial egg flavor like some of the other egg tarts.  I took a box of 15 home to my family and everyone loved it.  The coconut macaroons were bomb and the sesame seed balls were good too!  Be prepared to wait in line!!
author: Dorothy L.

description: I waited more than 2 months for this bakery to open! There was little line when I passed by there accidentally. So I was expecting more because of the hype, and ordered one dozen, just in case it's REALLY good. I was kind of disappointed though. I've tried about 6 egg tarts from 6 different bakeries in the area, and the taste of the tarts from this bakery is not that far off. I was expecting their tarts to be fluffy and all, just like what's sold in Macau. Oh well, this ain't Macau. But the best out of the six, I must say.
author: Em A.

description: I've had egg tarts in Asia and everywhere in LA. Their egg tarts are one of the best I've had!! Top 3 for sure. The egg part is warm, moist and the right amount of sweetness. The crust is super flaky. We went at the right time when there was no one waiting at 4pm. So sad I couldn't come back to get seconds :(
author: Carmen W.

description:
It's a family tradition for us to visit GGB everytime we visit SF.  We usually get the same thing every time, the rice cakes--there are ones that have peanuts and one without--we get the ones with peanuts.  We love these.  We also discovered, a while back, that their Napoleon desserts are really good too.  My wife LOVES their version of Napoleon and says that she has never had one as good as GGB.  Go figure.
There's always a line for this place and that just goes to show that we're not the only ones in town that enjoy the sweets from this bakery.

Try the rice cakes.  They're really good.
author: Darien R.

description:
Best dan-tats (egg custard tarts) ever, hands down.  It was not only large, but it's got a great, smooth custard taste.  The outside crust was a perfect texture. It wasn't so hard that it tasted like eating coins, nor was it so soft that it fell apart after you take one bite.

They are priced to go in larger quantities ($1.35 each, $16.20 per dozen). Too bad we were only staying for two days, otherwise I would have taken a dozen home with me. 

It was so crowded, many of the tourists walking by saw the line, and decided to line up even though they didn't know what it was for.  They just knew that the food here MUST be good.

At the same time, the ladies working there were running up carts of food/supplies into the store.  So imagine a doorway that's already crowded with people hungry for custard tarts, and workers trying to push their way into the bakery. Simultaneously, there was an older guy who was trying to parallel park his car, his daughter (presumably) yelling at him in Cantonese because he couldn't get his car close enough to the side of the road.  Hilarious!
author: Steve L.

description:
Honestly, the egg tarts aren't that amazing. You can get similar quality and taste without the wait elsewhere. They're now $18/dozen, which is really expensive for what you get. If you come around Mid-Autumn festival time (now), the lines are ridiculously long. I waited 2 hours to get inside. 

My favorite pastry here is the raspberry napoleon. Now this is 5 star worthy. Sadly, I came during mooncake season and the napoleons weren't available. Womp womp.

What really kills this place though is the service. One of the ladies working there actually yelled at me! It went something like this:

Me: I heard you had macadamia nut mooncakes. Can I have a box of those?
Her: (while giving me a dirty look) You want macadamia nuts?! GO TO COSTCO!!!

Needless to say, I was shocked.

Anyway, come at your own risk. I wouldn't want to wait more than 10 minutes for this place.
author: Theresa C.

description:
Yes they are almost never open. I've tried to come 5 times and only two of those times they have been open and I was able to get egg tarts. I think the key is go early, both times that I have been successful in purchasing these golden delicious tarts was getting here around 8-9AM. 

The ladies working the counter at this tiny place are pretty friendly. The egg tarts come fresh out of this oven right behind the counter and they pack it for you right away and cut steam holes so the crust can stay crisp. Best thing is not to wait though, warm just out of the oven is the best and only way to eat it.

You see nearby bakeries selling egg tarts for $1 each while Golden Gate is $1.50 each, it's worth every extra penny. It's creamy egg tart is complimented with the crust that is flakey and not overly thick. And these are fairly large in size, think about 2-3 small dim sum sized ones equals one egg tart here. However, once you start eating one might not be enough.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I have heard so much about these egg tarts, and was excited to try them for myself! And THEY WERE OPEN TODAY! One of my good friends texted me this great news, and though I was hesitant to go at first (the Warriors were playing today!), she convinced me that this was a very rare occurrence and that I should go.

And boy am I glad that I did!

I went around 6:30 PM and there was virtually no line - After hearing tales of the long lines, I had to double check the restaurant name since I wasn't sure this was the right place. At first it seemed that they had run out of egg tarts (inner turmoil: NOOOOOOOO!!!), but when I got to the front of the line, I found out this was temporary as they brought out a whole tray of them, fresh out of the oven. I bought two and immediately ate one. YUMMMM! It was so delicious: buttery and flakey crust, sweet (but not overly so) and soft center, and it was straight out of the oven so it was at its nicest and fluffiest. I tried to savor the moment, but it was so good that I also just wanted to keep on eating. The heat of the filling slowed me down a bit.

The egg tarts were $1.65 a piece, and you can get a dozen for less than $20. Cash only!

My friend also got the lotus mooncake with 1 egg yolk (you can order mooncakes with 0 or 2 egg yolks as well) and we enjoyed that later this evening. It was a wonderful contrast between the light sweetness of the lotus combined with the saltiness of the egg yolk. Loved both of these pastries immensely.
author: Vickie W.

description: Terrible bao zi (steamed buns). Maybe an off day? It tasted like coffee... Typical Chinese people line hype. Herd mentality. Great for business.
author: Chinthrilla M.

description:
Now that I live so close to Golden Gate Bakery, I find myself walking over to check if they are open or not very often. Apparently, they are on vacation very often and don't put on any signs about when they come back, but I found out you can check whether they're open or not on twitter at @is_the_GGB_open, and YES they are back for now! I have also heard that they for sure don't go on vacation around mid-autumn moon festival, as too many customers pre-order moon cakes at least one month before the holiday, so definitely visit around then!

Now to get to their egg tarts, they are AMAZING. At $1.67 each, they are a little bit pricier than the other egg tarts you can find in Chinatown but these are absolutely the most delicious ones I've tried EVER, especially if they eat them once they come out the oven. They are seriously amazing, words can't describe it.

This place is cash only, like almost everywhere else in Chinatown, so no surprise there. As for the wait, Ive been here on weekends where the wait is pretty much always at least 30 minutes long. I've also randomly walked by on a weekday in the mornings and still had to wait around 5-10 minutes. I've never been here without any customers inside, this is how good they are.
author: Christina S.

description:
Large enough, just sweet enough and just flaky enough. Delicious, except if you like overly sweet stuff then this might not cut it. 

$1.35 a tart as of this review. Quite expensive, but worth it. If you're stuck on parking, just drop someone off to line up to order the egg tarts and wait on the one way street until the cops show up.
author: Kelly G.

description:
The egg tarts are hands down the best I've ever tasted! The crust is so FLAKY and the filling is a really nice consistency and not too thick. At $1.25 each, they're not the cheapest, but it is SO worth it for the taste!

Also, they tend to go on vacation every couple months/weeks, so don't be too surprised if they're closed when you visit.
author: Audrey G.

description:
Stop #2 of my Dim Sum Bakery experiment after my doctor's appointment here in Chinatown.  My doctor told me that this is the other more "famous" bakery but warned me that they likely will be closed because they go on "vacation" often and that if they were open, there would be a big line.  But she told me that their egg custard tarts were worth the wait and to stop by on my way home.

So after an always interesting and convoluted walk to the store...I get there...closed!  On vacation as the sign says.  Sigh...Golden Gate Bakery must be the present day incarnation of the pop-up dim sum bakery!  They can open for a few days...get a ton of people for a few days and then close the business for two weeks!  I don't know any business that can stay profitable and operate in this fashion but life for them must be good for them to be able to dictate their schedules like so.

As much as I love egg custard tarts and many other Chinese baked goods, I don't have the luxury of following up and tracking their schedule of opening/closing.  I most likely can find another bakery that can make an egg custard as good as Golden Gate before I ever will have a chance to come back here to try one of theirs.

One day Golden Gate Bakery...one day...
author: Ben H L.

description: This place was highly recommended to us from friends back home in LA as well as many other Yelp reviews, so we added this to our itinerary of our one day trip in SF. We honestly didn't know what to expect since we're from Monterey Park and we literally eat egg tarts all the time lol! Like was it possible for these egg tarts to be THAT GOOD?! We decided to give it a shot. First off, the wait here sucks. We literally waited in line for almost 2 hours.... JUST FOR EGG TARTS! Jesus Christ, I can't believe there were so many people waiting in line. We witnessed so many people leaving the lines and also some people who literally waited in line that long just to order ONE FREAKING EGG TART. WTF!!! I wanted to give up so badly, but I figured since we had already waited for a long time and since there were so many people waiting, there HAD to be a reason why it was worth the wait. Once we finally got to the front of the line to order, we ordered one dozen egg tarts, which is $23.95. I've never seen such expensive egg tarts but I mean, we had to give it a shot. The workers were super friendly and packed our egg tarts very quickly! The reason the wait is so long is because they are constantly baking fresh egg tarts + other pastries, and that's the main reason I'm rating this place a 4-star on Yelp. The egg tart itself was pretty good, but I'm not sure if it was worth an almost 2 hour wait. There was definitely a lot more egg in the custard than most places, so you are getting your money's worth in a way. The filling was the right amount of sweet and the crust was nice and flakey. I don't know if I could exactly say "it melts in your mouth", but it does taste pretty good when you eat it when it's fresh & warm! I'm glad we were able to try this place out, but I'm not sure if I'd be down to wait again just for egg tarts lol!
author: Kiana N.

description:
After over a year of failed attempts due to the owners being on vacation, having sold out, or ridiculously long lines (pro tip: come on a weeknight to avoid any line at all), I finally got to try the highly acclaimed dan tat at Golden Gate Bakery last week.

The verdict? I wasn't that impressed, after an entire year of hype. Now, to be fair, it depends on what you're looking for in a dan tat: their custard is of the lighter, more egg-flavored variety. In fact, it feels more like you're eating a ever-so-slightly sweetened egg wrapped in puff pastry than it does an actual dessert. So, given your preferences, this may appeal to you - personally, I'm still a bigger fan of the Portuguese egg tarts at Sheng Kee, which explode with flavor, and have a much flakier, buttery puff pastry base.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - I'm not sure what Yelp is going on about, because Golden Gate is perfectly accessible, just a bit small, and, of course, in a fairly hilly part of Chinatown. There are no steps or anything to worry about with the venue itself though.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, but I kind of doubt they had any customer ones, given the size of the bakery.
author: Johnny W.

description:
-0.5 star because they are closed and on vacation every time I have a serious craving.

-0.5 star because I think its over priced. 

The egg tarts (dahn thot) are the reason why you come here. Its like going to the house of prime rib for the fresh fish. I'm sure the fish is good, but you're there for one reason, and one reason only. Same here w/ the egg tarts. People claim there are crazy lines, and I'll be honest, I've spent over 70 minutes in line before. But the majority of the time, if I'm lucky, and the owners are not on vacation in LV or HK gambling away all the money that we spend there on the egg tarts, then I can get in and out of there in under 10 minutes!

You know those little "fresh doughnut" neon signs at KK, this place doesn't need that, because the egg tarts are coming out ALL DAY LONG. I don't know where they come from, probably upstairs, but it could be heaven for all I know. A little chinese grandma picks up the phone screams something in cantonese, and a couple minutes later, more trays of this holy goodness appears. 

Much like the doughnuts at KK, when you leave the store, and before you get home, you must eat at least one of these, while they are still hot. The egg part is amazing, its not too springy, its not overcooked, the texture is creamy and just right. The shell is just ridonkulous! Its a flakey golden basket with a single mission in life, to contain all the eggy awesome that you are about to devour!

The egg tarts are larger than you'll find in most places, and I fully intend to continue buying these my the multiple dozen, but the little chinese boy inside me just can not get over how much each of these things cost.

How much does it annoy me? Well, it is my mission in life to replicate these tarts and one day be able to vacation for 1/2 the year! I'm on recipe 1.4, and lets just say, I have A LONG ways to go!
author: Benny N.

description:
Five Stars
Order the Egg Tarts here and you're basically Golden (Get it? Sorry, my sense of humor is a bit crumby).

Four Stars
Each person in line equates to about a minute of waiting time. That's a lot of minutes.

Tips and Fun Facts
http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/ 
Best when fresh, but we bought a few for later consumption and they were still very good.
author: Linda X.

description:
Like everyone else says... egg tarts.

Spent 40 minutes in line and $40... no regrets. =)
author: Kristy F.

description: I donno how to rate this seriously. Egg tart definitely is perfect but seems like they don't care about their business. Just close without notice :(
author: Janet P.

description: People hate the long line and unpredictable business hours. But there is a reason that they  open for business as they please - what they sell is so good. We wait in line for about 30 minutes, which is not bad and the the line gets longer after us. To make the waiting worth, we had three egg tarts, three mini Niangao, and a big sesame ball. The service is very good. The lady behind the counter is very friendly and happy to help out with my selection. Come here for a local experience and gain boasting right.
author: Phil Y.

description:
You know that chocolate-obsessed fish in that particular episode of Spongebob? The one who screams out "CHOCOLATE!" in the most inane manner? 
(For those of you who require a visual aid: http://24.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_lqcpigTeQD1qg0ucbo1_500.gif)
Yeah, that guy.

So what's my point? If you replace "chocolates" with "Golden Gate Bakery's Egg Tarts," you'll have a rough-sketch of me. You'll find me rocking in a fetal position - jittery as I hold onto the last crumbs in the pink bakers' box, and calling it my "precious" - as I go through these egg-tart withdrawals. 

As soon as I took a bite out of the aromatic treats, I forgot about the hefty price tag ($16.20/dozen). Heck, I forgot that I paid at all! There's a reason for the ridiculous line that spills over the neighboring merchants' shops: they're addictive. You'll stand in the rain, shaking (whether in anticipation, or the notorious NorCal chill, you don't know anymore), and wave your money in the air, hoping - nay, BEGGING - for the workers to take your money!

Currently, there are no nicotine-equivalent patch for these treasured treats. The Surgeon General requires that these consumable goods label their products as "extremely addictive," and "may cause severe depression and other side-effects of withdrawal." Consume with caution.
author: William C.

description:
You will wait forever in line especially if you're here when they just open the doors...even if you're the 10th person in line...WHY?? b/c the first 9 ladies in line will buy up the whole store handing over their hundys.
Those ladies are serious business...most likely taking the goods into the city and selling it in their little cafe's for about $5 a pop! haha

So 30mins later + 2 fake ray bans from the shop next door, you'll be happily greeted with the store workers who speak good enough engrish to get you want you want and out!

These little suckers are good only the instant you buy them...a few hours later, they get soggy and no more flakiness.
It's $1.25 each and they charge tax, yikes! lol

The egg tarts at Good Mong Kok (express dim sum place about 2 blocks away) will last longer....even the next day refrigerated and microwaved for 15 sec.
Believe me...I know...and they're only about $0.90/each there.
author: Christine K.

description:
This place is always randomly "on vacation". So much so that there's a freakin' website decided to whether they are open or not at: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com

Also, the wait is always a hit or miss. It's either always going to be no wait at all, or a long ass line that'll keep you there for about 45 minutes. 

ALSO, they're constantly raising their prices. As of this review, a dozen egg tarts custards run $18 (it was $13 just a few years ago)

But all that being said, this is still, without a doubt, the best damn egg custards I've ever had. Since I work in Chinatown, I've been able to try almost 20-25 other egg custards from all the different bakeries and this is still the clear winner. 

Most def lives up to the hype. Just make sure you call before you go to make sure they're open.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I grew up in a chinese household and subsequently grew up eating egg tarts on a regular basis. Like, every week or so. Given my love for egg tarts, I had to see for myself the "best egg tarts" around. 

The verdict is that they taste like egg tarts from any good chinese bakery. Nothing special about them, unless you count overpriced ($1.50 each, usually egg tarts are around $.50 to $.75 each) as special. Nothing to line up up 20 minutes for, nothing to rave about. Any other place in chinatown makes egg tarts just as well.
author: Mina K.

description:
*Note* Golden Gate Bakery may not open during their advertised normal business hours.  Some days they open at 1PM, some days closed for vacation without prior warning.

Luckily I called ahead to verify their business hours. Bakery ended up opening at 1PM (normally 8AM).  Arrived at 1:15 to a line of 10+ people, however they were not letting anyone inside yet.  Also, they were ONLY selling their famous egg tarts today, nothing else. Luckily, we were here for their egg tarts.

Waited 45 minutes to get 3 dozen egg tarts. Would have been shorter if they didnt let a handful of their "VIP" (chinese-speaking elders) cut the line!  Overall, well worth the wait for the yummy egg tarts, but just didn't feel treated fairly as a customer.
author: Wilson T.

description:
I'm pretty much an egg custard tart enthusiast. Every time I go to any Chinese restaurant or bakery, I would always order the egg custard tart for desserts!

This place is currently closed for "vacation" but a few weeks ago when me and my family came here, we ordered coconut macaroons, 1 box of egg custard tarts, and one whole banana cake roll. The banana cake roll and coconut macaroons were awesome, but the EGG CUSTARD TARTS were the best I've had in my life. I finished maybe 8 of these custard tarts in one sitting because I go big on desserts. 

Everyone who thinks they have had the best EGG custard tarts and haven't gone here are wrong!

You got to go to this place! And if you don't like egg custard tarts, there are tons of other choices! Recommend this place highly!
author: Jacob B.

description:
I've tried to come to this place on numerous occasions, and they are always closed!!  but I already knew that since they have a permanent on vacation sign outside their door. Good thing there are so many places in Chinatown to satisfy the egg tart cravings.

Can't wait to get my hands on another delicious egg tart from them!
author: Katherine L.

description: best egg tart in the world.
author: Vivienne K.

description:
There is such a big hype for this bakery. Few of my friends came here few times in the past months and they were always on vacation. Luckily this bakery was open on our last day in San Fran. We got here around 11am and there was a short line forming. It's not a big bakery at all! The line went all the way out the door..and after we got in line the line snaked around holding up the entire sidewalk.

There is limited selection in this bakery. I wish they had more items to sell. We only ordered 8 egg tarts since people were raving about it. It actually taste pretty good - very similar to how Hong Kong Lounge makes theirs. It is creamy and my friend said the crust is really good. We wanted some wintermelon cake (wife cake) but there weren't any. When we asked them, they gave us an ambiguous answer " they dont have it yet"....what do you mean by that? Will it be here tomorrow? later today?

Anyway the egg tart is good, but they are short 2 more stars because they lack a lot of selection. 

The old ladies taking the orders were nice, though.
author: Susie C.

description: So worth the wait first time every trying egg tarts best experience ever  thanks to my wonderful boyfriend
author: Bilegmaa D.

description:
Just don't do it. It's sorta like crack, you know its bad for you but you keep coming back.

The egg tart is delicious, the crust is flaky, the filling is sweet but there is also a bad after taste. I confirmed with a few people, including my talking cat and best friend whom is a panda about the after taste because I thought I was going crazy, they confirmed that it existed. But yet I keep coming back.

I have been there where I have seen the owner yell at customers and tell them to get the "F" out but yet, I keep coming back.

I have seen the owner grab the box of egg tarts back and throw the money back at the customer because she was annoyed. I try not to make eye contact, but I still come back.

I have gotten the "wtf" look from the owner because all I wanted was a bbq pork bao and a curry chicken turnover and not an egg tart, but I still come back.

Be like Reba Wilson. "Well sometimes I have the feeling I can do crystal meth, but then I think, mmm... better not. "
author: Vay V.

description:
I was with some friends who wanted to stop by and pick up some egg tarts and sweets for dessert.  Telling myself that I had always wanted to visit this bakery, I decided to tag along.  Lo and behold, as I was walking up Grant Ave, I discovered the my uncle's old store was located directly across the street from this bakery and memories of spending many a Saturday morning munching on treats from this place came flooding back.  Whoa.  How could I have forgotten this gem?

I decided to try one of their famous egg tarts as well as their old wife cake.  Luckily for us, we were told that in a few minutes a fresh batch of the egg tarts would be coming out of the oven.  Talk about good timing!  The egg custard was light in color and texture, very creamy, and wasn't too sweet or too egg-y.  The crust was flaky and rich and oh so good!  Were they good?  Yes!  Where they the best I've ever had?  No, I'm sorry to say.  I've had some that were slightly better, but these are really good.  Are they worth waiting in line for?  Yes.

The old wife cake is pretty good.  The melon inside was just the right amount for the size of the cake.  The crust was light, tender and flaky.  Let's get real here....only lard can produce something this well made.  This was the lightest version of this pastry I've had in a long time.  Usually it's heavy, dense and the crust is a solid mass of dough.  This is definitely worth trying.

Aside from speaking English and Cantonese, one of the ladies working behind the counter also speaks Spanish fluently (she spent some time living in South America).  The ladies were friendly and quite helpful.  On our visit on a Friday night after an early dinner, the line was short.

Definitely one of the better bakeries in Chinatown and worth a stop if you happen to be in the area.
author: Melissa L.

description:
JUST PUT THESE EGG TARTS IN MY MOUTH.
First morning in SFO, what do I do? I go to the bank. The bank's across from here. I wait for about 10 minutes, and get me some egg tarts. OH GAWD, were they good.

I came back for the second weekend.

I might have to go back every weekend.

I don't care that they're expensive. They're such a nice treat and HOT OUTTA THE OVEN. SO GOOD.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Best Dan tats (egg custard tarts) ever! If you come here, please get the egg tarts. Don't try to get anything but the egg tart because that is what this place is known for. The wait can vary depending on which day you go. Expect a wait on weekends! I waited about 45 minutes just to get inside. Was it worth it? Hell yeah if you're not in a hurry! They serve them deliciously warm and fresh. A bite into the egg tart and my teeth sinks into the softest egg tart ever. It's perfection. Trust me! And don't line up for just one or two tarts. Get a dozen to take home!

$1.60 for 1 egg tart = $19.20 for 12
+ .10 cents a bag

Also, try not to stack the boxes on top of each other, as the tarts will smoosh.
author: Laura T.

description:
I had never been in a chinese bakery before and was overwhelmed with the options. I strictly went for the egg tarts, since those are what everyone talks about, and when I didn't immediately see them, I grabbed a beautiful moon cake instead. As I went to the register to pay for my almost $7 treat, I saw the yellow tarts! I ordered two and went on my way.

The boyfriend had no idea what I was giving him...he actually expected some lemony thing. Oops! So he took one bite and made the saddest, most disgusted face. He had no idea what he was eating but he did finish it.

Overall, I think these must be closer to real egg tarts as the ones I've had before were much more solid. These were very custardy and had good flavor, but I think we both were not in love with the texture. Again, not their fault but more our familiarity with what egg tarts should be. I would definitely go again and try some of the other items. The red bean moon cake was delicious!
author: April C.

description: While this place really does have the best mooncake in America, I would NOT advise coming here. If you have anxiety or if witnessing any sort of inefficiencies drive up your blood pressure YOUR TEMPLES WILL SELF-IMPLODE HERE, EITHER WHILE IN LINE OR THE SECOND YOU STEP FOOT IN THE 3 FOOT BY 3 FOOT CUSTOMER AREA THAT CALLS ITSELF  GOLDEN GATE BAKERY! I'm trying to live a stress-free life, which is why I will only jot down a FEW catastrophes I experienced. But rest assured if you come here yourself during pre-autumn festival time, you will encounter ten fold more. There are 5 old women doing 1-2 people's job SOOOOO SLOWLY AND SOOO POORLY I seriously think they signed a contract to work as inefficiently as possible as to purposely make the line longer to drive up business. The phone rang and 3 out of 5 women tried to answer it and in the end no one answered it. The entire time the phone rang every lady stopped what she was doing. This one woman was mid-boxing a mooncake and PUT IT BACK ON THE SHELF!!! WHAAT!?!?!? Only 2 customers were ever being served at a time, despite the fact that there are 5 women, none of whom are baking, and only ONE of whom is only half-heartedly manning the register. ALL FIVE barely spoke Mandarin or English. No computers. No automated register. CASH ONLY. Just try imagining anyone, much less an old woman, counting out coins (from not her native country) and I dare you not to get a migraine. I saw one woman split a customer's order into multiple receipts even though the customer didn't ask! WHAAT!?!?!? MILLIONS AND MILLIONS of boxes of UNCOVERED mooncakes--COMPLETELY UNLABELLED. Over a dozen different flavors with 4 options each, MEANING LOTS AND LOTS OF SPECIFIC ORDERS all getting confused. I literally only ordered 2 mooncakes and it took me 15 minutes to get out AFTER waiting 40 minutes to GET IN!!! AND I WAS IN LINE RATHER EARLY!!! The women would try to convince you buy what was in their hand instead of looking through the mountains of mooncakes for the one you ACTUALLY want. Come to think of it she probably TOLD me the wintermelon flavor was sold out when it was probably right behind her to whole time and she forced me to get almond flavored! THE THOUGHT OF IT MAKES MY BLOOD BOIL!!! YOU'RE NOT SPENDING $14 PER MOONCAKE HERE IF YOU FACTOR IN NEAR-FUTURE MEDICAL EXPENSES (OR INSURANCE, 'cause I might fly back to SF to hurt one of those ladies).
author: Lucy C.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is a must if you live, or are visiting San Francisco. Heck, it should be on some tourist destination for San Francisco's Chinatown. The line outside was very long, but I knew the wait would be worth it.

We finally were the first in line, and although the english of the staff is a bit broken, it honestly is nothing to complain about once you sink your teeth into the smooth Dan Tat (Egg Tart). I bought almost one of everything.

DAN TAT (Egg Tart) = They are always fresh, warm, and out of the oven. There is a crisp, buttery crust which is complemented by the custard, which is very smooth. It has a very milky taste, but yes, there is also a large eggy flavor. The egg tarts are huge, and you always have leftovers.

I also ordered a few of their other pastries, which were all good, EXCEPT for the moon cake. The idea of the preserved egg yolk inside the pastry grosses me out completely. I took a bite, to taste a disgusting, hard egg, which was BRIGHT YELLOW. It was disgusting.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description: There is always a line at this place! Since I've never tried the egg tart here, we decided to wait in line. The line wasn't too bad - probably like a 10-15 minute wait. When we ordered our dozen egg tarts, it was still fresh and hot in the box. I took my first bite and was pleasantly surprised that I've never had egg tart that tasted like this. The consistency was more eggy, but still very good. It's quite greasy though. It was really good and at $1.50 each, I would come back. The ladies working in the bakery really don't like customers touching the glass. I heard them say it about 2-3 times while I was in the shop. I guess customers like to point and touch when they're ordering and it bugs the heck out of the workers lol. The ladies are very nice and quite funny as well, the one helping us especially. I'll definitely make the trip out again if I'm in Chinatown!
author: Jody C.

description:
The best egg tart I've had yet. Delicious. So flakey on the outside, yet so perfectly creamy on the inside. 

Cash only!

Try it if you're in the area. My old workplace was just a few blocks away and made it very accessible. 

Problem: They are often closed and it is extremely unpredictable to know what days they are open! It's horrible when you're heading out there, just anticipating the delectable egg tart.... To find out they're out on vacation!!!

But do not fear, somebody has already made a website for this. 
http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/
author: Lauren L.

description: Says they close at 8 but it was closed by 7 when we went? And we saw people waiting outside and were wondering why so we decided to wait and see. Turns out they sell only egg tarts after they close! We ordered a dozen and the people behind us in line spoke fluent Chinese to the ladies working there and they gave the egg tarts to them first... Okay, whatever. I would've been more mad if we had to wait a long time but I'll let it go this time. A dozen egg tarts is $18. Freshly made and I'm not a very big fan of egg tarts but these were good and very fresh! I heard they close at random times so Id call ahead to see what time they close. But then again they might tell you a certain time and close earlier than what they say.
author: Hannah C.

description:
The egg tarts and moon cakes are to die for!  These ladies know flavor - just the right amount of sweet and savory.  The freshly-baked egg tarts come right out of the oven (and into my mouth - ha!).  

Like any Asian bakery, these ladies mean business and their fast-talkin' bluntness can be overwhelming.  But I think that's just part of the charm.  

This place is cash only, but there's an ATM right cross the street if you need it.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Been here twice during the past two months and they were "CLOSED for Vacation"
with no updates on when they will re-open...arrghhh...
author: Mimi T.

description:
2 words: EGG CUSTARD.

I was surprise there wasn't that long of a wait and we went on a saturday afternoon. But we got 2 and ate one right in front of the store. I couldn't wait. It was very yummy! Never tried anything like it!
author: April B.

description:
EGG CUSTARDS heaven!!!  Whenever  I'm in SF Chinatown, this place is a must stop.  I don't care how long it will take for me to find a parking space or how long the wait is, I'm there.  I usually get a dozen of them to go but will end up eating 2-3 before I even drive off for they are so delicious especially hot off the oven.  

They have other goodies like sticky rice cake, coconut macaroon, cream rolls etc...  But I only want them flaky, semi-sweet, melt in your mouth egg custards.  Simply the best!!!
author: Anni N.

description:
Finally we got ourselves San Francisco reputable egg tarts. I came here three years ago during my spring break but they closed. I returned this time expecting crazy China Town parking and long line, surprisingly both didn't happen. In the heavy rain, there was no line, no wait, egg tarts here we come!!!

$15 for a box of a dozen of egg tarts. And we bought four of them! 

Make sure you do not close the box or else the Chinese women at the bakery will scream at you for not letting the air circulate.
author: Chau V.

description:
Best egg tarts (dan tat) period.  Don't bother ordering anything else on the menu.  After you try their egg tarts, that will be all you desire and crave.  Granted, they are pricier than average and the wait is generally 10x longer compared to other places in Chinatown, Sunset, and Richmond.

Completely worth it.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Egg tarts. Nom nom!

I should probably preface this by saying I lived in Hong Kong for 4 years, so I know my egg tarts! This was my 4th attempt over 2 years at Golden Gate Bakery because they were closed the previous 3x, and success! Only waited 15 minutes on a weekday evening.

+ Crispy but not too buttery/thick shell
+ Humongous eggy center, soooo deeeeliciouss 

It's hard to stop at 1. I gobbled down 2 before dinner :)
The eggy center is not as creamy as I prefer, but that just means it's healthier...
author: Joanne L.

description:
My wife and I were walking through Chinatown while on vacation, and noticed that this place had a line out the door.  She then looked up Golden Gate Bakery on Yelp, and noticed that it had thousands of wonderful reviews.  Noting the hype (and the long line), we decided to return to it.

We came at about 10:30 AM on a Tuesday, and there was no line at all.  I'd probably recommend this.

We walked in and bought 2 of the much raved-about egg tarts and 1 napoleon cake.  We then had one of the egg tarts and saved the other and the napoleon cake for later.

The egg tarts were very good, but didn't live anywhere near the hype by my fellow yelpers.  Perhaps I just don't get it--in my opinion the napoleon cake was actually better.  The egg tarts are kind of eggy for my taste.

Don't get me wrong--my experience with Golden Gate Bakery was a positive one, but I wouldn't go far out of my way to grab one of these egg tarts.  This provides a satisfying experience at a low price tag (which is extraordinarily unusual in California), but I wouldn't label the experience as "quintessential."

So, in summary, I'd give it 3.5 stars, but I think the rating of the business is a bit overstated, so I won't round down.  (Hey, C'est la Yelp.)  Check it out if you're in the area, but I'd argue it's not worth a detour.
author: Joe K.

description: Okay, be prepared to stand in line and don't expect to be coddled here. Have your order straight before you get to the front. But I will tell you...the egg tarts are worth the wait. Warm from the oven and creamy with flaky pastry. You may think "What's so great about an egg tart? I can get those at dim sum any day." I don't know, but it's just not the same. Just go...go get some.
author: Angelique N.

description: The egg tarts are the best i've ever had! Went to get some on a evening right before closing (9 p.m.) and they were still lining up and fresh egg tarts were still coming out the oven!
author: Jason I.

description: You know about the egg tarts here so there's no need to explain, but timing is everything.  It was a Sunday, so I called ahead for the egg tarts and they said to come soon because they was no line.  We moved brunch around to be in the area to drop by after our meal.  When we got there it was a 2 minute line, so we ordered 2 dozen to take home to our family in SoCal.  Know what you want when by the time you get to order; these establishments are quick and expect you to have decided by the time you're up.  That's how they get people in and out as fast as they do.  This seems to be the case at most Asian places.
author: Evan L.

description:
1.5 hour wait!!!  I'm very rarely in Chinatown, but I just happen to be there two days in a row for a Chinese dress alteration.  So, what the heck, my mom and I waited in line for the dan tat and two moon cakes the 2nd day.

In their defense, people in line ahead of us ordered boxes upon boxes.  This one group must have walked out with 15 boxes, no joke!  If that didn't happen I'm sure the line would have moved on a bit faster.  

I was so hungry I ended up eating the dan tat on our way to the train.  It was AMAZING!  The crust was flaky and crispy and the custard was so soft and warm.  I seriously could have eaten a few more.  

Minus a star due to their lack of organization.  I think the line could have moved a lot faster.  You would think they would have some system down since they've been doing this for so long.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
The first thing I ever liked during weekend Dim Sum outings as a child was a plate of egg tarts fresh from the oven. The flakiness, the little sweetness in every bite, the simplicity and beauty of something that truly tasted as good as it looked. So when I learned about the Golden Gate Bakery in Chinatown where they specialize in my favorite treat, I knew I just had to have it.

Known to the Chinese as "Dan Tat," egg tarts are popular any time of the year and are made in all sizes. GGB's version is larger than what I'm used to and not exactly cheap ($1 each), but they sure are delicious. After a surprisingly good first time experience at room temperature in a to go box, it was time for me to go there for a real shot at it.

After a nearby meal while in Chinatown, I made my way over to the tiny little bakery where there was (of course) a line of C-town locals that formed right out the door. After asking a few in line what they were waiting for, the answer was an obvious one: Dan tat.

Around 15 minutes of wait time, I managed to order a few egg tarts fresh out of the oven, along with moon cake and a bbq pork bun. Was it worth the hype? Sure. While the bbq bun didn't wow me, the  slice of moon cake were melt in your mouth good, and the egg tarts were fantastic. On a 1-5 scale, these mega egg tarts are an easy 5 - sweet, gooey, and holds shape regardless of how badly its stuffed into a box.

I will be back. For awhile there, I wasn't so sure about the quality of Chinatown joints but I'm glad there is hope with little places like Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Jando S.

description:
Here's a guaranteed way to make sure these good egg tarts taste GREAT: Wait over an hour on the street on a rather cold, dark and damp day all the while hoping that they don't run out just before you get to the counter. Then you're there, you hit it right and they're just out of the oven! They have that extra something! 
Nelson Q. was lucky to have them delivered right to his table after a wedding feast. But I'll tell you, if you've earned them the hard way, the right way--they're even better!
author: Peter C.

description:
I have tried many different items from this place. My favorite are the custard egg tart, and the sesame fried balls. The tart is very light. If you like Chinese desserts you should come here any way, if you want to try start here :)

Food Quality - Excellent
Food Taste - Excellent
Food Originality - Excellent
Price - Excellent
Customer Service - Excellent
Ambiance - Hole in the wall, to go only
author: Vibhor C.

description:
First of all the only reason I ever come here is because my grandma. 
The last time I went here I arrived at 10 and asked for 2 dozen dan-tats they told me to come back in 2 hours. I came back 2 hours later and they said they didn't have any for me because I wasn't here and I didn't actually place an order so everyone else who arrived in the 2 hours I was gone got served before me. So I placed my order for 2 dozen again they told me to come back in 2 hours. And I came back at 2 and they lady looked at me like with eyes that said "oh holy crap i forgot about you" and she told me it would be another 20 minutes. AFTER ANOTHER 45 MINUTES I FINALLY GOT 2 DOZEN DAN-TAT. 

what made me the most upset is that I come here all the time to get Dan-tat for my grandma and I was APPALLED at the service I received I waited almost 5 hours for 2 dozen dan-tat. 

I feel bad cause my grandma keeps asking for more dan-tat but i can't bring myself to go back after such terrible horrible service.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Totally worth it!!!!! They come
Out fresh and hot!!!! The hype is real and the ladies r so cute!!
author: jocelyn n.

description:
Best egg tarts I've ever had. And I've had quite a few. Waited about half an hour for them and they did not disappoint. Best eaten fresh but was still pretty decent later that night. 
Well worth the wait!
author: Derwei C.

description:
Flaky, buttery, fragrant egg custard.. who would say no?!
This place makes THE best egg custards, if you're in Chinatown, definitely drop by!

However, they tend to have a line out the door. But trust me, it's worth the wait.
The egg tarts are best fresh out of the oven, be sure to have one right away if you can!

5 STARS
author: Karen L.

description: After 2 hours of falling in line to get their Chinese pastry and the infamous egg tart. It was very good and crisp egg tart. it was like heaven....Oh so good. Bring cash !
author: j d.

description: OMG, best Don Tat (egg tart) in SF!  I love coming here to get a dozen.  It's pricy but it's worth every bite!  The filling is very creamy and soooo sinfully delish.  The crust is so flaky and perfect.  There is always a line but trust me it's wroth the wait.
author: Jan S.

description:
The egg custard tarts from this bakery are the best in the US and rival many places in Macau, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and China.

Trying these right out the oven is the best way to experience this heavenly delight. The warm flaky buttery crust and the sweet rich egg custard make the anguish of enduring the long line disappear.

Beware though... As I am away at university and can only return during my breaks, the owners and their family are often on vacation. So double check to see if their open before you go!
author: Alex C.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery has gained a lot of tourist momentum - usually there is a massive line waiting outside to get an Egg Tart. I've tried it and it's good, don't get me wrong, but also the most expensive in Chinatown. I'd recommend trying other places as the quality is just as good (as long as they're hot!), but for much less in cost and without the long line.

TIP: they frequently take vacations so you may want to check if they're even open. They take trips for 2 weeks at a time.
author: Albert K.

description: Tried the egg tart and it wasn't good. The crust was ok but I could only taste the egg in the middle. So I paid $2 for a small cake that tastes like eggs. Very disappointed
author: Sydney X.

description:
NOW I TRULY UNDERSTAND THE BUZZ ABOUT THIS LITTLE SHOP IN CHINATOWN.

I visited my best friend in San Francisco last weekend and I made it a point to stop by  this highly reviewed and esteemed place.

First, though, we had to check if it was open on http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/
This website tells you whether the bakery is open on not. It's updated daily (probably by some shopowner nearby lol). This is important because the shop closes randomly and often. They do so well they can take a whole week off just because it's Memorial Day. SO DO THIS AND SAVE YOURSELF SOME TROUBLE.

The line wasn't too bad, and you could smell the aroma of egg tarts wafting out the door of the tiny bakery. It's pretty cheap, too. Just over $1 each, and a dozen for over $16. They're pretty big, so it's definitely worth every cent. The egg tart was perfectly crispy and flaky without being drenched in oil. The custard wasn't too heavy and it was perfectly eggy. It's the perfect egg tart. My egg tart standard will never be the same!

I didn't try anything else at that time, and I don't think I'll ever need to. Next time I go up north, I'm getting a dozen and bringing them back for my family! (If I don't eat them all on the way down myself :3)
author: Patricia L.

description:
EGG TART .. That is all I have to say! People really line up for this awesome flakey treat. I've had egg tarts at dim sum restuarants and they will never taste the same ever again. Those are duds compared to the one from Golden Gate Bakery. The line quickly picked up with people anxiously waiting for their tarts. The tart part was lightly sweet with the crust magically falling into your mouth. Best egg tart on the planet.

Recommendation: Egg Tart
author: Andy N.

description:
I finally visited Golden Gate Bakery and was surprised that there wasn't a long line, unlike other yelpers have mentioned. Granted it was about 11am, but I was pleasantly surprised to see what looked like "regulars" at the store ordering dozens of pastries in pink boxes and red plastic wrap bows. I pull out my phone to check in on Yelp, when all of a sudden all the old Chinese ladies give me a look that only my grandma would give me when I pull my phone out at church. Then I remembered, no photography allowed! We ordered a dozen dan tat or egg custard tarts and a moon cake with yolk. The total came out to be $20 something, which is odd because they advertise the dan tat to be $16.20.. so the moon cake was $5? They have batches coming out of the oven every 10 minutes or so, so you'll most likely get one warm!

Dan Tat - I don't really like egg custard tarts, but these were sooooo good! The crust is so sweet, flaky, and warm and the custard had the perfect jiggly consistency. I was in dan tat heaven! I put my dozen in the refrigerator and found them to be even more heavenly the next day!

4 stars for that dan tat!
author: Joyce E.

description:
* For Mr. Hole in the Wall Marc D *

SF is a melting pot of different nationalities, hence different languages.  It just follows that most of its residents are bilingual, but I thought it was pretty cool that the Chinese lady behind the counter was speaking fluent Spanish to the Latina in front of me.  Cuanto cuesta and tu quieres were rolling off her tongue so fast, it was impressive.

Then she switches to English when my turn came up.

I'm half-Chinese but don't speak the language.  But I think it's safe to say that San Franciscan is a tonal language too, like Cantonese.  One word can mean 2 things with a shift in tone.  When you're in SF, you only need to know one word: Dude.

Dude! as in WTF!  did I just stand in line for 30 minutes just to get baked goods?!?

Duuuuude. As in, I can't believe I waited so long before hitting up this spot. The danh tats (egg tarts) have slightly crispy edges, flaky pastry shell and soft set (but not runny!) egg-y goodness.  Definitely worth standing in line for. Skip the coconut tart, but get the sesame ball and taro moon cake. 

Dude. As in, seriously.  You don't know what you're missing by sitting there drooling all over your computer. Go Now!
author: Janice C.

description:
EeK,! Methinks not at $1.40 an egg tart. it goes up .20 to .30 cents every time they return from their months long vacation.

I remember when it used to be .85 cents...and now $1.40 because they were featured on Eye by the Bay.
author: J. C.

description: I love baked good and pastries, so I read about how great the egg tarts were, okay okay so it says it in its name.. EGG but I didn't expect it to be "that" eggy. (If that makes any sense) the crust was amazing and I ended up just eating the crust from the three I bought. They're 1.40 each and the bakery isn't too busy after 6. The roll cakes look pretty good,will have to try that next time!
author: Chanel H.

description:
These are my favorite egg tarts, but I'm getting a bit exasperated by the bakery owners' whimsical "leaves of vacation"... I only came by three times between August and November since I don't live nearby, but store owners were on vacation each time. I actually suspect they've been on a continued break the entire 3 months. Honestly, call before you come. If they're on vacation, at least you won't waste your time on a profitless visit!

I thought the last reviewer had interesting points. The first was, there are many great egg tarts  to try, so not eating egg tarts at GGB isn't life changing. One of the other egg tarts I've tried is from Sheng Kee. Maybe they have more than one type? Or maybe they are different at different Sheng Kee stores? Because the one I tried in Cupertino was very much in the same style as this one with the eggy middle and buttery, flakey crust. Sheng Kee actually makes really good egg tarts by the way. Good amount of sweet and the crust is well-baked/not too thick/thin. I also tried a new kind of egg tart though at a bakery in LA, it's a Macao style egg-tart with a harder/more densely baked crust. Also very good. So if GGB is vacationing, be happy that there are many other egg tarts to try elsewhere!

I think what does separate Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts from other good places like Sheng Kee is basically that they put more sugar in the egg yolk part and more butter in the crust. The crust at Golden Gate Bakery is super, super flakey, like a great croissant. When I bite into a Golden Gate Bakery egg tart, my mouth isn't just satisfied, it does an extra dance. It's that sensation that comes when a taste is very strong, probably on the edge of being too much, but has perfectly balanced itself on the yummy side of that line.

Also, I think their big peanut butter cookies and their lao puo bing are good too.

THEY JUST NEED TO BE OPEN SOMETIMES.

Also, their egg tarts are expensive for egg tarts: I think someone told me $1.75 now per tart? You can usually get these for $1- $1.25 elsewhere.
author: Jill F.

description:
"ON VACATION" but not really... 

We're on vacation and stood at the front of the store in disappointment. We stood in front and started googling for our next stop until a lady came to the door and asked if she can help us. We asked for her famous egg tarts and was told to come back in a half hr because it's in the oven. Yayyyyy!!! Came back 40 mins later and got freshly baked egg tarts!! There was no line and she didn't let us into the store. We stood outside and she came back with my egg tarts in a bag. Two for $3.20! Ouch. Didn't expect that.

The egg tarts were hot, the custard was soft with a flaky crust. Yum!
author: Jenn R.

description:
the past three times I came to sf this place has been closed. finally on 1/3/15 and the 4th they were open. luck was literally on my side bc there was no super long lines ( I had 3 people in front of me ) and I got a fresh hot batch of there infamous egg tarts. these are so worth the price and wait. this is a must stop in Chinatown. especially if u r from LA u must try. the smell of these wonderful egg tarts can b smelled two stores down each side. 

the store itself is small, they sell other bakery goods but eggs tarts r the best.
author: Angela C.

description:
After trekking up a slant, only to find no line at the ever so famous bakery that Clinton and Obama has been to, it was a relief. 

Busting my way through the doors, the fresh scent of buttery, flaky cooked dough fills my nostrils. I was greeted by three unfriendly Asian women, who seems to hate tourists but asians even more. 

I got a box of them famous egg tarts, hot fresh kept warm in their oven waiting for Ms. Right to come haul them away. For 15$, I got a dozen. For 1.25, you can get one. I sank my teeth into the tart, the eggness hitting my tongue and giving it that aroma of buttery goodness. The flaky crust was the perfect balance to the sweetness. I hungrily gobbled up my first tart, headed out and began working on the rest.

Super tiny place and Important Note: my dear Jesus, whatever you do don't let them catch you taking pictures! They all will YELL at you and continue to about not being allowed to take pictures.  Seems double standard to me if famous people are allowed to, but regular people can't. 

Regardless, the egg tart lives up to its hype. Though not the best service and everything else is over priced.
author: Winnie G.

description:
Last summer when my boyfriend took me to the bakery I was sad to find they were on vacation for a good month.  So this year my boyfriend was determined to take me back.  He knows how much I enjoy having egg tarts when we get dim sum, so he figured I'd love the egg tarts here.

I had been warned about long lines but it wasn't as bad as I thought.  It took a while because people were taking their time making their purchases in the shop.  There isn't much space when you step into the bakery.  I think the max amount of people that should be in there to browse with ease is maybe 5 people and that might be pushing it still.  We picked up some raisin bread for bf's dad.  My bf wanted some sweet bread and I opted for a lemon and raspberry napoleon and a cream puff.

 I must say the only thing I love from the bakery is the egg tarts. They were hot when we got them and divine to eat. The best I've had ever.  I can't say the same for the baked goods. I've had better back home in New Orleans.  The only thing I would be back for is a dozen egg tarts for 15 bucks sadly.
author: Lina T.

description:
Definitely worth the power walk over there!

I was at Rosewood for a Gogobot event. My husband and I wanted to make the most of our time in the area so I Yelped for some good eats. Gold Gate Bakery showed up with an amazing 4.5 star rating. We left Rosewood about 7:45PM and rushed over there to make it just in time before they closed.

One good thing about coming right before closing... no line!

The egg custard tarts are $1.25 each or $15 for a dozen. The crust is flaky. The middle has the texture of creme brulee, but definitely not as sweet as one. It doesn't taste too eggy like some other egg tarts I've had. A nice balance of tastes and textures. 

I also got suckered into buying a BBQ pork bun. They were still warm. Fresh from the oven! The bread around it is fluffy and a little bit sweet to balance out the saltiness of the pork. 

Next time you find yourself in Chinatown, definitely check this place out. It's worth the wait in line. I heard they do a pretty good job of keeping the line moving, too.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Is this place really that good? It's pretty good, but I think that mostly has to do with the fact that it has such high volume that you can always get a hot egg custard.  Almost all  bakeries bake their goods early in the morning and rarely do you get a chance to have this delicious little pastry while its steaming hot out of the oven.

Occasionally you may be able to flag down a hot batch while having dim sum, but other that that, it just doesn't happen.  At Golden Gate Bakery, you are pretty much guaranteed a hot egg custard.  

I don't live in San Francisco, but when I do visit I tend to stay in Union Square, which happens to be very close to Chinatown.  Every time, despite telling myself, I've just eaten or whatever, I find my way to this line, luckily I've never had to wait that long, but it could just be that time difference working in my favor.  By the time I've had my dim sum for breakfast, I make my way over for some fresh egg custard and there are only a handful of people on line.

There other pastries are usually very good too.   My greedy self aways buys more than I can consume, since I love egg custards and all the other things look good too.
author: Tina Y.

description:
I am going to review this place again because I actually got to go to the location this time (last time my bf just brought me back an egg tart).

I came here ~2PM on Friday and there were only 5 people in front of me. After hearing about the atrocious lines, I was delighted to see that it was so short! Workers here bust their booties to make sure the line moves quickly, so they can seem a little rude when you don't know what you want immediately. There was this guy in front of me who wanted a lemon napoleon and one egg tart. The lady told him no and that he had to get half a dozen. He kept reiterating that he only wanted one and she kept saying that he had to get a half dozen. I think in the end, she ended up giving it to him but I thought it was strange how she acted... O_o

But hey, for the quality of their egg tarts, they're allowed to act however they want to as long as they keep producing these delicious little bites of heaven! MmM. Seriously the best egg tarts I've had in the bay. The sweet, smooth custard is encased in a buttery, flaky crust that makes me die a little inside because it really is that good. I can't praise them enough for what they do with their egg tarts. Eat them while they're still warm out of the oven. YUMMMMMYYY.

I asked my bf if he wanted any and his eyes lit up immediately as he shouted "YESSS! I WANT FOUR!!!"
Me: FOUR?!?!?!?! You're not going to eat FOUR today!!
Him: IS THAT A CHALLENGE?! CHALLENGE ACCEPTED.
A true testament to Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Ava S.

description: I've traveled the world and have tried many egg custard tarts. These are hands down the best. The crust is flaky, and light with a slight crunch. The custard is rich and perfect consistency. The line is always out the door, but I'll happily wait. Only down side with this place is they close for vacation at random times throughout the year. The ladies there don't seem that friendly, but they are actually quite nice just overwhelmed at times. I was there on a day without a line. Amazing!
author: Annie S.

description: Located towards the end of of the Chinatown souvenir stores, this bakery almost always has a line of people waiting for their infamous Chinese basked goods. Their superstar item in the place are their egg custard tarts. With the perfect balance of eggy, sweet custard with a flaky, buttery crust , the egg custard tarts are always being ordered by the boxfuls. I love when the egg custard tarts are freshly baked because they are most delicious when served straight from the oven. I also enjoy their coconut tarts which taste like coconut macaroons in a crust. Though this place is cash only, always packed, and always a line, it is the spot for delectable Chinese baked treats in San Francisco.
author: Cristal C.

description:
I came here with my mom on a weekend afternoon after having lunch in Chinatown. She's a big fan of the egg tarts here so I shut my mouth and stood in line for 45 mins.

There are always lines here! The egg tarts are definitely better than other places but I don't know if I'd ever wait in that line again. 

Thumbs up: they're fresh out the oven!
author: Stine H.

description:
OVERRATED...and here's why....

I don't understand what's the huge hype over this place...I know this place is suppose to be known for it's egg tarts but I honestly was not that impressed. For how long you have to stand in line, how many Asians you have to fight to keep from cutting you in line, and how many crazy people in front of you in line placing completely insane orders that sweep out the entire bakery so you have to wait another 20 mins for another batch of egg tarts to come out from the oven...I honest don't think this place is worth all that work! 

To be honest, I think I would have just given the egg tarts 3 stars...I think any other bakery has egg tarts that taste like this, I don't understand what's so special or great about these ones. I'm only giving this place 4 stars because I tried the "WIFE CAKES" here and that is honestly pretty good. They are SOO BIG and they fill it with big chunks of lotus which makes it pretty good. And I sense some extra salt in the filling which is a nice contrast to the sweetness of the lotus. So well done on the wife cakes...but OVERRATED on the egg tarts!
author: Amiee H.

description:
I'm going to add a non-value-add comment because everyone has said it already:

1. BEST EGG TARTS in my life
2. But, unlike many Asian foods which are open on holidays, they seem to close the stores during holidays and non-holidays.
author: El W.

description: Currently closed for vacation!
author: Danan R.

description:
I went on a Saturday and guess what?  It was open!  

Yes, it's a big deal when it's open.  I went into Ten Ren Tea down the street and even the Ten Ren lady looked at our bag and said, "Oh, it's open today."   I posted on Facebook and my friends said, "Is it open?"

With so many reviews, this review probably isn't needed, but then I brought the Dan Tats (egg custard tarts) to a dinner party of Chinese, Koreans, and Filipinos the same night in San Jose and some of the lifetime Bay Area locals had never heard of the place.  Jaw drop.  

Egg Tarts ($16 a dozen, $8 half dozen) - Everyone comes here for the egg tarts.  No one leaves with less than a dozen.  Some people leave with 5 dozen.  It's somewhere in the middle between a Portuguese Egg Tart and a the pie bottom one.  A Portuguese Egg Tart is a smaller egg tart that has a light, crispy, flaky crust, custard and is browned over on top to make it a little sweeter, almost like a creme brulee top.   The pie bottom one is larger, with custard (unbrowned), in a pie like crust... harder, not flaky.  The Golden Gate Bakery Egg Tart is full sized with a crispy, flaky crust, but not as light as a Portuguese Egg Tart.  Best eaten fresh and warm in front of the bakery, but if you pop them in the oven at home at 300 for 12 minutes, it's like fresh baked goodness all over again.  

Coconut Macaroons ($6 a dozen, $3 a half dozen) - An underrated star, I consider these equally as good as the egg tarts, but way less hyped.  Shaped like a large kiss drop, light, airy but a tad moist inside, and they have a fun crunch that holds, even if you choose to eat them five days later.  

Some swear by their Almond Cookies... I've never had them.  They also sell various Moon Cakes.  With or without yolk, double yolk, mixed nut, red bean, green bean, etc. There's about 10 varieties and then you can choose with or without yolk in the middle.    

There is always a line outside.  You'll have to wait anywhere from 10-30 minutes, depending on the day.  It's a wait because they literally walk the freshly baked egg tarts over from the kitchen after you order them.  

You want the true experience of SF Chinatown?  This is #1 on the list!
author: Howie C.

description: Hands down the BEST egg tart your mouth will ever encounter!!! I also think they make the best wifey pastry! Nom nom nom nom!!!
author: Alice X.

description: I was never a fan of egg tarts, but that all changed after trying one from Golden Gate Bakery! Literally straight out of the oven! Doesn't get fresher than that! The line can be intimidating but it goes by pretty fast! I just wish we had an appetite for more. They box your order if you order 6 or more!
author: Marc C.

description:
Traveled to SF (all the way from the east coast) two years ago and wanted to check out this place,  it was closed for their vacation. Two years later I'm back again, at a different time of the year, i can't believe it's their vacation week again.... 

Hopefully third times the charm. I WILL COME BACK!
author: Julia Y.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan!!! 
I've heard so much about this place and they are a little pieces of sunshine! 
I wondered whether i could get them during my short stay in SF and YES I made it. 
I called in advance on Sunday and they say they open till 8pm. (Honestly I'm not sure whether they had more egg tarts left till then. ) 
Only had to wait for 10mins and they were fresh and HOT!!  
I liked the fact that they are not overly sweet! So yumm!!
Theses were probably the best egg tarts i've ever tried. 
Just wished that they open more often. (you will even see on their door that they have a sign saying that they are on a vacation.)
author: Amy P.
Evelyn S.

description:
We were walking around taking in the sights of the Lunar New Year celebration in Chinatown, and my husband remembered that there was a bakery with the most delicious egg custard tarts around here somewhere. We wandered around a little bit, and then we found Golden Gate Bakery pretty quickly - even with all the booths in the festival, the line into the bakery for the fresh and piping hot egg custard tarts was one of the longest! We quickly got in line, which was comparable to the line at Bi-Rite, and finally got in the bakery after about 25 minutes. 

The inside of the bakery is super cluttered. You can't even go inside half the bakery, because it is so full of stuff (boxes, bags, junk (for lack of a better word)). The bakery case is in front, and features all the goodies, but you have to request the egg custard tarts, which I am assuming are being baked off and were not out yet when we were there. There was probably no time to refill the egg custard tarts in the case!

We ordered six egg custard tarts, two egg custard buns, and banh bo (not sure what the English term for it is, but it's like a sponge-y white rice-flour-based cake). We also got some vanilla sponge cake with pineapple jelly in the middle. I should have gotten some almond cookies, but we were so distracted. 

The egg custard tarts were so flake-y, crisp, and perfectly sweet (but not too sweet), while the actual egg custard still retained the egg taste but sweet and delicious. There's no way to describe it. The custard is still slightly jiggly but the outside tart shell is perfectly crisp. Pretty cool. I love the darkened lightly burnt crust on top, yum. Truly the best egg custard tarts I've ever had. 

$1.40 per tart, which isn't too bad, considering that macarons cost about $1.50 at least for a tiny cookie the size of your thumbnail. Definitely worth the schlep into Chinatown for these! Be sure to look inside and know what you want, the line is long, and people are impatient!

P.S. The tarts are often very hot and fresh! They are perfection in this cold nippy San Francisco air.
author: Anh D.

description:
Cash only, and there will usually be a line out the door.

But...... yeah... GET THE EGG TARTS!!! I was soooooooooo full after my meal at Sotto Mare, that I didn't even think I could eat one of these... I ended up eating two.

These egg tarts have a crispy crust on the outside, a sweet, gooey inside and a layer of eggyness on top.

Like the great man Drake once said, they were the "best I ever had, the best I ever had..."
author: Michael K.

description: Egg tart was good!  But they give you attitude so 1 star off for that.  Honestly, it is good but I don't think I'll miss out if I did not visit this place.
author: Leo Y.

description:
I think it's very apparent from other reviews that Golden Gate Bakery has great dan tats... so this review is really for my own documentation :) 

I always say I am the #1 fan of the tart family... egg tarts, creme brulee, fruit tarts, anything tart, so I am always on the hunt for the best dan tats in town. We got in time just before they closed at 8pm and waited for maybe 15 minutes for fresh dan tats. Unlike most bakery visits, I was not greedy and only got one (sad). 

It was the best dan tat ever- soooo light and fluffy, it actually jiggled like Jello! The custard was the perfect texture and the crust so light and crispy- not at all oily.

If I were to rank my all time favorite bakery dan tats, from good to so-amazing-I-will-tell-all-the-dan-tat-lovers-I-know... it would go like this: Chicago Chiu Quon, NY Manhattan, NY Queens Jade Asian Restaurant, Hong Kong anywhere, SF Golden Gate Bakery!!! 

Gold Gate Bakery wins for THE WORLD (so far in my life, at least)! I'm guessing the only other city to fight for a spot on my list is LA (but who knows, maybe someplace in Europe or Africa makes a surprisingly great dan tat as well.)

I LOVE them! If I ever moved to SF, I'd be sure I'm not too far away from Chinatown just to get these bad boys! yum yum yum. Wish I could eat five tonight and call it dinner.
author: Justine L.

description: There's always a line here.  I'm not an egg tart connoisseur so the quality is lost on me. They tasted good tho
author: t d.

description:
We've returned since our last visit but never when there is a long line.  Consider us opportunists, we slide in when there is no line.  We've since turned some friends into fans too.

Recently, we tried other items: 

the mochi balls with a choice of red bean paste, custard or traditional (peanut, sesame and coconut flakes) - these were tasty, the soft mochi has a nice hint of banana flavor.  $1.25 each?

banana flavored roll - not bad

custard bun - $0.99 - smaller than a cocktail bun but it was damn good.  the bun was soft and filled with delicious custard from end to end.
author: Gloria H.

description:
We were strolling through Chinatown when we stumbled across this little gem. We peeked in and there was a queue of Chinese people...good sign - we were looking for something authentic.

The staff were really lovely and struck up a conversation with us as they served us. We saw a lot of things that looked good and maybe went a little overboard!! My favourite things were the coconut biscuits (they're the ones that look like swirly cones!) and the packaged cookies with almonds on top - they are so light and crispy!!!
author: Stephanie O.

description:
When my friends found out I worked across the street from Golden Gate, I was sent on a mission to bring back eggtarts everyday. One day on my lunch break, I finally decided to pop in to see what the fiasco was all about. 

Considering that it was noon on a weekday, the line was quite ridiculous. I probably waited a good 20 minutes just to get eggtarts to-go. I also heard that they have extremely inconsistent business hours, I guess they're just that good to open whenever they feel like it and still keep people coming.

When I first saw the price, I was quite surprised. I don't think I've ever paid more than a dollar for an eggtart before. Although overpriced, I will reluctantly say that they were worth it. Such a smooth, perfectly sweet custard and flakey crust, these things were absolutely scrumptious. Very reminiscent of the eggtarts in Hong Kong. 

Being the good friend that I am, I bought a box to take home for my friend and had the smell of freshly baked eggtarts torture me for the rest of the afternoon.
author: Becky M.

description:
Finally we got to try their famous egg tart after many times of going to their bakery only to find out they were closed. 
Even the line was an hour wait, it's worth it.
Egg tart was fresh bake,delicious.....It's hard to describe how good it is. Must try it!
Now can't wait for next time to come here again,hope they aren't on vacation again lol
author: Yi H.

description:
Sorry GGB, you only get two stars from me.

I know, I know, I know... I'm probably sipping on so much haterade right now it's not funny anymore. I've walked by and after 10+ times of being in the area and attempting to check it out, only to fail miserably. When I saw the line pop up within the small Chinatown street, I knew it was finally destiny to determine if this place had it better than Tao Yuen Pastry (Oakland, CA).

I tried this place practically two weeks ago view my photo of their Custard Tarts and Vanilla Cream Bun (http://instagram.com/p/i2C1ULnh23/).

Let's start with the Cream Bun. The bread is moist, the vanilla filling is airy but the subtle shavings of coconut didn't rub me the right way. Had they mentioned coconut from the get-go I wouldn't have ordered but you gotta be open somehow, right?

Finally the battle of the bay area Custard Tarts. If you love your egg tarts with a soufflé consistency, then here's the 49ers of egg tarts for you. Skinny next to nothing crust with a whole lot of airy-eggy goodness shining through. The Raiders (Tao Yuen) holds a soft spot for me, not just for childhood purposes but the idea of a tart having two essential elements: A nice core ingredient (in this case a panna cotta like gelatinous texture) with layers of thick flakey crust holding the contents.

I prefer the latter and after hearing (and tasting) these overpriced mini treats ($1.50+ for each egg tart and the cream bun was a dollar). Ended up spending almost $15.00 of less than a dozen with a cream bun. As opposed to across the bay, it's a few cents cheaper and the quality makes all the difference.

I'm giving this place a 2.5 solely on lack of accessibility, wait time, pricing and quality of product. Sorry GGB, maybe you were good or I visited on a bad day? Either way, I hope the egg tarts will improve in the future. Cheers.
author: Ryan M.

description:
I'm an Asian-cuisine enthusiast and Golden Gate Bakery has THE best egg tarts and moon cakes!

There are many old ladies working the front of this warehouse-looking shop but their service system isn't efficient so expect long lines stretching outside the bakery at all times of the day.
The moon cakes are expensive, especially during Mid-Autumn Festival ($7.50-$9 each), but they are soooo worth the price. 
I recommend getting a box of Lotus Seed Paste, Taro and Black Bean flavors- ALL WITH YOLK because who eats a mooncake without yolk. Madness.

Egg tarts ($1.65 each) are Golden Gate Bakery's speciality! The crusts are flaky AND chewy/tender and the filling is not too sweet and not too heavy. The filling makes up an egg tart and I absolutely love this bakery's light fluffy custard! 

Don't forget to try out some pastries- I love the curry chicken puff ($2.15)!
author: Connie C.

description:
they always have the "WE ARE ON VACATION" sign up but they're actually always open.  they take random half days off bc they get tired of baking lol but they normally do reopen or you can just knock on the window like I do, and they'll open the door for u.

the dan tats are amazing and definitely lives up to the hype.
author: TM O.

description:
From New York City to Chicago to Hong Kong, the egg tarts at this bakery in San Francisco tops all of the above! Though I have heard the lines can be long, I have gotten lucky both times that I came because I waited for less than 5 minutes (around 6:30 p.m.).
