These egg tarts are filled with custard that are both creamy yet solid to an extent. When you take a bite, it literally melts inside when it is still hot. The flaky crusts are crispy and light, and all together, the dessert is not too sweet. 

$1.25 each custard? So worth it.
author: Lilian N.

description: Still my all time favorite egg tarts in the area. I have been back three times this year and TODAY was the first time they were NOT on vacation and actually open. Huzzah! I was so excited. I ordered me a box of egg tarts at $1.50 a pop and they were amazing. Crispy flaky buttery crust and creamy egg flavored (not diluted) center of goodness. well well well worth the wait. The people standing in the long lines know something is open. Follow the crowd, usually they do not steer you wrong, and this bakery, my friends, is the bee knee's!
author: Janet D.

description:
Coming from a lifelong Chinatown, Chinese resident; this place is over, overrated. You know how to tell if a place is good? If old Chinese ladies buy the stuff. This place is a tourist attraction and looking at all the "white people" it certainly isn't for the locals. I think the only advantage is that it comes out hot outta oven..period.

Go try the bakery on Stockton, between Jackson and Washington, AA Bakery, for the same sweet custards. And they're no closed for vacation 8 months of the year.
author: patrick s.

description:
For my 100th review, I wanted to choose a place that's particularly special to me. It's special because it has the ability to literally make or break my trips to SF depending on whether or not it's open when I'm there.

This place is called Golden Gate Bakery... and I'm unabashedly addicted to their egg tarts.

I've eaten hundreds of egg tarts in my lifetime (it's expected being Canto with Dim Sum and all), and this place has by far the best egg tarts I've ever had. The hype is real.

The crust supporting this large tart is thin yet incredibly flaky. The pale yellow egg custard middle is cooked to perfect consistency. The eggy flavor is pronounced and complemented by a subtle sweetness as opposed to other places where sweetness is all you seem to taste. It's an egg tart, not a sugar tart. 

At $1.40 a pop (cash only too!) it's not cheap. But it's worth every penny. And the lines out the door they have every single day throughout the day is a testament to that.

I really give this place 4.5 stars, docking half a star simply because they seem to close shop whenever they feel like it. Of all the times I go to SF, it's only been open during 60-70% of those trips. Fear not, however, there is literally a site, fan-made I assume, dedicated to letting you know if Golden Gate Bakery is open which is updated daily around noon. I'm not lying. Google it. 

And, like me, live by it.
author: Derick N.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery has been touted to have the best egg custards around. Yet, I've managed to miss out for all the years of living in San Francisco. Blasphemous, I know, but I have two reasons: I'm not really a fan of dan tat and I avoid Chinatown like the plague. Fate would have me in the area this past Friday so I thought I would finally give it a try. 

The first thing I notice about this bakery is that they run it like a drug operation. The lights were off, the doors were locked, and a sign was posted saying that they were closed for vacation. A winding line was forming outside. I thought they were closed, but after a few minutes, I noticed an old woman unlocking the door from time to time to accept cash only for freshly baked boxes of dan tat (ordered 1-2 dozen at a time). It took a good half hour to get a batch since it seemed like they were only producing a couple dozen at a time. If that's not shady, I don't know what is. 

The dan tat were piping hot and as fresh as could be. As I bit into one, I realized what all the fuss was about. The crust was perfectly flaky, the custard was silky smooth and not too sweet. They made a believer out of me. Eat them while they're hot or reheat them because they're not as good when they get cold. The prices are up a dime at $1.25 a pop.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
I've only had their egg tarts before but they are hands down the best ones I've ever had! My godmother loves this place and every time she goes to San Francisco, she always stops by to bring us a box of fresh egg tarts. By the time they arrive to my house, they're still warm!

The crust is flakey, while the filling maintains a light and sweet eggy flavor without being artificial tasting, or overly eggy. It's so hard to consume these slowly because they're so delicious!
author: Stacey L.

description:
You'll definitely know you're at the right spot when you see the crowd lined up. I don't particularly love dan tat but how can you say so no to 4.5 stars and over 1400 reviews!  

The dan tat was warm, flaky and not too sweet.  If you never had one before it kinda tastes like sweet scrambled eggs... yes, strange I know but good!  Coming fresh from the oven makes a hell of a difference in the quality :)  The wait was about 10-15 minutes on a Saturday afternoon.  It's also a hot spot for locals so you know it's legit :)
author: Stacey P.

description:
The BEST egg custard tarts. Period.  They're a little on the pricier side, but you're paying for quality.  I recommend you eat one right away when you buy it there - it's doesn't taste any better than right out of the oven.  Chances are the egg custards will be fresh from the oven.  People usually have to wait for a fresh batch to come out to fill their boxes and there's usually a line out the door, but it's worth the wait.  They're also still good if you pop them in the toaster oven before you serve them at home/parties.  I live in Oakland, but won't hesitate to make a trip to SF Chinatown if I'm craving really good egg custards.  

One tip I have for this place is to call to make sure the bakery is open before you make the trip down there.  Sometimes they'll go on vacation and be closed for a week(s) here and there.  I know they're closed now for about 9 more days.  

This is the place to hit if you want a good egg custard tart.  Try it and I think you'll agree.  It's one of my favorite places in San Francisco!
author: Julia C.

description:
3 stars because everytime I come to Chinatown and walk by this bakery,  the  Gate is there to lock up the place since it's closed.

Seems like they always close for vacation all the time especially during the summer months!

The egg tarts are delicious of course but the lines are way too long and then when there is no line, you realize it is because they ran out of egg tarts for the day!!!  

Talk about grouchy Chinatown people!  Anyways an egg tart is an egg tart and other bakeries sell it too so that's good there's other bakeries in Chinatown.
author: Gangsta G.

description:
Yeees.  Why can't we have one of these in LA?

I found myself with a little extra room in my stomach after lunch in Chinatown on Thursday (heck, I would've made room!) and made my way over to GGB.  I was shocked when they were actually open, and the line was only about 3-4 people in front of me.  

I ordered the red bean pastry and an egg tart.  I started eating the egg tart, which I cupped in my hand and felt that it was still warm, thinking I'd only take one bite.  About half way through Chinatown, I found the sides of my mouth covered in puff pastry and the entire egg tart, with all of its runny eggy sweet goodness, somewhere on its way to my stomach.  

It took an extreme amount of self discipline not to immediately devour the red bean pastry as well, but about half an hour later, I killed it like no other.  The red bean filling was sweet, but just like the egg tart, not overly so.  And the puff pastry shell was just the perfect consistency too.

I've only been blessed to have GGB about three times in my life, but each time, I have no regrets whatsoever.  I only wish it were more often!

Service:  Snappy Cantonese people, what do you expect?

Bottom line:  Even if they charged $2 for these heavenly egg tarts, I'd be a happy customer.  Again, why can't we have one of these in LA?  GGB makes Kee Wah seem so whatevz.
author: Denny C.

description:
" This place must be good, just look at the line"
" Seems super delicious"
"So I want to get 20 egg tarts...."

Yes, after hearing a few people talk about the bakery when I walked by, I decided to check it out. 

 I decided to yelp this place to see what exactly is their specialty during the wait in long, thus I decided to try their egg tarts. I mean I've had my fair share of egg tarts, in fact, I don't even like egg tarts......Thus, I really don't believe the hype of these delicious egg tarts.

Nevertheless, I bought five egg tarts. Upon leaving the store, I immediately took one and ate it while it was fresh out of the oven...........AND.......

IT WAS PHENOMENAL. WORDS CANNOT DESCRIBE THE TASTE OF THE EGG TARTS. The crust was just perfectly baked, and the filling was delicious, definitely not too overpowering/sweet. My sister also agreed with me, considering how she kept on nagging me to go back and buy 20 more for her, and it's been less than 2 hours since her last egg tart consumption!
author: Josie H.

description: I walked here at 8 in the morning for my girlfriend and she loved the egg tart from here. defiantly worth the walk from my hotel.
author: Sean P.

description:
super long lines (there was an old asian couple that caused a scene because of it, which made the waiting entertaining), really good egg tarts, and accepts cash only
they did raise the prices, which i guess is expected because a lot of things are getting more expensive these days, but it is a nice splurge when i do get the chance
the 2 times i've visited they have been open
author: Lily D.

description:
As a native bay area baby, I grew up with golden gate bakery. It's been a staple and standard for me to compare other Asian buns to. Their petite buns are the perfect snack, packed with richness, but not to the point of nausea! Filings are not overly sweet, just perfect. 

It has become as icon of San Francisco Chinatown and it deserves such spot. 

Aside from them being closed most of the year, the hour long waits are worth the hype.
author: Cheryl Y.

description: Phenomenal egg tarts. Flaky crust, creamy egg custard. Best enjoyed warm. The wait is long, but the ladies really hustle. Courteous service. Very small joint, standing space only. Bring cash.
author: Lo R.

description: Worth half an hour wait for egg tarts, even better quality than the one I had in HK. We ordered six egg tarts, and had one immediately. It is so good that I haven't had one with this quality for a while. The remaining five that we saved it for next couple days, we put it in small oven and heat in up for breakfast, not at its best, but still a good start of the day.
author: Raymond Y.

description:
HYPHY for the HYPE. Those custard egg tarts that put you through an hour or so of waiting in line? Totally worth it. Pure perfection down to the last bite: delicately balanced, not too eggy, not too sweet. The crispy, flaky crust has definitely got to be the best thing that sets these egg tarts from all others.

Prices have gone up to $1.40 per egg tart and $16.80 for a dozen. Considering this place could pay for my college tuition in full after just a day of business, you'd think that they'd offer a discount for buying in bulk, but them Asian ladies want cho money!! They might seem all cranky on the clock, but I swear after hours they be havin' the time of their lives makin' it rain in the back with your hard-earned cash.

You'll be in line for a hot minute, especially since all the Asian people comin' through this place wanna linger and have full on conversations with these ladies about the most arbitrary things. And I'm just standing outside like MOVE BITCH, GET OUT THE WAY!! Bitches be hungry and ain't nobody got time to be standing around while you talk up a storm.

These mamas don't play though, they strictly enforce the no photo/video policy here. Some idiot decided to pull out his camcorder and take a panoramic shot of the place, but homegirls put his ass on blast and made him put it away. Maybe there's something I'm missing, but I don't understand why they'd want to keep their goodies on the downlow. What they don't know is that they could be doin' it big and rakin' in 8 figures with my food pornography skills, but whatever, it's their loss.

The egg tarts here are definitely one of San Francisco's treasures. If time permits, this place is a must-try, especially if you're only here once. During this time of year, you can get one of those Asian calendars for free if you've bought more than enough of their baked goods. Just ask for one when they ring you up!
author: Peter L.

description:
There's probably a 20-30 person line consistently outside the door.. but my god... those egg custards...

I'm salivating rainbows right now just thinking how awesome they are.
author: Dave N.

description:
Love their egg tarts and sesame balls! They're so good and it's hard to have just one! There's always a long line but it goes pretty fast. 

One Caveat: they often go on vacation and close the store without warning. Be sure to call them to see if they're open. If the phone continues to ring, they're probably on vacation. For example, in the last 6 months, I've gone 3 times and 2 of the times (4 months apart), they've been closed because they were on vacation).
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Amazing.  The best egg custard I ever ate.  I ate egg custard all my life while growing up in nyc.  This is by far the best egg custard ever.  The bad thing is that it is a long line and they open whenever they want.  There is a sign that says they are on vacation to ward people away.
author: Phillip T.

description: Everybody raves about their egg tart which is well-deserved.  They are in a class of their own, by miles.  No one else makes them better. Believe it or not, the crust used to be slightly thicker and therefore even flakier, like biting-into-it-with-flakes-flying-all-around-flakier lol!  That was about 10+ years ago.  You know what else is really great from here? Their baked cha siu bows.  Brimming with lots of pork, no fillers.  Their gai mai bows are really good too. Yep our usual order is 1 dozen egg tarts, 6 cha siu bows and 6 gai mai bows. Like others have pointed out, they do shut down a lot. They take their cash back to China and live like kings for a half the year I presume lol. Factoid: GGB was started by 2 brothers who got into a fight one day and one brother left to start up Eastern Bakery down the street.
author: M Y.

description: Best egg tarts ever! Enough said! A must visit if you're in downtown SF.
author: Wenny L.

description:
One word "overhyped". For those going on Yelp to find out what's good in SFO - be warned - DON'T LINE UP for this! If the line is short (as in 2 to 3 people tops ahead of you) then go for it. But otherwise look away and walk the other direction.  If you're still going to be a sucker and line up anyway, make sure you have enough cash. They are CASH ONLY. We spent $35 on a dozen egg tarts and two moon cakes. People ahead of us paid $75 and $150 albeit they had 3 or so boxes of moon cakes and egg tarts on hand.

If you are from Calgary, just eat at the Grand Central on Center Street. They have the EXACT same egg tarts minus the hype and the wait. 

In fairness, the egg tart and moon cake were not bad, they were in fact good. But not good enough to wait in line for... honestly we waited for almost 3 hours in line for this and it's NOT (emphasis on NOT) worth it. I would line up 10 minutes tops (15 would be pushing it) for these. 

Good things: Food was good but nothing to call home about. Certainly nothing to line up for whatsoever. Egg tarts were cheap at $18 per dozen or $1.50 per piece. Allegedly, at least according to the locals waiting in line,  the savoury treats were even better than the egg tart - I can't say as they were not available that day. You make new friends waiting in line. 

Bad things: Service sucks! Did I mention yet that the line moves slower than molasses???! Inside, they literally write your receipt down on paper - why they can't make the process more efficient beyond me.  As in think of the most inefficient place you've ever been to, multiple the slowness by 7, and that would still be faster than the service here. Moon cakes were expensive at $7-$8 per piece (yes, per piece as in like one hockey puck). And to rub salt into our wounds, it turned out we were lining up for savoury pastries that weren't even available that day, and they had no warnings that  these were not available.The biggest delays were they were pretty much baking things to order (once they run out, decent bakeries will let you know. This one will actually bake things as people order and trap you into waiting until you have no choice but to walk out with something in a pink box anyway). One more bad thing, cash only. 

I wish I listened to the guy here who commented that "life is short" to be wasting time on this. I feel so embarrassed we spent that much time waiting... It's a trap were you go "I've been here 30 minutes already", "I've  been here over an hour", and 3 hours later you are just leaving the store.
author: Carla A.

description: Driving around in chinatown is a horrific experience alone and then finding out ggb is closed for vacation when you get there pisses me off.   This is the second time you went on vacation without updating yelp.
author: S F.

description: I visited the bakery to try their famous egg tarts last week (9/17) and was told they weren't making any that day nor any of the regular bakery items - such a disappointment.  They only had moon cakes as the Chinese Moon Festival is coming up, so this review is only on the Moon Cakes.  I bought 6, the white lotus seed, bean paste and the coconut.  Favorite was definitely the White Lotus seed.  It's delicious and I would highly recommend.  Hubby thought the Coconut one was odd with a bunch of nuts inside and it was dry.  This is a very traditional old-school bakery, so don't expect great service, it's quick and no-nonsense.  You go for the food and that's it.  They are cash-only and as other yelpers have indicated, often just close with no warning.  I'll be back in SF next month and hopefully can finally get to try those egg tarts!
author: Cindy Z.

description:
The wait was insane. Egg tarts are good but maybe a little more eggy than I like. $1.40 per tart or $16.80 per dozen. People were buying boxes and boxes of them. 

What really impressed me were the coconut cake tart things they have. OMG. Sooo good. Like a macaroon inside an egg tart shell. I wish we had them in LA!!! Also $1.40 each. 

I think the service is a bit slow because they chat with the customers. Super friendly ladies. Can't fault them for it because it is a bit of a neighborhood joint. If it wasn't for Yelp, one wouldn't know they are known for their egg tarts because they go so fast that they never find their way to the display windows!
author: Susan K.

description:
The line is worth the wait everytime. Seriously, the owners go on random vacations throughout the year yet we used to always stop by when we were in San Francisco just in case. Now that I live in the city, I make it a habit to pick up a box of desserts for my mom when I go to visit her.

They are without a doubt, best known for their egg custards, which are the best enjoyed when they're hot and fresh out the oven. They also make lots of other things, such as barbecue pork buns and savory pastries. Apparently, the chicken curry pastry is a lot like a cornish pasty according to my British boyfriend. If you like coconut macaroons, they sell those by the dozen and they're perfectly crunchy on the outside. 

Things to bring when you go: patience (I can't stress that enough), cash (you'll need a $20), and something to entertain yourself while you wait in line.
author: Emmie Y.

description:
Okay, I'm going to sound like an arrogant SOB, but I've had a massive number of egg tarts in my lifetime - including in Hong Kong. So, safe to say, Golden Gate's egg tarts have landed themselves a 4.2 star in my book. The egg taste was not too overpowering and smelly, and the crust was flaky, but not too crispy. Also, the egg tarts were not too sweet. I personally like my egg tarts to be a little bit more flaky and crispy.

An egg tart here costs around $1.25 a pop. I believe a dozen is somewhere around the $15 ballpark. A tad bit pricey for an egg tart and this place is a little over-hyped IMO (expect lines for this bakery to be out the door), but I guess it's something you've definitely gotta try if you've never had an egg tart before.

Golden Gate is located in the heart of Chinatown, so prepare to fight for parking and having random people pop out, crossing streets left and right as if standard traffic rules didn't apply. Is it worth the insane and overly-cautious driving? Eh....... we'll see if I decide to return again.

** Note: Egg tarts may not be for everyone. My cousin's friend noted that he didn't like egg tarts because they tasted like "fart" to him. Hah!
author: Sheena T.

description: After waited in line for almost 1 hour, finally I got it!!! The egg tart is so good. The tart is crunchy and custard is soft but not too much sweet = PERFECT!! wanna give 7 starts to the golden gate bakery for the best egg tart in town!
author: Orange S.

description:
As someone who grew up in Hong Kong, I can agree that these egg tarts ("dan tat") are really, really good.  In fact, so good that we have to make a stop here every time we visit the city to pick up a dozen in a box before heading home.  

Unfortunately, most of the time we are in the city, this place is closed because the owners are "on vacation" (really??).  Fortunately, thanks to someone who maintains this website, this problem is easily solvable.  Check here before noon to see if the bakery is open for the day!  http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/
author: Y L.

description: Wow! Amazing pastries....hit the spot! Not too far of a walk from our hotel....the coconut ball like things were yummy! I enjoyed everything coconut!
author: Caro D.

description:
As sacrilegious as it sounds after reading the raves of the egg tarts, I'm not a great fan of this place.  In fact, when people build up a place and it's just okay, even if it's good, it's still a disappointment.  

The place is super tiny and the way it's set up, you can't see the products until it's time to order, and they had like 5 things, moon cakes, egg tarts, egg muffins, sticky rice, and a few other items.  Maybe because it was around 7pm and they sold out of other stuff.  The glass cases are blocked by the line of people in front and I had no idea what they were selling until it was time to order.  The prices are also unlisted and for $1.35 for a sticky rice ball, it was pretty pricey as far as Chinatown bakeries are concerned.  

Service was standard for Chinatown, which is not saying much.  The sticky rice with red bean was good and the muffin thing I tried was pretty good too.  It tasted fresh and smelled good.  Maybe I'm not blown away because I didn't have the egg tart.  But I'm not from Southern China and never really cared for those.  Oh well.  It was a good pit stop after dinner and I will definitely try the egg tart next time.
author: Lin G.

description:
My 100th review and to quote Jackie Gleason "how sweet it is"!!!!

In San Fran on business and followed Bourdain's lead over to R&G Lounge (will be 101st review).  After this amazing lunch, we decided to walk it off and strolled through the streets of Chinatown.  As we are walking, we spotted a long line waiting at a bakery.  Of course we stood on line and asked questions later,

Turns out this line was a wait for what's considered some of the best Egg Tarts aka Dan Tat around.  We waited and joked and laughed with some of the people waiting and by the time we were at the counter we were well prepared to order correctly (images of Seinfeld Soup Nazi were floating in my head).

Once in this small, wonderful smelling happy little bakery it was amazing to simply watch the hustle and bustle of the staff running around taking orders.  As we are ordering, there are constant fresh sweets flying out of the ovens and into their pink bakery boxes.  They even cut two flaps in the boxes to let the steam vent, that's how fresh this is.

We ordered 6  Dan Tat's and a few rice cake pancakes as well as a few macaroons.  The pancakes and macaroons were sold out with another batch coming in about 10 - 15 minutes, Soooooo, what to do while waiting for 15 minutes when you have a box of Dan Tat's in hand, WE ATE THEM!!!   I have had egg tarts before and as a baked good they are generally delicious, these were incredibly delicious.  Flaky warm crust, hot and creamy sweet egg custard filling and a somewhat firm texture across the top of this 2 inch beauty!  Was it worth the 20 minute wait, definitely!

After 15 minutes and a so much happiness in my mouth and stomach, it was time to return for the pancake and macaroons.  I skipped the entire line, found the sweet nice lady behind the counter (spoke perfect English) and walked out with two pancakes and two macaroons. 

First up, the pancake.  It is a mochi type texture with a sweet filling.  Absolutely delicious, a bit chewy sort of like taffy and in all a great intermezzo to the macaroons.

There are so many reviews that mention the Dan Tats and I agree they are wonderful, however, the Macaroons may have been one of the best things I have ever put in my mouth!  Fresh out of the oven, these sweet small magical concoctions are little bits of heaven that melt in your mouth!  I have never had a warm,right from the oven macaroon.  Whatever you do, do not leave there without a half dozen of these. 

I can not wait to be back in San Francisco again, this bakery will always be on my list of places to stop by when in town!
author: Adam K.

description: This bakery has the most delicious egg tarts of all time!!! These egg tarts are soooooo yummy-the best I've bad in the states and comparable to the ones I've bad in Taiwan. The egg is sooo soft and everything is still warm.  When you eat it, it's a combination of sweet egg pudding with crispy pastry crust. We also got sesame balls. Boyfriend devoured them and I  scarfed down all my coconut macarons.
author: Grace S.

description:
If Chinatown was burning down, this place is the only building I'd risk running into - these old ladies are baking treasures! Ok ok, I know they take random, sudden vacations for weeks on end with the only notice being a taped sign to the door reading "On Vacation", but damn those egg custard tarts are the best in the States. 

I love how the egg custard tarts are always fresh and melt in your mouth. Its also funny how they've developed their own signature "Tiffany-like" boxes. They are pink with the corners cut out tied with pink plastic ribbon. My mouth is salivating just thinking of those pink boxes.
author: Henry W.

description: This review is purely for the egg custard tarts. I didn't get to try anything else since I heard it's not worth it. I came with a friend and thank goodness there wasn't a long line though one formed quickly behind us. The tarts were delicous fresh and warm. The egg custard was thicker and denser than what I am used to. I actually don't prefer the eggy consistency of the custard. What i liked was that it wasn't too sweet so I felt like I could have another. I LOVED the flaky crust. It was buttery and flaky and so yummy. I don't think I'd make a special trip for these egg tarts, but I'll have no problem eating one if it was in front of me!
author: Katherine L.

description: If you want a real egg tart, one that is fluffy and melts in your mouth, a treat that you won't get made the same anywhere else, wait in line. My friends mother can eat a box in a day. She would even skip meals if she had to. A bit on the crazy side but I've seen it done. The store tends to close for vacation frequently; probably due to the $$ they make from selling out daily on their delicious baked goods. I would call in advanced if you're making a trek to see if they are even open. But if you're in the area and have yet to try, stop and get in line; it's worth the wait.
author: Marlene T.

description: We have waited in line outside the door for more than a hour in order to get custard tarts. They taste good but not really worth that long time waiting to be honest.
author: Claire C.

description: Came here for moon cake on a Friday afternoon, the ladies working in the front were so rude. There was a short line. Everytime I would try to order they would help the people behind me. Never coming back again.
author: Lyna T.

description:
Location/Parking: This small little shop is located in China Town. There is very limited space inside the store so the line typically goes out the door. Parking is rather difficult. I did not see any parking structures around. Your best bet is to find meter parking which is limited. I suggest taking public transit if feasible. 

Wait time: This place is known to close whenever they feel like it. They make enough money where they don't need to stay open year round. I suggest calling beforehand to make sure they're open. After calling them on a Sunday afternoon to confirm that they were open, I waited in line for about 20 minutes before placing my order. Typically, you can expect to wait anywhere between 20-30 minutes. 

Service: They are fast! When you come in, they just ask you straight out what you want and they pack your order immediately. They do the math in their head pretty quickly and can tell you accurately how much you owe. I was impressed at how efficient these ladies were even though they weren't very friendly.  +1 star

Quality of Food: The egg tarts were delicious. Served warm and fresh out of the oven. Probably one of the better egg custard tarts I have tried thus far. The only complaint that I have is that the egg to crust ratio is off. I thought there was wayy too much egg and not enough crust. But, I'll live! +1 star

Pricing: The egg tarts are $1.40 each. Most of the pastries are under $3. Although I've seen egg tarts for a lot cheaper, they typically aren't as big as the egg tarts here. It is a very competitive price. +1 star
author: Nhimo P.

description:
BEST EGG CUSTARD TARTS IN THE CITY.

The crust is flaky and soft. The egg custard is light and flavorful. It's the perfect balance of dough, egg and custard.

If you love dan tat (egg tarts), GET THEM HERE!
author: Andrew C.

description: Why are you so creamy, flaking good?! They are always on vacation but will still answer calls to let you know they are on 'vacation'. Probably the best custard tart I've ever had. They used to be $1 then $1.35,..and now $1.75! You can get them much cheaper at other bakeries but they make some pretty mean tasty ones. This will def be a treat at this price (plus they are always on vacation, ha). Worth a try even with the friggin long line! Order at least a dozen!
author: Lily M.

description:
The egg tart ($1.25/each) here is the best you'll find in the Bay Area. The egg tart itself deserves 5-stars but knowing that they mark up their prices a lot more than everyone else along with unfriendly service, I really can't give them the full 5-stars. If everyone else can sell egg tarts at half the price with a smile, they can too. Granted, these are better than the others so yeah they are worth a bit more but not double.

Expect a line and don't expect friendly service.
author: Andy W.

description:
A three hours wait for half a dozen egg tarts and a box of mooncakes on the week before the Mid-Autumn Festival.

As I left the store I thought to myself I would never do that again. I knew I can easily find some nice mooncakes in any Chinese grocery stores or bakeries. Any of these places would be more than happy to have me as a customer.

I cut my first mooncake into 6 tiny slices. It was green bean paste with egg york, the only traditional flavor that I like. I took my first bite. The cake filling was perfect in every way possible - the sweetness, the flavor, the texture. I couldn't find any fault to this tiny little piece. It was so soothing and satisfying. I knew I would be sad when all the mooncakes are done. 

Would I really not line up again next year? I was not so sure anymore.
author: Mona W.

description:
OK, hands down best egg tarts in SF! (And better than some in Hong Kong actually), especially when they're fresh out of the oven! I wish they had some with a cookie crust too, because I like that more than the flakey crust, but I'm not complaining - it's still heavenly! 

Beware, there's always a line for their egg tarts, even at the middle of the day when you don't expect anyone to be there. Also, they tend to close on random days... I don't know how many times I've been there when it was closed. I was so disappointed :( 

Their Mexican Buns are also delicious, and their other baked goods (says the bf). Touristy, but it's worth it!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Yelper Kuanyu C. said it best. "If Chinese people are willing to stand in line for something, chances are, that something is great and totally worth the time, because we are some very impatient people."

Never in my life could I have imagined a Chinese bakery with over 1,000 reviews. Naturally, I NEEDED to see what the hype over the egg custard tarts was about... so when I walked up and saw a line that extended about 50 feet from the door and learned that some people have been standing in it for nearly 2 hours, I was more curious than ever, but slightly disheartened.

Luckily, a wonderful couple at the front of the line came to my RESCUE when they heard that I was visiting from New York and offered to pick up a couple of don-tots for me once they were inside! This was a hushed transaction, as either party could have been murdered by anyone waiting in line, and I'm forever in their debt.

The don-tots were still warm when they handed the bag to me, and I tore into them immediately. The crisp and flaky crust was the perfect vessel for a super thick layer of smooth, eggy custard! NOM!

They were delicious treat for sure... but would I wait in that line now that I know what they taste like?? ...Probably not.
author: Nicole C.

description:
This place is infamous for their egg tarts.
I was lucky for this place to be open when I came by. I was expecting a long wait but waited about 20-25 minutes. Everyone on line orders multiple amounts of egg tarts but they constantly bring out freshly baked ones. 

The egg tart is good, flaky crust and soft sweet egg custard. I would recommend to let it cool down a little if you're getting a fresh baked batch. It was difficult eating it when it was piping hot. Once it's cooled down a little, it was the ideal time to eat where it's not too hot or not too cold, just right.

They sell for $1.75 a piece which is pretty pricey. I wouldn't wait anymore than 30 minutes for these though. I would say if you find an egg tart that's just as good elsewhere, bring it home and reheat it a little. You will probably enjoy it just as much because a warm egg tart is much more enjoyable than a cold one.
author: Brian C.

description:
After walking miles around San Fran, I needed another snack. Taking a quick look at Yelp I realized that this place is a couple of blocks away and decided to head there.

Cheap and delicious pretty much sums it up; go go go!!
author: Dominique F.

description:
I was leaving SF on Chinese New year and had no choice but to swing by here right before my flight. 

It was crazy crowded. Waited in line for 1.5 hours.

Was it worth it though? Hell yes. 

Egg Tarts: Flaky crust, warm and not overly sweet custard.

Mochi with Red Bean: dusted with coconut shavings, not too sweet. So good.
author: Hannah S.

description:
After reading several reviews I decided to give this place a try and I did not get impressed at all. The egg Tart or Egg Custard was not bad but nothing to go crazy about.

Everyone talks about this item in a way that makes you think "my mouth will have a new life after trying this tart", but it was not as good, at least my expectations were a little higher.

I did like the staff members a lot, they were attentive, courteous and well-groomed. They were all very nice and made me feel welcome. 

I will give this place another try. Maybe it was just me that I went there with too many expectations.
author: Leslie R.

description:
If you know what you're doing this place is a gem! But as far as not being a regular or a tourist, you might seem a little confused. 

This place is known for their custard tart aka daan tat. Or however you would spell that in English. The crust is flakey and the custard is cooked to perfection and I can devour as many of these as possible. (But word to the wise, if you don't like flakey crust and you're into the biscuit crust, I won't judge. But you won't be getting that here) 

Besides the custard tarts, I also get their coconut custard and I love them. Not as good as you would get.. Oh in Hong Kong, but it'll do for not being thousands and thousands of miles away. 

Downside, parking is horrible. Sometimes the lines can get terribly long and they will be closed randomly so don't be upset when you see them closed on a random day.
author: Hepsie C.

description: Walked here after shopping at union squares. Last time I came here there was a long line but luckily there was no long this time. The egg tarts here are fresh and hot. Very delicious!
author: Anna W.

description:
This place is over rated. The line is always long and the price is high. In NYC you can easily find this kind quality of egg tart anywhere. True that sf people don't know how to make egg tart and I've tried a lot of bakeries who did a shady Job here. 

That being said, I still found some good egg tart shops. My fav is Lung Fung in inner Richmond area. In Chinatown ABC and Napoleon are pretty good. Golden gate egg tart skin is too thick and feels like a French tart rather than a Cantonese tart.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Yes, we waited an hour for the egg tarts. 

We went here years ago, and fell in love with the egg tarts, and had always wanted to go back after moving in the area. We were finally able to get them after 3 tries. Yes, the store closes a lot. The egg tarts are still delicious! No doubt about it. But I would skip the other stuff they sell. Just get the egg tarts.
author: Catherine Q.

description: Egg tarts are huge, fresh, moist, and delish!!! Best egg tarts I've tasted so far.  Worth the hour wait in line in the cold, chilly weather. :-)
author: Michelle H.

description:
Best dan tats I've ever had. YUMMMM.

My bf told me about this dan tat place and said it was amazing. I've had dan tats all my life and well...I've never had a craving for them (ex: whenever I eat dim sum, dan tats are definitely NOT something I plan to order).

There was a wait when I went (~3:00 pm) for about 20-30 minutes I would say. Since I'm kind of used to waiting in line for good food, this was definitely no big deal. The workers there were...well, pretty polite, I suppose. Typical see-lais :)

We didn't even eat them until 10 min later because we were pretty full from our meal. Well, it wasn't cold yet and SO delicious. Like I said earlier - best dan tats I've had. I like how they're not thin and the custard....oh man. 

I took a picture of the dan tats on my phone and every single time I look through my pictures and see it, I'm instantly craving for it. Yeeeeah. This isn't good since I don't live in the Bay anymore :((((
author: Cathy C.

description:
The owners are making too much money. They have lines going out the door on most days. 

Now that they are, they are taking vacation more and more. Living in San Francisco, it is hard to bring friends over here when they are closed for vacation almost every month. I had planned on bring a group of friends here a couple months ago and it was closed. Had the same plan on Friday and another vacation sign. 

Why don't they post their vacation calender on the door!
author: M C.

description:
You all know the golden rule on Yelp: The longer the wait, the better the food. And seeing how there was a 30 minute line for some cookies, I'd say Golden Gate Bakery is doing well for itself.

There might be a lot of people mulling around Chinatown, but the hustle and bustle around Golden Gate is apparent. You can tell the two ladies running the shop have their hands full here; so much so that they put up a sign prohibiting any and all pictures from being taken. Take that, tourists!

What really surprised me is how fresh everything was. The macaroons I got look like any other macaroon out there, but one bite changed all that. Slighty crunchy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside...it was the best .50 I ever spent.

I wanted to grab some more, but you know, that line...
author: Casey S.

description:
I'm sure everything has been covered by previous reviews, so I'll keep it short and sweet

1) Yes, we ARE standing in line 20 minutes to buy egg custard tarts. Yes, they are THAT worth it, even at $1.25 each.
2) Their other bakery items are really a hit or miss, with 80% of what I tried being a miss (apple roll, cupcake things, etc.) Stick with the egg tarts and check out some of the other bakeries for their specialties.
3) They close randomly. For weeks at a time. Safest to call first!
author: Andrew C.

description: Egg tarts are hot and fresh in the morning as soon as they open at 8 am! If you want the rolls and breads, they aren't ready until 11 am!
author: Jacqueline R.

description:
This place has the BEST EGG TARTS ever. After so many reviews I'm not sure if I need to say much except that these are delicious and must be consumed immediately while hot. 

The line was crazy long but we were able to cut it because my mom bought a ton of tea from the Ten Ren tea shop down the street from this place and the owners are friends. Which was cool. 

Besides the egg tart we had the coconut tart which I don't care much for because I'm not a huge fan of coconut. 

 I'm coming back this winter because my entire family still talk about the egg tarts.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I get it. I get why people love egg tarts.

Don't get me wrong.. I was never an egg tart hater. I always enjoyed it. But it was never anything special, nothing I'd go out of my way for.

Was it the flaky, buttery crust? Was it the fact that my egg custard was freshly baked, steaming, and warm? Was it the line that wrapped around the outside and spilled across to the store next door that told me this place was legit? All the personal recommendations from trusted foodie friends? Maybe. 

But above all, it was the egg custard filling itself. It's lighter than your standard egg tart. And this is surprising for me, someone who usually likes a denser, heaver dessert. But they have just the right subtly sweet flavor, combined with perfectly a soft yet slightly firm texture. 

Golden Gate Bakery: I'm sold. You've converted me. I'm now an egg tart lover.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Only here for the dantat which used to be .75cents back in the day and now it's $7or something. I just get the dozen for $20 because I can eat their egg tarts for days. Such yum. Much flavor. Literally as good as it gets as the egg is not too sweet or too bland and just the right texture while the bread is just the right amount of flake and bite. So good that they just open when they want and close when they want. No regular schedule, just gotta get lucky. The last time I visited was 830am Saturday morning and there was only 3 people ahead of me and we were all waiting as they JUST baked these bad boys. Unfffff sooo gewdddd.
author: Christal T.

description: I saw this bakery listed online as one of the top things to do/see in China Town, San Francisco but had forgotten about it when my family and I were walking around China Town that afternoon.  We just happened to noticed this young 20ish group with pink boxes and taking pictures.  I was kind of nosey and peaked over their shoulders and said "ohhhh...those are those famous egg tarts I've read about" and then asked where the bakery was at.  Luckily, it was just down the street we were on and we rushed over there.  The line was long, and we waited almost 35 minutes.  But, we were determined to get our hands on those egg tarts.  They had a sign that said they were on vacation and the door was locked.  But, you just have to be patient and they'll get to you.  Finally, we tried the egg tarts out and oh man, it was so good.  It was worth the wait and lived up to all the hype!  BEST egg tarts I've ever had!
author: Ernesto C.

description:
The BEST egg tarts of my life.
Got lucky and we only waited for about 15 - 20 minutes in line.
They were hot, a bit too hot, but delicious.
I also ordered mooncakes since it was Chinese New Year with were $7 each.
Very very good!

Worth the wait and this will be a must-go whenever I return to Chinatown!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Best c-town bakery. No doubt!

Over 1200 reviews for a cantonese bakery.  That says something!

Expect a long wait, and an occassional person trying to cut in line (please...you know what you are doing; it's sh*tty and shows you have a lack of manners...but enough of my soapbox).
author: Derek N.

description: I heard so many good reviews about the egg custard from this place that I had to stop by when i was in the area. Great egg custard, yes. The best, unfortunately no. It's crust has the right amount of flakiness and not too thick. The custard part was just good. Egg custards are my favorite so I might be a harsh critic but I've had my fair share. I've had some egg custards at Dim Sum places are some of them are just as good are slightly better than this one. The lines here can be a hit or miss. Unfortunately there was a line when I got here but it wasn't too bad. Just make sure you know what you want so you help that line move faster. Next time you are in the area try one for yourself and see what you think.
author: Nguyen L.

description:
definitely best egg custard in SF!!!! the line can be long but it goes by fast. They make the custards all throughout the day because its constantly being sold. so when you receive it, its steaming HOT! its actually alot tastier the next day lol.. 

WARNING: do not touch or smell the food in the counter until you bought it, otherwise the lady with long hair will cuss you out in cantonese! yes!!! cantonese hospitality at its best! HAHAHA!!

CASH ONLY!!
author: Steve S.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 2
Service: 3

Dropped by here around 12:30pm for some egg tarts after hitting up Good Mong Kok Bakery. Grabbed two tarts ($1.40 each). Only 2 people in line, so no wait.

The egg tarts were really good and probably the best I've had. Consistency was excellent, and a bit sweeter than typical ones I've had.
author: David L.

description: Hands down the best egg tart I've ever had.  I was lucky enough to be walking by when they were about to close up shop so no wait for me.  There were still a lot of people so they gave us "rations" and would only allow our group to buy six egg tarts :)
author: Mary V.

description:
I really waited 1 hour and 45 minutes in the cold for egg tarts. I'm so fat. -_-

Line was short but because they bake them fresh from the back bakery and people wanna order 8-10 boxes per order.. gawdd... we just stood there as people walking by questioned what the hell we were waiting for. After 30 min I wanted to leave so badly but didn't because I was also so close to the front..

After I got my box and walked down the street I took one bite into my egg custard. It was warm.. flaky.. delectable.. It sorta melted in my mouth. Well 1.40$ for one custard and 1 hour and 45 min later.. was it worth it? HELL NO!
If there was no line maybe I would've given this place 4 stars. Otherwise it gets more like a 2.5
Ladies in the front are extremely rude.. typical asian business.
author: Ames A.

description:
Yes, this place is hyped like crazy.

Yes, the lines can get super long if you don't come here early in the morning.

And yes, sometimes the bakery is closed seemingly arbitrarily.

BUT Golden Gate Bakery has some of THE BEST EGG TARTS I've ever had in in the Western Hemisphere. And believe me, that's the only thing that matters.

Make sure to eat your egg tarts (aka dan ta) when they're still warm. They taste amazing when fresh out of the oven but they can be disappointingly ordinary when cold...
author: Elaine W.

description:
The egg tarts are soooooo amazing! its definitely worth the wait. just be sure to order a couple of boxes to go. share them with your friends and family! not only that, their Moon Cakes are yummlicious as well. Seriously, Kee Wah Bakery has competition. 
The only downfall is... trying to get out of San Francisco after you completed your mission. Traffic is not your friend in SF.
author: Ames D.

description:
This is one of the only places that I have to say that the hype does live up to its name. I guess it really depends on how you like your dan tats. And this place is definitely the place to get your dan tat/custard tart/egg tart craving!

Well since Chinese New Years just passed this year, I figured the bakery would be open so I went by because the last three times I have attempted to go here, they were closed for vacation. Guess business is that good that they can close any time they want! So I guess that's a downside to this place. (minus one)

But other than that, I will gladly wait 30 minutes in line for some giant, hot, silky custard tarts! So good when it's freshly made, but still good when it isn't (just stick it back in your oven or eat it cold). The custard tart isn't too sweet, just a perfect texture that melts in your mouth. The crust is kind of oily and flakey, but nothing wrong with that. One bite, and you'll get crumbs from the crust but I think the important thing is the giant yellow center! 

It's 1.25 for one (pretty reasonable) and 15 for a dozen. Not bad, though I wish it was discounted if you were buying more. The ladies that work there, move fast so the line moves quick. Though if you don't speak Chinese, they might have a difficult time understanding you.
author: Joan T.

description:
I've tried to visit Golden Gate Bakery three times before and each time, the gates were locked and a small sign read "vacation."  But finally, this last time I visited, they were open.  At 9:00 a.m. on a Sunday morning, there was already a line coming out of the door about 15 people long.  It took about 20 minutes to get to the front and once there, everything moved quickly.  

There are three ladies that box and ring everything up in this tiny little shop.  I got a dozen egg tarts ($1.25/ each) and two moon cakes (starting at $6/ each).

The egg tarts were freshly made.  The filling was warm and creamy; the shell was crisp and flakey.  I appreciate the fact that they cut vents into their pink pastry boxes so that the egg tarts don't become instantly soggy.  The lady even put my box into a bag (which doesn't seem like much, but with a line out the door, it seems like many other businesses may have just handed me the ribbon-wrapped box without the bag.  

The moon cakes were fresh and very tasty as well.  The are quite large and have a thinner outside crust layer than other moon cakes I've had (meaning, more filling).  They were so good that my boyfriend, who usually doesn't like moon cake very much, liked them.

Notes:
-Parking in this area can be very difficult.  I got dropped off in front of the place so that I could stand in line while my boyfriend looked for parking.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Getting the perfect egg tart at Golden Gate Bakery is quite an adventure.

First, you have to stand in line along the super-busy Grant Ave next to all sorts of tourists and strangers, which--if unlucky--hugs all the way around the corner of the next intersection.

Second, you have to make it all the way to the front of line, where you will be informed that they've run out of egg tarts for the time being, and you need to come back thirty minutes later.

After that, you have to endure thirty minutes of teasing from the toxic aroma of all the other amazing pastries and goodies also being baked here (mm... moon cakes), all the while trying not to pay attention to all the angry mindless chatter going on. Especially hard to ignore are the ones where white people who spent maybe a year or two in China try to converse with the store owners in poor Mandarin, but I digress.

Finally, after thirty or more minutes, you pay your 15 dollars for your dozen (because the wait drives you crazy and makes you want to gobble down all twelve by yourself) and skip happily out of the bakery with your loot in hand.

PS: GGB's Egg tarts are best consumed while still hot, but they still taste victorious when cold; do not wear a black north face denali (i.e. The San Franciscan uniform) while consuming aforementioned egg tarts, because the crust will crumble like the pangaea with every bite because this is one of the few places that still get the croissant crust part right.
author: Scott S.

description:
One of the most coveted egg tarts known to man.

Always a line, so expect at least a 30 minute wait minimum. I was there Christmas eve and waited an hour. I was committed to getting these for a family dinner that evening. $1.60 per tart. But with the amount of time you wait, might as well order a dozen. I got two!

Because of the extremely huge turnover rate, their tarts come out piping hot and fresh. The crust is flaky and buttery, the custard is creamy and smooth. Just the right amount of sweetness and the perfect ratio of crust to custard. These are best enjoyed fresh! Not really that great next day, even with toaster oven heating.

Oh, and this place is notorious for being closed for "vacation" whenever they feel like it. I've been here 4 times, and they have been closed twice. But with how much egg tarts they're selling, I'm sure they are rolling in the dough...literally.
author: Minh N.

description: A friend brought us to this well known place, giving us the caveat that in the past it's always been closed whenever she stopped by. But it was open! The line was ridiculously long though, which does show that the community really likes the pastries. The place itself is one of the sketchier looking bakeries I've ever been to, but the ladies that were working spoke canto, mandarin, and English so it was easy enough to buy. Half a dozen egg tarts for $10.50, but they were warm and fresh even at 6pm on a Sunday night and actually could taste the egg which isn't the case at many a dim sum place or other bakeries: one of the more authentic egg tarts I've had in a year.
author: Lucy G.

description:
Freaking A!!!!!!!!!!!!

 Came here on Sunday around 5:00pm. By the time I was out the door it was 8:00pm. Yes that's correct I stood in line for about 3 hours for these egg tarts. 

The reason why it takes so long is they only make small batches at the time. Then all the asian people (myself included) want to order 1-2 dozen each batch only serves about 1-2 customers. Then you have to wait until they make another batch

The dan tat comes out very hot. You can see the steam coming out of it. Very smooth and not too much of a egg taste. The perfect balance of sweetness compliments the flaky crust. 

I also got their coconut tart. It's pretty much thick cake with mounds of coconut over a tart shell. Don't forget their mooncakes, which are pretty pricey for around $7.00-$9.00 for one mooncake. 

Price: $1.25 for one or $15.00 dozen. Parking is a pain so park in one of the structures. 

It's good but prob not 3 hours wait good..

Note: they say they close at 8:00 but if there are lines they may stay open till past 9 or 10
author: Cindy W.

description:
I know everyone is going to rave about the dan tat (egg custards) and you probably came here knowing this....

BUT THEY ARE THAT GOOD. AND I AM NOT SORRY FOR EMPHASIZING THIS.

Really though, the crust is flaky and thick. The custard is the best part. It really has a nice consistency and texture that you do not normally get in regular dan tats. The flavor is also great! Pretty life changing I must admit. 

Probably the most expensive I have ever had at $1.50 a piece but it really is worth it.

Okay, enough about the dan tat. The other stuff is also pretty solid! Standard stuff at a Chinese bakery but the quality is a bit higher. My personal favorites are the pineapple bun, bbq pork bun and the curry buns. 

The only down side is that they always go on breaks at random times. It is the hardest to try and get some whenever I crave them. Like seriously, they go on breaks for like weeks...and I am just left sad and hungry without them.

Anyway... while I have been writing this review... It just made me want to go visit soon.  /cry
author: Christopher Y.

description: In my opinion, Golden Gate Bakery has some of the best egg tarts out there.  It's nothing fancy...small hole-in-the-wall shop in Chinatown.  I always drop in when I'm in town.  However, they have been closed the last few times that I visited San Francisco (hence the 1-star deduction).  Luckily, there is no shortage of other culinary delights in the city.
author: Cindy W.

description: Seen all the reviews on here and being the foodie that I am I had to try it. The famous custard tart was pretty much eggs in a tart! Not good at all!!! Super eggy. I read a previous review that said to try the coconut tart so I got one and boy were they right that was super yummy!!! Not worth the drive & time to find parking.
author: Suzette P.

description: Dan tat is one of my favorite Chinese desserts so I naturally came here during my vacation. For $1.40 per custard, it was pricier than I was used to, but who cares?? These dan tat are so good. I luckily didn't have to wait in line to get these little things in my belly. It was fresh out the oven and still warm when I devoured it. The crust was so buttery and flaky, and the egg filling was sweet and aromatic. I'm drooling thinking back to that wonderful day... I wish I bought more to bring back home :(
author: Helen D.

description:
I was checking out Chinatown and simply had to try one of their egg tarts. I'd read (on Yelp obviously!) that they are really good and I had to get me one!

I got there and, as expected, it was pretty busy. I was lucky in that there was no line but it was a little bit crowded in there. 

Anyway, I got my egg tarts and they were really good. Golden Gate Bakery is not just about egg tarts though, they have a range of other Chinese desserts that look delicious and cheap too! 

This place is definitely worth a visit.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Best egg tarts I have ever ate! 

I'm so glad they were open this time I came versus being on vacation. I've heard so many great things so I made my fiancé get in line with me when I saw they were open. The line was pretty slow as it was moon cake season. Those must be pretty good as I saw people ordering multiple boxes. Too bad I've never been a fan. 

Finally an hour passes, and I was finally able to order my egg tarts! Warm as they're freshly baked and their crust is really nice. A must stop when visiting San Fran!
author: Wendy L.

description: I came for the "best egg tart" and left a believer! Best I've ever had. The raspberry pie was decent; it had nuts or something crunchy. There was a line out the door, but as soon as the next batch of egg tarts came out, the line went fast.
author: William L.

description:
Golden Gate wasn't the most AMAZING Chinese pastry I've been to; it was more of a "alright" place. 

*Food*
I tried the egg custard tarts and the black bean filled bread, which were both pretty good I must say. The tart was crispy on the outside and the was soft and tender on the inside. I went right when it opened in the morning so I guess it tasted better because it came straight out of the oven. Though I must say, $1.40 for an egg tart is quite expensive if you compare it with that of the other bakeries... The black bean was also really good too. It wasn't as sweet as I hoped it would be, but it can definitely pass for my standards (as a true Taiwanese) :) 
P.S. Bring cash with you!! They don't accept cards AT ALL.

*Service*
To be perfectly honest, the service wasn't all that great. Even though I was their first customer, the owner treated me as if there was a long line behind me and she just wanted to get me over with. I don't know if it's just me, but I didn't feel welcomed there. 

*Environment*
The bakery itself is kinda cramped, compared to Eastern Bakery, so the line is constantly going out of the store. The bakery is also pretty easy to spot. It'll be on your left hand side if you enter from the entrance of Chinatown. It's only like a block, or maybe less than a block from Eastern.

Overall, not so happy about the service, but the pastries here are great!

Happy Feasting!
author: Amy T.

description:
I have been trying to eat an egg tart from Golden Gate Bakery since the two years I moved out to live in the Bay Area. Every time I was actually free to go, they would always be closed. Every. Time. I eventually discovered a site (http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/) that is updated at noon DAILY to tell me when Golden Gate was opened, and it was pretty much always accurate.  My feening for the taste of potentially the best egg custard I'd ever tasted grew bigger and bigger as the days went by.. 

Then finally, FINALLY, I went on a day where they happened to be opened and lord oh heaven the line was only a handful of people out the door. As I was waiting in line, I didn't see any of the egg tarts on display and I swore I thought I went crazy thinking they sold out or something - HOW CAN IT BE!? But luckily, they just serve it hot out of the oven so they don't display it on the storefront - oh you sneaky bakery owners you. 

And then oh.. the taste, that first bite...into the fluffy, hot, flaky, light egg tart...(there is a pool of drool on my desk now) it was everything I wished for and more. For better of worse, I only bought one. Better because it lived up to the hype and was well worth the wait to finally try the best egg tarts evar. For worse because as impeccably delicious as it was, and as painful as it was to have only one serving, I would have not stopped at eating no less than 5 if there were 5+ tarts in front of me. Extremely worth it for all the little Asian kids who were tricked into eating any other Chinese bakery egg tart in their life..it's all been a lie.

But seriously they have stupid hours and when they are 'closed,' I am imagining the owners secretly sitting in the back of the bakery, eating all the tasty egg tarts to their hearts' content while the rest of the world suffers and wimpers from missing out on the beauty that is Golden Gate Bakery egg tarts.
author: Allie Y.

description:
I have never liked egg tarts. When I think of them, I think of soft crusts (not in a good way) and cold, dense, eggy custard. Despite my inherent bias, one bite into the egg tart at Golden Gate Bakery completely changed my mind. The egg tart was warm, fresh out of the oven. The crust was delicate and flakey, somewhat like a napoleon. The egg custard was soft, silky, and not too sweet. It was by far the best (non-portuguese style) egg tart I've ever had, and the first I have actually enjoyed. After trying the egg tarts at Golden Gate Bakery, I can now say I am an egg tart fan.   

My Advice
1) Expect a line - Don't expect to get in and out of there quickly. 
2) Buy more than 1 - you won't regret it.  
3) Bring cash. No cards accepted. 
4) Speak up when it's your turn. It's a mad house in there. Don't expect other customers will politely make sure you've been served first.

**UPDATE** 
I have docked a star for their unprofessional, unreliable hours. 

Recently, I wanted to serve GG's delicious egg tarts for dessert at a dinner party. On Fridays, they are supposed to be open until 8pm, but when I arrived at 6pm, they were inexplicably closed. Adding insult to injury, I had rented a Zip car explicitly for that trip. Very frustrating. (I ended up going to nearby AA Bakery for my egg tarts.) 

Apparently my frustration is nothing new. I have learned about a website where you can check whether GG Bakery is really open, regardless of their posted hours. It's sad that there's a need for a site like this. They're lucky that they have some very big, tech savvy fans.

Check it out here: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com
author: Cindy T.

description:
Hot fresh egg tarts are the hype here? Is it worth it? If you like Egg tarts and like the extra flakiness of the pastry and the hot centered huge creamy custard you'll definitely love their egg tarts... BUT... It must be eaten while it's hot. Once it cools down, it doesn't tastes as good. Just pop them in the oven again, and it's good to eat again. $1.30 a piece but you just got to try it once.

We also tried their coconut tarts, raisin bread, peanut and sesame mochi, almond cookies. Everything else was just average but very fresh.My mother loved their Peanut sesame mochi. She said it was so fresh and soft you can literally taste the freshness of the fresh ground peanuts. 

I love their old school wrapping. Wrap them in those pink boxes and tie them with that Pink string. Overall the egg tarts quality, the ambiance, the customer service attitude, and the old school box wrapping totally reminds me of Hong Kong. For a few minutes, I had a deja vu experience.

Driving down SF Chinatown, We see this LONG LONG line at the bakery. I lined up to see what the hype was about.  After waited 40 minutes, my family decided to go to dinner. I got out of the line to lock the door, thinking about giving up. But since my family decided to go down the block for dinner, I tried asking the "nice" lady if I can get back in line (I was only out of the line about 2 minutes) She was so nice in telling me where to go for good foods while I was in line, but when I asked if I can get back in space, she said "I think you lost your space" aarrggg... B*tCh! But I guess I understand.. but the least she can do was ask how many I wanted and she can order it for me and I can pay her back. 
So to make a long story short, the first night, I didn't get any. When I got up to the line they wouldn't take my order of 6 egg tarts, Minimum order, 2 dozens.(Apparently they had closed for 2 months to go back to Hong Kong, And that was the first night they opened, and they had very high expectations. Other days, I'm sure you can get 1 or 2 or 6 egg tarts)
  Uhh, what?? They yelled at me for touching one of their bread on the counter that was covered with plastic bag, How the heck am I going to know if it's soft or what is it if I don't touch it.
The second night, we returned to Chinatown, This time it was less people in line, The ladies recognized me as I whisper to my mom to say that lady yelled at me last night and I yelled back.. lol.. Must be the magic of Mom, but since we had to wait for the egg tarts to be done baking, they ha long, friendly conversation with Mom and I. What a 300 degrees turn in customer service!

Parking sucks as most of you know. Best bet to go later in the evenings to see if you can find street metered parking.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
People rave about the dan tats from here.  Even my Boston friends know about this place.  My friend Jolo brought me one of these at our Christmas dinner and I thought, "it's good, but I wouldn't wait for this."  *shrugs*

But a friend was visiting from NYC and really wanted some.  So there we are. Me who said I wouldn't wait for this and my bf who absolutely hates waiting in lines.  We kept quiet since our friend suggested that we get some pearl tea while we wait.  

We waited over 90 minutes.  Finally we get in.  There are tons of other things you can order (mooncakes, pineapple buns, taro buns, cookies, etc.).  But of course, the most famous are those pastries filled with egg custard.  We order a dozen (btw, it's not cheaper if you buy a dozen, but just do it since you've waited in line for this long) and have the older Chinese ladies wrap them the boxes in the red ribbon.  I can tell they do this all day because their fingers are red!

My friend was so excited, she burned herself taking the first bite of a don tat fresh from the oven and was saying how incredible it was.  So by then I was like fine, I'll have a bite.  Wow.  The outside crust was perfectly flaky whereas the inside custard was perfectly sweet and soft and smooth.   Yup, this really is the best dan tat I've ever had!  You have to have it fresh from the oven though!
author: Chantal T.

description:
First time trying this much raved about place & it didn't disappoint. Not that I'm a huge fan of Chinese baked goods or anything but it is fun to be in a place where the more experienced line-waiting crowd is recommending you all these items to try. 

We got the signature custard tart and the "wifey" cookie. The Chinese couple ahead of us translated what the mango flavored flaky cookie meant & that alone was one of the most charming surprises. 

In short...Line moves quick so don't be threatened! And people in line for pastries are always the friendly, excited types so definitely can't go wrong here :)
author: Gina M.

description:
Egg Custard Tarts are DE-LI-CIOUS!!!  So fresh, so creamy, so amazing when they're warm (still very tasty when they're not).  A dozen for $15 - and trust me, get a dozen because they will go fast!

The melon cake thingy is really yummy, too...

FYI: Cash Only
author: Rose A.

description: I'm not really into Don Tot but with all this rant & raving ... I just had to try it again ! I had it once before & can't even remember if I liked it. This time I decided to purposely give it a try. If course the trick it into catch them when they are open. I have figured out they usually for certain open for the few days near holidays ... I.e the days or week around thanksgiving, chistmas, new year. The lines can be crazy but I was able to catch them when the line was much shorter - weekday early afternoon! The crust is amazing, not greasy like others & the egg custard itself was not tainted with excess of sugar! Is it the best in SF ? Yes it is! Is worth the line for at least one time & at about $2.00 a pop. I would say that the crust is the best I have ever had or equivalent to the really deal - in HK ! At times they will only stand at the door, take ur order, then take ur $$, & hand you ur pink box of piping hot egg custard! Seems a bit sketchy w/the 'on vacation' sign still on the door & half lite interior, but it's all legit!
author: Jay S.

description:
Only thing stopping me from giving Golden Gate Bakery 5 stars is the fact that their egg tart doesn't blow me away for 5 stars. 

1. Now their hours are inconsistent, so good luck finding them open, but when they are, their buns, pastry and egg tarts are made fresh.
2. Try out their "lo po bang" which I say is comparable to their taste of the egg tart **personal preference
3. Reason why their egg tarts taste so damn good is cause they use epic bacon oil to bake from scratch. *well something my mom told me, don't know whether to believe it but mama knows best and the fatter the better tasting of course
4. If you do make it out here and wait in the line, you better make sure you're buying in bulk. Buying a few things is probably not worth the time! Be a pal and make other people in line hate you and buy egg tarts for your friends.
author: Sam K.

description: Yes.  I am willing to wait inline for an egg custard pie.
author: Lea M.

description:
Wandering around Chinatown with a friend who was shopping for cheap jewelry, I asked myself what I wanted out of Chinatown. 

The answer was, and always is, something tasty!

Checked the yelp app and found the Golden Gate Bakery nearby.  It was open and the line was only about six people deep.  

You have to order as soon as you get to the counter.  We ordered some of the famous egg tartlets, paid (about $1.40/tartlet) and zoomed out the door.

The tartlets were still warm.  Distinctly eggy, but sweet.  The crust was buttery and flakey.  I don't normally consider egg the taste of a dessert, but this was really good.  We were very glad we stopped by to try.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Sitting in City Lights Bookstore, realizing how late it was getting, wanting to get over to Golden Gate Bakery before noontime hell broke loose...

We made it, but just barely.

Recently out of the oven meant a soft, warm, messily flaky tart that was so huge I almost regretted my recent gorging of Good Mong Kok pork buns (but not really because that place rocks).  This is not the best egg tart I've ever had, but it was close.  It had that light yellow color that actually looks like eggs and not Yellow No. 5, a light crust that didn't overwhelm the custard but managed to still hold it in, and a pleasantly eggy flavor.
author: Hannah E.

description:
My friend brought me an egg tart from here. It was pretty good! 
The custard was really good and wasn't too sweet. The tart was probably one of the better ones I've tried. It was really light and flaky!
author: Kristy K.

description: I spent my entire lunch break waiting in line for a dozen dan tats and although they made me mouthgasm a little, I don't think it's worth the wait. Especially since I'm so intolerant of the rude pushy crowd that I tend to encounter in this area and cuz GGB closes down randomly, so it's a crapshoot. I'll still gladly eat them if someone else gets them :)
author: Jenny Q.

description:
Listed on the 2012 Big Eats for a very good reason: the egg custards. 

As everyone else on Yelp is saying, this place has THE BEST egg custards I've ever had. There always seems to be a line out of the door, but they are very quick with the orders so you'll be relishing in eggy goodness in no time.
author: Ada C.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS EVER!!!!! 

Why? 

- flakiest, butter crust
- smooth and silky egg
- the long lines of locals and visitors alike speak for themselves the popularity
- bc I'm Chinese and have had enough egg tarts to know when it's a good one

Also, because they can afford to shut down multiple times a year for vacay. 

Con: the price keeps going up :( I remember when it used to be .75c and now it's over $1.25?

Definitely give it a try and come back to tell me what you think!
author: Sharon G.

description:
A warm freshly-baked  "dan-tat" (egg tart) from here can easily take a Chinatown visit to the next level. If you like 'em fluffy, semi-sweet, with a bed of flaky crust, you need to try this at least once. I actually prefer my dan-tat's smaller and sweeter, so I'm not very keen on enduring lines of 30min+ for something that I just "like" not love. 

On the other hand, what makes me a HUGE fan of Golden Gate Bakery is their Coconut Macaroons. Those little sweet caramelized piles of shaved coconut, I lust for the perfectly crunchy edges and the soft flecks of tropical goodness pillowing my taste buds into an effervescent dream-like euphoria...

*ahem* I digress...buy a dozen and get back in line...because when you finish them all, you'll hands-down, guaranteed-or-your-money-back want more.
author: Nick W.

description:
The egg tarts are a definite must buy. Whenever I wait in line for this place, and yes there is ALWAYS a line and its unavoidable, some tourists are always in line and are curious to what is so great about this place. I always recommend the egg tarts because its what they're known for. They're quite pricey for one stupid egg tart, but it tastes like heaven. I kid you not, it melts in your mouth. They're $1.80 believe. I've tried something else from the bakery and it just can't be compared to the egg tarts. 

The line is pretty ridiculous. It's about a 30 minute wait to get in and if you're lucky, it'll be shorter. This place is always on vacation as well. They probably go on vacation every month with the amount of money they make lol. But I've also heard they have really bad health issues in the back of the bakery, but no regrets. Their egg tarts are a must buy and I never have to use the bathroom after eating anything from there.

TIP: Take advantage when you're buying because it's going to be a long wait again if you want to buy more. So buy as much as you can.
author: Vernice T.

description: Nice and tasty egg tarts but the wait isn't justified. I waited around 45 minutes as they cook by batches and the people in front were ordering MULTIPLE dozens... Should put a limit on how many you can get or make a line for those wanting less than a dozen.
author: Nghia N.

description:
Excellent egg tart!

amazingly this time the line isn't that long!

We also get moon cake, and we tried 2 so far
   Red dates with double egg yolks - not my kind of thing, i think not sweet enough but the skin is good
   green tea with egg yolk - just hint of green tea

Skin and egg yolk were yummy, but not sure about the non-traditional fillings.  We will have to try the traditional lotus filling one soon
author: Coco L.

description:
I stopped here because it had the longest line and I had asked a couple nearby shop owners and they directed me here.  Everything here is about a buck or a buck and a half and I spent over $30 so you can imagine how many treats I took home with me to Monterey to share with friends and family.  

I was looking for BBQ Pork Buns and Coconut Bread (that's what I call it at least, ovalish rectangular looking bread stuffed with buttery coconut filling sometime baked with sesame seeds on top) but I didn't get any here... they didn't have BBQ Pork Buns for one and I was too distracted with everything else to ask for Coconut Bread.  I love trying everything once... and I don't mean that just with food... wink wink.

Everything was solid but nothing WoWed me.   I wish I knew what the name of the treats were... Swiss Roll Cake, traingle guys stuffed with Pineapple jam and Raspberry and a couple savory items...
author: Shiho F.

description: Egg Tart - yes, it actually is the best egg tart I've had so far.
author: Jon P.

description:
Without no line up on a weekday morning, we decided to try this place out and find out if it lived up to the hype. 

It was Mid Autumn Festival the day we went, so they were prepping the day with boxes and boxes of moon cake. I was surprised there was no line up.

They were over a $1 each which is a bit pricier than normal. The one mistake we made was not eating the egg tart right away and instead ate it a couple hours later. 

To give it full credit, after a couple of hours, the flaky crust was still light and thin, and a buttery goodness flavour. The custard part was a good sweetness, with more custard than egg flavour. 

Was it the best egg tart I've ever had? No. Would I have waited in line for it? Probably not. But it was still a pretty good egg tart.
author: Vincci L.

description:
I've been going here off and on for the last 15 years whenever I'm in San Francisco.

It's right in the heart of Chinatown (old Chinatown) on Grant, so no parking but easy to find walking.

What it's really known for is the egg custards, featured on the picture of their Yelp profile.

But they also have coconut and red or black bean moon cakes. Which are hit and miss, sometimes great, sometimes so so.
