It's cheap (about $1 - $2 each)

On weekends a line can form, so if you don't want to wait 15 or 20 minutes, it's better to look for another bakery.

BRING CASH (they don't take credit cards or debit cards)
author: Jonah H.

description:
First time I tried a Dan Tat and wow are they good! They are a sweet egg tart; so kind of like quiche meets creme brulee. They are served warm, and ready to eat. You got to try one or five!

The line is very long (45min is average), the english of the staff can sometimes be broken and this place likes to close randomly. But I love them anyway! It's all part of the charm!

Their customers are so loyal they created a website dedicated to telling others if the bakery is open or not. That is how awesome this place is! I know no other business in the world where the customers took it upon themselves to make a website, Facebook, and Twitter and update it daily - welcome to San Francisco!
author: Chris S.

description:
I've always liked Cantonese egg tart better than Portuguese ones, but I think Golden Gate's recipe took the strength both styles. 

The custard center has the creamy steamed egg texture, which I believe is very nostalgic to a lot of you. But what makes the egg tart so special is the perfect quality and size of the pastry part. It has the puff-pastry-like layers instead of the shortbread kind. Portuguese egg tarts also have them but those are usually way to thick. In comparison, Golden Gate Bakery has the perfect bread-to-egg ratio. 

I know the long line can be discouraging, but trust me, it moves fast. Little bit over $1 for a perfect bite...it's worth it! Don't make your friends do pick-up for you, they're the best right out of the oven!
author: Cherry H.

description:
Egg. Tarts. To. Die. For

Warning: 

Super ridiculous long line (but I've never encountered it), but Worth the freaking wait !

Order 3 dozen and devour the first dozen because its best while hot & fresh. (Strategically divide and save the other 2 dozen for YOUR OWN enjoyment throughout the week .. don't share them .. you'll regret it)

Please contain yourself by keeping orgasmic eye rolling gestures and moaning sounds to a minimum .. you are in a tourist hot spot.
author: Brenda C.

description: My second time to visit SF and my friend told me about this store's egg tarts. I was suspicious at first because I'm not a egg tart fan. And to be honest, even if I were in a bakery, I rarely bought one. So I wasn't even plan to visit this place at first and another reason was because the thanksgiving holiday and I found that this store's owner vacation a lot (?). But, just as my last day to leave SF, I decided to give it a try and to see if they open. I arrived around at 8:30 but they hadn't open yet ( even though Yelp states they open at 8:00 ). The owner told me to come ten minutes later, and as I finished my breakfast around 8:50, there's already a line outside the store. I spent another 30min in line and bought a dozen of egg tarts. I have to say, IT IS OWESOME!!!!! I never had egg tart like this one before. The egg tart is crispy and soft. Even my boyfriend was amazed by the GOOD FLAOR. I felt regret now just bought a dozen, next time will have two dozen for sure!!!!!
author: Ying-Tzu C.

description:
Just thinking about the egg tart is making me want one now! I have to say like every other reviewer this is one of the best egg tart I ever had! Nice and warm, flaky, and just enough sweetness in each bit!

I also really enjoyed their BBQ pork bun as well, should have grabbed more for breakfast. It's okay I'll make my lovely husband go stand in line for about 20 mins to grab me some more.
author: Kim N.

description:
Uh... yeah... the line speaks for itself. When you see tourists and non-chinese people line up for something in Chinatown, then you know that place is cracking!

Egg tarts(don tat) and wifey cookies(lo poh beng) are my favorites. They make it soooooooooo goooooooood! The crust for the egg tarts are so flaky and the filling is so creamy. It melts in your mouth and you can't help but get another one. The wifey cookie is also so flaky and rich and has the best texture to it, other stores cannot compare to this place at all.

Be prepared to spend a bit of time in line, but trust me and all these other yelpers ('yelpers' is not a word?!?!) ... its worth every second.
author: Benjamin W.

description: I'm a fan of Golden Gate.  Even though the lines can be ridiculous and the owner goes on vacation really often and really unpredictably, I am still a fan.  I've never waited in line for the egg tarts - honestly they aren't amazing enough to warrant that when there are other decent options a block up on Stockton, where you can shove your way up to the counter with all the other Chinese folks and get a cold one.  The egg tarts are good though, always warm, extremely buttery, and so flaky it's actually fun to be messy while eating.  When I happen to be on Grant, see Golden Gate's actually open, and see there's no line, then yes, I am getting myself an egg tart (or a box full...) from Golden Gate Bakery.  What no one talks about is their moon cake.  No one makes moon cakes like Golden Gate Bakery.  The line stretches down the block the few weeks before Mid-Autumn Festival every year, because their moon cakes are dang good.  My mom always gets the coconut and the five flavor ones.  Pre-order them at the counter for pick-up at a later date.  They usually run out of those.
author: Tracey L.

description:
best egg tart ever.. enough said.  You must stop by and pick up one regardless of the wait.  I had to stop by and grab one before i left too!

Hard to find parking though since it's in chinatown so have someone wait in line while the other finds parking.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Seriously the best chinese bakery I've ever been to. ..why? Three words:

EGG CUSTARD TART!

mmmmm delicious. .first of all, I love egg!  That's why I got so drawn to this bakery to try it out.  I'm really not into super mushy stuff, but this I can definitely make an expection for.  When you take a bite of this delicious and savory and moist and warm custard you feel like you're in heaven (seriously!)  I've never tasted anything so delicious ever!  Too bad I only ordered 2 thinking that would be enough (also because we were going to eat dinner shortly).  I should have gotten more to go so I could eat it the next day. . .

So the next time I went I made sure I orderd half a dozen PLUS 2 for the road...call me a pig, but these are seriously so delicious that when you come up just to get these, you HAVE to have extra leftover for the day after.  They had other good pastries (don't know the names of the stuff) but everything was really good.  And I really liked how everything was nice and warm so if you wanted to eat it right away, you weren't biting into cold hard bread. :P

I definitely suggest you come here if you're in SF, but beware of the line!  It's super long and people push you around because it's cramped inside the bakery.  I'd suggest you have one or two people wait in line while the rest of your group wait outside or go look inside the tiny shopping area next to the bakery.

ps. there is garage parking about a couple blocks away - it's INSANE to find parking right near the bakery!
author: Grace K.

description:
#61 on the 2011 7x7 List: Egg Custard Tart

Everybody loves egg tarts, especially if you're from Hong Kong or if you're Jason S.  Golden Gate Bakery has the best that I've tasted in _America_.  They're big, they're flakey, the custard is firm and eggy, light in flavor, and the color looks deliciously Just Right.

Mindful that the store is smaller than a matchbox (they seem to be hoarders of boxes), filled mostly with baked goods and supplies, the line at the store can get super long. There's no hype, it's real.  Really good.  They can't all be idiots!! 

When I came here around 12:30pm on a week day, I was the only one in the shop.  I was snickering about the suckers in long lines for this place, but as soon as I got my order in, the store filled up with people and a couple of them were standing outside.  Holy crap!

I bought two daan tats - one for me to devour right there while it's hot and tasty, and one to take back to J...5 hours was too long to wait for J while the daan tat keeps calling me.  

I walked two miles round-trip for daan tat and was it worth every step?  Yes!  I totally regret that I didn't get a dozen.  Ugh!!!

2011 edit:  8am - no lines!  The egg tarts are of the same great quality.  They also have Mooncake when it's in season - the Pineapple with Yolk ($7.50) - awesome!
author: Winnie L.

description: Tiny little shop that pumps out major goodness. Often if you're heading here in the summer, they're on vacation. When they aren't on vacation, expect a long line to try their infamous dan tats (egg tarts). Very flaky crust and the custard filled to the top edges of the crust with the perfect consistency. Yum! I haven't been here in ages, but their prices have consistently been increasing. Last I heard, they were $1.40/tart. Definitely not the $0.35/tart when I was growing up. Craziness!
author: Kitty K.

description:
Egggcellent egg tartz.  Almost as good as HK.  Very lardy.

The filling is better than the pastry.
author: J S.

description: The line was pretty long but the EGG TARTS WERE SO WORTH IT.  I really don't know what else to say other than try it.  I liked how it tasted and the crust was good too.  Not too expensive but definitely worth the try!
author: Lydia K.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS EVER!  Trust me once you try GGB egg tarts, you will realize all the other tarts you thought tasted pretty good is actually nasty. lol  Crust is flaky n buttery and egg custard is light and so creamy that it jiggles.  And its always piping hot n fresh!  

Don't let the long lines discourage you-those ladies that work there don't play around. They keep the lines moving quick! Price may seem crazy at about $1.35 each but it's worth it!!  Get at least a dozen!!
author: Cathy M.

description:
My friend and I visited Golden Gate Bakery this past weekend to try their famous egg tarts...waited around 45 min on sunday just to get 1 egg tart each cause we were going to get dinner after. Honestly...they're good, but since I'm from SoCal...these were not better than 85c bakery. I wouldn't wait again for these. I did like the crust because it was nice and flakey, but the tart was too eggy for my taste. 
On a brighter note, we ended up sharing a coconut tart and we liked that better than the egg tart! I recommend that if you're getting the egg tart, try the coconut one too!

Parking...sucks on a weekend! Even on sundays you have to pay for the meters that run from 12-6pm usually. FYI, 25 cents gives you 5 minutes. 

Saw Tara Reid walking around the area! haha
author: Briii T.

description: One of the best egg tarts I have had.  Best in san francisco for sure.  The egg tarts have the right mix between custard and crust. The crust is also flakey, not the hard cookie like crust.  If you are willing to wait in line for a good egg tart I would recommend coming here.
author: Richard M.

description:
this place has been closed for like 2 months =(   waiting for the place to reopen for some delicious dan tat!!

For latest update on when they wil reopen, check this page!!

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Is-the-Golden-Gate-Bakery-Open-Today/394882013908745
author: Casey N.

description:
This is where you want to be if you are craving dan tat (egg tart) in the bay!

San Francisco's china town is the largest outside of asia. So, as you can probably imagine, this chinatown is teeming with little chinese bakeries that sell a wide variety of buns, cakes, and other little goodies. Still, I only visit two bakeries here because they are THE BEST. Golden Gate Bakery is one of them. 

The dan tat here is pretty much the stuff of legend and you would be hard-pressed to find a better egg tart (unless...you know...you're in china or something). So just save yourself the trouble and come here already, yeah? Cool.
author: John B.

description:
I will give it at least 4.5 out of 5 for the egg tarts but their attitude got to be -5!!! We are visiting from Canada and my aunt was kind enough to line up and wants us to try one of the popular food in SF and after waiting over 40 mins lining up outside their door, the lady that took the order actually slammed the door in her face because she addressed her incorrectly. My aunt addressed her "Pao Pao" which was out of respect because she look elderly and common for Asian to address elderly that way.
The lady lectured her before she took the order from my aunt.
Bad name for SF Chinatown and bad impression for visitors.....
author: Tom C.

description:
$15 for a dozen of the best egg tarts ever! It is so worth the wait in line inside this small bakery, they are always busy and appear to be doing very well that they go on vacations all the time. The store looks really cramped and they have a bunch of racks and inventory crammed and all over the place, they have a small display area with their eggtarts, pastries- including cake rolls, custard cream pastries and a few others. 

The eggtarts are slightly sweet to perfection, soo good especially when fresh and warm, they melt in your mouth and the yummy flakey crust gets everywhere so beware especially when eating these in the car! They called them "top secret" when my fiance called in to ask if they still had some. So now it's a joke when we order them. LOL!

The last time we were there, a couple of newbies came in and asked me and my mother-in-law what the commotion was all about. Of course we recommended the eggtarts and he ordered some and definitely agreed with the hype! Get ready to walk though, there's never any parking nearby at all! Park in the parking garage near the park, real close to most Chinatown stores and bakeries.
author: Jaclyn A.

description:
Really, I just find this place hyped up, especially by the local tourist companies. There are other bakeries around that serve just a good goodies as this spot, and it is cheaper and no long-ass wait. 

I admit, I have not tried the egg tarts, but my cousin, who is a local, has and she admits, she had better elsewhere. Bad service is expected in Chinatown, but it's not worth it with the wait.

Oh, there is no taking pictures either. I got shot down for that...=/ Oh well.
author: Alice C.

description: Get here early! Their egg tarts sell out fast. I'm not usually a huge fan of egg tarts despite growing up Cantonese, but the ones at this bakery are the BEST I've ever had!
author: Irene P.

description:
What a minute...they are OPEN?!?! WOWWW....

So i finally was able to make it in to Golden Gate Bakery after the other 9 failed attempts...I definitely have the same complaints:
1. They're hardly ever open
2. for $1.25 per dan ta (as of 12/24/2011), it is definitely on the more expensive side...and getting more and more pricey each time..

HOWEVER..even though the egg custard has changed quite a bit since 7 years ago..it is still freaking good.

The crust is not as flaky as I remember, but the custard to crust portion has increased dramatically. THERE IS SO MUCH EGG CUSTARD IN THESE THINGS...

Usually there's a line, but it goes fast. I was pretty lucky to catch a break in the crowd and get in then out with a dozen egg tarts. Nothing like getting egg tarts straight out of the oven.

P.S. To the lady who was smacking your child upside the head because he got an Angry Bird's beanie and thus prevented you from buying 3 additional egg tarts...you really shouldn't measure the price of your child's happiness with the number of dan ta's you could have bought. Iono. Just my opinion.
author: Jennifer S.

description: The line at this place can be long but some of it is definitely worth the wait. We got a dozen macaroons and a half dozen egg tarts. Have to say wasn't a big fan of the egg tarts but the macaroons were pretty good! Note that it's cash only and they close frequently without notice. They have a website that tells you if it's opened or not. Link: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com. Definitely recommended!
author: Jake S.

description:
We were passing Chinatown and saw a line forming outside. This must be a good place! So we waited in line and as we were waiting I was trying to get my order ready in my head to get the line moving and not hold it up. I recalled seeing this on yelp previously before and I remembered that their egg custards ( dan tat) were quite awesome. I ordered two dan tats and the white rice cake with the bean inside. Those white rice balls were pretty amazing.  Egg tarts = yum.

Important FYI: They only take cash and you can't take photos inside the store :)
author: Lynners C.

description: Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts are simply delicious.  Though I'm not as big of a fan as others, that might just be a personal preference on my part.  Some parts of my Dan Taat were not firm enough and were on the soupy side.  Nonetheless, they were still very enjoyable.  Texture was perfect and the temperature just right.  Most importantly, the taste was sweet and savory.  I'm a fan.
author: Angel S.

description: I have been to golden gate bakery numerous times and now finally decided to write a review. It is closed half of the time I try to visit. Make sure you call ahead. They are always on vacation. Hong Kong is known for egg tarts. I tried many places but nothing compares to Golden Gate Bakery which probably has the best egg tarts in the world. Both the crust and egg custard are cooked to perfection. The taste has been consistent on multiple occasions I have visited. Definitely is not as oily and the custard is warm, silky & smooth and the crust is deliciously flaky. These egg tarts cost around $1.50 which is a little pricey. Can't believe how the price has increased through out the years. This does not stop people from standing in line for up to one hour. If you are in the city, I highly recommend trying these delicious egg tarts.
author: Vivian N.

description:
Are you kidding me? Came here 15 minutes before CLOSING on a weekday night and the dan tats were hot?! Hot egg custard with a warm flaky crust. MmmMmm. Couldn't have asked for a better dessert to end a good and cheap Chinese dinner. And NO line to boot!!

The lines can get ridiculously long, especially on the weekend. They also have this bun that they only make on Sundays..or was it Saturdays...that are worth the wait to try at least once!
author: Jenna H.

description:
5 stars... DUH.

I've eaten egg tarts in China and Hong Kong, and this is comparable!  That's a serious thing to say, since they were THAT good in the motherland.  I would drive an hour, sometimes two, to get a dozen of these babies.  The egg texture is perfect and the crust, unlike most places, is not too flaky or doughy... just simply.. perfect.  Chinese New Year is coming up this weekend... I'm going to SF to get 8 DOZENS egg tarts... bahahah... all for myself.

The sweet sticky rice cake with green bean (with the green dot in the middle, not the red/green dot.. haha) is YUM-MIE!  It's soft and chewy like mochi, covered with coconut flakes, and filled with creamy green bean and a macadamian nut...mm-hmmm!

If you like BBQ Pork Buns (char sui bao), then you should try it here too!  The meat filling isn't fatty like most places and it's perfectly seasoned.  They only have the baked ones here, not the steamed ones, but that's fine by me... still delicious as ever!

If you have never been here before, yes, the line is WORTH THE WAIT :)  The atmosphere can be intimidating for first-timers though, since you are super rushed.. get in and get out before you get murdered by the mean Chinese ladies.  Well, they're nice.. sometimes.  

I almost cried once here... I have terrible allergies year-round.  And yes, I know my manners when I sneeze, aka I cover my mouth and have tissue handy.  However, that wasn't enough and I got yelled at to "STOP SNEEZING!"  Omg, I teared up.  If only the baked goods were not this good... this is why I keep coming back... I'll take another scolding for a bite of HEAVEN.
author: Mindy D.

description:
I didn't get a chance to post this but I'm finally taking my time to do so now. 

What to say about golden gate bakery. They are definitely known for their egg tarts here. I waited in line for 45 minutes just to be able to get this for the Wifey. I was telling myself that I should only get a dozen and a half but I ended with 2 dozens of egg tarts. 

Why the 3 stars you may ask? Let me tell you why. Their hours of operation are so inconsistent that I have no idea when they actually open and when they don't. This is my 3rd attempt trying to get this and finally I got to get it. They tend to be on "vacation" a lot. The second reason is the fact that we have to wait a long time to get the food. I understand that it's a little shop but seriously there were only about no more than 6 parties in front of me. Lastly their quality of their egg custard has diminished compared to the past while their cost per egg custard has increased to $1.50 each. In other words, quality of food dropped while price increased.

Overall their egg custard is pretty good compared to the other shops in the area in terms of taste. Its up to you if you want to wait in line for it. I know I would only get it next time of there's not too long of a wait.
author: Stephen W.

description:
Alright, I grew up in Chinatown.  There are tons of pastry places around.  The egg custards actually all taste the same to me... but having these egg custards from Golden Gate are really good if can eat them right after you buy them fresh and hot.

But if you were to buy them to go home, then any egg custard, toasted in a small oven  taste just as good.

But if you don't mind the line, speak loud in Cantonese, you get better service here.
If you don't speak Chinese, talk as if you know what you want, carry cash, don't delay the line.  Grab someone, anyone's attention behind the counter
author: Tony T.

description:
Golden Gate has the best egg tarts ever! I'm glad that it's finally open again although the price seems to have increased to $1.40 each. If you're not from the SF area, you can actually order a box of egg tarts ahead of time to take home, and they're still great after microwaving!

Apparently, the coconut cookies are quite popular too, but I'm not a fan. They're really hard and too sweet, so I would definitely stick to the egg tarts!
author: Angelic L.

description: The egg tarts are so good here!  Came here on Saturday and there was a line out of the door!  It's $8 for six egg tarts and one coconut tart.  The egg tart looks jiggles like jello and has a strong egg taste.  Eat while it's warm!
author: Chris L.

description:
I'm a bit ashamed to admit this, but having to lived in SF for almost 2 decades, I have yet to try Golden Gate bakery until now.

The long lines were always the turn-off. But this time, I was determined. I blended in quite well amongst the Chinese tourists, since we were all peeking through the glass and taking pictures of everything.

Waiting in line, I realized people had no idea what's good here. English-speaking tourists would walk by with curious looks on their faces. While Chinese-speaking tourists are in line simply because there is a line. As we all stood outside, we scoped out the people inside. "I see egg tarts!" "I think those cookies are popular!" 

Was it worth standing in the long line?? YES!
Was it worth paying $1.15 for one egg tart?? HELL YES!!

Hot and bubbly. Crispy and flakey. 
(http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/Y3K6ayU_btHH0WrELI9JQA/l)
(http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/5kYY77unfvcxvnZgrJJrZA/l)
I bought 8, but I gave 7 away. Why?! Why did I do that??
author: Marti L.

description:
The egg tarts here are amazing . . .
But to say they are the best, is inaccurate.  It is different.  The taste is very good and the texture is good.  This tart does well in that you cannot complain about and everything is right.

But to wait in line for a while, and to pay $1.40 for an egg tart when you can get them in Oakland for 60 cents fresh, without the wait makes no sense to me.  And to be honest, Oakland egg tarts are painfully good.   

I had this egg tart fresh and wasn't too impressed, but for the sake of the people around me, I acted as though I crossed one item off the bucket list.  As for the price , compared to american bakeries, a $1.40 for a pastry is hardly anything to complain about, but it is just the idea that chinese bakeries in Oakland is so much better. Try hong fook on 9th and webster.

So that loses two stars.

The other is their other selection.  Again my standard is the bakery in Oakland's Chinatown which has at least 50 variety of baked goods, almost which you cannot screw up your choice..  Golden Gate maybe 20 and they do all of them quite terribly.  I recommend avoiding all of them except the sandwich looking thing with egg custard.  The napolean was overly sweet, without flavor and dry.  The custard puff was simply disgusting.

So that loses another star.

Funny, I was reading another 2 star review and the person was from Oakland.  (they were comparing to Tao Yuan).This place really really is good.  But why wait and pay the extra amount when you can get the same, if not different.  I can understand if you don't want to trek into the East Bay and or are a tourist.

**
I don't understand how people can give this place 4 to 5 stars when they end their comment with " I will probably never come back here" and "It was not worth the wait"
author: Derek C.

description:
Okay, everyone knows that egg tarts here are the perfect heavenly combination of luscious egg custard that's not too sweet baked inside a flaky and light and buttery tart shell. I am drooling just THINKING about them right now. 
BUT! This review is not for the egg tarts, it is for the bbq pork pastry rolls! My oh my are these delicious! The bbq pork is so moist and juicy, and the pastry rolls are super flaky and crisp, not soggy at all from the pork. You really should try one if you love bbq pork anything! And if you can make it through the insane crowd of people that seem to always be outside this bakery.  They're like...mini char siu pastry pockets. Like...a hot pocket but a million times better! 

And a side note, if you are lucky enough to get inside the store and order, I would suggest ordering extra of the egg tarts. They are perfectly yummy again once you toast them a bit in the oven! True story :] Also, bring cash! It's cash only, which is quite inconvenient since I hate carrying cash around, but for them I'll make an exception because it's totally worth it!
author: Grace C.

description:
i cannot believe the line out this bakery and how people will wait for it.

i wouldnt wait in line couple years ago, but i did just the other day to get egg tarts that reminded me of my mom and childhood.  because moon day was coming up, i waited in line for an hour and half just to get 4 egg tarts! 

egg tarts are hot sellers, selling by the dozen.  crust is flakey and thin, filled with a generous portion of egg custard.  sweetness is perfect with a cup of tea.  it is even flakey and delicious the day after in the fridge.  $1.4 for AN egg tart + time wasted in line is pricey.

service is super unorganized and attitude can be horrible.  they gotta tighten up on being more organized so the line moves faster.
author: Linda T.

description:
Prepare yourself -- you'll burn your tongue... but you won't be able to stop eating. 

Why?!?!?!

The freshly-baked egg tarts are delicious. They are creamy morsels of heaven held together by a flakey crust. They also fully acknowledge how scrumptious they are. It's apparent by the long line that everyone adores and wants them. And we, the masses, continue to loyally, desperately beg for just a taste.

We bought 24 egg tarts while waiting in line for roughly half an hour. The workers took their sweet time as they worked. They knew that those waiting in line would stay put, and we did. It's a vicious process to get the goods!
author: May N.

description:
This place is so overly-hyped.  The egg custard is only AVERAGE.  Stop hyping it people.  The line is so ridiculous that they even have their own ghetto stand to get people to line up more efficiently.  I hate how people spectate when the see a lot of people waiting in line.  Lines attract people.  People like free shows and crowds.  Crowds create hype and block the street.  

I have had equally good tasting egg tarts at other places.   They all taste the same to me.
author: Victor L.

description:
Do get the gigantic, silky egg custard tarts.

DO NOT get the BBQ pork bun.
author: Jess C.

description:
I think this place probably makes the best egg tarts on the continental US! I am not being dramatic when I say that: nothing beats their flaky crusted and smooth, eggy custard pastry. They are even more mind-blowing if you toast them before eating! Warm, buttery, flaky...it just melts in your mouth. Sadly, it's best if these egg tarts stays an occasional treat, as with everything else that they sell because they're not exactly the healthiest things to eat everyday. But really, superb. Their egg tarts are truly one of a kind. 

Other notable selections: their coconut tart. It's similar to the egg tat except with a sweet coconut shavings fillings. Their napoleons and chicken pot pies are also delicious! 

I've been to Golden Gate Bakery many times and I still manage to miss it sometimes. It's a very small store crammed somewhere within touristy souvenir stores and Chinese herbal places. Not exactly the most eye catching bakery ever, and definitely NOT the cleanest. Another really annoying thing is that they close unexpectedly (probably because they have such good business, and they know people will come back anyways). We'll make the drive out to San Francisco to buy some egg tarts to bring back home, and then we'll see this poorly handwritten sign taped on the door that they are closed for the day. Super annoying.
author: Bonnie S.

description: LOVE coming here when I visit SF.  Their egg custard tarts are amazing!! sometimes the line is super long..last time I waited 45 minutes.  But it's worth it. All their pastries are good. But it's always the egg tarts that make me wanna come back over and over again.
author: Audrey C.

description:
Everything they serve here is large and in charge! The "dan tats" filling is super creamy and a very generous in relation to the crust. While it's always good fresh, I found it a bit chilled/left out for a bit tasted even better! 

They serve a variety of other things here so look around the store for hanging flyers for options or the display cases (inside the store and the one lining the store front). Availability (in flavors) changes though. For instance, they post 5 flavors of moon cakes, but on the day we went, they only had 2 flavors available (lotus seed and red bean). They also give you the option of no yolk, 1 yolk, or 2 yolks in your moon cake which is nice. They're about 1" thick and super dense. It probably weighs 1lb! They don't post prices for any of their baked goods other than the "dan tat" which is $1.40. We bought 4 "dan tat" and 1 moon cake and our total came up to $12 something!!! Holy cow!! That's one expensive moon cake!!!!

As with anything good in San Francisco, expect a line. They move you through pretty quickly though.

Not sure where they make their goods because their store front is packed to the gills with supplies and no kitchen in sight, but they're constantly bringing out fresh baked goods.
author: Alice L.

description:
I'm Chinese and I've been coming here for their famous egg custard tarts since the 80's!!

I've tried egg custard tarts everywhere, but trust me when I tell you this place is the BEST you'll ever have.  The crust is perfectly flaky and the custard is perfect!!

They are the most expensive, but worth every cent!!  They take CASH only.

Don't let this hole in the wall place fool you.  Their egg custard tarts are the BOMB!!  

WARNING:  
Their business is so good that ONLY THEY can CLOSE DOWN FOR A FEW MONTHS EVERY YEAR for "vacation"!  Yes, you heard correct.  I found out the hard way, so if you crave for their delicious egg custard tarts call them to find out when they go on vacation.

By the way, don't expect happy costumer service here.  Their business is so good they really don't care for your business, but I buy anyway because it's the BEST!!
author: G Y.

description:
The story of my experience at Golden Gate Bakery (on Grant Ave, btw Jackson St and Pacific St) begins 45 minutes earlier at the Good Mong Kok Bakery (1039 Stockton St, btw Washington St and Jackson St), a location west-southwest and ten minutes away on foot. Confused? Let me explain.

It was mid-afternoon on December 31, 2014 - New Year's Eve - and Chinatown was bustling as I had last remembered it, 16 years ago. I was visiting from out of town and my brother (who still lives in the city) had luckily snagged a parking spot somewhere on Clay St, so we proceeded on foot towards the Good Mong Kok Bakery, as we were curious about its high reviews on Yelp in the single-$ category. We arrived at about 2:45, purchased fifteen pieces of dim sum to go, but learned that the bakery had completely sold out of dan tat (the golden egg custard in a pastry crust).

"No worries," said my brother, "I know a place where dan tat is their specialty." And so, with the aid of Google maps, we meandered towards Golden Gate Bakery. We must have walked by the bakery - a small store front wedged between two large shops - at least twice before we looked up from our phones to gape at bizarre scene in front of us. The Golden Gate Bakery was closed: the lights were off, the interior was dark, no one appeared to be inside, and there was a sign posted on the front door, "Closed for Vacation."

Nonetheless, there were at least fifteen people waiting in front, standing in line along the sidewalk.

My brother and I looked at each other, shrugged, and got in line at the end. We couldn't see very well from where we were standing, but it appeared that there actually was someone in the store. This mysterious person would open the door just enough to extend a hand to accept some cash from customers at the front of the line, then close the door. A few minutes later, the door would open again to reveal a pair of arms stacked with flat pink cake boxes, wrapped in pine twine. The paying customers happily relieved those arms of said burden before quickly leaving, allowing the line of people to inch forward. With nothing better to do, we searched through the Yelp reviews on this store and noticed a trend: apparently, long lines aren't unusual at this location, and the shop tends to go "on vacation" quite often.

By then, there were at least seven people ahead of us and five more people had lined up behind us. As we neared the front of the line, we noticed the form of an older woman inside the closed shop. She didn't speak, but made eye contact with certain customers of her own choosing. Her silent gaze constituted an unspoken question, and the customers responded accordingly with their fingers. Some signaled "2", others "4". When she looked at us, we indicated "1". She nodded and walked away.

Soon enough, the door opened again: the arms appeared with boxes, customers quickly divested those arms of aforementioned boxes, then said customers departed - allowing us to inherit our new position as Customer #3 at the front of the line. The older woman opened the door and spoke in Chinese Cantonese to the Customers #1 and #2. When she turned to us, she paused before uttering, "Eighteen dollar, one dozen." Thus enlightened, we handed over a twenty-dollar bill, which she readily accepted before closing the door and walking away.

Now, at this vantage point, we could see more clearly through the darkened glass: the shop resembled a narrow hallway and the back room was dimly lit, where we espied another older lady carrying a tray full of pastries. She came into the front of the store, assembled some cake boxes, and starting arranging the pastries in the newly constructed containers. Once the boxes were filled, she painstakingly hand-wrapped each box with twine; using a pair of scissors, she then cut four venting flaps in the corners of the lid of each box. Finally done, she handed the boxes to the first woman, before retreating into the bowels of the shop.

The first lady opened the front door again and began distributing the boxes. We accepted our package of one-dozen dan tat, told her to keep the change, and turned around to walk past the line of waiting people behind us. The two younger customers (who accepted their order of four-dozen dan tat) were merrily digging into their boxes to get at the lovely, golden goodness, which they then greedily crammed into their mouths. I'm sure they did that just to spite the others who were still waiting in line. And as we walked away, we heard someone else (who had just arrived) exclaim, "Oh, but they're closed...!" We grinned and proceeded along without comment.

Thus ended my first experience of purchasing dan tat at the Golden Gate Bakery. Was it good, you ask? Was it worth it, you inquired? And what of the dim sum at Good Mong Kok? All valid questions, dear readers, but that's another story altogether.
author: Alan H.

description: Is it just me or GGB raised their prices on egg tarts again?  Granted they still have the same flaky crust & light & fluffy egg custard goodness inside, but get ready to pay $1.50/ea.   Seems like every time they come back from vacay, prices go up.  Are there places w/ less hype & the same eggy goodness, I wonder?
author: Stephanie C.

description: 4.5 stars over all on yelp but What the HECK does this place ever open?! My friend was in SF last month and attempted to visit only to see the sign that they were on "vacation". I was in SF this past week and they were also on "vacation". I need to try these egg tarts!
author: Jenny S.

description: Two words: EGG TARTS. Best egg tarts I've had so far. I love pastry & baked items, so this definitely climbed straight up my list of baked goods. The people here are super nice because they were closing & I really wanted to buy a half dozen. They opened it up for me and sold me my very first egg tarts. I was lucky enough not to have to stand in an hour-long line like the typical customers. They only take cash, so I would recommend to have some on you whenever you're in the vicinity of this mecca for egg tarts. As for the egg tarts, the crust was flaky and the egg custard wasn't too sweet. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone for their friendly service & tasty treats =)
author: Brittany D.

description:
With so many Chinese bakeries splashed all throughout the city like a rainy SF day... One would wonder... COULD there really be a bakery that sells "WORLD'S BEST" egg tart?  

Well, like Elf the movie... [Lily walks into Golden Gate Bakery and shouts]  "YOU DID IT!!!  ...Congratulations!  ...World's BEST Egg Tart!  Great job!"  The only difference?  ...these really are World's Best Egg Tart!!!  Here's why...

FOOD & TASTE:
"Dan Tat" ...aka Egg Tarts ...aka The  B E S T  Egg Tarts in the city!  ...so WHY are they so delicious?  First, they are pipping hot!!!  Warning... wait a minute or two to allow cooling... I once scalded my tongue.  Second, they are fluffy!!!  Like a heaven of egg pillows... intact jiggly outside, silky soft inside.  :-9  Lastly, the crust is flaky!!!  ...crispy, buttery, gets all over the place.  Yes... egg tart get in my face!  :-9

CONVENIENCE: * [Yup... that's right, just 1-star... cuz being located in CT, where it's really out of the way, where I have to deal with driving through massive amounts of people... and where I have to PAY for parking in a lot... and then, suddenly disappointed cuz I find a "CLOSED on vacation" sign taped on the door... AGAIN!
AMBIANCE: *** [Crowded little hole in the wall... Take out only... No seating available.]
SERVICE: **** [Fast service... but be prepared to wait 15-20 minutes in a line that wraps around the block... j/k, I mean store.]
PRICE:  $  [$1.35 for a SUPER HOT egg tart.]
OVERALL: **** [4-stars... cuz my chances are 3/5 on scoring an egg tart whenever I visit this tiny shop.  Please stop randomly closing... Chinatown parking really sucks.]

Gung Hay Fat Choy!  ...and they're most certainly CLOSED on CNY.
Nuff said.

[#16 of 100 YELP CHALLENGE 2013]
author: Lily Y.
Pauline P.

description:
Is the line necessary? Every time I come here there is a massive line with 50 people ahead of me. I'm not sure if a line for egg tarts is necessary but it happens every time, and like everyone else in line, I join in the fun of waiting for 45 mins (minimum) for these popular egg tarts. And of course with that amount of time invested your not going to walk in and order just 1 egg tart, with the time spent you feel the need to order a dozen. (genius marketing tactics) 

Here are my tips:
CASH ONLY (Banks are all around)
Make sure your meter is well-feed, because its going to be over for sure!!
Prepare yourself; water & bathroom breaks before waiting.
and lastly get the Candy crush app!! (its going to be a long wait!)
author: Paulie L.

description: 8/22/15 Closed again! We came last month and it was closed too... They must make a lot to be able to go on vacation so often...
author: Tami T.

description: I haven't tried anything else from this bakery besides the egg custard which deserves 5 stars! We got a fresh batch right out of the oven - perfect!
author: Josh L.

description:
This place way exceeded my expectations. With alllll the hype, I was pretty skeptical but now I see. I actually burned the inside of my mouth eating that egg tart, but I don't even care. If I could give 7 stars, I'd give that egg tart 7 stars out of 5. 

I also got a wintermelon pastry to see if this place is just good for egg tarts. I bought it, didn't eat it (was too overwhelmed by egg tart), put it in the fridge, and took a bite the next morning. It was....amazing. The best wintermelon pastry I've had and I've had a lot of them. And this wasn't even fresh, and I was too lazy to microwave it so it was COLD. And it still tasted like heaven. There were wintermelon bits and almond bits in the filling that gave a really nice and fun texture. It was just perfect.
[EDIT] I microwaved the rest and it tasted even more amazing if that's even possible.

If I could create magical pastries like these, I'd take 5-6 months off every year too.
author: Col C.

description: As a person from Hong Kong, I've still never had such great egg tarts before. The warmth and crispiness of the egg tarts are just perfect.
author: Michelle C.

description:
G.G bakery is well known, infamous for their quality of egg tarts! Not cheap, and the price increase basically every year. There's usually a line out the door, sometimes so long you'll feel a sense of regret while waiting. Also, the wait can be extended if the egg tarts are being made and you have to wait for it from the oven. 
I love the egg tarts here and the bbq pork roll, very expensive but hey, quality over quantity. If you come and ignore the egg tarts, then I'm speechless!
author: Hao B.

description:
I waited no more than 5 minutes in line, total score!

But was it the best egg tart I ever had? Negative

Flaky crust that isn't too heavy, the egg tart was smooth, not too sweet and not too eggy.

While it is a good traditional egg tart, I prefer 85C Bakery ( in Southern California) version of a mochi egg tart.
author: Nancy N.

description:
This place is never open!! 

The F'ers are always on vacation. 

Money must have gotten to their head, where they don't care anymore, they don't remember their roots.

I had friends coming to town from Maryland and told them about GGB. When my friends were in Chinatown & trying to find them, they saw the "vacation" sign

Golden Gate Bakery was on "vacation"
https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/248448_10100366777446908_5735473_55414750_824869_n.jpg

You're going to go out of business if you don't change your attitude.

(Tuesday, May 24, 2011)

Version 4.0
author: Kenny C.

description:
Is it possible to make love to an egg tart without burning your.... ?
Let's find out!
author: Kristine P.

description: The reason why they make the best egg tarts is that the crust is light and flaky.  Other Chinese bakeries make the crust really dense which I don't really care for.  I only waited 12 minutes so not too bad at 3 pm on a Saturday afternoon.  Buy a dozen and share with friends.
author: Brixton P.

description: I still just can't find another bakery that makes a better Dan Tat. The perfect flaky tart crust acts as the only formidable vehicle for this eggy custards that taste so pure without being overly creamy. Sinking your teeth into the freshly baked tart once you get to the service counter after waiting for 20mins in line reminds you that there are some lines you just cant quite skip because it's just so worth it.
author: Taffany H.

description:
I know.. EGG TART!! Lol, the one and only place I will ever eat these little scrumptious babies!! The line is usually long, but quick moving.. And most of the time when I come here they are "on vacation" which usually means they're sold out for the day. 
I usually buy a dozen and take them home to share. Their prices have gone up to $1.40/each. 
I like their sponge cake as well, but most of the time it's always those hot, flakey, custardy egg tarts.
author: Jenn L.

description:
As already mentioned by the first 1400+ reviewers, the 'Dan Tat' is really good at GGB.  However, I'm a goofy white kid who grew up in wine country suburbia with no exposure to baked goods from the far east, so my opinion regarding Chinese egg tarts is pretty much useless.

This review is not supposed to be about the egg tarts though, the best thing that GGB has going are it's mini macaroons!  If you looked up the word 'glory' in the dictionary, it would be accompanied by a picture of Golden Gate Bakery's mini macaroons.  Perfect amount of crispiness, and just the right amount of coconut where nothing is overwhelming and all the ingrediants blend well with one another. Even if you're just a little hungry, one could easily down 7 or 8 of these puppies.  They are only 50 cents each, so make sure you grab at least a dozen when you stop by.
author: Kyle S.

description:
A MUST IF YOU ARE IN CHINATOWN! Was just having a stroll in Chinatown. I was surprised they were still opened. Had two hot egg tart at 6:55 pm! $1.35/ea

---

Love the fact that they are still baking them fresh in the evening! 

Amazing that there were still 10 people in line so late!
author: Peter L.

description:
I've been here 4 times...and 3 of those times, the place was closed for vacation.  WTF.  

It doesn't matter how 'good' a place is if they aren't open 75% of the time!

The first time I was there, the place was empty and filled up as soon as I was walking out the door with my order.  The egg tarts were pretty good because they were fresh out of the oven, but definitely not good enough for me to drive to SF just for egg tarts.
author: Jenny L.

description: Their egg tarts are DELICIOUS and fresh. But they're just a little bit over priced. But I always come back!! Worth the wait they always have outside.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I'm a fan of egg custard pies, so had to drop by this place for the authentic stuff.

Luckily when we arrived, there was NO line. Several mins later, the line extended out the door. VERY small hole in the wall that sells a variety of baked goods. 

Decided on 2 egg pies ($1.15 each). The egg custard tart was delish. I didn't realize that they were HOT (temperature wise) and had to stop half way thru.

I ate the remainder at another time, and it was still good. The crust was light and flaky and the egg custard tart was not overly sweet.

Def recommend if you're in Chinatown. It's worth the trek uphill to get a piece of this pie...
author: Maria C.

description:
+ great egg tarts

I wouldn't recommend going here for any other Chinese dessert. I definitely think their only strength is the egg tart.
author: Margaret R.

description:
long lines and possible random closures but best egg tart I have ever eaten.

Average wait time is around 40 minutes and the egg tarts are significantly more expensive then other places at $1.40 each. They are bigger, sweeter, and fresher then other bakeries.

Before the autumn moon festival the wait can be 1 hr as their famous moon cakes are also on sale. Each moon cake is ~$8 each with a small discount if you buy a set of 4. The moon cakes are above average compared to other places as the lotus filling is not as overly sweet and the outside is not too firm and but still slightly flaky. 

Overall, I normally wouldnt want to wait just for an egg tart but if I have time to kill in chinatown, why not spend it in line for the best egg tart in san francisco?
author: Robert Y.

description: Wow. Hands down the BEST EGG TARTS EVER! I love that the egg part is custard-like and super soft. The coconut tarts are also tasty. They are $1.40 each and are the same price even if you buy a dozen. The line gets super long but well worth the wait! I plan to stop by once a week!
author: Lynn T.

description:
MMM, Golden Gate Bakery! I've grown up with your egg tarts and I must say they're delicious!

Usually, my dad buys a big pink box of Golden Gate egg tarts but by the time he gets them home, they're usually soggy and the flaky crust isn't flaky anymore.

Only recently did I find out the location of this bakery and decided to get a couple of them for my boyfriend and I. (My boyfriend loves GGBakery egg tarts) First bite was great, the soft, sweet egg and the flaky crust. YUMM

This bakery is also on 7x7 "The Big Sweet SF: 50 Treats to Eat Before You Die"
author: Mabel Y.

description:
The best Dan Tat (Egg Tart) and Gai May Bao (Cocktail/coconut bun) ever!!  

egg tarts are always cooked to a smooth flan-like perfection with a buttery flakey crust.  

cocktail buns have a good amount of filling, and it is never too dry.  its always moist, buttery, and delicious.

i cannot say the same for their bo lo bao (pineapple bun) - the topping is quite thin and not as crunchy/flakey/sweet as i like.

excellent customer service!  they even took the time to chat me up and make me feel like a valued customer, unlike all the other chinatown bakeries
author: Tina A.

description:
Hail and behold the best Egg Tarts I've ever tasted. Room for improvement? Of course! Anyone else top them to date? No...not yet at least. 

First impressions
Typical danky looking SF chinatown bakery with tons of people lined up outside. Wait 30 minutes the first time. Messy all over not a place you would expect such good quality egg tarts. 

I would only get the egg tarts here. I remember lining up an hour for the moon cakes which was not as good as the good brands! 

Their egg tarts are amazing. The tart is typically still warm when ordered. The filling is extra soft somewhat milky. The crust is not too try. I hear lard is used for the crust.  I would suggest the owner make different variations of it. Start with a sugar crust. Then maybe offer the Portuguese tarts too!
author: Sam T.

description:
I have to hang my head in shame.  As someone who loves trying great food and tries to be aware of food hot spots wherever I go, I haven't even heard of the Golden Gate Bakery until I was vacationing in San Francisco's Chinatown,mere blocks away from the place, and my sister came back with a whole box of the Egg Custard Tarts.

"I waited almost an hour for these", she proudly and happily proclaimed while showing the family what's inside the box.

Looking in, I saw some Egg Custard Tarts, or as us Chinese call it, "Dan Tat" and nothing else.  

Now, usually, I wouldn't be too impressed or excited by seeing "Dan Tats" since I'm not the biggest fan of them.  I will eat them if I have nothing else to munch on but otherwise I would eat other stuff if I have a choice.  But hearing how my sister kept saying that are usually almost always lines that are half an hour or more.  And how the wait is usually made longer because every other person seems to buy boxes of them at a time, I was convinced I would regret it if I didn't try some before heading back to NYC.

DAMN!!!!  THESE WERE AMAZING!!!

I ate these while it was still warm, and it had just the most thin yet flaky outer crust, with a smooth,semi sweet, soft custard inside that is so moist that it still jiggles a little if you shake it.  Normally, I find most Dan Tat's crust to be too dry and thick for my preference and the custard to be more thicker and more firm.  I much rather prefer the way they make it here, and apparently so does everyone else on that long line.  I found out that many people take out a few just to eat it piping hot right outside the bakery.  This is done because the turnover rate of the tarts are so fast, that new batches are constantly being made and put out.  Eating it right outside ensures that you are possibly tasting them mere minutes after it was baked.  Now that is fresh.

Hell, my sister bought enough to last us the next two or three days during our trip, and even cold or reheated, these beats the pants off any of the fresh ho hum egg custards tarts that I've eaten in NYC or anywhere else that I've tried so far in the USA. 

 It's the only Dan Tat that I've ever had a craving for.  Even now, after 3 months since I had them, I still think of them sometimes.  If you are in the area, I highly recommend you find a little time, get in line, and let this little bakery change your view of Egg Custard Tarts.  I know it did to mine.

Just be aware that this place have very haphazard, random vacations days throughout the year.  There are many reports of them being close for days and even weeks without warning, leaving disappointed people standing in front of a closed gate with a handwritten note saying they are on vacation.  That's what happened to my sister's first attempt to eat here on a previous trip a year prior to this.  

This happens so often that there was even fan created websites and facebook pages to tell others if and what time they are open on any given day so people won't need to take a long trip there for no reason. Crazy, right?  

Use the following links to see if they are open if you plan to head out here.

web page: http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/

fb page:  https://www.facebook.com/pages/Is-the-Golden-Gate-Bakery-Open-Today/394882013908745
author: Wing L.

description:
It's hands down the best place to get egg tart in the bay!

The flaky pastry + warm sweetened egg custard = heaven!

Of course it's the best when it came right out of oven, but even if you left it at room temp for 2-3 days, toast it again in little oven, it still tasted as good!

And not only their egg tart is so famous that people line up for it (one time i lined up for over half an hour....), other bakery goods are also delicious - buns, mochi....

One thing that I don't like about golden gate is they close whenever they like without any announcement. So if you are making a trip from far to visit golden gate, you may want to call ahead of time to make sure they are not on vacation!
author: Louisa L.

description:
There was a line outside this place and I read reviews on yelp about their egg custard tarts. So I had to try them. 

We waited in line and bought a dozen of those egg custard tarts and they were delicious. I'm a fan of custard tarts (eat them every time I go to dim sum)... and rating scale: this was 9 out of 10 for yummy goodness. 

The only problem with this place was the customer service. I know they are probably so busy that they forget manners, but don't yell at me and it wasn't the asian "they sound like they are yelling", no it was the "what you want" and yeah, I was getting irritated. But then a nice old chinese lady helped me and we got our food and left. Deal with the old Chinese lady, not the middle aged ones!

The egg tarts was worth it!
author: Laura S.

description:
You'll see this place right away, often with that ridiculous line!
If you're not here to try the Dan Tat/ Egg custard tart, you're here for the wrong reason.
Who knew such a common Chinese pastry could be so delectable! 
Their freshly made egg tarts are flaky and gooey in the middle. It's amazing! I've been coming here for a while and the egg tarts are delicious every time. 
Theyre very reasonably priced at around $1.25
It's freaking Chinatown so don't expect amazing service and clear menus.
author: Veronica L.

description: I don't normally approve of American Chinese food, especially desserts. However, the egg tart here exceeded my expectations. The flakiness of the crust, combined with the texture + flavor of the egg-center was phenomenal. It was especially good as I got it right as a batch was coming out of the oven. Definitely up to the standards of egg tarts in Toronto/Macau/HK.
author: Bernard W.

description:
HANDS. DOWN. BEST. EGG. TARTS. EVER. 

I don't think I can ever look at another egg tart the same way anymore. Nothing else compares :'( I was so excited to eat my egg tart that I burnt the bridge of the mouth. The crust was so flaky and the egg tart was sooooo soft I could eat a dozen. It's def worth it to wait for a fresh batch. Line is usually always out the door, but moves very quickly 

I would give it 5 stars if it weren't for the horrible service. The Chinese ladies are so rude, they pretty much ignore you if you don't speak Chinese (thank god one of my friends spoke Chinese) or you have to speak extra loud to get their attention, but they pretty much just wave you off and talk over you. CASH ONLY
author: Vicky T.

description: I make my husband drive me all the way to sf to get their egg tarts! It's sooo yummy! I love the flakiness and when it's still nice and hot it is amazing! I haven't found another bakery that has satisfied my egg tarts cravings! There's always a line and sometimes they are closed on vacation but always worth it when I devour it!
author: Susan T.

description:
Best egg custard ever.  The line moves fast, so worth the wait.  I actually don't think it's that pricey.  The previous reviews are right that it's about $1.15 per custard, and $13.75 for a dozen.  However I've been to places in the southbay that cost ~$1.50-$2 and they aren't nearly as good.

Definitely bite into it when it's hot.  I've never had an egg tart this fresh.  It almost melts in your mouth.  I drove back to the southbay afterwards, and they were still rather warm.  If you are in the area, definitely try some, you can't get it this fresh anywhere!

disclaimer:  I've haven't tried any other baked goods, so I can't comment on them.  This review is only for the egg tarts
author: Tiffany C.

description: Best egg tart I've ever eaten. They are warm and flaky and a new layer of crust seems to come apart in your mouth upon chewing. During the chinese new year festival I waited for 30 minutes to get in the store to order. As I waited the line started to pile up. Seems the average person has to wait 30+ minutes to get something.
author: Michael C.

description:
The "dan tat" is known as egg tart but not just any kind of egg tart, they have the best egg tarts in the US. Lines stretch and stay stretched for just this one delicacy piece of fruit pie looking dessert. So hot and sweet that it just melts in your mouth. Love coming here but make sure to come when they are open because the mom and pops that open it sure do love to go on vacation.

They also have other bakery like breads, cookies, and cakes.
author: Steven L.

description:
So many BEST ofs lately. I guess I'm just eating real well!

Anway! Golden Gate Bakery makes THE BEST EGG TARTS ever. Flaky crust with a not too sweet and not too eggy filling. Best when eaten right away and it's still piping hot. My friends and I experimented last time and found that a quick toast in the oven made the egg tarts just as good....so go ahead and buy a few dozen to take home!
author: Kathy T.

description:
Been coming here for years!!! Best Egg tarts around.

But they are getting kind of pricey now a days.
author: Tony Y.

description: I've passed up this bakery several times due to the ever-present lines, but finally decided to get in line and see what all the fuss was about. The perfect and warm egg custard tarts alone were worth the wait! We also tried the macaroons (delicious), and a wonderful little cupcake in a flaky crust that was divine! Definitely well worth the wait!! I will be in line any time I am in San Francisco!
author: Lori T.

description: I clicked in here by accident and saw all these reviews. It's just sad but having to grow up between Hong Kong and San Francisco, you know Golden Gate is overrated, overpriced and not worth the wait. It is as close as the quality of egg tart you can get widely in Hong Kong, but it is nothing more than that because egg tart is a very common pastry in Hong Kong, it really shouldn't be this expensive. My parents used to get them for us occasionally until I had encountered an incident and realized how rude these people are, so they are not only rude to non-chinese speakers, they are in fact just rude. After that, I told my parents not to get the egg tarts from this place any more, it's not worth it just because they make egg tart a little better than other average Hong Kong Style pastries in San Francisco. Our city has developed quickly the past few years, there are more pastry stores out there, so go somewhere else to explore, I hope you will get a better experience.
author: Cindy C.

description: Egg tarts here are delicious. They have the most perfect flaky crust that one can ask for. Prices are above average at about $1.39 each. The line here is often long , but dies down as the evening becomes later. Nonetheless , service is a bit on the slow side. Not sure if its worth the wait especially when egg tarts are pretty much always delicious  this place would be good to visit when the line is small to nonexistent
author: Patty O.

description:
They are known for their egg tarts. Honestly, just the egg tarts alone earn a 5 stars from let aside any other complaints I have with them.

From conversing with the ladies who work there, I learned that they usually don't keep most of their baked goods, and certainly not the egg tarts over night. They are either sold the same day or trashed the very same night. Frankly, I really doubt if the latter would happen much given how quickly their items get sold out before the store closes. 

So what are my complaints? Well, the lines are ALWAYS LONG! There was a few times when I was trying to surprise my friends with egg tarts when I visit them, guess what happened? they did not accept credit cards, which I found out the hard way... The other time? I found out after getting spending a good 15 minutes in line that they were completely sold out for the day..... 

So the lesson here is, go there early and always bring cash with you. I guess it's my fault that I don't usually have even $10 on me since I prefer going by credit cards. I heard it's not how folks roll in China town!
author: Victor K.

description:
Tips:

$1.35 for an egg tart.
$16.20 for a dozen egg tarts.

WARNING: They take random vacations during the year so there's really no way of knowing when they're open unless you can reach them by phone.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

This is really THE only place to get egg custard tarts. I LOVE IT HERE. Everything about their egg custard tarts is perfect. The crust is perfectly flaky and crispy. The inside is perfectly soft and sweet. After eating an egg custard tart here, no other place can compare. I can honestly say that I'm willing to wait an hour just to get a hold of these tarts.
author: Alice H.

description:
Best egg custards ever!! The crust is flakey, the filling is sweet and amazing!! And because they're always so busy, you're almost always will get a fresh hot batch everytime. 

One star deducted because they're always on vacation. Seeing that "On Vacation" sign used to always break my heart but I got smart and started calling ahead of time to make sure they're open to save myself a trip.
author: Jane Y.

description:
Now for someone who is NOT a custard fan in the slightest I do have to say YUM-O! Everyone we had come into contact with in the bay area all said that we had to try Golden Gate Bakery for their egg custard. Since I am not a huge fan of custard and read other yelp reviews that said the line can be crazy I was not excited to go but...curiosity got the best of me. 

First of all, there is NO parking. Good luck!!! My husband dropped me off in bitter cold (ok, it was 50 degrees...cut me some slack I am from Hawaii) and he began to circle for parking. I lined up in front of the store expecting a long wait and surprisingly enough I was done with tarts in hand before my husband found parking (about 10 minutes). 

Service is friendly and they aren't as rushed as I would have thought they would be. The ladies were pleasant and very efficient. I also got rice cake which was good...pretty much your run of the mill sticky rice pile. Not my favorite can you tell? My husband enjoyed it. The egg custard IS worth the wait. A warm flaky shell surrounds a rich delectable center of cholesterol laden goodness. Fabulous warm from the oven and equally as delectable reheated. 

If you are in the area and particularly if you like custard you really should make a stop here. Skip the car and let your feet do the walking...it won't hurt after you eat a million calories in custard.
author: Tracie F.

description:
Well, I gave it a second chance...and this time there was a 20 min wait...and well...still can't give it the 5 stars that everyone is. Sorry! It's a good egg tart but not as amazing as all the reviews claim to be. 

Also - i opted for their curry pocket...bleh. skip it. that was a waste of $2.

More of a tourist snack stop for me, than a "must eat before I die" item
author: Angela K.

description:
Best egg tarts hands down! Waited in line for about 20min or so. We went later in the afternoon and I was afraid they wouldn't have any more left, but they did. AND they were super fresh. It was so fresh and hot that I burned my tongue while eating one! Good crust, but what I really liked was the egg filling. My mom who doesn't generally like egg tarts liked this one too. 

A dozen egg tarts was just under $17! I think one costs $1.35.
author: Chris K.

description:
They are the best...hands down.  If you are visiting or even in sf, you need to make a quick detour and get a few of their egg tarts and old wife cookies.  Yes I don't know what it is in English, but those old wife cookies are sold out all the time.  And the egg tarts barely come out with a batch before they are gone and a new batch needs to be made.  They are for real! 

The line is not that bad, but there is always a line so be prepared.  

Word to the wise: know what you want before you actually step foot in the shop or the people behind you will get impatient.
author: Frederick L.

description:
Dan tat is not my favorite dim sum by far, but for a while now, I have been intrigued by the line that is always waiting in front of GG Bakery and the scores of people leaving with giant boxes filled with treats.

Luckily, during my visit, the line was not too long, so I ordered one dan tat for $1.40, the pastry was very delicate/flaky, and the filling was not too sweet, very soft and custardy.  It is definitely good, especially since mine was served warm.  The size of the pastry is also bigger than you get in a standard dim sum place.  So all in all, I was satisfied.

I also ordered a fried noodle pastry (similar to a rice krispy treat), as a throwback to my childhood.  It tasted just like I remembered, but I guess you get more excited about these kinds of things when you are a little kid, thus, my son was happy to help me gobble it up!

Very nice.
author: Burrito M.

description:
Finally open! Tried the world's best egg tarts this weekend. The hype lives up to it's name. Fresh from the oven, you have to eat 1 or 2 right there and then before it gets cold. Not only was the crust puffy and crisp, the egg custard was still hot from the oven, and it was so eggy and buttery! I bought a few, drove down to San Jose, and toasted them for 5 minutes so my fam could eat them warm and experience what I had too! It was close, but no cigar. Gotta eat them there on the spot! 

I tried coming here last year, but there was a sign that they were on vacation. I heard they actually go on a lot unannounced. The older lady and man that work there were really nice, they said they're going on vacation in April and July again! What a great life. HK, Vegas, you party animals. 

This bakery could really make anyone an egg tart lover!
author: Joanna S.

description:
I love it when I'm just happening to walk by, no real intention to step inside, when I realize for once there's actually NO LINE and I walk in and get egg tarts IMMEDIATELY and they're WARM and YUMMY and AHHH. Believe it or not it's happened. Once. But still, it happened.

Usually there's a massive line out the door. I wouldn't stand in line then--I'd come back later, or if it's already too late I'd come back the next day. Definitely if you're visiting Chinatown for the first time or just in San Francisco on vacation, you should come here! Really, really good egg tarts that are fresh and gooey and perfect. yes, other places still make great egg tarts. But this one is like...famous...so...yeah...it's worth at least trying.

Egg tarts are $1.40 which isn't cheap but again it's worth it (as long as the line isn't too long--again, you should come back later if it's too long). They put new trays in the oven as soon as they finish the first tray (and trays are empty in less than a minute), and the egg tarts take about 15-20 minutes to bake. Once, we got there right when they finished a tray and were told to wait outside, but as soon as they were done we got our egg tart and were on our way.

Honestly, I've never had another one of their pastries. Some of them look reallly good. But I've found other bakeries are just fine for those without the wait, so I really only come here when people are visiting from out of town.
author: Katie V.

description:
Their don tots are everything everyone says they are! Fresh, flaky, full of flavor, delicate, great smelling, and perfect texture. Totally transcendental. I wolfed down 3 of them in 5 minutes. Could have put away a dozen... also went on a Sunday and no line, no wait.

Negatives - 

1) There were handmade signs posted up saying no video or photography allowed in the store. Feels like they're snuffing out the friendly karma. 

2) And when I asked the old lady for a business card, she said we don't have any. Then she added in Cantonese, what good are they once you finish eating them?? I'll tell you ya old hag - like when I want to call and place an order for 1,000 of them for a family or church event! Diu na ma!!
author: Chet M.
Mike C.

description:
Why did the hipster burn his mouth on the egg tart?
...Because he bit into it before it was cool.

Though you may have waited in line for 45 minutes, and though you may have been drooling smelling the faintly sweet egg custard, have some patience! These babies will be piping hot when you get them. Just take a moment, let them chill, and then indulge yourself in the perfectly textured, delectably sweet, and satisfyingly flaky egg tart.
author: Emily T.

description:
I think the fact that this place is averaging 4.5 stars over 1200 reviews speaks for itself, so there really isn't much for me to add that's not the generic OMGZ THIS PLACE IS AMAZING. So while my comments aren't anything that haven't been said hundreds of times before, let me just spell it out really nice and simple: the egg custard tarts (dan tat) and pineapple buns (bo lo bao) are ridiculously good. Like, orgasm-in-the-mouth, party-in-the-pants good. Yeah, I went there. And it's not hyperbole when I say that I haven't had an egg custard tart this good since I was in Hong Kong, and this just may have been the best pineapple bun I've ever had. 

The egg custard tart has a perfectly buttery, flaky crust that is the perfect balance between being crisp, but not to the point where the whole thing shatters -- aka crust failure -- after the first bite. The silky smooth filling rounds out what just may be the epitome of the perfect egg custard tart.

As for the pineapple bun, I was actually kind of disappointed at first by the diminutive size; the bun is definitely smaller than your average pineapple bun. But as they say, size doesn't always matter, especially if you're talking about a pineapple bun whose bun component is the texture, consistency, and richness of a well-made croissant. Topped with a perfectly flaky and buttery shortbread-like topping, this is the pineapple bun that stands alone at the pinnacle of bun glory. 

So even if you didn't read any of what I have written above, my take-home message is this: go to Golden Gate Bakery and order the egg custard tart and pineapple bun. Once you recover from the sheer ecstasy that you'll be feeling after having something so pleasingly delicious in your mouth (that's what she said), you will thank me.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Lured by the 7x7 list, I ventured to Chinatown to try the famous Egg Tart. Be prepared to wait at least about half an hour in line! 

I completely respect the fact that you can tell that they're constantly churning out and putting out freshly baked goods. There are about 5 older Chinese women bustling around in the bakery constantly taking orders and bringing out new trays of delicious looking pastries. Maybe i'm not just not the biggest fan of egg custard tarts in general, but I didn't think it was anything special. I did really enjoy the mochi with coconut flakes. It tasted like it had a banana filling. We also tried the macaroons which were a little too hard for my liking, and really sweet with all the crystalized sugar sprinkled on top.
author: Brian L.

description: You still need to wait on line even before this place is closed. The egg tarts are amazing!!!! SO SO YUMMY!!! Maybe that's why there is always a line. Besides the egg tarts, the coconut tart was really yummy too!! Definitely worth the wait!! YUMM!!
author: Susan L.

description: Excellent egg tarts!! I don't usually like egg tarts, but this one is relatively light. It is pudding like with a buttery, flaky crust. Delicious!!
author: Cindy S.

description:
" DAAAANNNN TAAAAAAAAAAAT",

Probably one of the first things you'll hear as you walk in the door. The people working here are what you expect from a typical chinese place. They're loud (almost as if they're all yelling at each other), they can be rude, but what they serve is the best. Everyone practically comes for their egg tarts and once you try it, you'll understand why. So many people order dozens (literally), and take them back home with them. There's always a line, and the egg tart is always fresh. It's best pipin' hot. It's got the best texture and crust is nice and flaky. Yum.  I love egg tarts and I can't wait until I can come back here again.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Tried a bunch of their baked goods and not bad! 

They are very popular for their egg tarts.
author: Crystal W.

description: I'm glad my friend talked us into going here on Christmas day, after lunch since everyone is saying how their always randomly closed or run out of their famous egg tarts. Although it was a raining and it was hard driving through china town, the line wasn't too bad and they were after all, open on Christmas with plenty of egg tarts to go around. I ended up getting half a dozen and they were still hot! That first bite was delicious and rich. The egg tart itself is more like an egg custard souffle but a little more dense and just mildly sweet. It was a decent sized tart for $1.25 and left me feeling very satisfied after eating just two. My husband equally enjoyed his and hopefully, this wont be my last time going because this really is the BEST egg tart I have eaten yet! :)
author: Petra S.

description: Favorite place for egg custard! Trust me, I've tried it in several Chinese restaurants and bakeries. Best in city.. Best made anywhere. Always a line. I get so mad when they're on vacation because it seems like they're always gone, but I get excited when they're back open which will be again at the end of the month. Always warm and fresh!
author: Briana H.

description:
Best Dan Tat (egg tarts) ever!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

If you're ever in SF, be sure to stop by China Town and come here!!
They're bigger than normal, nice and fluffy, and DELICIOUS. om nom nomm
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
I stop by this place every time I'm in Chinatown and hope that they are open. 

This place closes sporadically because the owners head back to Hong Kong. So if it's open, you'll be missing out if you don't pick up a dozen Egg Tarts!
author: Winny F.

description: I followed the mass yelp reviews through San Francisco and this was the conclusion to my food crawl. Having never eaten an egg tart before and not being a custard fan--like, at all.. I kept an open mind and palette. I only ordered the dan tat and a coconut tart. The egg tart was warm, incredibly flakey and just the right amount of custard. Not too sweet either. It literally melted in my mouth. The coconut tart was just as good. This business has a great thing going here and the know it. It was definitely worth getting lost in Chinatown for and being the last thing I ate before I hopped the flight home.
author: Samantha R.

description:
Just how good can their egg tarts REALLY be, I asked myself skeptically as I was sitting in SF traffic for 20 minutes just to go 1.8 miles. I've been to Hong Kong many a times, and Houston's Chinatown has some pretty dang good bakeries, and I'd say Golden Gate Bakery is definitely up there at the top for their egg tarts. 

1. Perfect temperature / warmth (even when I went at an odd time of the night - they are always baking fresh batches)
2. Perfect insides - gooey, but still firm and not runny. 
3. Flaky - the crust was flaky but still held together so that each bite was full-bodied and with enough crust that didn't fall or lose itself on the wrapper.
4. Still delicious hours later and even when it's not warm anymore.
author: Jennifer M.

description: These are the best egg tarts you will have in California. Perhaps the entire US! They are SO crispy, flaky, deliciously eggy and the best treat for any day of the week. Hands down, the best egg tarts I have ever had in my life!
author: Sally C.

description:
First, let me start by saying that I am not a big fan of sweets or pastries.

On Christmas we decided to go to Chinatown for dinner. After we ate, my wife said she wanted to go to a bakery and get some sweets. Yelp lead us to Golden Gate bakery. The line was out the door, which I figured must be a good sign.

While I'm not a big fan of sweets, they had a raspberry apricot layered bar that looked pretty good, so I decided to give it a try. It was really good and not overly sweet. It wasn't huge, but like I said, I'm not really into sweets, so it lasted me three or four days at a bite or two a day.
