My wife got something that looked like a coconut puff ball and a lemon Napoleon. I had a bite of each, and both were quite good if you like that sort of thing. My wife, who is the one with the sweet tooth, confirmed that all of our treats were quite good. 

Despite my teeny, tiny sweet tooth I might even make it back to Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Danna C.

description:
We came at 8:30am right when they opened and completely avoided any waiting usually needed. We got a fresh batch of a dozen dan tats (egg tarts) for $16 that were still piping hot and it was amazing! (Freshness= A+++) We had some an hour later when it wasn't as fresh and it was still very good. The custard was soft, creamy, and just the right flavor and texture! It wasn't too sweet or thick. The pastry crust was just right- buttery and flaky. It was super delicious!  I can't say these are the best egg tarts in the world, but they are definitely up to par with the really good ones I've had from dim sum places around SoCal.

Service: The lady working was also very nice. We spoke with her in Cantonese and English. I can see how service can be slow though when there's a lot of people waiting.

I'll be back next time I visit SF for some more delicious dan tats! And definitely waking up early to avoid the wait.  :)
author: Donna V.

description:
By sheer coincidence, I went to the Golden Gate Bakery the day before going to the Golden Gate Meat Company...and tomorrow I'll probably be at the Golden Gate Medical Center after suffering a Golden Gate Coronary from all my blimp-like eating.

I've been wanting to try Golden Gate Bakery for a long, long time but was always intimidated by the ridiculously long line out the door. Well, on this particular Sunday, there was amazingly just one couple at the doorway, so we parked ourselves to ensure a purchase. Thanks to Yelp, I knew I had to get one of their Egg-Custard Tarts, obviously a hot ticket item given a Chinese woman was ordering box upon box of them in front of us. Yep, just one tart a piece...that's all we're getting...that's right...just one.

When it came to our turn, it was a moment of truth. I ordered two....but then I wanted to try the Raspberry Napoleon in the display case...oh and that Chocolate Sponge Cake Roll looks pretty good...and I was nudged to get the Fried Sesame Ball in the window...and since she's at the window, how about three wedges of Sticky Rice in the saran wrap? Oh God...is this what happened to Kirstie Alley? Am I destined for unsuccessful weigh-ins at Weight Watchers? Did it really have to take three paper bags to fill my order?

Unbelievably, the total came to less than $7, but now I have to lug the pink plastic bag to Washington Square Park, so we can devour them in a suitably pastoral setting. The tarts are all that...warm from the oven, they melted in my mouth. The rest of our pastry haul couldn't compare. The sponge cake roll was good but undistinguished, and the sesame ball was chewier than a radial tire. The napoleon was crunchier than I expected, and the sticky rice was a bit bland. But oh those tarts. The thought of having a box of them at home is too disturbing on so many levels.

PASTRIES - 5 stars for the famous Egg-Custard Tart...and 3 to 3.5 stars for the rest
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...it's a Chinatown bakery that makes Saigon Sandwiches look like Michael Mina's...OK, not quite
SERVICE - 4 stars...fists of fury and chop-socky fast...Hai-ya!
TOTAL - 4 stars...go for the tarts and don't look back
author: Ed U.

description:
I stumbled onto this place by coincidence as I was walking through Chinatown. Something about mobs of Asian people make me crave egg custards more than usual.. So I decided to go into the first store that I saw sold them. Didn't think about yelping it so I had no idea how amazing these were and only bought 4 egg custards. What a freaking mistake on my part! 

On the way home, decided to finally take a bite into it. Now I've only ever ate egg custards from local asian bakeries and I didn't even know egg custards of this caliber existed! This was beyond any sweet dessert I've ever tasted. It was THICK, plump, so rich and perfectly creamy with the right crust to custard proportion. MmmMm... you could imagine I was ranting and raving about it the rest of the day. Unfortunately, it was too late to go back and buy more. I'm still beating myself over it...

Next time I'm buying in bulk.
author: Kathleen N.

description:
I've had this place bookmarked for yeeeaaars! The last time I was in the area, I didn't have a chance to stop by so I made it an effort to ingrain the thought of "the best egg tarts in SF" in my friends' minds and appetites. It worked. 

We ordered a dozen to go and the bakery ladies packed it up in the box and lifted the corners so it can ventilate and keep the egg tarts crispy. 

Two hours later, I bit into an egg tart and it was heaven. The pastry crust was still crispy and flaky. The egg custard was perfectly cooked and wasn't overly sweet. It wasn't Honolulu Coffee Shop (in HK) egg tarts, but it came close. 

Word of advice... Get in line. Don't think you can walk in front of everyone and can place an order. The customers here are serious about their egg tarts and are not afraid to let you know it. My friends and I witnessed this firsthand when someone tried to cut the line.
author: Lily C.

description:
my friend and i walked by not knowing what it was but definitely noticed a long line outside. Then we looked it up on Yelp and realized it was a famous bakery! Since she wanted egg tarts really badly, we decided to just wait in line. 

The line goes really slowly even though the food is ready to go because the service is really bad. So don't expect to wait only 5 minutes. We waited about 20 minutes and the line had about 10 families/couples/groups in front of us. 

***I also heard that you can cut the line and go in to order and then leave and walk around the area and come back in 15 minutes to pick it up.

Egg Tarts: Very good,especially if you do not eat them often.  Try to eat them when they are fresh and still warm because once they are cold they are not as tasty. My friend and I think they are more like Portuguese Egg Tarts (without the brown sugar) The crust is flaky so eat it carefully.

BBQ Pork Roll: Good balance of sweet and salty. Flaky and lots of meat, not just a few chunks.

Curry Beef Pastry: Flaky and flavorful curry. 

***If you are a first timer at Chinatown, Walk along Grant Ave because there is more tourist-y stuff there.

Happy New Year!
author: Amy Y.

description:
As you can already tell by the long line outside every time: BEST EGG TART EVER! 

Every time we come to visit we have to get at least 2 dozen to bring back home and a few to eat on the go. They always know to cut the corners for the box to let the steam out and give you the even fresher ones to eat along the way as you dash back into the busy city.

Top notch: 5 stars! Bring cash!

=====================
1 star - "will be telling everyone to stay away" bad
2 stars - it's okay, i won't return
3 stars - it's okay, i'll come back
4 stars - it's pretty good, i'll come by again!
5 stars - it's really good, my go-to places!
author: Sandra C.

description:
There were less than 10 people ahead of me in line. As I walked in, I couldn't help but relive the "Soup Nazi" episode of Seinfeld in my mind. I moved down to the end of the counter and told the woman I wanted a dozen. "A dozen what?" "A dozen egg tarts please." As she was collecting the money from my BF, I put my finger in the pink box. She had cut a small corner off so it can breathe so I wanted to see how warm they were. She turned around and glared at me! "Why are you putting your finger on the egg tart? Your finger is dirty! Why would you do that?" I smiled thinking she was just messing with me but she didn't think it was funny. And I thought to myself, "But I paid for these! I can put my finger on them if I want to!"

These egg tarts were pretty yummy despite my grubby fingers all up on them but I wouldn't make a special trip there or wait in line more than 5 mins.
author: Cindy T.

description:
I'm going to round my stars up for this one.  THE best egg tart I've ever had!! Definitley the best in San Francisco.  For  $1.25 these things come out piping hot so be careful!  I also got the lotus bean moon cake which as dense and heavy as a brick but was soooo tasty!  
This place defines the hole in the wall chinese bakery.   There are piles of dilapadated boxes and stacks of who knows what cluttering the place.   Its located right on the main Chinatown drag of Grant street but it doesn't try to look inviting at all to tourists.  The tiny shop looks as dilapadated as anything you would find in some back alley in Hong Kong.  Don't let the appearance fool you though!
author: Richard U.

description:
O good Lord! This place is definitely a must if you've never been!!! Talk about the thickest, biggest, lightest, tastiest egg tart I've ever had! The egg custard portion, my favorite portion of this particular bakery's egg tart, was just perfect! Still warm from the oven, not too sweet nor too egg-y. The crust was also very good and definitely decadently melt-in-your-mouth flaky. I think I'm changing my vote from Portuguese-style egg tarts to Hong Kong style egg tarts after having Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts. 

This was my first time and my boyfriend's third time. He says the egg tarts here are still his favorite, but definitely not as good as the first time. ;-) 

We went on a Monday morning around 10am and there was no line. Staff is friendly here.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
The best dan tat I've had.  They come out hot and fresh.  The custard is nice and smooth.  And the crust - flaky with a hint of salt that really cuts through the sweetness.  Yum.

They taste good even room temperature/cold - which is actually how I prefer dan tats.

Parking in Chinatown is a hassle, that's the only problem.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
I normally wouldn't buy egg custard tart.
after reading all the great review so I decide to try it and yes, it's the best I've ever tasted. fluffy crust and the custart almost taste like pudding.
Love it!
author: Rina C.

description:
nom nom nom.  I didn't fully understand the meaning of that word until I ate a Golden Gate egg tart (or as they call it a custard tart, guess that sounds better in English).  

At first, I was hesitant because the egg:crust ratio was higher than usual.  I'm more of a pizza crust/pie crust type of girl.  But after that first bite into the tender, warm and crispy little thing, I was convinced.  The egg custard part had the consistency of a perfectly cooked chawanmushi and a flavor of a delicate creme brulee.  

Although I would recommend eating it as soon as you step out of the door, these things are also super tasty room temp, cold or re-baked.  Each time revealing a different, amazing taste. 

During my week of eating in SF, I came here 3 times.  The lines were crazy on a Sunday afternoon when the Asian masses covered the entire store front.  Best times were weekdays and in our case, President's Day.
author: Emily S.

description: Awesome Egg Tarts, discovered this place via previous reviews, first time we went they had sold out of Egg Tarts, a good sign but disappointing, returned the next evening to find a line of people waiting. A very friendly local told us they were only allowing customers 2 egg tarts each( this was his second time in the line as he was getting some more for his folks). When we finally got to the counter we asked for 8 egg tarts, the stern lady asked "how many people" we sheepishly said 3 of us, my wife, son and I, they gave us a nod and packed them for us. Great moon cakes too and they were selling boxes of those to locals who cut the line to pick up their orders. I'm half Chinese and know to not let gruff stern service get to you cause behind the tough front is probably some great food, so great they don't care about trying to be nice to everyone. Fine by me, yum and gone. But to the locals who cut the line, would be a shame if you dropped your boxes of goodies that you believe give you "good fortune" by gifting them to your friends and family, I guess you need it...
author: Justin H.

description:
Egg Tarts!!! That's clearly what everyone is lined up for at this joint. 

GG Bakery is located in the heart of Chinatown and is in a run down, narrow bakery that oozes poor layout. Nonetheless, their famous egg tarts keep people lined up around the block so I knew I had to go and see what the fuss was about. 

I waltzed into the bakery on a Friday night at 7:30pm. No line when I went in, but 5 minutes later, the line was out the door again. I bought a half dozen egg tarts ($1.35 each) and a lotus paste mooncake (because I wanted to see if this bakery did other things well). The egg tarts were baking in the oven so I had to wait about 7 minutes for them to finish. No biggie, but I imagine that may be why the line is so long sometimes. 

So, the service. A lot of people bitch about it, but really, what do you expect? The lady who helped me was very to the point, on the verge of abrupt, but she was in no way rude. She basically talked to me the way my mother (who I'm pretty sure loves me) talks to me. I really don't think they're trying to be rude, I think that's just the way it goes. They are very efficient and that may contribute to some of the behaviors other Yelpers have experienced

Regardless, the tarts were SPECTACULAR. The custard was the perfect consistency and the crust was hot and soft but not without crunch. HEAVEN. I also tried the moon cake and it was pretty baller. One of the better one's I've had. Good to know they are a well-rounded establishment. 

Anyway, definitely worth at least ONE visit, otherwise you're missing out on a SF food landmark.
author: Carmen K.

description: By far the best egg tart in the universe. Super flaky and hot and big and and and *drool* Long lines all the time but so worth the wait. I always buy a dozen when I go and it gets eaten up in a couple days! Can't compare to any dim sum restaurant. Nothing compares PERIOD
author: Matthew G.

description:
Their egg tarts are the best! I went recently and bought some egg tarts at $1.35 for each! I was like "What?!" They are so expensive! BUT so worth it. The tarts have a nice and crispy crust and the egg filling is so delicious. I only come here for the tarts. Haven't really tried anything else. 

A funny thing that I noticed was that they had a "Help Wanted" sign for a female worker. As if a man can't make an egg tart just as delicious?! Sexist pigs!
author: Alex T.

description:
Super duper hate that they randomly go on vacation for several days, but when they're open, those egg custards are no joke.  Absolutely delicious.

They don't take orders over the phone--at least that's what they told me on the phone, but when I was in the store I swear one of the counter ladies answered the phone and took down an order for a box of dozen egg tarts for someone...so...color me confused.

They speak Cantonese, Mandarin, and English.
author: Jess H.

description: I'm usually not a big egg tart fan, but these tarts are great. My while family loves them. I usually buy about 20 each time I go. Gotta make it worth it if I'm waiting in line for like 30 minutes! The other pastries here are kind of whatever. Don't bother getting anything buy the egg tarts.
author: Lisa T.

description:
best egg tarts I've ever had. EVER.

My dad and sister requested I bring these back to SoCal so I made the trek [quick walk really] over there in the rain.  There wasn't a line thank goodness.  Presumably because of the weather and the time [9am].  They came out of the oven and smelled AMAZING.  I dragged those babies all over SF before I finally got to eat one and they were still amazing. Definitely a do try if you're in the area.
author: Michelle K.

description: Egg Custard Tarts are amazing. Crispy, buttery, flaky crust. Creamy, not-too-sweet custard. Perfect balance. Chinese aunties are also really nice!
author: Leah H.

description:
The eggtarts here are pretty much the best egg tarts I've had. However, I would truly have to rate the eggtarts as slightly overpriced, and way overhyped at this point. Their various meat pies on the side are actually more appealing to me, since I'm not of the Canton persuasion. Since I live in SF, I bring friends and family who visit to stop by, and Golden Gate Bakery has basically nearly turned into a tourist stop, filled with people who are willing to wait an hour, or even longer for egg tarts. 

However great the eggtarts are, they aren't worth the wait. Stop by only if the line looks like it'll take less than 30 minutes.
author: Oliver Z.

description:
Yes golden gate bakery has good egg tarts compared to other places but for the price I don't think it's worth it anymore. It's not worth standing in a super long line, having rude service(for a local), and the taste and texture is not as glorious as it was once before. 

I feel that they earn from their reputation of best egg tarts but it's not as good as when they were the best. They raised the price every single time they come back from vacation. The servers were rude to my mom when she asked the price of one of the egg tarts. She no stranger to gold gate bakery but its been awhile since she bought anything there and she heard how they tend to raise prices. She asked and they told her not to buy one if she mind the price. That leaves a very bitter after taste for me so I don't really have good thoughts about this place anymore but nonetheless they still have decent egg tarts.
author: Tina L.

description:
You can't leave San Francisco without trying their egg tarts!! This is the best egg tarts in the bay and possibly all of California. It's the freshest egg tarts with the flakiest crust I ever had. Most places make it in the morning and let it sit all day and the crust would harden and the filling isn't so great. Yes, it's probably because Golden Gate sells so much that they would have to make fresh ones all the time. But it's because of that that makes it great. So no matter what time of the day you come by to get some, it's fresh hot out of the oven. It still tastes good after a day or two sitting in the fridge so feel free to buy dozens of 'em! 

Both times I have been here, there's never a very long line. All the ladies here are very nice and so hard working. They do try their best to move the line quickly so the wait isn't ever that bad.
author: Stephanie L.

description: My favorite egg tart place! We waited almost an hour to get some, but I don't care! I love this place! I was able to order some coconut macaroon looking thing too, which was also amazing and melted in my mouth! GGAAHHHH!!! I love this place! Soooo worth the wait if you love egg tarts and other Chinese bakery goodies!
author: Christina P.

description:
OMG.  

Egg custard tarts (aka dan tats) have long been a childhood favorite.  Unfortunately, most dimsum restaurants can really screw this up as they focus on their more savory dishes.  

However, GGB has mastered the fine art of dan tat making:  the soft light gelatinous center, with just a slight hint of sweetness, never masking the egg flavor.  The flaky crust that surrounds this delectable eggy custard is deliciously light and almost buttery.  

I used to scoop out the center first because I wanted to save the crust for last.  I'm sure some of you have done this as a kid!  ADMIT IT!!

The wait of 20 minutes was worth it.  These were served hot and fresh, and should be eaten right away... my sister and I were standing off to the side eating these suckers right out of the bag like a bunch of refugees!

We got some other pastries too, but these paled in comparison to the dan tats.  

Damn it.  Shoulda got a whole box of these suckers for the ride back to LA.  You SFer's have no idea how great you have it...
author: Sharon T.

description:
Always a long line here. Their egg tarts are definitely the best in the city. Always fresh and warm, the line is definitely worth it! I hear there's a trick though, if you're only there to buy one or two, you can usually jump to the front of the line and order :)

My only gripe about this place is that the business days and hours aren't consistent. It's so disappointing to travel to this place only to find that it's closed for a month. Although the warm flakey egg tarts make up for it the next time I'm there...
author: Mindy T.

description:
I'm not even that big a fan of egg tarts, but I was lucky enough to have one of theirs when it was hot and fresh out the oven, and it was damn good.

Their almond cookies are also pretty good.
author: Kimmy N.

description: BEST EGG TART EVER !!! I had a lot of egg tart growing up, but this has always been the best egg tart that I have ever tasted. The texture of the egg tart and the crust is perfectly. Compared to other egg tarts this has the most filling and the fluffy egg taste to it. Not only is there egg tarts delicious, but there other desserts there are also great. I usually love to order the mochi with the custard filling there. The only downside about this place is that it is closed pretty often throughout the year because every time I go the "VACATION" sign is up. However, if there is a long line it is worth the wait!!
author: Katie L.

description: Delicious (egg) custard tarts!  Too bad you may be standing in line for an hour for these things.  If anything else fresh out of the oven, get 'em.  We had the pineapple bun (bo lo bao) and they were hot, light, and yummy!
author: Karen L.

description:
I've had a lot of egg tarts in my life but gosh, these are the best ones yet!!! Definitely come here in the morning to beat the line. If you get here a little late, the wait isn't too ridic.

Just get ready for some piping hot goodness. The egg portion is so warm & delicious - it literally melts in your mouth. And the tart compliments the egg portion well - light & flaky goodness.

I'm coming back before I leave San Fran!
author: Olivia S.

description: Egg Tart! Gotta get the egg tart! 3:30 on a Sunday afternoon and they were hot and tasty!
author: Don A.

description:
OVERRATED. I waited in line in the cold and rain for over 40 minutes. The bakery is TINY so the line moved slowwwwwwwww.....

The egg tarts were right out of the oven. I appreciate the warm and freshness but the taste is totally bland. I'm not an egg tart expert but this is not worth waiting in line for.
author: Fonz G.

description:
Went there on a weekend afternoon and braved the long lines to get in and order.  They are well known for the egg custard tarts and they were very good.  But were they worth the wait?  Not really, because I think you can get just as good egg tarts elsewhere in Chinese bakeries in SF.  

The candied fried noodles weren't as good as Eastern Bakery, but decent nonetheless.  Unfortunately, I didn't think the coconut macaroons were that great.  

The line really died down later in the afternoon.
author: Doctor G.

description:
Yes they're good. However, they have multitudes of issues. The lines are long when they're open. Now that you need to feed the meters on Sunday afternoons means that it costs you more to wait in line. The other issue is just the ridiculous prices they're charging - about twice what other competitive bakeries charge. And of course the oddest thing is how they manage to be "on vacation" about every other time I walk by.

It's Chinatown, so you know the service is going to be an adventure.  I don't hold it against a place like this when the line becomes amorphous once you get to the counter and the person who waited behind you tries to jump ahead of you. I have had Chinatown clerks notice I was first and refuse to serve a line jumper ahead of me, so it's not as if they're not aware.

So in short, the sign that says "The Best in Town" (and wasn't this place shown in a BofA commercial with a banker repeating that line?) may be accurate. However, it's only marginally better than other places where you'll pay about half as much, where you'll only wait minutes rather than half an hour, and where they're probably going to be open. It's worth a try is you have the time and they're open. They're prices are high, but they're still pretty inexpensive treats. However, if any of these things are an issue for you, Napolean Super Bakery on Stockton (or Oakland Chinatown) are almost as good without those issues.
author: yp w.

description:
In my everlasting search for the perfect egg tart, I arrived upon Golden Gate Bakery. Lucky for me - the store was open, the line was short and a fresh batch of egg tarts awaited my consumption. 

However, drama ensued.

The workers began to argue loudly in Cantonese and thus began an episode of your late afternoon Chinatown soap opera . I believed one of them was caught with...a bun from another local bakery! *GASP* Betrayal and disloyalty filled the tiny store, I stood there anxiously anticipating their next crushing words to each other but I was handed my lone egg tart and suddenly the warmth of it shifted my attention solely to eating it up as fast as I can.

27 seconds was all it took and it was a delicious half minute. The custard was incredible and the crust was baked to perfection. I am ready to call my folks and tell them...your son has found the one.
author: Roy H.

description:
Reknown for their egg tarts. I came here around 5pm on a Wednesday and luckily did not have to wait in a line. Egg tarts were 1.35 each and 16.20 for a dozen. I expected to walk into a fancy Bakery but it turned out to be a small janky store with 3 Chinese ladies working. They were very nice and spoke limited english. It's enough to understand what you want order

Pros: the ladies work quickly. They always had egg tarts and they're bigger than your typical eggtarts.
Cons: store very small so no room to walk. Not many choices of pastries, so mainly known for eggtarts. Cash only.

I think their eggtarts are relatively better than many other places but not the best. If I had to wait for eggtarts then it wouldn't be worth it.
author: Lynn V.

description:
The Good: It's true, these Egg Tarts are PROBABLY the best I ever had. The egg is creamy and has the right amount of sweetness. The crust if firm but at the same time buttery, crispy, and moist.

The Bad: The line is balls, I would never have a craving THIS BAD. Their Pork Bun was average, although I liked the soft and appropriately oily bread, the filling didn't taste very much like anything. It wasn't particularly sweet or salty, but mostly forgettable.

The Ugly: If they run out of Egg Tarts when you finally get served (and they will), they will gladly give you fresh and hot Egg Tarts out of oven. HOWEVER, you have to wait for them. So this goes on top of the waiting time you already spent in line.

The Verdict: Would you kill a man for an Egg Tart? If you answered no then don't come here. Strictly for those who love Egg Tarts. I know, ridiculous, right?
author: Corey P.

description:
Ommm nom nom nom nom... Mmmm nom nom nom...

(Mouth too full of egg tarts to write a proper review)
author: James W.

description: Pretty good egg tart. Not too sweet and flaky crust. A must try for SF, that's if they open for business. Open for business as of 6/8.
author: Xing M.

description:
If your ever in SF Chinatown or even downtown shopping you got to come to Golden Gate Bakery. This place is so popular and rich that they take random vacations so please make sure you call to ensure they are open. I've taken hikes from Market st to the Bakery which is a very far walk and was extremely dissapointed that I didnt get my fluffy egg tart. 

When you finally get there, past the swarms of tourists then Chinese people you will find the Bakery with a line out the door. The service is fairly quick, almost like an assembly line. It was worth the hike and the wait and the egg tarts are absolutely divine. Make sure you eat them while they are still hot and fresh for the best taste.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
In Philly's Chinatown, they're called, "sweet butter buns." There's nothing inside, just a sweet roll with some sugary glaze perched on top like a jaunty beret.
Apparently they're not called that here, and if you say, "sweet butter buns," you get a foul-tempered Asian lady frowning at you and yelling, "SweeeBuhBuhns?" So you have to man up, yell back, and point like a drunken spider monkey at the treat you want. But whatever, they're worth it. Om nom nom. $1.90 for 3.
author: Mollie E.

description:
Long wait. Lot of hype. Was it worth it? Probably not.

But at least the bakery doesn't take advantage of the high demand by selling their goodies at outrageous prices.

The egg custard tarts were really good. Even better when devoured on a cold day as soon as they were purchased. They come out piping hot. So don't wait til you get home, rather, grab one and eat it right away.

As for their other goodies, they weren't that special. I tried the curry beef and pork buns. Both were mediocre at best. Stick with buying their main attraction.
author: Jack K.

description:
Egg custard tarts. Oh man! A buddy told me to stop by here because I LOVE EGG custard!


I live here now. Thank you Golden Gate Bakery!
author: Paul L.

description:
The Fantastic-4 took a little break from shopping in crazy Chinatown and landed at this continously busy bakery with more reviews than neighboring business in the area combine. We have passed by here so many times in the past, and could never get anything from here, because the long line stretched out to all the way to Pacific Ave. Give or take!

What a surprising scene! There were only a lesbian couple ahead of us, and our chance of getting their claim-to-fame Egg-Custard Tart was really good. There wasn't any at that time at our visit. So we each had one of the $1.00 Custard tart and it tasted yummy eventhough the cold dessert has been sitting on the counter a long-time. Wifey and the kids ate their treat with a somewhat smile. And then all of a sudden, with a blink of an eye; More Egg custard tarts arriving, fresh out of the oven and straight towards the counter.

Then once the fresh batch came out of the oven and to the counter, Wife and the kids begged Matt to get MORE of the Custard Egg-tarts.

Matt asked: How much you guys want?

The three in unison yelled, "A Dozen!"

Matt thinking and convincingly say, "Yeah, might as well. How often we get fresh Egg custards at our appearance?"

The friendly workers grabbed a dozen of the custards and boxed 8 of them in the famous pink box. While we have seconds on our treats and they gave each of us a piping-hot custard. Matt warned the kids that custards can burn you, so they have to wait at least 5 minutes to cool down and settle in. After the cooling-down session, we each woofed down the fresh and cool custard, and it tasted so yummy, which gave each of us a smile on our faces :-)
author: Matt G.

description: Best egg tarts in town for sure.  I waited almost 2 hours and they only gave me 2.  I didn't find out until I got inside.  I called in advance asking how many Egg Tarts they could sell per person before I decided to come, they told me 1-2 dozen.  Terrible business practice.  It's not worthy of 2 hours waiting for 2 tarts.  However, I still can't deny the quality of the tarts and mooncakes here.  I would give this store 5 stars, yet because of the wait I only give 4 stars though.
author: A T.

description: Be prepared to wait long if you come on weekends! Waited almost 2 hrs to place a small order due to the high demand for egg tarts. Normally you would get your order in and get out within 10min max but because custmers order by the dozens the shop here struggle to keep up with the demand  hence the wait.  Outside of the egg tarts they do  make really good coconut macaroons and melon cakes . Fyi the price for egg tarts went up to 1.65 each and  dozen of egg tarts are almost $20.
author: Brian L.

description:
Everyone raves about the egg tarts, but I'm all about the pineapple buns. The pineapple bun is soft but the top is lightly crispy and crumbly. I love it and could eat 4 in a row. 

The egg tarts live up to the hype. They are eggy and not soggy but lightly crunchy on the crust.  My boyfriend who has never had an egg tart at this bakery literally inhaled 2 egg tarts within minutes.  

All of the buns and pastries there are delicious but I have to deduct a star for the service. Yes, I am Cantonese and I understand that Cantonese business people have no patience for slow decision makers as they are losing money every minute you are standing there hemming and hawwing but that is no excuse to being rude. I asked for a small pink box so that I could separate out 2 egg tarts from the batch I just bought in order to give it to someone. The lady behind the counter barked at me for not just buying two MORE egg tarts and for being cheap. She DID have a point, but still, I did not want to buy 2 extra egg tarts. 

Anyhow, no need to go off on a tangent. Bottom line is 1 minus start for service, but taste-wise this place is a winner.  The store front is not much to look at, but let your taste buds decide on the quality of the goods!
author: Sabrina C.

description:
$1.40 for an egg custard is a steal...  I don't get why ppl think its we expensive...on any given day, go to a starbucks, you will not find a pastry item cheaper than $2... So, stop complaining....  $1.40 is nothing..... 

As for the service, its a mom and pop Chinese business, if you going for the service, look else where.  They can hire 10 additional counter help, but your egg custard would be $3.  So, expect crappy service in this type of establishment, get your dan tat fix, and get out....  

Leave the Dan Tat Nazis alone!!!
author: Good A.

description:
Probably the BEST Egg Custards (Tarts) I have ever eaten. They're usually freshly made and cut the sides of the box so that it can cool down instead of steam up inside making it super soggy. The crispy layers on the outside followed by a delicious soft, rich taste of the egg custard... making me drool as I type!

It doesn't even matter how much you buy. A single, a dozen, a box. It's all the same price so no worries. It's $1.15 for a single and $13.80 for a dozen.

Maybe I haven't been here during a busy time because there's only usually a few people ahead of me.

Parking SUCKS but is well worth it if you're in the area. I usually find metered parking a few blocks away and there's always the Grant Parking Garage if you're desperate.
author: Lauren K.

description:
When you stop in the Chinatown of San Francisco, this is one of the place that has to be on your list. Chinatown in SF has been around for many generations and egg tarts is a traditional chinese dessert. It seems so simple but the art of making it I guess is quite complicated. 
The tarts are bit pricey comapred to other places but it is bigger too. I seriously thought to myself, "how in the heck could it really be so much better than other places?" In general, the flavor is just the same, but the fact that they churn out so many and sell so many, makes them bake fresh ones consistently. We got em hot, fresh right out of the over, which always makes things taste amazing! 

For sure, it is worth getting! There is a long line usually but it goes pretty quickly. The egg part is super soft and perfectly sweetened while the crust is super buttery and flaky. Be careful not to eat too many of these...I can't imagine them being very low in cal! LOL. But you gotta try it if you've never done so. 

Must stop location in you're around the area!!
author: Wendy L.

description:
The first time I was here, I made the biggest mistake of my life: I only bought two of those delicious, creamy, silky smooth, fluffy, saliva inducing...oh I'm sorry, getting a little carried away here. But y'all get my drift? The egg tarts are overpowered to the max. Decadent egg custard filling that isn't heavy at all (I downed two in two minutes) combined with their signature flaky crust...each bite took me back to that Girls' Generation "Gee!" feeling- in other words, that magical feeling every time I saw saw a cute guy walking down the street. And trust me, that only happens ever so often. 

Yes, the lines sometimes can get long. Yes, the crowd here mostly consists of scary and loud Asian grandmas. These thresholds can be daunting...however, they are worth enduring to get to the prize. 

Get a dozen or more. Just do it.
author: Kero D.

description:
Stopped here Saturday morning before the Chinese New Year parade.  We must have stopped at the right time, because although there was a short line we waited less than 15 minutes.

The service was pleasant and all my questions were answered.

I got the egg custard tarts for my husband.  They were warm and he had no complaints.  I got the coconut tart, which was tasty and the right amount for a street side snack.  

I also got coconut macaroons which had a sweet, caramelized bottom and were fresh and light.  The kids got the chocolate and vanilla rolls, both of which were airy and not-too-sweet or over frosted.  My husband liked the almond cookies, too.

The prices are decent.  I was happy we stopped.
author: Kelly M.

description: I live in orange county and my friends and I are always down for a one day trip to San Francisco for the egg tarts at golden gate bakery. The best egg tarts I've ever tasted, bar none. Creamy, eggy, custardy and flakey!  When friends come down from the Bay Area, I always request a box of these delectable egg tarts and eat them throughout the week. The flaky crust can be revived in the toaster oven after sitting the the refrigerator. Also, eating the gooey egg tart warm is a great way to eat it!
author: Nancy N.

description:
I'm not a good judge of their famous egg tarts, but I can tell you that Golden Gate Bakery sells some of the best mooncakes in the city! They're a bit pricey (~$6 a cake depending on how many yolks you want), but you get what you pay for: they're delicious.

The crowds get unbearable during the weekends. It's a popular spot for both tourists and Bay Area locals, so be mindful of when you visit. I have a lot of friends whose families will drive or BART up to the city just to visit this bakery. The best times to go are weekday evenings. If you do go on the weekend, be prepared to wait in a line that stretches down the sidewalk.
author: Alyssa W.

description: Stumbled upon this place and had amazing hot custard tarts. Yummmmm. Stuff dreams are made of.
author: Michelle D.

description: It's good for the price. I think the service hasn't been as bad as people say, but the hours are very random.  When you call, sometimes they answer, lots of times they dont.  It's probably one of the better egg tarts in SF, but I've had a few random spots in SB that are better.
author: David L.

description: They have THE BEST egg tarts!! There's always a line on the weekends. Usually a 15 minute wait but definitely worth it.
author: Diana X.

description:
Two words: Egg Tart

Warm, toasty, crusty, perfectly sweet but not over-done, right out of the oven...

I haven't been too impressed by the other items I've tried over the years here (curry beef pastry not bad in the morning), but for egg tart... I also haven't found too many comparable places to this amazing place.  And I love how sometimes when its busy, the question isn't "how many" but "how many dozen".  My average is 2 dz a trip and yes... I CAN down a dz by myself...

Enough said.  Do it.
author: Annie H.

description:
I had egg tarts from Golden Gate Bakery before, from either my mom bringing it home or my relatives giving them to us. But its been so many years ago that I forgot how they tasted, so I was thinking if I never craved for them that they probably weren't that great.

My friend and I came here on our 3rd food-fest run and I'm so glad we did. She was raving about it and I was more like just going with the flow. Man I'm so glad my expectations were so low because these soft, buttery egg custardy pastries seriously blew me away. Total FOODGASM.

We had to wait 30mins for them to come out and they were worth every minute of waiting! I usually like my egg tarts chilled in the fridge, but when I had the egg tart's hot custard sliding down my tongue I just couldn't get enough even when it was burning my whole mouth from the daym heat!

Absoultely love! and a must stop bakery if you're in the Chinatown area (:
author: Marie N.

description: This just keeps me coming back to SF. The best egg tarts I've had were the Portuguese kind in Macau, but this comes second if not third. The crust was flaky and crumbly but also buttery, and the custard had the perfect consistency and sweetness. It's hard to get sick of them no matter how much you eat!!! Brought 2 dozens back to LA and they still tasted good after a night or two. Even though, of course, they taste best when fresh.
author: Patricia N.

description: I don't know what is good about the store but standing in line for 15 minutes without moving, I left. In front of me, there are about 40 people in line. What the heck! I heard the egg tarts cake are the best in town...I tried on cake from my friend which was tasting normally like other bakery places in San Jose. People is still spreading the "tale" about this bakery store, but to me, never going back.
author: Nhien L.

description:
what i ordered... egg tarts

same o same 

.........though now its a robbery but i guess it happens to any place, when demand rules over sanity (thank you very much tourists). go around the block at napoleon's for almost half the price.
author: Gors P.

description:
If you decide to go here just except to get only their egg tart (Dan ta in Chinese).  The other bakery items looked very average to below average.  But their egg tart is so so so spectacular that I have to give it must visit 5! 

Beware there will be a massive line with a minimum wait of 10 mins. So plan that in your schedule :)
author: Jack C.

description:
Okay y'all, I know, you're suspicious about the hype. You're suspicious about the line, that nearly touches the end of the block. You're suspicious because how can an egg tart be THAT GOOD? An entire hour's wait good? And so cheap too?

I know, I was there too. But they are. So amazing. And delicious. The egg custard itself isn't too sweet and so soft and flan-like and melts in your mouth. The crust -- so flaky, you might be afraid it'll crumble all away before you put it in your mouth.

Just go. And don't get just one, like I did. Get at least two. Maybe three. Bring some back for the fam. An entire dozen. You just might end up eating the entire box.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Since I grew up in the city I have been here or had stuff from here before but I guess never fresh out of the oven. People usually go, buy a lot, and give some as gifts. 

A couple of my friends from out of town visited this past weekend and we came here. We stood in line for a good 15 minutes. Not bad. 5 mins after we stood in line the line got super long. We're lucky.

$1.15 for an egg tart. It is kind of expensive if you ask me. It wasn't even that big. It was good though but I don't know the difference between all the egg tarts. 

Good experience. Fresh and jiggly. Who doesn't like fresh and jiggly? 

Probably only come back if I am with more tourists.
author: Sarah C.

description: I'm going straight to the point, I bought two dozen egg tarts to give to my family and grandparents--I failed miserably. I could not resist those flaky, golden, custard filled tarts. It is physically impossible to just eat one!!!
author: Legendary W.

description:
This place always has a line for a reason.  It's simply the best.  It has the most authentic egg tarts in the whole city.  It's the only reason to go.

Sure, the place is small, but what good bakery/restaurant isn't just a hole in the wall?  I've been going to this place for more than 20 years.  Man, I feel old now.
author: Wally W.

description:
The egg custards here are little bites of HEAVEN! If they're open (and not on vacation like they are every other day), they get long lines out the door. If you come on an Asian holiday, prepare to wait an hour, because that's what I did once - and it was totally worth it. If I could eat these every day and not get fat, I would. 

My sister enjoys their raisin bread too.
author: Mimi V.

description:
I've only been here once. 
I only got one thing. 
Egg tart.
Five stars. 
I'd write more, but there are currently 1,826 reviews on Yelp for this place. And all 1,826 are about the egg tart.
Bye.
author: Crystal J.

description:
I was exploring SF Chinatown for the first time and saw this place with a small line forming out of the door, and I had to come and check it out. Found that everyone was lining up for egg tarts.

5 stars for the egg tart alone, hands down. I can't imagine how to change it to make it any better. They were selling a lot so they were coming fresh out of the oven. They're a good size and they're real tasty.

Also tried the coconut tart, wasn't bad at all.

Do yourself a favor and swing by here if you're in the area and get an egg tart!
author: Francis F.

description:
I have been to golden gate a few times. I'm not the biggest fan of egg tarts, but I will say they do them right. I love my chinese bakeries and I love how traditional this bakery is. Everything feels like it's straight out of the stories you hear about Chinatown. It's certainly a fun place to visit. Give it a shot...the custard is usually nice warm and thick.(For those who don't know, an egg tart is a flaky hong kong dessert that has a crispy crust and a filing/middle of egg custard.) The only thing I could imagine that wasn't excellent was its crust. 

This place is a must if you're in SF's chinatown. Don't overhype it and make yourself thing it'll rock your world, but definitely come to eat something delicious.
author: Dawei L.

description:
Great place if you want to practice your waiting-in-line skills, but the main attraction here are the egg tarts. I had FOUR different types of egg tarts on the same day to figure out why GGB egg tarts were so great and it's clear why. I don't know what they do, but the taste and texture are top-notch and very consistent. GGB egg tarts also had the most custard out of all the tarts and they're amazing when eaten fresh. If reheating, put into a 320 F oven for 12 minutes.

The macaroons were also awesome - make sure you microwave if it gets cold and hard. Mooncake was also pretty good, but really expensive.

Great first time experience! At $1.35 per egg tart, that is almost twice as expensive as the egg tart from Super Napolean Bakery (which is really good too!), but it's worth it if you can tolerate the long line.
author: Jason T.

description:
Delicious out of this world egg tart, as good as the ones in Hong Kong.  Next time, besides egg tart, consider other baked goods like the coconut tart, walnut pound cake, and almond cookies, they're just as yummy.

 
Beware if you're visiting from out of town, they close a couple times throughout the year, usually after a major Chinese Holiday, expect month long closure after the moon festival.  Call in advance to make sure they are open.
author: Grace L.

description:
TIPS:

1. Chinatown's parking is rough. Be prepared! Street parking is limited and I've had my car dented (probably by another car's door) in a very tight and expensive parking structure.
2. Call ahead or check Yelp before driving into the city. They frequently go on vacation without any advance notice, but they do post a sign on the door.
3. Try the egg tart!
4. Try a couple of other things... the moon cakes or one of their freshly baked buns.
5. If you're going to get several dozen egg tarts, call ahead to make sure they can accommodate you. Otherwise, you risk having to wait in line even longer.
6. Enjoy every single bite because they'll be gone before you know it!
author: Kaly P. S.

description:
Their egg tarts are bangin'.  Their pastries are beautiful. 

The mung bean cakes are an acquired taste that I wasn't really acquiring while eating it, nevertheless, I think it would have been good had I actually liked the mung bean cake.  Make sense?  Nevermind, just take my rare 5 start rating at face value and enjoy some egg tarts or anything without mung beans, unless of course, you like mung bean, which I don't.

Clear as mung?
author: Stewart K.

description: I didn't read up on the bakery before coming. Just took a peak and jumped on the line. Amazing egg tarts!! If you love egg tarts, it's a must go. Light, fluffy and just flaky enough. One of the best of ever had. I wish I had gotten more than 3!
author: Bonnie W.

description:
I have no idea how long the wait is here because my friend got it for me. But I think they told me it was about an hour long wait - the line ordinarily would move fast but people get dozens and dozens of egg tarts at a time, so it takes longer. 

I know they have some problem with being closed on random days, but they let you know when they are opened on their twitter. They are also cash only. 

But all that being said, I absolutely love their egg tarts. I think it's the single best egg tart I've had. The shell is perfect, and the tart itself is HOT and it just melts and breaks in your mouth. I would have never understood why in the world people would wait in an hour+ long line for a pastry that is as big as the palm of your hand, but when you try it, it all makes sense. Really really delicious.
author: Liz W.

description:
Overall: Not my cup of tea. But will respect the large lines and high reviews. I didn't like anything I ordered, too bad. :( 

Give a 4 star to support their mounds of high reviewers to be fair.
author: Nate M.

description:
As everyone else has already said, delightful egg custard tarts.  I'm not an expert, but I've had a lot of bad tarts elsewhere, and I find these to be delicious.  $1.10 expensive?  Whatever, all pastries are overpriced...I don't eat egg tarts that often anyways.  The crust is always so wonderfully flaky, how can I resist...
The line can sometimes be horrid if you come at the wrong time of day though.
author: Jen F.

description: Well, if you find them open, then consider yourself lucky.  Of course, buy their egg tarts!  Their other bake goods are also delicious..  We love this place but you really need to eat them fresh and hot to get the experience..
author: Rick K.

description:
I don't make it to Chinatown often but my mission today was to get a custard tart, and I understand Golden Gate Bakery is THE place to get one. As if there could be any doubt, the long line outside confirmed I was in the right place. And it was full of moms stocking up for their families, leaving with those big, fun, pink boxes, so that always bodes well, too. The line moves quickly though, and people watching was fun!

I ordered the custard tart which was served warm, right out of the oven, not too eggy, not too sweet, and a lovely mouth feel. I wished I'd bought two! Total comfort food. I also got an assortment of other cakes from the window. I couldn't tell you what they're called, unfortunately, but my mix included some barely sweet steamed buns and cookies redolent of coconut. The prices seemed very reasonable, a good value for the quality of the product. 

The trip to the neighborhood alone makes for a fun excursion in the City! Check out the tea house, too, right across the street.
author: Mark N.

description:
Okay so I really enjoyed their egg tarts and sesame balls. This was my experience...

It was a cold Sunday afternoon and it also happened to be Chinese New Year. My bf and I were feeling festive so we went in search of some authentic dim sum. Our search brought us to...Chinatown! I recently read about Golden Gate Bakery on some list from 7x7 and kept it in my "must try" brain folder. I thought, "yesssss this is happening"

We navigate to Golden Gate Bakery and find player parking. Love it when that happens. Feeling good already! About to eat some egg tarts!

We get in line. A looooong line, which makes a u-shape on the street. It's cold. I'm in heels. Firecrackers are going off everywhere. My genuine excitement for amazing egg tarts outweighed all of these unfortunate factors! I wait patiently. About 20-25 mins later, we're inside the store! We get: 4 egg tarts, 1 honey bbq pork bun, 1 mochi-like thing, and to my severe disappointment, they ran out of sesame balls and i wasn't going to wait 30-mins for them to be ready. or was i???

Everything they serve was either piping hot or very warm. How do they do it?? 

Anyway, we pay for our things and scurry back to the car so that we can sit & devour our goodies. My first impression of the egg tarts...meh. It was really hot and the egg custard was still sorta jiggly, but the crust was perfection. My boyfriend really really really loved his bbq pork bun though. I mean, he LOVED it.

At this point, we still hadn't eaten any dim sum so we walk a couple blocks to pick some up. 15 minutes later we're back at the car and my bf says "I'm just looking to see if the line is any shorter" In my head im saying "are you crazy" but what i actually say is "if you wanna go back, im down" like i said, he REALLY loved that pork bun. 

Here we are back in line. Still cold. Still in heels. But this time, it only takes 5 minutes before we're inside the store! Woohoo! And guess what! The sesame balls are ready!!! My favorite!!! This time we pick up: 3 sesame balls, 1 bbq pork bun, and 1 curry pork bun. 

I really like sesame balls, and these ones are awesome. Not super oily, crispy and chewy in all the right places, just the right amount of red bean filling. *drool*

Later on that night, I had one more egg tart. By the time I ate this one, it cooled down. Whoa ho ho...WHOLE DIFFERENT ballgame. It was the best egg tart, ever. Yeah. It was.
author: Krystle I.

description: 4 stars mainly because of hours. You just never know if and when they will open or close. There is always a line, so come early when they first open to avoid the madness. Egg tarts are the best. Have not tried other pastries so cannot comment. Service is the usual Chinatown service.
author: Cari S.

description: Funny enough, I've been coming here with my family my entire life but never paid much attention to their Dan Tat as I was never much of a fan.  My tastes have changed quite a bit over the years though and I can safely say now that they're the best I've had yet =D  Soft, fluffy crust with creamy egg custard filling is flat out win.  Contrast this with the overly flaky crusts and almost gelatinous consistency of most competitors and you'll see what I mean.
author: Eric F.

description:
Oh wow, their egg tart is the best that I've ever had! So the custard is so light and creamy, the shell is very crispy & flaky. I was lucky that they just had a batch came out, so mine was actually warm, feel the custard was just about to flow out when bite into one ;-) 

The sesame ball is also very good, airy (instead of doughy) and full of red bean filling, eat them when they are fresh out of the oven! The crispy rice cake is also good.

Don't be surprised that you have to stand in line for 5 minutes, well worth it!
author: bone-dry-cappuccino L.

description:
Needless to say, their egg-tarts are on point!

Was able to beat a bit of the morning rush and didn't have to wait too far back in line by getting there a kind of early. They have a good selection and it's got that get in and get out feel. I suggest knowing what you want right when you get to the counter because they are so busy that there really isn't much time to peruse and be indecisive.

Along with the egg-tarts, I got a couple mooncakes which were also very delicious. It lives up to the hype!
author: Catherine Y.

description:
Came here today during the 4th of July holiday to grab some much needed munchies.  This place is super tiny but you can't miss it.  It always has a long line outside.  From locals to tourists, this bakery is no secret.  It has the best egg custards.  I also love the macaroons.  They have other pastry items but I stick to the one that everyone goes there for.....egg custard.  

The egg custard is creamy and smooth.  It has a beautiful flaky shell that just blends so well with the custard.  And it's not tiny either.  It is a large egg custard.  The place is inexpensive and although there is a line, it does move.  It may not seem that way because there are people with very large orders.  Today, I saw someone come away with like 6 dozen macaroons.  Wow, that's a lot calories!
author: Chrys S.

description: Yes, it's worth it! But you gotta read why! First, yes, when it is open there is always a long line that will take up a block--But! What I didnt know is this place is probably 50 sqf of space, so about 4 people can fit in the store to order. The most important thing to know is they serve your order FRESH and it's worth it! Fresh from the oven so u have to wait till the next batch comes out of the oven, cuz they won't make excess and have it sit in the shelf. Also best consumed NOW to melt like butter in your mouth, or if u take it home, reheat it in the oven. I did over order the first time I went, the rest I put in the fridge. When i reheated it the yumminess wasn't the same. Oh, CASH ONLY!
author: Mickey D.

description: I don't even like egg tarts, but these were absolutely incredible. I was initially pretty frustrated by the wait, but I would gladly do it again. Please come back from vacation, Golden Gate Bakery! I miss you. :(
author: Kelly R.

description:
SO SAD! It is closed for vacation. I don't blame them though. They make enough business in a month to last them for a year maybe... I come here every time i go up to nor cal. The egg tart here is so good It is always so crowded with the signature line on grant. 

But would definitely recommend going here when it reopens. The good thing about the crowd is that you know the egg tarts are fresh when you order it. It is for sure over price but something to try atleast once. Good to try an egg tart that is hot and gooey!
author: Willis W.

description:
You can't beat their egg custards baked freshly out of the oven. It's so tempting to come here since it's in a walking distance from my office in FiDi. The custard is rich and fresh at the right level of sweetness.

I also tried one sesame ball with red beans. It's kinda soggy after sitting out too long. If I had warmed it up in a toaster oven, it would have tasted better.
author: Saran R.

description:
I was so ready to be underwhelmed after all the hype I get about this place. 
BUT WOW I WAS SO WRONG. THIS PLACE IS SO AMAZING.
So happy to be wrong too. These people are the best at egg tarts. Makes me wonder how their other pastries are but not enough to actually try anything other than their egg tarts. This small bakery has well deserved it notoriety.
A friend and I were around Chinatown and decided to stop by. We waited about 20 minutes in line, but it was so worth it. The custard is the perfect amount of sweet and the crust is so buttery and flakey and amazing.
Will come back again for sure.
author: Sarah K.

description: A whole lot of hype for no effing reason in my humblest of opinions... When you can order something then thank your lucky stars they were open and order a ton cuz you probably won't be able to get any more. Have caution when eating them cuz the hype is most certainly better than reality.
author: Polar B.

description: Classic dan tats that are buttery and flakey. Just like the actual store's hours.
author: Jay C.

description: Line was RIDICULOUS, but we were tourists so we waited anyways.  Was encouraging to see that not everyone in line was tourists, so it's probably legit.  All we got were egg tarts, because thats apparently what they're known for.  Best I've had, although admittedly I haven't had that many in my lifetime.  Light, airy, flaky crust with an equally light, airy, and delicious filling.
author: Lisa P.

description: Best egg tart in CA. The crust is light thin n buttery, the filling is soft, smooth like silk. So good. There a reason why the line is long n it worth the wait because the egg tart is out of this work. You could smell all the goodies in the store when u r inline. I usually go there when I'm in sf get a box n it cash only. The egg tart are baked every min.
author: van t.

description:
This place serves some of the best egg custards I have ever tasted! 

The wait and line can be long, and out the door oftentimes, but I feel it is worth it, every time.

We have tried their Hong Kong style cafe dishes as well as other common pastries sold here. Those were OK, just to quickly satisfy your hunger. Again, egg custards, the best!
author: Nikki W.

description:
This bakery gets 5-stars. Their pictures say it... this place is know for their EGG-TARTS! A few years ago, I did a massive undertaking to look for the best egg-tarts in LA-OC area in Southern California... not one deserved a 5-star rating.

I'm happy to say this place blew my expectations out of the water.  Their custard was well-balanced between creamy and not overly sweet. The pastry was light and flaky, warm, and not too thick.

Go by Chinatown in SF and pick up some of these delightful treats! THIS place is worth going out of your way for (if you like egg tarts of course. If not, simply disregard my rant).

Hope that helps, have a great day Yelp!
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Ok now, these lines get long but that is because there is no place to wait inside......order, pay, out.....simple as that.........

Every visitor that comes, regardless of how many times they come to the Bay area, this place is a must...unless they are closed for vacay....

Egg tarts, macaroons, red paste puffs, chicken pies, char siu pies, that all goes into 2 boxes we order most of the time.......

There really is nothing more to say..........a must try....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
seriously the best egg tarts i have every had in my life :) and for $1.35 you get a huge egg tart!

the custard is so soft and not too sweet :)
author: Sarah T.

description: They have some pretty good egg tarts! The egg tarts have a flaky shell and the egg custard is smooth and delicious! These are some good egg tarts but I don't know if it's worth the high price point of $1.35.  To avoid the lines I would suggest going during the off hours of the weekdays because there can be a long wait. Also do try their other pastries. Their sponge cake with wafer is really good!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
The egg tarts (dan ta) are great here. Obvi you would be able to tell by the 45 min wait & loooong line. They are $1.35 each and you can buy them in a dozen for $16.20 (same price, no discount).

They also have macaroons with coconut filling, moon cakes, melon cakes, sa qi ma (rice crispy looking thing), and curry chicken & beef pies. I guess you could try 'em all if you wanted but the people I know usually just get the dan tas.
author: Julie H.

description: EGG TART. that is all.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Amazing egg tarts.  We also bought cookies, moon cakes and several other goodies. But the egg tarts were the best I've had.
author: Reena B.

description:
THEY'RE OPEN!!!! I've been coming here since I was three and always during the summer. Now they close randomly between June-September but will open on random days at random times. Today I was a lucky lady as it was my only day in SF and I walked by 'just for fun' since I knew they were closed after reading reviews from the last couple of days. To my surprise, the gate was pulled slightly open and there was a growing crowd of people outside the bakery and as I watched, the glass door would open and shut. There were only two ladies working that I could see, as I know they bake underground. One lady folded boxes behind the counter and the other was taking orders through the glass door. I waited patiently for half an hour as multiple customers formed a separate line, saying they had 'called ahead of time' and they were there just to pick up. The line that I had been standing in grew upset, and understandably so, as these customers who spoke Chinese were conversing with the one worker inside. 
As I was finishing my transaction, the line that had been waiting patiently began having words with the 'I called my order in' line.
Not going to lie, I too was getting upset at the line that claimed they were phone orders.
Cash only, and a dozen delicious tarts on their way home with me, I am a happy customer in the end! The line is worth the wait, but the wait may be longer with everyone trying to cut in.
author: Day M.

description:
I've visited SF many times but never got a chance to try this place out.  I finally made it a stop on my last trip to SF and I was AMAZED. 

At first you walk into Chinatown and find this long line outside of a cramped small bakery.  I waited for about 15-20 minutes with people walking by asking what the line was for. 

While the bakery sells other items, you really only go for their Chinese Egg Tarts.  You order it at the counter and they come out to you piping hot in a box that has pre-made holes to air it out.  The custard is hot and fluffy and the pastry part of the tart is crispy and crunchy.  Overall, it's the BEST Chinese Egg Tart that I've ever had. 

They also have these small white pan fried sweet rice cakes that my friend's grandpa used to make while growing up.  I ordered two and it instantly brought back those old memories.  

You have to order at least a half dozen when you go because you'll be devouring these like crazy!  I had like two while we stood around outside walking around.  They are just too irresistible!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
The most amazing egg tarts ever! Long line but definitely worth the wait. The interior is small, so don't expect to sit inside because there are no seats. 

Definitely worth the visit if you're in the area!
author: Mario A.

description: Do you know what Dan Tats are? Chinese Egg custards, the most delicious gooey smooth eggy desserts that melt in your mouth! They also have amazing coconut rice balls filled with coconut and peanuts :-)
author: Sara S.

description:
HANDS DOWN. BEST I've ever had.
They may look like regular "don tots" but they're definitely not!
The first bite is so warm and it literally just melts in your mouth with the soft crust just giving this egg tart an extra kick.
SOOOO GOOD. $1.10 for one? Eh, it could be worse.
author: Linda K.

description: One of very delicious egg tart in the Bay Area but too bad they are always on vacation. Do check Facebook page or call before going to ensure you get to buy it. Long line today due to holiday but worth to satisfy egg custard tart craving.
author: CH T.

description:
ARE YOU READY TO WAITTTT?!
BE READY TO WAIT IF YOU WANT AUTHENTIC HK EGG TARTS!!!!! THIS IS THE ONLY PLACE THAT EVER COMPETES TO HK EGG TARTS AS WELL. The egg tarts are just so darn delicious! It is freshly baked everyday none of them are left over night and they crispy on the tart and the egg tart is just so amazing. I feel like if i was in chinatown and i see them have eggtarts and I will tell them why do you even bother? You will never be able to compete with golden gate bakery. In all seriousness! Anyway the only reason why i wouldn't give it a perfect 5 it's because they might be ballin' but closing for a month is freaking ridiculous. Y U CLOSE SO MUCH GOLDEN GATE!? The other reason is probably at least a 20+ minute wait every time you come here...BUT MUST TRY HK NATIVES ! 


OTHER STUFF ARE DELICIOUS AS WELL THOUGH :) MUST TRY IF YOU NEVER TRIED EGG TARTS!!!
author: Ernest Y.

description: This place has hands down the BEST custard egg tarts ever....although the line can be really long, I encourage everyone to stop by and try some of these tarts when you're passing through china town!
author: Suanne C.

description:
I was walking through Chinatown earlier this year in February, so I thought, why not look for Golden Gate Bakery? It was on my bucket list for over a year, so it was definitely worth the trip.

After reading all the rave reviews on Yelp, I came in search of the famous egg tart. Save for the milky white filling and non-brûlée surface, Golden Gate's version is a close substitute for the Portuguese egg tart. Its puff pastry case is crisp and flaky, yet does not crumble easily. Its custard is sweet, creamy and smooth with the right texture. Overall a delicious, fragrant treat that rivals any egg tart back in Hong Kong.

Longing for more familiar Chinese treats, I bought a pineapple bun to try on my way home. To my pleasant surprise, Golden Gate's version was light and fluffy, and extremely crunchy in texture. Bakeries in Hong Kong seldom make buns as fresh as these nowadays, so I clearly hit the jackpot with this place.

Bottom line? Two thumbs up. Even with the notoriously long waits out the door.
author: Ines C.

description: stopped by while in SF and picked up an egg tart. It was served warm and was so delicious; I inhaled it before I got to the end of the block.
author: Megan R.

description:
Ever walk on Grant street in Chinatown in San Francisco and wonder what in the world are these folks are lining up hogging the side walk up?  Well you would probably are staring at these folks and wondering why such a line????

The secret is....... they make the best of the best Egg Custard's (DON TAT) pronounce in Cantonese.  It is sort of like a pie with a thick crust that is very flaky, in the center with a bright yellow egg custard that is soft and delicate.  One bite and you are addicted... OH MY!

Once you are inside the bakery, you can smell the sweet savory smell of authentic fine bakery that makes your mouth watery.  In your mind you are wondering what are they baking since there ovens are in the basement and the sweet smell is rising.  You will see a variety of different other goods from almond pound cake, chocolate spiral rolls, a variety of Chinese specialty breads and a lot more.

Overall, this place is the best Chinese bakery for Egg Custard's, sometimes it has a long line, but it is worth the whole time waiting for because nothing is comparable to this place!  I've been here sine i was a little kid and everything they sell is good.  This place is also famous for their Moon Cakes during Autumn Festivals.

IT IS A MUST TRY if you haven't... no REGRETS!!!

-parking-

parking.. oh boy.. this is in the heart of Chinatown in San Francisco, so it might be hard to find parking.  Go with a buddy or two and one can wait in the car while the other is in line.  I would recommend  to just double park in the yellow zone if its open and watch out for the hard working DPT or if you are lucky you might find a spot!  Parking here is very hard, unless you park in the parking lots in Chinatown.  Good luck finding a meter spot.  Make sure you bring coins for the meter because DPT works extremely hard to cite you!  Beware that Grant Street is a one way street. as well


**quick tip**
go during the weekdays and this place only accepts CASH!  Order a dozen so you can share, sharing is caring =)
author: Kenneth Y.

description:
EGG TARTS ! If only everyone just ordered egg tarts, the line here would prob go by faster. I personally hadn't heard of this place until the day I stepped foot into it. We must have arrived pretty early because this crazy line everyone speaks of hadn't really formed yet. Then again... I spent the past ten minutes chasing my friend through Chinatown as she was swiftly maneuvering her way through the crowds in order to get in line for us... haha. The store smelled delicious, I was so excited when I got my cute pink box, my only regret is not eating them right there and then. I could just imagine the taste of the hot fresh egg custard being cradled by a crisp fluffy exterior... but there was no place to sit and rest, so my box of treats was left unopened until I got home later that night. 

By then, they were soggy. I was sad. No more crispy hot warm tender amazing in my mouth. I think I put one in the toaster oven. Overall, the custard part was nice and creamy. Next time though... I'm eating it right away.
author: Christine L.

description:
Oh how I miss thee...you are so close but yet so far...

If someone is heading back down to SoCal, maybe he/she will be kind enough to buy an extra two dozen and drive it down to us LA folks... "pay it forward"???  

For those that say they have had better egg tarts...thats excellent...one less in line...
author: Justin W.

description: Everything here is pretty tasty.  Egg tarts are the highlight of the place.  They have this fluffy, melt-in-your-mouth center and a crust that's super buttery.  I also like their mochi-like desserts.  I can't wait to come back.  The main drawback is the location.  It's hard to drive into this are, since it's in the middle of busy Chinatown, the bakery is small, and the items are a bit pricey.  The food is great though!
author: Julie C.

description:
I'm not quite sure you can give an egg tart 5 'perfect' stars. Ever. I will say that the egg tarts that are cranked out here are good, best when you're there and they give it to you from fresh out of the oven. The flaky crust makes this dessert, and the balance of sweetness to the custard is pretty good. I'm not sure if I need a dozen or more (I've seen so many people with the pink dozen boxes being carried away), but definitely worth a try if you're ever in the Chinatown district. Now, for the long long lines for anything...I say pass. I happened to come here on a weekday so there was zero wait. Wait 'til the weekend to come here, you're asking to compete with foodie tourists who know to find this spot. Don't bother wasting time driving here is all possible. Parking in Chinatown is a nightmare!

Perhaps on another down day, I'll return to try their other pastry goodies. Be sure to bring cash and know what you want once you're in the front of the counter. Stupidity is not appreciated here :)
author: Sophia C.

description:
I was visiting SF the same week of the Moon Festival, I had to get moon cakes for my family...so I sacrificed my time to wait in this ridiculous line.  It really is ridiculous because it's almost an hour before you get in the door...why? Well, the women in the bakery apparently don't believe in calculators, or the cash register, everything is done by head calculations on a piece of paper.  THIS IS WHAT'S CAUSING THE LONG LINE!!! AND the fact that some people in there are ordering like 10 boxes (probably to resell it somewhere else for twice the price!!!)  Who dares eat 10 boxes of egg tarts???  

Anyway, on to my wait in this ridiculous line...this lady in front of me kept making fun of me for waiting in line for moon cakes.  She said it's not that great and she can't believe I'll wait in line for such expensive moon cake, she said it's around $9.50 each.  I was like "whoa...that's pricey"  Then she kept going on and on....giving me the evil eye...whatever lady!  So I finally get to the front and this stupid lady ended up ordering the very same moon cake she has been dissing about!!! WHAT??? AND it's not $9.50 each, it is IF you want like 4 egg yolks on your cake, I only wanted one and it's around $5-7 depending on what you get.  Not bad...more expensive than most but it is delicious! AND the egg tarts...OMG, so good!!! but you gotta eat it fresh, like right there.  I see now why people wait in line for the egg tarts, it really is THAT GOOD!!!  

Lastly, watch out for the lady from the next store to the right, she gets very upset if you line up in front of her store.  AND don't buy anything there either, she charges like 3x more than the store 2 doors down.  She tried to sell me this pendant for $10, then when I bargain it down to like half, she's like NO.  Whatever, I went down 2 store and the lady there sold me the same frickin pendant for $3, with bargaining of couse.   

ALWAYS bargain when you buy in China Town...everything is marked up like 100%!!! only suckers pay full price and since I'm asian, I'm no sucker!
author: Katie L.

description: A small little shop with what I would call the best egg tarts of SF! My only complain is that it's tiny and has few employees in the front so there's a line most of the time. Usually there's no line after 6pm though.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Believe the hype, but don't get in line. You'll probably be standing in front of me. 

I'm not generally a huge fan of egg tarts or eggy tasting custards, but this is just right. Ethereally light custard and very little egg flavor with a touch of sweetness, enfolded in thin layer upon layer of delicate, crisp, flaky pastry. They always come hot and fresh, and it's great when steam rises from the tarts when you take a bite. Had some damn good egg tarts in Hong Kong, and I'd say these are still among my favorite. 

Their other pastries are also delicious. The mochi, rolled in coconut and filled with peanuts, is always fresh and soft with just the right amount of chewy resistance, and the right amount of sweetness. Their little curry filled savory pies are good, but kind of skimp on the beef and veggies in the middle. The red bean moon cakes when they have them are also delish, but on the oilier side. Had a barbecue pork pastry there once, but that was cold and didn't taste the freshest, so I did not repeat. 

I can't tell if speaking Cantonese gets me better or worse service. Maybe it's just because I understand the cartloads of sass being flung back and forth by the old ladies who work there, between themselves and at customers. It's usually pretty entertaining. 

**Tips**
- Going on a weekday evening generally guarantees no lines 
- This place is cash only
- Don't let the old ladies talk you into buying other pastries that you don't want - especially the large gummy looking ones - I was coerced into this once and did not enjoy the experience
- If you get only one thing, of course get the egg tart
author: Selina K.

description:
I waited in line for a very long time to try the egg tart and the Chinese rice krispy. The rice krispy was mediocre. And though I'm a big fan of custards, this one was a little TOO eggy for my taste. (I'm not exactly sure what I was expecting; it is an egg tart, after all.) Egg filling aside, the crust on the tart was incredible--flaky and crumbly with just enough sweet. I'm sure if you're a big fan of eggy desserts, this will be right up your alley.

The service was rushed and less than friendly. Oh, and they only accept cash, which is an inconvenience for people like me who never have any on them.

I was so looking forward to the Golden Gate Bakery, but, it turns out, it just wasn't my thing.
author: Samantha D.

description:
Loved the warm flaky egg tarts. Am going again tomorrow to buy some. 
Go midweek for a no wait/no line experience. Have some there with some litchi tea from Vital Leaf and bring a few home to have later. Best semi sweet egg tarts ever.
author: Rutuja K.

description:
I don't like egg tarts. 

That being said, the egg tarts at this place are the SHIZZLE.  My taste buds have been opened to the deliciousness of these wobbly jello-y things but I'm doomed.. I can never eat egg tarts anywhere else again.
author: Brandon Y.

description: The egg custard tarts are so buttery and flaky... it's apparent by the zillions of positive reviews below me. No need to repeat what's been said a ton of times. There was surprisingly no line when i came by. How is that possible??
