The almond cookies crumble wonderfully and the sachimas (sticky chinese rice krispies) are thick and sweet enough to give you a cavity. Yum.
author: Samantha L.

description: BBQ pork bun and egg tarts are the best around, but everytime I go there, they are either closed for vacation or a huge line. Parking sucked too... Effin SAD........
author: George K.

description: More than 5 stars deserved! Super delicious EVERYTIME I'm in the city it is a must that I come here and get dozens of egg tarts because it's just that good. I do not care if the wait is long the wait is worth every minute and you cannot just get one egg tart because you will regret not getting a bunch. Their crust it perfect and the egg density is also perfect! Not too sweet either, I refuse to eat any kind of egg tart but this one. My sister never liked egg tarts until this was introduced to her, she was forced to love it because it was that amazing. Definitely worth a stop when you're around Chinatown!
author: Vi C.

description:
4 stars, instead of 5 stars because they cannot meet demand!

ARGHHH! Can someone please tell me why i waited in line for one hour AGAIN for these darn, delicious, right-out -of-the-oven eggtarts? At least this time it was only 1 hour; last time, i waited for 1 hr and 45 minutes. No kidding.

 JUST MAKE SURE NOT TO GO DURING the month of SEPTEMBER b/c of moon festival! I ordered two types of their mooncakes a couple years back (hence, the almost 2 hour wait), and it was DEFINITELY not worth it.  JUST come for eggtarts--hopefully, on a weekday to avoid the hassle!

The line was not even long, but it moves SOOO freakin slow cuz everyone orders eggtarts, and they cannot meet demand! The lady behind me ordered 5 dozen, the girl behind me ordered 2 dozens, and I ordered 3 dozens...GAH

Next time, I will order 10 dozens, and sell them in front of the store for $2.00, instead of $1.15! =P

Okay, i know after venting, i will forget it next year, and get in line again and wait for another 2 hours....

Gah, please help me stop this addiction!
author: Jen H.

description:
Would give it 4 or 5 but DANG it's busy. One time I was in SF but had to keep walking b/c all the tourists were in the lonnnnng line to get the egg tarts.

Another reason for star dock is that the prices are crazy premium here.  It's good but I don't think the extra cost equates with the taste so value-wise, it is not that great.  I've had similar quality egg tart in Oak-town.
author: Sonny W.

description:
I think the number of reviews, 4.5 star rating, and long line speak for themselves.

This place is a Chinatown classic. Prices have gone up over the years and I believe there are better/cheaper options around that are less touristy. 

Alas, it's an experience in itself to come here so I would definitely recommend it to anybody craving an egg tart or other baked Cantonese good.
author: Michael K.

description: Best dan tats (tarts) in the city. It comes hot with silky egg filling. The tart itself is soft, flaky and somewhat buttery. Also try the coconut tart, and pineapple filled buns. They also have delicious banana paste and low po bang (version of pineapple filled cookie, translated as "wife's cookie"). I've been here since I was a toddler and know the ladies who bakes these delicious goodness. They make so much from just the tarts that it seems like that's their main sell for now. As a local, their tendency to take random vacations and close the shop doesn't bother me since I can come another time. I am not sure if I would make an entire trip  if I lived elsewhere, just to come here. Expect a long line, and eat that damn tart immediately.
author: Rowena N.

description: My mum waited for an hour to buy egg custard. It's really delicious. It's very sweet and it match my taste. I love egg custard since I was in China. This one really worth the time that we spend in queue. A suggestion is to go early in the morning because they open at 8. The line will only take 20 mins if u come early.
author: Yiren S.

description:
EGG. TARTS. Goodness gracious Golden Gate, your buttery, eggy, delicate flakiness wins me over every time. Whenever I visit and it happens to be open (which it almost never is, unfortunately), I buy at least a dozen to bring home, and they never last more than a week.
Eat them fresh out the oven, chilled from the fridge, or reheated in your home toaster oven. Any way, they are delectable!

I haven't tried anything else in this simple bakery, but my stomach believes the egg tarts themselves warrant 4 stars. :]
author: Shirley V.

description:
GOLDEN GATE BAKERY! I don't know what else to say. If you ever hear these three words together in this order, your mouth should start watering immediately!

I always get the egg tarts here. They sell one for $1.15, and a dozen for $13.80. Give in to temptation and just buy one or two dozens. You won't regret it.

There's typically a line here, so prepare to wait. However, service is fast and the ladies are nice, so there's nothing to complain about. Golden Gate Bakery has yet to disappoint. 5 stars!!

Picture: http://bit.ly/hOs8eO
author: Katty K.

description:
Waiting in line for an hour? Yup. What are you waiting for? Egg Custard. That's it? Yes. You're crazy. No, you're crazy for not wanting to try some! Best damn egg custard I've ever had. Please note, I HATE egg custard, but this place is just extremely well done and put together.

First you'll notice how big they are. Look at how it looks. The casing and crust is flaky, light and buttery, not hard like a cookie crust like most dim sum places in LA and OC. Second, take a bite and slither that egg custard towards the roof of your mouth and let it just melt. Equal parts salty, equal parts milky/creamy, equal parts light and fluffy (yes the custard "feels" light and fluffy). 

I do not regret looking like an idiot standing out on the side walk that literally wrapped around and down the street a bit with my mom. Quite surprisingly, my mom was willing to wait and try and she even commented that this was the best she's had (other than her own). *shrug* It's what all mom's say huh?
author: Viet T.

description:
Note: I've never actually gone to GG Bakery to pick up a "dan tot" (That's Cantonese for "egg tart," my non-Canto speaking friend), however my friend recently offered me one, and ZOMG!!!

Golden Gate Bakery's dan tot is probably the best dan tot I've ever popped into my mouth!!  (And this is coming from someone who recently visited Hong Kong, the home of the dan tot).  Their egg tarts are the most lightest, delicate egg tarts I've ever placed my grubby little paws on.  They are not overly sweet, just right.  The crust is flakey and the perfect density.  Yum yum yum!

If you are visiting San Francisco, you DEFINITELY need to check out Golden Gate Bakery for their dan tots!!!  However, be forewarned, I hear that the shop is shut down randomly for days, weeks, or months on end.  So cross your fingers and swing by!
author: Matt S.

description:
I guess today must be my lucky day. Golden Gate Bakery is open once again after a gawd awful long vacation (how do these people make money?) and there was NO LINE. I ordered a box of six egg custard tarts and ate one right away.

They were lightly warm and the shell was noticeably deeper than most of its peers. Not that I am complaining because I don't mind the extra crust holding the soft but fluffy custard in the middle. A bite into this heavenly goodness--first into the smooth custard that's almost oozing out, then into the flaky crust shattering into little shards--and it makes sense why this is so popular.

But I refuse to declare this the best in town, at least not yet. The crust was flaky alright but it lacks the smell of butter. They probably didn't use it because butter is more expensive than say, shortening. At $1.35 a tart, I see only a very slight reason why GG Bakery's is better than competitors such as AA Bakery which only sells their egg tarts for $1. Nevertheless, I shall be back for more and other items if they soooooo happened to feel like opening their shop again few months from now.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
Best egg tarts ever! They're a little pricey at $1.25 each, but soooo worth it. The crust is super flaky, and the filling is great too. Eat it right away if it's fresh from the oven! I've tried so many other egg tarts, and I've never found anything on par with this place.
The biggest downside though is that they're closed a lot. So many times have I walked over to find a sign that they're on vacation (they pretty much take a vacation every season). They're also not that great at picking up the phone, so you can't really tell if they're open until you get there. But it's still worth it in case it's open! I like to check if there are recent Yelp reviews written as a sign as to whether they're open. :P
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This review is highly unnecessary, but after having Zanze's Cheesecake Disappointmentedness here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/zanzes-cheesecake-san-francisco#hrid:fA9eFg6NYRUc7_zvwMZO5Q I HAD TO REVIEW. 

You probably guessed it... EGG TART. Correct! One egg tart for you. You also probably guessed... Long lines that move fast! Correct, another egg tart for you. I bet you probably were shocked that the prices maintained relatively low even after being Yelpitized (Yelp+Baptism=officially being a business worthy of visiting)! Whoohooo you are at 3 egg tarts now. 

BUT WAIT! What you didn't know is that they also make amazing moon cakes, and horrible, horrible, "BBQ PUFF FLUTES". I ADVISE YOU TO STAY AWAY FROM THESE. I got seriously ill a few years back making the mistake of buying a dozen for my family. It is a bakery, please stay away from the meat being served here.

ALSO, they were always on vacation so CALL AHEAD and see if they are open! I just went today, and is happy to say that yes they are open! So go and get your 3 egg tarts you righteously earned, and pick up 9 more for self satisfaction!!!
author: Jay L.

description:
The Egg Custard Tarts come out all warm and flakey every time due to the high volume sold. This ensures a ridiulously creamy bite who's flavor goes on for DAYS....

Of course...should you come during peak hours it may very well take you DAYS to put your sweet tooth to rest due to how ridiculously long the lines can get without warning. 

Luckily , I managed to snag a bag of these much-sought-after goodies on a random Wednesday evening and was delighted to see that they kept their warmth after a drive out to Dolores park to enjoy my treasures while sprawled out in the sun.

Lucky me indeed:D

Are they as good as everyone raves? Yup

Are they wait-an-hour-in-line-amidst-the-hustle-and-bustle-of-China-Town-during rush-hour-good? Ummm...not quite, but if you're driving by randomly and the line is short definitely go for it!
author: Kevin T.

description:
egg tart egg tart egg tart egg tart egg tart

Tip: Don't plan your vacations around this place - they close randomly for days at a time. I've flown to SF just for them...twice. And they were closed both times :(
And please save yourself the heartache and don't go anywhere else nearby for egg tarts when they're closed. :( :( :(
author: Mikey T.

description: I was told I had to go here by an employee working in another shop in Chinatown and he was absolutely right - it was well worth the stop!  They're only open 8 or 9 months out of the year and there's always a line.  We got the egg custard and a sesame ball the size of my fist.  The custard is served hot and the crust is flaky.  It melts in your mouth - delicious!!  Their hours are weird sometimes and they are cash only but if you're there, they're open, and you're willing to wait in line, it's so worth it.
author: Sara R.

description: I can't really give a review, as they are closed and on vacation. Boo-hoo. So sad.
author: Julee E.

description:
I've always heard great stuff about this place! I finally got the chance to try this place when I was in the city for a day. 

I came on a weekday. I expected the line to be long but my wait was fairly short and fast! My cousin and I waited about 10 minutes? We each ordered a dozen of egg tarts. Let me tell you ... BEST EGG TART EVER! Worth the trip and everything. 

Totally coming back for more heaven in a form of egg tarts. hahahha.
author: Diane H.

description: For my last day I San Fran, I bought 2 of these for my plane ride home and as I was devouring it in the sky- I can see what the fuss is all about.  The egg tart is the perfect amount of creamy and sweetness and that sucker is massive and you can't stop at one.  If you are a lifelong fan of egg tarts- this place is a must try! But I recommend you stick to what they are known for since their other pastries are not nearly as good.
author: Betty L.

description:
This place is like a urban legend, except that its real.

The pros:

 Egg tarts come out piping hot - dont be those people who have wait until they "cool down", if its not molten, its not worth eating

The crust, flaky and delicious - who would ever eat the cookie/pie type crust that some other places serve?

Texture: right texture and consistency

The wait: none! come during a weekday if you work in the financial district, faster than in and out burger!

Not much of a con, but i thought it was a bit on the sweet side for me but that could just be preference..
author: B H.

description:
Overrated hype! This is just another Chinese bakery! Nothing special here. The time I spent in line was a waste. The baked goods tasted like the hundreds of other bakeries,and the packaging for the moon cakes are subpar. 

You could get the same thing at any other Chinese bakery and probably spend less time and money.
author: G. L.

description: My friend and I were in town for the weekend. We walked by this place a few times and the vacation sign was up, but there appeared to be bake goods in their interior case. Third time's a charm it seems, because on our last pass by we lucked out. The door was open and there was no line, we had an egg tart that was divine. Warm. Flaky light pastry. Not too sweet. Go here. If they are closed check back. It's worth it!
author: Julie K.

description:
Definitely as good as it gets.  Their egg custards are the best I've had, EVER.  They come out piping hot, the egg custard is just perfect and the crust is flaky.  

$1.15 is a lot to pay for an egg tart compared to most bakeries that sell them for $0.80.  But it is totally worth it.  The line can build up here but it goes quick.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Yo people, I'm really happy you are reading the other reviews, and I'm gonna let you finish.. but Golden Gate bakery has the best egg tarts of all time! OF ALL TIME!!

Ok, now that that's over with, here is why. The egg custard part is smooth and soft like pudding, not hard or gelatin-like like some other places. Their crust is thin, light, and fluffy. Some places make their crust with a lot of butter and oil which you can tell from your napkin, but this place makes it crispy without the oily mess. Sometimes I feel like their crust is too thin since the whole thing falls apart in my hand, but it really is the perfect ratio of egg custard and crust in my mouth.

If it's the weekend or a holiday, expect to wait in line along the sidewalk. Since the egg tarts have to bake, it could take a while. I would recommend going in pairs, so one of you can get that t-shirt that says "my coldest winter was a summer in San Francisco", or the Hello Kitty backpack. Once you make it through the line and get a hold of your egg custard though, wait a minute and just hold it for a while.. because otherwise you might burn your mouth because it's fresh and really, really hot.
author: Ken W.

description:
I've had my fair share of egg tarts and when I heard about this place I wanted to give it a try. 

The wait was ridiculous! And we were surrounded by tourists which has to say something. I'm even embarrassed to say we waited for over an hour and in the back of my head I kept thinking "this is going to be soooo worth it!" ..... And I'm left  just thinking "eh"

They were good - hot, flakey, sweet...but not as eggy as other places I've had...personal preference I guess.

I'd go again if the line took 10mins or less.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Best Egg Tarts!  The crust is flaky, and the egg custard is firm and just melts in your mouth.  It is well worth the wait. 

The other dim sum items such as the Bak Tong Koh (chinese steamed rice cake) is done perfectly.  It is light, fluffy, has a slight sourdough bread taste, but no aftertaste at all.
author: Shannon L.

description: I give them 1 star for bad service. They have the best egg tarts in town. They are the best and they know it. The old ladies behind the counter r not the most efficient or nicest to customers. They just don't care. They don't have to care, look at the long line of customers every time they open their door.
author: Eva W.

description:
I walked in this place and it was very busy. I came on the recommendation of friends and was happy to find it open as I've read and heard that it is often closed.

Service is to-the-point and fast. Not necessary rude, but staff can definitely be sassy, in a funny sort of way.  

I only had the egg tarts, but they were delicious! Probably the best I've ever had. Just writing this is making my mouth water.
author: Camille B.

description: My son and I are in San Francisco on a mini vacation. We stopped here today for a snack. I loved the coconut macaroon. My son had the Pineapple Napoleon and he loved it.
author: Nicole B.

description:
They seriously have the best egg tarts ever. I'm not a big fan for egg tarts so I was a little suspicious going this far (from Berkeley :P) to eat an egg tart. But when I took my first bite into this wonderful little pastry, it was AMAZING! 
I will definitely take friends here!
author: Kathy C.

description:
Worth the hype?  Yes!  A must try if you are in SF's Chinatown!  I like that the tarts are pretty large and fill with a good amount of custard.  Get just enough to eat the same day, as I don't think they are nearly as good the day after.  

For a bit more about Golden Gate and Dan Tats see here:
http://thirstyfortea.com/2014/01/23/dim-sum-recipe-4-egg-custard-tarts-dan-tat/
author: Bonnie E.

description:
The egg tarts are very good. I'm thinking that it's the super flaky delicious crust paired with the egg custard. I think the crust makes this egg tart a winner. It is way more costly than other egg tarts out there though :/

Also, the walnut pound cake is so good! This is a new obsession of mine. I never really thought that something as simple as pound cake can taste so good! It is very light and flavorful.

On occasion, I would also get the bbq pork pie or strudel? idk what it's called. And the white gooey banana flavored thing. idk what that's called as well, kinda reminds me of mochi, but in stick form.

If you happen to be in Chinatown and feel like lining up, this is a must go to spot.
author: Tina S.

description: I've tried custard tarts from many places including China, Macau, Hong Kong, Hawaii, etc... but the best is definitely from GGB. $1.15 will get you a warm and flaky custard tart.
author: Connie M.

description: Omg! The egg custard are to die for! Can't you tell with the reviews and lines out the door?! The egg custard is sweet, tasty and the crust is flaky and oh so good! :-p The coconut macaroons are delicious too! The best thing about the egg custard is you can refrigerate it and reheat it the next day and it tastes great! Definitely recommended!
author: Sue L.

description:
GGB, I sure do miss you from Dallas.  The egg tarts here are absolutely the best that I have ever tasted.  Large size, crispy/flaky warm exterior shells, but soft/sweet interior.  

They must be doing something right if they can always be on "vacation" and close the store at random days/times.
author: Stanley W.

description:
This is the destination for melt in your mouth egg custard tarts.  I have only tried it once and it has impressed me for life.  However, they seem to be on vacation every time I visit San Francisco.  

Too bad they don't travel well since I would like to bring them back with me on the airplane.  Another thing is that they wouldn't last too long because I would be sampling every one of them on the way to the airport!
author: Vicky C.

description:
For bakeries in Chinatown, Yes, Golden Gate Bakery holds the top spot for best Danh Tats (Egg Custard Tarts).   However, having been coming here for years, I would only come here for the tarts and just that.  

I can understand the long lines awaiting outside of Golden Gate Bakery as they are publicized in nearly all of the city guides as one of the must-visit spots in when in Chinatown for locals and visitors alike, but despite this, I don't think it deserves the award for BEST danh tats in all San Francisco.  

My award for that distinction goes to my childhood hole-in-the-wall in all aspects--Lung Fung Bakery in the Richmond District, that specializes in awesome Danh Tats as well as piping hot-ass Chinese buns and breakfast goods. 

With that out of my system, flavor-rise, the tarts are pretty darn good!  The egg custard is the thickest and deepest that I've ever had. Custard is nice and fluffy, but a bit too soft for my preference.  I would prefer my custard to have a little texture to them.  An example of what I mean: When I pick up a tart by the rim of the crust, I would prefer it not to bend and break apart on me.

I also ordered myself an Apple Roll.  Pretty much just a pound cake roll with glazed apples, just as you'd find in an apple pie.  I liked. 

Golden Gate Bakery is definitely worth a visit to while in Chinatown, but in terms of the best Danh Tats in S.F., well that distinction is a bit too high in my eyes.  

All in all, not THE best...but just one of the best.
author: Cass J.

description:
After three different failed visits staring aghast at their "We're away on vacation" sign, I was finally able to try their legendary Dan Tats. That's the sign of a booming business, taking a vacay whenever you darn well please.

For $1.25, Golden Gate Bakery produces ones the size of your palm with a deliciously flaky crust enveloping a sunny yellow custard center. It's like all the Dan Tats I've ever eaten didn't deserve to be called that. Clearly, the other three dozen people in line also agreed. 

Most folks mowed right into them as they stepped out of line leaning against nearby buildings and every single one of them had expressions of pure delight. The wait is a bit brutal but worth it!
author: Faith Y.

description:
I just had an mouth orgasm while eating their egg custard. OMGah! Need more!

Wished they open more often to satisfy my dirty cravings for their egg tarts.
author: Winn D.

description:
Egg Tart and Hong Kong Bread: 10 stars
Price: Fair
Service: 2 stars
Average: 6 stars

ALL ABOUT THE EGG TARTS!! This is the BEST, and I mean the BEST bakery in SF. Let me take that back, best asian bakery I've ever had! People come all over just to have their egg tarts. Everytime my family goes to SF, we would come home with maybe 5-10 boxes of these goodies! Gotta spread the love to all the families you know? I went last time (when I went to Wicked) and I think I came back with 5 boxes myself! We had them sitting in the car (for a good 4-5 hours in the heat!) .... and they were still so good by the time we got them home still. They make it sooo fresh and it runs out so fast, so you always get a fresh batch! We even ate one on the spot as we were waiting to pay. That's how good it was. Drool, I want another one now. 

Anyways, the locals (esp the younger kids/teens), seem to drop by pretty often. I see them stand in this crazy ass line just to order 1-2 custard egg tarts. WHAT? The line is crazy, I would at least get a box! I think if it was in my hood, I would go by pretty often to get myself this delicious treat.

Is it sad that everytime I think of SF, I think of eggtarts? I try to find some way to get there (crazy china town). 


Service: Okay, rude rude rude! They have yelled at my family members, myself, anyone you can think of. You know how it is, you're asian, you're the hot stuff in town.....you will make money no matter what. ATTITUDE! Don't even bother asking them for a separate box because you want to split your goods in half for another party. They will rip you a good one. You see, to bakeries, boxes are like gold. They don't waste money giving them away nilly willy.
author: Susan L.

description:
MUST TRY THE DAN TAT (EGG TART)!!

Yes, there are lines but the wait is worth the deliciousness of their egg tart.  If you've never tried an egg tart before, maybe you should consider trying one somewhere else first so that you have a comparison for how much better their quality is in comparison to many other Chinese bakeries in San Francisco.

The crust is flaky and just the right amount of crunchiness.  It's best when it's still hot out of the oven so if you order a half dozen or a dozen to bring home, be sure to stick them back in the oven and re-heat.  

They do not skimp on the size or their preparation.  The center of the egg tart is smoothe, creamy and full of flavor.  I literally start giggling by it's great flavor and texture!

They are quite expensive...  A dozen is $15.00 or $1.25 each.  YIKES!
author: Sandy L.

description:
This place have gotten more more crazy over the years. I would give it 5 stars, but minus 1 for the SUPER long line and minus 1 for the high price for chinese pastries and buns. 

This place is located on Grant Street in Chinatown. This place is small but usually filled with people. The wait in line can be up to 1or more hours. One time I wanted an egg tart from there and my mom waited over 1 hrs to get 6 egg tarts!!  In my opinion, they have good quality pastries but its on the pricey side for a Chinese pastries. I believe that for some items are double the price for the same thing at a different place.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Best egg tart I've ever had, go early, you'll be in a line getting ready for the best egg tart you'll ever taste. 

The sponge cakes isn't bad either.
author: Amy L.

description: Minus one because they are always closed. I want my eggtart and I want it NOW!!! ...Please? :(
author: Allison S.

description: The egg tart is really good. We had to stop to finish it.  I haven't try the other stuff.
author: Liz N.

description:
Got there at 10:30am; stood in line for 45 minutes, by the time I got to the front the line was 50% longer. it was so horrible: 

- you'll be STUCK there, falling to human irrationality, thinking 'man, I've already been in this line for 30 minutes... I GUESS IT'S TOO LATE TO LEAVE' 
- bring a hat and sunscreen because you will wait out there, slowly getting long term skin damage
- you will be 100% sure you could make egg tarts from scratch with butter, flour, eggs, sugar, and cream in the time it took to inch forward in line and finally get there
- everyone around you is NOISY and AWFUL. 
- passersby stare at you, thinking 'what hedonistic idiot would wait in line for 45 minutes on a smelly street in a tourist ghetto to buy pastries?' 
- people buy 4-5 boxes of pastries. there is no human need for this. no one has families this big. it is just a move brought out of stockpiling desperation as a justification for your human existence
- they're fresh out of the oven! GUESS WHAT I HAVE AN OVEN AT HOME TOO. 
- i'm pretty sure the major wait is that the egg tarts are indeed baked on the spot, and not because they are more magical than other egg tarts. 

I guess I was curious since they were on vacation for so long. next time I'll just make them at home. or pay some schlep to deliver them. 

at least the egg tarts are 20-30% better than a supermarket egg tart. 

seriously, DONT BE THAT PERSON. life is short.
author: S C.

description:
4.5 stars, 1400 reviews, and a line of 20+ people outside "this place has to be good" I thought... Wrong!  So much high praise on their egg tarts, I ordered 4 without hesitation.  Their moon cakes were also highly recommended, so despite the shockingly steep price of $7, I also ordered one of these (I believe it was white lotus flavor, the one the woman there said was their best and most popular).  

Well, the egg tart (which is supposed to have a sweet light custard flavor) tasted as if I had placed some runny-scrambled eggs atop a beautiful flaky crust.  The crust was fantastic, but the filling was so strongly tasting of egg, I couldn't finish one.  What a huge disappointment.  After that I still had hopes on the moon cake, but it was also a colossal failure, tasting like some sort of pasty spiced peanut-or something I can't quite figure out, but horribly bad to sum it up.  

So after about a 15 min wait, and nearly $15, I feel as if I wasted both my time and money with nothing good to show for it.  After a few bites of each, I dropped the remaining contents of my boxed goods in a garbage about 20 feet away.
author: Nick G.

description:
This was an impulse stop on my way home from lunch in North Beach.  There is usually a line to the corner on the weekends, so I jumped at the opportunity to get the highly recommended egg custard tarts while there were just a few people in line.  Had there been a line, the tarts would have been worth waiting for.  I had no idea what to expect, but these little tarts were sweet and light and fluffy.  The filling complimented the flaky crust perfectly.  They were warm and just tasted happy.  

It's a small shop with a no nonsense staff.  On a weekend, go in knowing what you want because the line is growing longer every minute,  It's cash only, but for under $1.50 each, I could pick up two tarts with what was in my pocket.
author: Lilly N.

description:
My friends and I came here after dim sum and surprisingly there was no line. The egg custard / don tot was good, but it was not the best I ever had; it's up there. We got ours fresh out of the oven.

The curry beef puffs were recommended to us; but, most of us weren't a fan. 

I would say just get the don tots here. Friends loved them so much they brought some back home to New York! True story!
author: Robert N.

description:
My friend introduced me to the famous egg tarts here and I, in turn, introduced them to my whole family. They are absolutely delicious. I've intended to try their other items but always default to the tarts. 

I do think that the lady behind the counter (I'm presuming she's the owner) should smile a bit more--I mean, she's raking in the dough (pun intended). It's hit or miss with her. Sometimes she's friendly, sometimes she's grouchy.
author: Vince L.

description:
They literally have THE BEST egg custards I've tasted in my entire LIFE. I wish I was exaggerating. In addition, since most people are probably tired of hearing the same suggestion every time, I would recommend the red bean moon cake with the egg inside of it. 

Tip: the employees get angry if you take pictures of the business. Bring cash.
author: Emmanuel C.

description:
About time I give this place a review. My family comes to this bakery every time we visit my grandparents. We usually take home a few boxes of goods for ourselves and friends back home. Be warned though, the line could get REALLYY long! 

We normally get the egg tarts and sweetheart cake (also known as wife cake or old lady cake). The egg tarts have a perfectly crisp and flaky crust that works with the soft, sweet custard. If you like egg tarts, you will definitely love these. They come hot from the oven, and nothing is better than a hot egg tart. Yum! 

I have not found another place that makes good sweetheart cakes, so I was very disappointed when I learned they would not be making them ]: We didn't leave empty handed though, 2 dozen egg tarts for the ride home! My boyfriend scarfed down 2 as soon as we were out the door -__-

I don't think it's worth a super long wait. When it's not that bad, go give it a try! Trust me, you will not be disappointed.
author: Fiona C.

description:
Lives up to the reputation of best egg custard tarts in SF, and possible the world! If ever in the area, always be sure to stop in to grab some goodies. The line may seem daunting but it moves quickly and the line is justified.

Beware they have random unusually long vacations so you could possibly make the trip all the way to Chinatown only to find scribbled Chinese on a piece of paper telling you they're close for who knows how long.
__
Feb '12 Health Score - 92!
author: Dennis L.

description: I recommend calling in before going to the bakery... they have a tendency to close on random days for vacation
author: Moly R.

description: I love the egg tarts here!!! Hot out of the oven, with crust that is crisp and flaky but just soft enough, and lots of egg custard! DELICIOUS! The only ones I've had that could compare were Portugese egg tarts from Margaret's Cafe e Nata in Macau, but those are different in kind so it's not even a fair comparison. I've tried egg tarts from all over Asia, searching for the perfect one, but none of them lived up to GG Bakery's - so glad that they're located in SF! Definitely worth the wait if you've never been before.
author: Rose Y.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery has always given me the warm fuzzies, and no, that's not because of my heritage.  It's certainly no secret (i.e., 642 reviews before mine), but this long time favorite destination cranks out some of the bestest, most gloriously rich and creamy "egg custard tarts" that money can buy.  In fact, if you're normally turned off by these "occasionally" gag-inducing yellow yolky monstrosities, then Golden Gate Bakery may even make you a convert.  It certainly did so for me!

It's because the "warm fuzzies" immediately start when you're thinking about your upcoming journey to this really old bakery, rumored to turn out the most delicious forms of this "treat."  Momentum builds when you're walking down Grant Avenue, where you'll invariably see a line of people standing in the street.  When you near the non-descript store front, you will usually need to careen, through a "somewhat" politely waiting mass of people, as if these treats were free. The ladies who work the counter will enthusiastically greet, laugh, joke, and treat you as if they were your "nice auntie."  Oh, and the prices are "right", being $13.80 a dozen and for just a single, $1.15. 

Overall, one bite of a Golden Gate Bakery "egg custard tart" will be just as mouthwateringly exciting as it'll be serene, and you'll immediately know that they take the "flakiness of crust," to the extreme.  I mean, I didn't even like egg custards until I came to Golden Gate Bakery, and geez, now they're something that I am beginning to "feen."  5 stars.
author: Luke S.

description:
Warning: they could close for vacation/ any reason so better call ahead before you come. 
You need to be patient enough if you want to try their famous egg tart, since there are always a long line.  One of the best egg custard ever that I tried .
Curry chicken puff also my favorite. 
The ladies in the counter aren't that friendly but they are quick in accepting the order
and counting the total :-)
Tried the mooncake during mooncake festival but just ok..
If you became their regular and order a couple dozens, then hopefully  you can order by phone and pick up.  :-P
author: Julia S.

description:
Is very hard to find egg tarts that are yummy in SF compared to the ones from my hometown. Golden Gate Bakery made it exactly what I've been craving for. 

SUPERB!
author: Rachel L.

description:
To many people, Super Bowl 48 was a total disaster. The game was completely lopsided and the commercials were horrible. The only shining moment was Bruno Mars during the halftime show and the fact that I wounded up winning two squares from my office Super Bowl pool. The spoils of victory? $100.00 cash and egg tarts for everybody!

After a nice lunch at the House of Nanking, I jaunted around SF Chinatown, like a tourist, to walk off the greasy goodness and prevent a pre-mature food coma. As I passed by Golden Gate Bakery, I am used to either seeing a huge line out the door or a metal gate signifying that they're closed (by the way, they are closed 'for vacation' way too often if you ask me, but if business is good and you can afford to do it, more power to you). But today, to my surprise, no metal gate and no line. I was like a deer in headlights, completely confused by what was taking place. Without haste, I bolted inside to order a quick dozen egg tarts to take back to the office. Other customers were equally surprised and we joked that we were in sympatico, one even walking outside to double check the awning. These egg tarts are simply the best in the Bay Area. Buttery, flaky pastry filled with the greatest mixture of egg and custard. At $1.40 a piece, they're a bargain considering an American bakery or patisserie would charge $3 or $4. And today, getting in and out under 3 minutes, that is the ultimate WIN!
author: Mike L.

description: There is a reason there is always a long line down the street - the egg tarts are worth the wait.  After I heard of this place, I had a few false starts (the store is perpetually "on vacation" until it's not), but the third time was the charm - on a rainy day, the line was short and I got to enjoy a half dozen perfect egg tarts without much of a wait.
author: Josh Q.

description:
All I can really say is WOW! The best and biggest egg custard tart I ever ate! The egg custard was sweet and thick in the inside and the outside was nice and crispy! The price for a dozen was $15, totally worth it! The other snack that we bought was a brown and white swirl pastry that was like chips, they were awesome too! 

The hype about this place is most definitely well deserved! I love this place! (Wish they had one here in Southern California though) =(
author: Connie C.

description:
I can't believe I haven't already reviewed this place!!

This place should be a landmark in SF, because if you're from SF you already know....and if you're not from SF, you probably already know too!! They make THE BEST, i kid you not, THE BEST dan-tat (egg custard tart) known to mankind. THe custard is light and fluffy, although super greasy, and the crust is so flaky its unbelievable (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=TMdKP5AxSMznFx1dHtFVFA)! During chinese new year, don't even try to come and get some because the line to list place is a mile long!! NO JOKE!

TIP: make sure to call ahead if you're going to venture out to the boonies in chinatown because they're known to close up shop for a month at a time when they go on vacay every year!
author: Kristen C.

description:
I simply love the place! The only issue I used to have with it was that it is a very tiny place and sometimes it actually seems to be a problem. It was long back when I first tasted their egg custard tarts, and since then I've become one of their fans. In fact, I do a lot of word of mouth advertising for them and I seriously feel that half of the people in my building prefer going to Golden Gate Bakery because of me. So, to whomsoever it may concern, you should consider sending me a thank you letter for free of cost advertising. :p

Nevertheless, the bakery is awesome, from chocolates to whatever you like, you can easily get everything here. The price is moderate. It open from 8a.m to 8 p.m, so you ca expect to get good breakfast meal and evening snackers.
author: Dinkar K.

description: For such a long line, I guess I expected a little more out of these infamous egg cakes. Don't get me wrong - they're good. But they didn't have that pop I was really looking for. However, the bakery did have a lot of other tasty-looking items for sale, so I'll be coming back to try those out instead.
author: John H.

description:
When i first came here..i saw alot of people lined up at this bakery not knowing why i lined up in the first place. The funny thing was, i asked the person in front and behind me what was good. They said they didn't know either and saw the line and decided to line up too!

Well well..the custard tart are soooooo freakin great. Luckily i don't live near there because i would order this everyday. 

The only bad thing is sometimes they close and when they close, they close for months. Best thing to do is to call ahead of time to make sure they are open. If your in China town, this is a must stop. Be careful when you are getting close to being the next customer. I would get alot of rude Chinese people cutting in line and trying to get ahead.
author: Nasser D.

description:
EGG TARTS!!! 

Yes they do have more baked goods but if you want to avoid the angry Chinese ladies then just stick with the egg tarts. Ok ok one of the ladies was pretty nice but my mom was with me so there was any "huhhh?! What you say?!". 

The egg tarts are most likely going to be fresh and piping hot every time you go in because of the amount of traffic they get in this little bakery. EVERYBODY that steps in orders egg tarts. You might be wondering why everybody praises these egg tarts and I, Harry MTHAFKN T. am going to break it down to you. Usually when you get an egg tart the crust is soft and kind of doughy BUT here at Golden Gate, they are sooooo flaky and crunchy. If they sold just the crust, I would buy it. If they made huge crusts that you can use as a bowl, I would buy it and drink some LOBSTAH bisque out of it. 

There's always a bunch of tourists in Chinatown on weekends so there's a line out the door all day. I went on a weekday and I walked right up the counter. 

***CASH ONLY!!!***
author: Harry T.

description:
They have the BEST egg tarts, ever.  They're so good you have to eat it right away.  They are also very popular so the staff are constantly making new batches throughout the day, thus your egg tarts are always fresh

At $1.15 each, they are a little pricey compared to the average price of an egg tart, but completely worth it because they're not your average egg tart.  

My boyfriend also likes to get those flakey pastries filled with curry beef, curry chicken, of bbq pork.

There's almost always a line here, but it's not too bad.
author: Vivian H.

description: The egg tarts here is a must.  We got a very fresh batch, which made it even more amazing.  The reason for the four stars is due to the wait, which is somewhat understandable.  They make batches on the go, and there was a group in front of us that ordered about thirty, which led us to wait.  I feel like they should put a limit on the amount people can order.
author: Ken L.

description:
OMG OMG OMG.....Wow, every time I walk in here...I get so nostalgic. Highly recommended from my late Grams & I :) Here's why:

-Egg tarts (Mmomomom, fresh & crispy...yea baby!!!!!!!!)
-Coconut custard buns (The long skinny ones that melt in your mouth and yep, thats right, they are the best morning bun you can ever have) I'll choose this over a bagel any day!!!!
-BBQ pork buns (Duh, everyone's had some version of it, theirs are traditional and so meaty) Ahhhh :)
-Wife's pastry (Its suppose to be "Coconut" but really its some type of melon custard, which is awesome!!!! They look like flat round pastries. You can't get anymore traditional than this. 

Bottom line, go cuz you won't regret it!!! I promise and yes it's a small joint so bare with the crowd. Its well worth it!!!

Oh did I mention the Egg tarts are to DIE for?! :) Momomomomom
author: Annie P.

description:
As other reviewers on Yelp said it, HANDS DOWN the best Egg Custards Tarts ever!  

During my trip to California last year, we walked through Chinatown and passed by this bakery with an enormous line.  Curious about what they were selling, we peeked through the window to find every customer buying egg tarts by the dozen or more.  Naturally since I love these myself, I had to go find out the real deal.  My wife and I bought two and after the first bite, I knew this was the most amazing egg tart I've ever had.  This beats all the NYC Chinese bakeries by a mile!  

If you are ever in San Fran and can visit this establishment, please do so!  I wish they were able to open a location in NYC.
author: Carson W.

description:
There is a reason why this little mom and pop shop has a freakishly long line.  Their known for their Egg Custard Tart and I have to say THE BEST I'VE EVER HAD!! (sigh... I need a moment to myself) 
This Egg Custard Tart was not greasy, fresh made and full of flavor!  They serve it to you right out of the oven.  I bought a dozen of these warm fresh egg tarts and inhaled two tarts before I left the store.  Definitely worth the wait!
author: Ying F.

description:
If I were to have one last meal on earth, it would be dim sum. And if I were to have just one last dish, it would be egg tarts.

Luckily for me, I have plenty of meals left and a friend good enough to surprise me with egg tarts from Golden Gate, fresh from San Francisco! I have to say, they were spectacular. True HK style egg tarts, complete with a perfect ratio of soft flaky crust and sweet eggy custard.

As the Singaporeans say: sinfully delicious.
author: Grace K.

description: Sign said they were on vacation. We were bummed. We glanced through the window anyways and there was someone inside who saw us. She said someone is there baking even if they have a vacation sign up front. She asked us if we wanted to order and we did. The lady was very nice and sent us happily back home with tarts for friends and family. Their tarts are the best.
author: Phil O.

description: CASH ONLY.  Closed for vacation as of Thurs 5/6/10.  Let me know when they are back!  Pic here: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=olj-Q-LhrfEqcfhbkRzYIA
author: Ann L.

description: I always go to golden gate bakery for some delicious egg tart! It's worth it. It's not to sweet, but sweet enough to want to eat another. The crust it crunchy and the yellowy egg filling is indescribable! The egg tart size is a fuller size than most places I've been to. This place, by far is the best egg tart I've had in California. There's always a line or a wait for a new batch, so be prepared to wait for it. But it's worth your while.
author: Paulina D.

description: I came back on a not so busy day, and got much better experience. The ladies were friendly and gave us newly baked egg tarts (we bought a lot - 5 boxes - because my family loves them). We waited for about half an hour but it was worth the wait. Tarts were crispy and tasty. Definitely call before hand to make sure they're open.
author: Anh N.

description:
Enough praise has been given about their egg tarts, so I'm switching gear here a bit.  Other than their "world famous" egg tarts, I actually enjoyed their moon cakes much.  I'm one of the few people that actually like eating moon cakes and eat them all year round (not just for Mid Autumn Festival).  These are among the best I've had.

If you ever visit here, don't miss the egg tarts and keep in mind that there are a variety of other things that are also worth trying.

One more thing to mention, despite the fact that the staff's manual cashier operations somewhat contributed to the long line, everyone working at the shop was very nice and friendly.
author: Elaine H.

description:
My favorite egg tart in SF -- always hot fresh out of the oven!  The line can get a little long/ annoying but still worth the wait.  The service is fast and straight forward.  I've never tried anything else but the egg tart from here, but I've heard their homemade moon cakes are also good.  Will have to try that next time.

Sometimes the owners will take vacations and the shop is closed for 1-2 weeks.
author: Imee C.

description:
This place has awesome dan-ta's. It's not too sweet, and the texture's perfect.

I regret that I shouldn't have waited to eat mine... We were walking around looking for seating. By the time I got to eat it, it was barely warm. At least it was still yummy.

My only complaint... the crust was a little too crunchy and oily for me. I'm not a big fan of the phyllo dough crust for dan-ta's. But man, the custard's great!
author: Lee L.

description:
Navigating Chinatown can be difficult for a recent San Francisco transplanted white guy given the many restaurants and menus looking very much like the next.  Thank you Yelp community!  You've helped me find some gems, the most recent being Golden Gate Bakery.  Not a tourist trap and nowhere near mediocre, some of the best Chinese pastries I've ever had!

Egg Custard Tart: More than I could ever imagine!  Most egg custard I've had has been from a cart when finishing off dim sum.  Nothing can compare to these steaming masses of egg pudding in a crispy/flaking tart shell.  It is worth the wait behind the partially dirty non-velvet rope!!!

Sesame Ball: Lightly fried exterior with smoky toasted sesame seeds.  Loved that the chewy mochi part was very thin.  Bean filling was a little too dense for my tastes.

Mochi Pancake: Don't know the name of it, but it looks like a pancake made out of mochi with a bean/jam filling inside.  Was ok, but very chewy and sticky.

Lotus Tart: A golden hockey puck with nutty tasting lotus seed paste inside.  Great flaky exterior.  Much lighter than a moon cake.

Red Bean Tart: Every bit as flaky as the lotus tart, but with a dense generous red bean paste center.  Somehow the red bean here tasted better than the bean in the sesame ball.

Coconut Mochi: Freakin' amazing!!!  In the center were some hidden macadamia nuts which played so well with the coconut.  I instantly envisioned myself in a Hawaiian Chinatown near the ocean.  So tropical, so delish.

Moon Cake:  A bit of a disappointment.  Most everything else blew away the competition.  This was about on par with the moon cakes from tin boxes, with a super salty yolk center.

Citrus Popover: Don't know the name, but it looks like a popover and tastes like citrus, perhaps orange?  Airy like angel food.  Refreshing.

Macaroon: When I first start biting into this I was like "Crap, hard as a rock".  I was too quick to judge.  The macaroon gave a bit and proved to be very supple on the inside.  Love the contrast of toasted coconut and soft coconut.  Might be the best coconut macaroon I've had!
author: Adam B.

description: The crust is so flakey and the custard is so creamy! I was in heaven with the first bite I bought 20 egg custards, and 24 hours later, there are only 6 left. :(
author: Victoria K.

description:
Great egg tarts but bad service!

I saw a worker there yelling at a 70 years old lady because she only purchased 1 item and asked for a receipt! Right after that, I got serviced by the same person whom was extremely rude to me, as well.

Well, I said to myself if I am driving this far to receive this kind of bad service, then I should never come back.
author: Jaylene L.

description:
My family and I just happened to come across this place as we were walking around in China Town. We saw a huge line out the door so we went to check out the fuss. I am so glad we did! 

Egg Tarts were phenomenal. The egg wasn't too yolky or sweet. It was just right. The crust was nice and flaky. Not only are the egg tarts tasty, but also very cheap.

Recommend:

- Buy a dozen or you will regret it
- Lines are long but worth it trust me
author: Justin R.

description:
Definitely worth the wait in the long line out the door. Also worth the $1.35 per egg tart. It's crispy, crunchy, lightly sweetened. The absolute best egg tart I have ever had!! 

I was so glad they were not on vacation for the 2nd attempt on coming here!

They have other goodies here as well. I tried the coconut sweet rice cake which was pretty good too. Other people were in line buying tons and tons of moon cake (it was right before the autumn festival) and they had tons of different types of flavor moon cake (green tea, almond).
author: Caroline C.

description:
Lines here are ridiculous.  Really, are the egg custard tarts that good?!  Uh, the skeptic says ... YES, they are!

Got them fresh out of the oven and piping out.  The custard is so delicate and soft but the tart holds the egg custard together so well.  It was the first time that my parents ever tried these ... and I'm afraid they're in for a disappointment going forward because all other versions probably won't measure up.

There $1.35 each ... but if you're going to wait that long in line, you'll most likely end up ordering a few at least (or in the case of some folks ahead me of me in line, order by the dozens).
author: F. P.

description:
I came here a couple times when I was out in San Francisco last spring. As I'm a big fan of pork buns, I came here to sample it against what I'd had elsewhere. I wasn't terribly impressed - the pork flavor was bland, and the bread - which should have a bit of a light, sweet flavor that's typical of brioche, was also lacking. Prices are cheap - it is Chinatown after all - but I came away a bit disappointed after reading elsewhere online that the best pork buns in the Bay Area were here. Some of the other things I grabbed to bite, such as the sticky rice, were delicious. But the pork buns were a bit of a letdown...

Next time I'm in the area, I'll have to try the egg tarts (given that it seems like the vast majority of folks have a great opinion of them), and I may revise my rating after trying them out. But for now, I prefer Good Mong Kok (just up the hill on Stockton), which has a wider variety to select from and is a bit more on the savory side.
author: Asuka N.

description:
I'm still in love with their egg tarts. I just have the super long line they always have.... But yum!!! The filling is perfectly eggy, creamy with just the right amount of sweetness. When they're still warm from the oven... It's just heavenly!

Keep your head up and know how to stand your ground. There are always these people trying to cut and yell in Chinese while ignoring the line. I've had to elbow some people and tell them to get in line a few times.
author: Vicky L.

description:
You've heard of their famous egg tarts.  A tucked away bakery shop characterized by a big orange signage and some Chinese characters, is not so much a hidden gem anymore.  You'll see it blocks away with the long line, night and day.  This tiny basic storefront showcased with an array of Chinese pastries, from melon cake, to walnut poundcake, to mooncake and the famous egg tarts.  

You'll never see any egg tarts displayed in the window.  It's almost like a legend that their customers talk about in Chinese.  That's because whenever the egg tarts is out from the oven (2 trays at a time), it's sold out right away.  People usually buy a dozen of them every time (at $13.80/dozen).  Gone, poof....!

The pretty layer of flaky pastries topped with light textured egg custard.  I personally think it's a tad watery.  Beware though, that the bakery is on their annual sabbatical twice a year: They're closed the entire month of August and October.  Call ahead to make sure.  And be prepared to stand in line.
author: Carina N.

description:
I am not a huge fan of their egg tarts, as I prefer a different bakery that makes them less sweet. BUT I do love the flakiness of their crust and the filling itself is very smooth. Some of the other pasteries here are quite good. Their "Old Wife" pasteries, as well as the "Coconut Mountain," (those small cake/cookie like that look like little stiff peaks) are oh so good. I especially love their White Lotus Moon Cakes here. There is no place that makes better moon cakes. The egg isn't super oily and the filling is smooth with just a tiny bit of crunch here and there that proves its not a pre-made filling. Mom, please buy these for me again for the Autumn Moon Festival. If not, I'm just hoping a relative will give a box to us.

Everything here is fresh since they sell out so quickly. The biggest downside here is that they are very pricey. Their egg tarts are almost, or already, double of other bakeries in Chinatown. 

Be forewarned that there will be a nice long line, especially as the day wears on. My family and I have been lucky to have relatively short lines.

Don't expect good service. This is Chinatown, afterall. Everyone is treated with the same brusque manner and you should know what you want before you are ordering, as the staff do get annoyed because of the hold up.
author: Jay L.

description:
Best moon cakes I've ever tasted. And I've tasted quite a few.

Tried the lotus bean paste, almond (with and without egg), and mixed nuts with ham. Flaky crust, delicious fillings. We paid $5 to $7.20 per moon cake, more than what we'd normally pay in L.A., but these were worth the price.

We also picked up a few egg custard tarts ($1.35 each). Flaky crust, soft center, vanilla and egg and just sweet enough with the right consistency. "They sell like hotcakes" should be changed to "they sell like egg custard tarts". They go fast.

They don't take phone orders, you have to wait in line, and you need divine intervention to find a parking space (though in SF, it seems like you need divine intervention to find a parking space *anywhere*).  But just get here; it's worth it.

Things to do in SF if you've got a day: Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, cable car ride, Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Johnson G.

description: I'm not a huge fan of their pastries other than their egg tarts, but that's not a reflection of the bakery.  I'm just not that into that type of Chinese pastries.  However, these ladies do make the best egg tarts on planet earth.  The tart crust is so flakey, crispy, and then soft inside.  Getting hungry just thinking about them.
author: Amy C.

description: egg tarts a must try! get it while its hot!
author: William C.

description:
I love how the people who hate this place say they've had better, but no one ever backs it up by saying where they've had better (unless they say China or Hong Kong LOL).

Look... the ladies are rude, yes.  The place is a bad collision of tourists who randomly hop into line and locals who like good Dahn-tots (Chinese Egg Tarts).  They're 50% more expensive than anywhere else, but at the end of the day, it's some of the best in the City.

I've lived in the Bay Area my whole life and no, there hasn't been a bakery to match their level of quality.  Is it worth the long line higher prices and rude workers?   Well, that's really subjective.

I for one, forget about the workers after taking one bite of the Dahn-tot.

Highly recommended but buyer beware ;)
author: Anthony L.

description:
There wasn't a line when I went again! (Saturday night at 8pm)

The egg tarts were as amazing as usual - I bought half a dozen so that I can store a few at home and bake them when I want them heated. MmmMM. I'm not sure if I can ever handle a dozen though even if there is that deal (a dozen for $12 I think, $1.50 each).

I still have yet to try their other baked goods because I am hooked on these egg tarts, but I noticed they have more than just egg tarts and mooncakes - they have buns and sesame balls.

Note that they are only cash only, but I saw that there was an ATM right across the street.
author: Lucia C.

description:
Oh man, everyone talks about this place like it's heaven of dan ta's. After walking around China Town in a mission to find this place, I finally found it! Very discreet and low key store but you won't miss it because there will be a line waiting outside. Expect a wait time of about 30-40 mins.

After examining their store layout, I realize what was taking so long. Their store setup is so inefficient, 3 old chinese ladies in each others way trying to fullfill orders. They had a small counter while the entire rest of the store is stocked up with random things that they could have cleared out.

My expert opinion from playing restraunt city on facebook, they would be maximizing so much profit if only their store layout was more efficient. BUT in other words, maybe they are doing this on purpose to keep that long line outside like a club so it looks tantalizing lol

Food, yes yes danta paradise, they were so soft but not mushy, pretty much the most perfect dantas ever. I got some moon cakes too though they were on the expensive side but they were pretty amazing too. You could tell these weren't no normal store bought mass produced items.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Another one of our tourists spots while we were on our trip to SF. SOOO worth it! Again better to find parking elsewhere and walk here. Anticipate a line, even during weekdays. We came here both on a Saturday and Monday. The egg tarts are sooo worth it! We made sure to stop by before our flight back home. Brought a whole box back, probably going to bring more back next time for our families.
author: Irene N.

description:
MUST COME and eat when hot out of the oven!  It cost $16.xx per dozen.  Most that line up typically gets a dozen or 2 for having to wait for their stash.  This is my must buy item every time I'm in Chinatown (which isn't often).

Your friends will appreciate it if you get them this as a treat!  :)  I'll have an egg tart over froyo or cupcake anytime!  Goes well with a cup of coffee.
author: Ju D.

description: FINALLY CAUGHT THEM OPEN! This is probably my fifth time dropping by. Definitely a mom and pop shop that decides to open whenever they feel like it. Don't get frustrated when they're not opened like they say they would - HAPPENS ALL THE TIME! When you're in luck, DO give this place a try. Their Hong Kong style Egg Tart for sure!!! It was fresh and delicious when we got there - possibly newly baked! They also charge whatever amount they feel like it too! If I'm ever in the area again, I would drop by if I was in the area - not worth making the trip to this place even if I called ahead to check if they were opened. The reason I'm rating this place a 4 start instead of 5. Either way, keep bakin!
author: Stefanie H.

description:
What's everybody waiting in line for? I have no idea, wanna wait in line anyway? I mean, I guess there's something cool happening. Yeah... why not...

BEST. DECISION. EVER.

EGG. CUSTARD. TARTS.

Fresh, hot, delicious egg custard in a flaky crust. Allowing it to cool slightly before inhalation was one of the hardest things I've ever had to endure. Actually, I tried to eat it while it was still scalding and all egg-y tasting, then promptly burnt my tongue and hand, simultaneously. But it's fine. I don't want to talk about it. The point is... just try one. You won't regret it (even if minor burns are involved).
author: Rachel R.

description:
I was walking through Chinatown on my way to dinner at The House in North Beach, when I noticed a large crowd in front of Golden Gate Bakery.  I decided to Yelp it and see what the hype was all about.  Ahhh, they are famous for their egg tarts.  Judging by the amount of people in line, I decided to continue walking.  I was not going to be late for my dinner reservation.  

I finished dinner and walked back to my car located in Union Square and once again passed by GGB.  This time, the store looked like it was about to close with their iron gates in front.  There were a few people inside the store still waiting.  I looked at my watch.  It was 8:15 pm and the store was closed.  There was a little old man guarding the door not letting anyone inside.  I thought I would give it a try and ask if they would be willing to sell me some egg tarts.  The man asked how many I wanted.  I told him that I wanted two and he told me to wait.  He told me it depends if they had any leftovers.  Fifteen minutes went by and he let me in.  The lady inside placed two, hot egg tarts in to a white paper bag.  I paid $2.50 and I was on my merry way.

When I reached my car, I couldn't help but eat it right away.  It was still warm.  The crust was light, flaky, and buttery.  The custard was lightly sweetened.  Yum!  I'm so glad that little old man let me in.
author: Laina T.

description:
The most amazing egg tarts ever.  I dont really have much to say, but they have a really different texture and flavor compared to any other ones I've had.  

Definitely worth making a trip for, though they have really irregular hours which is a huge pain in the ass.  Often closed on random days, even though there are people working inside.
author: Max L.

description:
Stood in a relatively short line after lunch to buy some of their signature egg custard tarts of course. So piping hot that we ripped opened the bakery box, and each ate a tart right on the sidewalk.  We could see the steam rising out of each one as we bit into the tart.

Sometimes there's a long line into the bakery while other times you can walk right in.

One time while I was waiting my turn in line, the street vendor next door asked me to monitor her sidewalk merchandise while she took a potty break.  Sure enough I was waiting in about the same spot when she returned minutes later.

Definitely worth waiting in line for the flaky hot velvety egg custard tarts.
author: Shirley N.

description: I walked by this weekend and noticed they were closed, again: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=nUU0h91_F8qIenWRXM2u7g. Are they ever open? I'm still a fan but that status is now at risk. Interestingly, I have conveniently become their reporter each time they go on vacation. How about bring me with you next time? I think I can still fit into a big suit case, in case you want to know.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Sorry to say that I don't really like their egg custard tarts.  But this is a MUST go place for my family every times we're in China Town.  I hate to come here because of the long line and you need to be lucky to get what you stood in line for.  

Damn, we can easily spend close to $100 on all the stuffs that they have.  I've to admit that I like the coconut cakes here as they make it very soft.  It's not as sweet so it's perfect to eat almost anytime.
author: Tony T.

description:
This is the king of kings when it comes to egg tarts! If you are in SF, this is the only asian pastry shop you need to make a stop. It's worth it. 

- May have long lines, so be prepared or have your friend circle the block multiple times if you can't find parking. 

- Get the egg tarts. The more the better, share with your family and friends because they'll love it too.

- Cash only. Almost $17/dozen. $1.35 each.

- CALL AHEAD to make sure they are open. They are quite the vacationers, and it's not just a day or so. So make sure you CALL AHEAD.
author: Kay C.

description:
OMG! I have found the best coconut tart!

7x7, the San Francisco magazine, may have featured Golden Gate Bakery's egg custards on its "100 things to try before you die" list, but boy, did they forget about the coconut tarts! Believe me, I love egg tarts. I inhale them all the time as my dad frequently buys them in an attempt to fatten me up. The secret to the perfect tart is the flaky buttery crust. 

Let's get back on track - the coconut tart! Its crust is just as flaky as their egg tarts. The only difference is what's inside of them. Instead of an egg mixture, there's coconut in them. However, Golden Gate's coconut tart is like none of the other coconut tarts I have ever tasted. It is packed with coarse coconut flakes on top, and an eggy-pudding-like texture on the bottom. It's similar to a bread pudding, but less moist. Every bite was perfection with its eggy-soft texture and milky sweet taste. 

Lastly, even my friend, who is a picky eater and is skeptical of Asian foods, adores this little coconut gem.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Best Dan Tat ever... but always on "vacation" 

Egg Tarts have the best consistency, they're best when they're nice and warm from the oven OR their insulated cases.. Line is crazy when the place is actually open.. 

I want a tart now.
author: J-nine I.

description:
If you don't live in San Francisco, I don't suggest you get their egg tarts cause you'd be so frustrated in trying to get them ever again.

Is there an equivalent one in our area? Perhaps, but until I find it, I still want some more delicious, flaky, crunchy, perfectly balanced egg tarts.

NOM NOM NOM
author: Edwin B.

description:
dudes. check out what i discovered today!! 

http://www.is-the-golden-gate-bakery-open-today.com/

not sure if anyone have posted the link but thought i'd post it (again). 

you will never have to worry about their unpredictable operating hours bc someone have created a website that you can check before you make the trek to chinatown! so. awesome.
author: Natalia H.

description: Dirty place I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone. They had roaches everywhere and to top it off treat the customers without respect. I don't recommend this place to anyone!
author: Mark M.

description:
No doubt, THE BEST custard egg tart. Get 1 doz ... maybe 2 doz

Beware, they are ALWAYS on vacation.  Though, they can afford it.
author: Anna W.

description: Synopsis of my visit: short line, no egg tarts, reserved egg tarts with lady, wandered around Chinatown for 30 minutes, came back, cut to the front of line, got freshly made egg tarts, eagerly ate one egg tart after exiting store, burned mouth with molten egg custard in process, painful regrets, still will buy egg tarts again, will wait until I return to car to eat egg tarts, The End
author: Randy T.

description:
I know the line is always really long, so I haven't been dying to stop here, but on a Thursday evening at 6:00 PM there was not one, so we popped in.

Had a bite of my friend's dan tat. It was super warm and fresh. I'd go back for more off peak hours.
author: Conrad B.

description:
Awesome custard egg tarts, rain or shine, there's always a line, they taste the best right after you buy them, when they are still hot. 

I love you GGB, but pls stop raising your price! :-(
author: Jim C.

description:
I typically love Portugese style egg tarts since they are richer than normal egg tarts but GG bakery's egg tarts are perfect. The crust is extremely flaky and the custard is light, silky in texture, and the perfect amount of sweetness. 

I tried coming here 2 weekends ago and they were closed due to the owners being on vacation. Pretty sure I was depressed for the rest of the day.
author: Grace Y.

description:
OMG... I can't believe I haven't written a review for my most precious guilty pleasure... don tat (egg tarts) at Golden Gate Bakery!!!  I don't CARE if they're way more expensive than other egg tarts.  I don't CARE that they abandon us for 1 month of the year when they go on vacation.  I don't CARE that they can get soup nazi on you and make you cry.  They are the best and I will always love them... so long as they don't change the recipe or something. 

See ya there.

PS  If u come from long distances just for their treats *guilty*, call before going to make sure they're there and not on vacation.
author: Susan D.

description:
I will start off by saying i really love eggs, any style, shape or form.
My boyfriend and i came here specifically for the egg tarts.
I have to say we were a little tiny bit grossed out.
The flaky dough around the egg tart is awesome, and they are warm so that's a plus! But the inside was soupy and tasted more eggy than sweet (i know, they ARE egg tarts afterall) I think the combination of the warmth, and the eggy taste and the almost mushy consistency did not work for me.
The place is TINY, and the ladies barely speak english and are not the frendliest.
I would not stand in line for one of these :/
author: M K.

description: best dan tat I've ever had.  The pineapple bun and curry bun are also pretty good.  Prepare to wait in line.
author: Peter C.

description:
Now that I am older and (maybe) have slightly more refined taste buds, I regard Golden Gate Bakery to have the best egg tarts. There's something about their flaky crust and soft eggy filling that I can't find in egg tarts from other places. I always get half a dozen, refrigerate them, then reheat them in the toaster oven when I want to eat them. (But they almost always happen to be on vacation when I am craving an egg tart, in which case an egg tart from someplace else will have to suffice.)

Another item I frequent is their char siu so - it's long and rectangular, and the pork filling is flavorful and is actually pork and not just fatty pieces! (I like non-fatty char siu. Others might find theirs too dry and not saucy enough. For this reason, I avoid their char siu baos.)

I have also tried their coconut tarts - I like it, but disappointingly, it's not all coconut. The top layer is coconut, middle layer is coconut mochi (?), and it all sits inside the same flaky crust as their egg tarts. For a coconut lover, I think the coconut macaroons are a better choice than their coconut tarts.

Lastly, I love their mooncakes! Come mid-autumn festival season, they sell only 2 things - egg tarts and mooncakes. They make the best coconut mooncake because it's chock full of mixed nuts in between desiccated coconut! Their winter melon mooncake also incorporates nuts! I otherwise eat white or dark lotus seed paste mooncakes, and I especially like theirs because of their skin and I find it not as sweet as packaged ones.
author: Christina C.

description: Because they're always closed every time I attempt to get an eggtart. (3 attempts so far). They just put a sign up that they're on vacation, just wish they posted that on yelp or on a site so I wouldn't be disappointed every time. I understand they're humans too, but vacation mid April and end of May?
author: Wenny W.

description:
If you've heard the hype, BELIEVE IT. This is THE place for egg tarts/dan tat, and I know because I've tasted the difference after buying egg tarts elsewhere in Chinatown. The ones at Golden Gate Bakery are standouts with their flaky, buttery crust and smooth, slightly creamy custard. I've had the traditional egg tarts as well as the ones made with egg whites - don't be afraid if you're weirded out by the white filling, you really can't go wrong either way!

I took one star off because it is a bit pricey, but of course their dan tats can't keep me away. Celebration ensues whenever my mom brings a box of them home.
author: Caralisa L.

description:
Not bad, but not the BEST EGG CUSTARD either. It was... extremely yolky and not a good combo w coffee. 

I like Yummy Bakery's egg white custard better.... heh
author: Ami Y.

description: I have to stop by here everytime I'm in town. Hands down the best custard eggtarts I have had in my life! Very consistent. The filling is always thick and moist. It's served fresh each time, probably due to how busy they are.
author: DT D.

description: After trying multiple egg tarts in one day (I had dim sum earlier & The AA Bakery & Cafe a few blocks away), i can finally compare and say they have the FRESHEST AND BEST EGG TARTS! My order of four egg tarts came out hot, (it literally was still steaming when i devouring this amazing dessert) fresh and super delicious! Their crispy crust was the best part. I was lucky enough to only wait a few minutes in line :) $1.25 per egg tart! Enjoy it fresh so eat it asap!
author: Shirley N.

description:
Egg tart = $1.15

Is it worth it? 

I guess if you want to try one and experience it.... just eat it after it's cooled down and solidified! XD I got too hungry and ate it as soon as it was packaged in the pink box! It was like eating mush and thought, "Mann, this is what people are raving about???"! :P After fridging it in a tupperware, I ate it this morning and the custard was better. I really like the flaky, greasy crust. But mann $1.15 for ONE egg tart? You better take your time eating and savoring it!!!

BUT.... I think I still like the custards at New Asia. o.O

Aside from the egg custards we got (12 for $13.80), we also got their melon cookie?, coconut tart, raspberry napoleon, pork pastry, chicken pastry.. and we were $30 poorer. =\ haha

Expect LOOONNNNNGGGGG lines and to wait at least 30 mins before you get inside the store! Patience is essential if you want your egg tarts! :)

Golden Gate Bakery: Did you know I attempted to come here twice this summer? And both times they were closed for vacation! O_O asdhaukwdha FYI: Saturdays, they close at 8pm! So yay for finally trying it!!!
author: CeCe C.

description:
Closed in Early May 2013 for Vacation.

Definitely the best Egg Tarts in the SF Bay Area.
Their large sesame balls and old wife pastries are also pretty good.
author: Ellen H.

description:
Best Egg tart (Dun Tat) Ever.

 It is expensive relative to the area,but no more than $2 each. I'm sorry, forgot the exact price. I enjoy eating dun tats. However, I don't eat them often, so eating a hot, soft, and crispy one  is great for me.

During busy hours, they will only allow you to purchase a limited amount due to demand, if there is a line.
author: John K.

description: I SWEAR TO GOD these people take the most random vacations. They always have this "closed for vacation" sign up, never a return date, no apologies, nothing. They just up and leave whenever they feel like it. The last three times I've gone, completely random times in three different months... ON VACATION!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This is the only reason they're getting three stars. If they would just announce when they'd be back, they could have one more star. What does it matter anyway though? Their egg tarts are crack and I just keep coming back in hopes that they'll be open. Damn this place. Damn them. Supply my demand! Grrrrr...
author: Judy L.

description: The egg tarts here the biggest egg tarts I've come across in America. We came on a Saturday around 5 pm and the place was closed (???) I think they might've been undergoing temporary renovation or something, but when we went up to the gated door, a lady peeped out and asked us what we wanted- rather sketchy but hey. Then she told us to come back in one hour, which we did, although the place was still closed. She handed us our order through the half open door, strange..but I think it was just that particular day! Though I did kind of also want to try their mooncakes but since they weren't "officially" open, it didn't seem the most appropriate to order more. Oh well, I'm just glad I got to try their delicious egg tarts.
author: Lucy X.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is one of the best places for Dan Tat in the US.  It has the honor of being my 300th review!

My family and I have been coming here for years.  I haven't found a don dat as good as GGB's unless I'm in Hong Kong or Macau.  There is always a wait, so be patient and you will be rewarded.  Save room in your tummy for one, as eating it fresh out of the oven is to die for.  Everything is perfect with the don dot, from the moist egg custard to the crispy crust.  

On my last visit, they had ran out and said they would be available in 1.5 hours.  That was fine as I was with my parents and we were running errands.  1.5 hours later, I"m back in line where it's wrapped around.  I get to the front and they run out again!  grrr - just my luck.  The staff member said it would be ready in 30 minutes.  She also said that I could walk around and come straight back in front of the line and that she would remember me.  I was a bit hesitant but took her word for her and went to a few more stores.  About 30 minutes later, true to her word, she remembered me and gave me my don dat's!  Taking the first bite, was an ineffable feeling worth waiting for.
author: Albert L.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS EVER!
They're big, light, and custardy-delcious bomb.com
