My grandmother always takes me here every time we visit Chinatown, its like a tradition. Their pastries are one of the best here especially their wife pastry cake. 

During Moon Festival I suggest getting their moon cake it is also one of in my opinion the best.

They have other pastries here too, but the three I would get is coconut tarts, egg tarts, and wife pastries 

cons:
LONG LINE that stretch out for half a mile sometime (but doesn't that say something about the place?) LOL
small bakery
author: Vicky H.

description:
Can't go wrong with the egg tarts. Been here several times. Took people from Dim Sum in SF (tried egg tarts there) to here to compare the difference.  There is clearly no comparison.  This egg tart gem is very soft and has a nice flaky crust, showing that it is fresh and very delicious.  Definitely recommend!

PS: Do not eat the egg custard immediately if it just came out right from the oven.  Let it cool so that the sugar in the custard can rest so it will have more flavor, otherwise, it will taste like a tasteless hot mess.
author: Lawrence E.

description: These guys must be on something. Who charges two dollars for an egg tart? And they don't even open for business nowadays.  They take orders and tell you to come by certain time. If you don't show up at 4:30pm, and made an order, you don't get your pastries.  They act like they don't even want business anymore.  That's bad practice!  There's better Chinese bakery shops in Richmond.
author: K M.

description:
Finally got to try the egg custard tart - it is soo worth the hype!!  I waited in line for about 45 minutes; thankfully I had company, otherwise I'm not sure I would have stood in line for that long. The bakery is supposed to close at 8, but it seems like it stays open until everyone in line is served. 

We didn't eat our tarts while they were hot, but they were still absolutely delicious warm. The egg custard filling was sweet, but not overpowering, and the shell was perfectly flaky.  My mom is not big on desserts, but she loved this one. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Nadia S.

description:
I don't like eggs.  
I don't like scrambled eggs.
I don't like omelettes.
I don't like poached eggs.
I don't like breakfast burritos.
I don't like egg drop soup.
I don't like huevos rancheros.

But I love egg tarts and I've had plenty of egg tarts in my life.  Yes, Golden Gate Bakery - your egg tarts are good BUT I prefer Portuguese egg tarts, which you do not carry.  Luckily, the line was only moderately long when I was there and I only waited about 15 minutes.
author: Yi Z.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco all my life and have been to Chinatown numerous times.  This is my favorite chinese bakery.

There are others that may be cheaper, but for the best, this is the place to go. There are always lines outside of this place.

Believe me, the wait will be worthwhile.

Don't you dare leave Golden Gate Bakery without having purchased at least 1 mini-custard tart.

There is no custard tart even 1/2 as good as the one made here.

Although I have never had problems eating here, it does have a very low rating from the SF Department of Health. I've eaten here at least 20 times and have never had any upset stomachs and have always felt great, however, it has an 91/100 rating from the SF Dept of Health.

http://www.dph.sf.ca.us/eh/Violations/Loc_CurrentViol.asp?LocationID=3524
author: Tony U.

description: I give them  3.5 stars.  They have a pretty good sized egg tart. The only thing I would want is a flakier crust.  Thats how I like them.  I went there at like 7:50pm and there was no line just a 10 minute wait for them to bring it out.  It is pricy, $1.35 for one
author: Chloe K.

description: What is everyone smoking? This place was nothing special. My wife and I spent two hours of our Saturday standing in line to try the coveted egg tarts this place supposedly make. Finally we got up and ordered....I took one bite and realized I had been swindled. Honestly don't waste your time...try somewhere like papa beards....waaaaay better desserts and no line.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Best egg custards I ever had. Hands down. Hot and fresh from the oven, flakey crust, and delicious custard filling. The long line is well worth the wait. It's part of the experience. Every time I walk through Chinatown, I always overhear one conversation about the epic Golden Gate Bakery with its long lines and delicious custards. The bakery may not look like the fanciest place from the outside, but they have wonderful, fresh pastries. 

What I appreciate about this place is that they are so quick and efficient. They make sure to address each customer and get their orders in quickly and accurately. Additionally, if you have fresh custards in a box, they will cut it up and wrap it such that  your pastries stay in good shape as you transport them. 

I guess this place is so successful because I hear they take really long vacations, so they would be closed for a period of time. Sounds like a great job to work and take long vacations, right? Well they earned their way through making yummy pastries. Those egg custards thooo~! :D
author: Elle L.

description: Holy cow, they egg tarts are $1.25 now or $15 a dozen.. but they are still the best!!  Especially when they are fresh and warm right out of the oven.  The banana rolls are still good too, yum.  The only bad thing is... they are always on vacation, I think this is the first time in years that I have been here and they were actually open.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
Was it worth a 30 minute wait? Definitely Yes. Their egg custard tart was to die for. It was super fresh and sooooo good. 

Nom Nom Nom.
author: GeekyDino S.

description:
Really guys?  You've never had a better egg custard tart?

I have, both in LA and at other random bakeries in Chinatown up here (though I think it's hard to really screw it up).  And they didn't make me wait 28 minutes.  But I'm not knocking theirs by any means - I just don't think it's worth the line.

Now that it's Autumn Moon Festival, I actually do like their black bean mooncake with 1 egg yolk, but their pineapple one was actually pretty disgusting.  It didn't taste anything like what I thought it would (I imagined it to be a little slice of pineapple shortbread pastry heaven.. and if you're Chinese you know exactly what I'm talking about).  Instead, it had a highly artificial flavor with zero real pineapple flavoring.  Minus one star.

Oh, and despite the huge long line, old Chinese ladies were pushing their way in and just ordering ahead of everyone else.  Disorganization and chaos ensued.  Minus one more star.

I'll definitely come by when there's little to no line, but until then I'll just walk up to Stockton St. to get my goodies.
author: Tori S.

description:
After a long hike at Muir Beach Overlook, my gals and I came to SF to seek out the amazing wonderful egg tarts that my friend had been talking about since last year (we got lost in SF last year and there was a friggin festival so we were pretty much doomed in our expedition to find the bakery--also we didn't know the name of it hah!) FAIL. 

An who, we came here during the Moon Festival. What a delight. Another chaotic sight of SF. Usual business. This time we were able to pay for parking and find the famous bakery. We waited in line for over an hour.

After all the fuzz and the roar and calamity over the egg tarts, we finally were able to snatch a dozen for ourselves. Not to be an asshole, but they werent all that and a bag of chips, but I liked them.

I was let down. If something is being over hyped then my expectations go right along with them as high as the sky. Unfortunately, that was not reflected in my taste buds. Customer service was not great---they were all in a hurry and rushed to get people in and out, which is understandable, but they were mildly rude and terse with their words. Alright, so I let that pass.

After an hour and 20 minutes of waiting, we were finally in, paid, shared a dozen with my gal pal, and shoved one in my mouth. They were yummy, but not overwhelmingly delicious. I've tasted better desserts at a Mexican bakery. They were simply OK. 

And if that makes you angry, then go suck on an egg. My advice: if you really want one, go to SF when there is no line (who the hell knows if this ever the case!) or make someone else wait for you because you can probably get a same quality egg tarts somewhere else. Come on, theres bound to be some place else.

Oh, the moon cake was actually pretty good.
author: Noel G.

description:
NOTE: I'm not a big fan of pastries, baked sweets (brownies, cake, cookies, custards, pie, etc.) or breakfast items like waffles, pancakes and/or donuts. 

Now that I got that out of the way... Let's start! Golden Gate Bakery (GGB) is located in the heart of the clusterf*ck we all know as Chinatown. It's kind of crazy. I've been to the Chinatown in LA, NY and SF. They're all nuts - a lot of slow moving people walking the streets. So if you're in the rush to get somewhere, get ready to move at a snail's pace while maneuvering through the human traffic. 

If you're walking to GGB (I highly recommend this rather than driving there and attempting to find parking), you'll instantly notice a long ass line before approaching the store. When my girlfriend and I got there, the line was about 30 people deep which translated to a 20 minute wait. There are three things I'm not a fan of: 1) Slow internet, 2) Traffic and 3) Lines! Can you see the trend? I hate anything that requires me to wait. Yeah, I'm not the most patient guy in the world, so you can imagine how god awfully irritated I was when I was forced to wait in line because Sandy wanted to get her hands on a box load of egg custards from GGB. WHOEVER INVENTED THE LINE NEEDS TO DIE! (Chances are he/she already did.).

EGG CUSTARD: Sandy got a dozen. It came in a pink box just like the ones you get at your typical donut shop. Just an FYI, she was j*zzing over these things the whole day (made me jealous). That's why we had to go. I didn't understand what all the fuss was about... until I tried one. Dude! It was actually pretty good! It literally blew me away. The make up of these egg custards spells something I would absolutely hate putting in my mouth. However, I was very pleased after my first bite. The flaky buttery crust played very well with the creamy and smooth custard. The actual custard part of it was the star - so decadent, so comforting and so good. Like the best Yelper I know (Cherylynn N.) said, the custard's texture is similar to panna cotta. She was also right about it being more milky than eggy which makes for a better eating experience. Photo cred to Cherylynn N. - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/golden-gate-bakery-san-francisco?filter_by_userid=True&select=v3wxIov6yVvs_FcQCdwc1Q&userid=eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg#v3wxIov6yVvs_FcQCdwc1Q

The only reason I'm not giving this place 4 stars is because even though I enjoyed the egg custard, I'm still not a fan. I personally wouldn't go back for several reasons. Mainly because the line is ridiculous and because, well, I'm still not the kind of guy who likes sinking his teeth into baked sweets. But if someone happened to offer me one, I'd totally eat it. 

Egg custard. Who would have thunk it?!?!
author: Bruce C.

description:
So I heard of this place on yelp before I was planning to take a trip to SF. Egg Tarts are absolute favourite treat in the world as I love all that is custard and buttery pastry.
Thus the pilgrimage began. It was a demanding journey walking through the confusing streets, resisting the seduction of all the cute shops and fresh pork buns. When we found it we almost passed it since it's hard to the see the logo, it's just a tiny thing written in small print on a window. We ended up there around 6-7, not very busy, a lot of items were picked over but there was a lot of rice pastry and it seems they keep making egg tarts throughout the day. 
There was 2 Chinese families(you know its good when other Chinese eat it!) before us waiting for the famed egg tarts. They just pulled it out of the oven and the families almost took them all. However we managed to get about 3. 

Egg Tarts-  When fresh out of the oven it's very delicate. They must use whole eggs and plenty of milk instead of the rich egg yolk recipe as the custard is light and jiggly and moist. Also it's very sweet. The buttery crust was crisp/salty and not over whelming however thin so it could not stand up to the generous custard. It really plays on that perfect sweet and salty combo.

Coconute rice bun filled with macadamia- This is pretty much mochi or manju but I'm not sure if there's a name for it in Chinese. This actually turned out to be my favorite. Very sweet, the rice pastry was very very soft and melted in your mouth, complimented by the delicate coconut flavor and sweet macadamia mix inside it's definitely the perfect sweet treat. Also it's very cute covered with coconut flakes and a little frosting to make it look like a bunny. A good treat to bring to a friend. 

 I've tried ALOT of different mochi and manju and egg tarts as I live in a highly Asian populated area and these are always my go-to at the bakerys I frequent. With that in mind this is DEFINETELY a place to hit! :D

PS. if you don't know your way around it's pretty deep in Chinatown and if you enter from the dragon gate then it's straight down. Just pay attention to the streets though. It's on the left side of the streets.
author: Lily T.

description:
All right. This review is on the egg tarts - oh, those egg tarts - only. They are the reason people line up in Chinatown in the freezing cold, and are they worth it. You haven't had an egg tart until you've had it from Golden Gate - the pastry shell is flakey and crisp, while the custard is piping hot and falling apart soft. It is always fresh and make sure to enjoy one right after exiting the storefront.

This place is cash only, and the lines can get long - the ladies aren't the nicest/most hospitable people in the world (and speak mostly Cantonese) but this is a staple, and for good reason.
author: Jocelin L.

description:
Based on the Yelp reviews and friends' recommendations, I came here expecting heavenly tarts spiked with ambrosia. What I actually got was your slightly-better-than-average dan ta. The custard had an overwhelmingly eggy taste and the filling to crust ratio was criminally high (although the latter is a personal preference). 

Pick up a few if you're in the area and have a hankering for something sweet, otherwise it's not worth going out of your way for.
author: Hannah L.

description: My review is entirely based on their egg tarts--so bomb! I first tried them on a Sunday, and I had already returned for another taste two days later. Never have I ever loved egg tarts more than when I had my first bite of the warm, custardy egg tart with flaky pastry crumbs falling down my shirt. They're always the highlight of my Chinatown adventures.
author: Carolyn K.

description:
Everyone knows about their egg tarts. I like them too and Golden Gate bakery makes the best egg tarts.

However, I recently found a new favorite here - their cream puffs! The filling of the cream puffs are thicker and not like those weak whipped cream ones. It reminds me of home-made cream puffs I ate when I was just a little girl. 

They also have delicious giant sesame balls. Crispy and yummy. The macaroons are also pretty good.

So, go out of your comfort zone and buy something other than the egg tarts from here. You might just like it.
author: July N.

description:
This place will forever be a mandatory stop when I visit SF. The lines can get pretty long depending on the time you go, but the lines move pretty fast and even if it didn't, it's SO worth the wait! 

Priced at $1.25/each -- CASH ONLY!! 

You should ALWAYS eat one right after you purchase them since they taste THE BEST when they're piping hot/straight outta the oven. Mmph! The silky custard, buttery flaky crust = excuse the language,  jizz in yo' freakin' pants good.
author: Anita C.

description:
I cannot fathom how Golden Gate Bakery makes such insanely delicious baked goods. The place looks like someone's garage storage facility, but if you're churning out such damn good Chinese pastries, I'd be happy to have you serve it out of a cardboard box on the street. 

The standout item that I'm sure you're very well knowledgeable of by now is their Custard Egg Tarts. I've lived in China and I've had Custard Egg Tarts all over the place, and I can swear on everything I hold dear that Golden Gate Bakery makes the best Custard Egg Tarts I've ever had. Better than anything I've had in China, better than anything I've had in any Chinese bakery or Dim Sum restaurant in California.

The trick to Custard Egg Tarts is to not make the custard part too sweet and to make the pastry part extremely flaky. Golden Gate has mastered this art. The custard has the perfect amount of sweetness and the pastry is unbelievably flaky. And the fact that they come out piping hot is the icing on the cake. Even after days of sitting on my kitchen counter, the lukewarm custard egg tarts are still better than most egg tarts out there.

I've also tried the Curry Beef Tart and the Char Siu Pork Tart, both of which are delicious. But the main event of Golden Gate is definitely their egg tarts, which completely steal the show.

One downside is that they seem to always be on vacation. There have been many times where I'd make the trek out to get a custard egg tart and I'd find out that they're closed for vacation. I guess when you're this damn good, you really can't care less if you take time off whenever you feel like it. More power to them, because no matter how many times I'm disappointed that they're randomly closed, I'll still be loyal as hell.
author: Roy C.

description: We waited 45 mins in line and another 15 mins to complete the order.   We tried the custard tarts, coconut tarts, bar-b-cue baked pork buns, bar-b-cue pastry, chicken pie pastries which  IMO were all below average,  custard tarts and lo paul beng were average.  The long wait may have been due to being New Year's Eve.  There are shorter lines, better prices and quality at other locations on Stockton Street, Richmond and Sunset Districts. This place is overrated, overpriced and I do not plan to return.
author: Gary F.

description:
I always come here and get the ones that come out of the oven... I buy a dozen and cannot wait until they are cooled.. it goes in my mouth and yep.... instant gratification. 

The coconut tarts aren't half bad either... 

My dad got yelled at by the ladies behind the counter for "cutting in line" (he was looking at the different pastries since he had never been).. that in itself was worth the five stars... 

We bought a dozen and then 
2 were eaten on the spot by bf's dad 
1 for dad 
1 for bf's mom 
1 for me 
1 is being eaten by me while writing this review... 

Definitely worth the walk..... and the walk back after stuffing yourself :-D  

1 dozen egg tarts, 1 coconut tart and a bag of those almond cookies was around 18 bucks
author: Vicky T.

description:
You had me at Egg.

Egg tarts have been a treat since my childhood. My mother would get them regularly when we visited the chinese bakery. I know my tastes for food have evolved since I was a young lad, because I do not remember them tasting as good as the ones that come from GGB. 

These little treats from heaven are best eaten warm. No other place compares to how good they are. At $1.25 per tart, it's a small price to pay for this little treat. You can go elsewhere and pay less, but as I always like to say, you get what you pay for.
author: Johnny K.

description: My friends and I were recently in Chinatown having Dim Sum. After Dim Sum, we thought we'd check out Golden Gate Bakery to see how bad the line was. Thankfully, the line wasn't too bad - there were about 10-12 people in line ahead of us. After patiently waiting our turn, we finally made it into the store. They don't have the typical variety of pastries that you might find in a Chinatown bakery, but what they offered looked delicious. From word of mouth and past yelp reviews, the egg custard tarts are apparently the items to get. I ordered two egg custard tarts and brought them home to share with my fiancé. Despite eating them the next day, they were still pretty good - the pastry tart was nice and flaky and the egg custard was not overwhelmingly sweet. Wasn't really tempted by anything else, but they had different pastry offerings - kochi cakes, napoleons, and moon cakes. If you're in the Chinatown area, I'd recommend stopping by - if you're willing to wait in line - but I wouldn't recommend making a special trip.
author: Irene L.

description: Not the best in customer service, especially when you're obviously not Chinese. But it is true... Their egg tart is to die for! I like 85 degree bakery's but it's too buttery. GGate's is just right, especially when warm.
author: maritess b.

description:
The egg tarts here are so delicious! 

The line outside can be a bit daunting, but it seems like the workers are able to get through it pretty quickly. Parking is also a nightmare. We just dropped a friend off to stand in line and circled the block till we found a spot. 

But trust me, all the hassle is well worth it! Also, be careful when they're still hot! I learned the hard way because I got too excited and couldn't wait ):
author: Malyssa C.

description:
I was absolutely famished. Two and a half hours of shopping, another hour of walking/exploring, and a strong cocktail will do that to you.

I pulled out my trusty Yelp app to check up on this place I saw across the street. Lots of great reviews and a high rating and I'm in like Flynn.

I really wished I had taken notice of the highlight to buy the egg custard, but went for the moon cakes instead, which I also had read somewhere were pretty good. At first it's just me and one other woman in there, but soon it's swarmed with about 10 other people in a tiny aisle and showcase of the day's baked goods. Since it took me a second to decide what I wanted, I stood back and watched what everyone else got. When it was finally turn I asked questions about the pricing of the moon cakes and one of the ladies behind the counter pointed to the paper list taped to the counter, "Right here. It's all here." Now I have no idea about moon cakes, but I saw that they ranged from about $5 to $6.70 or something, each.

 I got a perfectly baked green tea moon cake. Not thinking it would be more than the range I've just seen from the pricing list, I go with it. The green tea cake's price was not listed. It came up to $7.70 I was so confused, but the woman was insistant, "yah, yah it's right here" frantically pointing to this list. I did not see the green tea moon cake listed on there, so who knows if that's what the price was. I felt so rushed! This really irked me, but since she had already put it into a bag and my mentality being of both "Well, I'm on vacation," and "I don't want to be shot dirty looks by this lady," I pay up. 

I hurried out into the street and thought to myself, "This better be worth it..." The outside was perfectly golden brown with a bit of a shiny glaze on the outer bread part. Inside was really dense, light green, and some sweetness. I loved its flavor and texture, but because of its denseness I knew I wouldn't be able to finish it in once sitting and it was right before dinner. The rest lasted me to the next day.

Keep in mind it's CASH ONLY. Next time I've have to try the egg custard and see what the hype's all about.

Thanks little moon cake for holding me over before dinner. I probably would have passed out in the street of Chinatown if it wasn't for you.
author: Alison A.

description:
Out of all the Chinese bakeries in China town, of course we go with the one that's yelped the most.  Not very original I admit, but the choices were so overwhelming. 

In any case, I'm sure the other Chinese bakeries were also very good, but we were happy enough to try this one out.  I could have used a larger variety of goods, but I guess that's what you get for trying the most popular Chinese bakery in the city.  The moon cakes were absolutely delicious (but very pricey -beware!) and I generally do not care that much for moon cakes.
author: Nora S.

description: If you like egg tarts, this is the place to go and well worth the wait so give yourself plenty of time in case there is a line. I went during the time of the moon festival which was super busy. We waited a little over an hour for a little bit of sunshine! The texture and taste is soo good - best I've ever had (I'm from Seattle). I'm soo sad to have tried this place and not be able to go there conveniently! They're especially delicious to eat right away because they're freshly made. They're a good size too, not tiny, or super expensive. The bakery also sells an assortment of moon cakes which I thought were very well made and delicious too.
author: Sarah R.

description: I love dan tat (egg custard tarts)!  Twice last year I travelled to Hong Kong, home of this delectable treat.  I consumed numerous dan tat from a number of different well-known and lesser known bakeries and restaurants throughout HK including the most popular and renown Tai Cheong Bakery as well as Lord Stow's, popular amongst some food bloggers in HK and Singapore.  Golden Gate Bakery still tops my charts for the best darn dan tat I've ever had in my life and in my opinion is very likely the best in the world!
author: Erich D.

description: I don't live in SF but the two times I've made it out this year the place has been closed. Owners are on vacation. Yelp says they're open. Sorry 2 stars because this place is never open during their said working hours. Hopefully you can try this place when it's open because it is delicious.
author: Jeremy F.

description:
The best egg tarts ever...

They've been on vacation for the LOOONGEST time, but they're back!!

Many religions like to reference a place of paradise --- Eden, Nirvana etc, but I think mine would be called "golden gate bakery"

You see, these are not regular run-of-the-mill egg tarts... The crust is flaky, while the custard is smooth. And I got it from a warm batch! The softness of the custard is one thing that I would never forget.

If I ever leave San Francisco, this will be one place I come back to. LA has Portos, SF is golden gate bakery. 

So what are you doing still reading this? GO GO GO
author: Kimihiko S.

description: Oh wow. These are the best egg tarts I've ever had in my life (although I've never been to Hong Kong, so this isn't as big of a statement). They are so flaky and the egg filling is a perfect custard. They are also huge, and eating it fresh and warm is the way to go. The lines out this place are always huge now, since the owners arbitrarily close the shop for long spans of time. Worth the wait if you pass by and the store is open! The coconut macarons are great too!
author: Matthew L.

description:
DEEE-LICIOUS! :D

Warm, custard-y, and flaky crust. 

Always delicious when you get it fresh and warm out from the bakery, but still very delicious the next day (if there is any left!!)
author: Tianna W.

description: I love their egg tarts its fresh and fluffy but because I asked for 24 egg tarts at 7:30pm and closing at 8:00pm and only would give me only 6? Just because im by myself and they have others waiting in line? I usually tips these guys for good service but Fair or not I waited my fair share of 1+ hours for them and they limit 6 per customer... telling me its their last batch?... load and behold there was another batch? that's messed up. 2 stars for eggs tarts, service gets ZERO. That's my  experience of nearing closing time. If you plan to grab these in bulk, I suggest during the day in the afternoon.
author: Jay K.

description:
Okay. I just want to say I've literally tried to come to golden gate bakery ever since I found out about it as a freshman at Berkeley. After 3 failed attempts.....it has finally opened AND NO LONGER ON VACATION (for the time being). Since my sister was here this weekend and an avid lover of egg tart, I called GGB to make sure they were open and we walked straight from union square after shopping.

I knew the egg tart was good from so many different sources but what I ended up loving from here was their coconut macaroons. Obviously there was a line so during the line a lady in front of me suggested that if I loved coconut, I needed to try their coconut macaroons. She also warned me constantly about how impatient/hectic/busy/snappy the workers were inside since the business moves so fast and there is always a line. 

Basically gotta know what you wanted to order not just "Uh...UM....Can I have..No wait.." because they will get impatient and snappy at you! (Which i think, sadly, is the direct result of their success (due/not due to yelp haha))

I ordered a dozen egg tarts and I wanted to try their coconut macaroon but I didn't want to get a whole batch, little did I know they didn't sell macaroons one by one. But I ended up convincing the worker to sell my 4 for 2 dollars. And he was right...I regret not getting 12. They were so goooood. Even better than the egg tarts which I would say may be the best in SF but not the best i've ever tasted. Nevertheless Golden Gate Bakery was worth coming and standing in line in the touristy busy streets of Chinatown SF.
author: Jessica K.

description:
My fav. place to grab egg tart!

FYI: Since Yelp says "Vegetarian Goes Nuts for this Place". The reason why this place has such delicious egg tarts is because generally, the crusts are made with lard. I'm not sure if they've changed the recipe (and changed it to vegetable lard or butter), but I know for a fact in Chinese traditions, egg tarts (especially made with the delicious flake-y crust) is made with lard. Just an FYI. If I'm incorrect, please send me a message and I'll retract my opinion.

Like other reviewers say, the egg tarts are amazeballs! My new favorite item is this coconut round thing with cake and cream. I am in love with it! The napoleon and the banana thing (don't know what it's called in english) is to die for! Even though everything is super expensive, I don't mind!

Only gripe I have is that they are CONSTANTLY ON VACATION! It's rather annoying...I tried calling once before heading over for my lunch and the phone line was busy. I thought...oh..ok...it's busy that means someone's there. NOPE! It was friggin closed! Ugh!

****TIP****
As with any place with a lot of hype, best time to go is the down time. I usually like to go around after lunch....so around 1 on a weekday. The lines are pretty tamed around then.

Love this place. My coworker and I have had a running joke for about.....a month or two where everytime we see each other, we go..."dan tat?" Because we KNOW this place is closed and there would be no way in heck we'd be able to get one =(
author: Denise L.

description:
After two tries when the bakery was closed for vacation, I finally got my grubby  little hands on these famous egg tarts. Six to be precise. And a custard-filled pineapple bun. The tarts were served warm and I immediately tasted one as soon as I stepped outside. (And then ate another one after I was done.)  

Yes, they may actually be the best ones I've had. Definitely at least one of the best. BUT--are they FAR better than other egg tarts? Nah. First off, I've rarely had a bad tart as it's a basic staple of dim sum and Chinese bakeries that tastes pretty similar (delicious) everywhere. Main differences are whether it's a "cookie" or flaky crust (Golden Gate's is flaky, which I prefer) and how firm, yellow, and eggy-tasting the egg part is. Depending on your preferences, Golden Gate's may not even be your favorite.  

Golden Gate's filling is actually not that eggy/yolky tasting given how hefty the egg part is. The filling is pale yellow and has a very fluffy, loose texture and light sweetness to it. Very very good. The taste is comparable to other great egg tarts I've tried, but it is unusual for the large amount of custard and the slightly lighter color and texture.  

Bottom line: Trek here if you are within a couple of blocks or you're an egg tart afficionado. But no regrets if you skip it in favor of one of the many bakeries and dim sum places in Chinatown. I would definitely go back to Golden Gate, but wouldn't wait more than five minutes for tarts.

Note to DC-area folks: The egg tarts at Oriental East in Silver Spring--at least the Portugusese-style/burnt ones--are similar: tall, light, loose, fluffy custard with flaky crust.
author: Chesty L.

description:
That egg tart... Wow... DAMN. That is a damn good egg tart. Perfect combination of flakiness, rich egg and custard flavor, and not too sweet or greasy. Worth the wait.

Also tried the BBQ Pork Roll and Beef Curry Pie. So flavorful, and once again, perfect flaky crust. These old ladies know what they're doing. :)
author: Alvin C.

description:
I like that you don't need to speak Chinese in order to actually order (and more importantly get) what you want. 

Price is standard for egg tarts and quality is obviously far superior than that of Ranch 99 markets and dim sum restaurants. Their almond cookies are a nice option if you want to have something that keeps longer. The coconut tarts also rock.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Okay, seriously- this place is open whenever they want to be and closed when they feel like it. Which means I can't get my egg tarts and curry beef pastries when I'm in the city. Minus one star.

Otherwise...amazing. You need to have at least ONE egg tart in your life from GG. My mom always makes me bring a dozen egg tarts back to South Bay when she knows I'll be in Chinatown.
author: Sally C.

description: The egg tarts are good... But the ladies that work there r rude and talk crap about there costumer in front of them.. The store is a complete mess not sure how the city allows it to remain like that.. Looks like hoarders live there.. Yuck
author: Karen C.

description:
As for egg tarts go, these were really good and big. They have other bakery items like the sponge cakes types there that were really soft and fresh. Lines went fast and kids liked it there too so it is a stop to try if u are a dan tat lover. 
Like others have said traffic and pedestrians are crazy. finding a spot is never ending ppl are always walking out everywhere
author: Mrs H.

description:
Omg, 4.5 stars and over 1000 reviews?! That is cray cray!!!! No wonder the owners are always on vacation, lol! 

REAL TALK: I don't understand what the fuss is. This bakery is completely overrated in my opinion. I mean their egg tarts, when warm, are super good but... they're just egg tarts... and I've for sure had comparable ones. For me, they are not worth the insane search for parking and suffering in the line that will inevitably form.
author: I. L.

description:
lived in SF practically my whole life but i've only had a fresh egg tart from here for the first time last week.  i generally don't think any place is worth waiting +40 min for (esp in the city of food bounty).  but this is worth the hype, trust me.

sometimes you have an egg tart and it's too sweet, too oily, too eggy, or too something.  yank sing is pretty damn good.   but at golden gate it really is the perfect balance of flavors, sweetness and texture.  the crust is ridiculously flaky and light.

the fresh ones make a huge difference, eat it while it's hot from the bakery.  but they keep for a few days in the fridge, and to reheat, a toaster oven or oven works like magic.  350 degrees for 3-5 min.

don't think i would wait as long as i did that day anytime soon (45 min), but if you decide to make sure you have some good company/ cell phone/ good book/ warm jacket!

pass on the banana roll and red bean cake.  save your tummy for the egg tarts!
author: Josie M.

description:
Best egg tarts in the world! The custard is smooth and perfectly made. The crust is flaky and crisp. I've burned my mouth several times because I just couldn't wait til they cooled down. The last time I was there they were $1/each. Usually, I pick up 1 or 2 dozen and share among family.

It's definitely worth the 20-30 minute wait on the crowded sidewalk! Yes, the line is out the door onto the sidewalk. There's another bakery about half a block down the street that but it's always empty... hmmm which one do you think people like?

Checking Yelp is probably the best way to find out when the owners are on vacation. Sometimes they'll close up shop for weeks at a time. There's nothing worst than dreaming about the egg tarts on the way up to San Francisco...working my way through the crowds and not seeing a line. That means they are on vacation.

I remember going here as a kid 20+ years ago.
author: Tim Y.

description:
Egg tarts are 5 star worthy, but parking is terrible and it is overpriced.

But those tarts are awesome. The crust is flaky like a croissant and the custard is rich and delicious.
author: Billy T.

description: My favorite and most authentic egg tarts I've had in San Francisco! Definitely worth the wait and try to get it straight out of the oven!
author: Peggy L.

description: Instant drool factor. The things I dream about. Luckily for me, this place has always been open every time I've been in the city and most if the time, no wait! I know amazing. But honest to god, THE BEST EGG TARTS, DAN TATS I HAVE EVER EVER HAD IN MY LIFE. And I've been to China, Hong Kong, Macau and I grew up in the 626. I know my egg tarts, and these are the amazing !! The custard is soft and creamy. The crust is flaky and airy. They are worth the wait and more. Just trust me and get them. You'll thank me later. In addition to these amazing gems these talented ladies produce, they also have delicious other goodies. The napoleon, banana slug things and a few other rolls. (They have the lemon flavored rolls here which I have been told you cannot find anywhere else). Everything has been equally delicious and I am always satisfied. I just wish they were opened more consistently. Love this place and I will be back every single chance I get!
author: Vivian K.

description: After dim sum with my friend, she suggested dropping by here for the "best dan ta" around. They're apparently famous for their egg tarts (and Yelp confirmed so!). She said that there's normally a line wrapping around but we came at a good time when it wasn't too busy. We only ended up waiting a long time because they ran out of egg tarts right before us so guess what? Egg tarts FRESH out of the oven! It's a cash only place so keep that in mind when (not if) you visit. The dan ta were so amazing when hot and later on in the day too when they settled/cooled down. The flaky crust was spot on and not too buttery. The egg part was silky smooth and just the right hint of sweetness that wasn't overpowering. Easily the best dan ta. I'm salivating in my mouth thinking about them again...
author: Minerva T.

description:
I came, I ate, and almost cried at the first bite of these egg tarts.

My girlfriend and her sister laughed at how much I paid for one (since they're used to getting them for half the price), but they didn't understand... yet.

These things are flaky, sweet, creamy, and just... beautiful.

You HAVE to eat these within a couple minutes of purchase to REALLY experience it. I have to have to have to put emphasis on this, because I tried one about an hour after purchase, and they just weren't the same! Tried heating them up too, but it seriously doesn't compare to eating it out of the bakery.

One runs for $1.25, and it comes with quite a bit of filling. These dan tat are perfection.
author: Patrick K.

description:
Easiest 5 stars to give.

First time hitting this spot after word of mouth. Luckily, had about a 1 minute wait just like IKE's a couple hours before. Guess we got lucky at these high wait locations!

Ordered 6 ET's, wrapped up and paid in a about a minute, and chowed down in the car. 

O.M.G. 

Melty, hot, goodness pretty much sums it up. Taste and texture spot on. Price clutch.

GGB FTW
author: Joe C.

description: Thank you to my coolest friend for showing me this place. I was lucky enough to catch the Golden Gate Bakery open, considering it's arbitrary business hours. I never thought I would care for egg tarts but then I had theirs and holy mother of Lao Tzu, they are exquisite.
author: Britt H.

description:
On vacation AGAIN!?!?!?! WTF? You take more vacation time than the French. Seriously, search the reviews, I'm not exaggerating.

Your stuff is great but I'm going to start going someplace else. You could at least put a sign up, or an outgoing phone message, or a basic website with your return date.
author: Hunter R.

description:
Some lady in line told us that the egg tarts are only available in the morning. Luckily right as she said this they pulled a huge tray out of the oven. OHYEAH!!!

This was my first egg tart experience. You know what they taste like? ... eggs. Yeah they totally do. Common sense would have prepared me for this but I was not ready. They are still very delicious and uber flakey eggs but eggs nonetheless. I eat it all up!
author: Tai F.

description: Worth the drive AND the wait. Haven't had an egg tart anywhere else since I've been here. Now that I've tasted the best, I have no desire to order these when I go to dim sum. I just wait until the next time I'm randomly in SF on a weekend morning so I can go stand in line w/ all the other folks, who apparently have nothing better to do than wait around for an egg tart to come out of the oven.
author: Anh-Dao T.

description:
OMG, the best egg tart I have ever tasted!  I visited 3 times during my short trip to San Francisco.  Worth the waiting on the long lines.  $1.15 for each.  Tried to bring a dozen back to NYC (very carefully) for my family but it just tasted not the same.....

My husband also liked the old wife cake but was not available on the subsequent visits.

The egg tart is one reason for me to visit San Francisco again......
author: LoveToEat Z.

description: This place has the best egg tarts (蛋撻)!  By far the best I've ever tried.  Fresh baked right out of the oven.  Very creamy and buttery with thick and savory custard.  The flaky crust was amazing.  The service is typical of most Chinatown establishments.  Also, they were $1.50 per egg tart, which is a bit more than other bakeries.  But the egg tarts more than made up for it.  There were better than any egg tarts that I've had in Taiwan or China.  We bought 18 of them and they were even good reheated the next 2 days.
author: Thomas W.

description:
Still eggscellent. Busy at weekends and price has gone up.

Wonder what the breaking point is for price of an egg tart.....?
author: Nick L.

description: Came here to since I heard so much about the egg tarts.  They are GREAT!  Picked up a dozen on a Monday with no line.  Ate 7 of them and felt guilty so I gave the rest to my sister!  She loved them!  I have been here 3 times and his is the first time they were working.  Call ahead since they take some time off during the year.
author: May N.

description:
Prologue: 

I recently found myself with 17 hours in San Francisco.  I decided to throw hunger to the wind and use my time wisely--a shopping spree for fall was certainly in order in my books.  

Yes, that's right folks, my sole intention was to shop, I didn't care if my only meal that day consisted of a greasy slice of pizza eaten in haste on my way to Ross and Macy's.  I had made up my mind--I was going to shop and the foodie side of me was going to be compromised.  
When I set out at 9am to the hotel lobby, the concierge told me stores dont open till 10. There goes my master plan.

Then I remembered that Marc D had suggested going to Golden Gate Bakery and eating their egg tarts.  There wasn't any free wifi to be had anywhere I looked, but thank god for the dinky map I ripped out of the San Fran Where mag and my photographic memory of his message, (I remember seeing "Grant") I made my trek out for the grail of tarts. 

The Tart

*I cannot believe I'm standing in line for an egg tart*
The line up outside the door was insane.  Sure it was Autumn Moon Festival but the people in line were there for the Egg Tarts, not the moon cakes.  The bakers downstairs could not make them fast enough.  As soon as one tray came up, it was taken away by one customer who had ordered 2 or 3 dozen of the things.   Sheesh,  should I abandon my post and go to the mall? 

I waited.  and waited.  and waited.  The lady in front of me said she waited an hour last week and to counter that instead of getting the one dozen she came for, she got 3 dozen to pay for the long wait. 

Finally it was my turn.  I ordered 4 egg tarts and 2 moon cakes (one lotus seed and one red bean-NO YOLKS!)  The tarts were place in a white paper bag piping hot and not sealed to let out the steam.

At 1.19USD a pop they are not cheap, but man, are they delicious!
The crust is thin yet flaky like those crisco commercials with the fork flaking at the pie crusts. The custard was still warm and very sweet.  There was a thin layer of clear sugary liquid that seeped out of the custard while baking and was resting on top of the jiggly tart goodness.  The ratio of crust to custard was perfect. 

Epilogue: 

I had already devoured 2 of the Egg tarts by the time I was barely 2 blocks away from the bakery.  In my defense, it was already 10am and I needed to speedy gonzalez it to the stores before I was back on the plane in a few hours. 

Next time I'm there I'll make it a point to get at least 1 dozen of them!

PS:  the moon cakes were good too, but pricey!
PPS: if any of you know how to tag yelpers in reviews, please fill me in!
author: Yoony P.

description:
A toss up between this and the AA Cafe just around the corner. Personally, I would go with AA Cafe cuz the setup there is nicer and the egg tarts just seem more traditional to me. Workers here are very friendly and actually seem kind of passionate about their bakery while the ones at AA Cafe are just kind of doing their jobs.

Either way, you can't really go wrong.
author: John N.

description:
Some of the laziest and least friendly women in Chinatown run this joint and the lines are often extremely long as the bakery is famous throughout SF.  Its egg custard tart is in the 7x7 Magazine as one of the 100 eats in the city and they are pretty good.  The macaroons are better.

Just be prepared to have to fight to get your order made and the women may start other conversations before actually getting to your order.
author: Chad S.

description:
Oh Golden Gate Bakery, why do I love your egg tarts so much? It's because that's what they are famous for and above all, they taste divine! There's usually a line out the door every time I stop by but that means they are constantly baking fresh, hot batches of egg tarts to accommodate the demanding crowd. I'm all for that...yuuuum!

They also sell various buns, cookies, and cakes (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/m3xdxV8YNH5uh1N01xdnLA?select=q_OTiNRzlRLxFK0C8R6Ytw). I have tried their lemon sponge cake and it was quite delicious too! Back to the egg tarts though. They are a little pricey at $1.15 each but they still sell like crazy and are worth every penny. I love the flaky, buttery crust and the sweet, soft custard-like center! I've been lucky to have eaten those fresh out of the oven but be careful as they can burn your mouth.

They are not small egg tarts either and make for a hearty dessert after some to-go dim sum! I've tried egg tarts from many different places in my lifetime and I've got to say that Golden Gate Bakery tops them all!
author: Karen Y.

description:
Ok so I ordered the egg tarts.. and ok Yelpers, you're right.. sooo good! And got to eat it warm which prob made it even better. I made the mistake of eating 2 though.. it was just too much LOL. Eat one now, save the other later. Resist the temptation to eat the 2nd one because it's warm like I did! 

Line was not too long at about 2pm on a Saturday. We bought some other items. If this is your first time and you don't speak Chinese, go ahead and browse the items while you are in line so you know what to order before you get to the front.. it can be confusing once you're ordering.  Just point! haha We'll be back, we're just 15 mins away yay
author: Vol T.

description: My friend picked up more egg tarts last Sunday to enjoy while we watched the 49'ers win at Green Bay. This time, both the custard filling and the crust were perfectly cooked. When that pink box with the cut and upturned corners hit the buffet table, people abandoned the 7 layer dip and devoured the tarts. Complete and utter obliteration!
author: Cece E.

description:
My cross country road trip has finally brought me to my half way stop, San Francisco; and what's first place I have to visit in SF? CHINATOWN! Meeting up with a local friend of mine first, we make our way to Chinatown. After a quick walk around I spotted another bakery showing some custard cups in the window, and that strike up my appetite; however, I was denied. "This place is okay, but I take you to another one around the corner, Golden Gate, we might have to wait, but it's good."

Let me tell you one thing, if Chinese people are willing to stand in line for something, chances are, that something is great and totally worth the time, because we are some very impatient people LOL! So we came to Golden Gate Bakery. Best. Egg. Custard. Around. No joke. My first recognized favorite food at three years old was egg custard. The custard did not taste watered down unlike other places, where they skim on the filling by adding more water into the custard batter. 

But Golden Gate Bakery is not all about egg custard cups. Their Po Lou Bao (similar to Japanese Melon Bun, or Mexican Conchas) tasted so good fresh out of oven; the crust was buttery and sweet and crispy, and the bun sweet and soft in the middle. Other traditional pastry items like BBQ rolls, butter cream bun, and "thousand egg" cake are all very good.

Also since it's now around the season of Moon Festival, it's the prime time for freshly baked moon cakes. I got more than just a few, and willing to haul it all the way back to the East Coast to give them out to the family there.
author: Kuanyu C.

description: EGG TART. These happy looking sunshine desserts melt in your mouth. My friend accidentally dropped his on the floor and still ate it. It's that good.
author: Christine C.

description:
O-M-G..... EGG TART heaven! its nice and fresh, warm and tasty, and the shells perfectly flakey. This was by far the best egg custard tart I have ever had. This really is die and go to egg tart heaven.


Other than the egg tart, everything else I tried was pretty good. Got this custard cake w/ coconut filling? YUM! also tried a sesame ball with red bean filling and a rice cake mochi with lotus seed filling?? not bad. but no joke, get the egg custard tart.
author: Lana N.

description:
Their Egg Tarts are like crack cocaine.  Addictive and sooooo good.  Known for their delicious egg tarts they have other yummy baked goods too.  I vote for their bbq pork pastry, super good and super big.  
Located in Chinatown SF, means forget about driving UNLESS you park at the Washington Parking structure.  Don't bother with street parking, so many double parked or illegally parked cars.  
Lines worth the wait, oh and they're closed on random days or weeks.    Silly little bakery, I love you.
author: Carol V.

description: Do I need to say more? THEIR EGG TARTS ARE BOMB! The outside crust is buttery and crispy while the middle is sweet and eggy. A true definition of what egg tarts should taste like. When I arrived, there was a little line that went out the door, but the ladies working behind the counter were really quick with helping out the customers. Their BBQ buns are delicious as well, very soft and fresh. The egg tarts are on the pricier side, $1.60 a pop. Imo, it's worth it because it's legit and fresh. The egg tarts definitely lived up to their hype.
author: Wendy L.

description: The best egg custard tart EVER! It came fresh out of the oven for us so they were still steaming hot! I had to order one separately (not boxed with the other food we ordered) because I wanted to eat it NOW! I just couldnt wait! The custard was creamy and the crust was crispy. I'm sure they use lard to make things so crispy.  We also ordered plain bread rolls. They were amazingly soft, even days later. They taste the best toasted and smothered in butter. They usually have a line out the door but service is quick.  Its more expensive here than any other bakery ($1.15 per custard tart compared to $0.70 at other bakeries). But with their reputation for delicious tarts, they can do that!
author: Janet E.

description: There seems to be a big fuss over this bakery. Mostly for their fresh danh tats (egg tarts). I myself, am also a huge fan of danh tats and have to admit they're pretty damn good. Super flaky and very fresh, pretty much out of the oven and in your box/bag within a span of 10 minutes (they A LOT of these and fast). Most of the time you should expect a line out the door. It'll probably take around 30-40 minutes to wait to get your stuff. Which is why I knocked it down a star for the wait. It isn't THAT bad, but for getting a pastry that fits in your palm, most of the time people order boxes which leads to a longer wait sometimes. Another star knocked off because 2/10 times i visit this location, they're always on vacation which is a hassle. Especially, when I make an effort to visit the place. =/
author: linda p.

description:
Oh Golden Gate Bakery...why must you tempt me with  your diabetes inducing treats every time I am in the city? I am of course referring to the famous Egg Custard Tart of Golden Gate Bakery that everyone and their mother goes absolutely bonkers for. Well, most of us who live in the Bay Area anyway. Well, most of us who are Asian in the Bay Area...I mean, chances are, if you're reading this review on Golden Gate Bakery, you're not from 'round these parts...and if you are, you're living under a solid mass of granite 'round these parts. Not to say you should feel bad for not having ever heard of Golden Gate Bakery, I myself have only heard about it from my beautiful girlfriend just about a year ago...but I'm from Arizona, so I get to play that card, which is a nice card to play. Though if you really have not heard of Golden Gate Bakery and want to try it awesome contents, BE FOREWARNED: They are notorious for closing their doors randomly for extended periods of time. So much so that there is a group on the 'Book called: Is Golden Gate Bakery Open Today? (and yes I do follow that group) that lets you know if the bakery is open on any particular day. Anyways, on to the more productive less-ADHD part of the review:

Golden Gate Bakery is vastly well known for their Egg Custard Tarts, as you can probably tell from the other reviews on the GGB (pardon the Bay Area-esque acronymization). Their Tarts are very famous because they are (imho) not too sweet, yet not in the least bit bland, and the pastry part of the tart is very soft, yet flaky at the same time. The custard portion of the tart has the consistency of freshly mixed homemade pudding, and believe it not (Ripley eat your heart out) still holds the same consistency after being refrigerated over night. The tarts are best when fresh, which means you (ctrl+i)* should  (crtl+i)* eat them right after you walk out of GGB, but you can toast them the next day or even 2 days after purchasing. I am unsure if they are able to keep longer under refrigeration, as I have only kept them at most 2 days after the initial purchase...and believe me, 2 days means I know how to show Buddhist-like restraint. I recommend preheating your toaster oven at about 350, then throwing no more than 2 custards in the oven for about 2-3 minutes, in my past experience that worked super well, remember to throw in  sheet of foil under the custards. The custard are tastiest when warm, though just last evening my better half and I did the unthinkable and ate the  tart cold, and man...it was still wicked amazing.

The custards are not the only amazing thing that GGB offers, and you should feel ashamed for even thinking that...tsk tsk...obligatory 3rd tsk. We also tried GGB's beef curry pastry, chicken curry pastry, and their Wife Cakes (haha...wife cake...). GGB's curry meat pastries are super tasty, though be cautious, if you eat them fresh from the bakery they are freaking HOT, I mean they contain curry (which is part liquid) which can be molten hot magma (admit it...you read that in Dr. Evil's voice...didn't you) in your mouth. Imagine biting into a Hot Pocket the second you remove it from ye olde nuker...instantaneous 3rd degree roof-of-mouth burns. The pastries can come off as a bit salty, but I still find them delicious and very addicting. The wife cake was ok as well, though I feel that it left more to be desired. 

Please note that since the egg custard tarts are the fan favorite, there are times that GGB does not make enough (if at all) of the other offerings to facilitate the necessary baking of the tarts. I gave GGB 4 stars, not because of the quality of the food, but because of it's typical Chinatown service: get them in, get their payment, get them out. Being a kid of the 'burbs, I can't bring myself to rock 5 stars to any place with anything short of impeccable service.

All in all, the GGB is a great place to grab a not-so-quick pastry (typical wait-line is about 10-25 minutes), and if you're ever wondering about the hype, it is most surely worth the drive and wait. 10/10 would continue to eat their deliciousness again.

* I know that physically typing the command for italics doesn't make my font appear in italics...but admit it...you liked it.






TLDR? ;)
author: Julian N.

description: YES. i don't know what else to say. Egg tarts are the best things in the world... its hard to resist. Eat it when its still hot and even chilled a bit its good as well.
author: Ashley L.

description: Must come here to try the egg custard (don tot). They make it fresh and was always served hot for the couple of times I've been here while on vacation. It's probably because every time I'm here, there was a line to buy don tots. I've seen batches come out and go in front of me and I would have to wait for the next batch. It was about a 10 minute wait but I didn't mind because I knew I was getting it fresh and hot.
author: Samantha K.

description:
I think the Egg custard is a little over rated.

Stopped by here to day on our way to grab lunch. After reading all the sea of raves over there custard tart and being a huge custard fan, I was anticipating on trying something spectacular.

Not exactly. The place is situated right smack dab in the heart of china town, being a Sunday it was extremely busy. There were an array of pastries to choose from Mun bean, Delicious looking Moon cakes, red bean filled pastries ect...but my reason for being here were to try one of there custard tarts. So I picked up one for myself and a friend.

Custard was certainly fresh, still extremely warm as if just thrown out of the oven. I did not like the fact how the bottom was so soft and was literally falling all over the place. It was good, though I think the profound smell and taste of the egg was a little too overwhelming. The crust was buttery, flaky and soft which is a plus, though it seemed slightly under cooked to me as well as to my friend.

It was very inexpensive; I believe $2.25 for 2 tarts certainly not bad.

I don't know, maybe I just am not used to it that fresh, or maybe mine just happened to be  slightly under cooked. Anyhow, I do believe I will give them another shot, however I will be getting one of there moon cakes or red bean filled pastries. Maybe try the tart again to.
author: Shannon H.

description:
Wellp, this place gets 5 stars for the epic and delicious daan tat. That being said, good luck on finding it open when you walk by.

For the past EFFING 6 times I have brought visitors here this year (all different months), they have been closed with an "on vacation" sign and no inclination of when they'll be open again. Lots of depressed friends and family because of me hyping it up, only to have the owners go on a random vacation for 2/4 weeks of the month yet again. 

On the most recent let down, I called and someone actually answered the phone, saying they'll be back next week. Guess they're just taking a much needed break from all the money collecting....hukk..if its too much work, just hire one of CA's 13% (reported) unemployed to run the bidness and stop letting ur customers down.

It is not 1 star because the tarts are tasty and the experience, despite the line, is not complete shit. But it is not much better than 2. I dont want to come back here, but ill try again like a sucker if i have visitors...dammit...

My name is Boris Yelpsin, and I approve this message.
author: Daniel S.

description: 15 min after buying a dozen macaroons, a curry pocket, black bean cake, and 3 eggs tarts had disappeared : )
author: Andrea K.

description:
I would literally kill for these small yellow pieces of deliciouness! 
I don't even care about the 11/2 hours that I have to wait in line for this heavenlike treat. Each bite of their egg tart is totally worth the time to wait! By far the best ones I ever had! Compared to other egg tart selling Chinese bakeries in Chinatown, GGB egg tarts have a significant real egg flavor. Love this about them! 
Their macaroons are awesome, too! Great coconut flavor! But watch your teeth, the first bite is a challenge!
Have to admir that their pancakes are weird, though. We tried to share one, forget it, unbreakable. And without any taste. Better get 2 more eggtarts worth the calories instead ;)
author: Ronja E.

description: If you really knew how I ate at home, I would never consider eating egg yolks, let alone custard. BUT, when you're on vacation, heck so should your diet! I came here specifically for the egg custard tart. They mastered the perfect dessert regardless of the gazillions calories in each bite. When I bought it, the tart was still warm in the center! It melted literally in my mouth. The crust was baked with a nice flaky shell. After eating one, I wish I bought two! Remember, I was on vacation!!
author: Santi T.

description: I grew up eating eggtarts! They were my childhood treats & these are MOST DEFINITELY my favorite of ALL TIME. They are so delicious & right on point. Whenever my relatives or friends come from out of town, I always bring them here and everybody I've brought here love it as well. :) This place will not disappoint & you will always leave with satisfaction! Oh and there is often times a line but it moves very quickly.This really is as good as it gets.
author: Mel T.

description: I came here as a kid with my aunts. I remember standing in line back then too! The dan tat (egg tarts) are just as good as they were back then! It's definitely worth the wait in line. This hot fresh egg tarts are so creamy and the flaky crust is perfect! The macaroons are also very good. Go there for the tarts! I went around 4pm and waited for a fresh tray of tarts to come out. Perfect afternoon treat!
author: Joy C.

description:
The egg custards are good, but truthfully not worth the 30 min wait. I got there when the line was kinda shorter.

The sesame ball are no good. They arent even really filled with red bean paste... its like only the last two bites. 

Suggestions, only get egg tarts. Everything is just whatevers.
author: Susie P.

description:
Not only did I have the best egg tart I've ever had in my life at GG Bakery, I also had a great service experience.  One bite into these bad boys and a smile of content slowly took over my face that I just couldn't wipe off.  I won't repeat what everyone else has already raved about the flaky crust, silky-smooth egg custard filling, and how they're best eaten fresh and hot.  Words just can't describe how good these really are.  

But I was truly impressed by the smiling faces of some of the old ladies who work there.  I mean, have you ever seen a take-out server in Chinatown smile . . . ever?  Not only did their cute smiles make my day, one of them chased after me as I left the store because I had left my wallet behind.  Two thumbs up for this place!
author: Tommy W.

description: Once again, YELP had lead me to another hole in the wall. This bakery is very small but it's not hard to find because there's a line all the way out in front. I stopped by here on Saturday and grab a dozen egg tarts for $15...I would imagine it to be cheaper since you can always find a good in deal in Chinatown. But then you definitely get what you pay for because these egg tarts are extremely delicious. This is definitely a must go to place for me every time I visit SF now. I also tried one of the moon cake that they were selling...I tried the one with Taro fillings. The mooncake was just okay to me..nothing exceptional. I also got one of their mochi pastry..which I didn't like that much. The only thing that I will come back here for is definitely the egg tarts.
author: Ngoc L.

description:
Mmm warm, fresh egg tarts! The egg tarts are pretty big and worth the $1.25 each. The crust is light and flaky while the custard is creamy and not too sweet. The custard is good compared to other places that make it too firm and gelatin-like. 

I've read about the long lines and unpredictable store hours but I didn't have to wait long before getting my egg tarts. I guess I got lucky because a line started forming after I got there.
author: Wanda K.

description: Like everyone else, I came here for egg tarts.  I loved that the egg tarts here don't have an insanely sugary custard and are actually somewhat eggy with just a hint of sweetness.  That's a lot closer to how they should be, because traditionally Asian "sweets" aren't actually all that sweet and are more on the savory side.  Only thing is I wish that the crust would be a little thicker so it wouldn't go soggy from soaking up oil so quickly.  Other than that no complaints.
author: Christine W.

description: Everyone comes here for the famous eggtard right?? so do I. I love their eggtard~~ Would buy a dozen to share with my co-workers! I also really love their curry beef bread?? Don't really remember what it called because i can't read Chinese. One lower star because I never know when they open!!!! I remembered everytime i walk by, there was always a paper wrote "On Vacation" or something like that.. Got so pissed off. The service wasn't that good, i mean they don't care if you like them or not. It's true because the shop is already so famous! Who care about the service?! LOL Over all, good pastry place :)
author: Janice N.

description:
Always a line but worth the wait. 

Seriously, do yourself a favor and grab one of their DELICIOUS egg tarts. Warm, flaky, big and custard-y. Need I say more? Just go get one!
author: Sophia Y.

description: Waited in line for about 20-30 minutes and everyone around us was a first timer like us. Make sure you have cash on hand, that's all they take. Also know what you're going to order beforehand so that you don't keep walking in and out of the store. This speeds up the process tremendously. It's a small ma and pop like store that specializes in a select amount of Chinese baked goods. The egg tarts are huge, flaky, and pretty delicious! It was worth the wait
author: Surim H.

description:
This was, hands down, the most delicious egg tart I've ever had. Creamy deliciousness - just makes you

The only reason that I am giving it 4 stars instead of 5 is because $1.50 is kind of ridiculous for an egg tart.
author: Thao N.

description:
THE BEST egg custard anywhere hands down! Enough said.

There's always a line. Even though I've never actually bought any myself. My mom has the patience to wait in line to bring some home for me. I wish all egg custards are like Golden Gate Bakery's!
author: Josie W.

description: We waited in line for the Egg Custard Tarts.  When we got to the front of the line, they just had a fresh batch out of the oven. DELICIOUS! I think it was worth the 20 min wait!
author: David K.

description: It was my first time going to this bakery & luckily there was... NO LINE! For a moment I was wondering if I was standing in front of the right place because I was expecting a hoard of people. Since I don't live in SF I decided to get 2 dozen egg tarts because my inner behemoth just can't get enough pastries/desserts. They were fresh & flakey; although I think they taste better after being refrigerated because it kind of feels like I'm eating flan. The egg tarts are tasty, however,  I don't think I would wait in line for them.
author: Juliet C.

description:
I passed by this place on multiple day trips to Chinatown b/c of the line.  As chance would have it, I found myself waiting for a friend for dinner one night and thought 'what the heck, i'm a tourist in SF and i might as well try it'.  Make no mistake, the line moves slowly.  I think i stood for 40 minutes at around 7pm before I got to place my order.  But..

It's worth it!

I've never had daan tat (egg tarts) anywhere in the US that tasted as good as these.  The egg filling isn't too custardy/sweet/eggy, and I was surprised by how light it was.  The crust was a perfect thin flakyness, none of the cheap mini-pie crust crap.  My fingers weren't oily after touching them either, always a plus in my book.  I didn't feel weighed down after eating one (dangerous b/c you can scarf down multiples) and went to dinner in a great mood.

I originally planned on getting just 1 as a dinner pre-game, but added on more with each five minute block i had to wait in line.  Ended up getting a dozen, which were half gone by the next morning.  Very common to see local chinese ppl buying these in bulk (2, 3, 4 dozen).  

Wait in line!  That's why your phone has games.
author: Michael L.

description: There is a reason there is always a line...they have the best egg custards ever that people buy them by the dozens.  When I have egg custards at other places, if I eat a second one, I usually remove the crust since they tend to be quite thick.  Not here as you will want to eat every bite including the crisp thin crust.  Because of the huge demand for them, you may be lucky enough to get them nice and hot where it literally just melts in your mouth!!
author: Joyce Z.

description: The best egg tart ever! $1.25 hella guud!  Each tray that comes out sells almost instantly.  The egg to water (or milk) ratio is perfect! Holds together perfectly on the verge of falling apart (but won't) perfect amount of sugar not too sweet (so you can scarf down 2 or 3 if you are me!). A memorable experience on my trip to San Fran. Egg tarts for the WEEEEEEEEEEEENNNNNN!
author: Jan Y.

description:
Waited in line for 20 minutes, and a long like after me developed about 20 people deep. This place was worth the wait!

Not too sweet, full of flavor and baked to perfection. The egg tarts live up to the complements given by the many yelpers. 

Coconut tart, white lotus moon cake with one yolk (beautiful and worth paying almost $8), lemon nepolian cake was just as delicious as the egg tarts. 

It is nice to eat pastries without the extreme sugar rush. Im sure everything offered here is top notch.
This place will be my new habit whenever I visit San francisco.
author: Suzy N.

description: We came here on a weekend and the line was so long that we didn't get to try the egg tarts. We then came back on a Tuesday afternoon and luckily the line was short and jumped on the opportunity to order some. We ate them immediately while super fresh and hot! Seriously, the best egg tarts. The egg custard is thick while the shell is thin and flaky.
author: Amy S.

description: I'd never had an egg tart before but am so glad I did here- got it warm. I love that it wasn't very sweet. There was no line when I arrived- 12 noon on a Friday.
author: Tymberly C.

description:
YUM, those egg tarts are so good. As someone who spent a lot of time in Hong Kong, I grew up eating egg tarts a lot. And these are pretty darn good. The custard was really tasty -- not too sweet. And the crust! Glad it wasn't super thick and cake-y. It flaked just as it was supposed to, and didn't have THAT much grease.

I also got a sesame ball and a gei mei bao (I have no idea what that is in English, sorry...). The sesame ball was big, but really hollow, and the filling was red bean rather than lotus seed paste. I probably wouldn't get that again. The other bun was delicious though!

And four egg tarts, the sesame ball, and the other bun came to $6.65.

Not bad for a mid-day snack. And thank goodness the line was short. Probably only had to wait 5 minutes on a Saturday morning around noon!
author: Alison C.

description:
Golden gate bakery is known for their dan tat (egg tart). They're only open a few months a year, but when they're open there's always a long line outside. But because of the long line, the egg tarts are always fresh! 

The egg tarts are a bit expensive but they are heavenly!!! But don't eat too much!! Its made with a huge heaping of lard!
author: Jess s.

description: EGG TARTS at Golden Gate Bakery are, veritably, golden.
author: Emily Z.

description:
Guess What?

Panda Butt!

Guess Who?

Panda Pooh!

*DING!*

You know what time it is!

Huh?

Its baby-making egg tart time :)

GET INTO MY BELLY!

(I also had some red bean filled sesame ball thing that was pretty good, I love red bean)
author: Anthony N.

description:
Holy crap, I just orgasmed in my mouth.  

These little egg custards (dan tat) are so freaking delicious, they make me wanna slap my grandma. 

Ignore the rotting oranges and aged bread outside on display, it is not a true representation of how great this bakery is. If you're lucky enough to come here when its opened, you're in for an experience. They bake their dan tats and sell them fresh from the oven, so you have to eat them while they're still warm. ie: rip open your bakery box on the sidewalk outside and enjoy. Do it!!

These dan tats are big, creamy, and crispy. My mouth watered with every succulent bite. My mind screamed for more as I kept ramming it in me, until I attained ecstasy with my last bite. The best part was probably the egg custard itself, which fills your mouth. Warm and smooth. Mmmmmm. :D 

Catch them if you can though. It's as elusive as the #151st pokemon, WITHOUT a masterball. The chef is always on vacation, and I've left here 5 times empty handed before I caught them this past time. Score!!
author: Ray W.

description:
Every single time I come to San Francisco, I always (and I mean ALWAYS) come here to this bakery and wait in a long line (oh yes it's true what other yelpers say... there is always a long line here...and that should tell you something) for their famous egg tarts... mmm, so good and sweet. Perfectly baked, fresh out of the oven taste (because they bake these all day long), flakey and excellent balance of flavors. Honestly the best I have ever had, ever! 
Although this bakery also sells other delectable Chinese pastries that you find in just about any other bakery, I always just go straight for the egg tarts. I've had the wife cake here before and I didn't really like it. But it's not because of their wife cake, but that I don't think I like wife cakes. They aren't really that sweet, they are more on the savory side and I prefer pastries and baked goods to be sweet. 
Granted the egg tarts aren't exactly that cheap when they cost about $1.25 a piece, but when it taste this good, it's totally worth paying for. Especially for me since I don't even live close by to just have one at any given time (darn, I wish I lived by right now so that I could just buy one and eat one right now). 
If the majority of all the other yelpers are yelping about the egg tarts, then that should tell you something... so what are you doing reading my review for? Just go already and buy one and try it!
author: Vic C.

description: Do not know why the hype. For my taste, it is ok. But everyone i take here loves the tart. I think because it is hot and right out of the oven. Just so you know, reheating is not good. Gotta eat it there. I find myself all the time going to San Francisco and waiting an hour in line for this. Maybe it is just something to do.
author: Connie L.

description:
What you know about "Dan Tats" (Egg Tarts)?. 

This is THE place to get em. Never tried them before? Get them here and you won't go anywhere else. There a little over $1.00 each and they are to die for. Watch out though cause they'll be hot! Also, don't be the sap that only buys one.. you'll regret it because you'll have to get back in line. That's the only reason why I'm not giving it the full 5. The line can be killer. 

Helpful Tip: Because their Dan Tats so good, these guys go on vacation (A LOT) without notice! Don't be surprised if GGB is closed for weeks to months, they deserved it.
author: Albert L.

description:
You MUST try this place if you ever stop by Chinatown. I don't care how long the line is, it is totally worth it! 

And don't just buy one or two eggtarts (is that even allowed?)! You need to buy BOXES. 

They are simply that amazing. The custard is so delicious and warm and not too sweet. My dad said it felt just like biting into egg yolk! 

I also love how when you get to the front, they give you freshly baked egg tarts. :)
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Best. egg. tarts. ever. 

Worth the trip, worth the wait, and worth taking the time to come back. 

It's not possible for these to taste this good. 

I love you GG Bakery!
author: Amrita R.

description:
Totally overrated.  True, one of the best egg tart places in the city but the Asian pastry scene in SF is sad compared to South Bay, LA or, uh, Asia.

Egg part is good but crust excessively oily.  Not worth the wait.
author: Miss K.

description: not worth 2 hours waiting, taste ok, but I still don't understand why this place is so popular, even KFC in China make better egg tarts than they do.
author: Len W.

description:
Either I came on the wrong day or I just don't like egg custards but my experience here was horrible.

For reference I have never had an egg custard tart so I didn't know what to expect. We waited the normal 30 minute wait and got three of the egg custard tarts. I waited about 5 minutes to let it rest and then took a bite.

The taste reminded me of scrambled eggs. I'm not sure if this is normal for people who normally get this, but for me, I was hoping for a good custard treat. The wait along with the flavor was a little disappointing for me. 

Unless I got a bad batch if you don't like an eggy treat don't go here.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
Got egg tarts and jin deui (sesame balls)...

My friend insisted she wanted to wait to see what all the rage was about.

The egg tarts were good, but you can get the same (maybe even better?) at Dick Lees' or at any other place. 

The jin deui was really disappointing... It was HUGE! About the size of a baseball, and I thought it would be filled with red bean paste. Boy, I was wrong. There are only about three tiny squirts of bean paste.

The price was alright and the tarts are good. But why wait then you can get the same thing that's just as good with little or no wait?
author: Aya R.
