description: I actually made it to this place when it opened.  Woohoo!!!  Only here for one reason...the dan tats or egg custard tarts.  Ordered one dozen for $20 or so.  It came out piping hot and you can tell it's super fresh and not as sweet as other places.  To me, the best dan tats all taste the same but I was fortunate enough to get it hot so It was a notch up.  Was I that impressed?  not really.  However, I soon was a few days later as I ate it cold and somehow the crust was still flaky even out of the fridge.  With this, Golden Gate should get a 4.5 rating.  I could see why they can open and close anytime they want.
author: Ricky C.

description:
$1.25 for a "dan tat".  

Flakey, warm and delicious.  But the filling was a little on the sweet side. They also sell other Chinese bakery items - but the dan tat is the most popular, if you couldn't tell by everyone else's reviews. 

If I had to wait in line, I would probably pass on going to Golden Gate Bakery. So come often, or on a weekday.
author: Lisa L.

description: Such yummy egg tarts! The line looks pretty long, but the wait goes by fairly quickly. They definitely have a lot of loyal customers since they can take days off without giving anyone notice.
author: Heather R.

description: Happened to be open, line was one a 5 minute wait. I guess I got lucky. I don't have much to compare it to but they were great. Also, there was a newlywed there on her honeymoon!
author: Andrew W.

description:
Gung hay fat choy!!! I can't stop thinking of those darned Dan Tats! So yummy! Best I've ever had, aside from the Portuguese versions (that I also like). 

Guaranteed that you'll stand in line, even just for a little bit but sooooo worth your time. I swear. The egg custard is perfect. Not too hard not too soft. PERFECT! And the crust is perfect too, not too much and not too little, just the right amount. In fact, dare I say the ratio of crust to custard leans more in favor of the custard, and really how many places do you know who do it like that?

$1.25 a pop. I suggest you get a dozen and hope that ties you over. Once Chinese New Year is over, I'm making sure we head back into Chinatown and I've getting my family our OWN box of a dozen :P
author: Dina V.

description:
Absolutely love their fresh out of the oven custard/egg tarts!  So delicious.  $1.15 + tax (comes to to $1.30).  

If there was a competition between other Chinatown bakeries for Egg Tarts, Golden Gate Bakery wins BY A BIG MARGIN.

Also, noteworthy to try is their coconut macaroons! It's so A-M-A-Z-I-N-G-L-Y delicious.  I think they top it off with a coat of honey or some thin layer of syrup (but its like perfection and adds a carmelized coat - and its not too sweet, which is definitely a plus).

I also decided to try their Oatmeal Walnut cookies - these are simply a disaster.  Each cookie was more than $1.  You can get better quality cookies from Bristol Farms for $0.90 or so...so these cookies were a NO GO for me.

dont be surprised when you go if there's ALWAYS a LINE!
author: Steph L.

description: Not a fan of their egg tarts. They taste like they are made from cheap ingredients. This is no Tartine, that's for sure. Place was dirty too.
author: Chuck G.

description:
It's my second time to go there. The first time, it was closed for vacation...

There is a long queue waiting outside. Other than the famous egg custard tart, they have other things like coconut tart, banana cake, BBQ bun etc. 

I got the egg custard tart and BBQ pork roll. Frankly, I have very high expectation but it was just so so.  The custard is not so soft and the crust is not crispy enough. A good BBQ pork roll should have juicy BBQ pork inside, it doesn't need to have a lot of meat but it MUST be juicy. They have put a lot of pork inside but they are rather dry. 

Probably it's famous because it's the first in town to have HK style egg custard tart. It's quite expensive as well. An egg tart costs $1.35. 

If you really want some REAL and GOOD egg tart, you'd better visit HK. 1/3 price but it's 3 times better.
author: Mag L.

description:
Craving for some really good egg tarts?  Golden Gate Bakery is the place to satisfy that craving.  I've tried egg tarts from quite a few places in SF, and this bakery has the best ones...hands down!

I also tried a wife cake for the first time, from here, and I was quite pleased.  Not overly sweet, and really flaky...just awesome!

Rachel Ray also dropped by here...
author: Michelle N.

description: I'm hoping to change my star rating once I actually get to eat a dan tat!!!  The weekend I went, they were closed!!! I found out later that they do so well that they have the luxury of vacationing quite often... Damn, the envy!  Vacation and dan tat!!! Not to mention it's in SF, such a great city!   I was looking forward to a flaky crust with hot egg custard filling... booo... maybe next time... no, definitely next time!! :)
author: Christine C.

description: Visiting from out of state my friends told me to check this out since it is the best place for egg tarts. Being that I have a sweet tooth, I was determined to go to this place. So upon my arrival, the place was closed...for vacation. I understand people need a break but out of all days, why do they have to be gone the time I come visit? So I can't really give them a ranking just yet until I try their food but it is centrally located in the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown. Looks clean from outside ...would be nice to know when they be back from vacation. A big disappointment.
author: Jaime W.

description: If you are looking for the best egg  tart this is the place to go.  It is delicious and very light.  The crust is nice and flaky.  There's always a line however the ladies behind the counter keep the line moving.  You can walk right by it - but you will always see a line of people waiting on the street to get their egg tart.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
People - OMG - let me share this with you.   There are many bakeries in Chinatown that make awesome egg custards.  You don't have to wait in line for an hour or pay $1.40 for one egg custard!   While making egg custard is somewhat an art, it isn't so unique that other bakeries haven't perfected the art!  You just have to explore other bakeries in Chinatown & try them!  Most of them make them.  Some better than others.

My favorite is the bakery on Stockton & Jackson St (next to Republic bank).
Their egg custard is light, jello like, not too firm that it is eggy and never too sweet. eThe crust is golden brown & so flakey.  YUM.  I prefer the crust to be golden brown.  They charge $1.00 for an egg custard!

The other bakery is across the street & it is good too.  Their crust isn't as brown as I'd like, but it's still great.  They charge .70 for a custard.

The best time to eat a egg custard is when it has cooled off. If it's hot or too warm, it'll just fall apart.  The egg custard has to set & firm up before you can truly enjoy the favors.  

BTW - I don't have names of these places as they are in Chinese.
author: Marie E.

description:
Mmmm, egg tarts!

Heard about this place and there was a long line the first time I went by.  A few days later, no line and only a couple of people in the store browsing so I figured it was a sign!  Hurried into the store and handed over my $1.15 for one of their infamous egg tarts.

I was very happy - still warm with a soft and flaky crust that was perfect and a nice egg custard filling.  Honestly, I have no complaints and would definitely come back again!
author: Katie F.

description:
BEST EGG CUSTARD TARTS EVER.  and i mean EVER.

Fresh, warm, cheap and totally hits the spot.  I think the 1200+ prior reviews sums it up pretty well so I dont really have much to add.  

recommendation:  stop compulsively reading each and every single one of these reviews and just GO GO GO! :)
author: Jenni Q.

description:
This is an old school, family run bakery. The inside is organised chaos, with stuff everywhere & a tiny serving area surrounded by baked goods in the display counters. 

Lucky me, no lines on a Thursday lunchtime. I ordered an egg tart(dan tat), cocktail bun(gay mei bow/long doughy bun with coconut insides) & a sesame ball. 

The famous egg tart was freshly warm out of the oven, it had flaky pastry & soft, not too sweet custard, definitely the best I've had.

The cocktail bun was half the size of the ones I'm used to, it lacked filling but it was very good.

Finally the sesame ball was nice & crisp on the outside, not too greasy or too thick, with lovely red bean paste in the middle. 

Excellent baked treats, I'll be back when I'm next in town!
author: Gar Wing L.

description:
Great egg tarts, especially when they are still piping hot and just out of the oven. Perfectly flaky crust and soft egg custard. If you can't eat it all in one day, put them in the fridge. They can last a while, although after a while the crust starts getting soft, so eat them as soon as possible! You can either heat them up in a toaster or eat them cold - they're good either way!

The wife cakes are very good as well (though huge, like the egg tarts), and my father devoured them after I brought them home. Like the egg tarts, they had a nice flaky skin.

Ironically, when I came here the first time, the stand out ended up being their banana mochi. Nice and soft and chewy. Definitely try it out if you like mochi.

Skip the sponge cake (dry and dense) and roast pork puff pastry.

Before you know it, you've just spent $30 at the bakery.

My only gripe is that of the 10 times I have been to chinatown, they've only been open 2 times. They're basically on vacation all the time.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I hate the lines!  Yes...a freakin' long line for egg custards!!

With that said, it is that freakishly good.  Eat it while it's hot, straight from the oven...it'll melt in your mouth. 

When and if I go line-up for these egg custards, I usually start off thinking that I only want like 2 custards....but by the time I get into the double-digit minutes of waiting...I say screw that...I'm getting 2 dozens!!  For reals...

People say that their secret is the lard (pig fat) they use to make the custards.  Traditionally, Chinese egg custards are made with lard rather than butter.  This place uses lard and so do a few other places.  However,  what kind of lard do they use to get em' soooo tasty!?  Is it from some supercalifragilisticexpialidocious pig or something??
author: Patrick C.

description:
After dinner we wanted a nice dessert to take home so while walking down Grant, we remembered going to this place a few years ago. Loved it then, when we got them fresh out of the oven and we loved them when we got them to go and couldn't eat them till an hour or so later. What I mean to say is that the custard tarts are delicious and rich, and the pastry shell is flaky and delicious. 

My BF also got me a black bean cake since I was getting nostalgic (black bean cakes are my parent's favourite snack) and they were exactly like the ones we used to get. They also tasted great with the flaky crust.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Consistently adequate. Not bad, not great..just adequate.

The prices are a little steep for what you get, IMOP.
author: Jason B.

description:
This little hole in the wall serves the best pastries ever. I love almond cookies and they were delicious. We also tried pastries we've never seen or heard before and we were very happy with it.

You need to be careful though. This is easy to miss.

Really, really good desserts.
author: Ravi G.

description: You know this place gets good business because they can afford to always be closed. I've attempted to come here on several different occasions but they are always closed on random days (WTF on vacation for 2 weeks AGAIN?!) I finally came here on a Sunday afternoon and stood in line for a 45 minutes. Egg tarts were so warm with the flaky crust and the gooey center. This place can really get a lot more business if the little Asian workers were a little more efficient.
author: Cindy A.

description: yeap, hands down, best egg tart I ever had! be prepared for the wait, and try not to stand in front of the store next door or else the lady will yell at you.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Go every once in a while to treat yourself to a custard tart.

Although pricey ($1.15 per egg custard tart and $1.75 for a lotus moon cake) when compared to other bakeries in Chinatown, this place is a must-visit if you want the best bakery Chinatown has to offer.  

I took my family there to pick up some of their delicious delicacies.  My mother (who is dirt cheap when it comes to food) wrinkled her nose at the posted prices ($13.75 for a dozen custard tarts) and expressed hesitancy for me to spend my money there.  However, a well-groomed Asian man in a business suit who enthusiatically proclaimed to us "This place is the best!" as he walked past us and into the shop, caused my mother to change her mind and allow me to go inside and buy some deserts for her and the family.  Two minutes later, my Chinese mother, White father (oh yes, you don't have to have an Asian palate to enjoy an egg tart - if you like custard and warm, flaky pie crusts, then you will thoroughly enjoy the tart),  and two sisters were all oohing and ahhing over the warm, flaky goodness of the tarts.  And 2 days later, when they were no longer in San Francisco, they were still talking about it.

We sampled other deserts there too which were also very good but the egg tart is by far, their specialty.

(IF FOLLOWING MY "CHINATOWN FOODIE TOUR, get one egg custard tart per person.  You can also try other items if interested.)
author: Linda H.

description:
came here twice to get some Egg Tarts for breakfast, it was expensive $1.17  but it was the best egg tart I've tasted in the chinatown area.  
The crust is perfect and the tart was nice & warm.   I've tried other bakeries in SF and most of the time their tarts are cold!   But Golden Gate Bakery has it just right =)     it's a must try at least once!
author: Monica W.

description: Yeah, I'd come here again. The egg tarts are that good.  So good my friends & I waited friggin 3 hours. Make sure you don't go before the moon festival in late August or early September. Moon cakes are sold during this time.   Customer service is lacking, but oh well. It's Chinatown. What do you expect? Space is limited in the bakery, so you've got to wait for the tarts to get baked to perfection. They can only bake a few dozen tarts at a time. :-(  If you don't being treated like crap for a chance to enjoy these delicious, fresh egg tarts, then move on. A second location needs to happen now!
author: Liz J.

description:
First time I attempted to come here it was closed for vacation. Go figure. Apparently this happens a lot.

Anyway, the bf and I were already in Chinatown on a Saturday morning and decided to see if they were open. Wow, they were. So we got in line and wait, and waited... and waited (we had some tourist couple ask us what we were standing in line for too). After about 30 minutes, we finally made it inside and ordered 6 egg tarts, a mooncake, and some muffin thing. Tarts were $1.65 each when I stopped by which sounds like they've gone up in price quite a bit. 

However, I'm happy to say my first ever egg tart and moon cake experience was not disappointing. The tart crusts were crispy around the top and sides, a little soft at the bottom. The filling not too sweet. Mmmm. The moon cake was delicious as well, but I wasn't a huge fan of the yolk in the middle (a little too dry and salty for my liking). I'm not sure what the muffin was exactly, but it was buttery and fluffy.

Overall a good experience, but I have nothing else to really compare it to.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
As a visitor from LA, I just can't miss giving this place a try. The MOST famous..well known place for egg tarts. However, I felt like I came during the worst season. Next week is the Asian "mid autumn festival" and EVERYONE  was FIGHTING.....FIGHTING to buy mooncakes. All that I want was just some egg tarts..but had to get in a very long line. A line that wrapped around the block. Yes..WRAPPED around the block. lol. 

I waited for a good 45 minutes. I talked to some grandpa/grandma while waiting and they indeed agree that these were the best in town. After the long anticipation...it felt like a golden moment when I finally got the opportunity to buy my egg tarts. I blew $50 with 6 tarts & 4 mooncake. I would say rather expensive but ppl were buying bulks and busting out alteast 2-3 benjamins. I heard some grandpa pleading to buy more but they were limiting. Talking about profit? Especially during these economic conditions. 

About my egg tart. The crust was very flaky and baked to perfection. It did have a golden touch. However, rather greasy. The egg custard itself was a light yellow color, warm and wasn't too sweet. Overall, I would say that they did taste different because you can actually taste "the egg" in the tart and not just food coloring with a mix of half egg and some kind of filler. A method rather typical for most dim sum places. The main difference would be that they use lard instead of vegetable oil? You can taste the greasy goodness. 

I would totally come here for egg tarts whenever I visit but it's not something that I'll crave and go head over heels about. They're different and pretty good but most dim sum seafood restaurant in LA will make the cut for our egg tart cravings. They're $1.15 a piece or $13.88/dz. NO DISCOUNTS. sighs.

Well..since I was at it..I gave the mooncake a shot too. Bought one that was "five nuts" and the other 3 were coconut since moms' favorite was coconut. These mooncake run around $8-9 a piece. I have to say that the "five nuts" was surprisingly good. The crust/skin wasn't all too amazing since it was rather dry and didn't have too much grease. however the filling itself was awesome. It had a load of macadamia nuts, pumpkin seeds, sweet wintermelon, shreds of chinese preserved meat, almond, salty egg yolk and some other nuts which I cannot recall. It was the generous portion of macadami and almond that really blew me away. Those of you who has tried the typical "five nuts" should know that mooncakes from China, Hong Kong and Taiwan never includes macadamia or almond. Macadamia is one of the priciest nuts and is definitely a US local. 

This place is insanely shabby and has only 2 tiny tables and like 4 chairs at max. Oh..I also grabbed a macaroon (chinese style) and it was ehh..nothing amazing.

Service was rather bad as the ladies work at a nonstop rate. Don't bother questioning of asking what they'd recommend. You'll most likely end up with a dirty look. Don't ask me why. lol. Can only be dumb once in a scenario like this.




Crying in pain in my heart*
author: Susan T.

description: BEST egg tart ever! No wonder it made the 7x7 list for SF's 100 thing's to try before you die.
author: Angela K.

description: I tried their egg tart, definitely not worth the line. I had taste much better egg tart from Starry bakery and Taipan Bakery or the bakery in Oakland. I definitely will not coming back for their egg tart but maybe I will try their bun.
author: Linna S.

description:
The BEST EGG TART I'VE EVER HAD. The line speaks for itself because it's usually pretty long but luckily I came on a day when it wasn't busy. I got there at around 10:45am and realized that there was no line, so I figured I'd get a couple egg tarts before it gets busy.

When I took the first bite, I felt like I had an orgasm in my mouth. The egg tart crust was flaky and had a good crunch to it. The egg portion/filling was creamy and smooth. It was pretty warm too. I didn't get a chance to try anything else but the next time that I'm back, I'll definitely give other things on the menu a try. Hopefully the line isn't long the next time I come back.

***Parking***: EXTREMELY hard to find in the day time unless you park in the garage. C'mon now, it's Chinatown. You either take the bus or park in one of the garages.

CASH ONLY!
author: Johnny G.

description: Best bakery in China town. Love love the mini custard pies. Delicious moon cakes. The line is always long so be patient. It's worth the wait!  I would recommend this place to everyone.
author: Yette C.

description:
My cousin was craving her egg tarts. So we found the place with a line shooting out the door. It was like 85C Bakery in Irvine but this place is much smaller. When it was my turn to order I asked the lady if they had a toffee cake. She didn't know what I was talking about but told me they had a coffee cake, haha. No worries, so I got an egg tart, a coffee cake, and a red bean moon cake.

That is the best tasting egg tart I've ever had in my life. Fresh. Warm. Flaky. Perfect. 

The coffee cake is your standard coffee cake. Yeah.

The red bean moon cake... although I love me some red bean, that thing was thick! I couldn't eat it all. I got a fourth of the way through and I was over it.

Overall, very awesome bakery at reasonable prices.
author: Laura F.

description: This place is NEVER OPEN. I think I've tried to come here 3 times now and every single time there's a on vacation sign posted. I know of this place because I tried their dan tats when I was a kid. Hopefully, I will be able to try them again so I can review this place accordingly. Please be open next time!!
author: Vivian L.

description: Must taste custard egg tarts. They are so good. Take cash with you they only accept cash.
author: Ravi Teja T.

description: Egg Custard Tarts ... these were the BEST I've ever had.  Awesome !!! When we first walked by, we saw a little chinese girl holding one in her hand with such a big smile.  The line was out the door.  On our way back to our hotel, the line was short so I stopped in.  I'm sure glad I did.
author: Troy H.

description:
YOU KNOW WHAT'S WRONG WITH THIS PLACE?! there's not one in Socal :[

The Skinny:
A San Francisco-Native friend of mine (HI CHETT!) told me i had to hit this place up and get my self some egg tarts. My eyes went from - _ - to O _ O (that's not racist). This place is small, easily missed, but if found, you're in for a treat. Best egg tarts i've ever had. EVER.

The FOOD:
There's not much more to say, except I wish i got one of everything. If their other bakery goods are as good as their egg tarts, then this place is champion. The puff pastry crust was nice and thin, and the egg tart custard was so good, sooo...smooth...sweet...and it was fresh too...oh my, i felt like I almost had an out of body experience eating the egg tarts on the streets of Chinatown. I must say it was PFG, Pretty Darn Good (...)

The Service:
old chinese ladies. Get ready to get in, order, and gtfo. Seriously, don't mess, and dont get butt hurt if they yell at you. That's just how they talk (STILL NOT RACIST). 

Again, this place is a diamond in SF chinatown. If these old chinese ladies ever decide to move to socal and open a bakery here, i'm going to throw a freakin' parade for them. in my heart.
author: Ken L.

description: Sf's best egg tart! There's always a line so be ready to wait.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Mmmmm, man those are some tasty egg tarts! We honestly stopped in here because we saw the line coming out the door from the other side of the street.  Thank God for our cat-like curiosity! So, across the street we went to join the folks in line! We didn't even realize what we were waiting for, so we asked the nice lady in front of us, "So, what's everyone lining up for here." Then she told us that this place has the best egg tarts of any bakery in the city.

Now, honestly, we were both like- What the heck is an egg tart?!? Because in the south, we call it egg custard, and it was the same! These little mini egg tarts were in fact very tasty! Now, it's not mamma's egg custard, but it's pretty close!
author: Jonathan D.

description:
"Oh my god, this is soooo good!"
"Oh my god, let's wait in a 20 person line!"
"Oh my god, these eggtarts are to die for!"
"Oh my god, BEST. FOOD. EVER."

Me: ....

Are we eating the same food?  

I like me a good eggtart every now and then too, but this is getting a little ridiculous. Okay, so their eggtarts are pretty crispy, tasty, and fresh out-of-the-oven-hot.  But, really?  That amazing?  

Recommendation: Walk up the block to Stockton, and stop by Red A, or Napoleon, or any of the dozens of Chinese bakery establishments, and you'll get a decent eggtart.  Sure, you'll have to brave the millions of senior citizens ready to attack you with pink baggies, but it's worth it.  And if you want fresh-out-of-the-oven taste, you just need to bring them home, and stick them in your toaster oven.  You'll pretty much get the same result.

An eggtart is an eggtart is an eggtart.

Final word:  Good, but overrated.  Hella hoopla = annoying.
author: Vivian C.

description:
We have been coming to Chinatown for three years now and this place has not always been open.  It was open the first time we came but way too long of a line.  Yesterday we stopped by and there was NO line at all!  We ordered the Egg tart and the Lemon Napoleon.  The egg tart was delicious and was not excessively eggy.  The Lemon Napoleon was not yummy and I did not even finish eating it.  The cake was very spongy and the lemon part was a little gross.
Today we went back and ordered the 3 coconut macaroons, 2 chocolate chip cookies, and 1 Vanilla Bun.  The Sweet lady gave us 6 coconut macaroons! :)  The macaroons were perfect and were moist and chewy.  The cookies were crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside.  And the Vanilla Bun, words can not describe this one.  Great prices too!
author: Michelle C.

description: Hype is justified. Egg tarts are on another level of any other egg tarts I've ever tasted!
author: Michelle N.

description: 3.5*s Best Dan tat in SF!!! Too bad I don't like Dan tat... OR Chinatowns. Which makes this place not a travel destination for me. Thus, if friends are trying to convince you that "this place has the best dan tat in SF!" and you, like me, don't care for dan tat or chinatowns, I would deffo recommend skipping this!!!
author: Sam W.

description: Waited in line for 40 minutes. Still the best Don Tot anywhere! The Moon Cake and other pastries are also still the best around. The only draw back is they are unorganized when it comes to people cutting in line. They have 4 people behind the counter and it moves at a snails pace. The Owner would make even more money if she can get organized and get customers served in a timely manner because while waiting in line, I noticed several people discouraged and didn't want to wait in such a long line. Can you imagine she can take even longer vacations!! LOL!
author: Rod W.

description:
PROS: The egg tarts are warm when you order them. The lady at the register on this rainy day that we went was very nice and greeted us as soon as we walked in soaked by the rain. I'm a sucker for a friendly face and a warm greeting. To me, that is how I decided if my money is being well spent. These are SO good. I ordered 6 and two red bean pies (which were a bit too much because they were HUGE). But this place is good for an egg tart fix. 

CONS: Parking is a hassle. We went on a rainy day so it wasn't too crowded, but parking wasn't even an option. I can't imagine how crowded the streets would be on a rainy day. Be prepared to make a trek to the store or to have someone circle the block a few times.
author: RoseMichelle M.

description:
Came for one thing, and one thing alone:  Egg tart (Dan Taa)

Yes, the rest of the pastries were tasty, yes they were enjoyable... but this is the best Dan Taa in San Francisco... and it far outshined the ones we have in Chicago.

If you're in the area, worth stopping by this small business to pick up an order or twelve.
author: Derrick T.

description:
Creamy egg tarts! For all you egg haters out there, I am one too but these egg tarts are so good...it's like eggy but so sweet at the same time! Yup, definitely go a little earlier to get the oven-fresh egg tarts. 

And it definitely is a nice treat on a cold, blustery day. Of course, there is no room inside the place to eat your treats so you're out in the cold within a minute of ordering, but at least you have your egg tarts...so good!
author: Kara K.

description:
I've been coming to this place for the last 15 years. It definitely helps that I live just a few blocks away. But i remember my mom taking me here, waiting in line, and walking out with a box of egg tarts and curry pies. This place definitely is worth the hype. The eggs tarts are a little more expensive than other places in chinatown but is definitely worth it. The lines can get pretty long and the bakery itself is very cramped.

I brought a good friend of mine from SoCal here who have tried and love their egg tarts but was hesitant when i bought her the bbq pork pastries. But, of course she was wrong and loved them too. People need to learn to stop doubting me.

Cash only mudahassholes!
author: Steven L.

description:
Finally caught this place open!

We had some time to kill before our reservation at z&y and i noticed gg bakery for once wasnt gated so we had to try it. there was a short line and a couple of delicious looking pastries in the display cases tempting us.

got ourselves the famous egg tarts. we thought they were cheap but im assuming they are more expensive than average. the crust was buttery and flaky and the filling was just set not at all dry. it was slightly sweet with a definite 'eggy' finish. granted i haven't had many egg tarts, but this is definitely the best i've had yet. personally think they'd be perfect slightly sweeter but the overall pastry is great as is so im delighted!

i'd give them five stars but its been impossible to find them open in the past so they still could work on that
author: Sam H.

description: Why do you randomly close and take holidays at will? Because you know you're that damn good. The egg tarts here still are the best. Perfect sweet egg filling with crusty buttery flaky sides. Just hope you can catch them. I'll stick my elbows out like the tiny Asian ladies in a fight to get my dozen.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Best place for Egg Tarts!!!! I have so far only tried their egg tarts from here, but everything else in this neat little bakery seems also very delicious!!!! They are a bit pricey just for egg tarts if you buy a couple boxes but I think it is worth every single dime!! When you visit china town make sure you visit this little gem and get at least 2 boxes of egg tarts cause you'll end up wanting more!!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Im a pretty big fan, when it comes to egg custards. 
Ive been eating these little delicious treats for sometime now. and I thought there was only one place that had the Best Egg Custards Ever, a place called "The Best Dim Sum/ Pastries", which is located in Oakland. They are the Best in the East Bay. but Golden gate bakery would be my favorite outside the town.

Im glad I discovered this new chinese bakery in frisco. actually, its been there for a minute now by the looks of it, maybe even before i was born. well, its brand new to me and i am feelin' it. They have it all here and many more just like a chinese bakery should be like. and a Big Plus is they bake everything Fresh throughout the day.

I sampled a few of the pastries here already. they were pretty good, but isnt something i would go out my way for. The Thing that I would go out my way for, would be the Egg Custards. These things are quite popular here, guess thats why theres always a line. They're pretty expensive, doubled the original price. ($1.15 each, I believe). Always fresh and warm everytime i place my order. The custard isnt as sweet as other joints but it taste just about right to me. the flakiness of the crust is what its all about. not much a fan of the cookie type crust other places make. This egg custard literally just melts in your mouth, No joke and no need to chew. On weekdays, the lines arent too bad here. i hear weekends are much worst.

Basically, Im the type of person that DOESNT like to stand in lines for Anything. its not because im lazy, i just dont have the patience. But i'll give it up to golden gate bakery for their delicious Egg Custards. These lines dont fade me, plus i love chinatown.
author: Rudy R.

description: The egg tart is great! It is so well combined with the crispy pastry and tender egg stuffing! The line is pretty long, because it was moon cake festival, people were eager to buy the moon cakes! I am not a moon cake guy, and don't enjoy that sweet taste. Also, this time I find the moon cake disappointed. The stuffing are too sweet for me. Also, the price for the moon cakes are kind of expensive. But the price for egg tarts and others are reasonable. I get a box of the egg tart and love them very much!
author: Lei G.

description:
Went back today--confirmed. Egg tarts are amazing. Nothing else is worth it, especially given the opportunity cost haha.

Remember to bring cash! They don't take cards.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
The egg custard tarts are hands down the best I've ever had. And judging by the 1,100+ reviews here, it's the best all around. There's usually a line and the service can be brusque. I find it funny how well this business does as the owners close the shop whenever they feel like and they don't give you any notice as to how long they'll be closed for. 

Word of advice, get extra to bring home and toast it in the oven for a few minutes for that fresh, hot out of the oven taste in the comforts of your own home, instead of in the smelly streets of Chinatown.
author: Chi N.

description:
The egg tarts are delicious, but really not worth the 45 minute line!  Good flaky crust, plenty of egg custard, and it's not too sweet or buttery.  I've had better dan taats in hong kong and macau, but this is pretty much as good as it gets here!  The other bakery items are so-so.  The cake was really dry, so I wouldn't order cakes here.  You pretty much come here for one thing, the dan taats!  But it really isn't worth the wait just for dan taats;  you could get your dan taat fix at any nearby dim sum restaurant!  Unless your like a daan taat connoisseur!  

If you've never had a daan taat, you might think these are the most amazing tarts in the world.  But really any upscale dim sum place has these, and they all taste just as good to me.

At $1.25 per dan taat, it's a little steep...especially since all the other Chinese bakeries sell egg tarts for under $1.  One of my other favorite Chinese bakeries is Alex Bakery, they also make a good dan taat and you don't need to wait nearly as long!
author: Terence N.

description:
motherofgod.jpg I think I've discovered the best Hong Kong Milk tea and Egg Tarts outside of Hong Kong. The line to get to these tasty little suckers had to fold on top of itself twice because the lady next door who sells glass balls wouldn't let us stand in front of her store. 
PS: Whatever you do, don't believe the hype about raisin bread. A lot of people were snatching big loaves of these up so I bought one just to see what the fuss was about, and it tasted like regular bread with raisins. -__-
author: Shuang C.

description:
In the name of all that is holy, Golden Gate Bakery...you are the Dan Tat King!

Here it is, my grandmother lives in the heart of Chinatown, yet I only recently discovered this bakery by accident.  Oh my, the lines sure do get long for this place, but, damn it's worth it! 

The Dan Tat is soooooo incredible, I can't even find the words to truly describe it!  The egg custard of the dan tat is soo perfect its ridiculous.  It's smooth, silky, sweet, and melty goodness that sits on a bed of flaky, light crust that makes for an overall orgasmic experience.  

My recommendations: if you're new to this place, order more than one, heck order half a dozen.  Reason being, I bet you can't eat just one!
author: Merisa M.

description:
The egg tarts are as good as you'll get outside of Macao.  Buttery bottom, not too sweet filling, and at $1.35 fairly priced.  The moon cakes have fun flavors and they are very good about asking whether you want something with or without egg yolk.   Don't commit to them unless you really like mooncakes though.  A small one is about $3.50 and a large one is $7.35!

I didn't like the curry chicken pies. 

They're very careful about the wrapping for all the pastries that you get, which I really appreciated.  They cover everything in wax paper and position them in paper bags very delicately, so that nothing flakes or breaks on your way home.  

The store proprietress is very sweet!  I asked her about her recent vacation and she said they had a great time, went every where.  They go on vacation three times a year, which refresh them for the rest of the year - it's largely a family operations that works about 12 hours a day.
author: Di Yin L.

description:
Very yummy mooncakes, especially they have the special flavor of Taro (my favorite), so i am definitely a fan!

the egg tarts have always been good. i have been having them for years now. prices are also very reasonable.  highly recommended!
author: Ed L.

description:
Seriously, is there any contender that will match Golden Gate Bakery and their Egg Tarts/Dan Tats? No? So one must make the trek to Chinatown and head over to GGB for this amazing treat. Be prepared to wait in line or sometimes face disappointment for the random vacations the owners/workers seem to take. However, don't fret, keep trying, trust me, all these reviews certainly help point to a positive foodie experience.

Memories of being a little kid scooping out the custard with a spoon, because those generic hard and tasteless crust are quickly diminished as the taste of GGB's layers of flaky crust perfectly encases a huge egg custard. As someone who loves the taste of egg, it could not get any better; unless GGB decides to make a pie level size egg custard...one can dream. For over a dollar for one of these bad boys, they are one of the most expensive on the market; however, they are one of; if not the best egg custard around. The smell is intoxicating as you should eat one fresh to sample heaven, however they are still good cold and can always be slightly warmed up for a later snack. 

They are well known for their moon cakes as well, but as someone who doesn't really eat moon cake as much, I cannot attest to how good they are.
author: Casey L.

description:
Just stop reading and go stand in line because 1. You will have to wait and 2. It will be worth it. Just like everybody else, I recommend that you get the egg tarts. I was skeptical as to how much better their egg tarts could be (I mean egg tarts are just egg tarts) but after trying them, I gotta say these reviews aren't exaggerating. Something about the crust...it's like crack. 
A dozen=$15
1=$1.25
author: Emily T.

description:
Yes, it is true.  They have the best flaky egg tarts (Dan Tah) in the area.  

Would drive over the bridge for their dan tahs.
author: Wendy H.

description:
OF COURSE all the bakery is FRESH.

In fact, it is so fresh and amazing that they are closed half the time (baking probably). I love love love the egg tarts, it is better than HONG KONG. And every time I come, I have to get almond cookies for my mom.
author: Linda S.

description:
Its always worth the wait but you know we all hate the long lines... go there early!

The yummy goodness you can never just buy one you have to leave with a dozen especially when it is straight out of the oven! Can you open more locations lol!
author: Akiliano T.

description:
I don't care if they're probably made with lard or that they are overpriced or that you have to wait in line for half an hour...Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts are freaking out of this world - and that's coming from someone who has eaten countless of egg tarts in Hong Kong, the origin of egg tarts. Extra kudos to having flaky crusts instead of the cookie-crust.

The best part, and the most important, of their egg tart is of course the egg-custard filing; it is silky-smooth and full of egg-flavour. All of this divine goodness is wrapped with their buttery, crispy and flaky crust. Moreover, the filling-to-crust ratio is just right. And somehow coming in a pink cardboard box just makes them a little more legit.

Trust no other bakery's egg tarts in the Bay Area. Sure their service might not be the best, they're expensive, they're always closed for vacation (tells you how much money they make), there's no seating and you always have to wait in line, but....IT'S ALL WORTH IT!!!!!!

Man, I kind of want to eat one right now.
author: Grace C.

description:
The famed egg custard tarts certainly did not disappoint.  Perfect crust and just simply delicious.  Everything else I tried there was good also, including the sesame balls, nian gao, and suncake (tai yang bing).

We had to wait about 30 minutes to get in though, which is a bit ridiculous for a Chinese bakery.  And once when we went, they were closed due to a vacation!  Not sure if the high quality is worth the inconvenience, especially if you are not from the area.
author: Andrew K.

description: Yummy pork buns, tasty egg or bean Tarts, fresh fortune cookies. I have been going there for years. Authentic Chinese food. Get there at the right time and you can get fresh hot baked goods. Always fresh and very friendly service. I always stop here when I'm in Chinatown and get some fresh fortune cookies to take home. Inexpensive treats. Casual attire. Parking in Chinatown? I doubt it, maybe a few blocks away...
author: Ron W.

description:
Okay first off let me start by saying yes the Egg Custard Tart is good. Probably the best, yes the best Egg Custard Tart I'll ever eat in my life. After saying that, I'll most likely never eat an Egg Custard Tart again. I'm really not a big fan of Egg Custards and Golden Gate Bakery did NOT change my mind. 7x7 list "100 Things to Try Before You Die", I'm not with you on this one. On my death bed and you offer me an Egg Custard Tart? PASS! 

Just to clear out some rumors, yes the line is most of the time out the door, yes it's in Chinatown so forget about the drive by pick up, and yes this place is close a lot of times. The owners are probably so rich from all the Egg Custard followers they can afford to close the shop down and go to Hawaii or something. Reading some of the reviews here I am so amazed how many fellow Yelpers love this place. 

Bottom line, for you Egg Custard Tart fans, you probably won't be disappointed and to the non-fans don't set your expectations too high!
author: Mel B.

description: Finally tried the egg custard tarts and so worth the $1.40. Wondering if they use shortening in the crust but one of the best crusts I've ever had. The custard itself is delicately done - not too eggy. Friend showed me an insiders tip. You can microwave any you take home for 20 seconds to bring take out to life. Yummalicious.
author: Paul F.

description:
This place wasnt to far from our hotel and we decided to stroll or rather hike over there for a late afternoon snack. There was a bit of a line still at around 2-3pm so we patiently waited and waited. The people in front of us seemed to be making large orders as they were walking out with boxes and boxes of items, it was not until after that we realized that there would be Chinese New Year celebrations going on.

The place is tiny and sometimes you have to get over your issues of personal space, I did feel the lady behind me that kept pushing up on me to see what selections there were in the window was a bit much since they weren't going to change every 30 seconds as she seemed to think...but I refrained myself from brining my elbow up and jabbing her once in the jaw and told myself that people have different concepts of personal space and I must respect it.

At any rate, we got one egg custard tart and one baked pork bun to go please...waundered around a bit and got some taro flavored bubble tea at some random dim sum place. My bf bit into the tart and almost spit it out declaring that he did not like eggs...I reminded him that it was called an egg custard tart and he said that it tasted like someone put a whole egg in there with the custard. I had no such qualms about the egginess of the tart, I love custard I used to eat it alot growing up and it was warm, gooey and flaky and pretty big for $1 and some change esp compared to the other bakeries we passed by. 

The pork bun was also very good, it was not shredded pork but little diced pieces of pork with onions in it and my bf ended up demolishing most of it, baked was also interesting as we usually have steamed so that is worth a try as well.
author: Angela M.

description:
Yummilicious! I burned my tongue with my first few bites of these juicy, soft, golden, heavenly smelled flakey egg tarts. But hey it didn't stop me from eating more.

These egg tarts are huge, unlike the little bitty ones typically served at the dim sum restaurants. I was really pleased with my visits to the Golden Gate Bakery, in fact i even bought half a dozen egg tarts with me back to Texas.
author: Sallio H.

description: Just randomly walked by and there was a line at 7p. It was a line for moon cakes for the Mid-Autumn Festival. I hopped in line and chatted with the guy in front. He mentioned that I should try a one-yolk white lotus moon cake. The black lotus was also recommended, but at a buck more (and with negligible taste difference) the white one was the way to go for my inexperienced pallet. I was in Chongqing last year for the moon festival, so this line brought back good memories, and now I'm glad to know one of the best places in SF to buy a moon cake. I'm eating it right now!
author: Brian J.

description:
The BEST egg tarts EVER. They're a lil on the expensive side (it's like .90/each?), but they are DEElicious so it is totally worth it.

They are always served fresh out of the oven. They are the flaky shell kind, not the hard kind. It's always warm and the egg is soft and semi sweet. It kinda melts in your mouth as you eat it.

The Chinese women who work here may not be the friendliest. Don't take it personal.
author: Rosie W.

description:
Egg Tarts - The best ever. Period. Especially when it is hot and fresh from the oven. Parking is a pain in the butt. You need to check to make sure they are open. & bring a friend so you have company while you wait. 

Egg Tarts - gooey goodness - the flakiness of the crust just melts in your mouth and it is kind of worth the burn when it's just fresh from the oven. the tart is not overly egg tasting and hard... just simply delicious.

Their other pastries are good too, but not as good as the fresh egg tarts. It is totally worth the price - esp when you get a dozen. Love it love it.

Just be forewarned - the lines will be around the block!
author: Chloe C.

description:
First off i dont know why people are complaining about their egg tarts having an "eggy" taste.... i mean hello does the name egg tart mean anything to you people hah!

It's great, the filling is sweet but not too sweet and it's hot fresh out the oven everytime. the crust is flaky and it's different from all the other bakeries

I think what makes this place more known for their egg tarts is really that it's fresh out the oven everyday and they put enough milk in the filling mix so that it stays soft and moist even when cold. The fact that the crust is flaky like a crossiant makes it the best combination. 

Definitley try because it's different.
author: Josie L.

description: Best egg tart outside China!! Owner is always on vacation though, shop close quite often.
author: E C.

description: As in love as I am with this bakery for their legendary egg tarts, THEY ARE NEVER OPEN WHEN I CRAVE THEM. Whenever I am conveniently in Chinatown, they seem to always be on vacation. This is the only reason I give it four stars. Besides that. They are most definitely the most delicious egg tarts that I have ever tasted
author: Leah C.

description:
The best daan tat (egg tart) in the area.
They're so delicious, because they use the traditional pig lard to make their flaky crust. Best served warm!

Their moon cakes are also super delicious (stuffed with a mixed variety of nuts).

Typical Chinese service: quick and impatient
As other reviews say... they come and go, open and close whenever they please.
author: Adorable T.

description:
Rumor has it, "Golden Gate Bakery" is THE stop for your egg tart fix - all over San Francisco, California, the West Coast, and even America.

Now that's a lot to live up to.

Did it live up to the hype?

Yes and no. 

For a buck and a quarter, you get one gooey, freshly made egg tart surrounded by a perfectly flaked crust.

Taste was great and the temperature was perfect.

This bakery had a lot to live up to - and on a typical day, and typical wait for this place (I've heard, from 30 minutes to over 1 hour), I'd rather spend my time leisurely indulging on nearby sweets in the area.

Fortunately for us, we stumbled across this place at 8 pm on a Sunday - with only a 15 minute wait. So, get there late on a Sunday if you'd like to spend your time enjoying tarts, not waiting for them.

On another Sunday evening, I'd definitely give this another go.
author: Jamie L.

description: My favorite Egg Tart place in San Francisco. However, expect long lines from tourists and foodies who love their Dan Tats (egg tart). I still wait in line though, because of the tasty flaky crust and the warm sweetened egg custard. This review is just for the egg tart. I don't buy the other pastries at the bakery. I would probably just go to a less crowded one if I needed them.
author: Jason L.

description:
So yes, they really do have the best egg custards in town. Maybe even in the state of California!

Surprisingly there was no line when we showed up at 11am on a Saturday, only a handful of patrons ahead of us in the process of getting their orders fulfilled. The place can be described as unassuming and looks just like any typical Chinese bakery: cramped storefront, no-nonsense display case and utilitarian baked goods that are all tasty substance without the unnecessary benefit of decorative frills. 

The egg custard tarts are so good. Soooo good. The pastry shell is light, flaky and buttery with a creamy, generous center. I ordered an array of treats : Special chicken pie, curry beef pie, almond cookies ( just to name a few) and everything was good. Particularly the special chicken pie, I'm not exactly sure what was in it but it was definitely special. 

The ladies behind the counter were all business, but efficient and diligent with packing and securing the order, even cutting flaps into the pastry box to vent the hot baked goods. Can't wait to come back!
author: Eileen C.

description:
Warm delicious melt-in-your mouth egg tarts fresh outta the oven, always delicious.  You know that you should wait for it to set for like 5 minutes, but you can't wait and it just goes straight into your mouth and it kind of burns but it's soooo worth it.  

There is almost ALWAYS a line, so that just sucks, and the price is almost double the other bakeries nearby.  They lose a star because I haven't liked anything else they have.  It's not bad, but nothing else is worth the twice the price.  

Honestly, most of the reason it's so good is that it's so fresh.  Since everybody comes here and orders it, they are never sitting very long.
author: Aly A.

description:
Dear GGB - 

You have the BEST dan tat's ever. BUT why are you always on vacation?!?!! Just tell me when you'll be back, and I'll come crawling back. Just stop toying with my stomach cuz I'm getting hella hangry!!!
author: Calvin W.

description:
The World According to Noelle
~Allergic Girl's Guide to Life~
Issue 264

Freshly baked Chinese pastries. We were on one mission and one mission alone- to purchase dan-tat (Chinese Egg Tart). I wanted one but he purchased a dozen (for me to share with my parents and grandmother). It was baked to perfection, not very sweet. The best dan-tat I've ever had in my life was on vacation in Hong Kong a couple of years ago. 

Noelle's Notes
Hard to find parking.
author: Noelle J.

description: Its worth the hype about the egg tarts we waited in line about 30mins. they are so light,buttery,and flaky and still hot when we got our (not warm) they were good...But the almond cookies are to die for me,they are sooooooo good, could it be that they were just flew then in from China eating one now while yelping.
author: Tommy M.

description:
Had to try this for myself, since all reviews for this place was stellar!

It was the most amazing egg custard tart deliciousness I have EVER tasted!  (1 for $1.25)  OMG, came out super fresh and hot.  Every bite was scrumptious and oh-so- good!  Crust was nice and flakey.... Can't wait to come back to this place next SF visit!
author: L G.

description:
It's easy to look pass this little dingy hole in the wall place when you're walking down the busy streets of China Town, but it would be a mistake of a lifetime if you didn't stop to try one of their delicious golden egg tarts! 

I have been coming to the golden gate bakery for my egg tarts my whole life, and whenever my parents brought it home in that oh so familiar pink box I would be so excited that I would eat one right away. These egg tarts are unlike any other egg tart i've tried anywhere else. These egg tarts have the most light, flaky, buttery, golden delicious pastry crust that gives you that little crunch when you bite into it. The golden egg tart filling is sweet, but not too sweet, rich, warm, silky smooth satisfying custard that melts in your mouth. In all the years I ate here, I have never been disappointed with the egg tart being too eggy, too sweet, too anything. It is just perfect.

Once a year the golden gate bakery does make moon cakes for the moon cake festival. I have lined up super early in the morning before they open for hours to buy moon cake. It is worth it, as their moon cake has been one of the best mooncakes I've tried, but the egg tart is still near and dear to my heart.

As a suggestion, try to go to the bakery either in between breakfast time and lunch time, or late afternoon because they are a very small store and the line gets relatively long. But for me, waiting in line to is worth it when I leave with a pink box full of golden delicious goodies. :) Good luck!
author: Hilary C.

description:
I came here after running around the china town grubbing on dim sum. Was totally looking forward to these egg tarts because I'm so in love with them, but they were ok.

I was expecting a long line after reading some of these reviews, but there wasn't a line at all. The place is incredibly small so I can understand why the lines can get long. Anyways, on to the egg tart... they weren't anything out of the ordinary except for their unusually large size. They did satisfy my egg tart craving though so if I'm ever in the area again, I'll be coming back for more.
author: Jessica V.

description:
I liked egg-tarts before they were famous. this was my 2nd favorite place to get egg-tarts, next to garden bakery. True, garden bakery in chinatown does not rank nearly as high in reviews or rating as golden gate bakery. however, i am a fan because I ate there each day before chinese school. anyways, golden gate bakery is 2nd best to me. the eggtarts -inside is fluffly, outside is cookie. its a very good item for desert, and the recipe is top secret. This little shop has been here for as long as I have been on this planet (23 years), and as a little boy who only lived a couple blocks away in CT, it was a savory treat each rare time I got it. 

The price has gone up quite a lot due to popularity, but its definitely worth a try -a taste of chinatown. I.. wont even disclose how much each egg tart cost because it is best that you try it first, uncorrupt of any monetary detriments to the taste buds.

-wifive-
author: simon k.

description:
What people say is true: the egg tarts at Golden Gate Bakery are the best. 

Delicate egg custard flavor that's not overly sweet, nice flaky pastry and  no tin pie shell that seems to be the norm at other Chinese bakeries that I find annoying because it's not necessary and adds one more step, impeding me from getting that egg tart into my mouth.
author: Lee H.

description:
This is THE place to get the best egg tarts around.  However at $1.35 each AND 1 HOUR or longer wait time, one really needs to think about whether it's really worth it, time and all.  But we went for it. Total wait time for us was just 1 hour and 45 mins (it was also Moon Cake season).  Not surprisingly, there's no discount for buying a dozen egg tarts at a time either.  Guess they never heard of Baker's dozen. But then they sell every one they make. 

 We purchased six egg tarts and one pineapple moon cake and went over to one of the Italian cafes along Columbus Ave and enjoyed both great coffee and great egg tarts.  Total time for this excursion... 3 hours.
author: Acura Nsx T.

description: Get the banan.....oh yeah, they're never off of vacation.  I haven't been in for over a year. I need that much vacation.
author: Jeff H.

description:
If all my friends jumped off of the Golden Gate Bridge, I'm not sure I'd comply.  But if all my friends are in love with the Golden Gate Bakery, there is a steady desire to follow along.  

So... when I say "Yay, I'm a fan", it's more because there is nothing awful about the place.  The bakery serves a decent selection of Chinese baked goods/desserts, and amongst them, is the infamous egg custard.  I'm not a fan of egg custard--do you see why I'm perplexed?  These egg custards weren't amazing enough to flip me into an absolute awe that triumphs any previous lack of desire for egg custard.  But, they weren't bad either, and they were better than others that I have tasted.  So, it's worth the trip, especially for all the Chinatown tourist trotters.
author: Diane N.

description:
The egg custard tarts (dan tot) are the best I've ever had. Better than L.A., better than Hong Kong, better than China (and yes I've had them at all of those places). For those who don't know, these tarts use the flaky butter crust (versus the old school hard crusts). A few caveats before you go:
1) you have to eat them right then and there, burning your mouth with the creamy egg custard. 2) You cannot, should not, will not only buy one. Buy a dozen, share with friends. The egg custards reheat well, but ONLY in an oven. 7 curses on your soul if you use the microwave. 3) The store is always closed. They take like 10 vacations a year, I kid you not. So you take your chances. But it is o' so worth it. I always take my out of town chinese relatives and friends here and the egg tarts have never disappointed.
author: Dom L.

description: This overhyped, overpriced place doesn't deserve that high rating. If you tourists must buy from here, just get the pricey egg tarts. Extra butter on the food doesn't mean it is the best. Go to Mong Kok, they are more worth the hype.
author: Dan A.

description:
$.75 for an egg tart :) you can only get them in the pretty pink box if you buy at least 6. We bought 8 and got confused and just got 2 bags :( wah we lose! But they're so delicious and GOOEY and HOT and FLAKY.. OMGOODNESS. So loaded up. They should defintely have more than one flavor. But again, if it ain't broke, don't fix it!

Waited in line, and then some more, and then this lady and her hubby cut us and the whole crowd got antsy and boo'd her away. Crowd mentality I guess. LOL!

Did a double take on the reviews and people are saying they are $1.25.. maybe because it was the Chinese Lunar New Year weekend that we got them for $.75?! Bc I remember panicking bc we only had liek $10 of cash and I told my bf that they were $1.25 but then I was dead wrong lollll. Who knows, maybe they're like airplane tickets, LOL
author: Jenna L.

description:
I'm somewhat of a snob when it comes down to chinese food.  Growing up in chinatown has set a very high stand for what good pastries are.  This establishment in my opinion is one of the best I've ever had.  

Freshness is the critical element here.  The ladies behind the counter who pretend they don't speak english know this well.  Egg tarts are best enjoyed fresh and warm which is why they are packaged with open holes cut into the box to keep from getting soggy.  The egg tarts themselves aren't on display... which makes you feel "in the know" for asking for them!  
The puff pastry shell is sinfully crispy and the custard has the silky smooth texture and sweetness that reminds you more of well done flan than custard.  A MUST TRY.

The lines are indeed long but good things are always worth waiting for aren't they?
author: Winson K.

description:
I'm rating this place solely on the egg tarts, which are frankly all you need to get. 

To add to the chorus of praise, these egg tarts are the best I've had outside of Taiwan. The crust is perfectly buttery and flaky, and the custard has just the right ratio of sweetness to egginess. 

My old roommate introduced me to this place; she brought some dan ta home to share so I didn't even have to wait in line. Come to think of it, I should've never moved out...
author: Joann T.

description:
I waited in line for 15min today for one egg tart. And it was definitely worth the wait.
There was a huge line of people outside the shop when I came by, which almost put me off. However, the line moves pretty quickly, and luckily the sun was out today. The egg tart is definitely hands down the best egg tart I've ever had, and growing up in Hong Kong I've definitely had my fair share of egg tarts. It was fresh, the filling was smooth and sweet and the crust was light and buttery. I really wish that I hadn't waited until getting into the car before eating it, or else I would've definitely gotten a dozen instead.
author: Helen Y.

description: We waited in line for about 45 minutes, and it was totally worth it.  These guys have strange hours so if they're open when you happen to be nearby, just do it.  Egg tart heaven.
author: Lindsey G.

description:
Day 4 AND 5 of MWLAWMBF:
On day 4 of my adventure in SF, we ventured into Chinatown to get some egg custard tarts (dan tat). I heard that these were the best around so we decided to get them. WOW. They were amazing. Walked right in and got 2 of them for $2.30 and are them right outside the doorway. They were amazing. Delicious. Perfect - flake-y, rich...a bit on the oily side, but that's not that big of a deal to me.

On day 5, we were doing a photoshoot with a friend so for lunch we happened to be in Chinatown...again. Stood in line for maybe 15 minutes and got 2 more. Whenever I'm with my boyfriend, we're fatties, but it's just amazingly good. Orgasm in your mouth good. 

Remember to ask for the nice fresh ones because they may give you the older ones if you don't ask.
author: Nina Y.

description:
So I am walking down Grant Street the other day and I couldn't believe my eyes, Golden Gate Bakery was open and there were only five people in line. Although I was not very hungry  (ugh I had just eaten) I decided to say wtf and jump in line anyway. 

In no time, I had the lady behind the counter  fill a few of those classic pink bakery boxes with goodies.

My cache - Warm egg custards(also called dan tart, dan tot, don tot, don tat, dan ta, etc.) an assortment of meat and chicken curry turnovers, and a moon cake for good luck or heavenly blessings of longevity and good health.
author: Theresa H.

description:
The last time I was in SF they were closed :( They usually have a long line out the door but its worth the wait. The egg tarts are crispy/ flaky on the outside.. very fresh. Egg tart is not my favorite but I would go here if I ever wanted to eat one because it's just that good :) 

Hope they are opened the next time you go!!
author: Elsa Y.

description: I went there three times and wanted to try the egg tart,1st time - sold out and told me to come back later. 2nd time - no more. 3rd time - no egg tart and they don't know when they will have them. I have no idea how they run their business.
author: Va D.

description:
Just come here for the egg tarts because thats is what they are known for. It is big and filled with a lot of egg custard. I heard it was cheaper before but I did not mind paying 1.25 for a delicious egg tart.

Just be careful that they tend to go on vacation randomly so they might not be open. Test your luck!
author: Pin X.

description: Since my friends and I had a change of plans and was not going to do dimsum in sf chinatown anymore, we decided to at least stop by golden gate bakery to get some egg tarts.   SO freaking fresh and warm.  It literally melts in your mouth.  I'm not an egg tart conniseur but the egg tarts here are thumbs up for me!
author: Di L.

description: I've been wanting to check this place out since forever but every time I come here they're always closed!!  They close on the weirdest days too.  I had to call ahead of time to make sure they were open before stopping by.  When I got there the line was already out the door.  My friends and I waited in line for about 40min before we were able to squeeze ourself inside and order what we wanted.  Their egg tart is delicious but still can't compare to the ones in HK!  The crust is thick and flakey and the middle part is eggy.  Best part was that the egg tarts were still hot.  I would come back again. This is probably one of the better places around the area.
author: Joyce L.

description:
We've been coming here since I was in middle school for egg tarts. Cute mom & pop bakery located on Grant St. in Chinatown. There's usually a huge line outside waiting to get the fresh egg tarts and other pastry items that they offer at this bakery. 

The egg tarts are freshly made and it's served warm. They also have soft sponge cake but my favorite is still the yummy egg tarts!

Definitely check this out if you're ever in the hood!
author: Cynthia C.

description: Why is it every time I come here it is always closed or "on vacation". Also when they put up the sign "on vacation", they should tell us when they will be coming back?  Are they closed indefinitely ?  Are they really on vacation? What's going on?  Hey need to be more consistent.
author: Alice M.

description:
I never understood why I had to stand in line for these as a kid, but now I better appreciate the silky yet thick custard filling and the flaky crust of their fresh egg tarts.  The filling doesn't pull away from the edges, and like most Chinese bakeries, they're very cheap compared to your mainstream bakeries (especially in SF).

I don't know why I used to bother with coconut tarts and chicken pies when I should have just gotten a pink box full of egg tarts.
author: Marilyn T.

description: I guess they were closed for a few months and just reopened yesterday. The line was really long and I waited 2 hours for my egg tarts. I got them right when they came out!They were hot and fresh. The crust was buttery and flakey. The yolk wasn't too sweet, it was just right! I personally thought it was too long of a wait though.
author: Winnie S.

description:
Gal pal Q drove me to the City for a conference.  I was staying at the Hilton that night, and wanted to treat her to dinner for being my taxi.  We wandered around Chinatown, not really having any plans.  Ate at Kay Cheung and found ourselves here at Golden Gate Bakery afterwards.  There was a short line that was not moving at all, but we discovered that people were waiting for the next batch of egg custards to come out of the oven.

With nothing better to do, we decided to wait, too.  Hubby's a fan of egg custards, so I bought one for him and a sponge cake for me.  Later in the evening while sitting at my desk in the hotel room, Q calls and tells me I must eat the egg custard.

"No," I tell her, "it's for hubby.  I don't really care for them myself."

"No," she tells me, "you must try it.  I haven't even driven out of the City yet and I can't believe how good these are.  You have to eat it while it's warm."

Well, alright, I will take a bite to please my sweet friend.  Wow!  This is really good.  Wow, it disappeared like magic; nothing left for hubby.  The sponge cake disappeared, too, and I don't even remember what it tasted like.

Moral of the story:  always buy two of each item if you're planning to share any of the treats from Golden Gate Bakery.  (And thx2Q.)
author: Sherri C.

description:
D A N - T A T! best egg tarts ever. best egg tarts in the west coast at least. brace yourself for the long line, but its def worth the wait and the price. 

oh, and they tend to go on vacation pretty often too.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Finally got to try this place. Hopped inside the tiny bakery when there was no wait. I got a red bean moon cake for $6. Hefty price for dessert, but mooncakes are usually a little pricey. It was delicious! Lasted me a week. I put it in the fridge when I wasn't eating it and cut myself a small slice every day. I don't think mooncakes are the healthiest things... but I love them!

I also got a custard egg tart for $1.25. Decently big and it was piping hot. The lady handed it to me and told me to be careful. The custard was delicious and had the perfect sweetness. The crust was not memorable... I really just don't remember what it tasted like or the texture.

Great when there's no line.. It's kind of like any other Asian bakery, which are all pretty yummy. I don't know why people wait outside for it..
author: Nancy L.

description: My Chinatown walking tour guide highly recommended this place. Picked up an egg custard tart and a cake with a creamy filling( cannot recall the name). They were $1.50 and $2.00 respectively. I don't think it is expensive or what the going rate in this area of the city is. But I have bought cheaper pastries in NYC. But It is still worth a quick visit. Go for it!
author: Arch T.

description:
The only chinese bakery with line ropes in front for crowd control.  The line goes fast so it is worth the wait.

We had pork puff pastry, egg tart, "bolo" bread, black bean pastry, etc.

Everything was so so good.  And my wife agreed it was one of the best.
author: Addison P.

description: I don't even care that I had to wait an hour and a half for these egg tarts because they were so damn delicious. Freshly baked out of the oven, warm and still gooey in the center. This place is like a little hole in wall. The line was ridiculous but it's so worth it. Nothing lives up to these egg tarts!!
author: Nguyen T.

description:
Been coming here for a couple decades now. Yes, the egg tarts are good but if you come everyday it gets a bit boring. I found that a lot of their stuff is pretty top notch and you're not likely to get the same high quality product anywhere in the bay area. 

Fresh "Bo loh bao" pineapple bun - no it doesnt have pineapple in it. Just a sweet crust on top that reminds one of it's lumpy texture. 

"faht gok bao" Bun of France. Fluffy chewy yellow bread with sweet crust on top. Weekends only. Only the French can beat this one. 

Coconut filled bun "Gai Mei Bao". Coconut flakes and filling inside. Soft and chewy.

Those are my favorites. 

Notables: mooncakes. This is why they are really famous in certain circles of the Chinese community. Their mooncakes are made fresh on the premises. To the Chinese, that was a godsend since imports were the norm at the time - read: stale/old from Hong Kong, Taiwan or China.

Their mooncake recipe has only improved since I first had them. They now even come in half-sizes which are more manageable but just as delicious. If you like nutty get the "Mm Yun". "Bak Leen Yong Dan Wong" is Lotus Paste with Egg Yolk - that's the original and really yummy.

Beware though mooncakes are pretty heavy and fattening. Probably not vegetarian as they are rumored to use pork fat.
author: Shum S.

description: Only if they are open, their schedule is so inconsistent.   Not worth trying cause you will be disappointed  when they are not opened.
author: Rey D.

description: Despite all the reasons why you shouldn't come to this place: long line, ridiculous vacations that these people take and the place is closed for weeks in random, rude service, rude customers trying to cut in front of you, overpriced for an egg tart that normally sells for half of the price, and they won't even give u a box unless u buy a dozen -- I do admit, this is the place that makes the best damn egg tart EVER!  I can seriously say, I haven't had a better one in SF or anywhere else for that matter. So just try it once and get it over with.
author: Lilian T.

description:
I am a fan and love to stop by when I'm in the area.  However, over an hour wait for  egg tarts?? They were delicious but the line was not that long and I didn't understand what was taking so long. (I secretly think everyone was just chatting inside because they have been on vacation for soo long).  

Wait a couple of weeks for the excitement to mellow out and after the moon festival, they said they will be open for a while :) Enjoy! Oh, and they raised the prices a bit, inflation I supposed.
author: Yodlee Y.

description:
YUM. Bought a dan tat. Ate it. Bought another one. 
The crust was buttery and flaky, egg custard still warm and supple--not the gelatinous texture you get when it's been sitting out forever.
author: Nicole L.

description: Despite always being "Closed for vacation", the egg custard tarts are REALLY GOOD. I wasn't too impressed with any of their other pastries and treats but the egg custards alone are worth the trip! They do speak a little English so you shouldn't have any issues ordering.
author: Clarice C.

description: I love egg custards, and this is an amazing dan tat place! Don't come here during Chinese New Year though, unless you want to wait in a long line. But even then.. worth it!
author: Carmen T.

description: I only come here for egg custard! Line can be out the door and I always feel rushed when ordering but thankfully I only order the egg custards so its not a problem for me. I think that if I can speak Cantonese well, I would ask for recommendations and try other baked goods but since I don't, I just want to order quickly and get out of there. There's really only standing room in the bakery.
author: San H.

description:
they are delicious when fresh, and what pastry isnt delicious when theyre fresh?
plus that theyre open late too.
a must go whenever i'm in the area.
author: Anita W.

description: Very good egg tarts (dan tat), hot milk tea and moon cakes.  But they are closed this past week because they are on vacation.  They can't just leave, what about us loyal needy customers? Wahhhhhh
author: Michael L.

description: Agree on the best egg tarts ever and I've been eating them for over 10 years now! Try the hot milk tea also you won't be disappointed.
author: Mel S.

description: I have loved every type of thing I have ordered here, from the red bean cake to the mochi and the egg tarts. Everything is delicious. The ladies inside are no nonsense and work efficiently. There is almost always a line, during off hours the wait isn't too bad though. I'm glad I don't live closer or I would be here all the time...
author: Daniella O.

description:
I've been getting food here for a while, but I've never really went to the bakery personally. So one day, I was craving it and so me sis and bro took the BART to SF. Walked to Chinatown. Visited a friend. Stood in line at the bakery. And got a dozen for 13 dollars of egg tart. 

Let me tell you, THEY HAVE THE BEST EGG TART (DAN TAT) EVERRRRRRRR. THEY PUT SHAME TO ANYWHERE ELSE. TRUST ME. THE crust is so flaky with so many layers of deliciousness. The egg tart part isn't made too hard or too soft. It's just the right consistency. The flavoring of the egg tart is delicious too. You'll have to wait a little line entering the bakery, but it's SO worth it. Best Egg tarts EVERRRR!!!
They're the perect size and they're always making it so you're probably bound to get a hot toasty one. 

They sell other goods too which we buy too, but i try only eating egg tarts from here. :] bombshidigity
author: Justina L.

description:
The small store may not look very appealing but their egg tart definitely does. 

Whenever I come to Chinatown and feel like having dessert or something sweet, I'd drop by Golden Gate Bakery just for their egg tarts. After eating egg tarts from various places in the Bay Area, I gotta say this place makes the best egg tarts. 

The egg tart has the sweet and eggy flavor, a smooth jelloey texture, and the flaky crust just compliments the entire tart. You can even leave it in the fridge for days and it's still good cold or hot. The egg tart is HELLA good when it just comes out of the oven all warm and fresh. So hopefully by the time you get there, it had just came out of the oven.

A fun fact about this place is that they will close for months after the Chinese Mid-Autumn Festival since they make hella money by selling their very own moon cakes. What I mean is that they go on vacation every year after selling moon cakes. So don't expect them to be around during parts of fall and winter. 

But definitely give this place a try if you're craving dessert in Chinatown. Or if you wanna bring home some treats for the family, just order a dozen to go. ;)
author: Victor Q.

description:
*drool*

I don't even like egg tarts...probably because I had never had a good one. **Enter Golden Gate Bakery** The egg tarts here make me soo happy. They make so many every day that they're almost always warm when you get them! They're well worth the wait on a warm Saturday afternoon. 

You'll recognize the place by the line out the door. The bakery itself is big I'd assume (the Chinese ladies helping customers bark over walkie talkies when they need more of something!), but the customer area is tiiiiny, making it difficult to see all the goodies they have in the display. They can fit maybe 5 customers in there at a time, hence the long line out the door. They typically have 4 or 5 Chinese ladies asking 'What you want?' or the equivalent in Chinese. Be ready with your order and your cash! Buy 8 or more things, it'll come in one of those pink bakery boxes; any less will go in a bag. If in a bag, they're even careful to separate your egg tarts with a folder paper plate. No need really, I'll eat it all before I fight my way out the door.
author: Christine L.

description:
So.. there's definitely a difference between WANTING to like something and actually liking something. I really wanted to like the egg tart from Golden Gate Bakery.

I stood in line for about 10 minutes, behind people who ordered in Cantonese (good sign). This tells me this place is popular, and it's popular with the right people. Also the SMELLS are heavenly. Who doesn't like the smell of baked goods?

The place is cramped, practically bursting at the seams with baking supplies (probably bought in bulk because it's a better value.. you know how us Asians are), but in a cute charming way. The older ladies manning the counter only add to this charm.

When I got my egg tart, it came straight out of the warmer/oven/thing and was warm and fragrant. As soon as I was outside the shop, I snapped a quick picture and bit in.

And I didn't like it as much as I wanted to. Previous reviews have called the tarts greasy. Yep, definitely greasy. It's also not a well-executed custard, technically.
