The top of the custard filling was smooth and creamy, but the bottom was cooked at too high a temperature and the egg curdled, which gives it that very strong egg-y taste. Or maybe it was cooked perfectly but got too hot in the warming oven, so it curdled there. Either way, it was overcooked and didn't taste right as a result.

I was really sad because I so wanted to like these egg tarts, but alas, it wasn't meant to be.

But, it is somewhat of a landmark so still worth a trip. Just get a different pastry, they have plenty of choose from.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
The egg tarts are definitely worth the wait in line to get while piping hot. I don't even leave the store before stuffing my face with two and burning the roof of my mouth. The  custard is creamy and slightly sweet, contained in the perfect flaky pastry shell.

Tip: You need to order a dozen, seriously, these egg tarts disappear!
author: EurJean C.

description: A buttery, flaky crust that holds molten, golden, eggy goodness inside all come together harmoniously to make the best dan ta I've ever had. I've never waited more than 10 or 20 minutes in line, and I always, always leave happy with a warm dan ta (or 2 or 3 or 23913, don't judge me) in my hands. There's nothing quite like eating a warm dan ta on a chilly day in San Francisco while walking up those goddamn hills. It's like doing cardio while eating a stick of butter at the same time. Bliss.
author: Andrew C.

description: I usually don't like egg tarts but after the first bite, I was like "whoa!" It's so good that I drove from sj to sf, waited in line for an hour and then drove back to sj. The line sucks but hey, i'm a hungry hippo so I will wait =)
author: Tammy V.

description: My friends have raved a lot about the egg tarts from Golden Gate Bakery, and now I know why. The egg tarts are SO GOOD. Super comparable to those I have eaten at authentic Chinese restaurants and bakeries in Asia. I especially like how the puff pastry is not too thick, flaky, and not overwhelmingly pastry margarine tasting. The filling was really good too, sweet, eggy and wobbly. It comes out warm, but even if you take it back and warm it up in the oven, it still tastes good!
author: Olivia P.

description:
Golden Gate bakery, my waistline hates you. Yes, you and your egg tarts!  I've had lots of good egg tarts before, but this place really stands out because not only are they delicious, but they are HUGE. They also seem really fresh, it's always warm when you eat it right outside the store. But not to worry if you're traveling, they taste good the next day too. I haven't tried the other items here but friends have said they were not as great.

The only down side is their customer service. The second time I went with non Cantonese-speaking people and we were ignored for a really long time, they even served 4-5 parties that came in line after us. waah.

I've been here twice and really both times I went there was not a bad line (including Sunday afternoon after-bunch time).
author: Sabrina T.

description: Their egg tarts are a life-changing experience: flaky on the outside, gooey on the inside, and warm from just having been taken out of the oven.  I tried other things in the bakery, like their pineapple bun and honey cake, which were good but not as outstanding as the egg tart, but the egg tart alone warrants 5 stars!  Prices are very reasonable; I bought all three pastries for a little over $3.
author: T T.

description: As like many others who have rated the Golden Gate Bakery, the egg tarts are what you come here for. They are light, fluffy filling, with a flaky crust. Every time I come to San Francisco my girlfriend and I come and get a dozen. They are best when the come out fresh from the oven and worth the wait. The line can get long, especially during the summer time. The longest I have waited was an hour. Usually the wait was no more than 20 minutes.
author: Raul B.

description:
I'm originally from LA (keep your snide remarks to yourself) and was here for NYE. I'd heard SF had some of the BEST food around so I relied on my yelpers to show me the way. And show me the way you did!!!! 

Came here solely for the egg custard and it was phenomenal! I'd read all the reviews and was prepared for what was to come, but my goodness... It was mind blowing! I don't feel I need to say more because it's already been said.

If you're in Frisco, make sure you make a stop here. The wait can be long, but trust me totally worth it. Also some advice, make sure you eat the custard while it's still warm. It's good warm or cold but you really have to taste it while it's still steaming. And don't just buy one, you want to make sure you buy at least 2-3 per person. If you get more trust me no one will judge you. Yeah, they're that good!

I would advise walking since it is Chinatown and parking may be a bit of an inconvenience. Luckily our hotel was within walking distance so this wasn't a problem.
author: Keesy S.

description: On vacation...again??!  :(
author: Kim S.

description: Great little tarts, yes, but the peanut/coconut mochi - wow! WOW!!
author: Carolyn F.

description:
I was waiting for my alterations to be ready at Yee Hing Clothing Store so I thought I'd kill some time by waiting in line here for the famous egg tarts.  I wasn't even sure if they had any left since it was 4 p.m., but I figured I had time, for once, so why not wait and see or order something else?  

Thankfully, the wait was only about 10 minutes and they did have egg tarts.  Warm, buttery-crusted, sweet-but-not-too-sweet egg tarts.  The ratio of custard to crust was perfect, as someone who prefers the custard to the crust.

A bite of heaven.
author: B. Y.

description:
While many egg custard tarts are made with shortcrust pastry, the ones you'll find here are made with puff pastry (layers of thin pastry) and this fact makes all the difference. The resulting product is an unbelievably flaky tart. Try one and you'll understand why scores of folks in Chinatown are willing to line up for the opportunity to buy pink box upon pink box of them as they come out of the oven. 

One bite and I knew that my search for the perfect egg custard tart was over.
author: Miriam W.

description:
I'm not surprised at all the 5 star reviews. I've lived in SF for over a decade and this is the go to bakery in Chinatown... Nice savory handheld pies like bbq pork and curry beef wrapped in the classic chinese pastry dough with a good egg wash. 

But, listen here, it's all about the ALMOND COOKIES. These are not your run of the mill almond cookies that are too crumbly with their yellow dough and a stale almond pressed into the center. GGB's almond cookies have more class: a nicely sized three bite cookie with just enough almond flavor, a good clean tasting dough that hold together well with a nice balance of crunch and slight chewiness, plus a sweet sprinkle of toasted almonds. 

I bought a pack of them and my first bite reminded me of what almond cookies are supposed to taste like... Go down and get a bunch of stuff in the old school pink bakery boxes with red string!
author: E L.

description: I have heard so much good things about their egg tarts so I wanted to check this place out. My friend advise me to call before I stop by the place because a lots of times the owner will close the place and go on vacation. I made two attempts to stop by this place when I was in the area but before I stop by the place, I made a quick phone call to make sure that they are open. Luckily I called the place, because both times they were on vacation. It was nice of them to pick up their phone to let me know that they were on vacation though. I appreciate that because I would have been so mad driving there and leaving with no egg tarts. Hopefully I will have better luck next time.
author: Linda N.

description: I waited an hour in line for these egg custard & I must say they're the best egg custard I've had in my life!
author: Catheryne H.

description: OMG THIS PLACE HAS THE BEST EGG TART EVER! I have never tried a better egg tart then theirs. Too bad they on vacation now though. I want some of their egg tarts now! This place gets really crowded during the autumn moon festival week.
author: Christopher G.

description: Great Dan Tat at a reasonable price.  Beware of long lines. A couple times I've visited the store, there was a sign on the door stating that the owners would be on vacation.
author: Kristin C.

description: Hands down, the best Egg Custard Tart I have ever eaten! It's so good that if someone told me they have had better, I would call their bluff. Thus far, since I have been back to So. Cal I have not eaten one, because I know it will not be as good.
author: Gaddi Father G.

description:
$1.10 for ONE egg custard tart, $13 for a dozen.

JUST EFFING BUY A DOZEN.

You can give me a "Thank You" comp later. ;]
author: Susy C.

description: 5 stars for their custard tarts. We also tried their sesame ball, cream cake and sweet rice cake. Those are good but nothing special.
author: T Y.

description:
I was recommended to try this place out for their egg custard tarts. I figured, "why not?" and decided to make the trip over there to check it out. Turns out, this bakery had been closed for vacation for a while, and today was the first day they were opening! This was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for me, as I am from Boston, leaving to go home tomorrow, and I happened to show up at the bakery 15 minutes before they were planning to reopen. It was fate! After reading Yelp reviews, we came to find out that a long line is typical of this bakery, so we thought, "no big deal". We ended up waiting TWO HOURS until we got to put in our order for the egg custard tarts. People were buying DOZENS of these egg custard tarts! The system they had for taking orders was a little slow and weird. They didn't let anyone in the actual storefront; the lady would come out and take a few orders at a time. It took about 10-15 minutes to fulfill each order, the customers would pay, and then she'd move on to the next one. The lady running this whole show was super friendly and nice, but she is definitely not someone you want to mess with. After our super long wait, I finally tried the long-awaited egg custard tart.....

It was the BEST I've EVER had in my entire life. It's melt-in-your-mouth, creamy, flaky goodness.

I would wait nearly any amount of time to have more of these. I would recommend this to absolutely anybody who happens to be in the SF Chinatown area.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Egg custards are no joke. They are big, filling, and served hot/fresh. $1.15 for one - not exactly cheap but well worth it. A bunch of Chinese ladies work here but don't be intimidated if you don't speak the language...you can usually get away with pointing and saying the # of custards you want :)

CASH ONLY.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
The moments after I ordered the dan tat, I re-lived my short trip to Hong Kong this past summer. I've never had the chance to appreciate Asian desserts, so HK opened my eyes to a whole new spectrum! 

Thankfully I grabbed more than a few pastries from GGB and devoured them all too quickly.The anticipation was too great so I ripped open the bag and dripped custard all over the sidewalk in my attempt to multitask.  There's usually a line at this place, so be prepared to wait at least 15 minutes. The sesame balls here are also delicious (when they come right out of the oven)!
author: Tory L.

description:
This bakery is not at all what I expected. It's run by 4 Chinese women who practically ignore you if you don't speak Chinese. The interior is a mess. It looks more like a storage unit than a place that should be allowed to serve food. 

Once all the other customers had gone and they had no choice but to serve us, my boyfriend and I each got an egg tart because they came to highly recommended. For $1.80, I thought it was very reasonable. The egg tarts were kind of disgusting. The crust was flakey, but too thin. The filling was gooey and it tasted like sweetened, undercooked scrambled eggs.
author: Dar E.

description: Wow, really the best egg tart, EVER!!!  I dunno if I'd wait an hour for them, I got lucky and there was no one in line when I got there, in and out in 2 minutes.  I was there on a Monday afternoon, around 1pm.  Can't wait to go back!
author: N. Danny S.

description:
DELICIOUS egg tarts! One of the best egg tarts, I've tried. It's best when its fresh out of the oven. I walked 10 blocks just to try it and it was worth it. It's a VERY small bakery with two ladies in the front. I came at a non-busy time, so they were very friendly and attentive to me. However, I can see that if it was really crowded they could be a bit mean and rush you. 

I also got a moon cake, but it's not worth $5 a piece. Just stick to what they're good at, which is the egg tarts and maybe a few other tarts or chicken pot pies. 

If you're a tourist, YOU NEED TO TRY what the locals are eating. If you're going to visit Chinatown, then visit this shop. Best price is to get a dozen for $15. I think it's worth it to share with friends and family as well. CASH ONLY.
author: Joanne T.

description:
everyone talks of golden gate bakery's egg tarts and though i'm not a fan of tarts, it's one of the places you have to stop by in SF. there's always a long line or they also close down for a short period every year to travel -- so i haven't had a chance to try the egg tarts...until now.

hot damn, i always wondered how they kept/brought back business after being closed for weeks but now i get it. having eaten their egg tarts, i freakin' get it. they could close down for years and people would still line up/walk by in hopes of catching a mere whiff of the golden, flaky, rich, eggy tart. 

i tried several egg tarts all over the city before deciding i don't like egg tarts. and i will stand by the statement but with one amendment: unless it's from golden bakery.

$1.75 for one or $16. 20 (ish) for a dozen. go early so they're fresh, warm, and in hopes of avoiding a line.
author: Melissa N.

description:
The line is atrocious, not only because it's obscenely long wait for baked goods but also because people invariably cut since it's so confusing: as you can't form a continuous line (it would block foot traffic) the line cuts open so there are so many openings and it confuses everybody. And then you stand there absolutely irritated that you've been waiting 6 people longer than you should have. Not a fun wait at all.

We got the bbq pork buns and dan tat (duh!). I would say that my dan tat craving is satisfied after like two at most (though they're the best around town/the bay!) The pork buns make a good breakfast on the go too.
author: Alice W.

description:
Custard tart

if you love Custard tart this is a place to stop and get the best. The custard was warm and just melted in my mouth delish. I just say....just go and you know why this place is worth the $$ and wait

CAN'T EAT JUST ONE....
author: linda t.

description:
omg. heavenly, heavenly egg tarts. 

i'm from the east coast & the egg tarts here are better than any I've had in NJ/NY. you have to eat the tarts there on the spot in order to taste the warmth, sweetness, and perfection of the shell. 

there's always a line so be prepared to wait. it will be worth your time!
author: Bonnie C.

description:
This is the only place I will eat egg tarts at.

The crust is flaky and the custard isn't too sweet.  
This is a must try if you are in san francisco.

It may be a bit pricey, but it is worth it.

best egg tarts!
(other bake goods are just as yummy! piping hot and fresh!)
author: Steph Q.

description:
Dangit. 

Boo to four unsuccessful visits in the last 2 months. Why are you STILL ON VACATION???? 

Sigh. I give up.
author: Joy A.

description:
Sadly they ran out of Egg Tarts when I stopped by around 8p. It was my first time I ventured to try something else.

I got EC a coconut tart (about $1.29), which he devoured. Lots of nice coconutty shreds, and tasty chew with the crust. Pretty dense tart.

I tried the Coconut Custard Sponge Cake ($1.29 or so). This was pretty darn good. I had never had it before. On the counter it looks like a big powder puff - 4" in diameter, 2" thick, a dusting of white coconut shreds on the top and sides. And then you bite down, finding very light texture and layers since the sponge cake was rolled. In the center is a custard cream. Yum.

While it doesn't make up for the lost egg tarts, the experience opened my eyes to the fact that GGBakery could possibly offer something more than just egg tarts.
author: Cindy W.

description: Egg tarts are the bomb.  4star because I have to wait in line for 45 minutes to get these.  On top of that for another 10 minutes to get my egg tarts from the oven.
author: Michael N.

description:
While my brother was visiting me here in SF, I decided the best tour I know how to give him was a foodie tour!  After grabbing some dim sum at Great Eastern (my go-to dim sum place in Chinatown), I decided to go check if the famous Golden Gate Bakery was open today.  As awesome as GG Bakery is, it is also infamous for being closed many days as well.  When we first got there, we thought that it was also closed that day...but turns out, they were selling their famous egg tarts through the closed doors (weird...).  Oh well, 5 egg tarts please!

For 1.50 each, these delicious pieces of heavens are pretty pricey for egg tarts, but they are still worth it imo (especially compared to American treats out there like $4 cupcakes...).  Love the flaky tarts, the hot-out-of-the-oven freshness, and the creamy sweet custard!
author: Alex T.

description: Egg tarts here are great as everyone says.  I've been here a couple times and once it's been closed around Mother's Day...it happens.  My sister loves this place and we both love egg tarts.  When there's a long line out the door you know it's good.  So fresh we got it right out of the oven.
author: Kim D.

description:
NOMs!!! A place that lives up to its hype is really rare, but THIS PLACE LIVES UP TO IT! Golden Gate Bakery! The line outside may be long, but the wait is about 20 minutes. They have around five people inside quickly getting people in and other. This place is small so it's all for to go. There's no place to eat inside.

The egg tarts are NOM NOM NOM good. BEST EGG TART EVER! It tastes more eggy than your average egg tart and the tart is a lot more flaky. This is definitely a winning combination!

Currently as of today it is $1.25 per egg tart.

They sell other things here besides egg tarts. There's all the commonly found Chinese pastries here such as moon cakes.
author: Steven B.

description: The sesame balls with red bean are bomb.com ! Huge, warm ball of yummy goodness .. Wish I bought more for the flight home.
author: ANGELIQUE V.

description: Their egg tarts are to die for! Good price for such an egg tart with great quality and size! I always buy AT LEAST a dozen! All my relatives love eating them and i do too! The ladies who work there are really nice too! As a tip, dont go there during chinatown event unless you wanna wait for at least an hour! Their other goodies are just as yummy! That one sticky rice ball with red bean filling is really good too! Everything is good! XD
author: Quincy M.

description: The coconut macaroons are heavenly.  Moist and not overly sweet.  Perfect.  The coconut tart is also wonderful.  I'm not an egg tart fan but everyone I know that is addicted to them comes to Golden Gate for their fix.
author: Donna P.

description:
I think the last time I came here we waited 30 - 40 minutes in line. I love me some dan tat back in the day at the ripe old age of 8 I considered myself a connoisseur of egg tarts. This place is pretty top notch.

I saw people skipping the line &  walking in like they owned the place. Ima have to try that trick next time.
author: Shirley T.

description:
it can be a long wait but the BEST egg tart in SF. even if the egg tarts are sold out, the other pastries are just as good. Once you arrive INSIDE Golden Gate Bakery, try to be somewhat agressive when ordering because it can get hectic. 

YUM!
author: Carol Y.

description:
This place DEFINITELY meets all the hype and good reviews.  Many times I'm skeptical of such popular places because they end up feeling overrated, but not the egg tarts here!!  WOW!  They're really warm right after you purchase them and melt in your mouth....amazing.  I think these are the most memorable egg tarts I've ever had.   I tried another pastry item - not sure what it was called - that was also quite good.

There's a long line that snakes around the entrance, but it actually moved quickly on a busy Saturday afternoon, as we only ended up waiting 15 - 20 minutes.  So don't let the long line discourage you!  The servers move rather quickly once you're inside.  Definitely worth the wait and next time I go, I'm stocking up!!
author: Tiff K.

description: This place was always a usual stop during my visits to SF when I was a kid. I was one of the kids that never liked the egg tarts...rather the middle part but I loved the crust. It's flaky and buttery. One of my favorite here is the coconut cookie...actually I think it's a coconut ball. It's their version of a macaroon.
author: Eve C.

description:
So I kind of just want to jump on the 5-star bandwagon since everyone pretty much gives this place 5-stars. But I grew up here so this is a review from a local...

OK...the Egg Tarts...I do admit, are 5-stars. I grew up in San Francisco's Chinatown and I've eaten probably 10001 different types of egg tarts from SF's Chinatown to China, but this is pretty much on the top of the list (except for those Portuguese Egg Tarts in Macau). 

But the line? The 1-hour line? I just can't do it. I'm a local and I can come here any time I want but when I see a 1-hour line...it's just not worth it for me. I only come here when people come to visit and so I bring them here...to wait in line. But it's not all that bad, you can make some friends and talk to different tourists while in that line. 

But when you reach the front, you better not be ordering just one or two egg tarts...you better be ordering like a dozen or so, or else the Lady will yell the crazy out of you (but yeah it'd be stupid if you waited in line for an hour just for a few egg tarts). But i was with a friend and she only wanted to try it so we waited in line just for that one egg tart. 

1 star for that Lady but 5 stars for the Egg Tarts.
author: David W.

description:
Epic fail on my part - I tried to bring their legendary egg tarts on the plane and only to find them smushed by the time I got past security :( I still ate them anyway and they still tasted amazing. The crust was very light and crispy, although in my case, a bit soggy because I smushed them. The inside part was delightfully sweet in a refreshing way, unlike some other egg tarts I've had that were just too heavy and overly sweet. 

I don't think this place has set store hours though since it's a family-run shop. I've stopped by at times where owners put up a sign that says "Away" without a return time. But people still line up for their egg tarts like they are the hottest things in town.

Note to self: never try to bring the egg tarts on the plane again, they are, in fact, quite fragile and smushable.
author: Melody L.

description: Amazing egg tarts! Reminds me of the ones from Hong Kong!
author: Yvonne F.

description:
I made the ever-so-smart decision of stopping in to give their famed egg custard tarts a try a few days before the lunar new year... womp womppp.

An hour wait and six egg tarts in hand later, all I can say is... H Y P E.

For $1.10 a piece (about 20-50 cents more than other bakeries), don't expect your extra money to go toward quality. In the case of Golden Gate Bakery, you get what you pay for... literally. They're about 150% bigger than the usual, but bigger sure ain't always better.

The crust has the characteristic flakiness of egg custard tarts and does its job of supporting the filling, but doesn't stand out otherwise.

The filling, which separates the average from the spectacular, is silky smooth but lacks the creaminess I typically enjoy. Worse, the vanilla overpowers the egginess, which is quite the feat given an egg's strength (of flavor). 

After sharing one with the bf, I was sick to my stomach of GGB. If the greatest reason for liking their ECTs is because they're fresh and warm, that's a damn piss poor reason!!! There are other bakeries a stone's throw away in Chinatown that'll give you warm,delicious tarts (and some change back in your pocket!).

Force me to withstand an hour's wait for subpar tarts, shame on you!

Allow myself to spend another dime on subpar tarts -- wait or no wait --, shame on me!!! Thanks but NO THANKS, GGB!
author: Pauline D.

description: I've never had egg custard and so I have no form of comparison... However I imagine that this is what good egg custard is.  Flaky and not too sweet.  With that said I haven't suddenly become addicted to egg custard and I couldn't tell you the next time I will seek it out.  Btw not a fan of moon pies but that has nothing to do with the establishment sweet beans that taste almost fig like is just a bit odd.
author: Uni T.

description: Probably the best egg tarts in San Francisco. So why the 4 out of 5 stars...well, it's not as good as the ones I get in Hong Kong. Hee hee. I would highly recommend dropping by to get some if you're in Chinatown. Luckily, I never had to wait longer than 10 minutes to get the egg tarts from here.
author: Kai C.

description:
Place is a little over rated.

The egg tarts are good, but for $1.25 a piece...that's a little pricey for me!

Other bakeries such as ones in Oakland Chinatown sells them for 0.50 cents a piece!

Lines were out the door during Christmas day, we were lucky enough to have our hands on a fresh piping hot batch.
author: michelle h.

description:
Grossly overrated. 7X7 reviews failed here.

Anyone that says that the egg tarts here are amazing have yet to try a good egg tart. The crust was good but the filling was very eggy and tasted more like a sweetened egg than the egg custard it's supposed to be.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
Forget about their dan tat (which are admittedly, awesome), because it's really all about their curry puffs.  

They have chicken, beef, and bbq pork, each filling embedded into the flakiest, tastiest pastry dough and then baked to a golden perfection.  You'll likely make a mess trying to eat it, but it'll be a small price to pay.

The mochi-like banana pancakes are good too.
author: Joanne G.

description: The custard egg tarts are amazing, but the wait is long. If you are lucky, the line moves fast (Depends on how many dozens of custard egg tarts the customers in front of you got. Sometimes you'll have to wait for the next sheets of custard egg tart to be made.) Call ahead and make sure they are open.
author: Polly P.

description: Just the luck of the draw that every other time I attempt to come here I either arrive on a monday or they just so happen to be on random vacations here and there.  Because their egg tarts are seriously one of a kind, I have to forgive them for taking these surprise vacations.  They are slightly overpriced but you do get what you pay for in delicious egginess held within a flaky hot crust.
author: Dee L.

description:
I don't eat egg custard tarts...unless it's from Golden Gate Bakery. I won't eat it anywhere else.

Prices went up. It's no longer $1. I think it's $1.10 now?

There's always a line but it's worth the wait.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
-yes, do expect a wait. it's not that bad btw
-they're $1.40 each now
-amazing when cold, lukewarm BUT 1000X BETTER WHEN WARMED UP
-CASH ONLY
-when i brought the box home, ALL my relatives were impressed because THEY even know how delicious the dan tat is AND how annoying it is that they're barely ever open.... do yourselves all a favor and join this page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Is-the-Golden-Gate-Bakery-Open-Today/394882013908745
author: Priscilla W.

description:
I try to go at least twice a month.  I love this place.  I have never experienced excessive rudeness.  And I work close by, so if the line is prohibitively long, I know that I can always come back another day.

True, it is sad to want for delicious Chinese baked goods, and leave without.  But I do.  And no other bakery will scratch the itch.  Here is why:

Egg Custards.
I have these so often now, I have a point scale.  Occasionally my egg custard is a 10.  Generally it's between an 8 and a 9.  On bad days, it will be a 6 or a 7.  Every other egg custard I have had from other bakeries tops off at a 4.

When they are at the top of their games the custards are,
HOT - straight out of the oven, into my mouth, scalding as I eat the first one on the sidewalk
FLAKY - with an outer crust that bursts into a million pieces as you take the first bite (there is no way to share one of these)
CRISPY - a bottom crust that is burnished, and provides structure for the tart, and some resistance for the teeth
UNBROKEN - cooked to the point of just setting, before the egg-protein bonds become too tight and scramble the custard inside (which is almost impossible to do without a water bath)

Even when they are not hot, they are at worst warm.  And I love how they are less sweet than their counterparts at other bakeries.  Plus, the custard has a nice natural eggy color, and is not shockingly yellow, which is appealing.


But egg custards is just one of the many delicious sweet and savory treats you can experience at golden gate.

My other favorites:
Pineapple Bun: So soft.  So warm.  So comforting.  With a crunchy top.  Just had one today.
Cocktail Bun: Rich and sweet.  With filling and icing.  And warm.  And soft.
Macaroons: So crispy.  Amazingly crispy.  Did you fry these? They are so good.  
Coconut Tart: Like the egg tart, but with a mound of rich chewy coconut.  Think of it like a cookie in a pie shell.
Baked Pork Buns: Tender, non-grizzly pork, in a salty 5-spice sauce, surrounded by rich sweet dough.  Melts in the mouth.  And it's meat.
Those Sponge Cake Cupcakes: but only if they are hot.  But if they are hot... watch-out.  Kind of like a popover, but lightly sweet.

There are more.  But part of the fun is in the discovery.  

So go early, skip the line, and consider it a late breakfast.  OR eat dessert before lunch.  Now that we are grown ups, we can do that sort of thing.
author: Daniel B.

description: This place is recommended by my local friends. Best egg tart I've had so far! Crust is flaky and custard is just melt in your mouth. A dozen for about $17, not bad at all
author: Thanh N.

description: BEST EGG TARTS I'VE EVER HAD!!!! SO delicious and creamy!! Everyone always get a box  which is why they take so long but don't hesitate when you see their long line because they are seriously worth it =3
author: Mimi H.

description: Get the egg tarts when they are fresh out the oven, usually there is a long line just to get one, be careful of rude Chinese people who cut in line, after a long line I had a lady with a kid just walk into the store without queuing and just cut in line and order. I was expecting the sales clerk to say something but she just took her order. Not happy about that -1
author: Harold W.

description:
Though I heard that they use "pig oil" (translated from Chinese) in their egg tarts, I still love to eat them!! They have the best Egg tarts in the Bay Area. 

minus one star for crappy customer service. They have so much business, who cares about service, right?

Minus another star for short changing me by 9 cents today! She gave me a penny back instead of a dime! I wonder if they do this to every customer, since it's so busy and us customers just wants to gtfo and enjoy our tarts. Just unfair if they follow such business practices.
author: C L.

description:
We were in the Chinatown during the weekend and were just strolling by and saw this huge line outside and were wondering whats it all about. We looked for it on Yelp ofcourse and found the great reviews. And since we were looking to eat somethinfg not super sweet we decided to join the queue.
We ordered:
1. The. Egg tart ofcourse
2. The coconut tart - i will definitely go back for this over and over again
3. Macaroons

I wasnt a huge fan of the egg tart only because it was too eggy for my taste but my husband liked it and generally he's the fussy one when it comes to food.
But both of us freaked out on the cocount tart and regret not getting more since we dont stay in the city :(
I will surely go back for the coconut tart!!!
author: Natasha B.

description: Warm, fluffy egg tarts. The ladies behind the counter were nice and courteous. The egg tart is definitely one of the best I've ever had.
author: Winnie W.

description: This place is good but they are closed for vacation. :( I called and found out they will reopen on September 8, 2012. If you're reading this review before 9/8/12, do not go!!!
author: Laura L.

description: Was just walking through Chinatown looking for a bakery and saw a long line for this one. It had to be good with such a long line. I got a little of everything to try but it's true what everyone says, their egg custard tarts are amazing!! Especially when they're still warm from the oven. The sesame balls are huge and has enough bean filling inside too. Definitely coming back here to get some tarts though! Don't forget your cash, they don't accept cards.
author: Christine H.

description: Always full yet worthed of line, get the mooncake and egg tart for sure.
author: Bryan T.

description:
I was always fortunate to come home to wonderful egg tarts.. but I never knew where they came from. I asked my mom if she's ever been to "Golden Gate Bakery" but she only really speaks Chinese, so she didn't know. One day I decided to follow my fellow yelpers and check this place out.. turns out.. I've been eating egg tarts from here for YEARS.

I must say, hands down the best. Word of advice, after trying out their version of a egg tart.. all others fall in comparison. Frankly now, I don't eat any other versions.

The store also sells other great baked goods, ranging from moist cakes, macaroons, and even cookies. Everything I've tried there has been fantastic, so if you like variety like me this place is for you.

Some workers speak Mandarin, Cantonese, English, or even all three.
author: Austin N.

description:
**CASH ONLY**

AHHH!! I know I'm going against the consensus on this one...I couldn't give it a 4+ because Im not a big enough fan to drive and stand in line again.  The egg tarts were good but not my very favorite everything else I tried, I wouldn't get again.

Items I tried:
1. Egg tarts (of course)  $15/dz or $1.25 ea
2. Asian chocolate cake roll
3. Chicken pie
4. Asian rice krispy looking things --you can find them in 99 Ranch markets, packaged and some have raisins in them.

The egg tarts were good, and the other thousand reviews were right about the very flaky and crispy crust.  It is much larger than the egg tarts you'd find at Dim Sum restaurants and the custard here is way better.  Though that doesn't say too much because egg tarts at restaurants are not usually good.... the Golden Gate's custard is too soft for me...almost like the consistency of very soft tofu.

I personally love a shortbread crust but I can also appreciate Golden Gate's ability to make a great flaky crust.  If you were to hand me an egg tart from JJ Bakery and one from Golden Gate...I'd pick JJ's every time.  I'd come here again to get these egg tarts for other people because they are good, just not for me.

The chocolate cake roll and chicken pie were good but I've had better at other Asian bakeries.  This is the first time I've seen those Asian rice krispies sold fresh!  I do not like raisin and they made ones without them :D  These were chewier, sticker, and oilier  than the packaged ones I've had.  I'm glad I tired it fresh but its too oily for me :/

PARKING: Street and good luck finding one OR a structure somewhere

STORE: Literally just enough space for about 6 people in line.  A glass display counter and the register.
author: Sunny W.

description:
This place is known to have a line out the door but we got lucky! We went on a Sunday after 6pm and we were one of the few customers there. We got our desserts quickly and left happy! 

We ordered a dozen egg tarts for $15. Their egg tarts are about palm size and the fillings were still hot when we got them. We also got other miscellaneous desserts that were still good even after a few days. Definitely very quality Chinese dessert!
author: Helen C.

description:
Everything they say is true: their dat tat/egg custard tarts are the best. They are served to you warm which just makes them so, sooo good so you better eat it up right away! 

The line is always out of the door and be prepared to be pushed/shoved by an auntie/uncle.
author: Stella C.

description: Best egg tarts that I've ever had in the US!! I love this place, and I always try to come out here when I'm in SF, even if I'm on the other side of the city, because it's just that good.  I always get one to eat right in the store, and get another dozen to bring home.  They're amazing when they're still warm, but still very good after they cool down.  The egg custard part is very light and not too sweet.  For me, they have the perfect custard to tart ratio, where there is a ton of custard in a thin flaky tart crust.  I hate places that have really thick shortbread type of crust with a little bit of custard.  The downside is that parking is horrible in the area, and the bakery will close randomly. They must have really good business, because I've had a few times when I get there and they're closed.  Now I always call before I head over to make sure they're open.
author: Jenny H.

description: Mmm....... Almost everyone I know living in the Bay Area know of this golden gate bakery and their egg tart and often say how awesome their egg tarts are. But to me....... Over the years it's quality is going down. The biscuit portion is supposed to be between soft and crispy but over the years it's getting softer and softer.... To a point that the egg almost float out (okay a bit exaggeration here but you get what I mean) and the egg, yea it's hot it has a strong egg smell but it is a bit on the watery side. Is it their signature way to make egg tart? I'm not sure, it's just way too soft. Yet the lines are getting longer and longer over the years, which I don't feel it is justified. And sometimes you crave for it you go there and the shop is closed..... I'm quite sure the owner has really earned enough that they don't have to open their shop everyday even on the weekend, but this kind of disappointment plus the downgrading quality just does not attract me to come anymore.... Sad about this but that's the truth.
author: Simon C.

description:
GGB egg tart.

warm and wobbly, sweet and smooth, flaky and all in all, phenomenal.

do not, and cannot, stop at just 3.

it hails GGB egg tarts in god's pastry kitchen. no lie, bro.
author: Eliza D.

description:
Two words: EGG TART. or the proper chinese way DAN TAT. 

Best egg tart I have found in the city. TRUST. There's a reason why they're $1.15 each. Everytime I come back home to the city, I always try to make a trip to GGB to satisfy my egg tart craving. I can bet every person who has visited this bakery has tried one of these golden delights. And if they didn't, SOMETHING must have went wrong. 

And the other baked goods are delicious too! Buy a whole box and you can put whatever you want inside. Just remember to add those egg tarts in the end!
author: Amy X.

description:
Had to see for myself what all the fuss about this bakery in Chinatown was all about... and yes, it is worthy of the hype!

Typically there's a long line out the door from this place. Was walking by and shockingly there wasn't a line at the moment I walked by. Had to try these supposedly magical egg custards (dan taats) and they were FANTASTIC.... each egg custard was a buttery and thick crisp crust containing the silkiest and most flavorful Chinese egg custard... it was freshly baked and still warm - wow!!   I've had tons of these before in my life and I would have to say this was one of the best I've had.  

Bottom line: Little Chinese egg custards from heaven. But warning - these do taste really fattening and buttery, so not for the calorie timid.
author: Jim C.

description: I always make sure I stop by this bakery for some of their famous dan tat before heading back to southern Cali. I'm never disappointed. I just love the flaky crust and the warm egg filling. So light and delicious!! It's worth waiting in line for.
author: Hailey V.

description:
I've only been here once, and got the chocolate chip cookies as well to be novel. From that standpoint, it was alright.

But the egg tarts here... these pretty much beat out any egg tart I've ever had. That's quite a feat, and for that I salute this place with 5-stars.
author: Don W.

description:
I'm always happy when I see a big pink box.  (Wait, that didn't come out right).  

I mean I like it when I see one of Golden Gate Bakery's distinctive big pink bakery boxes tied up with pink ribbon because that can mean only one thing.

EGG CUSTARD TARTS.  

Believe the hype people.  These babies will make your eyes roll back into your head and have you coming back for more!
author: Amy C.

description:
What to add that 1200+ others haven't already said? I'll just chime in that, sure, you might happen upon the occasional bakery that might be as good, possibly better, but seriously, so few and far between! These guys have perfected the ratio of crust to filling, which most places get wrong (including many of the nearby bakeries with no wait). The crust itself, buttery tender and flaky with a hint of crisp. The filling, silky richness that's not too sweet or overpowering. Complaining about $1.25 per tart? I've seen places charge $2 for mediocrity!! That long queue isn't just full of tourists or me-too and "kia-su" folk jumping on a bandwagon (ask a Teochew or Singaporean to explain the concept). And don't be a fool and buy anything less than a dozen. Eat 1 or 2 (or 3) immediately, refrigerate the leftovers and pop them into a toaster oven to repeat the original amazing experience. Sigh.

Oh yeah, call before you drive down and hunt for parking if you're not local, just to make sure they're not on vacation. I did try their lotus seed mooncake too: pretty decent, solid filling, but I'm unfortunately still partial to the expensive stuff imported from Hong Kong. Must be crack mixed into that $^!#. Or peanut oil. Something...
author: Hia P.

description: Opium Laced Egg Tarts.  Wait time in line: 45 Minutes.
author: Brian P.

description:
A line outside the bakery was a good sign however i don't think the stuff is so great in the area with such a HUGE chinese community.

The egg tart (i can't remember how many i have had since i was a kid) was good, warm and flakey. However the egg custard isn't flavorful enough (i suspected not enough egg & sugar) and the pastry isn't very buttery and bit too thin. If the tart wasn't warm, you would find it tastes very average. I did have much better egg tarts in chinese dim sum restaurants in both Seattle and Vancouver, Canada.

But the price really surprised me:  I paid $7.40 for 3 full size egg tarts, 1 BBQ pastry and 1 chicken pastry.  This is really the cheapest I have ever paid. Maybe this explained the quality..
author: Sandy L.

description:
You know you've hit a sweet spot when it's 2pm on a weekday and the line is out the door and the length of the shop next door..and populated mostly by locals.

Take out only, we tried everything in this itty bitty bakery. ..and it was all delicious and fresh!   Definitely a hot spot we'd hit again..and again..and again!
author: Wendy H.

description: After waiting 30 minutes in the cold, biting a freshly baked egg tart with silky golden custard and flaky crust was the best! :)
author: Mary L.

description:
This place is probably by far the best place to buy egg tarts if you're a huge fan of egg tarts! They especially do a good job at making the egg part of the egg tart taste yummy! They cost around $12 to $13.50 for a dozen, I forgot the exact price. The bakery is not big so don't be surprised if it's kinda cramped on the inside.

It seems that every day, there's a line going in that bakery. It might look a little bit intimidating but the wait is usually about 10 - 15 minutes, which is not that bad I think. Workers there are very efficient. They usually close some time during the summer (surprisingly!) and open again right before the Moon Festival to sell moon cakes. I swear, this place is so popular they can open and close whenever they want. I've heard it happened where one day they just decided not to open their bakery. 

So, to sum it up, if you love egg tarts, it's worth it to wait in line here.
author: Selina T.

description:
Cons:

- long [never-ending] line
- interminable wait
- owners are always on vacation [3-4 weeks at a time]
- $1.15 for an egg custard tart/$13 for a dozen?

Pros:

- feathery light, flaky pastry shell
- creamily sweet, firm egg custard center
- fresh baked out of the oven, always

It's been a long, desolate year since my last Golden Gate Bakery egg custard tart. Nobody does it better, not even in Vancouver. One more reason why I love my beautiful city.
author: Lisa W.

description:
AMAZING!!

Came here around lunchtime on Xmas eve and the line wasn't long at all. The egg tarts were fresh out of the oven so they were piping hot. The custard is sweet and literally melts in your mouth, and the crust is baked to a perfect brown crisp, none of that floury pastiness that leaves your mouth dry and sandpapery. I seriously have never had such delicious egg tarts in my life.

Bonus: the lady at the counter is super sweet!! She has really great English and she made interesting conversation with us. 

I really want more egg tarts now. This always happens when I write yelp reviews...makes me want food like a fat kid even if its 1:30 in the morning.
author: Joyce H.

description: Average, I ordered the egg tart which was good but nothing exciting about it compared to others. Had mochi too and it was okay. It was my first time there and waited about 30 minutes in line. Not worth the wait to me.
author: Mai T.

description:
You know when your going to a good bakery when there is a long line. I waited in line for the egg custards. These were the best egg custards in the world. The crust was so flaky and the custard was so smooth and light. 

This place is located in Chinatown and parking is horrible.
author: Sara N.

description: Egg tarts are what you come here for, period. Long lines though because people be dumb and shit and wait for 2 hours and then ask shit loads of questions when they get up there. Like really? You didn't just have 2 hours to think about it? Nothing on the establishment just the patrons who go there. Order egg tarts, hand money to person, receive pastries and walk the fuck out!
author: Jeromy G.

description: Golden Gate bakery has really good beef curry turnovers. I recommend them over the chicken version they have. The turnovers are flaky and remind me of pate chaud, the Vietnamese flaky bun which is filled with meat or a meatball inside. The egg tarts are good and so are their small pound cakes as well. The line is definitely long but it does move fast with the women working there taking orders faster than a McDonald's.
author: Danster L.

description:
CUSTARD TARTS ARE SHEER PERFECTION

I must have been coming here for over 30 years, which is probably why I don't have a photo of me like much of the cute young yelpsters do :)  The egg custard tarts have been just as good then as now, only price is higher, of course.  At $1.25, they are steep as far as Asian custard tarts go, but a steal compared to some American bakeries, for the quality.  I have tried to cheap out, rationalizing that I could save money and pay a fraction of the price ( actually found a bakery that charged 3 for $1 a few years ago), but the experience was unsatisfying.  I'll just shell it out and do it right when I'm in SF Chinatown AND the bakery is open.

Generous amount of warm silken egg custard encased in light very flakey slightly crispy crust.  I have tried a lot of don tots and have yet to eat one finer than from Golden Gate Bakery.  Unless you are planning to eat it right away, best to order enough of them to get them to pack into a pink cardboard box.  The ladies will even cut the corners to vent the steam (turnover is so fast, the tots are often still quite warm).  And make sure the whole box doesn't turn on it's side like I've had happen when I've had a bunch of other grocery bags dangling on my arm.  Still taste ok, but nicer when they are round, not squished and oval.  At home, they warm up nicely in a regular oven, NOT microwave which will soggy up that beautiful crust.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: I was just here today waiting and waiting in line. This place has the BEST egg custard tarts and Chinese beef and chicken empanadas!!!! If you're in Chinatown you have to stop by this place and try it for yourself!
author: Tonya L.

description:
The line is worth the wait.  Make sure you get a dozen of egg custard tarts or else you will regret it.

Over the years this place has grown more and more famous and more "expensive".  Do the egg custard tarts now go for $1.20 each?  Whatever - it's worth it.

I'm a picky egg custard tart eater.  I like the custard warm and semi-gooey and the pastry bit flakey and fresh.  I CANNOT WRITE THIS REVIEW without my mouth watering.

This place is the best thing about China town.  Have I gone too far?  Doubt it.  It's probably the only thing I'm willing to go to China town (and deal with the parking, crazy driving, etc.) for.  

I think I've tried a few of their other pastires.. nothing too amazing.  Just get a dozen of egg custard tarts and you will be a happy bee.  They're great for a few days - stick 'em in the toaster oven and WALAH you've got a hearty breakfast, sort of.

Only shitty thing is that they make a ton of money off those tarts and like to take long vacations.  It's the most depressing thing when you drive all the way out there, park, walk towards the place mouth watering....... and you see a white 8x10 paper on the shut door that says "On Vacation until..blah blah" FML.

Love love loveeeee their egg custard tarts.
author: Melody T.

description:
Hands down the best egg tarts I've ever had in my life! But you already know that if you believe all the other reviews. I always end up buying about a dozen (for $13.80) when i go here but you really should eat them while they're fresh out of the oven! They get kind of "mehhh" after a day or two.

I've been here a couple times and twice they were closed on random Saturdays! Probably because they make so much money that they can take unannounced vacations whenever they want. What a life! Make sure you call them to make sure they're open if you don't have any other business in Chinatown.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Hands down, the BEST egg tarts EVERRRR. The thin, super flaky, buttery crust and the most delicious egg tart filling. These babies are ORGASMIC when they are fresh and still good after a 5+ hour drive from SF to LA. Thanks to the best sister in the world for getting me a half dozen and delivering by carrier. Slowly eating one each day [:

The only downfall is that they seem to be on vacation a lot (or at least whenever I'm in the area) and the lines are crazy ridiculously long (but so worth it).
author: Steff L.

description:
I use to come here for their dan tat by the dozen cause that's what their famous for. But after they became main stream, it totally isn't worth it.  Well, I take that back, it's worth the wait if you've never had one before, but for locals, we should know better.

I grew up eating these things at 20 cents when I was 10 and now they are well over a $1 for ONE! I mean they're good, but not that good. I can go to another bakery (AA Bakery) on Stockton for their egg tarts that are just as tasty and has a flaky crust for half the amount that golden gate charges. The only thing that separates them from other tarts? The unmistakable light, fluffy, flaky, crispy crust. And their secret in getting it that way? Pig fat oil. After learning that, I've definitely calmed down on eating their tarts.

My opinion? Over priced for what it is, but for out of towners or even non-asian people.. They would come back thinking it's worth it. Don't get me wrong, I still have a bunch of friends who come here for it and I also take friends that are out of town to come get one, but if you were a true San Franciscian, you would know that there are better places to get a good dan tat.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Iniitially, I was not really sure what the fuss was about. But when I saw how big their grease balls were here and their dan tat's, I had to agree with other yelpers, this place is pretty damn good for value and for the quality. Check it out when you have the chance. There will most likely be a line - you were warned.

Also, I wasn't sure but I think they had wifi, while you wait!?!?
author: Michael C.

description: They have the best egg tart in the bay area. The wait line can be crazy long sometimes. But then again it IS the best egg tart in SF. So if your a fan of egg tarts you gotta try it out. But if you don't care much for egg tarts go to another bakery, the wait wouldn't be worth it unless you want LOVE egg tarts.
author: Diana K.

description:
I use to come here when I was much younger and get almond bread and egg tarts, and as I grew up, I ate egg tarts less and less so I just got almond bread from here. Recently though, I was in line for bread and decided..."hey.. i think i want an egg tart" so i bought half a dozen since i had some relatives visiting as well. I ate it right away since it was still warm and O.M.G.!!!

I swear i had a foodgasm right then and there! I know this sounds kind of weird.. but i just stood in the middle of chinatown with my mouth full of egg tart thinking about my childhood days. it was just... an odd feeling. man.. i just forgot how freakin good those dagnabbed egg tarts were!

if this review's rating was solely based on their egg tarts... then godamnit, it would be a 5 star! but see.. this is chinatown so the customer service is horrid and the rest of their stuff like... pineapple buns and whatnot were just decently good... so yea... 4 star. 


but im telling you.... go eat one of their egg tarts while they're still warm... AMAZING.
author: amelia g.

description:
Just thinking of their Dan Tat makes me drool.....! This is my favorite go to place for Dan Tat, aside from the long lines I can't think of any thing bad about this bakery. I have a really weird way of eating dan tats everywhere. I only eat the egg custard and leave the outer layer... But the dan tat here I finish the WHOLE thing!

Be warn that there is always a line here! if you're lucky you'll wait about 5 minutes, and there are days where you might wait up got 1 hour for dan tat!! I've waited 1 hour for their moon cakes before.  It's well worth the wait because the dan tat are freshly made, the egg custard is so smooth it just slides down your throat, the crust is toasted to perfection with the right amount of crustiness, it's actually very flaky which is good!! the whole thing just melts in your mouth! 

speaking of them makes me want to go there now and buy me a dozen !
author: Jenny G.

description:
This place is highly overrated and expensive.  I know their egg tarts are great but it's not all that.  Especially for $1 each, sheesh!  You can get this half the price at Wonder Foods on Waverly (just as good).

They are a pain to buy mooncakes from.  You have to wait in a long line during the autumn festival to get the cakes and then they may not have what you want (the nut filled ones are always hard to get your hands on!).

I used to get their Napoleans and sponge cake but stopped since they raised their prices!
author: Wendy H.

description:
Not really an egg tart fan but after reading all the reviews, I had to try. I was lucky as the line wasn't that long, took me less than 5 minutes to place my order - 2 egg tarts which were still warm.

Immediately after leave the shop, I took one out to try. I must say that was the yummiest egg tart I've ever had - the crust was flaky and the custard not overly sweet. 

I will most definitely be back for more!
author: Jean K.

description:
How do you diss a legendary bakery?  I'm not going to, but I'll try not too hard to hide my comparative disappointment.  We went there on a Saturday at around 3, and it had a little bit of a line.  The egg custard tart is this bakery's raison d'etre, and that's what let me down.  I noted that it was slightly over-baked (no big deal), but the separation of the 96 layers just isn't there!  The tart shell is meant to be a work of art, the testing stone of a Chinese pastry chef.  I was so intrigued by this art-form that I once tried it myself (as in "making it").  The way it works: you have the water dough and the oil dough (made from lard if done properly, but don't let me gross you out); you layer it one upon the other - first 2 layers, rolling pin, followed by folding the layered dough (4 layers), rolling it again, folding ... Legend has it that the egg tart shell has 96 layers, but an amateur math student will tell you that it's gotta be 64 or 128.  No matter.  The one I made (YEARS ago) separated like a blossoming yellow rose.  This baby at Golden Gate?  Not so much.  I wolfed that baby down.  The custard tasted fine, but let's face it, egg custard tart is MUCH more about the shell than the custard.  We also tried the glutinous rice ball with peanut filling (you could also have lotus seed and red bean): good texture, but unusual banana-cake flavoring.  The coconut tart, my wife's fave childhood dessert, was a sold 3 as well, but no more.  Maybe they were having a bad day, overblown legend?  

YOU decide.
author: Paul L.

description:
I love love love their egg tarts!

Once I went with a couple of "ghost boys" (white boys) and had trouble finding parking on the busy Grant Avenue. So I taught them how to say "dan taat" properly, but once they walked in, the lady behind the counter knew what they needed before they even opened their mouths! That's how popular their egg tarts are, which is lovely because the turnover is so fast the tarts are always fresh out of the oven. They were fresh even at 7pm on a week night, when nothing else on Grant was open and the street was deserted.

The ladies working there may be a bit too nosy for their own good, but I suppose that's part of the charm! It's pretty out of the way for me but I like treating myself once in a while.
author: Tracy W.

description:
The egg tarts were awesome. Possibly the best I have ever had. There was a good inch of egg on each! 

The lineup was a bit long (15 mins?), but it was worth the wait.
author: David W.

description:
Always a super long line for egg tarts - yet so worth the wait - I bought a dozen, split it with a friend, and somehow managed to finish 6 by myself within 3 days... 

So amazingly good because I love my "dan tat" more egg-custardy without too much pastry and not TOO sweet. This continues to be amazing. Too bad its far from home...
author: Jamie T.

description: Everyone was right.  The egg tarts are to die for.  I will wait in line all day if I could just have one bite.  Okay, maybe not to that extreme.  But they're so delicious!
author: Choua W.

description:
The BEST EGG CUSTARDS EVER! 
Delicious, flaky, fresh! Yummmmmmy. 
Cash Only.
author: Grace W.

description:
You know what, this place was like a foodie epiphany when I first got here....but can anyone say OVERRATED!!! Its in the heart of the kitschy Grant Ave of Chinatown which is the absolute pit of tourist crap and a laughing stock of the Bay Area and the Chinese community. Even if you go ONE block up or down you'll get wayyy more authenticity.

Granted these egg tarts are good, but for $1.50 each??? or is it more? that is WAYYYYY too much for something you can get just as good, for a lot less. AND the HUGE lines of tourists/whites waiting outside for their insight into chinese bakeries....not a good sign.

I'm always intrigued on coming here, but they also seem to be closed randomly for 'vacations' to the extent that I think they're always on vacation.
I'd say hop over the bay to Oakland and sample stuff in the real Chinatown for a LOT less and equally tasty and hot!
author: Nehal N.

description:
I've had egg tarts from a few Chinese places. These are the best. The custard still tastes like egg rather than cream.

The ladies behind the counter are brusque and speak little English, as it should be.

IT'S SO CHEAP!
author: Anton S.

description:
I dig it. No line and fresh to death at 8 in the morning on a weekday. I am amazed there is SO MUCH egg to crust ratio (which I prefer), and even then... their thin crust is crispy. That is some rocket science mess they figured out.

Pretty good and will come back again - can't say it's my best ever. Hong Kong/Macau takes the cake. BOOYAH! I know, not fair but hey... Golden Gate gets to play in that ballpark, and that's quite a compliment.
author: Jenny C.

description:
The egg tart is the best I found in SF.  Although they are are a bit expensive, totally worth it.  We went again for the moon cakes.  We stands in line for an hour.  The moon cake came out straight from the oven!  They were still hot!  

We got the traditional moon cake, white lotus, wintermelon, and chestnut mooncake.  Love all of them!!!
author: Deb L.

description:
I don't have much to review. 

Yes, be prepare to stand in line, usually 30mins to an hour.

Yes, they make the best egg tarts, given you like the flavor of sweet egg. 

The price for the egg tarts increased to $1.25 each, $15 a dozen, which is still $1.25 each lol, i guess no more discount. 

If you are in the area and have time to spare, definitely go get some, they are flaky-egg-custard-tastic.
author: Amy C.

description: Egg tarts are good,  but considering the wait time and price.... it's not worth it.   There's a bakery called New Hollywood bakery around the block with OG Chinese folks instead of the hipsters at Golden Gate.   The egg tarts are just as good and 3 for 1.40 instead of 1 for 1.40.  Plus,  no wait.
author: Trach L.

description:
I would like to put this out there - if anyone is going to Golden Gate Bakery, please, please, please bring some egg tarts back for me!  I have had quite a few egg tarts in my life and I could not understand why anyone would stand in line for over an hour for one.  Well, I stood in line for over an hour and now I can understand why people do it.  I gave myself little goals during this period, like "I can't wait until we reach that parking meter in front of me."  In the freezing San Francisco summer, no less!

The bakery actually sells items other than egg tarts, but most people just get the egg tarts.  The store is tiny - a total dive - with cardboard boxes taking up most of the space and the ladies behind the counter take your order amidst the chaos and then add everything up on a little hand-held calculator.

What's so special about these egg tarts?  (And, by the way, you have to eat them warm!)  I'm not sure why people think these are overpriced; $1.15 per tart is pretty standard if you buy them from a bakery.  These are special because the crust is perfectly thin and chewy while the custard is thick and creamy, almost like a flan instead of the lame-o custard they give you on dim sum egg tarts.

Just get here on a weekday when it's less busy and bring me back a half-dozen.  No, make it a dozen!
author: Cheryl T.

description:
They're the egg custard tart Nazi.  They treat you like crap.  You'd better have the cash ready, know exactly what you want to order, and fire it off with efficiency in fluent Cantonese, because they have no time to spare.  The whole place feels like a freakin' assembly line.  NO customer service whatsoever.

Yet, the lines are always long.  Their warm and flakey egg custard tarts are so good they make your knees weak.  

Oh the sacrifices we make for a bite of pastry heaven!

I hear that they close down for a whole month every summer so the owner can go on vacation.  IF that's true - then I'd have to say that's rather unusual, as most Chinese owners in the food/restaurant industry work around the clock and almost stay open everyday.  So, if they do indeed go on vacation for a whole month every year, then good for them!  I like people who work to live.
author: Kristen S.

description:
WARNING 8/3/11!!  We just drove long a time to pick up some bomb-ass egg-tarts.  We hit the corner and find it fenced up at 4:45pm!!  I remember another review where they do not follow their schedule- wells it's true. 

There's a pink "closed for vacation" sign!  The worst thing is that they didn't even bother with a "BRB on xyz date!".  It's just a simple "We're vacation" sign, WTF yo!  

Anyways, through word of mouth, they will return from china approx sep/oct.

FOOD -
Though its roughly $1 a piece,  they do ... do, do, DO!!! have some bomb-ass egg-tarts that is laced with ... geez idk .. crack!!  Seriously, save your time and get at least two dozens!!

SERVICE = 3 stars
EGGTARTS = 6 stars
author: Hank C.

description:
Seriously peeps, if you want to try a good eggtart- go to this place. It's not so much the egg custard that's worth mentioning but the tart! It is so flaky! While a lot of the common eggtarts are solid and more like solid cookie crust than flaky- Golden Gate Bakery's eggtarts are genuinely fluffy and flaky- you can see each layer of the tart. It's what Canto people call, "so pei dan tat" as in flaky egg tart. Egg tarts are supposed to be flaky and fluffy and Golden Gate is one of those rare places where they do this. Takes skills. 

Their eggtarts ARE a bit on the expensive side at $1.25 each, they are a bit bigger than the average egg tart so I'd say it's worth it. At least worth it for you to try. 

Aside from their eggtarts, I really like their baked BBQ buns and banana roll. Those have pretty good prices and are super good too.

There's almost always a long, long, long line in front of Golden Gate Bakery the wait in line can rate from 2 minutes to 30 minutes. But, seriously, as a regular customer, even if there's a line, even if they're a bit expensive, and even if whatever whatever whatever you SHOULD give it a try because just the fact that they're open that day is a miracle! Golden Gate is probably closed 100+ days out of the year. So if they're open, just thank your lucky stars, get a place in line, and order an eggtart :)
author: Kelly Y.

description: Yes, really good egg tarts and reasonably priced.  Takeout only.
author: Jim T.

description: There was a huge line outside this bakery so  we decided to try it out. We had the black bean moon cake, egg custard tart. Overall the quality of the items were good: moist and fresh.Lemon Napoleon and custard Napoleon. We didn't like it at all. The lemon one was pretty decent. The ladies were pleasant and friendly.
author: Sahar A.

description: Chinese New Year won't be w/o their tasty treats! Welcome The Year of Horse Families. They got BBQ pork roll, baked, perfect layers pastry exterior, moist BBQ inside, fabulous dann-ta', WISH there r curry beef only if someone didn't buy ALL of them. Then have to wait...for another freshly out of oven batch. Thank you all making these wonderful tradition!
author: LindaLu N.

description:
I am basing my five star rating solely on the custard tarts. 

Originally, I was on the fence about it because I'm not a tremendous fan of custardy things. However, I waited in the stupidly long line just to try one (I believe it was a Saturday), and it was totally worth the wait. It was fresh the oven! Next time I go back, I'm going to buy all of them and make San Francisco really sad.

As for the tarts being greasy--well, I would say that they were no greasier than a buttery croissant. If you are really that concerned about this--maybe you are counting points or something--perhaps you should go to another establishment, preferably one that does not serve baked goods.

I will definitely go back next time I am on the left coast.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
So I agree with all of the reviews - awesome egg custards. You don't need to get anything else.  Just get the custards by the dozen and go!  I also agree they are pricey - now over a buck apiece - but they are really worth the treat.  

My hubby and I have fallen victim to their "on vacation" sign several SEVERAL times. ARGH!!!! (GGB - at least say when you'll be back *from* vacation!)  How do you get around this frustration? (1) call ahead! Google their number and CALL. (2) drive by their store, and if you see a line, park at the Portsmouth garage and jet in and out... takes like 30-45 minutes, of course. 

So, enjoy the egg custards whenever you can and sharing is caring!
author: Wendy A.

description:
This is a pretty good place for eggtarts.  But highly over priced.  Its about $1.20 per tart.  The crust is flaky and very buttery, and the tart itself is yummy.  If you get it fresh out of the oven, that's the BEST!  The ladies there always cut a small hole in the box for the hot air to get out - makes for a good take home tart.

Usually if you go on a weekend, at any time, they're packed with people.  Luckily, I work a few blocks away, so I can get some minus the lines.  

For a while, in 2008, they were either changing chefs or something, because the tarts were coming out either too sweet or over done or something else was wrong with it. Lately, they've continued to make the good eggtarts that they usually do.

Around mid-late September, they stop selling eggtarts and sell moon cakes instead.  They also tend to close for weeks at a time when they go on vacation. But with business like theirs, they can afford the lost in revenue.  If you're craving a good eggtart and find yourself in the Chinatown area, Golden Gate Bakery is your place to go!
author: Lily W.

description:
The coconut with nuts and egg yolk moon cake is amazing!! It's filled with coconut flakes and various nuts like macadamia, sunflower seeds, peanuts, and various goodies. The egg yolk adds a perfect balance of sweet and savory.

The egg tarts are good too; soft silky egg custard with a thin crispy crust. I like a tart with more filling and less crust, and this place gets it.
author: Jun W.

description: I try to visit this place as often as i can when I'm in SF. They have the most amazing egg tarts and coconut tarts. The crust is superb. The flavors mesh well and are not overpoweringly sweet. The wait is usually long, but well worth it.
author: Christal G.

description:
I tried five things here for $6. The coconut tart was my fave. The much loved egg custard tart was good but a little eggy for me, but I realize other people aren't as picky about eggy taste, so I can appreciate a good, albeit eggy, egg custard tart. The BBQ pork pun in a long pastry is pretty good (good meat quality, too) though not my favorite around sauce-wise by any means. It was my first time trying a lotus seed paste filled pastry, and I can say that I'm definitely not straying from my love of red bean paste pastries in the future. The chicken pie (not curry chicken pie which I've heard is fab) was OK. I only finished half.

Counter people were very proficient in English, which was very helpful.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
== Egg Tarts == 

What?!?  Egg tarts?  what is all the hype about the little egg tart?  Well, get it and you WILL understand!  

I was here early in the morning (9:30am), so was able to walk in and get service right away.  They have many other bakeries and goodies besides the egg tart.  

Egg tarts - warm, flaky crust.  The egg custard is soft and not overly sweet.  

Besides the egg tarts, I also got other bakeries (BBQ pie, curry pie).  ALL really good!  The little ladies in there are really friendly, cute!
author: Sandy T.

description: Truly best egg tarts!  Even better than the ones in Hong Kong.
author: Amy N.

description:
Best. Freakin'. Dan. Tat. Ever.

I know I am repeating what everyone else has already said, but WOW! Where they get their soft, delicious custard flavor and crispy-to-perfection crust is beyond me. I tried their egg custards for the first time a few years ago and was stunned by how great it tasted even after hours of sitting out. Warm or cold, it still tastes ridiculously good.

I finally had the chance to go there myself about two months ago, and unfortunately that was the day of the Chinese Moon Cake Festival in China Town. You can imagine how crowded it was... it took us an hour and a half waiting in line to get to the front, and my friend just COULD NOT understand why I would ever wait so long for such a silly thing (and why I wanted to buy 10 of them)... until he tried it for himself!! He ended up eating 3 or 4 of the ones I bought. They've always made their egg custards consistently THAT good... so if you haven't tried one yet, it's definitely worth the wait.

Speaking of which, I've heard that the original baker/egg custard recipe guru has passed no more than a month ago. Rumor has it that their egg custards are not as good anymore (oh no!), but I haven't been back to confirm it since...
author: Joanne Y.

description:
This place is fine... but there are plenty of other places that are just as good but half the price, and serve more variety.
You guys should get out there and explore some of the places where you don't have to wait in line, even if you don't speak Canto and have to gesture with the person behind the counter instead.
author: Marcus L.

description: We decided to try this place because of the good rating on here.. The tarts smell very eggy, the whole family tried them anyway & they taste like egg... Not our idea of a good dessert. The moon pie was different I wouldn't recommend them. The lady was not friendly either...
author: Vikki A.

description:
Gotta love these asian bakeries. Everything here is delicious, but like everyone mentioned, them EGG TARTS ARE BOMB !! It's like goodness in your mouth. NOMNOMNOM (=

They're always fresh tasting, pricier than the usual egg tart, but way better. Warm inside, flaked crust, just SO goood. Do try !
author: Connie Y.

description:
Long line = not so fun
Egg tarts = oh so good
freshness = hot & sizzling
price = just pay a little more for great food
Egg tart fart (few hours later) = i think they smell good =)
author: Alex A.

description:
egg tarts!

YUM! 

the best ever! i'm fortunate to have never waited in line..
but definitely worth the wait.

i don't care if its a million calories. it's worth it.
author: Heejin L.

description: Customer service or even service with a smile does NOT exist here but who cares because their EGG TARTS are the BEST in the BAY!  The crust is light and flakey and when it comes to you straight from the warmer, it's MONEY!!!  :)
author: A C.

description:
Places with perpetual lines tend to leave me a little bit bitter.  My inner grouch grumbles about how anything could possibly be that good, and then it sets about telling me how important it is that those crazy kids get off my lawn.  Every time I found myself in close proximity to Golden Gate Bakery, there was a line.  So I grumbled, and I walked on.  Until one day, the line wasn't quite so bad and I resolved to go inside and see what the fuss was about.

In typical Chinese bakery style, there are tons of yummy delights crammed into every nook of a very small space.  Being fairly new to the world of Chinese bakeries, there were many things that looked delectable but unfamiliar.  I expected someplace so crowded and popular to be very no-nonsense: get in, order, get out.  But the women behind the counter were so incredibly helpful!  They told us what everything was, they made recommendations, they smiled, talked, laughed, and generally made us feel welcome.  I was expecting good food.  Good service?  Not so much.  To get such excellent service?  I must say that it really floored me.

So long story short, we bought a lot of food.  We bought rice cake and moon cake and egg custard tart and wife cake and dumplings and something awesome stuffed with winter melon.  Though I'm no expert, I found it all to be really freakin' tasty.  The rice cakes were chewy, the dumplings were crunchy, the pastry was flaky, and the melon/lotus fillings were sweet and nutty and creamy and crystally in the way of things that probably contain a goodly amount of sugar.  The egg custard tart was definitely the most impressive thing we had to eat, and what really struck me was how brilliantly light the filling was.  It just tasted like egg, slightly sweetened.  I've never really had a dessert before that just felt so pure.

I don't know if I'll always find myself wanting to brave the line to get my hands on Golden Gate Bakery's baked goods, and I'm not even educated enough in Chinese pastries to tell you that it's really a head above the rest.  I guess I'll have to do more research.  Tasty, tasty research.  In fact, maybe I'll go back...tomorrow...
author: Becca S.

description:
THESE ARE THE BEST EGG TARTS I EVER HAD. No wonder there's always a line up outside for them.

The second day I was in San Fran, my cousins brought me to this bakery wanting to pick some up. But, in the end, we got sooo lazy to line up, we left, because the line was sooooooooo long.

The week after, I went with my aunt since I was dying to try the egg tart. We were so lucky that when we went in, there was no line up. Yay us!

The egg tart filling literally feels like heaven in your mouth. It's perfectly made that you can eat it without making a mess everywhere. It's not overly sweet, unlike most egg tart I tried. This egg tart was soft, sort of like jello. 

I WOULD DIE IF I DO NOT GET ANY MORE OF THESE EGG TARTS THE NEXT TIME I MAKE A TRIP BACK TO SAN FRAN!
author: Susan C.

description:
This place is my go to egg tart place in San Francisco. Their egg tart is the best one I ever ate from many countries. Pastry is so flaky and their custard is so creamy and not too sweet for me. If you buy it to go, tart is gonna be so good. But if you have chance to go to China Town, San Fran, you must try one in front of the shop. That's haven!! In addition, let's try their macaroon and melon cake too. 

However, the owners always take monthly vacation without advance notice. It's kind of annoyed when I went to this place so many times and didn't get my eggtarts :(
author: Jareerat C.

description: Best egg tarts! Crispy and flaky crust. Perfect egg custard center. Little bit of a wait but def worth it. Also got a couple coconut and BBQ buns. Both excellent but the egg tart was the winner for sure!
author: Danielle L.

description: When it comes to Dan Tats... this is the place to go!  I can say that it is the best I have had in Cali!  The line sucks in the afternoon, but we went early morning and did not have to wait too long.  So fresh!
author: Guillermo C.

description:
The Short:
A family favorite. The bakery delivers well on its offerings. From the "Wife-Biscuits" to the Egg Custard Tarts, they do them exceptionally well.
