The Egg Custard has a luscious consistency that makes you want to eat more! My main gripe would be the frequent closings throughout the year for vacations and preparations for events such as Lunar New Years.

Recommendations:
- Egg Custard Tarts

Pros:
- Great baked goods!
- Fresh!

Cons:
- Long lines.
- Frequently closed for periods of time (for vacations, and weeks leading up to big Chinese holidays like Lunar New Years, Mid-Autumn Festival, etc.)
author: Ernie F.

description:
The don tots (egg tarts) are really great especially when they're hot, creamy and so smooth. They were one of the best don tots I've had but they didn't blow me out of the water or anything.
 
I give them 3 starts because of the line which is crazy long and they are quite expensive for don tot. 1.25 per tart which I mean they can afford because of the crazy long lines but still not worth it for me. I tired their guy mei bous and char sieu bous and they weren't too great. 

So if you are a don tot connoisseur, this place is for you. Bring a harry potter book to read while you read in line. As for me, they were good but not worth it.
author: Spencer H.

description:
Every time I make a trip to San Francisco, I always have to stop here to get me a dozen egg tarts. I only knew of it because my sister goes to school here and told me I had to try these one-of-a-kind sunny golden pastries. I can't remember how many times I've gone since 2008, nor can I remember how many times I've gone only to discover they were closed for "Vacation"! Yea, you'd think after the 3rd or 4th time, I would've learned to give them a call before I make a trip to Chinatown, but I guess all too often I get caught up in the rush of hopping the morning muni, or making my way up the 101 as soon as I get off my plane at SFO.

This may be blasphemous, but the tarts are just as good reheated in the toaster oven. Since it's simply not a syrupy-sugary-based egg tart, it won't melt or dry up into an unrecognizable crusty mess. Just use a sheet of foil over the top so the custard doesn't burn.
author: Thai P.

description:
EGG TARTS!

EGG TARTS!

EGG TARTS!

MOCHI ROLL!

Definitely one of the best I've ever had and I've eaten at many chinese bakeries in NYC and Toronto.
author: Vio H.

description:
I'm not a big of the egg tarts. Sorry people. This isn't a review for them. I took the bus here on a Sunday afternoon around 230pm. There were about 4 people in front of me. They had all sorts of stuff and fully stocked too. I asked for the pineapple buns and they gave them to me off the rack piping hot! Yummo. I think that they have THE BEST pineapple buns in the city. The top does not crumble like most places. They are soft and have just enough flavor to them. I will continue to go here for my buns. 

3 for only $1.90. Cheap!
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Great egg tarts.  Easily can eat 2-3 in one sitting.  They are so light and fluffy. :D

I am only giving them 5 stars because I have never had to go wait in line for these tasty egg tarts.  I have friends and family who crave them more than I do who would do that.  I just get to benefit.  

If I ever have to wait in the incredulous queue or deal with the nightmare-ish service (or pay, for that matter), they may lose a couple of stars. :D
author: Cindy C.

description: Great egg tarts.  $1.65 each. It is still hot. A must try if you are in the area. Grab and go. No sitting area in store.
author: Tina Q.

description: A charming little spot. Try the black bean sesame buns! Lesser known and so tasty! Egg Custards, are of course, mouth-watering. Sometimes there's a good line but if never gets more than 20 mins long.
author: Debra A.

description:
Everyone raves about their egg custard...

But I will tell you, their sa-chi-ma is amazing! Anytime I go to SF, this is a required stop...unless they're on vacation, which then makes me sad and the whole trip a waste. Okay...maybe I'm being a bit dramatic...but their sa-chi-ma is something I dream about when I haven't had it for a long time!

If you live in SF, and you haven't been here...that is a travesty!

If you're planning to visit SF, you have to come here to get some great Chinese sweets!!!
author: Herbie H.

description:
Like some other reviewers said, overhyped.  I mean it's good egg tarts, but I've definitely had better for a lower price in other chinatowns, like Oakland's.

Just good marketing strategy like always.  I only go here if some of my friends I'm going with are like touristy and wants to go to a famous bakery in SF. But if I ever just want to get bakery goods I wouldn't come here just so I could line up to get something I can get somewhere else.

So overall, good egg tarts, overpriced, haven't really tried the other baked goods.
author: Willis C.

description:
Egg custards and black bean with egg moon cake! Very yummy. And their lemon cake too!. Gf and I ordered 12 egg custards (they still warm when they packed it into a box), and one moon cake along with lemon cake. Everything was good.

Oh do yourself a favor, if you don't like egg custards, just don't even bother go to this place or even write a review on how much you hate it because you already realized that you hate egg custards in general. period.
author: Yohann S.

description: Effin amazin. Like they took it straight out of the oven... OF YOUR HEART.
author: Dora C.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS. The custard is SO light and fluffy, and the pastry shell is so crispy with a million layers...ahhh. If you're not lucky enough to get one straight from the oven, just plop it into a toaster oven when you get home for about 5-10 minutes and you're good. My parents used to get a whole dozen (cuz then you get one free) and we'd toast a few every morning for breakfast for a couple of days. They're still good even 3 days later haha ;) Plus, I think they're only $1 each?

Their walnut cookies are also crumbly and good (and HUGE), as well as their mooncakes and other red bean pastries. Parking in the area really sucks though, so it's probably better just to get someone to drop you off while they circle the block...
author: Kate Y.

description: Such a old style place. The only thing that hold me on the line waiting for almost one hour is because of my wife. The tart doesn't look attractive.
author: Harry W.

description:
Egg tart = foodgasm

Steps to Continued Enjoyment:
Buy several, eat half. Take the rest home, put in fridge, fantasize about as long as you can stand it, let come to room temperature, put in your oven at 375 for 8 minutes, and they'll be almost as good as when you walked out of the store.

However, as much as I love these little bundles of heaven, I honestly hope that the owners keep the business small and don't sell out to the tourist trade. I've yet to run into a small business yet whose quality didn't drop like a stone upon doing that. Don't worry GGB, I'll wait in line any day of the week.
author: Amanda S.

description: Freakin egg tart Nazi's! Everytime I make a trip home I try to stop by this place and I walk away with nothing! They might as well have a mustached guy say "NO. No dan tat for you"
author: Vanessa T.

description: A friend took me here after finishing a meal at the nearby Capital restaurant.  We stood in line for 15-20 minutes to get the egg custard tarts.  Worth the wait- these were, hands down, THE BEST EGG CUSTARD TARTS that I have ever consumed in my life.  Now, I know what I'm missing.  Every other egg tart that I consumed at a Dim Sum restaurant pales in comparison to these warm, tasty gems.  Yes, it was worth standing in line on Saturday evening at 7:00.  HEAVEN. Yes, yes, yes,  I want to come back.
author: Alison ..

description:
My friend was showing me around chinatown and he recommended this bakery. When you pass by it, it's just a small store with a LONG line. The line probably goes around the store because the space is so small. I had to wait a good 40 minutes to get to the front. There weren't a whole mess of people but I think the reason why the line was so slow was because the service was so inefficient. The ladies who work in the front only know how to speak chinese so it's hard for non-chinese speakers to communicate. Not everything on the menu is available in the store so don't expect to get everything you want.

I originally wanted 2 egg tarts and one pineapple moon cake. Confused on how to order, one lady pointed at me to order and when I hesitated for a few seconds, she straight up ignored me and moved on to the next customer..rude much? Also, since I ordered in english, I think she thought I said 3 egg tarts and a moon cake, so I had no choice than to get one more. I think the baked goods are only good when it's warm and straight off the oven. The egg tarts were impressive. The tart wasn't overwhelmingly crunchy, but had just enough crunch and flake. The egg custard was soft, sweet, and yummy. I can't really say much for the moon cake except that it's how I imagined a regular red bean bread would be except a bit crunchier. I have yet to try more egg tarts so I can compare this place to another.
author: Kayla K.

description:
I normally would bypass such a long line, but I was with my mother who insisted we wait it out. 

"Good food always equals long lines! Never eat at a place that isn't busy."

That's her mantra. And today, it was mine too. 

The five of us waited it out so we felt justified ordering enough to feed 10. Kids in a candy store. 

With our load of pastries and 30 bucks later - we enjoyed several of them on the trunk of the car in the china town parking structure. Awh, memories.

Even my teenage taiwanese cousin said that it was the 2nd best tart he ever had. The first being at 7-11 in taiwan. wtf? anyways.

The macaroons were tasty! They also have really good baked golden Char Sui Bao!!!
author: Tina P.

description:
My boyfriend and I were walking around Chinatown when we spotted a huge line. We're not from around the local area, so I had no idea what was going on. We kept passing the same place, and the line remained consistent, if not longer than what we had previously seen. Being without a smartphone, I couldn't just look up the place. I dragged my boyfriend to the line and we stood there for a few minutes before I asked the girl in front of me what the deal was. 

She said the place is known for their egg tarts. And we decided to give them a try, along with some other baked good. A curried chicken pastry was among our box of baked treats.

Everything was delicious. The sizes were generous. I don't think I'm too fond of baked things, so it was just "ooh, yum" to me. Definitely better than your average egg tart. The crust was flakey and buttery. I'd recommend this place to those who love baked foods :]
author: Anna B.

description:
WORTH THE WAIT!
WORTH THE DRIVE!
WORTH every bit of the oh so good Egg Tart!

Remember...just bring home a dozen.  You'll thank me you did!
author: Thien N.

description: We walked by this bakery earlier today, saw the longest line ever for a littlte bakery shop. We will have to try the egg tarts first thing tomorrow
author: Bill L.

description: The Macaroons were the best cookies I've ever had besides my Mother's chocolate chip cookies.  I bought 6 and walked down the street.  I managed to eat them all within a few blocks and walked back and bought another dozen.  They were that good.
author: Joseph W.

description:
Their egg tart is good, but not THAT good.  The last time my friend tried to bring me here, they were also "on vacation," so I thought I'd come by and see if they might be open today to try it out.  Well, this was the only place on Grant Ave that had any sort of line, so I was lucky enough to come on a day it was open.

I'm not that big of an egg tart fan to start with, so based on the ratings, I was thinking that they'd have a magical product which would blow me away.  Well, it was good, but blow me away it didn't.  It was probably every bit as good as all the other reviews say, and I even didn't get any negative attitude from the ladies behind the counter.  There was about a 1/2 hr wait in line, which only grew longer while I was there.

Anyway, I can't really say that I can appreciate what a makes a good egg tart, besides being warm and coming right out of the oven, so to me...it's just "A-OK."  But if you love egg tart, then I bet you'll really love it here...
author: Jimmy W.

description: It was ok. The little egg custard was super fresh but it lacked flavor and the pastry wasn't flaky it was kind of soggy.
author: Reiko n.

description:
Seriously,
One word. 3 syllables.

DE-LI-CIOUS.

$1.25 for an egg tart.

Friends and I came here when they were closed. We were so disappointed. A few days later, we happened to stumble upon Chinatown and we saw a line outside and inside was pitch black. People were lined outside and taking orders of eggtarts as they made them. Seriously that good.
author: Markie J.

description:
The custard tarts here are crazy good!

I didn't see anything else that appealed to me in Chinatown, but I would come back just for the tarts.

I thought the tarts would be small too, but it's actually pretty big!
author: Lori F.

description: I luckily had no wait today to get my egg custard fix (it was 5pm).  This egg custard is as good as it gets; it's got a perfectly crisp and flaky crust and a delicate soft barely set custard that is piping hot and very lightly sweetened.  This is the type of egg custard I remember from my childhood that I never seem to be able to get today.
author: Lisa W.

description: Getting the famous egg tarts. Line is out the door! If you've been to Chinatown, then line up while your guest peruses the knick knacks along the streets. Catch up with them when you have your handful of egg tarts as your surprise!
author: Anne T.

description:
Went here based on the Yelp reviews. Tried the Egg Custard since everyone said it's a must. It was very flaky, with almost falling apart moist custard. Worth the wait in line. 

The only other thing I ordered was one of the Lotus Moon Cakes - I obviously didn't know what I was ordering and it was expensive and not my cup of tea. 

If I was in the area again I would go back to try the pork pie or the almond cookies.
author: Jessica B.

description: It was good, but Egg Tart King in Houston still trumps it, I think. Just sayin'.
author: Catherine L.

description: Do you like egg tarts?  Then what are you waiting for?  Hands down the best egg tart in the WORLD and I was born in Macau, close to Hong Kong.  Eat it right away if you can and you will be addicted.  Only bad thing about this place is that they close randomly for a month or so for vacation, but hey, they know people will come knocking at the door when they are back because it's that good.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
You can tell where this place is by just looking for a long line on Grant Ave. Seriously shabby looking mom pop joint, and of course don't bother getting other bakery goods here,stick to the plan.  You're here for the egg tarts. 
How good can a pastry filled with egg can be? This place will answer that for you.  One word of advice, don't waste your time waiting in line for twenty minutes and get two tarts per person.  The lady in the shop will say something in chinese that won't sound pleasant.  Also, you'll kick yourself after taking a bite for not buying more.  Here i go again to the end of the line....
author: Mindee C.

description: This Place has the BEST BEST BEST egg Tart... You can't get them like it anywhere.. The only bad thing is there is always a long ass line..  But trust me its worth the wait. I had cousins from out of town they waited in line for 45 minutes and they said worth every minute.  Also, Don't try going to this place on a holiday they will most likely be closed.
author: Jenn J.

description:
I've had tons of Dan Tat [Egg Custards] in my life, even the ones in Hong Kong don't got anything comparable to ones here. I can only describe the Dan Tats here as hot, flaky, buttery goodness with the sugar just about right. 

The only thing I can think that comes close is the Pou Tat [Creme Brulee like Egg Custards] from Macau. 

Aside from the Egg Custards $1.40 each now as of January 21st 2014, the Cha Siu Sow was pretty awesome as well. Also very flaky and from what I can tell, they didn't give me lard infused Cha Siu, which is downright appetizing and much healthier. I took a huge bite in and saw nothing but slim meat and I couldn't be more pleased.

I didn't have so much of a line wait issue when I got there, maybe I got there at the right time? It's always time dependent, I think I was there around 2:30ish pm so the line was only 3-4 minute wait tops. 

Suggestion: Have a late lunch/brunch and come here for dessert.
author: Ken N.

description: I called tonight and they are on vacation for another two weeks. I wished that there is a way to communicate that. I called at least, so I saved a trip to the city.
author: Winglo A.

description:
Ok so if you haven't been here and you are around the area, shame on you. Actually it maybe ok so there will be more egg custard tarts for me.

If you don't know by now this is THE best place for egg custard tarts in many cities around. The crust is flaky and crisp, not like the shortbread crusts found in other places that tastes dry.  The custard itself is light and sweet.  I always get a few and eat one right away as it's the best when it's hot out of the oven.  I'd occasionally get their cocktail buns and white sugar sponge cakes.

You'll most likely have to wait for a bit to order but it's well worth it. The only thing that I'm sad about is that this place seems less open these days. The past few times I wanted to get my fix they were closed. I even suggested this place to some wandering tourists but they came back minutes later to tell me it was closed.  Open, open, open.
author: Davey L.

description: Tasted like sweet scrambled eggs in a pie shell. Not sure what the fuss is about. Waited over an hour in line as the people in front were buying three dozen tarts at a time. Craziness and totally not worth the wait.
author: Jessica D.

description:
I pointed at a pastry I didn't recognize, and one of the ladies behind the counter hissed (if Cantonese women can do such a thing), "Don't touch."  And then she glared at me (which Cantonese women definitely can do).

On a completely unrelated and completely unoriginal note, the egg custard tarts really are non pareil.  So, I suppose the admonition it was worth it.
author: Albert L.

description:
Egg tarts bring me back to my childhood... Over the years I have seen the line at Golden Gate Bakery grow longer and longer and the prices go higher and higher. The egg tarts however, remain relatively the same. For a while I did think the egg tarts were getting smaller but than maybe I am getting bigger.

No other place in San Francisco can compare to the egg tarts from Golden Gate bakery, especially if you are a fan of the flaky crust (I personally am a big fan of the flaky crust). The crust is super buttery and flaky, so amazing... the egg custard is soft and smooth. Perfection! I can always tell when my parents bring some egg tarts home whether or not they were from here. The only egg tart I have had that was better than Golden Gate Bakery was in Hong Kong, the motherland of egg tarts. 

Aside from egg tarts, their other baked goods are also very good. They are very well known for the moon cakes, so in September, the line was be super long. I used to get almond pound cake for my grandfather and that was also very good. 

But alas, the fact that the prices seem to be going up every time I go back does not make me happy. They also like to take vacations every so often... saddens me when I bare the drive or bus ride to Chinatown just to return without an egg tart...
author: Angela T.

description:
Been going to the GGB for many years... finally reviewing. Dan tat=awesome as has been noted by many. I'm among the legions who rank them as my tops in the Bay. Moon cakes are pretty good too and the have some ones with funky fillings 'round mid autumn festival time(coconut mooncake??)


But not to be discounted are their chau siu sou which are also the best I've ever had anywhere and what I ask for anytime my better half makes the rounds through China town. The egg tarts are good and all, but those bbq pork pastries are my kryptonite


Definitely been disappointed more than a few times when I've tried to go and they were randomly closed.
author: trvs l.

description:
It's ALL about the Egg Custard Tarts here. If you find yourself wandering through China Town

This is NOT an American Bakery!!! It's a CHINESE BAKERY. So I get sooo annoyed when people are like 'where are the donuts and lady fingers?'

Get yourself some wife cake, moon cake, and sweet buns. But NEVER pass up the Egg Tarts!
author: Lacey C.

description:
I have nothing to compare it to since I had never had an egg tart before, but we walked past and the line was out the door so when I checked it out on the iPhone Yelp app we decided to stop.  My fiancee is a big fan of egg tart so we hopped in line, which although seems long actually moves pretty fast (the inside/counter area is tiny, and holds maybe 5 people) and we got some egg tarts, BBQ pork bun, and pineapple bun.  I don't really like the buns, although they're good.  Very good mix of sweet and savory in the BBQ pork bun.

However, the egg tarts are AMAZING!  They come out warm out of the oven and they have the flakiest crust I've ever had.  The egg is slightly sweet but still kind of egg-like.  I'm confused - is this a breakfast, a desert?  What!?  I don't know but it sure is good.  We got a dozen and snacked throughotu the day but frankly next time I would just grab a few and eat fresh out of the oven instead of getting some to take home, especially if I'm going to lug them around the city all day.
author: Robert K.

description: Love their en tat! Reminds me of being a kid, when we'd wake up early and drive 3hours to NYC Chinatown to get food to go and hightail it back home.  I'd eat 2 on the street & sneak 2 more on the ride home. En tat was always my fave and this place has the best! Whomever compared it to sweet scrambled eggs is wrong. It's sweet velvety custard and is worth the trip & the rather brusque and somewhat intimidating service. A smile helps! Their baked pork buns are the best I've had so far in SF. No fat, nothing questionable, and all delicious porky yumminess! The sticky rice wrapped in leaves are good here too...comes with meat, chinese sausage and either peanuts or beans inside. My American-born, Cantonese mom calls them Dung which always made me laugh. Not sure what they are really called but when I asked the lady what kind of dung it was she understood. Love this bakery!!
author: Emily C.

description:
HANDS DOWN THE BEST DAN TA (EGG TARTS) YOU CAN FIND. 

Seriously, I make it part of my routine when I'm within 5 miles of Chinatown to head over Golden Gate Bakery and grab a bunch to indulge. Sure there are other goodies, like the macaroons, the 2-yolk moon cakes (why get 1 when you can have TWO?), cream bun, cake rolls/slices, cake triangles, napoleons, and a bunch of other yummies I can't think of at the moment.

I'll refresh my memory by dropping by on the weekend to order one (okay, a handful) of everything and stuff my face with some friends. Of course I'm going to grab some dan ta by the dozen (heck, maybe even 2 dozen). I don't care, we'll gladly spend $100 here (and it's Spring Break, so time to eat!) at one go. Shoot, when I used to go with my mum, we spend around $40 between us. It's that good. But don't think it's expensive, it's just too delicious that you gotta buy in bulk. And why would you buy a measly bit when you had to wait a while in line? That's just a waste of time.
author: C. H.

description:
I have tried sooo many times and still never been able to get something here. The 3 random times I have gone all the way over there they are always closed (plus all the times I have called)! Darn vacation sign!! The least that they could do is on the sign put something more like when they might be open again. Either they are rarely open or they must know when I want to go and will never be open then.
The only time I tried it was when someone brought me some. They were the best egg tarts but it's no use if they are never open.
author: Hungry G.

description:
Love this place. Especially the egg tarts, which it is obviously famous for. I only like to eat the egg tarts for this place. Whenever someone in my family bring home egg tarts, I always ask "where is it from?" if it is from Golden Gate, then I will eat it... otherwise I will not touch it. 

What makes Golden Gate egg tart stand out from the other is the crust. It is really flaky and crispy, kind of like a croissant flaky texture. And it is buttery and golden brown.

I also tried some of there other pastry here and they are all pretty good. Like the wife cake... but the stuff here is a bit oily.... mayb that is just how chinese food is...
author: Alicia W.

description:
Literally THE best dan ta in the fucking world.  All those reviews about how it made people cry?  Not even corny in this case.
I always have to wait about 15-20 minutes for new ones to be made since the stuff sells out before it's even made, but the fresh-out-of-the-oven taste makes it well worth the wait.  My dad ended up buying a dozen of these bad boys just today.  My dad doesn't buy a dozen of anything.  

TLDR: Get the custard (egg) tart.  In fact, get a dozen.
author: Christine C.

description:
WARNING:  super long lines

EXTRA WARNING:  their dan-tat are addicting

I love love.... love their crust.  The custard is just a bit sweeter than what i normally get but that could just be because i scarfed it down right out of the oven.
author: Joanne H.

description:
closed very often for vacation :) But when they are Open get in line and be prepared to wait. of course the egg custard tarts are warm & delicious baked all day Long.
(so forgive me I don't know what that are called)But they make these round spongey coconut vessels with sweet nuts on the inside.........I recommend these
author: August S.

description: The Dan tat wasn't rich and creamy like the ones I've had in Los Angeles.  The puff pastry was not flaky and light.  I did like that it was warm and straight out of the oven.  For $1.40, I have had much better.
author: Donna V.

description: 5 Stars for the freshest Egg Tart I've ever had in my life and I've had MANY!!!  I was surprised after coming here and reading the reviews regarding the line and the wait to order from Golden Gate Bakery.  My fiance and I had a totally different experience; we came around 730pm and walked right up to the counter and ordered our two tarts to-go.  Well...actually, we only stepped outside and devoured - or at least tired to, the custard was piping hot - the scrumptious snack.  Sigh.  It was SO GOOD.
author: Angela N.

description:
Whatever you do, be prepared to wait anywhere from 20 min to an hour in line for this place.  I haven't really ordered anything else from here except for their egg tarts (daan taat).  The only reason you'd ever need to come here is for their egg tarts.  They are larger than most places but oh so good when they are fresh and warm.  You may want to order a dozen because they are always devoured with the quickness.

On another note, the store is periodically closed due to the owners going on vacation, which seems like every other month.
author: Ben H.

description:
This place is usually packed with a lot of customers waiting for egg tarts according to my friends who went to get egg tarts and was waiting for the new fresh racket of egg tarts that was just came out of the oven. 

Honestly the egg tarts here are just too good especially the tart shell, it's so crispy!!!! I think it's currently closed for vacation or something. But it does have THE BEST EGG TARTS I EVER HAD.
author: Katherine W.

description: You have to early in the morning for the egg tarts to be warm if not hot right out of the oven. I know these as "daan-tat" in my world. As a kid roaming around Chinatown, Los Angeles, it was always a great treat to have one or three of these. This is one of the few places that still makes them just as good and just as big. If you haven't been to any dim sum restaurants and noticed byte size mini egg tarts, you haven't been experiencing anything else at all. Yes, I called them egg tarts if they are going to be byte size which does not resemble anything but puff pastry itself. The whole point of a daan-tat is the middle part which is the egg. The pastry was always the container or the vessel for you to pick it up with your hands and take a huge byte of daan-tat. You still have two more big bytes after that before you finish it. If you don't know what I'm talking about now, you'll just have to try them for yourselves. If you think what I speak of in this review is truth, you may now bring me three of these back with you to LA. I'll be waiting...
author: Tim C.

description: Delicious egg tarts; the only thing I really come here for. The line can be as long as 20 minutes, but I think it's worth it. You can get 7 for under $9 (I'm too lazy to find the price). The dan tats are piping hot and amazing. That's all I can say!
author: Claire S.

description:
I don't usually eat egg tart unless if I visit downtown SF.  Golden Gate Bakery in Chinatown does have something worth waiting for and also dying for!

I've never got my egg tarts without waiting in line, and expect wait time of approxmiately 30 minutes. The egg tarts are always freshly baked, which means you will be getting hot egg tarts most of time! The taste? It tastes like heaven, and don't be shocked if you get addicted to it. This also makes a great gift to your family/friends when you order a box of a dozen. Order 2 of tarts would be a smart idea if you planned to enjoy the tarts right after the purchase!

An egg tart with a cup of warm Hong Kong style milk tea will definitely make my day. A must go when you visit San Francisco next time!
author: Stephen H.

description:
No, I'm not about to have a seizure - my eyes are rolling back in ecstasy from biting into one of these scrumptious EGG TARTS!

While most Chinese bakeries I've been to (in SF, Vancouver, Hong Kong) keep their egg tarts in a glass display case - allowing them to cool and become stale, Golden Gate Bakery keeps theirs in a warm oven in the back so they stay hot and fresh! Like cookies, fresh egg tarts are infinitely better than ones that have been sitting out.

The warmth and freshness only enhances how delectable they are. The (plentiful) egg filling is sweet-but-not-too-sweet and has a creamy and custardy texture that contrasts marvelously with the perfectly flaky crust. Simply exquisite! (I could go on and on about them and use all the synonyms I know for "delicious" and "amazing", but I won't.)

I always eat mine as soon as I step out of the store. My face and shirt is often littered with remnants of the crust and custard, but it's a small price to pay and I wouldn't have it any other way.

While their egg tarts definitely deserve 5-stars, I haven't been very impressed with the other items they offer. I've had way better versions of napoleons, moon cakes, and wife cakes (filled with lotus paste) - mostly from bakeries in Vancouver and Hong Kong. A lot of their baked goods are also coated with an unsightly orange-coloured wash. I do really like their chocolate cake rolls and curry beef puffs though!
author: Steph L.

description:
Expect a long line and a long wait.  Also be prepared to dress warm in case it is cold outside and you have to stand in the windy city.  

I came here for their famous egg custard thing.  It was really good and I'm usually not a fan of those things.  A+ ! Honestly better than anything of that sort of nature I have ever had here in the states.  If I was keen on turning into a fatass, I would eat tons of these a day to accomplish my goal.

We bought about 2 dozen and they delivered them to us piping hot.  FRESHNESS FTW! 

I can't comment on their other items but they looked ok.  But you never know till you try.

CASH ONLY.
author: Dennis C.

description: It's no wonder why the lines are so long at this San Franciscan institution for baked goods.  If you're a fan of egg tarts, this is the best place for the fluffiest egg custard in a crispy shell in the city.  However, be prepared to pay at least a buck per egg tart.  Some other goodies to try include: pineapple buns and curry puffs.
author: Jenny L.

description: If you want a really good egg tart done right, get it from here! It's worth the drive and wait!
author: Jenny N.

description: so sad. it was closed on the tuesday I came here!! I was about to bring home a dozen of these on the request of my mother :(
author: Dixie L.

description: The gold (ha!) standard for SF Asian bakeries, renown for  their egg tarts. Downside? Anti-camera establishment! They wouldnt let me take a photo :( Long lines too.  Get in line, load up, and get out.
author: Allen C.

description: The hype.... yes it's legit. But for some reason their famous egg tarts seams a bit smaller now since they have came back from their last vacation. Anyways, the warm egg custard filling along with the flaky crust are yumm. At $1.35 a piece is on the pricey side, so make sure you consume some immediately while it is warm to get your moneys worth. BEWARE if you go on a weekend, be prepared to wait in a line. If you get lucky, only a few minutes.
author: Steve T.

description: Likes: tried one of their famous egg tarts and it was warm and delicious, also inexpensive
author: Karen M.

description:
Now I am really curious about this place! Is there a wiki page for this bakery? I want to know the history and how this all came about. 
I finally stood in line to get an egg tart. Yes it is good. Yes it makes you feel like it was worth the wait. Try it.

There are random days they might be closed,  just because.That was always my impression. If you order a dozen sometimes it wont be available . Only bet on getting 1 or 2 for sure
author: Veranna N.

description:
When my sister got married we order 500 dollars worth of pastries.  Man, are they good or what because even the Westerners love them.  They took some home too.  The Walnut cookies are what most people like.  The egg tarts are awesome, but I still like portugese egg tarts which they don't have.  I'm a fan of sponge cakes, but I don't like their sponge cakes here because it's flavored in lemon.  I like the regular egg flavored sponge cakes.  Oh yeah, you should try their curry pastries, my husband loves it and their walnut cookies. 

Don't expect good service, but expect a line.  Cash only.  One more thing, they are pricey.
author: Joelle C.

description:
Yummy, wholesome, flaky egg tarts...and the coconut tarts!!! 

My wait last time was 45 minutes, but bought like 3 dozen to take back to LA.
author: Calvin Y.

description: So gooooooddd!! I got lucky and didn't have to wait in a long line. The egg one is so good! Get like a dozen when you go here.
author: Jeffrey K.

description: Very good egg tarts, also good sesame balls, but overall I think it is overrated
author: Sasan A.

description:
EGG TARTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!

These are amazing here...i've never ordered anything else, nor do i want do. Give me tart or give me.....hahah. Love it
author: Justin N.

description: This place hands down the best egg tart you can find. Line is always long, but well worth it. Order at least a dozen to make up the long wait :)
author: kevin z.

description: As with everyone else, I come here to get their egg custard tarts. They are so delicious! The crust is always flaky, yet not too messy. The custard tastes divine. There does tend to be a long line out the door to get these, but since you expect it, it's no biggie. When you get to the front of the line, just buy a lot to make it worth your while. :)
author: Mary D.

description: Came to this bakery back in 2013 and it was on vacation.  Checked them out again and guess what they are on vacation again.  My relatives tell me the owners make so much money they open n close when they feel like it.  I'll stick to Lee's custard pie when I go home to Honolulu.
author: Hawaiian G.

description:
WTF, how could a dan tat (egg tart) taste this good?!

Couple nights ago, I finally got to tried the most legit dan tat in my life, ever. It was late at night so I tried to refrain myself from eating. But then, my friend came over and bought me a dan tat. Needless to say, "I'll just have a bite" didn't quite work out. I finished 3/4th of one. The crust is so flaky and buttery, and the custard was so creamy - just melted in my mouth like butta!!

CAN I PLEASE HAVE ANOTHER ONE WITHOUT GOING TO CHINATOWN AND WAITING IN RIDICULOUS, LONG LINES?! I'm craving for one. Or maybe even two.
author: Annie S.

description:
Customer service?  Really?  Come on, it's an Asian place... and an old school Asian place at that.  They don't really need to worry about customer service...

Plus, you're not here trying to make friends with them.  You want the egg custards.  Get about a dozen for yourself and maybe another dozen for your friends so you can share and they don't call you greedy and you're done and DONE!!!

Plan on getting here early so you get them fresh out of the oven but if you don't, expect a wait!!!
author: Penn T.

description: Pretty much what everyone else is saying. Best egg custards on the planet. Enough said.
author: Justin N.

description: Honestly I think most people shop by there are totally Tourist , if you are smart enough then you can tell how many people in line are from Local. Come on! Similar Chinese bakery in Stockton street, which  is just a block from there ,is weight much cheaper, and even better quality! That's just for tourist ! Come on!
author: Babebaby Z.

description:
I drive from San Jose for their baked goods. 

I drive from Davis for their baked goods.

I stand in the line that runs down the block for their baked goods. 

And when they're sold out at at 2pm on a Wednesday, I place my order, take a walk and come back in 45 - 50 minutes for their baked goods. 

It's good. Everything is good. 

On a side-note, because Mr. Man wearing the ed hardy sweatshirt, cap and jeans, ahead of me in line felt compelled to scream his order at the grandma behind the counter. The ladies work hard and the bakers work even harder, and I know for daaaang sure that they've brought more happiness to this world with their custard tarts alone than you ever will; so BE NICE!!!
author: B D.

description:
There is a reason why people are willing to wait in line. The fact is that this bakery makes really good pastry. Top on the list would be the egg tart.

First, the shell of the egg tart is made from  puff pastry. Secondly, the filling is very light and cream but not to sweet. I always come to get egg tarts here. It is really rare to find a place that makes egg tart with such quality.
author: Christopher W.

description:
SOO dang good. 

Sure, I doubted the long line, but after one taste of the dan-ta and the "Mexican cake", I was sold. We went twice that afternoon and bought a TON. 

Everyone is so nice, too!
author: Tsou D.

description:
Mom.. again!!?? I hate going to Chinatown!!! It's sooooooooooooo BOOOOORRRRRINGGGG...

When I was a little girl, I used to come down to Chinatown regularly with my mom and brother. Me and my brother followed my mom for what seemed like hours, trekking up and down the hills of Chinatown as she scoured for fruits, veggies, and misc groceries. We waited patiently, toting those pink and white plastic baggies as she shopped. I hated fighting the crowds of anxious shoppers hunting for the cheapest greens and fruits,  the workers shouting out their deals, while the tourists taking in all the smells, sights, and noises moseying along.. where everyday seemed to be a never-ending parade. 

The one highlight was stopping by Golden Gate bakery for an afternoon snack before the ride home. There was no line or craziness like there is now. You could just walk in, order, take a seat, and enjoy their infamous dan tat.

3 reasons why this is the best dan tat: 
1. EGGY CUSTARD goodness with just enough wiggle and jiggle in its custard. 
2. The right tint of YELLOW-just how an egg custard should look, you know? Not those bootleg ones that look orange. 
3. All wrapped inside a FLAKY, crispy, crunchy tart. The messy kind of crust that leaves a mess of crumbs all over your lips and mouth, clothes, and car (if you can wait that long). That's the kind of messy I like. 

All in all, a perfect little tart. 
And every tart is served warm, which adds to just how delectable this tart is. YOU NEED TO EAT IT WARM. If for some reason you have enough self control to wait, reheat in the toaster oven.

Note: They like to take long vacations at random times and will just post a sign on the door saying they will be gone for several weeks.
author: Angela W.

description: On our trip to San Francisco, I stood in line at this bakery not knowing what to buy or expect. The ladies inside were very helpful and very nice, I bought 5 egg tarts and this bread with a red dot on top, so so good. I wish China town was near me in San Diego :( if you like egg you will love the egg tart, I don't like eggs and I loved them, I just sprinkled a little sugar on top. And the other one tasted like coconut but the texture was awesome, I have never had anything like this. This place is a must. Take cash.
author: Maria S.

description:
I love custard tarts, and Golden Gate Bakery is by far the best, and usually there's a line just to get into the store to get the flaky morsel.

Absolutely love their custard tarts!
author: Alex C.

description:
The egg tart is pretty special! Get ready for the long wait, bring a friend or a book along, you'll have to wait!  But you won't regret it, mmmm freshly baked egg tart... 

The store's other baked goods are pretty tasty too... So order a lot when your turn finally comes...
author: Anette N.

description:
I have had a lot of egg tarts in my day but this place was good and affordable. 

Get the dozen its worth it, and maybe not enough. 

The white sugar sponge clear cake was delicious too, and the brown multi-piece square cake was really goo but hard. 

Everything was so fresh it was mind boggling.
author: Sanora A.

description:
I found this place because some friends from out of town mentioned it, so I decided to check it out. 

Let me be the first to say that I am not very knowledgeable in Asian delicacies (specifically sweet buns, tarts, cakes, muffins, etc), however I do know when something is pretty darn tasty. 

When you arrive at this location you'll notice that it's just a simple shop inside Chinatown with a line going out the door. Yes! A big ol' line that took about 20 minutes for us to conquer before even entering the store. The fact that there's a line usually means that something of HIGH QUALITY is at the end of it - and yes, this was the case. 

I bought myself this muffin-like bread and this coconut flaked, vanilla cream filled pastry of amaziness! I spent 20+ minutes in line just to buy two pastries and I was out the door within 5 minutes, and the pastries were BOTH gone in about 10 minutes. And let me tell you, I would gladly go back into that line, wait 20 minutes again, JUST to have another pastry. It was amazing!! 

The cream was authentic (not fake frosting), the bread muffin thingy was so soft and tasty that I couldn't help buy devour it all. The wait is worth it! 

The one thing I learned about some places: if there is a line of people waiting outside - it's probably something worth your time, or in this case, worth the extra calories. :) 

Please go and try it out. 

Oh...and don't let the outside rundown look of the store deter you, because like the old saying goes "it's what's on the inside that counts".
author: Alfred B.

description:
Long lines mean good food, right? Well it certainly does here. The Golden Gate Bakery never disappoints in my opinion. 
 
You have to try the egg custard tarts - probably the best on the planet - try to get them  when they come from the oven. You get all gooshy inside just like the tarts from feeling so so good after the bite/chew/swallow cycle goes down. They are simply amazing.
author: Regan A.

description: There is always a long line here.  If you happen to be in china town, u should stop by and pick up a warm egg tart!
author: Tiffany H.

description: One of the BEST finds in SF so far. Egg custard tarts are my favorite dim sum dessert and I can truly say that I have never had one as flaky, delicate and scrumptious as this. The line can really be a killer but absolutely worth it (if under 45 minutes and you have some extra time to kill). A must try for all dan tat lovers!
author: Ming C.

description:
Egg custard tarts are one of my favorite snacks if made right and the ones here are excellent. All the ones I've ever eaten here have always come straight out of the oven which just tells you how quickly the inventory turns over. The flaky pastry melts in your mouth and the filling is not too sweet and and has the perfect consistency. It is not runny and there's no crack in the center. They are picture perfect! 

Yes prices here are higher but well worth it. For a dozen, expect to pay $13.20. If you buy them singly, they are $1.15. Most other bakeries sell them for around $0.80. I've been here mostly in the afternoons and the lines are never long - less than 5 people. The ladies all speak some English. I ordered a dozen that came out steaming from the oven. When they were packaged in the pink box and secured with the ribbon, they tipped up the corners of the box to allow the steam to escape so that the flaky tart shells would not get soggy. Nice touch!

Why didn't I give them 5 stars? Because my second favorite snack to eat are the sesame balls and the two that I got looked great in the window but the dough was gummy and the shell did not have a crispiness to it. For a basic Chinese snack these should have been better.
author: Lily L.

description:
OMG everytime I come to SF, I have to , HAVE TO, stop by here. 
Favorite items:
1. EGG TARTS- must try!!! Best I have ever had!
2. Coconut Macaroons- I am not a fan of macaroons, so only bought 5 for my bf, when I came home, he insisted that I try it, AN BOY DID I REGRET GETTING ONLY 5. Sweet, crystalized coconut with a soft buttery center..... MmmMmmmm I'd drive 45 minutes just for this.
3. Coconut tarts- Very good, I get it every now and then.
4. Banh Lo Tai Heo- I don't know the English translation of this, only Vietnamese, but they are the bags of chips with the brown and white swirls, thin and crispy, not thick like other places. My family loves them!

TIPS- There's always a line, no matter what time of day. I hate that they close for a month during the Moon Festival season, but I hear they have the best moon cakes and people order them months in advanced!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
This is just for the dan ta (cause isn't that why people come here?) 

Ever since I was little, my mom used to yell at me for only eating the egg part. This has not changed. 

You know, how there's a thin layer of liquidy goodness on the egg part? Well at this place, it's a pretty thick layer. The egg part for some reason is not as firm as other places. I'm not sure if this has to do with the freshness. The crust is flake-y and pretty buttery. But what makes their egg cupcake so delicious is definitely the egg part.   

Usually I get my dan ta at dim sum places or Sheng Kee Bakery. There's just no place that compares, hands down. 

in the spirit of Chinese pride:  A++ uhhh...
author: Amy W.

description:
pretty good for being so cheap. 
taste is average; i've had better egg tarts...
but it is worth its price! 
lots of custard, crispy shell, but don't try to stuff it in your bag and take it on a plane because #1 the oil from it seeps through the paper bag, so double ply with plastic, and it gets crazy squished and smooshed. same flavor though, but maybe a little soggy haha. and this is the reason why i could not deliver the egg tart to my sister, who is an egg tart fanatic. 

if you are looking to buy some before it closes... they run out earlier in the day so don't even bother.
author: Erica S.

description:
what's all the hype about?

it's just an egg tart. sure, it has more of the yellow goodness in the middle and it's warm... but it's not worth the 20-30 minute wait and the price. 

i also had the white sugar pastry and the red bean mochi. it was OK at best. def not worth teh wait.
author: Robert Y.

description: I'm going to make this short because there have already been 1700+ reviews and mine probably won't get read.  I love these egg tart especially when they come out fresh even though it burns my entire mouth.  There have been a couple comparable ones in Chinatown which are a little bit cheaper, but this place is still the best place to go for egg tarts if you're willing to throw down a lot more money.  The line is always super long and the owners love taking vacations.  Who says you can't spend your money if you own a restaurant?
author: Steven S.

description: Amazing! But everytime I take my fiancee up to SF, this store is on vacation for like a week.
author: Amy V.

description: Went here just for the egg tarts and I have to say, they are pretty darn good. Compared to the other egg tarts i've tasted, this one leans more to the milky side, but the flavor is still really nice. And the crust lies between a flaky and cookie crust which give it a nice balance. Definitely a one of a kind egg tart and a must try at least once!
author: Tasha T.

description: If you never try the egg tart at Golden Gate Bakery, you must! This bakery is so busy each time when I go to Chinatown. Even if I have to wait, it's worth it. The flaky puff is so crispy and the filling is not too sweet. It's perfect!  Each time I go to the city, I try to swing by Chinatown to get at least a dozen, but the last two time I went, they were on vacation. I was very disappointed that they were close.
author: Connie W.

description: We didn't really understand the hype with this place. I took two bites of the egg tart and it tasted like a scrambled egg pastry to me...not really my thing. You can walk into just about any other restaurant in Chinatown and get the same thing.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
Well, Yelp was certainly right -- it's the best egg custard tart I've ever eaten. Why? Because it's HUGE and oh so fresh! For $1.15 you get this delicious chinese dessert that is about 3 inches in diameter and somethin like 1 inch thick of warm, just-sweet-enough, ooy-gooy, yumilific custard -- popped fresh out of the oven! 

They do NOT skimp out on the custard! Most amount of custard I've EVER had in one of these things!

Now on to the warm, flaky crust...omg it's flaky good! Like...it's the kinda crust you wanna make a whole pie out of! Though..there is a down side -- it's a tad bit oily...

I also tried the Lotus Seed Cake for $1.60ish -- it was packed with lotus paste scrumdidiliumptiousness and also nice and flaky, but I wish it were served warm.

I will certainly be back! 

*NOTE*: At about 2:30pm on a Thursday, there was a line which took about 10 minutes (I'd imagine it would be even longer in the evenings and weekends), but the ladies at the counter have it down! They're very efficient!
author: Gail N.

description:
After my grandfather retired and closed his dim sum shop, this was the next best place to get a dan tat.  I remember when one cost as much as a certain over inflated Swiss cheese like rapper.  
Most times when I walk by the place is closed for vacation or there is an obscene line -  they really need a velvet rope policy during the weekends.  

Today, I had a lunch meeting in Chinatown they were not on vacation nor was there a line.  Score.

I bought a dozen fresh hot egg tarts.  It took all my will power not to dig into the silky custard immediately.  GGB has mastered the art of a moist custard with a flaky crisp tart crust.  There is nothing worse than a soggy dan tat.  

As anticipated, I was hugely popular at my meeting.
author: Monica L.

description:
Long lines (today I waited 40 minutes) and a language barrier do not impede me from getting yummy treats from this bakery.   Treats come out of the oven regularly so you can eat something fresh & hot out of the oven.

My favorites are the custard Napoleons....and my friend Scott W. swears by the Pineapple cakes (which apparently they either stopped making or ran out of--we couldn't understand which). 

I like the Chinese ladies that frequent this place.  The ones that speak English are very helpful when it comes to translating for the bakery staff.

They were also out of Bao this trip and I want to go back and try some of their savories.
author: Katharine A.

description:
Egg tart! or is it a custard?

Though I am not really into pastries I have to admit the egg tarts here are damn good. I prefer them better when they are hot and not after refrigerating them. 

The place is pretty small and will go unnoticed if not for the line of people waiting outside. There is just a counter where they take your orders and then youre in and out. The wait is worth it though.
author: Andre W.

description:
We got lost, endured the stressful hills that make up the majority of the streets of San Francisco, managed to find parking, and found this placed CLOSED UNTIL 6/11. Such an anticlimactic moment. 

Fortunately, I ventured into SFO again today, and waited 20 min. on line, in addition to 5 hours (devoted to exploring SFO with cousin) before I was finally able to experience what many have deemed to be "the best egg tart of the US". 

As for the egg tart itself....pretty darn good...for an egg tart. I love egg tarts, but it's difficult for an egg tart by itself to blow me out of the water. Still, yay, I'm a fan. The crust is probably the best part (flaky and light, and not dense, as is the case for some places), and the custard itself is not bad-fluffy and has a kind of melt-upon-contact-in-mouth kind of thing going on that makes you question just exactly how much butter and/or egg went into making it.
author: Angela S.

description:
I'll recognize the bakery for making really good, fresh egg tarts, but yeah, it's a rip off. The line also takes way too long. 

But at least the hype for the egg tart is real. Eat it warm, and it's super tasty. The custard is sweetness and the flaky shell of the tart isn't too flaky to the point that it's dry. 

So I'd say try it once in your lifetime, and you'll be set. 

It's also right now just before the moon festival, so they have mooncakes everywhere. I've gotten their coconut cream bun here and it's super tasty but I couldn't find it this weekend. Not enough space so I guess they didn't bother. Aww. But I still got a pineapple bun, which I thought was okay. The top was toasted more than to what I like, but the bread itself was still good. 

Another time I came, they actually ran out of the egg tarts so beware! Sneak a peek inside to see their supply before you invest thirty minutes in line. 

Cash only.
author: Sally T.

description: Literally.  Hands down THE BEST egg tarts I've ever had in my life.
author: Jessica H.

description:
THE best egg custard place I have ever had. 

You need to eat it while it's hot - the custard will melt in your mouth. Absolutely orgasmic. 

I'm not sure about the other items. There's usually a long line, but it moves pretty fast. I would also recommending calling ahead to check if they're open that day, because I went a few times during their supposed opening hours, and they were closed.
author: Kimberly F.

description:
I have had many, many egg tarts in my life from a variety of places up and down CA, but I have never tasted any as good as Golden Gate Bakery's. Seriously.

Also try their "wife cakes"! My favorite.
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
One of the best dantat (egg tart) I've had. A lot of other places usually get the balance wrong, either, too much crust or too much egg. This one gets the balance just right. Also, it isn't heavy or greasy at all. Most of the time when I eat a dantat it feels like I just ate a donut.

The best part of Golden Gate's dantat would have to be the crust. It's flakey and has an awesome flavor. The egg custard isn't overly sweet either. The only downside is that it's a little pricey at $1.15 each. But when you're one of the best I guess you can charge that much.

I tried another custard filled pastry here too. It had the same quality as the dantat. Soft, airy, and not overly sweet. I didn't have any greasy stomach pains afterward.
author: Michael H.

description: Dan tat! We got there early before the lines. Ladies we friendly,and our daughters got o use their Mandarin. Dan tat,Wow! It does not get any better. A delicious custard tart in a flaky light crust for a buck.
author: Jack B.

description:
Oh Em Gee!! Daaaan Taaats! *drools*

Egg Custard Tarts here are THE BEST! Think of a flaky crunchy crust with warm and gooey awesomeness in the middle...(it's best fresh out of the oven! and trust....its worth the price and wait) The prices have gone up in the past years but damn, can u blame them?! If you're smart, it's really all about supply and demand. gotta milk it for what you know you can get them for.. smart Chinese people right here..not to mention probably stinkin' rich cuz of the egg tarts alone. 

Not a fan of custard?.....speaking from experience...their other buns and desserts are pretty bomb too!
author: Christina T.

description: There is always a long A** line here. And, the owner always goes to vacation in summers. Because of their best Egg Custards in Chinatown, line here is always long. I do not come here often, I would always wait in line for about 30 minutes and buy a dozen of egg-tard. The services here are not great. The owner is always mean to the workers there.
author: Evan L.

description:
My experience here was... abrupt.

My friend was dropping me off at a bookstore, and we were driving down Grant St. when all of a sudden she speeds to the side of the road, puts on her blinkers, leaves the car while saying "I'll be RIGHT back." Ummm... what? She RUNS into this bakery and I'm sitting there with the car running, pretty confused.

She comes back and says that this is THE BEST bakery in all of Chinatown, if not in San Francisco. She bought me a pork bun, and an egg tart to try. The pork bun sounded like something I'd like, but egg tart? Huh? Honestly, that doesn't sound appetizing at all to me. I don't even like egg that much.

I took a bite of the pork bun. YUM. Just as I expected. It was insanely good. A yummy buttery bun with pork inside. How do they do that?? I guess it's better not to ask, and just eat. Next was the egg tart. Boy was I wrong to judge that little treat. It was AMAZING. Like sweet custard pie. Not too sweet. Not really that much of an egg flavor, and the texture was just so creamy.

After doing a bit of research on this place, it's apparent that they are KNOWN for their egg tarts. Just go there, and give it a chance. I'd be surprised if you came out of there disappointed.
author: Ashley D.

description:
just reviewing the egg tarts like everyone else!

the place is so easy to get to, i walked alllll the way from bloomingdales in the rain!

luckily no crazy line, but your typical pushy chinese old ladies :(
i ordered 6 of them. 1.25 each or $15 for a dozen
i know they taste really good when fresh. its shell is flaky and light and buttery, the egg custard is what i think stands out the most.

i ate it hours later and it still tasted great. the custard is full of eggy flavor. salivating as i think of it. sigh should have bought more.
author: Christine M.

description:
After reading the reviews I waited in line in the cold. There were numerous people behind me praying they wouldn't run out of the egg tarts. 

I was able to get some but was disappointed. They're essentially flaky pastry tarts filled with egg custard. Don't know what the fuss is about. The pastry is good but I wouldn't line up for it.  

Also got date moon cakes and these are awesome!
author: Haris H.

description:
"Best egg tart this side of the Mississippi." Said the tiny old Asian lady in her think Chinese accent, while we waited in line. She would end up buying several boxes worth, close to a hundred tarts. I would manage to place an order for one.

 I've been back many times since. She was right.
author: charles t.

description:
Ok....Not many places that a Chinese person would throw down over a dollar for a custard tart but we stand in line with all the tourists and people that drive from out of town to chow down on the custard goodness right out ot the oven.
Virginia is the owner and she speaks English, and several chinese dialects along with Spanish.  Yes you heard right, she and her family can bake (her brother owns Eastern Bakery) and take your money with a friendly smile and say thank you in many different languages.
author: Curtis L.

description: Not a mooncake fan, tried their pineapple mooncake and it was way too sweet! Minus one for that but gotta give it up for egg tarts!!!!! The custard part was just right not too sweet, it was even better after the super sweet mooncake! Best part of this eggtart was the crust! It was put all together, doesn't break when I pick it up, and has a nice crunch to it! Waited 1 hour on a wrong day, moon festival right in front. It was worth the wait!
author: Jane S.

description:
Sugar... and fat.  My two greatest loves in this culinary world.  There are just 3 things I have come across that have paired the two in a face-melting, brain-shutting-down, manner...

First, the meyer lemon cream meringue at Chez Panisse (the lemon creme tart at Tartine, a close second).  Not only sweet and lusciously fatty, but masterfully incorporates the perfect amount of tart as well.

Second, an elegant, eye-popping slice of cake from Extraordinary desserts in San Diego.  The only "American-style" cake-maker that uses butter cream and rich cocoas that aren't overly sweet for my taste.

And then... there is the Egg Tart at Golden Gate Bakery.  No perfectly constructed mounds of fired meringue... no decorative floral arrangements vying for your attention... just a simple circle of the most delicious dan ta I have ever tasted.  Crisp and flaky shell, warm rich, egg custard, no hardened custard "skin" to skim off the top.  A must try in SF for sure.
author: Virginia L.

description: If you love coconut macaroons this is the place!!!  We bought 6 and went back for 2 dozen more to take back home. The custard tarts were a huge hit too and will make great gifts.
author: Jeff M.

description: Went there just for the egg tarts after reading about it on Yelp. Yes, it was delicious!
author: Annie S.

description:
egg tart from this small Chinese bakery is my fav dessert of the entire universe~ its crust is baked so flaky but the egg part remains tender and soft. the combination of the two puts forth it's aroma of wholesome goodness~~  

the fresh from the oven egg tarts are the best.  but since i travel from LA,  i always bring two dozens home.  this thing is so delicate so i gotta put the boxes on my laps to make sure "my treasures" will not collide with each other through out the trip.  and i will leave the box slightly open so the crust will not get moist and lose its texture.

i visited this bakery every single time i traveled to SF.  but not every single time i got to eat my treasures because sometimes they close the shop for weeksssssss without any notice...  :(
author: Pheel W.

description: Best Chinese style egg tart in Nocal period!
author: Bill z.

description:
I wasnt planning on a stop here during a recent chinatown jaunt (see review of red bean tart at another locale).  I then stumbled across the line at this place (only 7-8 ppl at 6pm).  

I quickly typed it into yelp on my phone and saw all the reviews, so I felt dinner reservations be damned, I need to get in line.  I had the famous custard tart.  I have to say it was worth the hype.  It was hot fresh from the oven (probably because of the volume they do).  It was definitely the highlight of my walk through chinatown.  The flavor and texture were great, it was cheap, and did I mention it was fresh and hot.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I CRAVE their egg tarts!

If the line is long...wait! The egg tarts are so good I could have 3 or 4 of them in one sitting. The crust is out of this world and the filling is sweet but definitely not too sweet. And they are usually hot and fresh...simply the best time to eat them.

My husband introduced me to this place and now everytime we are even near Chinatown I make him stop so we can get them.

Okay, no more talking about them, I am am starting to drool.
author: Donna S.

description: Delicious egg tart. Fluffy filling in middle and flaky thick crust. Quality of pastry is their. Price was worth pay for it. If you love egg tart would recommend go here and get some. Would come back here. Cons is frequently close for business since they do good business and when open long line but worth wait in line for it.
author: Gruber T.

description:
These egg tarts are really really good. I've tried many egg tarts, but this is the bomb! Maybe it's because it's fresh out of the oven that makes it extra delicious (it seems like they come out in several batches of the day) or they give you lots of egg custard that melt in your mouth...maybe all of the above, but you gotta try it if it happens to be your lucky day and they're open for business.

Yea, minus 1 star because they have some mysterious opening hours like they close early without notice or they go on vacation for months at a time. Their limited business hours make it hard to get one, but I guess a successful business doesn't need to try that hard to lure its customers.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I've been here a bunch of times and 4 of them had been ultimate fail. Twice they were closed, on vacation, once they ran out of egg custard, once the line was so long I just said eff it.  With that said, unless you are already in the area for something else and can swing by, I would call them to see if they are open before making the trek out there. 

Additionally, it is possible that you may get yelled at by one of the old ladies, both there and on the phone.  The problem is their egg custards are bomb....and they know it- so combine that with an old chinese lady and it becomes lethal.

So I take the yelling, random store closures, and long lines because the egg custards (dan tat) really is THAT good.  When it is fresh out of the oven, it is extra yummy- nice and warm.  They crust is flakey and crunchy and the egg is soft, non greasy, with the perfect hint of sweetness. Mmm mmm.  I also tried the coconut custard, coconut mochi like pastry with peanut butter filling, and white cake with lemon spread- all very good.  The coconut tart has similar crust to the egg tart but with toasty coconut filling.

This deliciousness comes at a steep price.  The egg tarts are $13 for a dozen or $1.15 each, which is pretty steep as you can get them for $.60 at other pastries, but of course they aren't as good.  Also, as with most other stores in Chinatown, it's cash only.
author: Krystal C.

description:
Really good baked pork buns and really really really good curry turnovers.  My husband and I had 3 each, standing by a lamp post.  I grew up Chinese (not that I'm not nowadays) and eating in the street, especially Grant, is a no-no.  Oh well.  The turnovers were so good.

I got a message from someone... I forgot to mention the excellent don tat!!! The best.  I had 4 of those.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
RUDE. & EXPENSIVE

Egg tarts are not the best I've ever had. People just like it cause it has a lot of the custard filling. $1.25/tart.. I'm telling all you people that 1.25$ can buy you AT LEAST 2 custard tarts at other bakeries. 

Other items there are just average. You can go to many other places in Chinatown that have better bread.

Very rude people which annoyed me the most. 
1.) they go on vacation whenever they want and they go pretty often. Bad business model. 
2.) my friend coughed in his sleeve/elbow and they complained  and told him to turn around when there was no food in front of him. and I see the woman rubbing her nose. gross
3.) they are so rude, if you dont speak chinese, they give you attitude. This girl behind me forgot her custard tart because they didn't tell her that she needs to wait for the other women to pack it and the women there were just talking smack about the customer. They were also rude to my friend because she pointed at something and it wasn't what she wanted and the lady started mumbling chinese smack talking and I understood what she said. 
4.) lady next door would rudely ask you to move and make a U line so that you wont block her store. There isn't even room to make a U, I get why shes mad, but wow. RUDE.
5.) I ordered 2 custard tarts and they were like "thats it?"
author: Erica L.

description:
The best egg tart ever.  Even better when you get it still steaming hot! My dad lost a crown off his tooth a couple years ago from one! Be careful!
So good that I couldn't wait 'til dessert time... my grandma caught me eating one outside NewAsia before I was supposed to meet her for dinner!  It was still warm, so I had to indulge!
If a tart ever makes it home with me, I microwave it for 30 secs and then toast it in the toaster oven to make the crust crispy.
author: Melissa F.

description: I read on yelp that they had the best custard tarts, so I decided to give them a try. The reviewers were right! The crust is thin and crispy and the custard (there's a lot of it!) has great texture. The price is pretty good too. They're $1.35 a piece and $16.20 for a dozen (if I remember correctly), which doesn't really give you a discount for buying in bulk, but w/e.
author: Sado S.

description:
Make sure you know what an egg tart is before getting excited about this place and you wait in line for an hour with a child-like giddiness and heart pounding exhilaration. (Well... I only waited 15 minutes, but I thought my heart was going to explode with anticipation of trying their egg tart.)

Probably the best egg tart/custard I will ever have because more than a thousand yelpers had said so, and I believe them. Yelp has not failed me 99% of the time. But I was stupid... I should've known what an egg tart was in the first place. It turns out that I am not a big fan of egg tarts. But their moon cake was good.
author: Lina S.

description:
Got four words for ya,

HOT EGG CUSTARD TARTS.

The best. Lard crust, silky filling, the best of the best of the best.
Be prepared to wait out the door, though, up to 15 minutes. And have a sesame ball while you wait; it's crispy.
author: Y K.

description: Custard tarts have a rich filling, flaky crust, pricier than at other places.  Be prepared to wait in line for these tasty treats.  Small bakery can easily fill up with a handful of customers.
author: George L.

description: My favorite place to get dan tat. I've been going here for years, and after going to Hong Kong, in the states, Golden Gate is the closest thing they have to the motherland. The prices have definitely gone up over the years, but it's worth every penny and every second you have to wait. But be smart, go on a weekday and at an off time. Don't get anything else, just get the darn dan tat.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
The longest wait I've had ever waited for some egg tarts. Came here for some egg tarts with friends and waited in line. It took about 40 minutes because there was a line all the way by the person who sells random things outside. Had to use the bathroom so I left my friends to search for one and I hate S.F. because there's practically signs everywhere stating "restrooms for customers only!" asked a few places and got turned away. Was gone for awhile i knew that and came back; still gotta wait in line.. but I just handed my money to my friend to buy me some because I wanted to look around at other shops. Finished looking around and still not done because the people in front of the line ordered around 6 boxes of pastries. Also they ran out of egg tarts so we had to wait for some freshly made ones which is a plus for us, but their egg tarts are always fresh since there's so many people desiring it.
+2 for the egg tarts
+2 for the egg tarts
and 
+1 for the egg tarts
havent' tried anything else but they looked delicious
author: Dave Y.

description:
So I'm giving this bakery just 4 stars because they lack major efficiency behind the counter!   We were there in line long enough to see Chinese women fighting over the line!!  I knew this place was authentic :-D  So it didn't help that it is also lunar festival because the line was full of locals and tourists I'm sure waiting for both delights.  The line was full of Chinese people so at least I felt validated for waiting the whole hour, my fiance doesn't like crowds and he says the dan tart was super yummy and therefore worth the wait. 

 I'm just glad now, looking at all the other reviewers, that I only waited 1 hour.  The line was down the block and hairpinned to the entry way.  The line definitely caused a spectator slow down, the local Chinese ladies peddling their wares near by were upset the line was blocking their business, hehe.  I'm sad we only bought 6 egg tarts, I dream of them now and look forward to more in November when we return.  We felt obligated to get mooncakes since we were in line so long, our parentals will have to be the judge of those.
author: Mae-Lae L.

description: Yes, the line seems to be getting longer and longer, but it's well worth the wait. Hands down the best Don Tots (egg custard tarts) ever. They're lighter than most and perfectly sweet. Also, try the Cha Sui So (BBQ pork wrapped in pastry). Less popular than the egg tarts, they are a highly underrated favorite. So delicious!
author: CJ J.

description:
My FAVORITE Chinese bakery :)

This is a family owned business. I have been going there since I can remember. Be aware that there is always a line out the door. 

I love their don tots (egg tarts) especially. Baked perfectly and piping hot from the oven.
author: Jaime L.

description:
If you walk past a bakery with lines down the block, YOU BEST GET IN LINE TOO, especially if the lines has residents of SF along with tourist. The wait is bearable as long as you keep the mind on the prize, that warm, sweet, eggy, flaky tart! Once you get inside you will be in a very small space with Chinese people so be prepared. It is very easy to work with the ladies behind the counter, just state your order, pay and be on your way. There is no point of making it complicated considering you spent at least 30 minutes in line already. I know now a days bakery are trying to buy with presentation. That is not the case here. The egg tarts come in a pink box that they cut two ventilation holes at the top. They are separated by a paper plate and the box is wrapped by red ribbon. Everything is very basic, the same way they did it years ago. The only difference is that the price goes up, last time I went it was $1.35/tart I believe.  It would help if you brought a Cantonese speaking friend but that is not necessary. 

Good things comes to those that wait. So be prepared to wait in the SF cold.
author: Amy G.

description:
Red Bean Mooncake... NOM NOM NOM! Chinese bakeries in Sacramento only offer these during the moon festival but as expected, every bakery in Chinatown has it all year! 

Decided to check out Golden Gate Bakery based on Yelp reviews. As usual, finding parking in that area is nearly impossible. I suggest saving yourself the headache, time and gas by using the parking structure on Jackson (pass the bakery on Grant Ave. and turn left at the next block. Parking will be on your right hand side. ~$2.50 per half hour.) Also, remember to have cash as they don't accept credit cards in this bakery. Conveniently, Chase and Citibank are located across the street. 

Now back to the mooncakes. You can choose from a handful of filling selections including some with egg yolks inside. I got several red bean mooncake for $5.15 each (only comes in large sizes--no minis) and got out of there with a big smile on my face. The filling was perfect; not overly sweet. Never noticed it with other mooncakes made from other bakeries but the ones from Golden Gate had tiny pieces of nuts (off white) in it. Unnoticeable unless you look closely but a definite no-no for people with peanut allergy. 

Glad I found this place. Definitely will be coming back for more mooncakes throughout the year.
author: Yan S.

description:
I agree with everyone else - this is definitely the place to get egg tarts! Having eaten at most dim sum joints around the Bay Area and being a egg tart lover, I place Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts as the "gold standard". Nowhere else has come close to it's greatness.

I've only experienced them being away last year during the month of July, which was depressing...couldn't get my fix after the SF marathon...

Overall, for you to get a taste of San Francisco - Chinatown you must try Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts!
author: Brad T.

description: I thought it was all hype. Then I took my first bite. Was it worth the long wait? No!!! Was it worth paying the guy in front the line 5 bucks to get me one to try? Yes. The line is ridiculous on the weekends. If you really want Dan Tat from here I suggest going on a weekday. Warm, flaky, sweet goodness and terrible service is why I love this place. It's Chinatown! What do you expect?
author: David W.

description:
Finally got me some famous egg tarts.

Gots me a box of 1/2 dozen tarts.

Egg Tarts. Noms. Though they are definitely not cheap! I think the ones at Ruby King Bakery in Oakland Chinatown are comparable. This was my 6th trek over to the bakery to get these egg tarts because it's always freaking closed these days. Waiting so long for them was highly disappointing, so I guess in that sense I don't really see how they are so famous.
author: Constance C.

description:
I've purchased egg custard  tarts, moon cakes and other items at Golden Gate at least 30 times over the past 34 years.  I consider these just  snacks, just cheap pick-me-ups to munch while I stroll.  A $1 pastry is not worth exercising the food critic mind into high heat. 

I've had better tarts and pastries elsewhere out in Sunset and Richmond neighborhoods.  And I've had a LOT worse items right in Chinatown & out in the Aves.  

If there's a long line at the door, skip it.  If you can walk in & easily order what you want, give it a try.  You might find something you like for 65 cents to $1.
author: Tom S.

description:
This place is one of my favorite bakeries!  The custard tart has a nice and flaky crust and the custard's soft and smooth with the perfect sweetness.  

My mom is actually a huge fan of their "Faguo Dangao" (you can ask for the French bread, though it's not really French bread).  It's basically a butterfly-ish top bun with a crusty sweet top.  The bread's really soft, light, and good with hot cocoa, coffee, etc.  Usually when I go here I get a box of that bread, but I believe they only have it only weekend in the afternoon to late afternoon.
