I also get one of those peanut-sugar mix filled mochi-like desserts, that is covered with coconut and has a green dot on top.  It's pretty good and I tend to get one of those every time I come as well.

The macaroons are also really good!

The desserts, bread, etc are all, in my opinion, really good, and coming here since I was a kid, I've never been disappointed.  Nothing's too sweet, and most of the time you can get stuff fresh outta the oven!  Mmmm.... tasty warm goodness!
author: Rachelle T.

description:
There is always a line outside of this bakery!

I was at the Moon Festival in Chinatown, so I decided to get some Asian pastries from this bakery.  There was already a line out the door with about 20 people, but I still got in it.  After standing in line for 1 hour, I finally reached the door..lol.  Looking through the window, I noticed a lot of the pastries were already sold out.  

After 20 more minutes, I finally got to put in my order with one of the servers.  I was only able to get sesame ball, and 'wife cookie'.  I really wanted to get egg tarts, but they were sold out.  When I was about to pay, I noticed 2 fresh egg tarts tray coming out.  I quickly ordered 1 dozen egg tarts.

The egg tarts are definitely great here.  The crust is nice and crispy.  The egg filling is delicous, too.  

There should be a number system for customers in line.  I noticed a lot of people sneaking into the store.  Some got yelled out, but others were able to purchase goodies.

Next time I see a line, I probably won't line up.  1.5 hour wait is a bit crazy for me..lol.  I'd rather get pastires from Sogo or Sun kee. =)
author: Rita V.

description:
Went here for a egg custard $1.15, but they were all out!  So instead I got a yellow bean moon-cake $4.95.  It was pretty good, as Pauline said, it was dense.  Reminded me of Pumpkin spices.  The line was kind of slow because the old people didn't know what they wanted.  This place always has a line which is good for them, but bad for us.   I will get there custard and let you know how it goes down.

Update:  I have now ate an egg custard and they are so delicious!  Now I know why there are lines here.  It all makes sense.  The custards are super flavorful and the crust is flaky.   A really good treat if you've got the money to spend.
author: Michelle M.

description: ERHMERGERD!! By far the BEST egg tarts I've EVER HAD. And I've had so many in my lifetime. Warm, flaky, custardy, sweet, gooey, soft, ADDICTING, "I've-only-had-one-and-I-already-want-five-more!"......
author: Tiffany L.

description: As long as you eat your dan taat fresh after buying it, worth the crazy wait (of if someone is picking some up for you =P).  But this is my favorite dessert besides a napoleon, so I'm always eager to get some. Being on the East Bay, Sheng Kee or any other bakery is just as good, as long as it's the pastry type.
author: Glen G.

description:
People living in SF are spoiled with great egg tarts.  It helps that the bakery is always so busy so the egg tarts comes out hot and fresh each time.  Maybe thats why their egg tarts are so good.  I had to wait 20-30 mins each time I come here.  

I was surprised that the customer service was really good, even though I am not Chinese.  Maybe looking Chinese helps?  I was buying a lot of egg tarts (a dozen for my family and like 6 or 7 more for my friends) and a bunch of other goodies.  The lady helping me was very patient and didn't rush us.  My sister and I have eyes bigger than our stomach and just pointed to anything that looks good.  I forgot to tell the lady to separate them into 2 boxes for me, my fault.  So I asked for her to give me another box so I can do it myself later since they were TOO busy.  She didn't understand what I was saying and I had to explain to her for like 1-2 mins and she INSISTED on separating the egg tarts and putting them into two separate boxes for me when I insisted on doing it myself cause they were too busy.  The egg tarts deserves 4 stars, but the customer service boosted it to 5.  =]
author: Tommy D.

description:
Came here because of all the good review on egg tarts. I ordered 1 dozen and it was really good! The size is big compare to most egg tarts that were sold else where, which means you get your money worth. It is $1.15 each and I think it is a very good price for knowing that you'll fresh hot egg tarts every time. 

I also tried the pineapple buns which was just so-so, a little too dry and hard. Definitely not as good as the egg tarts.

I come here when I visit SF and I have been getting 2 dozen of egg tarts every time.

If you live far from SF and still want to eat yummy egg tarts you can freeze them, just take it out thaw it and put in toaster oven.
author: Vivi C.

description:
Absolutely amazing egg tarts but the bakery as a whole is just average. This place really reminded me of a Sprinkles Cupcakes except that Beverly Hills is replaced by Chinatown. The reason for this comparison is that they are both very good but may get an undeserved amount of business based on their hype and reputation. It seemed like half the tourists jumped in line thinking that this place must be something special since its the only line in chinatown. I honestly feel bad for most of the tourists cause none of the tourists that jumped behind me ordered any egg tarts.The restaurant really should just rename themselves Golden Gate Tarts.   

I ordered a dozen of their signature egg tarts and they did not disappoint. I brought them back to the westfield mall and ate them with a liter of milk from Bristol Farms and they were the perfect combination. I really liked how they were huge and flaky without being too sweet.  These were by far the best egg tarts I have ever had, though my dad thought they were simply average.

I also tried their pork bun, coconut tart, and my favorite, the cocktail bun. The cocktail bun was disappointing. The bread was just so soft and there was barely any filling. The pork buns were average and the coconut tarts were almost as good as the egg tarts. I'll stick to nothing but tarts next time. I'll be back again just cause its so close to BART and Union Square.
author: Tim T.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! i always crave for their egg tarts and dont forget the baked pork buns! I live in San Jose now and have not found one place in SJ that has anything comparable to GGB. The egg tarts are just so moist and yummy! Not too sweet and the crust is just the perfect flaky consistency that makes the egg tart more enjoyable. 
As for the pork buns.....can't get better than this. They're a good size (not too small) and the pork on the inside is just so delectable. Not like other places where the pork is kind of dry. 

This place is definitely worth the drive. Be prepared to wait in line because they do get busy, especially on weekends; and sometimes they go on vacation for like a month at a time (happen to me twice when I drove the whole way to find out they were close on vaca).
author: Aliya L.

description: de Best "Egg Tart" in USA & de only place you can find "Coconut Tart" "Sesame Roll".... worth all the wait "No matter what" ! Those commented that "Rude! Bad service" I'm sorry.. folks! language barrier.. I found them really sweet and friendly... like home :-) Always love to come by whenever I visit the city!!!
author: Vincent W.

description:
This place was introduced to me by a friend that had exclaimed to me "You've never had "dan tat" from Golden Gate Bakery?!" I was intrigued at the quality he described.

RECOMMENDATION: Get the "dan tat" or egg tart. It's sweet and best eaten when you get it fresh. It's warm and gooey with a pleasant sweetness that will bring a smile to your face. It's a little pricier than other places in the area, but this is what you pay for quality.

ATMOSPHERE: People in line are usually friendly and just trying to get something sweet for their pallets just like you. The staff isn't very personal, but they're quick. The place is pretty small and there is only street parking close by with the exception of paid parking, but it's in SF Chinatown and that's to be expected of the area. Prepare accordingly.

WHY FOUR? There is always a line. This place is always busy and sometimes the staff can seem a little rushed because of how hectic it can get. Be patient, order your dozen or so "dan tat" and enjoy them. Don't worry too much about the wait, they're pretty quick.

CONCLUSION: I love sweet things and this place is a must if I'm even remotely nearby.

-TanK
author: Kevin T.

description: Wow. Their egg tarts are as good as any I've ever had. The other reviewers are not kidding! Great little bakery.
author: Francis C.

description:
A daan tat is a daan tat to me.  With that said, the egg custard tarts here definitely aren't bad but I'd rather save 35 cents and buy them from somewhere else.  Compared to other places, they seem bigger and contain more of the egg custard filling.  But I'm still hesitant to buy it for $1.15 each.  (That's partly due to the fact that one daan tat disappears into my stomach after about 30 seconds for me.  Hmm, is $1.15 equal to 30 seconds of joy??  Maybe.)

What I definitely wouldn't pay for again are their mochi items that they offer.  I ordered the ones with red bean as the filling.  Sure, they're larger than usual, but there's hardly any filling.  It's predominantly mochi.  And how much did I pay for them?  $1.35 each.  A bit overpriced, don't you think?  I can get 5 mini buns for $1.50 at another bakery in Chinatown, which would satisfy me a lot more!!  If it wasn't because I had a craving for them, I would not have gotten them.  What I do have to commend them on is the banana flavor that seems to be infused into the mochi parts.  

The last few times that I've come to golden gate bakery, there have been no lines whatsoever, despite what many seem to experience.  Maybe that's what makes the daan tats good.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
BLAH BLAH GET BLAH BLAH EGG BLAH BLAH TARTS. 

That's pretty much it. Egg tarts. Don't deviate and try to defy gravity, Wicked.

Read how this got on the 10 Best Eats from the 7x7 Big Eat Lists: http://abelin.net/the-10-7x7-big-eat-list/
author: Abel L.

description: I'm personally not a huge fan of egg tarts but the one that I tried here was actually enjoyable! It is best when eaten fresh out of the oven. I nearly burned the roof of my mouth on that thing! If you're a fan of egg tarts, definitely check this place out...all my egg tart fan friends love it! Also, don't be weary of the line...it moves fast!
author: Krystal N.

description:
I've been ball-n-chained to my cubicle these days, so thanks to Marc D's dan tat (egg custard tart) quest, I was inspired to escape momentarily to Chinatown for this prized treat.

Just as I ordered two custard tarts (I was going to give the other one away, but couldn't resist devouring both), I sp-eyed a mini-chicken pie.  They were all flakey, fresh, with delicious middles!

The lady who served me was sooo nice - she had a great smile the whole time! Now that's service!

**now back to the cubicle**
author: Cathy K.

description: Believe the hype, the dan tat (egg custard) is AMAZING! Perhaps the best I've ever had, ever. Why? The crust is the perfect amount of buttery flaky without being greasy. The custard was warm and sweet but not too sugary. It was so good that after my father-in-law ate one, he went right back and bought another one to eat. The jin dui, on the other hand, was not that great (hard, greasy). Bottom line: stick with the egg custard and you won't regret it!
author: Amanda Z.

description:
The bestest dan tat (egg custard tarts) in the Bay Area, hands down.  It's popular with the local Chinese community, and now that everyone knows about this place, the lines are even longer.  But that's ok you see, because it insures you that:

1.  You'll always get a fresh egg tarts, still hot out of the oven with golden flaky crust.

2.  The short pushy Chinese grandma happens to cut her way in front of you.

3.  You'll get a $45 parking ticket for your expired meter or not curbing your wheels.

But it's all worth it once you taste one of Golden Gate Bakery's freshly made egg tarts.
author: Dan C.

description:
Completely overrated and overpriced. The egg tart is good as the crust is just fluffy and soft. But, considering $1.25 for a small one like that, I would rather good to Napoleon, Washington or Anna's Bakery. They may not be as good as Golden Gate but the price is at least 1/4 less. If you are willing to go to Clement Street in Inner Richmond, go to Red A which sells $0.80 each and the size is bigger or go to Cherry Blossom which sells $0.85 and tastes just as good. Definitely, Coffee Cafe in Sunset sells cheaper egg tart with the same quality.

Their mooncakes are nice but waiting for more than an hour just makes me sour and cranky, not mention that mooncake is not something healthy to eat, too much fat and greasy.

I heard that the workers/owners are from the same family. They are still using old type management skill to run the store. Customer service is not something they believe. They are not friendly or are willing to offer help. Moreover, they have nobody to direct traffic during mooncake season. People cut in line and the workers always get the bill calculated wrong. I'm avoiding going there.
author: Roserrele W.

description: There's only a handful of places I would be willing to fall & wait in long lines for...this is one of them--well worth it for my LOVE of the BEST EGG TARTS!!!   The little individual pie crust is so light & flaky, and the filling is so moist & warm that it just melts in your mouth.  Whether you buy 6 pcs. or a dozen...they always come freshly made right out of the oven! The best part is that it even taste just as good, if not better served chilled! So what are you waiting for?!  Come & try it for yourself!  I guarantee you, you'll keep wanting for more ;)
author: Ann E.

description: The only thing I like about this place is cheap and most affordable pastry products with freshness. However, the deliciousness I rank for this place can not be higher than average. Everyone is talking about how good and tasty the egg tarts are. Seriously? Since I have been eaten so many deserts, cakes and pies. I could make them myself too so perhaps, my opinion may be different to the others
author: Hallie N.

description: Prepare to drool in a 20 min.+ line even though the sweet ladies inside pump out goods as fast as they can.  Those heavenly golden egg tarts are worth the wait every single time!
author: Michelle T.

description:
30-40 minute for an eggtart isn't much of a pain on the butt once you taste these egg tarts. These fluffy pastry on the outside and custard to perfection, eggtarts.

I can't speak for anything else because eggtarts are all I've had and I will ever want from this place. Hands down, the best eggtarts I've had anywhere else in the world. Please let me know if any place in LA area can beat this place in terms of eggtarts. PLEASE!
author: Cassandra S Y.

description: Awesome egg custards and the coconut macaroons are to die for!
author: Zach B.

description: When you mention dan tats to anybody who's Chinese, they will ask you, "Golden Gate Bakery in Chinatown?" If you don't reply with a "Yes" then they probably think you don't know anything about good dan tats. This is the place where every Chinese families go to buy dan tats when they visit family and friends. You can never go wrong with a dozen of these!
author: Edgar G.

description: Do they make anything else here besides egg tarts?  I have no friggin clue.  Do they need to?  No.  I agree with everyone else.  Delicious egg tarts.  This is coming from someone who was never really a fan before.
author: tom j.

description:
As if other reviewers haven't raved enough about this place... i HAVE to add my two cents just to show you how worthy this stuff is.

Call me crazy, but I missed my flight to LA just so I can stand in line for 30 minutes to grab a batch of their Winter Melon Mooncake ($7/ea) and 2 dozen egg custard to bring back to LA.  I told the lady in line I was traveling by plane and she cut two slits on the box and repackaged my baked goods so they would be travel-friendly.

Behold- when i arrived at home in LA and uncovered the lid, the mooncake and egg custards were still fresh! yum yum! My parents loved it and wanted me to bring back more next time! If only they knew how much trouble it took me...but it's all well worth it!
author: Shirley W.

description:
THE BEST DAN TAT IN THE CITY! 


Pros
Flaky crust, creamy warm custard.....


Cons
Over priced
They're ALWAYS on vacation
The line is crazy long


Do I buy them? Yup
Do I keep trying ..... Yup, that's why I know they're always on vacation
Do I wait in line... Who doesn't?


Will I continue to patron them.. Heck yeah!
author: Minie J.

description:
3.5 stars!
My aunt goes here all the time just for the egg tarts. This place is known for its egg tarts. They aren't too sweet but subtle in flavor. The texture is dense when you bite into it....hmmms I'd say its the texture of tofu but more dense and viscous. To me the egg tarts are to subtle to me and for some reason whenever I get them which is a lot, the crust/pastry part is always soggy. Even when I go to the store directly and buy it from them its always soft and not crispy like I want it. I like trying the other things there though as they have so much to offer. The coconut filled balls are very sweet and a bit overwhelming. The sponge cake muffin is yummy and soooo soft and fluffy it feels like you are biting into a cloud. MmmMMs hehe.


They usually have long lines of people so be prepared to wait for at least 15 mins-20 mins 

The prices are reasonable too
3.5 stars
author: Sofi P.

description:
On one fine day, I was innocently strolling the streets of Chinatown like the tourist that I am when I stumbled upon a long line trailing from Golden Gate Bakery.  My friend informs me that this is the home of "the best egg tart in San Francisco!"

I love egg tarts, so I built a bridge and got over my disdain for standing in long lines for extended periods of time.  I sucked it up and went to stand in that darn long ass line, which was on a very crowded sidewalk.  None of that cutting in line by sneaking in front of some unassuming old lady :(

Mmm, the egg tart here really is bombskiiiis for reals.  The custard is so rich and creamy.  And it's so soft like a baby's butt.  (But please don't be picturing babies' butts in your head as you're eating these, you sick sick pedophile!) All of that custard is encompassed by a yummy and flaky crust which can only be the result of using sh!t tons of pig lard; Paula Deen would be so proud, ya'll.  The egg tart tastes best when eaten warm, so try to eaten them ASAP after purchase!  SHO DEE-RI-SHUS!!!! GAH-LEN-TEED.

I bought two egg tarts for myself.  I greedily devoured the first one.  As I was about to take a bite out of the second one, it slipped from my butterfingers and fell to its demise to the dirty ground, custard-side down.  SPLAT!  There it goes!  What a tragedy; my heart shattered into a million pieces.  I didn't want to wait in that dreaded line again just for one egg tart, so I walked away with my head hung low and my pouty lower lip dragging along the concrete sidewalk.  Hmmph, party foul :( What's the penalty for that?
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Okay, an actual tear welled up when I returned to bite into my second egg tart from the now gone Lord Stowe's in HK.  (The first one was a revelation, the second one was a relief and wash of infinite joy.) 

Did I cry at GG? Almost...

Good thing getting to GG is rare, otherwise I'd be as wide as the GG.

...so very worth the wait... 

BTW, I have no idea what else they sell there... does it matter???
author: K K.

description: AH just had an amazing egg tart from Golden Gate Bakery... they're apparently on vacation so they were only selling egg tarts and a couple other pastries, whatever they had left before they "went on vacation" I guess. We got the first egg tarts out of the oven, and it was so hot I burned my mouth but so worth it. Perfectly flakey and creamy and surprisingly filling... one was enough for my brunch!
author: Vivian H.

description:
This small bakery shop bakes the best egg tart in the USA. Egg tart is actually the influence from Portuguese during colonization period. It started become popular in Hong Kong and Macau where east meets west. Cantonese is very well known for their skill on cooking. 

The crust is crispy as well as flaky and chewy and truly get along with egg custard which is melted on your tongue, creamy, buttery, not too sweet, and very aromatic.
author: Arnond S.

description: Whenever I'm in SF's china town, I try to stop by here. What else can be said? 830+ reviews and a 4.5 star average! I do wonder why they bother making things other than the egg custards...
author: Leo I.

description:
Absolutely lives up to the hype; absolutely worth the wait.

While the egg tarts are their famed specialty (and best when right out of the oven), their other wares give them a run for their money. Black bean cakes are rich and creamy, with a fair amount of bean, and the macaroons are absolutely to DIE for: crunchy on the outside, sweet and sticky on the inside.

I would wait for hours outside Golden Gate. Hours.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Sooo good.

Get in line and get a box of their egg tarts.  Don't even think about getting just one.

Freshly baked, so hot it burns your tongue!!  So be careful with that first bite!

The custard is just the right consistency and not too sweet or creamy.  

Then, share your new found treasure with others :-)
author: Rossini P.

description:
if you don't know about their egg tarts, you should be ashame...
if you do not order their egg tart when you are in chinatown and they are open, you should be even more ashame!..

best egg tart.. always hot.. always yummy..

the sesame ball was huge but it was just ok.. wish it had more red bean paste..
the wife cookie or "lou po penh" is big, flaky and tasty.. would order again..
author: Linda N.

description:
Wolfed down 4 egg tarts from here the other day. They were perfect: the edges of the crust were crispy and flaky, and the middle was fluffy, and just sweet enough not to be overpowering.

The other time I dropped by, I met what must have been the only shy Cantonese person in all of San Francisco Chinatown. I was buying steamed pork buns en masse (I think I got two boxes of twenty), and she managed to cajole me into getting another five, baked, with a shy smile at a slightly reduce rate. My only reason for bringing up this story is that prices here are negotiable, and you can probably chop off 20-30 cents per item if you buy many, or possess extraordinary charisma.
author: Daniel C.

description: 2 and a half stars! I don't see what the big deal is for this place. The egg tarts are good, but only because of the extra sugar and butter they use. You can't sit down to enjoy your tart, and the ladies behind the counter are major rude. I know a lot of bakeries have rude employees handling the food, but damn these ladies take the cake on bad customer service. Order quickly or be ignored.
author: Alex M.

description:
My friend got me half a dozen.  I ate it all in less than three days.  Even when its cold the dan tat is amazing.  

I also love how standing in line for these dan tat is pretty vicious.  Don't stand in the way of  Chinese ladies trying to buy dan tat.... they get really mean and will probably bite your head off.  

Eat your dan tat in front of the store before it gets cold.  It's the only way to roll, yO!
author: Anna T.

description: The dan tat is pretty good here - reallyyyy rich and custardy. Too bad I'm not that big of a dan tat fan :( I think that's pretty much what they're known for here, although Kenny says their moon cakes are good too! Dan tat's were 1.20 each so a little pricey, but a good place to take your friends if they love eating 'em ... plus a chance to check out Chinatown!
author: Rachel L.

description:
I've been hearing about this place from my  Aunts and friends all around the bay area and needed to see what all the fuss was about. I went to visit this place around 5pm on a Wednesday hoping that the egg tarts didn't run out yet. To my surprise, there was a bunch of egg tarts ($1.25 each) left and there wasn't even a line at all!!!! However, I wouldn't doubt that if you come earlier there would be a huge line down the block because their egg tarts ROCK!!!
I've been to A LOT of bakeries and Dim Sum places and this egg tart DOES NOT COMPARE..... The crust is super thin, light, and flaky (how it should be while other places are drenched in oil or super dense and buttery). The egg custard itself was ridiculously smooth and soft, I'm going to assume because its really eggs and not a whole lot of other stuff. BEST GOLDEN TREASURE EVER to land in my mouth. 
Expect it to be CASH ONLY since its in China Town and you know its a must try because Asian people are willing to wait in line. Next time I'll probably get other pastries (I came too late, most of their stuff sold out).
author: Emmellin T.

description: Good egg tart, $1.25 for one. Do not touch any cake when shopping if u don't wanna be yelled at.
author: HM H.

description:
I think these are the best egg tarts in the U.S.  I've had the ones from Tai Pan in NYC, and these trump those for sure.  

Another item to check out is the BBQ pork pastry, which usually sits on top of the glass counter top.  They are super good!  Heat them up in the oven so they are a bit warm, but also great at room temperature.  SO FREAKING GOOD!  I want one now...sigh.
author: Wendy S.

description:
Believe the hype. These custard tarts are the best custard tarts I have ever tasted. I can never go back to my 99 cent Sheng Kee Bakery egg tarts that are so conveniently there. I will trek through Chinatown and wait in line for these babies. I've tried a couple of times to get a taste of these tarts, but apparently I have horrible luck. Each time they were on a vacation and closed down the bakery. But finally on a gloomy and rainy Saturday afternoon, they were open and people were still lining up outside the bakery for the tarts. They even had a velvet rope for the line-goers that wanted to taste one of the 100 things to try before you die. Even some guy came up to us and said, "Is this place supposed to be that good?" Judging by the line, I'm pretty sure it should be decent.

But after waiting in line, we finally got our custard tarts and melon cakes. Freshly made and taken out of the oven and neatly packed into the nice pink box. Although it is a bit pricey, it's Chinatown first of all and this place can be considered a tourist destination. Rest assured, it will be all worth it once you have one.
author: Leslie K.

description:
Egg tarts to die for. 

Constantly crowded and lines out the door. The bakery is able to sustain itself with long and frequent holiday breaks, as well. So, catch them when they're open! The family-owned bakery has been around for a long time and they bake fresh batches of sweet and savory breads, cakes, pastries and cookies all day long. 

Other items to go for:
pineapple bun (plain or filled), lotus cake, curry pie.
author: Karen W.

description:
Again the sad news before the good...My friend from LA introduced me to this one too.

Their Dan Taat (Egg Custard Tarts) are the best ever! They're pretty rich n creamy though, so moderation is key (although, i could eat more than 4 by myself in a sitting if given the opportunity). I love the flakey crust...and if they're fresh out of the oven...man! talk about melt in your mouth!

They do have other baked goods, of course, including chinese rice crispy (ok, that's not the real name for it, but that's how i best describe it!...it kinda looks like a square brain...just point, or, they speak English there too...so you'll figure it out), the coconut filled bun, the pineapple crust bun..haha, yes. it tastes better than it sounds right now. and they also have moon cake! yay!

This is another place where there's always a line out the door. It's a small place in the middle of Chinatown...and the longest i've ever seen the line was out their door to the next stand's door...but they're also good at moving people in and out courteously. 

The Dan Taat's used to be a dollar, but now they're a bit more each...but ah, what can you do? Their the best and the economy sucks. This place is so popular and does so well that they can even have the luxury of taking a few weeks off for vacation a year (i found this out when i went there once and they were closed to my surprise...but good for them! they deserve it!).
author: N C.

description:
The BEST dahn tat (Chinese egg tarts) in the Bay Area. People become vultures when they pass by this bakery. It's nuts! If you haven't secured a spot in line yet, DO NOT go in there to check out the pastries. You'll get death stares from everyone. Just patiently stand in line and wait your turn to order quickstyle once you get inside. 

The banana roll is always awesome. Anything that comes out in the pink box from that bakery will leave your tummy wanting more.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
My first time here! I've heard so much about the egg tarts at this place so when I came here about a month ago I was horribly disappointed when I found out they were on vacation for a month! You know a place is good when they get so much damn business that they can just close up shop without warning and leave a paper sign on the door saying they are gone on vacation. 
     When I came here last weekend, the weekend before Chinese New Year, it was packed. The streets were crowded and the store was too! Surprisingly we were able to get our order in about 40 minutes. I thought we'd be waiting for well over an hour but the line moved at a decent speed! 
     After the long wait I definitely ordered a lot of things. What a great business cycle for them huh? Have a huge line that people will wait in, and then because they waited so long they buy a bunch of stuff to make the wait worth it!
     Anyways my first time here I of course ordered egg tarts, 15 to be precise. Not all for myself! I also tried banana mochi, sweet rice cake, coconut tart, some yellow bread thingie, and a pancake thingie. 
     The egg tarts are definitely the best thing there and the only reason you should make a trip to this bakery. I ordered the regular flavor and they are hot and yummy and not to sweet on the inside and the crush is nice and flakey on the outside. Unfortunately when you bring it home and try to re-heat it yourself it is not as good, tasty still but not as good. Definitely the moment you step out of that mess grab one out of your bag and chomp away. Don't burn yourself though! 
    Everything else was eh. It was good but I definitely wouldn't go here specifically for those items. I have other chinese bakeries that are closer to my house, cheaper, and less crowded that do a better job with the other types of bakery. But purely for the egg tarts I would come back.
author: Gabby N.

description:
This small Chinatown bakery ALWAYS has a line, but it's definitely worth it!!!  I come here all the time for their egg tarts, which are heaven on earth!!  They're warm, the filling is just sweet enough and the crust!!!
I don't know how they make the crust, but it's the perfect combination of crispy, flaky and light!  The egg tarts are definitely more expensive than other places in Chinatown, but it's worth it! :)

I should probably try some of the other pastries too, but I just can't resist those egg tarts....hmmmmm
author: Kei H.

description: After recent encouragement to make sure i go here, i will admit...the egg tarts are damn good.  Next time i'll pick up some additional items as well.
author: Dilly M.

description:
My taste buds have been spoiled by this place as a child. I can ONLY eat a "DAN TAT" from Golden Gate Bakery. As a child living in CT this was the snack I craved and could never get sick of. The lines here are RIDICULOUS and they are always on vacation. The crust is so flaky with a crisp and the egg custard melts in your mouth. The texture is like SILK. 

I love how they are CONSISTENT. Every time I bite into a DAN TAT it taste exactly how it was when I was a child. Oh memories :) 

OMG cravings!
author: Rose L.

description: What am I doing here on a Friday night? Well, it's drizzling in SoCal so I'd rather have a glass of wine while I salivate over the thought of the warm, soft, not-too-sweet custard, and crispy crust of GG's egg tart. I'm paralyzed by the fuzzy feeling it brings me. How I long for you, oh egg tart. Come to me and I will devour you. Oh wait, what? I just had a flashback there. What's going on? Where am I? Oh yes, last time I was in SF I was able to eat this goodness while I join the parade during Chinese New Year. Best eaten when warm. :)
author: Xioux Xioux X.

description: Dessert Heaven! Just bring your patience and cash, you can select from a variety of Chinese desserts. Most people order the sweet stuff- namely Egg Custards or sponge cake. Others order the savory stuff like their Chinese chicken empanada. I stick to the egg custards. The shell is flaky, buttery and soft while the custard is thick and custardy goodness.
author: Thomas L.

description: This place has the best egg tarts, second to tai cheong bakery in hong kong. Credibility: I've personally slayed over 2000 egg tarts in Asian bakeries around the world. Locals warn that this place is only open 50% of the time, they don't seem to care because they know their product is so good that we'll come back another day!
author: Vince C.

description:
One of the best egg tarts in the nation especially when eaten just baked fresh and hot.

I will definitely be back. My trips to San Francisco always include a stop here.
author: Lih-Wern W.

description: Hands down the best egg custards you'll ever find! This is a must if ur in the area.
author: T L.

description: The staff is rude and the place is overrated. You can find better Chinese baked goods in the Richmond District. Because of it's location (in the heart of Chinatown), it draws a lot of travelers and those who don't know much about Chinese food.
author: D C.

description:
Waited about 15 minutes for warm flaky egg custard...

Verdict?

Loved the flaky crust and the fact that the egg custard tarts were hot out of the oven (doesn't get better than that), but the actual custard was too eggy for me. If you love egg custard I am assuming you would love this, I just don't love egg custard.
author: Elaine S.

description: I honestly do not know why or how Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts became so popular. Super long line to get some ordinary tarts that don't really stand out from any other bakeries in SF Chinatown. It's possibly the line that makes it all worth it somehow. Not only is it ordinary, but it's also expensive by Chinatown standards at $1.35 each or $16 for a dozen. I honestly have had better!
author: Brian M.

description:
So we came here because this place was supposedly the best egg tarts hands down in SF. A little bit disappointed but might have been because we ate them still rather hot so the custard had yet to cool and solidify.

The egg tarts were nice in that they reminded me of getting them at dim sum restaurants just bigger. The pastry was nice and flaky but the egg custard itself needed more time to cool down. Will have to try them again when cooled to make another decision. The other pastries just aren't worth a try.
author: Justin C.

description: I was told they had the best egg tarts in SF.  I'd never liked egg tarts before so I was not expecting much. Turned out to be very tasty. The egg part had a nice, firm  consistency and definitely tasted like egg.  I usually dislike the crust the most, but this one was solid, flaky but didn't fall apart all over me.
author: Seong P.

description: The Dan Tats are worthy of 5 stars - so darn incredible and unmatched!.  Tender, flaky and buttery crust with a soft light eggy custard that's not too sweet and not too yellow (I hate those artificially yellow colored custards.)
author: LK W.

description: Ugh, I hate to admit that a place with lines this long is justified in having such long lines, but this joint is worth it. Curse you! That means I will wait in line again, wasting 20-30 minutes out of my life on occasion just to indulge in your moon cakes and egg tarts. I really must agree w/ the other Yelpers, their egg tarts are superior to others in the neighborhood. So effing yummy. Additionally, the moon cakes are stellar. I had the lotus moon cake and the pineapple one. Both were awesome, really awesome. So my review thus far is glowing, why not 5 stars you ask? Well, I also sampled a chocolate chip cookie which was awful. Also, for 5 items, it came to $22.70. I realize moon cakes are a bit more, but that felt pretty steep for 5 items from a bakery in Chinatown.
author: Kim S.

description: I have seen all the Yelp views and i have wanted to come here for awhile. I tried the Sweet Coconut balls: glutinous rice, coconut, and a coconutty floraly, almost banana-y filling w/ macadamion nuts *was my favorite* i also tried the Dan Tats for the first time which was great and a moon cake. I've never had Moon Cakes before this, it is very dense and soft. The Lotus seed almost tastes like cashews and almonds- very nutty. Was good but not what i was expecting because i've never had it before. Would probably prefer the Red Bean w/o the yolk. The yolk inside this moon cake is alot saltier than i am used to. Women are amazingly sweet! No lines in the morning, i imagine the lines start around lunch-closing when the tourists come around. Go in the morning and take them home for later ^-^
author: Brittainie B.

description: Golden Gate Bakery is a small, family owned business in the heart of Chinatown.  Its hard to miss because there's always a line out the door and halfway down the street.  Last weekend, we made a pit stop at Golden Gate Bakery with one specific thing in mind: macaroons!  They literally have the best ones here and it's very worth the wait =)
author: Amanda G.

description: Came here today for the first time!! I came early so line wasn't too bad. I got egg tarts and a lemon roll (I believe it is called). The egg tarts are mediocre. The custard is smooth and had the just amount of sweetness. Their shell around the custard was okay. Wasn't that great.  Service here was a bit rude. The shop is family owned and lots of stuff around. They have a tiny area where you order bakery goods.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Long ass lines. Seriously. We walked around for a while hoping the line would get shorter. It didn't. Even after we got our pastries, stopped for some coffee, and did a little shopping, people were still lining up for this place!

So I guess everyone comes here for their tarts. My boyfriend described them as custard tarts, which I was happy to hear because I love custard. 

Erm. They are egg tarts. And when I say egg, I really mean egg. Because like someone else explained, the tart is very "eggy" and a bit runny. Suffice it to say, I didn't enjoy the egg tarts, though the crust was good.
author: Sydney E.

description: This is the PLACE to get your egg custards.  Lines are long and move quickly.  The only drawback is that sometimes they are closed for weeks and there's no sign indicating when they are coming back.  They do have other bakery items which are comparable to other china town shops but they are known for egg custards, which have a very good custard consistency and the requisite pliable and flaky crust.  I think they take cash only.
author: Bebe W.

description:
So I heard this place is absolutely amazing and that people will line up and wait for months while its closed for their supposed heavenly egg tarts. I'll be honest, I've never had an egg tart and I heard these were the best so I had to try the best as my first.  With my San Francisco friends in hand, I ventured to China Town and finally had this famous egg tart. My thoughts: it was good. I liked that it was nice and warm, but I thought the crust was a little too buttery.  The gooey inside was, I must admit, delicious. Not too sweet and not too bland. I would say a 3.9, but not quite a four. And its rare for me to give fives. 

Definitely a San Francisco, China Town MUST.
author: Aurora P.

description:
We were here because we were curious on how they make fortune cookies!Pathetic? haha!

We were at the door and we saw how they make cookies in actual. Very interesting. Then I saw:

"IF YOU TAKE A PICTURE, PAY 5 CENTS".

We started laughing so what we did is that we went far enough where they won't see us and took the Golden Gate Bakery sign (yup, just the sign, not the bakers... so no pay haha).

There's a barber shop beside this bakery and there's this old chinese barber whom we thought he would stop us taking pictures. He was laughing with us actually. 

Fun times.

It's a landmark, go see it!
author: Thigh C.

description:
Does Golden Gate Bakery really need another review for their famous Egg Tarts? Not really..... 

I want to tell you about their  (pronounced fot gwok bao in Cantonese), literally, "FRANCE BUN". OMG, so good. This is the hidden gem that no one really knows about since they only make it on weekends. And even then it's hard to get your hands on one! Everytime I come here, I make sure I stock up on a dozen! It's a really fluffy bun.. there's nothing inside.. reminds me of a croissant, but there's a sweet crust on top of it. One of the best things about it is that when you peel the wrapper off, the bread does not stick to it! Sounds simple enough right? But only mastered by a few! 

I'm a firm believer that the ultimate test of how good a pastry/dessert is, is how it'll taste the next day. If it can taste as good as freshly baked goodies, then you know you have a winner! Everything here passes with flying colors... their egg tarts, buns, turnovers, you name it, I've tried it.
author: Lina W.

description:
Yes, ive never had gg bakery's egg tart before, crazy huh. And yes it was the best ever. Super flaky crust and the eggiest egg custard I've had. 

Must try - 5 stars
author: Derrick V.

description:
My crackspot.

Don't expect to just trot right in, lines are ridiculous and it's worth the wait. Those things are piping hot when they're wrapping it up for you. DON'T expect super friendly service. they're quick and efficient and have plenty of die hard fans that buy these things up by the dozens and don't to answer any dumb questions you may have. 

$1.15 per tart is a little pricy, but they are the effin' bomb.

My family likes the moon cakes from here too. Yup.
author: My C.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS ANYWHERE!!!!!!!!

Downsides?
Horrible parking and horrible lines.

BUT, TOTALLY WORTH EVERY BITE!!!  It practically advertises itself, really!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
The lines here are very long and they move incredibly slow.  I made the mistake of coming here around the time of the moon festival (while they were selling their mooncakes) which probably doubled my time in line. It was about a 2 hour wait. I got blisters on my feet, it was hot (80's for SF).  I would never wait this long for egg tarts, but I knew my brother loved this place and decided to wait in line to get him a dozen dan tats (egg custards).  

The bakery is cramped, seems a bit disorderly, but the business is so good here they don't have to please customers other than by doing what they do best  - which is baking delicious egg tarts. I haven't tried anything else, but I'm sure if their other stuff is as good as the egg tarts they can continue to have crappy/slow service (employees will argue with eachother right in front of you) and still have a huge line out the door--uh, well I guess they already do!

Their dan tats are definitely the best sold in Cali. A close second (just cause I don't like standing in long lines) for egg tarts is the AA bakery on Stockton Street.
author: Ivy P.

description: I would venture to say these are the best egg tarts on the West Coast, if not the entire country, IF NOT THE ENTIRE WORLD. Absolutely worth the 1+ hour wait. So warm, flaky, and buttery... YUMMMMM.
author: Annie Y.

description: Terrible service + long wait + good egg tarts gets you about three stars. It's good but nothing to get all riled up about.
author: Soohyun K.

description:
I'm gonna make this quick only because when I think of this place I wanna go, stand in the line...and get those amazing treats.

i've had pretty much everything here at least once and there isn't a thing here I wouldn' t say to try.

all of it amazing, all of it inexpensive. for 4.00 you walk out with three days of pastries...and they all kick ass...need I say more?
author: Dean M.

description: While I was walking through CT, i saw a long line outside. After yelping it, i realized it was actually really popular. I got the lotus mooncake and egg tart. The old ladies there definitely work at a leisurely pace. The mooncake was average. The egg tarts were delicious, warm and buttery flaky crust.
author: Angela L.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!

I loved the egg tarts before I even moved to the bay and started school here and EVEN before they made the 7x7 list for top 100 places to eat. 

I can still remember my first egg tart. My parents had took me here on their random grocery trip to sf, and the line was ridiculously long, and will forever be. Since we'd drive all the way up, we got two dozens of mixed bakery goodies for our trip home because we use to live so far and there wasn't an Asian bakery in sight where I came from. 

Anyways, now that I live here in the bay, I love going here to get the egg tarts. I usually buy a lot  when I come, even though I live out here only because I get lazy to wait in the line for 30 minutes for one egg tart. SO therefore I usually buy half a dozen or a dozen ..all for moi :]] I can eat those little things in one sitting, because that's how good they are.

The service is always fast and the Chinese ladies do it old-fashion, and write your order down and count it on paper. The owner, I heard from my mom opened that bakery with her husband. But when her husband passed away she only made half of what they use to make. Kind of a touching story, but hey when something's good, it'll be forever good. Glad the recipe wasn't changed, and every time I get the egg tart esp when it's still HOT, the inside is still so buttery and the outside is still ever-so crispy. 

happy eating! :)
author: Liberty C.

description: Best bakery that I had gone to in Chinatown.. Me and my sister enjoy going to this bakery to buy our eggs tarts .
author: Siuhin C.

description: Quality if food maintains the same, but customer service is as usual from poor to fair. Pretty pricy selections. Giving a 3.5.
author: Michelle K.

description: Have only been a few times.  The service is really slow.  Very nice ladies once you get to the front of the line.  Egg tarts are great.  Fresh.  Thank you.
author: Arthur D.

description: Really good egg custard tart and usually I'm not even a fan of egg tarts.  My friends came to visit so they wanted to get it and we stood in line for literally an hour in the cold.  I wouldn't do this on my own lol
author: Trynh K.

description: The cream of the crop in SF. Lucky for me a pretty short line on a Saturday morning. They come out fresh and piping hot, so they poke holes in your box for breathability. They are on the pricey side at over $2 a pastry but I guess cupcakes are $3+, so it's still cheaper!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
It costs $1.15 for a perfect egg tart right out of the oven. I stopped by around 9:00 AM on Sunday and there was no line. The egg part is firm and not gooey. The pastry part is perfectly flaky. 

$1.15 for a perfect egg tart. Take my word for it or just go try one for yourself.
author: Byoung Kyu S.

description:
I'm sorry, but I'm a huge fatty. I blew $60 with no regrets here recently clearing out most of their inventory. I'm one of those guys who buy all the egg tarts and make everyone wait in line...

I waited maybe 30 minutes max to get in and out, but when I got out there was a line down half the block. Eat your egg tarts within a week or else they won't really taste good anymore =(!

I also bought 1 of every possible mooncake they had here just to see if they were good. MMMMM not bad. Got em with yolks, maybe I shouldn't have done that.

I make this a regular stop if the line's not too crazy. I don't mind competing with the grandmas. They're tough, but I have the height advantage.
author: Charles L.

description:
Does this place even need my review? It's pretty famous without the assistance of Yelp.

Better question: Why are you always closed on vacation? I see you through the store window, you're there...

Anyways, if you're in the area, just go check out the bakery to see if it's open. The egg custard and coconut macaroons are totally worth it. Seriously, they are. Golden Gate Bakery has been closed on me the past 3 times and it's fricken annoying, but I keep coming back whenever I'm in SF, like a clingy ex-girlfriend who can't let go.

TRY IT.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I was brought here by a friend who loves Egg Tarts.  I was not looking forward to this.  I don't really like pie or tarts (pie crust is not my favorite thing), but she was so enthusiastic...why not?

We waited in line for about 10 minutes while the smell of freshly baked Dan Tarts wafted over us.  My companion bought a dozen and made me eat one standing outside of the bakery.  "It's tradition!", she said.

I soon had flaky, buttery crust all over the front of my shirt, but I didn't care.  I was lost in creamy, eggy deliciousness.  I easily could have eaten six more (but in the interest of the weight limit of my pants I did not.)  

Eat a dan tart.  You won't regret.
author: Michelle P.

description:
The three stars are strictly for the egg custard tarts -- that's all I've bought here.  They really taste like egg, which might turn off some people more used to sweeter, creamier custard.  I wasn't crazy about them myself at first but they've grown on me.

Expect a long line out the door.  Parking is a pain but there are a few public garages nearby.
author: Arthur C.

description:
If you don't mind standing in line for 30 mins or more, these are some of the best egg tarts I've ever eaten! They taste best when fresh out of the oven. Unfortunately, the owners seem to take 2 2-week vacations a year and when they return, the price goes up another 5-10 cents. Recently, the quality of the crust on the egg tarts haven't been as good as 4-5 years ago when I first started buying from them, but it's still better than other places! 

They lose a star because of the typical traditional Chinese business owner attitude that you get from behind the counter (I'm not very picky about service, but I've been treated better at McDonald's!).
author: Garin W.

description: My Girlfriend took me to this spot this past weekend because she heard that their egg tarts were pretty amazing.   We ordered two at first just to try, ended up going back for a dozen more later in the day.  I'm usually not a fan of egg tarts but these were nothing short of amazing! A must try if you're in chinatown!
author: Keith S.

description:
My "FAT BOYS" are currently in line at GG Bakery for some DAN TAT ( egg tarts ) and have been waiting for over an hour.

I don't like dan tats nor do I order it during dim sum,. but the DAN TAT here is to die for,. literally,. my "FAT BOYS" are waiting in line, in the cold for an hour,. can show you how good it is!

I use to come with my mom, but we would go during non peak hours to buy the egg tarts.  There is usually no line during the weekday and they make so much business, that they can afford to close the shop down and go on "VACATIONs". This is the only Chinese bakery shop/ store/ restaurant that I know, takes vacations and close down the shop for weeks!

The egg tarts are expensive, about $1.15 per tart.  But the tart is big and sits on my hand perfectly.  The egg is soft and silky, creamy and light,. esp the crust, a light flake that is separated in layers, unlike most dan tats where it has one hard dark tuff flake!  I can eat 3 golden gate bakery egg tarts!

I can taste it now,. I am just waiting for the "FAT BOYS" to bring it over! =)
author: Chanel L.

description:
This place definitely has one of the best egg tarts in California.  I would even say the best in the country since I doubt you can find egg tarts in most other states.  Maybe NY.  I couldn't even really find any good ones in LA, but maybe I just didn't know where to go?  

So what's amazing about these egg tarts is the flakiness of the crust and of course the egg tart itself.  Eat it when it's hot cuz that's when it's really delicious. And remember to call ahead in case they're closed and on vacation.  But don't call them too much or they'll get annoyed at you.

And don't get the coconut red bean mochi.  The sponge cake is ok to get.
author: Minako S.

description:
OMG! I've gotta say, the BEST egg tarts Ever!!!
It's totally worth the wait.
author: Hana K.

description:
Definitely the best Chinese bakery I've experienced. So far I've only tried their almond cookies and egg tarts, and both are really good. The almond cookies come in bags of 6 for $2.40, while the egg tarts are sold individually for $1.15. Both prices are pretty reasonable for how good they taste. Be sure you have the egg tart when it's still warm. The soft center and perfectly crispy outer shell separate their egg tarts from everyone else's!

The only gripe I have is that this place takes looong, extended vacations after the mid-autumn festival every year. I recommend going on a weekday when they're open, as the lines will generally be pretty short. If you go during the weekend, good luck. You'll be standing in a long line for at least an hour.
author: John C.

description:
This place has the best egg tarts ever in the U.S! :) Egg tarts have a soft flaky crust with delicious custard filling.  

Bakery goods are definitely to die for!! There is no other place compared to Golden Gate! :)
author: Eric V.

description:
i know everyone's saying this, but im gonna go ahead and say that this was the BEST dan ta i've ever had HANDS DOWN. i came here with a friend visiting from out of town and she claimed that these were even better than the ones she's had from china.

a little play-by-play of how digging into these wonderfully flakey yet moist and custardy pieces of heaven:
FIRST BITE: mmmm
SECOND BITE: yum this is good!
THIRD BITE: oh my god. this is GOOD.
FOURTH BITE: i dont know how to express myself right now.
FIFTH BITE: NOMNOMNOM

the end. now go get yourself some egg custard tarts.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
oh. em. gee.

There's a reason why this place is listed on the 7x7 100 foods to try list and I finally know why.

We waited for about 10 minutes for our turn, and when the time came, freshly baked dozen of egg tarts came home with me. I figured I could give my grandparents some and my co-workers some. 

My grandparents, normally really picky eaters, left me only one out of the 12. That's how good they were. Normally there's an abundance of overly dry crust and not a lot of the custard. Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts were AMAZING, just amount of warm flaky crust and a lot of the custard.

I will definitely be back!
author: Victoria L.

description:
In terms of seeking out good food places, I sometimes follow the crowd literally. So, as we were wandering down Grant Avenue like tourists in Chinatown, I spied a long queue snaking out of Golden Gate Bakery, which seemed to be an unassuming bakery.

So I asked someone in the queue what they were queueing for and I was told that this was the best egg custard tart place in town. For those who haven't eaten one of these, they differ from the western version in that the pastry is a lot more flaky in layers - not quite filo but like that and the custard seems smoother.

Well, if you can't beat them...... I emerged after a short wait with some of the loveliest egg tarts I've eaten. And I scored a couple of warm ones out of the oven.

One piece of advice - join that queue!
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
If you want to eat the best Chinese egg tarts in town, you have to come here to get it! They probably serve one of the best egg tarts in America!

Especially when it's warm right out of the oven, the flaky crust is perfectly crisp, the egg custard is very smooth and creamy. Mmmmm.. And these tarts are larger than regular egg tarts and for only $1.15 each! Well worth it!

I heard that their moon cakes are good as well, but I've never tried it. There was a long line for it during the moon festival.

There can be long lines during busy hours/days.  Just go during the hours when there isn't as much people in chinatown(not rush hour) and there won't be any wait.
author: Jannifer H.

description: FYI They are on Vacation till this Wednesday
author: Chie J.

description:
Once I was in Chinatown, this was my first stop.

I had heard stories about these giant egg custards and how they were so popular that once they run out you gotta come back the next day.

We came early...around 10 am.

There wasn't many people inside so I was kinda sad thinking maybe they had already sold out.

But NOPE, they had a whole storage area full of them

We got 6 for the 2 of us.  It comes in a nice box with a bow around it.

What did it for me was it was CHEAP!!!  A little over a dollar per egg custard.  And these things were HUGE!!!  The size of about 3 small ones I usually get in Houston.  They were so creamy and delicious.  I didn't have to wait in the lines that everyone else describes but even if there was one I would have gladly waited.

Best food on the whole trip.
author: David N.

description: Can't say that I've been to all that many Chinese bakeries, but I'm certainly a fan of this one. We tried a wide variety of their items and nothing was even close to subpar. Don't let the line out front deter you, it's worth the wait.
author: Brad H.

description: I did not understand the hype.  It was very custardy.  Other than that.  Meh.  It's still better than a lot of random places, but I wasn't very impressed.
author: Darren T.

description:
Egg Tarts- yum

these are very dense and rich..and delicious. their flaky tart is not sweet, which compensates for the sweet eggy part. 

i don't think i would buy anything else from here though.
author: Lily N.

description:
So I am going to give it an extra 1 star because I came by after 6pm and realized most bakeries (non-restaurants) close at 6pm and this place opens 8 to 8! And the egg custards were way better than my previous encounter! The "Lo Pau Bang" ("wife cake") and moon cake were also pretty good.

I know I love sweet stuff and my gain of 6 pounds is contributed by the larger consumption amount of food I have been having, the less frequent to the gym, and definitely the recent increase of my happiness index by going out and having some fantastic food and beautiful and fun company. And I ponder, maybe it's okay to gain weight as the Chinese saying goes that when one is truly happy, he or she "Fa Fook" (grows more prosperously, an indirect term to gaining weight)...
author: T L.

description:
Best egg custards - very flaky crust,delicious filing) and fresh off the oven.   

During Moon Festival, if you have the patience to stand in line an hour or more and rushed by limited speaking English counter staff  then try their delicious moon cakes.   The crust is moist and tasty compare to dry out moon cakes found in supermarket or store.   .

The bakery closes for a few weeks right after Moon Festival so call them before heading over there.
author: Chau H.

description:
Egg tarts.
There's something inexplicably addictive about them.
There are also two schools on the subject: flaky-pastry and cookie crust.

I'm a cookie crust kinda guy, but GG does the flaky-pastry-type well; they're flakier and also much richer than the ones in Hong Kong, the MOTHERLAND of all egg tarts.  One will fill you up.

Only downside: expensive.  $1.15 each and rising.
OH, and if time is money to you, waiting in line for 20+minutes will not bide well with your beliefs.

PS: Don't forget to grab a Pineapple Bun or two or six, they're good.
author: Chase C.

description: Besides their famous Egg Tarts which is simply the best on earth, they have the best coconut/macademia nut mochi balls.   They are so soft they almost melt in your mouth.  Their BBQ pork bun is good too -- the filling is filled with good non fatty pork.  I plan to keep going back again and again until I have tried every single item in their store.
author: Anna C.

description: Definitely the best egg tart I've ever had. It's not too sweet or too greasy. SO DELICIOUS!
author: Caroline S.

description:
My friends and I was walking by and one of the guys in the group decided to drop by the bakery which had a loooong line.  I was very skeptical and kind of cynical since I had this preconceived notion that all Asian baked goods tasted the same (maybe because I've eaten them all my life).  

Later on that day, as we were going home, I began to hunger. So I asked my friend who still had stuff from the bakery for an egg custard tart.  This was my first time eating it and HOLY EFFIN' CRAP!  This was the best stuff in the whole wide friggin' world!  The crust was so buttery and not smushy at all.  The egg custard itself was not too sweet and had an amazing texture.  Just from this 5 minute experience of eating this tart, I must give GG Bakery 4 stars (I don't want to be bias since I haven't tried any of their other stuff).  GG Golden Gate Bakery! haha. :)
author: David T.

description:
So...

You walk into Golden Gate Bakery (if you're smart enough to get there before the lines forms out the door and continues up Grant north towards Sausalito) and they have (what one would have no trouble calling) a wide and enticing array of baked treats for sale.

Skip the rest and go with the coconut tart. It's the best in Chinatown (I've checked) and is just about the darn loveliest thing on Grant. (Don't let Eastern Bakery hear me say that.) There's a moistness that's missing from other Chinese bakeries in the area. It's less cake-like and is comparable in the slightest way to an egg custard. The tart's crust is flaky and makes for a chic touch to any sweater or blouse you choose. 

So, really, two words: Coconut tart.

And get there before the line.
author: Mick S.

description:
This is the best egg tart I've ever had.  The only reason for the 4 stars instead of 5 is because the egg tarts are not as good when it's not fresh out of the oven.  Don't get me wrong it's still fresh (like same day egg tart) but it's not as good as the ones that just comes out of the oven.  Those are really yummy.  But be careful because they burn your mouth, I got burnt once.  
This is the place I take all my Asian friends that visits me in the city.  Don't let the line fool you, it moves fast and it's totally worth it.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Every single time I eat a bad or below average eggtart, I remember this place. haha The only negative thing people can actually say about this place is the price because:

Service: its chinatown, what do you honestly expect? they did add a red velvet rope in front. haha
Parking: its San Francisco/ chinatown, what do you expect? either park in the garage or have someone drop you off and circle the block.
Long wait: this means its good, popular, and made fresh

The price for one eggtart isnt THAT much more expensive. When I eat a bad eggtart, I wish i paid that extra 25 cents and gotten a nice warm flaky yellow pastry instead.


Hence, this is one of the best places to get an eggtart in San Francisco PERIOD.
author: Stacy L.

description:
Was in town this weekend (from SoCal) and met up with Erich D.  Took his advice to check this place out.  Highly regarded as having the best egg tarts around, I had high expectations for this place.

Nothing fancy about this bakery from the outside. It blends in with the rest of Chinatown here but the lines are literally out the door. Wow...that good huh? 

And the verdict?  I am certainly not disappointed. In fact, I've become an instant fan of GGB! These are definitely one of *thee* best, if not already the best, egg tarts I've had outside HK. 

The crust is fluffy and flakey. The custard is not only sweet but you can actually taste the egg flavor.  Not too sweet and not too eggy, altogether baked into perfection. The aroma, the taste - pure bliss! Just be careful how you handle them cause they are oh-so delicate.

I may not be a particular fan of the larger sized egg tarts and while I much prefer eating the mini ones you get at dimsum restaurants (where the more neon-toxic-yellow the custard looks, the better it tastes), Golden Gate Bakery has made an exception for me. 

So why the 4 stars? At $1.25 each, it's a bit hard to swallow. But still reasonable for such greatness nonetheless and a far cry from those expensive cupcakes out there. I'll stop on by the next time I'm back in the Bay. I just hope I don't miss them dun-tats too much. Oh, and Erich - thanks for the rec!
author: Raymond S.

description: Walking down Grant Ave doing the touristy thing, I noticed the line out the door at Golden Gate Bakery. Might as well join in and see (or taste) what the fuss is about. "What are you ordering?" I ask the person in front of me.  "Egg tart". Egg tart it is. The line moved quickly and when I get inside, I noticed everyone is paying with cash. Oops! I remove myself from the queue and stop at Chase Bank's ATM immediately across the street. Back in line, I watch customers saunter out of the shoe box-size shop while bringing their lips to an egg custard tart, teeth piercing creamy  yellow custard and golden flaky crust, expressions of gastronomical bliss. Finally at the front of the line, I order a dozen egg custard tarts. Pricier than other C-town bakeries, but other bakeries do not have lines out the door. With a box of tarts in hand, I find a quiet spot on Grant Ave to enjoy my sweet treats. Hot creamy custard cradled by warm flaky crust is a flavor explosion. Wonderful mouth feel. Custard is delicate like flan, not rich as creme brulee. No greasy feeling in mouth from the flaky crust. Best eaten fresh and warm. Not nearly as wonderful cold, next day or microwaved. Golden Gate Bakery also sells lean meat BBQ pork buns. Tasty! Juicy! No need to swallow chunks of fat while eating BBQ pork buns in front of others. Yay! =P
author: Liv K.

description:
At this bakery, patience is definitely a virtue.

Just about every time I've stopped by for one (or two) of their famous egg tarts, there's a line going out the door! But believe me, the wait is worth it. Seriously, once you've had one of their egg tarts (or any of their other baked goods, really) you'll be hooked and back before you know it.

The only thing is, once you're inside, it's super small and crowded. Be prepared to have your personal space invaded!
author: Anna T.

description: Everyone say this place is good, but what ever man. They open once in a while like they dont give a crap, yes, there are hella people in line for their baked goods but honestly, you will just be waiting for some over priced but yummy baked good.
author: Frederick A.

description:
I personally prefer the creamy caramelized goodness of the similar pastel de nata -- Portuguese tart (or at least the Macanese version of it anyway), but have yet to find a decent shop in the Bay Area. For Hong Kong-style egg tarts, however, this is the place to go in San Francisco.

On a recent visit (having been away from SF for awhile), the flaky crust seemed slightly off from what I remembered of a couple years ago. I'm not sure if was a variation in that particular batch, the heat and humidity of the day, or a change in the recipe (Reduced the lard? I wolfed down two of them too quickly to tell).

Even so, those egg tarts still top any other in town hands down.

Call ahead if making a special trip to Chinatown. They tend to close for vacation often, often for weeks at a time, and apparently with little advance notice.
author: Leo G.

description:
Eat the best, and forget the rest.

The egg custards, known as "dan tat" in Cantonese, at Golden Gate Bakery is equivalent to the malasadas at Leonard's Bakery in Honolulu.  There is none like it in the world.  

What makes the egg custard so good is the flaky, pastry crust with a non-runny and not too sweet egg-flavor custard filling.  Eat one or two when you just get it fresh and warm from the oven.  Eye-rolling experience expected.

Each egg custard is about $1.20, almost one third the cost of a Sprinkles Cupcake.  Buy a dozen if you have friends and family!  You can easily make 100% markup from any egg custard crackhead, including me, who hate standing in long lines.

This secret recipe is guarded like a kung fu master, unwilling to share his "fatality" move to any of his disciples.  When the owners take 3 to 4 weeks vacation a year, the entire operation is shut down.  Please call ahead before trekking all the way to Chinatown.

However, with all the money the owners take to the bank, GGB gets a -1 star for not having an express line for these "dan tats."  A teller window would eliminate the HELLA long line that snakes across several other stores.

Final tip to tourists:  Don't double park on this one way street.  Your ticket can buy more than 90 GOLDEN GATE treats.

I dedicate this review to Carina N.     Oink at ya:   ^(o o)^
author: CT L.

description:
Ok, if do you go to SF's institution - the Golden Gate Bakery for their famous egg custard tarts (tan tart in Chinese), here are a few tips to ensure you get the egg custard tarts. The owner I can only describe as the "Soup Nazi" in Seinfeld's episode, except that she's an Egg Custard Tart Nazi (ECT Nazi). Here's what you can expect when you get there:

1. There will be a line outside the store. The store square footage is really small, I mean is tiny. Is a one way in and one way out situation. Get in line.

2. You will have to wait because the egg costars are being made as you wait and they come out of the oven in batches and they are super fresh, piping hot and the smell of buttery pastry and sweet eggs mixture are intoxicating. 

3. Be prepared to place your order when you get inside. These people don't mess around and they move at the speed of light. You'llneed to know exactly how many pieces of egg custard tarts you want so they know what size boxes to bring out. They do not like it if you tell them 6 and then change your order to 12. When in doubt, get more. You'll thank later. 

4. Have cash on hand. You are in China Town now, cash is gold. No cash, no egg tarts. Capisce? 

5. Be patient. Sometimes it will take a little waiting if the egg custards aren't ready or they are out. 
 
6. Don't whine, complain or roll your eyes at them. I have witnessed patrons who whined about how long the wait was and went up to the line to complained to the store owner and she got thrown out of the store. Literary -- No Egg Tarts For You! 

I know it seems like such a hassle just for egg tarts and yes, I agree that they store owner has a little attitude, but hey, there is a price for everything right? And if you like to try SF best egg tarts and you should, you will endure this little agony. Trust me, it will be all worth it when you bite into a piece of buttery, flaky, warm pastry dough filled with sweet, creamy, smooth egg custard center. All your agonies and sufferings will melt away and you walk down Grant Avenue a happy camper. Enjoy!
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description: Definitely not hype!  Egg Tarts are DELISH here, especially when you get them still warm.  Flaky crust and not too sweet.   Perfection!!  My favorite, but AA Bakery is a close favorite.  One star taken off since they like to take vacations at RANDOM times!  Can be frustrating when planning your trip to Chinatown.  Call first.
author: Marie S.

description:
egg tart with golden colored egg custard, flaky crust, and warm in your hand.  I feel the love.

To experience the love, you must wait in line during the weekend but you will not regret it.  

2 minutes after purchase...
"Hey! Where's your egg tart?"
"What egg tart?"  **munch...munch...munch..**
I need another one.

Buy a box of egg tarts to take home.  
Heat it up in the toaster oven.  I still feel the love.
This is better than dim sum.
author: Wei C.

description: The most AMAZING egg tarts and moon cakes EVER. Only downside is that they go on vacation for months at a time without telling you when they return. Guess it makes you miss them that much more...
author: Laura C.

description: Omg... I never had an egg tart before. They are delicious! I just had one yesterday and I'm already craving another today. Also the ladies that work inside were very nice and helpful when me and my boyfriend were trying to figure out the best pastries for his mom and grandma. They packaged everything up very nicely. I will be back!
author: Jennea N.

description:
My brother said this place is known for their egg tarts and macaroons.

Boy are they!  I've never had a macaroon like this before!  Crisp and chewy on the outside and thruout!  Very coconutty!  Good, even a few days later. 

The custard in the egg tart, rather than gelatinous, is much more light and delicate -(even puddinglike) - than I expected.  Delish and flaky!  

The line out the door was a bummer and great advertising strategy.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
AHHH if I could eat their egg custard everyday I would. Check it, it should be a staple. It's amazing. 

We have a love hate relationship-- I love the way they make me feel, I hate the way it makes my butt look.

Treat yourself. Heaven.
author: Alli J.

description:
EGG TART HEAVEN! I was stuffed to the gills, but I couldn't resist -- they were open, I was in the neighborhood, no line -- and I just HAD to get one.

The tart survived being stuffed into my purse for a long walk, though by the time I finally sat down to eat it, it was a bit misshapen and the bottom had gotten a bit soggy. But it was still just as delicious as I remembered -- soft eggy filling, light and crisp crust -- truly a perfect egg tart.
author: Eeeeestar T.

description: Hands down....the BEST Chinese egg custard tart that has ever touch my tongue!  They're extremely fresh and is warm when you order them!  The custard is perfectly sweetened and the crust is light and buttery not to mention how flaky it is!  People wait in line to get a dozen of these scrumptious little pastries here.  This is could be the only chinese owned place that will close for vacation!  So be careful when you venture out there during chinese new year or during the holidays.  They may be closed.
author: Gina S.

description:
"As good as it gets" is right! Their popularity (and prices) reflect this well. This is where the golden gates to egg tart heaven is located. Buttery, flaky crusts...smooth, rich custard... Golden Gate Bakery would definitely have to be the Paula Deen of Chinatown. I am also a fan of their baked BBQ pork bun. Lots of meat and good bread. 
 
The consistently long lines and 600+ reviews attest to this. However, watch out! They have some mini off-seasons, when they take vacation and close down after major festivals...or like after mooncake season. So for those who are thinking about making a special trek over here...call ahead and make sure they are open for business!
author: Emily L.

description:
Mm...delicious treat in the middle of Ctown.

Flaky crust filled with custardy goodness. Always get a dozen, no point in getting one, then find out later that you're fiending for another one. Plus it's always nice to share.

They keep raising their prices and more people keep coming. I'm one of them.

FYI, they take a bajillion vacations a year so make sure they're opened before you head to Ctown for some egg tarts.
author: Jimmy N.

description: I remember coming here as a kid 15 years ago and waiting in line with my parents to get a dozen of these famous egg custards. Fifteen years later the line has only gotten longer, only now it's usually a bunch of tourists or local foodies rather than just the Chinatown gang. The egg custard tarts really are the best that I've had -- nice consistency of the buttery shell and the custard itself is soft and fluffy enough but not watery -- and I have eaten more than my fair share from other Chinese bakeries and at well regarded dim sum restaurants. They really do taste best fresh so be prepared to eat at least one while walking out of the shop. If you wait they'll get cold and you see how much oil is in the shell... taste fairly good after reheated in a toaster oven, but not the same! The ladies behind the counter also try to talk you into trying their other goods like sesame balls, sponge cake rolls, and other options, but I wouldn't bother -- just save your money and appetite for the egg tarts.
author: Shirley L.

description: I have a love and hate relationship with this place!! I hate the fact that you are always on vacation (business is too good)! Your line is always long and you live too far away from me!!!! Why 5 stars? I love your egg tarts too much to not come back again.
author: Aylee G.

description:
$1.15 is a lot to pay for an egg tart, but if you're a fan of these delectable pastries, you have to try it here.  don't get scared by the line that may form outside of the store has it goes by pretty fast.  if you're going to stand in line, you should order at least a half dozen (they give you a box).  the best way to enjoy them when you get home is to heat them up for 20 seconds.

also, beware that they might take these month long vacations and just close up shop.
author: Carli F.

description:
Where do I start? I first heard about GG Bakery on the Chinese radio when I was younger. The radio commerical went something like:

What is the most popular park in SF?
GG Park
What is the most popular bridge in SF?
GG Bridge
What is best bakery in SF?
GG Bakery

I thought that was a lie since I had never heard of it before. As I got older (and before the times of Yelp), and I don't know or when I had my first egg tart from Golden Gate Bakery, I was sold. Soft custard on the inside and slightly sweet, and flaky on the outside. At the time, I didn't know that there needed to be standards for egg custards, but that became my standard. You can bring it home and put it in the toaster oven (and make sure not to burn the crust) and it's still very good. Actually, it tastes good cold, refrigerated. It always tastes good, but even better fresh.

I also like the coconut tarts they have there. Oh so good!

They do close at certain times of year for vacation or to make mooncakes (sorta expensive, but good). Lines are common, and sometimes when I pass by and there is no line, I have to go in and get an egg tart even if I'm not craving one. It's like seeing a pig that flies, a UFO, a dog with 5 legs. OK, I've never seen those things, but that's how rare it is or how impossible it is for GG Bakery to have no line.

I've come here from when each egg tart was 80 cents, then 90, then eventually 1.15. It's like I can see inflation in action.
