Makes me feel old (I'm not right? *pulls out mirror to look for wrinkles, crow's feet, and white hair*) Even though are costly I sometimes buy several since my sisters and/or friends crave them.

I've definitely waited in line for 2 hours before. So though the line looks lik 15 people, it could take that long. Well, the time we came it was mooncake time so people were buying more things. But it just gets to the point where you have waited so long, you might as well keep waiting.

By the way, if you are in line for an egg tart anyway, can you bring me one?
author: Anita C.

description: My family has been going to Garden Bakery for years to get our Chinese pastries fix, but I finally decided to try out Golden Gate Bakery during my most recent trip to Chinatown.  I waited in line for 38 minutes and finally got my hands on some nice hot egg custards.  I immediately ate one, and I was disappointed.  There is so much hype around these egg custards that I was expecting something amazing.  The pastry was nice and flaky, but the custard was slightly undercooked and not sweet enough.  Definitely not worth the 38 minute wait considering I could get egg custards that are just as, if not more, tasty at Garden with a minimal wait at half the price.  I say save your time and skip Golden Gate Bakery.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I have such a love-hate relationship with Golden Gate Bakery. WAIT! Hear me out first! I remember the first time I ever tried a custard tart from here. It was heavenly, but I didn't know it was from here because a family member brought a dozen (YUMMMM) when they came to visit my family. I don't remember how I finally realized it was GGB that these delicious little tarts came from, but I swear there is none like these. NONE!!!

I've been craving for them so much that I didn't care for the price of them. I just HAD to have one.... or two... or six.... :) I came in today and hallelujah! NO LINE! This place is usually flocked by many people. I ran in and asked for SIX custard tarts and realized it's $1.15 per tart now. Super sad, but I don't care. I'm still coming back for more!!! 

Seriously, you would not be able to find any other custard tart that tastes sooooo good! The pastry part is so nice and flakey and the custard is just.... you just HAVE to try it! 

So yeah, it's a love-hate thing. Love it because its so damn freaking good. Hate because if I keep eating them at this pace, it'll dramatically increase my chances of high cholesterol. But who cares! right? :)
author: Eugenia G.

description: I'm from out of town.  Took me THREE tries before I finally got my hands on these little suckers.  I loaded up and bought 18 eggtarts.  Totally worth it!
author: Vicky C.

description:
Damn. It's all true, it's all SO true. 

Golden Gate Bakery, I just don't know if I will ever be able to settle for anything less than your eggy custardy works of  tarty art.
author: Jasmine C.

description: May be I was lucky that there was no line there when I went during lunch hours. Got cocktail bun, sesame balls, coconut macroons, and of course the  famous egg tarts. Everything is delicious in this place.
author: Chellam C.

description:
There wasn't a line around 2:00 pm on a Tuesday. I actually thought they had sold out but I asked the women at the counter and they still had some!

I bought a dozen of the egg custard tarts. 

I forgot how spoiled I was living on the east coast. I had access to NYC/DC and was use to delicious egg custard tarts. San Diego's tarts aren't as fulfilling and tinier. Golden Gate Bakery reminded me of what a good egg custard tart looked and tasted like. 

The crust is flaky and tender - slightly crispy - like puff pastry and delicious. The egg custard was perfect - flan/pudding in texture - a wonderful balance of vanilla, sugar, and eggs. 

It was worth the $1.15 for each. 

Even after 3 days in the refrigerator (an amazing feat since I wanted to gobble them all up but I had to share with my SD co-workers), they were still delicious. 

Also, got the huge sesame seed ball. I didn't eat it but I'll have to get one next time.
author: Linda S.

description: This is my third time visiting this city and my third time having the Golden Gate Bakery egg tarts! There was a line-up but it goes by fast and once you have that warm and fresh egg tart in hand : totally worth it.
author: Po On Y.

description:
This is my favorite place to get egg tarts. Dim sum and Asian groceries simply do not compare. The ones you get there are burnt on the top, TINY, dry and the crust just never tastes right. Never flaky enough. Sometimes chewy like a cookie (whaaaaattt?!?). Okay, actually  that last one was actually from a batch I tried to make myself but still. Nothing beats Golden Gate Bakery.

Went on a Thursday around 4pm-ish. There were around 3 people in front of me so I was able to get in-and-out quite quickly. A dozen egg tarts (duh, that's all I'm there for) ran for about $14. 

The moment I walked out, I ripped the box open (no, really) and distributed two among my friend and I. DELICIOUSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS. Warning, it's hot! I burned my lips/tongue twice. You'd think we'd learn but it's so good.
author: Sara T.

description:
My friend and I came her on a Friday, a little after 10 A.M. We're not familiar with SF, so we went wandering around and she was like, "I FOUND IT!" 

I kept thinking, "where, where's the line?" and followed my friend when she walked into a shop." I was shocked that there was no line. (My first ever) and we got our order of a dozen of egg tarts and a few banana rolls. It came out to be $18ish

I would like to argued and say that the price of the egg tart is steep, but if you were to measure the size of it, then it's well worth it. The egg tarts in my area are way small and does not taste nearly as good. At all. 

Eating the tart can be sort of messy because the crust crumbles when you add too much pressure and the egg "pudding" tastes like ...well pudding. 

The banana rolls (do not know the real name) was tasty. I think it's made from sticky rice and is sort of soft. 

Service was fast! 

Over all, 5 stars!

Oh, and cash only.
author: Shelly C.

description: When I lived in sf I always went this place once a week !! Now I live in SJ but I still drive to here just to get a egg ta !! I love this place very much because the cakes are  warm and delicious.
author: Anita J.

description:
Hot out-of -the-oven egg tarts.  

These tarts goes straight from the oven, into a pink box and carried away within 10 minutes.  I always stop by here every time I visit San Francisco.  Must eat it ghetto-style: on the curb outside the store.

Never waited more than 15 minutes though.  But then I usually go around 11am.
author: Mar O.

description: The best egg tart but just ok customer services, not to say don't like. The coconut macaroon is good but a little bit overpriced. So hard to find a parking space in china town
author: Mai L.

description: I don't get why people rave about the egg tarts from here so much. I tried it and seriously felt like I was eating an omelet and quiche. Not good. Too much egg, not enough custard-like texture. However, I appreciated the crust...that was about it, which as we all know is not the selling point for an egg custard tart.
author: Surge C.

description:
I had to give this place a try when I saw a line out the door on one of my outings in Chinatown. They supposedly have the best egg custard ever, so that is what I got.

I have nothing to compare it to so I don't know if I can say that it is the best. What I will say is that their egg custard is served hot and is very good. I also tried their Chinese New Year bread which was also very good. 

I am more of a chocolate person, and I don't think I saw a single desert with chocolate so I can't give them a mind blowing review. But they are for sure worth going to if you are in Chinatown.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Totally worth the wait and the hype. If you're in the area might as well stop in and check out what these egg custards are about. 

Way better and fresher and flakier than the run-of-the-mill ones they have at dim sum. 

It wasn't too "yolky" like most are and the pastry is just the right amount of flaky! 

It's $1.15 per custard and they are pretty good sizes too.
author: Allison C.

description: Best egg custard... When they are open. It seems like they really enjoy going on vacation. Good for them! Tip: call first to make sure they are open before making the trek there.
author: Victoria C.

description: closed right now. went there but there was a sign on the door that they are on vacation
author: Aileen B.

description:
The Golden Gate Bakery has the best pastries in Chinatown!

My mom always buys heaps of egg custard tarts, coconut tarts, and macaroons!

There's a variety of delicious pastries to choose from here. 

The place itself is relatively small and the line almost always stretches out the door!

IF YOU HAVEN'T ALREADY, MAKE SURE YOU TRY ONE OF THEIR FAMOUS EGG CUSTARD TARTS!
author: Frankie W.

description:
I visited SF for my honeymoon this past weekend.  This spot showed up on our yelp radar within hours of our arrival...A quick and scenic walk into Chinatown, and there we were in front of Golden Gate Bakery.  I marveled at my new husband as he dusted off some of his rudimentary Cantonese and ordered us some egg custard tarts and a sesame ball.

Wow - everyone has already said the egg custard tarts are delicious.  I concur - what a lovely flake-y crust!  These will haunt my dreams at home (nearly an authentic Chinese food wasteland...with a few oases...none of which are dim sum related).

We walked across the street so I could snap a picture of the bakery, and then I tasted my sesame ball.  As my hubby looked at me in anticipation of my reaction...I had a moment where a sesame ball nearly brought me to tears.  It was as big as a softball - I understand because it was expertly fried by skilled hands that know the magic way to help them expand.  It tasted so crispy and delicious...and nothing like the sad counterfeits I've had elsewhere...the whole thing made my head swim.  The loving new hubby, the joy of yelp, the delicious taste of sesame fried dough and red bean paste...it was all a bit too much for this Texas girl.

It's been 2 days...I already miss you Golden Gate Bakery...I hope to see you again very soon.
author: Roxanna L.

description:
How many of you remember eating only the custard of the egg tart and giving the empty tart to your parents? Well... that will never happen again!  Golden Gate Bakery has the best egg tarts ever!  As soon as you sink your teeth into the tart, you will know that you're getting a freshly baked tart.  The egg custard is so hot and the tart is so flaky and crispy. 

I remember when they use to be about $0.80, which I thought was pretty expensive already, considering other bakeries sold them for only $0.50.  I believe they now sell them for $1.10.  But that makes sense - according to economics, high demand drives the price up, right?

Other things worth mentioning are these cookies that come pre-packaged. I'm not sure what they're called in English, but if I were to translate it directly from Chinese, it would be "cow ear cookies" LOL I know it doesn't sound very appetizing, but these choco swirled cookies are very crunchy and make a great snack.  During the mid-autumn festival, GGB also makes moon cakes.  Their packaging is not the prettiest (comes in a paper box), but they make them in a variety of exotic flavors in addition to the traditional white lotus with egg yolk.

The wait on a normal weekday probably wouldn't be long, on the weekend will probably be around 15 minutes, but during mid-autumn festival... be prepared to wait 3 hours. Yes that is three hours.  And if you're willing to wait three hours, be sure to just pay for parking at the garage and don't park at the metered parking, because you will end up buying very expensive moon cakes.  

Last tip: Be sure to eat the tarts right when you get it - that is when it is the bestest!
author: Elaine C.

description: Best egg tarts ever! Flaky crust and great custard consistency and sweetness. As a San Franciscan myself, I still come here for them even though they are definitely over-priced and that goes to prove how good they are!
author: Shirley M.

description: Out of all the places where I tried egg tarts, these were the best. It's a little pricey for an egg tart but it's worth it. The crust was crispy and the inside was fluffy. They are best serve warm.
author: Jessica C.

description: $1.25 each for Dan Tats (egg tarts) kinda pricy but well worth it for these giant bad boys. Made fresh daily its the only reason I came by. Just about the best I've had in the western hemisphere.
author: Wil Y.

description: OMG, the best egg custard tarts I have ever had in my life.  What other reviewers have said below is spot on.  One one morning last year, we got a few that were right out of the oven, ate them, and were so amazed that we immediately went back to get a dozen more.  At the end of the day, before leaving Chinatown, we went back to buy a few more hot egg tarts to eat right away.  That's three purchases in one day!
author: K L.

description:
The egg tarts are really that good!! Making egg tarts, the ingredients are very simple. However, the technique of beating the eggs together.Depends on experience. You can't over beat it, overfill your wet ingredient on the too much or nor too little, can't over bake it.  And of course, the smoothing method. 

The result is like fluffy steamed egg with lightly brown flaky crust. You actually taste eggs. Not to be confused with egg custards which is made of cornflour, gelatin, and food coloring. 

 Just have to be careful when you carry these things around in a box. It gets bended easily. Best to eat it RIGHT AWAY! *Cash only*
author: Amary N.

description:
Three words: egg custard tart.

They're amazingly delicious, especially fresh and hot from the oven. The crust is buttery, the filling soft and moist... Unfortunately, I can't count how many times I've burned the roof of my mouth stuffing these tarts into my mouth.  (Let's just say it's been more than a few times. But no pain, no gain, right?)

The lines are long but the wait is well worth it. Plus, while you wait, you can 1) check out the faux Gucci purses the store next door sells and 2) bond with the hungry people standing in line and salivating against the window of the bakery. 

Other than the custards, the almond gems, the coconut macaroons, and the sponge cakes are also yummy!  This is definitely one of the best chinese bakeries around!
author: penny t.

description: The buns, pastries, and cakes here are pretty dang good.  But, more often than not, the queue here is ridiculously long.  I wish this bakery would sell a front-of-the-line pass like they do in Disneyland.
author: Subrosa I.

description: the BEST dan tats EVER!! the line is always out the door. so, you have to buy at least a dozen. no other dan tats come close to these! mMm... I want some now..
author: Ann T.

description:
This is THE place to get dan dats (egg tarts). theres usually a line and ppl are waiting for the FRESH out of the oven egg tart. literally they come out of the oven and then they pack it up for you. these egg tarts do not stay on the shelves. you go in and you can't find them because they are still in the oven. cha siu bows(bbq pork buns) are also VERY GOOD here.

service is sucky and i think they are nicer to you if you just look patient.. those chinese ladies can have an attitude. but you shouldnt expect too much cause you ARE in chinatown. be prepared to WAIT in line. They go on vacation at random times of the year so call before you trek over there.
author: Irene L.

description:
This is literally the ONLY PLACE I actually eat egg tarts from. It makes any other egg tarts taste like total crap. 

There's a reason why they can still be in business despite shutting down for vacation for like half of the year.
author: Christine A.

description: I'm not too sure why this place has high stars because the custard pies are nasty and the chicken pie didn't appear to have chicken in it. However, the mochi was the best. But what was I ordering?  Other Chinatown bakeries have English labels. Why not this place?  Get it together ladies. For now Yummy gets my vote.
author: Eric M.

description:
Perfection. Enough said. My mom used to get us egg tarts as a kid from here long before the craze that it's become. To this day, the crust is still as flaky and crispy as ever. You can't just get one. Back then I think they were 0.80cents but im sure they upped it. But it'll be the best 0.80 cents or even a dollar you've ever spent! 

Cons: Lines are pretty long. Expect a 30-40 minute wait on the weekends.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Eggactly Eggcellent Eggtarts!

Hands down THE BEST egg tarts my mouth has had the pleasure of tasting. We got here around 9:30 purchasing the last batch of egg tarts of the day and the were still delectable. Perfect crust, perfect egg texture, and perfect taste. Damn dan tats....

Live, Laugh and Lunch
Patty
author: Patty N.

description: Best bakery every, best egg tart for sure, and all the other goodies, also for a very decent price :)
author: Connie V.

description: Well the line is ridiculously long and full of Asians which is always a good sign when you go to a Chinese bakery. My friend demanded we stand in line to try their egg tarts, which I have to say were pretty tasty. Not only did they literally flake off all over your taste buds and your face, but while trying to walk in busy ChinaTow, everyone stopped to ask us where we got them! Get ready for a long line, with delicious smells, and you'll probably end up buying more than you came for.
author: Jesse J.

description:
This bakery in the heart of Chinatown is by far the best!!  They have the freshest, tastiest egg custart tarts!  Also I'm not sure what its called but the flat white chewy things are super good too!  Some kind of pancake?  Yum to pineapple buns!  Everytime we go we try a new treat and they've been all good.

The line is usually out the door but its so worth waiting for!

By the way when you're here in Chinatown pick up some authentic Lap Chong.... Chinese sausage.  Go to the shop right uphill behind the Portsmouth Sq garage!  He the best!  Love to cut em up and put it in fried rice!
author: Janelle A.

description: Egg Tarts are definitely the best I've had!  Go early when they open, there won't be any lines!
author: Sw H.

description: The best you'll ever have. There's not much to say other than the 30 minute wait and line is all worth it once you get your piping hot "dan tat" egg custard in your mouth. Oooo my goodness..it is the best custard you'll ever eat. I entered with anticipation of getting my hand on a dozen of these tasty treats and left with the biggest smile on my face knowing I'm about to consume one of a foodie's treat to deliciousness. If you haven't had one..DO IT. It'll be all worth it and you'll never want to go without it again. :)
author: Bernice L.

description: Highly recommeded custard tarts did not disappoint.   Warm and flaky ...nom nom nom
author: Paul W.

description: came back with my Chinese parents.  By the way, I too am Chinese.  Awesome to hear my dad exclaim repeatedly, "they melt in your mouth!"  (In reference to the egg tarts).
author: Ash T.

description:
Everyone seems to know about the egg custard tarts ($1.15 each) at Golden Gate Bakery (hence the ridiculously long lines).  Since they're so popular, the ones you get are still warm (and there aren't too many places where the egg tarts are so fresh and warm). The shell is very flaky, crispy and buttery and the custard is light, moist, eggy and sweet.  Though I like the tarts, I wish the bottom of the tart was a bit firmer because the tart falls apart too easily.  Crumbs wind up everywhere!   Also, I don't like the careless way they shove the tarts into a paper bag because they always get squashed that way.  

My favorite items are actually the sugar topped French buns.  They're so light, soft and airy and the sugar crust adds that extra oomph.  They seem to run out of those quickly too.

I've had some of their other items that aren't as good (baked buns, cookies, etc.).  The curry beef turnover is expensive and the filling is just okay.  The vanilla cake roll is also expensive ($1.25 a slice) and mediocre  - the cake is tough and I found some eggshells in my cake too. Sheng Kee has better cake slices.  

I heard they were famous for moon cakes but I wanted one without the salted egg inside and they didn't seem to have any without eggs.  I usually go to Sheng Kee for mine since I like getting the mini moon cakes.

While overpriced in general, it's worth coming here for egg custard tarts and sugar topped baked buns (and possibly moon cakes).
author: Lolia S.

description:
If your a fan of Chinese egg custard tarts, this is the place to get them. I would have to say best in all of SF. I have my own spot in Oakland that i go to all the time, but if I'm in SF this is where I'm going. 

Yea there's usually a line and yea it is doubled the price from other Chinese bakery's for their egg tarts. But it is well worth it. When you get to the front of the line the nice Chinese ladies greet you with great customer service, surprisingly. I usually get bad customer service at Chinese joints. But this place was very nice, and the tarts are super warm and crispy. The egg custard filling is very tasty, has that nice egg flavor and just sweet enough. Not too sweet, just how i like it. And the crust is very very flaky, very delicious. Cant explain it, you just have to try one for yourself.

I also tried the chicken turnover, stay away from this it was pretty awful. I also had the black mung bean cake, that too was also pretty bad. Next time i come by I'm going to stick with the egg custard tarts.

5 Stars for Golden Gate Bakery in SF
author: Lux K.

description: I had these a few years back in SF.  My friend and I were there for the weekend and she recommended these.  They were very good.  They're the best I've had.  They're bigger than the ones I see in most bakeries and dim sum places.
author: Kaylin O.

description: This place can't get enough praise from me and other Yelpers. Golden Gate Bakery was at the top of my list of places to eat when I visited in SF. Needless to say these were the best egg tarts I ever tasted. The custard was silky smooth and the custard and crust ratio was perfection. I can't wait to go back and eat them again!
author: Cindy C.

description: First of all..I don't know what all the fuss is about the egg tart from this place. It's nothing special. I drop by here with my wife to pick up some egg tart cause she wanted some. I had the rudest customer service from these old ladies. We waited a good 10min before it was our turn to order. When I had the chance to call out my order..i holla at the old lady across who was signaling me for my order. I holla...Give me a Box egg tart.. plus 6 more in a separate bag in Cantonese. Dumbass old lady don't understand. She kept asking what I want. I just told your ass. LADY...you got a big ass sign behind you saying 1 box = 1 dozen egg tart for $16. 1 dozen = 12pc + 6pc = 18pcs. Figure the math yourself. So then the confused old lady look at the other old lady who also seem not to understand my order in Cantonese.  They were talking smack in Cantonese cause they not understand my order and was holding up the line. As if I didn't understand their trash talking.  She then look at my wife asking if she speak Chinese...LOL. My wife is Korean. So then a customer behind us intervene in my shouting match with these dumb ass old ladies. He clarify FOR THEM my order 1.5 dozen. Old lady then attempted to ask for my order in English..How many pieces do you want? I said give me 18pcs for crying out loud. I said to the dude behind us...how they not understand? how they not figure out the math? They only pack 12pcs in a box.. I wanted 6 more in a bag. 18 PIECES LADY. OMG!!.. Guess what? The old lady put the extra 6pcs in another box!! F' ing dumbass. I told them to put the 6pcs in a paper bag. So a tip for you all who go there..tell these old ladies the total pieces egg tart when you order. They can't seem to be able to do simple math.
author: Mao M.

description: The best dan tat (egg custard tarts) in SF. Big, flaky, custardy goodness for $1.15 each.   7 x 7 magazine has these listed as one of the 100 foods to try in SF before you die. I can now die...
author: Kim W.

description: If im ever out this way, we usually stand in their line that goes outside the store for an egg tart. Not sure why the egg tart here are so different from other competitors but their stuff is good. I guess this is their specialty because i hardly see people ordering anything else.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is famous for its egg tart , theres alwas a line out there waiting for there egg tart to come out . 

There egg tart worth 5 stars itself , i think its one of the best egg tart u can get in the bay area.

But for the customers service , i can only give them a 2 or just 1 star. Over all they are not too nice to cusomters . I saw a woman want to get an extra box from them but the lady (seems like related to the owner somehow) gives her a hard time. 

They will have a vacation once a year and everytime they will post a notice to tell the customers when they will be re-open but 4 out of 5 times i find out that it's not accurate. For example they wil say store will be close from Aug 1st to Aug 14 so when i come back on the 15th , a new notice will be there saying the store will be opened on the 20th. I mean come on , i dont live in the city and everytime if i go there i have to drive 30 miles. If u intent to open on the 20th why dont u just say it at the beginning ? This had happened to me many times. 

Also during the chinese moon autumn festival , they will be very busy too. When u order it takes more than 3 days to get ur order done . Last year we order and told them we will pick up about 5 days later which happened to be a fri , I went there in the morning and the only thing the tell me is that it's not ready yet. It will be ready in the evening but i told them i cannot wait that long cause i have to get back to work on the other side of the bay ! Another lady is having the same issue. I recomment ppl called to see if there order is order during moon autumn festival before they go to the store.

I am sorry but they have to do better than that !
author: Ed B.

description:
The line may be wrapped around the store, but it is worth the wait!  They are known for their yummy-oh-so-delicious egg tart.  The pastry portion is made just perfect... and the custard itself.. sighhh.. it's ohh soo goood.

They even place it in a pink paper box and tie it with red strings to give it an asian oompf!  :)
author: Lisa T.

description: Egg tarts are amazing. Slowest service ever.
author: Michael E.

description: Egg tart haven.  But I wish they made small egg tarts too.  They box these suckers up in that pink box and tie string around it for easy transporting.  They made it down to San Diego easily as carry on.
author: Grace P.

description: They r re-open now! Best when it's warm, flaky crust and smooth custard. Yummy egg tarts!
author: Miya Y.

description:
the best egg tart ever period.

call in to make sure that they are open. they might take a long vacation in the summer.
author: Te R.

description:
What is this line all about? Wrapped around? Really?! *Walked by it once....

*Walked by it again---should we just stand in line? Nah.

*Walked by it again---oh hell let's get in line. It's shorter!

So waiting about 10 minutes and looking behind me at the 20 people that just lined up, we finally get in the door. I had to just call out whatever it was that I wanted right then and there because it was so chaotic for a small place. 

Walking out 1 minute later, I got a bag full of stuff and excited to dig in. I hope it won't be a disappointment! And good golly miss molly it wasn't! 

The chicken pie was good. I wish I had ordered more. Sponge cake muffin was a bit sugary on top but moist once you get down to it. Rice cakes were good and the egg tarts are bigger than most places and amazing! They have different flavor tarts too but I didn't want to take to long to order or else I was scared I was going to get jumped. lol.

Absolutely deliciousness! This is a must stop shop every time we head into China Town.
author: Betty D.

description: This place easily lives up to the hype!  There is nothing to add.  If you want delicious Chinese desert, it's either here, or head to Beijing.
author: Pedro P.

description: This place has hands down the best egg tarts. I would recommend getting in line early since the line can get long fast! And don't buy just one because you'll regret it the moment you finish it!
author: Kristina P.

description:
Their egg tarts are why people stand in line for this bakery.

The egg tarts are crispy on the outside and perfectly warm and soft in the inside. It is cooked to perfection and its probably why they're usually bought in large quantities and are sold out quickly. 

Walking through the hustle and bustle of Chinatown is worth it for this egg tart.
author: Nance H.

description:
These are the BEST egg tarts you will ever have. Worth the wait in line. 

I always eat one right as I walk out of the store since they are usually always still warm from the oven. At home, I pop one in the toaster oven and as the edges get slightly crisp and the egg custard nice and hot, I slowly eat my yummy little egg tart. mmmmm. 

beware, every so often they are closed for like a month at a time "on vacation"
author: Jennifer T.

description: I have been stopping by this bakery a handful of times in the past 2 months with hopes that the gates would be open and the on vacation sign is gone... sigh, not yet. Couldn't they have added the date they expected to return on the sign at least?
author: Amy C.

description:
Egg custard tarts, blah blah blah. Preaching to the choir here.

We all catch glimpses of each other standing in line at Golden Gate Bakery, knowing that each queuemonger is twitching, money in hand, for that special fix of silky, succulent cream nestled in that flaky crust. GGB is that most excellent of crack dens whose gorgeous spread does more than enough talking to drown out the stark fluorescent lights and accidental sweatshop decor of the place.

Glorious selection! Beautiful roll cakes and pastries galore, none of which I have tried because why would you need to when there are those custard tarts, hot out of the oven and ready for your greedy, hungry hand?

Lines get long but the transactions are swift. Know what you want to order and how many. An assembly line of ladies takes the order, dishes it out, packages it, takes your money and hands you the goods, all in the blink of an eye. Get a few tarts so that you can have one at its ultimate freshest, when the tart has not yet set and delving into it is like eating the best, sweetest, most gloppy, vanilla-y, crusty oyster. Then relegate the rest into the fridge; it's better when the custards have set, and this crust ain't gonna sog up on you like you'd think.
author: Nuri K.

description:
I LOVE this place! Their dun tacs (egg tarts) are the best, & it's always fresh. Yes, it's a little bit overpriced compared to the other dun tacs (egg tarts) in Chinatown ($1.15 each), but I swear, it's the best dun tacs (egg tarts)I've ever tasted. There is a lot of people here sometimes ordering dozen or a couple of dozens of dun tacs (egg tarts), so I would try to come in here when there is only a few people inside. If there is a lot of people ordering dun tacs (egg tarts), you would have to wait a little while for them to give you your order. But they are pretty fair, they take and give their customer's order by the order they come inside by.

Now that I think about it, I'm really craving for one right now ha
author: Yummy T.

description:
Great egg tarts, but they close their bakery way too often and long.

FYI, they are closed for ANOTHER vacation since 9/26 for three weeks.
author: K C.

description:
I've been here a few times since I was little, but I don't ever remember eating an custard tart from here. My friend was appalled, and told me the tarts is a must-try at this place, so off we went.

I wasn't surprised to find a line out the door! I've never been here when there wasn't a line to wait in. 

We came pretty late, so everything in the store was almost out. However, there was about 3 trays of different pastries left. I got my usual sponge cake and ordered 6 custard tart (2 for me and 4 for my friend). The custard tarts were fresh and hot out of the oven when I received them. I think that was the reason why the wait seems longer than usual. 

The custard tart is now my absolute favorite there! OMG! It's so f'ken amazing! I would wait an hour for these nom nom tarts. Oh! the sponge cake never disappoint me here either. It really is a must-go-to place in Chinatown (or if you're near Chinatown, like how I was).
author: Tina T.

description: I live around the area and i always see lines outside of the door! i would recommend the egg tarts. I've eaten  egg tarts around that area, at other dim sum shops and restaurants but i like the ones here the best, My parents bring some home sometimes  and i just gobble mine up. i look at my sisters and i say "hey u gonna eat that?"
author: Calvin C.

description:
This place is by far the best place to grab egg tarts. Truthfully I don't order anything else other than the egg darts. 

I was never a big fan of egg tarts until I tried GG's. The crust is crisp and flaky and the egg filling texture is super soft.

My journey to retrieve them.....
Looking aimlessly for parking in the crowded streets of chinatown
Waiting in line for at least 30 minutes
Making sure you order at least a dozen of egg tarts($1.15) to compensate for all that time 
Savoring each bite when you get home.... PRICELESS

Nonetheless, the egg tarts are truly AMAZING minus the drag buying it.
author: Sophia S.

description:
golden gate bakery, where have you been all my life?  

how could i have failed to visit this place the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th..+ times i've visited sf?  

i can finally cross this off my list.  made my way to this famous landmark this past Sunday around noon.  the line wasn't long when he and i got in it.  we waited patiently as everyone in front of us were getting their moon cakes. got our fresh out of the oven egg tarts, and the boyfriend gobbled one right up.  he and i both really enjoyed our tarts, and will be sure to pay another visit next time we're in town.
author: Sharon T.

description:
On my last trip to the Bay Area I was staying downtown and went for a walk in the morning with one mission in mind - get myself to Golden Gate Bakery and get me some egg tarts.  I remember how wonderful they were from many years ago.  

But after waiting in line and finally getting my scalding sweet morsels (after being body checked by an elderly lady from HK that was on a mission), I realized that it sucked.  I hate Golden Gate Bakery.  I hate everyone who enjoys them - all 300+ Yelpers!  

What went wrong?  I hate them because they are so far away.  I live in Vancouver, which arguably has the best Chinese food in North America.  But we don't have egg custard tarts like Golden Gate.  That sucks.  

Enjoy your damn perfect delicious egg custard tarts, San Francisco!  At least I can console myself by having better xiao long bao here - as if that is really consolation.  

I'll be back, and I'm ready to brave the lines again.  I'm an addict without a nearby fix.  Crap.  First step is admitting I have a problem, right?
author: Marc D.

description:
I'm totally a fan! Delicious egg custards and THEE BEST ones I've eaten. Normally, I'm not such a big fan on the plain old egg tarts you could find at any Chinese dim sum place. But here at Golden Gate Bakery, I could eat these egg custards forreveer!
It's a fairly small bakery located in San Francisco Chinatown and the line can get long. Once I've been here and we had to wait 30 minutes.. at a bakery. The ladies working there can be a little restless, after all, there's always people in line so they're working nonstop. 
On to the egg custards... Eat them right when you get them because when it's fresh and warm, it's the best! The crust is flakly, not hard, and crisp. I don't know how they do it because the crust is different from any other egg tart. The egg is sweet, but not too sweet,  and not soggy. (I've eaten ones where I've taken a bite and the whole egg tart fell apart in front of me..)
I wished I lived in Northern Cal...
author: Rochelle S.

description:
One of the few reasons I drive up to SF to satisfy my egg tart cravings!

It's consistently made right every time, flaky pastry crust and all the goodness of egg.
author: Caroline S.

description: OMG this is the place to get your custard.  It's a good thing if there's a line just for the un tat. Worth the wait!
author: Covenant E.

description:
This place is famous for their moon cakes but I've got to say--the macaroons & custard napoleon are worth saving some room for.  The napoleon is made with eggy fluffy sponge cake, creamy custard, & a light lemon zing--almost made me want to shove it in my face & root around like a crazed truffle pig.  Almost.  The macaroons are all about the texture.  Moist chewy inside, golden crunchety outside with just the right amount of sugar.  How can you say no to coconut?  I'm assuming that the almond cookies are also delish.  *I* can't say since the hubby snarfed them up in record time.  I'm just grateful my appendages were nowhere nearby at the time.

The cute little grannies behind the counter love the fact that everyone is so excited to get their goodies, even the pushy Asian aunties who think a queue is something you wore during the Manchu dynasty.  It's all good, there's enough for everyone.  As with a lot of places, this is cash only so map out your ATM routes.  Get whatever looks interesting & carry it home to snarfle later, it's so cheap you'll be kicking yourself for not getting that last egg custard tart....
author: Cam T.

description:
Food display in the window with only pastries + a long line out the door = A very successful place to snag a mid-day snack

There aren't too many choices, just the right amount if you ask me. Intrigued by the line that went out the door and down the street slightly automatically screamed "Um....Hello!" So like those around me I stood in line and waited. The line moves extremely fast and these ladies know their goods. There's boxes on the back wall so if you're looking to buy a few things in bulk they're stocked and ready for your orders.

My friend picked up a Coconut tart and I the Lemon Napoleon but secretly wished I'd gotten the Curry pastry. The Napoleon was spongy and the outter crust was light and not overly flakey and the lemon not over powering.

Heavenly, cheap and fun. This most definitely will be a place to stop at whenever I'm in the area and looking for a little nosh to nibble on.
author: Morgan M.

description:
An assistant is seven months pregnant and not feeling great. I figure I'll get her a treat for the afternoon. 

Ordered two custard tarts and a lemon filled sponge cake.

One of the four ladies behind the counter gets the cake under the counter , then I watch her get the two custard tarts with the metal tongs. Whoa.....Her hands have major Excema...dry seriously horrible looking peeled skin. 

When she said $6.00, I was in such shock and disgust, I didn't even realize she had also overcharged me, but that's okay. She probably needs it for her skin conditions.

On the way back, I threw away the pastries.  Couldn't do it.

I just have the image of those horrible scales and peels on her hand.

Too bad she can't even wear cotton gloves.

Hope she continues her treatment. Happy New Year!!!
author: miriam b.

description:
Does anyone know how much are the mooncakes here plz?  Preferably the white lotus with yolk.  

And egg custards are the best here!! =)
author: Johnnie C.

description:
Hands down, this place makes the best egg custard (dan ta) that I've ever had in my entire life.  And I say this without hyperbole.  I've loved dan ta ever since I could eat solid foods as a toddler.

When it comes fresh out of the oven (and it usually does because there's always a long line waiting out the door for it), the custard is warm and gooey and the crust is flaky and moist.  A tourist waiting in line even thanked me for the recommendation after she had just a bite.

Be sure to take advantage of little to no lines outside.  These desserts run out fast!
author: Julie C.

description: Everything that comes out of this bakery is freaking good. The place oozes authenticity down to the loud Chinese ladies who some will perceive as rude but most Chinese people will consider normal. I love the egg tart but think the curry and beef pot pie is overshadowed by the egg tart. I just love the flaky layers in both egg tarts and pies. I usually buy 3 dozens of egg tart and whatever is left over of the pies, usually not much. During the moon festival I come here with my mom and stand in the 3-4 hour line for moon cake. I'm not  a fan but its tradition to buy boxes and give them away. Hot & fresh out the oven egg tarts + hot tea = happy tummy on a rainy day. I wish they post when they are closed for vacation though. We tried coming here 3 x's and they were closed. We have quite a drive from Sacramento.
author: van t.

description: Well I'm a custard buttery fanatic pastry's are my go to happy place and now Golden Gate Bakery is my Mecca for all that's good in the world of affordable egg custard tarts what a treat a must go and have it place if your a foodie like me. the line is most all ways wrapped around the corner fantastic lil stores next door to entertain till you till you get in but I digress , not for us this time tho right on in and to the wonderful creamy sweet eggy buttery crusted goodness the lady's there are sweet and very help full know what to get or you get rebuked tho be prepared the moon cakes are Devine coconut and pineapple are so delish' the custard cakes wow ' two wafer cookies sandwich delicate custard and powder sugar sprinkled delicately to cover it gently on its outer sides YUM" the have the macaroons do die for in your mouth very affordable...
author: Keith K.

description:
Speak English. Speak Mandarin. Speak Cantonese.

It don't matter. They understand you as long as you're asking for IT. Yes, the flaky, golden, buttery delight that is the "dan ta" - the egg custard. Like a mini custard pastry, this looks golden with its hues emanating from within a crispy doughy shell.

One bite in and the buttery crust melts into your mouth. The hot custard (much better hot or warm) likewise dissolves into pure sweetness and satisfies like nothing else. 

They've gotten more and more expensive over the years given their popularity in the tourist books, and the wait is usually 5-10 minutes for a short line and progressively longer for a long line.

It's worth it in either case! Promise!
author: Aaron F.

description:
Waited 20 minutes in line on a Saturday, early afternoon. Worth the wait. 

Egg custard tarts were great.
Moon Cake the GF really really liked.
And everything else we tried tasted better than expected.
author: David G.

description: Not worth the 1 hour wait. Save time and get similar crappy egg tarts and moon cakes in other bakeries. Egg was undercooked and the moon cake bland (not to mention expensive at $10 a piece!). Skip this spot. I don't understand all the hype.
author: Ross A.

description: The food here definitely deserves 5 stars but the service and prices speak otherwise. My family used to get baked goods here for years, but I haven't been back since b/c my mom claims she found hair and they didn't believe her, haha. So I recently came back and the egg tarts (my fav) are just as good as I remembered but the lines are UUUUBER LONG! and the prices are so expensive for Chinese baked goodies!! Not to mention service was ehh after waiting 30 minutes to order... GAWD! Is good food and good service too much to ask for?? I'd rather go to clement for my egg tarts, at least the ladies there smile!
author: Jen L.

description:
Definitely make a stop to try the $1.15 egg tart while you stroll down Chinatown.  The egg tart is so darn good when its fresh out of the oven! Warm, mushy egg with light and flaky crust.  Combine this with a hk milk tea (stop by ten ren down the block) and you have a great light breakfast/snack to energize you as you stroll down the super packed chinatown.

I also tried the bbq pork turnover, which didn't taste so great (maybe if i had just stuck with the egg tart, i would be able to give 5 stars).  The bbq pork was just ok and the crust was not light and flaky - nor did it have the honey glaze that i like.  I would skip this and eat an extra egg tart instead!
author: Nancy F.

description:
I don't like egg tarts, and this is the ONLY place I will eat them.

It was love at first bite, and this past weekend was my second trip back, and it was just as good as the first.

Chances are, there will be a line, but a line surely worth waiting for if you appreciate pastries.
author: Vanessa A.

description:
All I can say is I literally stumbled into this place and as I was preparing to write this review I had no idea this place was so popular with my fellow yelpers!!  All I can say wow to the egg tarts!

I have loved egg tarts ever since well I can remember.  I remember going to Dim Sum with my family and being immediately obsessed with the dessert cart because these little beauties were on the cart!  So as I was exploring Chinatown with a friend I said to him we have to find a Chinese bakery---yeah you guessed it I had egg tarts on the brain and I needed my fix --BAD!

We went past one bakery and it looked sorta sketchy so we crossed the street and walked down Grant and there I saw Golden Gate Bakery....there was no line (probably because it was a Wed at 2:30 pm) and the service was as you would expect in Chinatown - Quick, no muss no fuss - what you want, pay. bye.  The end.  I guess when your pastries are as good as theirs are you don't need to woo your clients with great service!  But again - hello its a walk up bakery I am more obsessed with what is going into my mouth not what they are doing behind the scenes.  

I ordered 3 egg tarts and two coconut cake yumminess that were very good as well!  Those egg tarts will have me dreaming again tonight...I may need another fix again very very very soon....mmmmmmm egg tarts.
author: Heidi S.

description: Short and simple. We had the egg custard tart and it was hot out of the oven. It was the best I have ever tasted. It melted in your mouth. There was a line but it moved quickly. It was funny to see the lady who waited on us add up our tarts on a piece of paper to tell us how much we owed.
author: Lynn K.

description:
I went here the day before moving out of Chinatown after reading great reviews on here and wanting to try it before I moved the whole 8 blocks away that I was. 
I found out that I do not like egg tarts. I went in enthusiastically, ordered 4 and couldn't get through one. I'm sure they would've been good had I liked them...
author: Constance C.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is good. The custard and coconut tarts are the best I've ever had. My parents, who grew up in Hong Kong, agree wholeheartedly. 

But Golden Gate Bakery is TOO good. In fact, it's so good I wish it didn't exist - that I might stop wasting my health away frequenting the place - sort of like that whorehouse in the TL (except less itchy).
author: Keane L.

description: One of the best egg custard. So warm and fresh. The wait can be long during the afternoon/evening.
author: Aniko N.

description:
Damn you Golden Gate Bakery, damn you. I thought I'd already had the best of the best egg/custard tarts (I mean come on, I'm practically from Asian breeding ground!)...until I came here. Now, nothing quite does it for me. I'm ruined. I bought a few pastries that the lady recommended along with the egg tart. They were all good, but that egg tart was BOMB.

I hear that Golden Gate Bakery opens and closes whenever the owners damn well feel like it, and thank god I got lucky! The place was open, no lines, and the ladies working were even helpful enough to refer a good foot reflexology place just down the street.
author: Michelle L.

description:
My family and I have been customers for YEARS..and I could say the line for this store is outragous, but trust me, it's worth the wait.

Hot and fresh daan taat (egg tart) anyone? Yum, it's like, heaven in my mouth once I take a bite. Even if it's cold, it's still good. Just not as good of course. It has a flaky crust with a smooth and sweet egg custard filling. (Being Asian myself, I can obviously tell the difference between egg tarts from different bakeries) And I certainly cannot have enough of this deliciousness.

Whoever comes to Chinatown MUST come here and try their egg tart!!
You'll regret it if you pass it up!
author: Jenny Y.

description:
The line out the door exists for good reason. I've never heard of an egg tart before, but my friend insisted that I buy one (in addition to the oatmeal raisin cookie I wanted). That tart puts to shame all other egg products I've ever had! I wouldn't have thought that a jelly-like egg inside of a sweet crust would have tasted as mouthgasmic as it did, but I stand corrected. I've heard this place can be sporadically open, so if you walk by and see it open, make sure you stop there. 

As an aside, the oatmeal cookie wasn't so great.
author: Adam D.

description:
I never knew that egg tarts could ever be this good.

These puppies are worthy of the long ass drive, the crazy Chinatown traffic, the maze of dazed tourists, and the velvet rope that stands between me and my egg tarts.
author: Bonnie L.

description:
Psst! It's all about the egg tarts, blokes!!

Get your 1.10 from that man purse for the guys and handbags for the ladies for 1 egg tart. 2.20 for double the order. 3.30 for your 3 times the charm of egg tarts. And as you go on and on for more, you do your own math. With long line going on, I'm helping ya'll out with not solving the time consuming and mind torturing math. This way, while you do the math and trying to figure with how many of them tarts with your 50 bucks, next thing you know you're almost there!! But that is if you do get and they still have a couple left. Imagine the sucker in front of you bought the remaining left of what they had for the day..what would you do?!

Moral of the story, if you're in Chinatown of SF, pay a visit to the temple of egg tarts. Come early if you hate lines. Don't give any strangers any crazy eyes, or you're just asking for it. You know what happens when they take you to the street of Chinatown..

One star off for getting denied on my last trip!!
author: Rick W.

description:
any chinese people every notice that the "taat" in the pronunciation "dan taat" sounds pretty close to just saying "tart" with a chinese accent? is "taat" even a chinese word? i mean in China they still call it a "dan taat," so it can't be them just saying "tart" with a chinese accent, right? oh my, now i'm just rambling. these are the types of things that run through my head on a regular basis.

anyway the egg tarts here are killer. light and smooth. not too sweet and flaky. love!
author: Regina C.

description: Best egg custard tarts I've ever had. The cocktail buns are damn good too. Actually, I think I'd eat pretty much anything that they bake in there. They do well enough, that when they want to go on vacation they just throw up a sign saying when they'll be back to slang more bakery items. Enough said.
author: Wayne L.

description:
Fellow Yelpers...I am surprised at how easily you award 5 stars!  Not to rain on anyone's parade, but my purchases at Golden Gate Bakery this weekend were disappointing.  

Pardon the makeshift canto pinyin--but those of you who know the Chinese names should get the point...I bought:
-beef curry puffs (ga lay goc)
-steamed sweet rice cakes (bok tong go)
-old wife cakes (lo po beng)
-glutinous rice cakes with red bean and taro (naw mei ji)

Although the beef curry puff had solid looks, when I bit in I think I made a sad face.  What is it doing with corn kernels and tomato pieces?  Unacceptable filler items.  Come on Golden Gate!  Secondly the bok tong go had more of a mushy consistency rather than the normal "glutinous bounce" that most bakeries make it with.

Haven't had a chance to officially review Eastern Bakery on Grant, but I do recall it to be more pleasing.
author: Christopher W.

description: I love their egg tarts and mooncake!  Everytime I'm in Chinatown, I HAVE to get at least half a dozen of their egg tarts!  Yes, they're THAT good!  The tart itself is flaky and crispy, while the inside is light, creamy and smooth! mmMmm!  Definitely worth the wait!
author: Melissa T.

description: Yay, egg tarts! They were warm and delicious! Although I thought there was going to be some special filling so I was a little disappointed when it was just the usual egg custard (albeit delicious custard of course). The loaf of sweet bread I had was also good. I went on a weekday morning and there wasn't a line.
author: Rina L.

description: Egg tarts used to be more awesome but apparently the original recipe never got passed on when the grandfather passed?  Theses were rumors that I have heard from the locals so unfortunately are not validated.  $5 for 4 egg tarts, but they do have a fast moving line.
author: Peter L.

description: BEST EGGTARTS. Hands down. Long lines are so worth it!
author: Jerica S.

description: This the best egg tart I've had in SF. There are many close seconds, however; the city's egg tart selections are not too shabby.  This is more on par with what you'd get most bakeries in Hong Kong (not the best bakeries, mind you, just if you went to a random one).  The first five times I tried to come here, they were vacation.  Yes, every time... and no, I didn't come five days in a row.  One day, I strolled by on my way to the bank and whoaaa!  They were OPEN!  Is this a mirage?  I rubbed my eyes and saw egg tarts.  I left with a box.  Deliciousss.
author: Erika C.

description: Thanks to the popularity of this place you can be guaranteed a fresh egg tart any time of day. This is indeed the best egg tart I've had. Flaky crust, ooey-gooey filling, funky texture, easily worth trying for about a dollar. Their other baked goods pale in comparison.
author: Rahil P.

description: ahhhh Goldent Gate Bakery... its like a love hate relationship here. i LOVE their Dan Tats (egg custards) and their Moon Cakes during moon cake season BUT WHY ARE THEY ALWAYS CLOSED FOR LONG PERIODS OF TIME =.= i'm not always in the area but i feel like every time i just HAPPEN to be in CT, THEY ARE CLOSED -____- it breaks my heart knowing i will go home dan tat less for the evening. but still their egg custards are amazing. probably the best in sf. i haven't tried it in any other cities so i wouldn't know but their lines are worth it.
author: Kristina L.

description:
People said the best egg custards, I'll say the best green tea mooncake.

Waiting is common here. Prepared to wait 15 mins at least cause usually they run out of egg custards pretty fast and you have to wait for them to bake some more.

Noisy crowded little Chinese bakery but tasty and rich egg custards (have flaky crust too!) and mooncakes.

If you are in a hurry, you can get pretty much the same good egg custard at AA bakery at cheaper price. So your call
author: Cliff T.

description:
Holy shit. *proceeds to salivate* This bakery does not look like a bakery inside with all the boxes and junk piled in the back.  So where do they actually bake their goodies?  I wonder the same thing.  

You'll notice this place very easily as there seems to be a line outside often.  They are famous for their egg custards and for damn good reason.  Those babies are to die for.  They are de-fucking-licious when fresh and warm.  The buttery flakes fly to the side of your mouth and cheek because it likes it like that.  If, for some reason, you cannot finish one or two egg custards but don't feel like throwing them away, pop them in the fridge.  They are de-fucking-licious when cold as well - a SURE indicator that this place is BAD ASS.  Their other items are definitely good as well but who cares when they have the best egg custards?  

Word to your mother.
author: Alice C.

description:
Their Egg Tart is what to get.
They have a very small selection of baked goods is why I am giving them a four. But their Egg Tart is the best I have ever eaten. I have never tried a more warm, crispy crust, and creamy custard. Another why I gave this a four was because it was 3 bucks!!! That's nuts!!! I can get three of them at dimsum for that much!!! Of course their reputation and value allow them to price the custard higher. But if you're looking for a small snack, this is perfect to fill that small void before dinner!
author: Jessica Y.

description: another hype gone wrong.  these "famous" egg tarts are super greasy and eggy....not magical at all.   I liked that it was hot and the pastry was soft.  BUT it's not worth the wait, it's not worth the rude service and it's DEF. not worth $1.15.  I rather pay toll with that money than buy these tarts.
author: Jang David K.

description: I've been coming here for as far back as I can remember.  This is the #1 spot in the Bay Area for chinese egg custards.  There is always a line out the door.  Since today was Thanksgiving, the line was a bit longer than usual.  I would have to guess there was about 20 people in line ahead of me.  The wait was over 20 min but well worth it.  Eat them while they're HOT.  The "Dan Tat" will melt in your mouth.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Goddamn. I said GODDAMN.  These are the best chinese egg custard tarts that you can find in SF.    Normally, these desserts are far from my favorite, but I can't stop myself from buying these if I am walking by.

Stress is the only thing that deters me from stopping here more often.  Stress makes this a 4 star review instead of a 5.  What causes the stress?  Let's make a list:

1. The line.  It's long.
2. I don't speak a word of chinese.  I'm sorry lady, you can yell at me in cantonese all day but I have no idea what you're saying and I am not letting you cut.  
3.  Not having enough cash.  Bring more than you think you need because invariably you'll want more than just a couple of dan tat's.
4.  I'm going to be all sweaty running back to the office late from lunch and even though I will try to hide the obvious pink bakery box,  I'll still have tell-tale tart crust bits in my hair and all over my shirt.  Nosy coworkers will force me to share.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
3 words is all you need to know: Egg custard tarts. 

I'm sure the other things they sell are good, but honestly, why come here for anything else? I give this place 5 stars for being the best for what they do.

Once I was on Bart, and there was a Chinese woman with a pink box. It could've been anything from any bakery in the city, but I asked "Are those the custard tarts from Golden Gate Bakery?" Oh yes, they were. She was shocked I had any idea what they were, and frankly pretty impressed. She had come from the East Bay just to pick some up.

Golden Gate Bakery, bringing strangers together on Bart since 2005.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Hands down the best Chinese bakery i've ever been to in the US. If only it wasn't so run-down and they close for weeks during the most random times. Pricey, but i've never felt ripped off from the quality of the food here. Definitely get the egg tarts, as most people have commented, they are the best egg tarts I have ever eaten. Pay specific attention to the crust.. very flakey, reminds me of a croissant.
author: C W.

description:
"I remember when eggtarts were only $.10 each!!!!  "

Oh Wait.. You must NOT be talking about Golden Gate Bakery. On 1/24/09, they are going for $13.80 per dozen. Holy shiiiiiiii But they taste so awesome!!!  like HOLY SHIIIIIIII!! 

The wife and I were armed and ready for a looong line at Golden Gate Bakery. But today was different which knocked me off my game. But good Mooooo fortune must be on my side.  it's chinese new year festival. The street was closed. Somehow the line was short and probably cuz they are not getting their normal drive-by - drop off line builder crowd. 

I thought I was a bad-A$$ big spender to order 3 dozen eggtarts. $40 worth of pastries is alot in my book.  Then this non-asian middle-aged lady walked up. Started her order with 5 dozen eggtarts. Sure, that raised an eyebrow. But the bakery lady didn't even blink and just said "ok, what else?". By the time she was done, the bakery lady told her $146 to be her total. My jaw dropped. I was impressed with this customer AND i'm impressed with GGB's bakery quality assurance that someone would buy that much pastry from them.

Step aside Rice-A-Roni, GGB's Eggtart is the real San Francisco Treat.
author: Denis K.

description: Golden Gate has the best tarts, though $1.50 each is expensive, Sat, waited an hour and half. Line moves slow, Moon Festival weekend, so wait is long..Coconut Moon Cake , the BEST....Today being Moon Festival Day, I ran out of Moon Cakes and  Went to Ruby King Bakery in Oakland, egg tarts 60 cents!!!  They were Yummy, NO WAIT, their Moon Cakes are made in house too, Their light lotus Bean  was better than GG. So , when I'm in SF , GG is my go to Bakery for egg tarts....Ruby King will serve me well in the East Bay, They even have Chicken Buns...Yummy
author: Anna H.

description:
Via a recommendation of my good friend, I came here for one thing only and that is the Egg tarts! You know those little egg pastries that you find on those magical dim sum carts? Yes, I'm talking about those little morsels of happiness. However, Golden Gate Bakery takes the egg tart to a whole new level of food sexiness.

The triple threat:
1) Size: size really does matter. I think it just happens to be a general universal law that big things will entertain your mouth ;) the egg tart of this place is HUGE. It is the big foot of egg tarts.
2) Consistency: the texture is marvelous. Given it's bigger size, the egg custard center doesn't get dry when baking which makes it this gooey jelly like consistency. If I had to pick something of a similar consistency, I'd pick maybe pudding. And with the juxtaposition of the soft delicate melt-in-your-mouth To the crispy puff pastry shell, it really just slides in. Mmmmm.
3) Taste: I think this might sound like a complete surprise but these egg tarts have a really strong prevalent egg flavor LOL. Usually dim sum places egg lots of sugar to give the egg tarts a sweet flavor, but this place knows how to please. The egg tart is the diva to this pastry and it does not fail to impress.

The egg tarts can make everyone happy. Who wouldn't like a big delicious thing slide down your throat? I think these egg-wonderfuls which are famous apparently can stop wars.

Tips: it's really a hit or miss with this place timing wise. Apparently it closes on random days. I came during their reg business hrs and it was closed -.- my suggestion is to just stop by when you can, but don't plan on it being open. But when it is open, buy dozens. DOZENSSSS. They are pretty good to just pop into the toaster for another day :) also, the line can get pretty long. So just know that at the end of it all, you'll have a spectacular reward haha
author: Jon N.

description: all I have to say is EGG CUSTARD TART. fresh, warm, big, and toasted on the outside.. deliciousness inside and out. YUM.
author: Ivy N.

description: The dan tat, pineapple buns and almond cookies all dericious.
author: Dee I.

description:
So overrated and overpriced.  C'mon guys!!!  Look at the egg tart!!!! It glows fluorescent YELLOW.  I just hope it's not some sort of chemical that they are adding from Asia to make them glow like that.  I rather get a Portuguese Tart from Sogos.

stinky tofu
author: StinkyTofu S.

description:
On my umpteenth visit to Golden Gate Bakery on a chilly weekend after Christmas, I found myself waiting in line along the curb next to worn-out velvet ropes that looked like they just came from the 60's. Out of all the years coming here, it was by far the longest wait we had to endure. 

It seems like after every visit, the price of their egg custard keeps creeping up. Before you know it, one of those circular yellow-colored bad boys will be hovering around $3. And I'll still be in line, waiting next to an old velvet rope if I have to.
author: Dru C.

description:
Hands-down the best dan tat in San Francisco.

Yes, I eat other things here.  I usually pick myself out an assortment including lotus bean cakes, red bean cakes, 1-yolk moon cakes, maybe their "special chicken pie" or beef curry pie, and I'm quite happy.

But always, ALWAYS, I load up on the freshly-baked dan tat.  I have never eaten an egg custard tart that's made me so at peace with the world around me.  These ones are nice and eggy, but not so much that it throws off the delicate sweetness and light texture.  I don't know what their secret is, but I wish I could learn it.  There's a reason a line always curls out of Golden Gate Bakery when the dan tat is fresh, and I hope it remains a local perk rather than a tourist destination.
author: Nick B.

description:
My gawd, the crust to the egg tarts were flaky and buttery like a good pie or croissant instead of the usual tart type crust.  Cheaters!  But smart.  Make the tart unique.  Maybe baking it on that is what makes the custard so melt in your mouth.  

Minus one star because this place is the size of a freaking closet and unorganized like one.  First time I went here after 10am it was crowded and out of egg tarts, so I went bright and early the next day and already they were packing boxes of them for customers!  Damn those popular tarts.  This place seemed full of stack of delivery boxes about to tip over or stuff hanging all over the wall behind the counter that made it difficult to read the sign of the items and prices.  The set up and style of the place was just lacking when compared to modern bakeries like Yummy Bakery and Cafe or Washington Bakery and Restaurant.  Of course, you don't need to judge so much on looks when taste matters, but everyone knows the egg tarts are the best.  If business is booming, why not use the money to get a bigger or prettier place?
author: Missa P.

description:
Let me start off by saying this place is located in Chinatown and not in Nob Hill. In no shape or form is Grant Ave. a part of the Nob Hill Neighborhood. Yelp can be confusing at times...More times than not, actually...


Golden Gate Bakery is one of many examples of my rule for eating good Chinese. Notice I didn't say great. That's because great Chinese would take you to Hong Kong and China, NOT San Francisco. If you would take notice, the line that is almost always there is lined up with Chinese folks. Old, young, short, tall...You see them all lined up for one thing and one thing only...Well, maybe something else but the main attraction is the almighty egg custard tart. Dahn Taht. You gotta pronounce the "ah" like when you open your mouth and say AHHH!!! except with the letters that start and end it. The best known dahn taht in San Francisco and probably in the entire Bay Area. Maybe even in all of California but that's left to be seen.

Let's start off with the the shell. A flaky, crumbly, buttery-like maybe shortening but could be a mix of all that crust that is delicious. Soooo tender to the touch and melts in your mouth slowly. And if you take notice at how thin it is...Makes you wonder how they can afford to put in that much custard. And the custard! Ohh so sweet and light...You'll love it once you bite into it. You'll try your best to find yourself another dahn taht that is like this one but to no avail. You're screwed! That's why people leave with dozens.


Now, to the reason why I left a star off. You must be scratching your heads. Well, the reason is the price. They keep jacking the price up everytime they close the place down for a month or two. Now, I don't live in North Beach anymore so I am not sure if they still do that but under the guise of a vacation, they are actually cleaning the place up for their yearly inspection. You know, that green postcard type thing that rates eateries on their cleanliness. Everytime they close for a spell of time, almost everytime they raise the price. But damn us morons for falling for them. It's amazing at how hooked we are to these things that we will pay the amount just for a taste. Sad, really...

Also, the way they come out in batches...If you can call them that. They present them on trays from the kitchen where they are prepared. Now, we all know it would make more sense to come out with more than just one tray at a time but the thing is, if they do it that slowly, people would line up and wait. This is making the line extend itself out the door, therefore making them seem like they are hot shit, which they are and always will be until they call it quits or someone totally destroys the recipe. This is called self marketing and strategy. Because they know a crowd will attract an even bigger crowd because we Chinese are gluttons for this kind of stuff. Even though it ain't free, it must be good! Trust me! I'm Chinese!
author: Anthony L.

description: i happened to eat it's egg tarts twice and i think the egg tarts are really delicious, but the store is always closed and there is why i cannot always go there.  When it's opened, there is a long line of waiting.
author: Mike T.

description: They really do have the best egg custard tarts.  I would give them 5 stars but nfortunately, many times we have tried to get them, they are always on vacation!
author: Gordon C.

description:
What sick gluttony.  Nobody needs pastries like fat Americans. In this place, make it fat asian americans.  The line is always full of aunties and uncles hoping to be lucky enough to have gotten there early enough in the morning to surrender their hard earned money for fresh out of the oven goodness.  All my trips to SF always include a stop at Golden Gate Bakery. Everything is so delicious!  

Their macaroons and their oatmeal raisin cookies are my absolute favorite.  Their lemon bars have just the right amount of tart and their egg tarts are nice and flaky.  I don't know how to judge egg tarts other than by their crust.  I approve of their crust.  Other people mentioned mooncake, I don't like mooncakes in general so i can't speak for them.  My mom loves this place too. This is the place my dad hates when in SF.  He hates lines.  He hates pastries.  He hates spending $60 on pastries. But he will.  because we're so damn lovable!

This place is expensive compared to other asian bakeries, but worth the extra $. You get what you pay for. I've had to come back multiple times in two days because they kept selling out.  If you've been to chinatown you know parking is a pain and traffic stinks, I ended up giving the lady my number and told them just to call me.
author: alphabet s.

description: I am not a fan of egg tart and generally don't bother eating them at dim sum or buy them.  But theirs is great!!! So good that I'd want to  eat them.
author: S S.

description: These are epic egg tarts. Chunkier portions, smooth custardy centre and flaky pastry. Nuff said.
author: Charles K.

description:
Remember growing up and your grandma buying you pineapple and cocktail buns from chinatown?  at first it was..."yum, they're delicious grandma."  then grandma buys them 3-4 times a week and they became breakfast and after school snacks for the next 10 years.  

You then grow tired of them, but don't want to hurt grandma's feelings...so you stuff in that pineapple and cocktail bun week after week.  You finally sum up the nerves and say "Grandma, I don't like them anymore."  Then you see the disappointment in her eyes.  And from then on, she buys only enough for herself.  

Well..from time to time, I'll stop by and grab a pineapple or cocktail bun.  And every time, I'll think of my grandma.

Btw, like what other yelpers have said...the egg tart is the best in town.  They are good!!  You know it's good shit when we, cheap ass chinese, are willing to pay  a whole $1 per tart.  Now..if I could only get my hands on the recipe...
author: hello k.

description:
I will be divulging trade secrets in this review.  Chief ingredient in the dan tat's : CRACK!

If I happen to mysteriously disappear, Golden Gate will have tracked me down and ground me into their next batch of egg tarts.
author: Eric W.

description: I love the eat tarts here!!! All eggs and barely any flakes, whole lot of goodness =)
author: Lilly T.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery...... I hate you!

I hate you for going on vacation so many times a year!
I hate you for increasing your prices from 60 cents (yup that's how long I've been coming here) to now $1.10! 
I hate you for making me wait in line every time!
I hate you for baking those scrumptious egg tarts with the thin flaky crust and the hot eggy custard filling!
I hate you for making me go through withdrawal symptoms when I happen to be in Chinatown and you're not open!!!

And lastly...... I hate you for making the best egg tarts that I can no longer enjoy another egg tart at any other bakery as comparable as yours!
author: Sue Y.

description:
This place truly does have the best egg tart. I have not been able to find another place that makes them as good. With that being said, it isn't the best dessert ever. Anything at Schubert's is better than this. Also, they've been raising prices like crazy. You can get egg tarts, granted..not as tasty, for half the price just about anywhere. At $1.10 a piece, this is my limit. I already have stopped buying them as frequently because of the ridiculous price but if they raise their prices anymore I will stop buying them all together because they are good but not that good!

Minus 2 stars for deliberately gouging people.
author: Diane M.

description:
This place is pretty famous for their egg tarts so when I was in Chinatown with some time to kill I made sure I made a trip to Golden Gate Bakery. I ordered egg tarts ($1.15), a vanilla creme bun ($1.75), and large wife cakes (more than $2 each). 

The egg tarts I got were warm and fresh out of the kitchen. The egg custard is different from most bakeries, it's very delicate and soft. The consistency and texture is a lot like silken tofu. The egg part is good, but I didn't care for the puff pastry crust. At $1.15 a piece they're very pricey and IMO, not worth a special trip. The vanilla creme bun was tasty, but nothing special. The filling has a slightly butter or shortening taste to it and is whipped - I wouldn't buy this again for over $1. I almost never like wife cakes (winter melon filled flaky pastry) and there are few Chinese bakeries that make them to my liking - but when they do I LOVE them. The only other time I've had a wife cake that I liked was when someone gave our family some souvenir wife cakes from Chicago and Golden Gate Bakery is much closer. At over $2 a pop they're not cheap, and I actually think the ones I got that day were a bit burnt. Overall, I don't think Golden Gate Bakery is so super duper special that I would make a special trip to try their goods. Since they're so successful I think they feel that they can get away with charging more than other bakeries in the area. I bought 4 egg tarts, 1 bun, and 2 large wife cakes and it left me $11 poorer. I can get a lot more for $11 elsewhere.
author: Monica W.

description:
OMG the baked curry pies here are a must! 

It comes with a brown flakey crust in chicken, beef, and bbq chicken. They have lemon custards that are also tasty. They have orange sesame balls that are tasty. They have cakes that are tasty. They have cookies that are....

Need I say more?!??
author: Vada K.

description: Wow.. holey moley the egg tarts are good! They are delicious not to mention rather large in size! This beats any/all dim sum place I've visited! This place is cash only, and you may experience a long line. I came in on a Friday in the late afternoon, there was barely a wait. Cash only I believe!
author: Angie Q.

description:
I LOVE egg tarts!  I think I have tried egg tarts in majority of the cities I've visited, and Golden Gate is definitely one of the best places -- this list of cities includes Hong Kong! (Aside: but then there's this place in Osaka that's just out of everyone else's league).

The trick to eating egg tarts is to engulf it while it's hot, bearing through the pain and burning sensation on your upper palate -- a talent requiring years of practice.

The only bad thing about this place is that it's always "On Vacation", and they go for WEEKS at a time.  I swear that've been closed since early August, and I purposely choose a route (through dirty Chinatown) that allows me to walk by this place every day on the way to work, hoping to be greeted by the smell of freshly baked tarted, but to this date, there has been nothing but the feeling of hunger, frustration, and disappointment.

Update:

They are supposedly opening again on Saturday!!! Rejoice~
author: Bill T.

description:
be patient when standing in line, because the egg tarts are worth the wait. flaky buttery crust with creamy smooth custard egg filling. 

the chocolate sponge cake rolls are yummy too. the cream is light and doesn't overpower the taste of the soft chocolate cake. 

then there's the chinese version of a rice krispy treat, but instead of rice krispies, longer/larger bits of crispies are used. i can pick at one all day...it's just fun to eat.

and for something totally not asian, they sell chocolate chip cookies. and honestly, they are pretty damn good cookies. light crunch on the outer bites and chewy soft melty center. 6 for $2...can't really go wrong.

the "paper wrapped cake" or sponge cake is so light and fluffy. i always eat it too fast and it forms into a thick mass that gets stuck in my esophagus leading me to have severe heartburn. even a drink of hot tea or water won't help...but i never learn. it happens everytime!
author: Charmaine L.

description:
Not a big fan of their Egg Tarts. Too Greasy.
So I stop by today and tried their Chocolate Chip Cookie. It's okay and kinda dry. I give it 3.5 stars. 
 I also got the Custard Roll Cake. I give it 5 stars. It's a velvety sponge cake with custard in the center. With thin piece of pastry on the top and bottom. Plus some sprinkles of coconut. Custard's sweetness is just right for me.

I think their stuff is on the pricey side. The silver lining is that you don't have it everyday.

UPDATE: Had the Custard Roll Cake again. This time it was on the sweet side and way to much custard. Not consistent with before.
I finally tried their other Custard Cake. It's a lemony cake with custard. Nothing special, but it's very pricey tough.

At last, their Lao Por Ban is the best. Not sweet, but the filling is just right. the crust is really fluffy. Worth the price and going back for more.  I wouldn't mind having one every month.
author: Toeknee T.
