description:
I've passed by your store before
Eaten one of the custards galore
And seen the line go out the door
And down the street
Customers waiting for their treats
About a block from the Beats

All beautifully baked 
Egg custards, angel food cakes, mooncakes & more
But I implore...

Is it really worth waiting an hour in line for this?

PS.  Mucho thanks to rhymezone.com for graciously helping me with my rhymes past & present.  Thanks also to the real KC for noticing the line during one of his visits.
author: Jen L.

description:
Over 300 reviews giving praise to the city's best egg tarts should be enough for any visitor or resident to want to stand in line for a taste. The egg tarts at Golden Gate Bakery are the best I have ever tried, this includes the egg tarts found in popular bakeries in Taiwan and Hong Kong. GGB bakes their egg tarts fresh- hot out of the oven and quickly packed in a generic pink bakery box ready to go. 

The bakery itself is a no-muss no-fuss shop that also serves other fresh pastries and cookies. Unlike frilly bakeries like Miette or Madeline's, GGB places little to no concern with respect to presentation. SF locals flock to this little gem in the middle of Chinatown for one thing and one thing only. So don't expect any little cute tables set with teacups and doilies. You'll be eating your egg tart out of its box... perhaps squatting on the sidewalk... balancing on heels. Like I do!
author: Elaine T.

description:
The first time I came by Golden Gate Bakery was during the Lunar Festival in Sept. The line looked deceivingly short. I had nothing else to do so I figured, hey, what the heck... I'll wait in line. I hear inklings in my ear that this line can be up to two hours long.... pshhhh I say to myself, no way. 

One hour goes by, I've moved 10 feet, 20 feet to go. Two hours later... I get to the door, soooo closeeeee... I get in 20 mins later only to be bombarded with people inside. I knew exactly what I wanted, 4 moon cakes and an egg tart. All the math is done by hand, so you kinda either have to trust the lady or keep an eye on the math. I jet out of there and hop on my train. I sit down to try the moon cake and its pretty decent. I had the lotus seeds and coconut and pineapple. Of the two I actually liked the coconut/pineapple one more. As for the egg tart, someone else ate it before I got to it :( Which brings me to..

My second trip to Golden Gate consisted of a line as well :( This time, it was only 15 mins long. I ordered my half dozen egg tarts and I'm outta there within 20 mins. The egg tarts are deeeeeelicious. The crust is flakey like a croissant and the middle is more eggy than sweet, which is actually really tasty.

Be forewarned that you'll have to wait at Golden Gate. If you have time, its absolutely worth it. Bring a friend to keep you company :)
author: Danvin R.

description:
CRAZZZZZZZZZZZZAY LINE!!! 30 minute wait at least! There's always  a few middle aged LV bag wearing Chinese ladies ahead of you  hoarding 4 boxes of egg tarts. But the egg tarts are just so damn good! The custard is so fluffy and the crust is sooo buttery and flaky. Right after I obtained these little golden treasures I parked my butt on a bench at the park and indulged. All the old Chinese men thought I was crazy because I was laughing the whole time while eating. I don't know what it is about these egg tarts. Probably about 500 calories pure lard? All I know is that I don't mind that it went straight to my ass for one day.

Coctail bun- too sugary

Curry pie thing- FANTASTIC! Almost as good as the egg tart! Sheng Kee has nothing on this curry pie. It was so warm, not overly curry, not overly meaty and had little bits of corn inside. The crust was similar to the egg tart. Definately will get it everytime.

1 star off for the ridiculous wait and small space.
author: becky s.

description:
I used to work down the street from Golden Gate Bakery and found it on a fluke. On a 3 hour lunch break, I was looking for a chinese bakery that had the white sticky rice cakes, I'm not even sure if that's what they're called. But I love this bakery, their pastries are always fresh, busy as hell but totally worth the wait. The line moves pretty fast considering that it's long most of the time.

Does anyone know what the real name of the sweet sticky white pastries are?
author: Norma P.

description: Damn, they sure raised prices since the last time I've came here. Still the best! Should come after 5pm if you really really want some, there is no line then :) .. Otherwise, forget it.
author: Allyson L.

description: Up early for the fresh dozen and it was heavenly. They sure don't make it like that in NYC anymore. Amazing!
author: Ricky V.

description:
I'm usually not a big fan of egg tarts... so I was skeptical to try this one.  My friends from San Diego have even heard about this bakery, so I had to try it with them when they came up here....

I have to say... it's pretty damn GOOOOOODD... I can see why there's ALWAYS a line out the door.  The line moves pretty quickly though.  Each tart is $2.75 or something like that... but it's pretty big, and definitely FRESH.  It's still warm when they give it to you!  They also have different pastries also... but I didn't want to try them quite yet (but now I wish I did!).  I believe they also sell moon cake too!  You'll see chinese women come here and get a whole box FULL of these egg tarts.  That's gotta be a sign that it's DAMMMMN GOOD AND AUTHENTIC!   YuMmMm I love the crust of the egg tart and how flaky it is.   

It's just a shame that it's in the heart of china town... so difficult to get to!! You'd be insane to drive through chinatown in daylight...
author: Diane L.

description:
The only reason we went here was because of the reviews.  Disappointed I didn't eat the treats right away because we were heading to dinner.  

Just had my egg tart for breakfast with a good cup of coffee...delish.  At first I wasn't sure, because it was my first egg tart.  It was really good, not overly sweet and flaky crust.   

We also ordered the regular rolls, macroons, sweet bread with coconut, and a few other things.  

We had to wait in a line about 15-20 people.  Definitely worth the wait!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Chinatown cops get their donut fix here, except they don't want that sprinkled glazed twisty shit.  They want a dozen dan tats to go along with their morning "cha" or tea.

Order a baker's dozen... 12 for the family get together for Chinese New Year, Moon Fesitval, birthday, funeral, wedding, or just a regular ol' Sunday and 1 to eat right after you slap $13 to the elderly Chinese lady collecting her riches off of egg, sugar, and butter!  

Two of my friends ate one right away and each had chins with flaky bits on them.  But they know better not to brush it off.  You must use the tip of your index finger to collect each crumb and lick it back up.  Those three specks cost $0.02 each!  Expensive crumbs!

We pass by all other Chinatown bakeries and we laugh.  "You no got line out the door!  You call that a 'dan tat'?  That egg jello on pie crust."
author: Chris T.

description:
OH MAN. Golden Gate has the BEST egg custard tarts aka FAT TARTS in the world! I was staying at the Hilton near Chinatown and with the bakery only 2 blocks away I just had to try it. Moist, warm, sweet, and full of egg yolks. :) 

Would recommend you go early in the morning to avoid the lines and walk around Chinatown to burn off the fat tart that probably went straight to your fat thighs. MMMM....

5 fat stars
author: Sarah H.

description: Dis be de best place in town fo' little Chinese baked baaaads. You's gots'ta hit dis place down early o' durin' de weekday o' ya''ll be spendin' yo' sweet time in line. But it be still wo'd de wait. Man! You's hear me?
author: Yue T.

description:
For years I walked by this bakery and the line was always out the door. I didn't understand the appeal of it. The pastries didn't look that impressive. In fact they looked rather bland. Then one cold winter day, when the line was only 5 people long, I decided to see what the big hoopla was about. I ordered a few "baos" and a custard cake thingie and paid about 25 to 50 cents more for each piece than I would have anywhere else. When you're used to pastries being only $0.50 a piece that's a 50-100% price increase right there! "This had better be good!" I thought as I marched out of the bakery. 

I was so angry that I paid double what I was used to paying, the moment I got 10 steps out of the bakery, I opened my bag and grabbed whatever I could reach and took a bite. Yep - definitely worth it! All of the pastries were soft and rich. The lines are well deserved for this bakery. 

One time I came in and they had TONS of empty cereal boxes piled high. That's probably their secret ingredient that has us all coming back. There...I said it. Don't tell anyone I told you.
author: Candy C.

description:
The only thing I ever indulge in here are the chocolate dipped macaroons. Seriously they are amazing little stacks of heaven! I love this place because it is a simple order and leave type place. So go in & know what you want or else the asian ladies will eat you alive!

Also, the life size pictures of Bill Clinton visiting their store makes for great entertainment while waiting :)
author: Alyssa S.

description:
I strongly disagree with whoever said the dan tat are not as good as before.  They're just as incredible as ever (at least as of 3:30 pm today)..  and I have a sample of 2.5 dozen to prove it.

The curry beef, chicken and char siu pies are also delicious.


Tip:  If you REALLY wanna indulge yourself, go home and sprinkle a little plain white granulated or turbinado sugar (moist, regular brown sugar doesn't work) over the top of each tart.

then carefully slide them out of their paper muffin cups and take a creme brulee torch to the top (just 7-10 seconds will do or else you might scorch the pastry edges).

Voila! - Instant portuguese (macao) dan tat..  with a perfect little caramel crunch at the top!
author: Nicole L.

description:
A coworker just offered me an egg tart from here. It's already gone. I'm sucking the remnants from my teeth as I type this. So delicious.  Thanks for reminding me to review this place.
 
My first trip here was with friends from LA who insisted that we stop here for egg tarts. I thought he was crazy. There are bunches of bakeries in Chinatown and you want to stop at the one place with a giant line? And it took a while.  Apparently they were baking fresh ones. "Whatever" was my initial thought. My friend was nice enough to share in spite of my disbelief. OMG. I don't care that it's touristy, expensive ($1+), and there's a line out the door. The egg tarts are large and perfectly sweet and buttery and yummy. Man, I need another one. 

BTW, there's a Washington Mutual right across the street ; )
author: Yan E.

description:
We were depressed & feeling disappointed after a horrible dim sum experience, when my BFF remembered this fantastic egg tart place that her friend had taken her to before. 

We eventually found Golden Gate Bakery after wandering around Chinatown for a while. There was only 1 person in line ahead of us when we got there (not very soon after we got to the front did a line materialize out of nowhere)! 

We scored 2 big boxes of warm egg tarts and resisted the urge to try one until we got to our car. Once in the safety of our car, we dug in to surprisingly warm, deliciously sweet (not too much), eggy, creamy egg tarts! After the first bite, our spirits were lifted and into our second egg tart we believed in San Francisco's Chinatown again.
author: Janny W.

description:
4 stars for the eggtarts only.. but they used to be better. there's a RUMOR that the original chef died making eggtarts in the basement but i bet its just a rumor from competitors...

the other pastries are just okay. but really, i haven't found a superb Chinese bakery in the Bay. ... The best cocktail buns closest is in Vancouver BC, Canada.. Michelle's.

there's a line every time i come, but its Chinese, so it goes fast. The ladies are helpful and speedy. pricey, yes, but fresh eggtarts are worth it!

thumbs up: speedy, fresh, warm eggtarts
thumbs down: pricey, other goods aren't as good.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Their egg custard tart is like a delicate, flakey, flavorful foodgasm for your mouth.  Second only to the best egg custard tart I've ever had, which was actually bite-sized egg custard tarts, which they served at some shishipoopoo dim sum restaurant in Hong Kong my rich aunt took me to many years ago.  Every egg custard tart I've had since, for the past 12 years, has fallen somewhere between pretty good and straight up janky.  The shtuff they're pushin over at Golden Gate Bakery, though, comes pretty damn close to the Best Egg Custard Tart I've Ever Had.  The lines out the door don't even bother me.  I like to stick my face up on the window and just drool directly onto the glass.  It's fun for me.

Word to the wise, though: eat it while it's hot.  Otherwise, the bottoms get mushy.  Mushy + Egg Custard Tart = Taste Disaster.
author: Diana Y.

description:
ok ok so friends have been criticizing me for my recent barrage of shitty reviews and for that i apologize.  i will make it up with this review.  well, at least ill try.

you know what?  golden gate bakery deserves 5 stars.  it truly does.  anyone that knows chinese deserts knows about the egg tart.  flaky pie quality crust with egg custard innards.  the fact that it comes straight out of the oven and into my mouth, burning several layers of epithelium off the roof, gives new meaning to the phrase 'hurts so good.'  

BUT....twice have i come here during normal operating hours and twice have i stared at the note saying "we are the shit and dont need to uphold normal business hours" (paraphrase).  twice have i ran home with watery eyes and an empty tartless belly.  indignation has forced me to exert all of my diminutive power over this establishment by removing a star....twice.
author: Paran Y.

description: By far the BEST egg tarts!!! Worth the 40 minutes wait. The custard so creamy and the outside is flaky. $1.25 is so worth it.  Can't wait to go back for more.
author: lisa w.

description: The egg tarts are worth standing in line 30 mins for and I'm not even that big of an egg tart fan!!
author: Anita L.

description: The line was super long but I bet that had to do with the Chinese New Year festival that weekend. I got the customary egg tart and found it to be really good and really eggy. I wasn't too fond of the chicken pie or the pork bun, but I will come back for the egg tarts.
author: Michele M.

description:
ALL TIME favorite chinese bakery. I love their egg tart ($1.15 each), coconut macaroons, and crushed peanut mochi. All egg tarts are right out of the oven. 
I bought 2 dozens today and my family from New York finished all of them in no time :)
author: K L.

description:
Golden gate bakery: GGB as my close circle of buddies call it.

I have a very nostalgic attachment to this place. Why? Because me and a group of friends would have DAN TAT (egg custard tart) THURSDAYS, which means i made the trek to Chinatown all the way from 1 market to grant and Jackson, for what? That sweet little flakey crispy goodness of a dan tat. I would look forward to Thursdays just to get my hands on a nice toasty warm and fresh dan tat from the one and only GGB. No where else was acceptable. 

One time (actually on many occasions) the family that owns it will randomly close down the shop for days, maybe even a couple weeks, at a time to go on vacation. Of course, they're probably raking in tons of sweet moolah from all the people that line up out side of their little bakery everyday. They can afford to just pick up and go on vacation whenever they want, because they already know, that they already have a set clientele that so devotedly will come back for more upon their much anticipated return. 

When I was young and stupid, I thought getting any old dan tat from c-town would be ok, I was desparate for one and GGB was closed. So I went down grant and came upon the other bakery (the one with bill Clinton's picture in it) how could you go wrong?!?! Bill Clinton was here!!! But I was so wrong..... thus this brings me back to GGB.... 

Seriously, if you like egg custard tarts. You MUST. I really really really mean it. MUST try one from GGB. If I knew you, I'd buy one for you to try it. i buy like a half dozen or so and share the tarts with my dearest co-workers. Spread the joy...

One down side. Just one.

They charge $1.10 for ONE tart. That's outrageous. But do you know whats more outrageous? I walked all the way there even though I knew I was getting totally ripped the heck off. But I'd be taken to bliss again once I got my tart... unless I came on a day where they were on vacation... ALL OF THAT? FOR NOTHING!!!!  *eyes burn with rage*  yes, I get very upset over the tarts from GGB.

And their sponge cake is good too. :)
author: Irene C.

description:
Everyone's already said it but their eggs custards are soooooo good! And I always try to drop by when I am in the Chinatown area (once every few months).

But my gosh, it has been closed 4 of the 5 times I've ever went. Therefore, I've only tried it one. I wouldn't make it a trip to go there but will definitely keep dropping by when I'm in the area.
author: Van C.

description: EGGTARTS!! They taste almost the same if not better, than the ones I get at home in Malaysia. This bakery is so popular that there's always a line ...but it moves pretty fast and its definitely worth the wait. Unfortunately I can't say anything about the other baked goods because all we really wanted were the egg tarts.
author: Shan K.

description: I grew upneating their egg custards! The taste is one of a kind. You can't buy the same custards anywhere else. However the lines are really long because the employee calculate the totals mentally. So the wait it quite long.
author: James L.

description:
I used to walk past this place and wonder about the long line outside. Was this place really that good? So I always went there for my egg tarts and sponge cakes. After some research about the place I learned a couple of things people might not know..

The reason why you wait so long in line is because their service is slow, now why would they want to give slow service? So there would be a line, creating the idea to people passing by that the place must be good. I know this because I kno people that work there heh heh seriously...anyways though, they are not the best in chinatown but they definetly are not the worst. I dont really have much to say about disliking their pastries. I mean the egg tarts arent really that bad, tell you the truth i think they are pretty good. The sponge cake is also quite yum, especially with a nice glass of milk. Yes they are overrated and you can definetly find better but they still taste good.
author: phillip w.

description:
The last time I was here, I was probably around 9 years old. And of course, at 9 years old, I wasn't Yelping yet! To me, I'm not super crazy about egg tarts or anything, but my more traditional-Chinese boyfriend, loves them. Everytime he goes out to the city, he tries to buy some of these at Golden Gate Bakery. Last weekend, we came and it was my first time going back since I was little.  

When you hear the name and the popularity, you would think Golden Gate Bakery is some big bakery with lots of items.  However, it's the total opposite. When we went, there was a line out the door, and inside of the store, it can literally fit around 4-5 customers maximum. 

Golden Gate Bakery has other items besides their egg tarts, but that's all that we bought that day.  and let me tell you, these egg tarts are AMAZING when fresh. I'm usually not a huge fan of egg tarts, but the egg tarts here are sooo damn good. Definitely brings me back to the egg tarts I had in Hong Kong.. mMmmm.

Funny thing happened while I was here... They have some squishy looking white dessert that kind of looks like Mochi, but I had no clue what it was. But since it looks squishy, and I apparently have my childish moments, I just had to go and poke at it. Next thing you know, one of the ladies behind the counter throws a little sign onto the dessert platter that says "DO NOT TOUCH!!"

the funny part of it is, she said something in Cantonese pretty loud, but I had no clue what she said since I don't understand Cantonese. But my boyfriend told me that she pretty much said something like, "and they still keep poking at it.. i don't know what is so funny to poke at it." it doesn't sound so funny in english, but when my boyfriend translated to Mandarin to me, I thought it was pretty damn funny.

Last but not least, some important information: parking is very hard to find. On the intersecting street, there is a parking garage that is cheap!  Golden Gate Bakery only takes cash, and egg tart's are around $1.80 each I believe, if I remember correctly
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Although their goods are highly priced since they straight up got a monopoly on the tart-baking business, the stuff is damn good from the renowned egg tarts to the mochi to the coconut tarts. The crust is virtually puff pastry, very flaky and buttery. 

Like apple pie to Americans, egg tarts are a staple baked good to Chinese people. And like the $1 Chicken Sandwiches at Mickey D's,  eating $1+ tarts from here for 30 days straight will result in the same pain felt by Morgan Spurlock. Yet, Chinese people, myself included, will continue to crave this stuff like crack cocaine. In the future, GG will become an evil corporation, taking advantage of the price inelasticity and burden the blame for obesity on the Asian population in America.
author: Ed L.

description: Hands down, they have the BEST egg custard tart "dan tat" in the BAY! there is almost always a line when i go and i usually pick up half a dozen to a dozen because those bad boys disappear as soon as they arrive home. The crust is super flaky! Even after its popped in the toaster oven. =)
author: Jo L.

description: there main item here is their egg tarts "don tot " they are the best ! but it is not cheap I think it is $1.10 each but worth it. they do have other items but I don't recall how they taste.
author: Nellie J.

description: So I bought egg custard tarts to enjoy for dessert. I even popped them back into the oven to warm it up and make it a little flakier, but BLEH. The egg custard fell apart as soon as I picked it up. The crust was all chewy and soggy. The custard was ... eh.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
OMG, i finally PASSED MY LA LIMIT... *gasps*

i wrote 2 reviews today, and they both go out to the GOLDEN GATE. this one (bakery) & the golden gate bridge ... chk the next review. 

***

Was it WE~~~~LLLLY WE~~~~~LLY worth waiting almost an hour or so for this bakery? I have to say, unfortunately, so. Being an Asian pastry fanatic I am, came here and Garden, and I swear, 5 people have been raving how awesome their egg tarts were, and I have to say, my GOSH. After waiting an hour, I was lucky to say that I was one of the few victims to be in getting those freshly baked suckers.  

You don't understand how GREAT it felt stepping IN the door as I became the few who were ready to get my claws on those monsters! 

ALAS! COME TO MOMMY!! =)

DAYAAAAAAM.  

Can I say, "o m g!" the second it landed IN MY MOUTH and went RIGHT through the canal... I had to get 2 especially after waiting in line so long, but I had to contain myself only because I knew I was going to hate myself to come back another egg custard. But you know it's REALLY funny when you have to eat your mooncake w/kimchi ... 

LOL. Sorry guys, I was craving Kimchi for some odd reason. 

Since it's the mid autumn festival going on, my friend & I literally went in and out of all the streets of Chinatown. 

Def try their moon cakes (I tried the one with the yolk inside) & their egg tarts, and I'm telling ya, it was SOOO BOMB...I took a picture of a squishy one since it was too hot for me to hold onto, and I didn't wanna get my hands all oily. I swear, you have to try it when it first comes out, all fresh and shit. You get taken away from all the mid autumn festival madness and wonder where you're at.. The flaky part was super crispy... mm. oh and my beautiful precious looking FAT mooncake. 

What really annoyed me was watching all these elderly ppl cut in line, and having the Asian blood in me, biting my tongue wondering if I should say something or stand back and respect them.. UGH. OLD FARTS... You love 'em and hate 'em. *shakes head* what can you do?

But, def, try it, it's def one of my favorites in the city and worth standing in line.. lol.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Yes. The egg tarts ARE all that. This hole in the wall did NOT disappoint. Not only was the egg tart super delicious, their other items were fantabulous as well! I feel like they just kept everything old-school, and that's exactly what I like about it. Yummmmm
author: Es L.

description:
i have to say they have the best egg tart i've ever had in my life.  Despite the long wait during lunch hours, it's well worth it!!  The other bakery items are great as well, especially the pineapple bun, and the cocktail bun.  I've heard that their beef curry bun is very yummy as well (damn it i'm a vegetarian).    

Thus far Golden Gate is the best authentic Chinese bakery i've found in the bay area.
author: Mandy C.

description: YUMMY is all I have to say for this place. Not just great bang for your buck but the customer service is excellent. We have always had a great experience and great food when coming here. ENJOY
author: Maria L.

description: I don't think these were the best egg tarts that I've ever had but they are delicious nonetheless. I was lucky enough to be there when there was no line!
author: Yumi H.

description:
The line was about 15 people long and I only waited 20 minutes. Of course, this was around 2pm on a Sunday afternoon - I usually see much longer lines in the morning. I suppose people think that the egg custard tarts are fresher out of the oven in the morning, but this is not true - Golden Gate Bakery is making fresh egg custard tarts all day! When it was my turn, a fresh batch had just come out of the oven :)

I also bought a mooncake the day after Mid-Autumn Festival. I like that they sold moon cakes individually since I don't want 4 of them.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Hands down, the best egg custard (egg tarts) ever!!! EVER!! Did I say ever? The lines are long as hell but it is so fricking #%^#$%@%# good. And yes, I think they are like friggin $0.90 for one. It's worth it though.

Trust me, you will get a foodgasm when you take your first bite into that flaky buttery yummy crust... I want one now...
author: C. T.

description: These are the best Dan-tah (egg-tarts) that I have ever eaten.  Worth the little wait and just amazing flavor/taste/texture.  You will not regret making a detour to come here for an egg tart.  Price is very reasonable/cheap and tasty.
author: Helicon K.

description: This review is only for the egg tart.  The crust has the right balance of softness and flakiness.  The custard has just the right amount of sweet and is almost flan-like.  Definitely the best egg tart ever.  I'm not an egg tart fan but would definitely come back.  No lines at 6pm on a Wednesday afternoon.
author: Will W.

description: Hands down most delicious flaky custardy egg tart. I stand in line every single time in rain and storm lol. But call ahead to see if they're open, they close for vacay a whole lot.
author: Linh V.

description:
As everyone else has said here on Yelp, it is the best egg custard tart in town.  I've waited here for upwards of an hour and a half just to get inside and get my order of dan tats in.  The dan tats are fabulous, especially if you can get the straight out of the oven.  When they are warm, the custard just has this wonderful silken texture and the crust is perfectly flaky.  They are sweet, without being cloyingly so.  We usually try to order at least a dozen, just to compensate for the time we've spent in line.  While we'll eat a couple right off the bat, we save some for the next day and they are still great cold or slightly re-heated.

In addition to the dan tats, we'll get the wife cakes, though its not as great as the ones I remember from Hong Kong.  However, they are the best I've had in SF, so I'll continue getting them here until I can afford to go back to HK.       

I also like to get the coconut tart - a lovely confection made of the same basic crust as the dan tat, but with a filling of coconut.  The filling again, isn't too sweet and the flavors definitely hold up for eating the next day.

My sister likes to order what I call the Chinese version of rice krispy treats.  I have no idea what they're called, but they come in blocks and I usually just point to them as I order.  Unfortunately, they were a little dry and slightly stale on one visit, and hence, GGB gets a -1 star for that.

Overall, a great place to try dan tats and other delectable Chinese bakery items.  There is a long wait on weekends, they are closed some months of the year, and they do charge much more than other places, but the dan tat is definitely worth all the aggravation.  I go there every chance I get!
author: Angela H.

description:
Who doesn't know Golden Gate Bakery? I've been coming here since 2001. The egg tart is so DARN good that my friend wants to place order all the way from Atlanta, GA. I tried egg tarts at some of the dim sum places but they weren't just the same. Another not bad substitution is the egg tarts at Wonderful in Oakland. Of course nothing beats Hong Kong!!!

Besides egg tart, you can also try coconut tart (macaroon), mooncake, or winter melon biscuit (wife biscuit). Make sure you bring enough CASH and there is always a line at the store. But those warm and flaky egg tart will warm your heart!!!!
author: Emily L.

description:
So I finally did get around to trying Golden Gate Bakery today at 2pm after I took off work to start my weekend and after I assumed the lunch rush would have subsided. Still had to wait in line for 5 minutes which makes me wonder what the hell the line is like during lunch.

Yes, the Egg Tarts are the best I've ever had. I can safely say this without inhibition. They are not too egg-y, the custard is silky and almost melt in your mouth, and the pastry crust is so flaky and rich that you can almost feel the butter coursing through your veins. Yes, they're that good. They are worth the heart attack that will later occur. They are worth everything. Do they have crack in them? I don't know, but they are good. Yelp is correct.

But are they worth $1.10 for one egg tart? No egg tart is worth that price. Yet I will probably go back... multiple times this month... simply because they are delicious and I work not even 4 blocks away...

The other items I bought today were less satisfactory. The beef curry pastry was tasty, but too greasy. The filling was good, but it would have been so much better as a bao instead with a sweet, almost hawaiian roll quality to the bread dough. I also bought a sesame ball, which was a total rip off. It had a tablespoon, MAYBE TWO of red bean paste in the middle of a ball that was 3 inches in diameter. Mostly air... not even enough rice to make it worth while.

And despite these negative points for Golden Gate Bakery, I still give them 4 stars. The egg tarts are just that good. Hell, I'd give them 5 if it weren't for the price and the line.

I managed to feel less bad about my caloric intake by walking up to Coit Tower to eat my tart there. The greatest thing was it was still warm when I got up there. Must have been steaming hot when I got it from the shop... yum...
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I'm not going to say that Golden Gate Bakery is bad, but I was not very impressed by the egg custard tart, which is supposedly the best pastry they make. It was too eggy, messy, and rich. I took about two bites and then threw it away- normally impossible for me.

They still get 3 stars because I'm chalking it up to different tastes. I'm not used to a dessert that tastes so strongly of eggs... it's like a souffle x 10. Maybe I'll try something else, but I'd be really pissed if I'd waited in a long line for that!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Did my share of waiting in line for 3 hrs at golden gate bakery...tho it wasn't for the egg tarts, but mooncakes. We did get egg tarts tho :) and as always it was yummy. 

I got 5 diff mooncakes: coconut, almond, green tea, date, taro. My fav has to be coconut-it has nuts in it. Date is probably my least fav coz it is way too sweet. I dig the taro, would be better if it's more chunky tho.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Sweet, EGGY custard? Check.
Served warm and ooey gooey? Check.
Flaky pastry that crumbles as you eat it? Check.
The best Dan Ta in the Bay? No question, Golden Gate ftw.

Now the better question.. is Golden Gate or Kee Wah better? SF vs. LA. A side-by-side showdown is physically impossible, you could never get the freshest, just-out-of-the-oven specimen next to each other fast enough.

Golden Gate has the advantage of a madhouse atmosphere where the constant stream of pushy Asian Grannies ensures you'll get the freshest goods. Their tarts are also bigger than Kee Wah's.

I don't advise waiting for the rush to die down because the tarts don't maintain their perfection in the later hours. I bought some around 7 p.m. and the outer layers of pastry shell had hardened. The custard stayed too wet after cooling to room temp, but if you chill it further, it'll set better. Kee Wah gets points here for investing in a warming oven to preserve the quality of their tarts and pies throughout the day.

What about the rest of Golden Gate's merch? They have a relatively limited selection of baked goods. I didn't see Pineapple Buns. The Custard Buns weren't on the display. And their set-up makes the shop ridiculously difficult to browse. You better know what you want when you get to the front of the line. Lucky for you, their English is significantly and demeanor friendlier than the belligerent ladies at Kee Wah.

Another goodie: They have a fantastic Chicken Pie! Get it, you'll see. It's so much better than you'd think it'd be. MMm, nummy in my tummy.
author: Albert H.

description:
Okay, I may come off as a cheap bastard for complaining about the price of something that's around a dollar, but it has to be said. I swear I'm really not this frugal, but that is one OVERPRICED egg tart, homie. If you're Chinese and/or an egg tart fan, you know what's up. When you take into account all the other Chinese bakeries in the Bay Area and the egg tarts that you can order at yum cha (dim sum), it's not really worth it for the trek into Chinatown unless you're already there and craving it.

In all fairness though, it is pretty yummy. They're a little bigger than the norm (as they should be . . . for that price) and the best part is the crust - buttery, flaky, and mouth watering when fresh and still warm and crispy. The egg custard filling is solid, sweet and eggy. Definitely worth trying, but I'm not sure I can say the same for making the trek out here just for a pricey little thing of essentially eggs and flour.
author: Betty W.

description: Stopped in here to try one of their popular egg tarts... and I gotta say, I wasn't too impressed.  I mean, it was certainly tasty, but the consistency was way off.  It wasn't nearly firm enough, and as soon as I picked it up to eat, the bottom fell out.  I managed to quickly scoop it all into my mouth while I stood on the sidewalk, looking like a starved pig to anyone walking by.  If only the custard was a bit firmer and held together better, I would have been able to savor each bite as it deserved.
author: Deanna T.

description: I went on a Monday morning around 1030am, and it was only a 5-7 min wait.  Their egg tarts were fresh, warm, and soooo milky-custardy.  Delicious!!!
author: Angela L.

description:
We come here everytime we visit Chinatown, which is quite often.

This bakery sells pastries that are fresh (baked that day) and are very delicious. Its well known both by the locals and tourists. You'll always see a line out the door any time of the day. The prices are higher than other Chinatown bakeries, but you know you're getting good quality pastries. There's also a huge selection so you're bound to find a few items.

Most pastries are the traditional Chinese types, but they also carry Napoleans as well. Their egg custards are one of the best (you get a deal if you buy a dozen). Other good items include: wife's cake, cream roll, moon cakes aren't too bad, baked pork buns, a stacked cake like item w/a biscuit on top with a dusting of powdered sugar (can't remember the name, but it's one of the items upfront on the counter), white lotus rolls, walnut bread loaf/cupcake, and so many more. Just try any of their items and i'm pretty sure you won't be disappointed. 

Minus one star for inconsistent treatment by the staff. The ladies that work there can be the friendliest at times or very rude. The bakery itself gets very packed and crowded so I wouldn't recommending sitting although there's about two small tables w/two chairs each.
author: Veronica H.

description:
Best egg tarts in America.  

Only place in the planet where I've eaten better tasting, creamy, buttery, flaky tarts is in Macau.  In case you don't you know..think of Macau as a Las Vegas but in Asia.  Likely more corruption and way more prostitution...but I diverge.

Go here.  Family-run..always a line.  If you're in the Chinatown area I'd recommend putting your order in and grabbing a number..so you can come up in 1-2 hours to pick it up rather than wait.  Especially if you intend to order a dozen or more!
author: Yup S.

description: I have to add my two cents (for free). SO GOOD. The best part is the egg custard is not too sweet, just flaky crust and delicious custard. The coconut tart is pretty good too, it is more cakey but you can definitely taste the coconut.
author: Cherish H.

description:
As we all know in San Francisco, short, feisty Chinese women with their pink plastic bags will try to take advantage of organized lines. In this case, DON'T LET THEM. As everyone proclaims, the Dahn-taht/Egg Tarts are the best in the city. 

Try the other pastries too... from the sesame balls filled with a sweet red bean (jeen-dui), or the "loe-poh-bang," which is a flat, flaky pastry that tastes like the baked, buttery crust of your momma's warm, apple pie. Or just point... it's all pretty tasty.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
The best dan tat (egg custard) I've had was in Taishan, China. The second best dan tat I've had was at Golden Gate Bakery so I give it more like 4.5 stars. I treated myself to one today and it was simply satisfying despite the minimal wait. It's definitely as good as you can get around here and their cha siu baos (baked bbq pork bun) are one of the best around.

I admit it, I'm a dan tat and cha siu bao snob. I refuse to buy my custards and buns anywhere else except here. It's definitely quality over quantity with their freshly baked items. Their custards are served hot and fresh with a glistening silky filling and flaky crust. Their buns filled with lean meat are juicy and baked to perfection. Other places serve rock hard custards and buns with fatty junk meat and enough dry bread to choke you! Fork out the extra change and you won't be disappointed.
author: Sara N.

description:
The best egg custards I ever had in the states, period.  And I've had been to many places in NYC, LA, and SF.  

I absolutely love their egg custards!!  The thin flaky crust makes room for extra egg, and is baked to perfection.  Every time I am in Chinatown, I will try to swing by get my egg custard fix!  Oh... they're soooo good... especially when freshly out of the oven, well worth the wait in line.  And I remember how disappointed i got in the summer when they close down for month-long vacation.  (Yes, they have enough business to do that!)  I want to eat one now just writing about it!!
author: John C.

description:
When going to Chinatown and looking for a pastry shop, ignore every single shop you run across until you get to Golden Gate Bakery. Don't even think twice about it and just go here, even if the line happens to go out the door (which it usually does).

All of their pastries and pies are great here. They make great almond cookies, chicken pies, and curry pies. However, as anyone will tell you, most people come here for the egg custard tarts.

Simply put, they make an egg tart the way it is supposed to be made. The custard stays incredibly soft and has exactly the right amount of sweetness. The crust is flaky and buttery, which is the right way an egg tart should be and not the standard pie tart crust that some places  use for their egg tarts. Also, they have their ovens running all day, which pretty much guarantees when you order your egg tarts, they will be warm.

Yes, most of the time there will be a line, but believe me, it's worth it. I brought a friend here a couple weeks ago when we were trolling Chinatown for Asian movies, and after eating just one bite he was immediately convinced that he had to buy a dozen and take it home.

Make sure not to go during Chinese New Year or Mid-Autumn Festival, because the store closes during those times. The rest of the year, though, they are open.
author: Brandon T.

description: I decided to stop in for some egg custards and of course when I get there I see a line outside the shop. I walked over and stood in line. The line was so so so slow but I eventually made it to the front. I ordered a dozen of those little egg custard for around $13. I thought it was pricey but oh well. The egg custards were hot out the oven, the crust was flakey and buttery, and the custard was light. It was great!
author: Mimi L.

description: Unforgettable.  Don't miss this bakery while visiting San Francisco.  I have been here on 3 separate occasions when I visited San Francisco and all 3 times the food was simply amazing.
author: Protorontonian C.

description:
IF I WERE STRANDED ON A DESERT ISLAND...I would want a dan tat/egg custard tart to eat everyday.  IF I COULD PICK WHICH PLACE TO MAKE IT...I would pick Golden Gate Bakery to bake it for me!

YES, it is the most expensive dan tat I've had.  YES, there is usually a long line at the bakery.  And YES, it's really fattening!  BUT I LOVE IT..I LOVE IT...I LOVE IT!
author: Angie K.

description:
Lines out the door for Pastries???  What's going on here.  All the people in line have this glow on their face like they are going to heaven.  Well, if you've seen this phenomenon on Grant Street in San Francisco, looks like you just might have to join this line.  You won't regret it.  

Been coming here off and on throughout my life.  And yes, everyone comes here for their custard tarts.  Perfect texture with a bit of flakiness.  It has progressively gone up in price throughout the years and I kind of hate that.  However, if you really, really think about it, a $1.10 (I think), which is what it goes for now is nothing if you compare it with some other pastry places.  But you know how it goes, we just want the Chinese "Discount"........

On my last visit here, I had actually went to La Boulangerie in Hayes Valley earlier in the day and my sis picked up a couple really small pastries (about the size of a half dollar) for $3...  2 for $3!!!!!  

Nuff Said....  Give me a dozen custard tarts please......
author: Mark W.

description: Best egg custard tart i've ever had in the states! And i grew up on these babies, so I know a good dan ta when i eat it.
author: Heidi J.

description: Expect long lines but delicious "dahn tas" (egg tart).  Golden Gate Bakery has some of the best egg tarts I've ever had and they are HUGE.  I can easily split one with a girlfriend and feel satisfied.  However, the glutton in me (I think I was a fat kid once upon a time) always wants to devour more and more.  Do yourself a favor and buy a box full but split it with friends...ok, maybe hide a few just for those strong cravings but otherwise, it's a wonderful dessert to share.
author: Karen N.

description:
These lines are freakin INSANE!  If you've never been here, you'd think that this was a line for free food.  If you do go here, you gotta watch out for the people who rudely cut you in line and you have to be vocal about it.  These are usually regulars that know some of the ladies that are behind the counter.  

Must haves here:  the egg tarts...even though they're pretty pricy for just egg tarts.  Sometimes, they are a bit on the oily side as well.
The coconut tarts - one word - YUMMY.  There's also another item (a fairly newer item) that they have on top of the glass counter.  I only know what it's called in Cantonese, but it's the circle looking thing that has a flaky pastry top, round sponge cake on the outside with bits of shredded coconut, filled with a creamy custard.  Can't find this at another bakery. 

Minus 2 stars for the insane prices and another for the horrible wait no matter what day or time you go!
author: Selene K.

description:
Food: They ain't lining up for no reason!
Service: Some friendlier than others, but they're not there for chit chat
Price: More than most

Does this place really need anymore reviews? Likely not. But I like to share my loves with everyone else so here it is:

Absolutely the BEST egg tart I've ever tasted in the whole wide world! Fluffy, phyllo dough-ish crust and a DEEP dish of egg custard perfectly baked with melt-in-your-mouth goodness filling! $1.15 for one but totally worth every pretty little dollar and 15 cents. Almost always warm straight out of the oven.

Never tried anything else but nothing else really looks interesting.

Get there early on the weekends - we arrived around 10:30AM on a Sunday morning and still waited roughly 30 minutes.

Deduct one star only because for a bakery, it really lacks selection. I went here for the egg tarts and Napolean Bakery on Stockton for everything else.
author: Pachi C.

description:
Yupp, this place serves some fierce egg tarts! I mean if 600 other reviewers follow this bakery like a cult it probably signifies something ;) Their other branch is in Toronto (Canada) chinatown where i grew up and it's absolutely delicious too! Can you imagine how happy i was when i realized there was a Golden Gate in SF??? So i usually get A LOT of baked goods when i make a trip up:

Egg Tarts (it's got the right jiggy to it, the filling's not too heavy unlike some other egg tarts, so you can eat them one after another without feeling sick :)
BBQ Pork and Curry Puff Pastries
Sponge cakes (zhi bei)
BBQ Pork buns 
Coconut buns (with creamy custard filling)
Sachima (for the parents, too fried for me)
Sadly there are some buns i just dont even know the names of, i just point and say please. Then there are others I dont know how to translate "/

ps. don't expect great service, it's an asian bakery manned by asian ladies. Enough said.
author: Jenn L.

description:
The egg tarts are really the best here.  Hands down.  They are expensive, but I rather eat one of these warm than 5 of any other.  Most of the other stuff is also very tasty, however most of it is more expensive than other bakeries.

Speaking at least a little chinese would be a plus!

Some of the other good stuff: macaroons, sponge cake, wife cookies :) Enjoy!
author: Richard H.

description: Yes, this is absolutely THE BEST dan ta you will have in your life.  But why only 3 stars?  Because the first time I came here, I had a dan ta and I fell hopelessly in love with this ridiculously incredible piece of confection.  The next four years I've visited San Francisco, all at different times throughout the year I've gotten nothing from Golden Gate Bakery other than a raggity old sign taped on the glass door letting me know that the store is 'closed for vacation'.  Sometimes I see workers in the back, even while the store is 'closed for vacation'.  I sincerely question 'closed for vacation'.  That sign is older than dirt and I know you've been using that same temporary, hand-written sign on and off for quite some time.  I need my fix, but I can't get any.  It's been four years since I've tasted my coveted dan ta.  I've forgotten how it tastes.  I'm depressed and defeated and I'm lashing out by granting only 3 stars to Golden Gate bakery.  Minus 2 for keeping me from my coveted precious dan ta.  I lovehate you Golden Gate bakery.
author: Ken H.

description:
Yes, the egg tarts are amazing -in fact, these are the only egg tarts I will eat and of course I order plenty of them when I'm there but they are not my primary reason for enduring that long line of agressive Chinese women who don't get the concept of lines.   Unlike everyone I go to GGB for the CURRY PIES.  I can't even describe how yummy they are.  It's pure savory goodness stuffed in a flaky pastry.  Try one - you'll see what I mean.  The chicken and beef pies are my favorites.  The pork pies share the stuffing with the bbq pork buns and I find it a little too sweet for my taste.  I have not ventured beyond this point except for the bbq pork buns which everyone seem to love but again I find too sweet and the sesame balls which are also good.  The curry pies and the egg tarts are the winners in my opinion.  

Tip:  These items are great for entertaining.  Buy a bunch for your next party - it will save you some work and money and impress your guests.
author: mia s.

description:
I took my first trip to Golden Gate Bakery this weekend!  I was in the city on the Mission District and felt like a nice walk.  

Imagine my surprise when I got to the bakery and there was a line only 8 deep or so.  SCORE.  I stood in line for about ten minutes before one of the surly women behind the counter filled my order.  I got a nice little variety pack of 1-yolk moon cake, egg custard tarts, mochi, and these little coconut things I don't know the  name of.  I had the nagging feeling the whole time I was there that I really wished I spoke Chinese! 

So, what I didn't realize about this place because I didn't read the fine print on Yelp is that it is CASH ONLY.  I should have guessed and I had the suspicion when I saw everyone around me using cash.  Owing to the fact that I almost exclusively use my debit card, I passed it over the counter to the woman, who promptly yelled "CASH ONLY!"

So, I told her to hold that box and I ran directly across the street to Chase (phew) and got some cash.  I returned and took my pastries, the woman was a bit grumpy about it, but in the end, she got her money, so, who cares? 

  13.60 for all of this stuff...yes, it's pricey, but hey, every one has to make money.  And not many people can make egg tarts that are so balances...flaky pastry, sweet custard....mmmm.  

Check it out!  And remember...it's CASH ONLY!!!
author: Catrina N.

description:
Asians hate standing in line for anything.  Just ask anyone who has to deal w/ those old Chinese ladies at the Muni stations.  But this place commands my people's respect.  Not only do they stand in line, but they stand there for a long time...quietly...patiently...with one single focus... THE EGG CUSTARD TARTS.  

Unlike other Chinatown pretenders, these tarts have a light flaky crust, are larger, and not overly sweet.  If you are brave enough, you can ask them to give you the ones which are fresh from the oven. (Say it in Chinese and you get 'bonus' points.)  Whether they will give it to you depends entirely on those ladies' moods behind the counter. Still, no loss if you don't get the piping hot ones.  Trust me, these are the ones you would kill for.
author: Angela K.

description: The best egg tart I ever had. My family loves this place and we hardly buy a couple of them. We would always order by the dozen. That's how much we like them. I remember when I first moved to the bay are my dad would always tell me to go to Chinatown and pick some up before I visited him. He finally realized the bay area is big and I don't live in San Francisco. Also I don't think I would drive there just to buy egg tarts. Parking in Chinatown is just a pain. I would usually either take the bus since I work  in Downtown or have my husband drop me off and he drives around.  I like the egg tarts from Golden Gate because the center is so soft and the shell is so flaky. I always prefer having egg tarts that have a flaky shell rather than the ones with a stiff shell or in foil cups unless they are Portuguese Egg Tarts from Sheng Kee. Yes I agree with some of the yelpers. They are addicting.
author: Annie C.

description:
i guess...
i mean, the egg custard tarts are tasty, but not, i-need-to-travel-far-wait-in-a-long-line-tasty!
also, the service isnt that great and im pretty sure you can get other egg tarts somewhere else!
author: The Fuzzies S.

description:
Lines? What lines?...Kenny was smoking that magic weed again when he said I'm going to hit the chinatown wait-out when I got to this bakery. First off, never question the chick from SF Chinatown hood...I know my peeps and how they flow. Sundays are always slow and only the truly brave wants to come out and buy baked goods at 8 in the morning.

It's kind of cool to see the huge amounts of moon cakes along the window counter...I don't usually see that many unless it's moon cake festival. But the major attraction here isn't the moon cakes...no my friend, it's the egg tarts...and at $1.15 a piece...kinda pricey.

Mine came straight out of the oven...and noticed that the egg coloring is less yellow than I'm used to. But the hot creamy texture coupled with the extra flaky crust after the first bite made me a believer (does this mean I'm now a tart-ho?)...my tears are a flowing cause now I see the light (cue choir music)...all these years of scarfing down what I thought were good egg tarts...shame on me....

Make sure to get in line (when there's line) and make your order to the ladies of the counter who love their chicana music (yes the chinese lady can sing spanish songs!).
author: Pauline L.

description: yummy egg custard tart: best eaten when warm and fresh out of the stove. No lines when I went (mid-afternoon Saturday). Didn't try the other pastries, but will next time!
author: S S.

description:
I've really yet to go to a place in the city that's actually lived up to its yelp hype.

The egg tarts here live up to that hype.  Normally I respect that other people have opinions, but if you claim to like egg tarts and don't like the ones here, then you just have no fucking clue.  

I sound exactly like the kind of snobby elitist that I hate when I say this, but I've not had an egg tart this good outside of China.  You won't find better in the city.  And if you do, holler at me...so that after I try it, I can call you a moron.
author: Per C.

description:
This is the best bakery on the planet!
Pork Buns! YUM!
Meat Pies! YUM
Cakes, pastries and cookies! YUM!

There is always a long line out the door.  The place should be much bigger.  Great Bakery.
author: Allison C.

description: "Dan Tat" aka egg custard. If you come here, be prepared to wait. YES, its THAT good!! The crust is toasted to the perfect amount of crunchiness, and center egg custard filled with a slight vanilla taste just melts in your mouth. I bet you will eat more than just one... I always do!!!
author: Linda P.

description:
There's not much to say, their egg custard is the best.

It sucks when I make the trip across the city and they are closed for vacation.

The line can get crazy long but moves fairly quickly.

Double check your bag before you leave as the lady who rings you up is not the same lady that bags it for you. I had to go back several times to get what I wanted to buy in the first place.
author: Evan W.

description:
YUM! I had heard about this place countless times and saw the reviews so I just had to try it out. I went on a Sunday evening so it wasn't as busy, but everything was still as fresh as ever! We bought some of the famous egg tarts, almond cookies, mochi and cake rolls. After paying and walking out, we couldn't resist the temptation and sampled the egg tarts right there on the street (we saw at least 3 other people do the same ahaha). After a couple of bites, we headed straight back to the bakery...why you ask? To get ANOTHER DOZEN. No we are not crazy, we just appreciate a good egg tart! It had just come right out of the oven too, so it was just simply HEAVEN. The custard was not too sweet and was of the right consistency, and the pastry part was flaky and delicious. *DROOL*.

The almond cookies were good too, and the mochi *MORE DROOL*. It's perfect and soft, and the inside is a mixture of coconut(?) and peanuts....I think they actually used walnuts which I have never seen before in Chinese mochi...it was GOOD =P. The people at the counter were pretty friendly too. I'm definitely going again....and you should too!
author: Chrys U.

description:
When I lived in SF, I use to walk to Golden Gate Bakery from the Lower Haight in order to burn off all the calories I was about to consume here!

Chinese bakeries, like restaurants, are a dime a dozen, mostly serving 'okay' quality food.  That's why when you come accross someplace good, there will inevitably, be a line.  It's sort of a non issue, here. The wait is never more than 5-10 minutes (asian ladies are fast!) and the treats are worth it.

My favorites are the meat filled pastry and of course, the egg tart. Everything that I have gotten here has always been fresh out of the oven. Flaky, piping hot, and gone within 10 minutes!
author: Angela C.

description: Hands down the best egg tarts ever!!! No one in the northwest can topped this. Tried them all, but this bakery never fails me. Been growing up eating at this bakery when they used to be cheap but now they're a bit pricey. Made sense since they're known for the best in town. Definitely a must go to place when you're ever in Chinatown.
author: Annie C.

description:
I seriously will walk from Market & 3rd to Grant and all the way up to this bakery. Actually I've done that quite a few times.

I love the delicious egg custards and the chicken pastry the best! They're extremely affordable too. $1-2 for most yummy items.
author: Andy B.

description: Went there on a saturday on fleet week..IT WAS PACKED!! line was at least 20 people plus...good thing we came before the crowd. Delicious egg tarts from what i remember...Now i cant eat them so i ate a pineapple bun instead...it was so light, warm and tasty.
author: Brendan L.

description:
Weekends Only:  French BUNs (Hella good~  My mouth is drewling just thinking about it,  I can eat four!!!)

Weekdays:  Egg Custard(sold out in minutes)
                      Mexican Buns (modify versions of French Bun...except is 
                      bigger and fuller)

(Avoiding the Wait:)        You may Prepaid, if  you buy a good quality amount of it.  You can just jump ahead of the line and pay and come back an hour to pick it up. (I meant dozen of egg custard or dozen of french buns)
author: evelyn y.

description:
Man this place is on hit! If you don't know then you probably should go.  I'm not gonna repeat what the previous reviewers have already stated but if you love asian baked products like the pineapple bun and egg custard bun..you should call up your homies and roll up to this spot and have them fill up those pink boxes with your fave buns so you have plenty on hand to eat.  You can't eat just one and Chinatown is far away to drive if you don't live close by.  So stock up.

So,during the month of August the place might be closed but really they are on vacation.  The sign will say closed without an announcement but that means they probably chillin in China on vacation.  They don't give you a date but it's all good thats what our peeps do, no need to announce when we come back from vacation from the motherland.... anywho peep this place out when they are open and load up on the baked asian goodies.
author: marcus o.

description: Hands down the best egg tarts there is!  Worth the wait and you should definitely get more than one!  They are warm and fresh outta the oven when you eat them,  absolutely delectable.
author: Linh C.

description:
You can't just order one dan tat here. That's just absurd!! (And yes, I actually saw someone do that. Sigh, noob.) You want the pink box...the big one...filled with dan tat. The more, the merrier.

The line is always super long, but well worth the wait. I always try to see if they pull out a fresh batch as I approach the front of the line. Been successful once and holy moly, it was the best egg custard tart I've ever tasted. Everything about it is perfect - the buttery flaky crust, the warm succulent custard that just slides down your throat. Just the scent of it's sensational aroma is orgasmic.

Crap, I might just have to go there tomorrow and bring home a box.
author: Michelle W.

description: I bought a slice of chocolate cream cake. It tasted day old, DRY.  Not going back again.
author: Pat W.

description: I concur, those egg custards are GOOOOOD! I'll be back.
author: Jen K.

description:
Hot Damn! 

These are the best egg custard tarts I've had in my life. It's no wonder there is a continuous line two buildings down all day, every day. 

And the best part: because they sell so many, yours will be guaranteed fresh and piping hot from the oven every time.
author: Deanna T.

description: BEST EGG TARTS EVER!! I've tried many many egg tarts. I've never been a huge fan of them, maybe because all other ones are just subpar to the ones I had here. I used to be ok with eating the inner part of the egg tart, and then dislike the outer part, but the egg tarts here are soooo good! it's cheap and the eggy part is perfect. not too eggy, not to sweet, tastes absolutely delicious. I never knew there could be such a huge difference in flavors between the average egg tart and the great ones. The outer crust part is also really good. i used to think egg tarts were simple, but there is a lot of complexity to it that makes it actually great!
author: Liwei Y.

description: I did end up going back... line didn't take so long this time. Ended up picking up another dozen egg custard tarts along with a few moon cakes. Definitely my favorite moon cake and egg custard tart place so far.
author: Steven T.

description:
Like most folks who review this place, I am a fan of their yummy egg tarts.  However, I am not a fan of their rude customer service and crazy long lines.  Seems like the more people are in line, the longer the line gets.  And it's also hit or miss if you want to get something here, since they close their doors for vacation for weeks at a time with no warning.

I'd get their egg tarts if I'm in the area and the line isn't too long.  An hour+ wait just isn't worth it.
author: Sam C.

description:
Ah yes, small, dirty, always packed...F-A-B-U-L-O-U-S!

If you're asian and don't know this place, I would have to ask you...WHY!?  This is the ONLY bakery I know in all of the bay area that can have a one month vacation at anytime they want and then reopen with a long ass line of old chinese ladies, tourists, and young people alike fighting to get one of their delicious egg custards (normal or portuguese style) only to stuff it down their throat and return for more.  What is the world coming to!? 

I LOVE this place and have been coming here for years, every chance I get, to have some yummy egg custards.  I don't even eat egg custards at any other place anymore.  TOO GOOD.
author: Linda C.

description: I don't know about their other pastries, but their egg tarts are A-MAZING! When my bf first told me about it, I was skeptical because really.. how great can an egg tart really be. An egg tart is an egg tart! They're always good. But no. This place knows how to make the crust extra flaky. The custard center isn't too sweet or gelatinous. It's a very nice texture with a subtly sweet taste. I love it! No wonder their lines are always ridiculously long.
author: Thy L.

description:
Having not consumed my first egg tart until a year ago, I'm still acquiring a taste for them.  I find them enjoyable, yet when the taste of sweetened scrambled eggs kicks in, I'm torn on how to feel.

F.L. and I dropped by Golden Gate Bakery just before 2:00pm on a Friday.  My friend had suggested it when I told him we would be going to Chinatown, and since F.L. had a craving, we stopped by...for an hour.  The line was already out the door, and we parked ourselves at the end of it.  During our 60 minute wait, countless people walked by asking what the line was for and assumed that a line so long must be for something incredibly awesome.

I only tried the egg tarts; I had one freshly baked, as a reward for waiting in line, and the egg custard was warm and pleasantly sweet.  The sweetness and moistness of the custard balanced well with the light, flaky pastry.

I had another egg tart the next day and since the custard had cooled and firmed, it was easier to eat, but just as good.  It still tasted fresh, despite lacking that fresh-baked warmth.

Other notes:
-You're better off walking, since the street is small and crowded.  (What do you expect?  It's Chinatown!)
-Of the two women working the cashier and fulfilling orders, there was an older, friendlier woman who spoke pretty good English, and a younger, hastier woman whose English was a bit difficult to understand.  The non-Chinese speaking customers before me had a miscommunication in the price, and there was a good 20 seconds of verbal exchange between them before the older woman cleared things up.  (Having a Chinese-speaking companion is highly convenient although not absolutely necessary.)
-I felt the egg tarts were bigger than typical dim sum size, but they are also more expensive at $1.15 apiece.
author: Keiko N.

description:
Bestest Dann Tatts!  (Egg custards for you non-Cantonese)

They are the flakiest and butter-packed goodness!

For my health, I'll just eat one.  Thank you.

How you know they're good.  Well, try visiting that place and see when they actually don't have a line outside.  like... never?  (okok, maybe 9am in the morning.)
author: Gigi T.

description:
Although the egg tarts are a little pricier than others, they are worth the wait. This is the only place I had these were te crust is perfectly crust, flakey and tender while the filling is warm and not too sweet! Yummerz!

There is often a wait here outside the very cramped quarters. They do have a velvet rope outside to guide the waiters and keep them off the sidewalk where people are passing! Fun and very asian!
author: John W.

description:
I was dragged here by my co-workers because they claimed that the egg-tart was the bestests .. sss...sss ... in town.

Hands down, this shit is good!  but there is always a long line but moves pretty quickly.
author: Sam K.

description:
Holy Eggy Tarty Goodness, Batman!!

Do not, ever under any circumstances, no matter who you're with, or where you're coming from, or where you're going, ever, Pass on the opportunity to grace this little spot when you're in the neighborhood. The fresh, flaky, steaming hot, fresh-from-the-oven egg tarts are worth the half-hour wait in-line by the sidewalk. Bring friends; the tarts taste better when enjoyed with company, the wait more bearable.
author: Shobi L.

description: The egg tarts are on the 100 things to eat before you die list from 7X7. So I had to give it a try. When we got them, they were warm and just baked. Unfortunately I had to wait until that night to eat it. I must say, they were good, but not must-eat good. The sweet smell reminds me of beard papa's cream puffs. The texture is a little wet--maybe due to condensation while it was cooling down. I would get them again if I happened to be there, but probably won't make a trip to Chinatown just for that.
author: Candice B.

description: SO and I bought 2 boxes of custard egg tarts and other treats the nice hard-workin' folks here suggested to bring down with us to LA for family and only 1 made it back. Nuff said.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
It's like you died and went to 'danh taht' heaven.  I'm talking bout the egg tarts, yo!

Bobby said it best when he sang "too hot to handle, too cold to hold". hot out of the iron oven, they come out flaky like a croissant, the custard is so fresh, it hasn't even set and they are icey smooth the whole way through.

They got the recipe on lock.  And everyone knows if because of the 40 times I've been here, there's always a line! 

I hate to keep using the soup-nazi analogy, but better know what you want, because if you don't the people behind get in a fuss.  Today, this old lady tried to creep up on me!  It was like I had on a Chinese old lady backpack, she was so close.  Good grief.  

But once I bit into the buttery vanilla flan, all was forgotten....
author: Isaac L.

description:
Derek says:  Must have in San Francisco Chinatown.  Could be considered the best chinese bakery in the city.  Ive been to this place all my life, i even remember when my parents took me here after pre-school to eat and drink vitasoy.  The portions are small, they are a bit pricey, and there is a long line.  BUT it is all worth it when you order the egg tarts.  Simply the best.

Janice's view:  I think the egg tarts are way too sweet and oily.  Personally I like egg tarts with the pie crust not the filo type kind. Their mooncakes are good though, but i wouldn't wait in line for their stuff unless i have to buy something for other people.  but 4 stars bc i would love to picture derek there drinking vitasoy after preschool. hehe
author: Janice's A.

description:
Three words:
Egg Custard Tarts. Those = Heaven on Earth!
Toasted flaky, crispy edges with warm, jiggly egg custard center that melts in your mouth. Mmmmmmm -ust try!!!! Your life won't be complete until you try one of these.
Don't be intimated by the long line. People who don't know about this place are missing out. But once you see a long line of Chinese people--even if you don't know what they're waiting for--you know it must be good.
Be aware of the random vacations that the storeowners will take though, because they don't give warnings before shutting down the store for a few months in random times of the year!!
But this is definitely a de-lish place!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Elaina T.

description: I absolutely love their egg tarts.  I''ve tried so many egg tarts before and this place is the best, hands down! It's so light, super flaky on the outside, steaming hot on the inside.  It is that good!!! If you are ever in Chinatown, you have to come here and try their egg tarts.  Sometimes you will have to wait in line for their egg tarts, but it is so worth it.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Worth the trip, we came all the way from so cal to try the custard. I ate it right away when it's still warm but I think it taste better when it is out from the fridge.
author: Kay H.

description:
If you're from Taiwan, don't go here. KFC makes the best dan-ta and this place cannot complete. 
If you're not from Asia/Taiwan, this might be new to you, but KFC is infinitely better there for some reason. 

I was craving for dan-ta one day and we just so happened to be running around China Town looking for airsoft guns for my boyfriend's inner child. While he was engaged in debating which ones to get, I swung by the Golden Gate Bakery. 

There was already a line and they said the next available batch will come out in 15 minutes. Most of the people were waiting to buy a dozen or more, I only wanted 3, so the lady boosted me up in line and had me waiting across from the cashier. 
After waiting for 15 minutes, I got my 3 scalding hot dan-ta's. I was SO EXCITED I cannot describe to you how amazing I thought these hot babies would be. 

I was extremely disappointed. It was greasy beyond belief. The bag holding the dan-ta was drenched in grease, so were my hands. I had to put the greasy dan-ta in a plastic bag so they don't grease-stain anything else. The dan-ta was okay, It was liquidy and not enough eggs. It's got a eggy flavor but it tasted like it was water-downed. The color wasn't very pretty, it was yellow on the white side, not a solid nice yellow you get when you know they use enough eggs. The crust was not up to my expectations either, it was crumby and made the whole thing bland. 
My boyfriend had half of one because he was starving, but refused to take another bite afterwards. If a starving person's not eating it, you know there's something wrong with these dan-ta. 
Some people say cold dan-ta is the best, I tried that, I saved it for later, and when I picked it up to try it again, I knew it was a mistake. Let's just say it wasn't good. 

Save your tummy space for something better! This place is not worth it!
author: Erica L.

description:
This bakery = a store front, a glass shelf, and a public sidewalk for people to line up to buy their egg tarts.  (If you're a tourist, this isn't a place to rest your stems or people watch.)  

The reason everyone loves GG's egg tart is because GG figured out how to make a flaky crust that everyone loves.  

So here are 2 tips: (1) the egg tarts aren't that great if they aren't hot so wait longer for the fresh ones and eat soon, and (2) if you want to try anything else, stick with pastries that are flaky crust dependent, which is why people recommend the bar-b-que pork flaky roll, chicken pie, and beef pie.  TTFN
author: Caitlyn K.

description: Waiting in a line that went out the door was no biggie... The egg tarts were amazing, definitely worth the reasonable wait time. They had about 3-4 ladies helping behind the counter. One of them was not-so-nice when we visited on a Sunday afternoon... I dont know, maybe she was over-worked. It was extrememely busy here, and for GOOD reason! Didn't really matter, I'll be back. :)
author: Christine A.

description:
i LOVE this place.  It's my go-to for egg custard tarts.  They are usually piping hot when I get them.  Super flakey crust with a sweet enough but not overly sweet custard filling.  I think it's kinda cute that lil old ladies bring them up from the basement.  I also really love how they put the goodies into lil pink boxes, which would have been ordinary, except these ladies tie those cheapy strings around the boxes...they got that down! They also have really yummy coconut macaroons.  I usually buy them by the dozens so that I'll  enough to munch on at the moment and some to bring back home. 

Overall, very delicious, but not as cheap as the other stores in Chinatown, but very much worth it.
author: Linda Y.

description: WTF hold a normal schedule or notify people in advance if your going to be closed!!! some of us do travel to visit you, but NO!!! you have to be on vacation!!! geez some of us crave your dantats!!!
author: John F.

description:
There is alwaysss always always a long ass line here~
I only come here when i accidentally stop by chinatown to see some puppies at the pet store and..........eat egg tarts!

Must GETS:  

EGG TARTS duh.  THEY ARE THE BEST I HAVE EVER HAD, besides when i was in macau, those are they best of the best. 

and the coconut cookies? i forget what theyre called..like they look like bells sorta..youll find them.  Theyre chewy.

Pretty pricey for some egg tarts, $1.10 for one if i remember correctly, but its well worth it and a San Francisco MUST TRY.

The ladies are kinda mean here because they can be, they dont really need your business when so many others are lining up outside.

DO NOT ever ask them if they sell Portugese Egg Tarts, they get offended for some reason..
:P
author: kim w.

description:
I was never a fan of egg custard tarts till I tried one from here.  The crust is AMAZING.  It is the perfect level of flakiness.  The custard is smooth and creamy and just the perfect amount of egginess.  it is the perfect combination.

The other bake goods are also very delicious.  We especially love the gui-ma bas.  Your ride should plan to circle the block a good 10 times going 2 mph before you make it out of the store with your bake goods.  The place is always packed!
author: Alex H.

description:
Food/Quality:
This bakery is great and located in Chinatown. Get the egg custard tarts, but don't be afraid to try other items because they can be just as good especially if you can get them fresh.

Atmosphere:
There is usually a line outside the door, but it seems to move pretty fast. 

Service:
There isn't too much to comment on about service. Just point at what you want and enjoy!

Value:
They do seem expensive, but I wouldn't go very often anyway to avoid the calorie overload!
author: Cynthia D.

description:
BEST egg tarts in SF, hands down.  The fresh tarts are snatched up hot out of the oven and people will wait in line (which always goes out the door) for the next batch to come out.

The other baked goods are so-so, but GO FOR THE TARTS!
author: Christina J.

description:
Dear,
I have talked to them on phone, and they told me that they would open again on Aug 30, so will they open on Aug 11 or 30?
author: BB A.

description: Even though you might be the best at making your egg tarts, it doesn't excuse the fact you close down your store whenever you like. Not even having a notice of return written on the door, I could live without your egg tarts.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Every single time we come here, the wait is forever, but its worth it since we spend over $40 anyways. You can really taste the freshness of ever single items since they bake them hourly. 

They have the best coconut macaroon  ever! The egg tart are also very fresh. 

If you wait in that line, better order a lot!  =)
author: Emma L.

description: One dozen Egg Tart (Dan Tat). Walk out. Feast.
author: Will T.

description: EGG TARTS! Everytime I visit the city, I make my host take me to this bakery. These babies come to you warm with a silky smooth center. I eat them right outside the door (cuz I can't wait any longer) and contribute to the congestion on the sidewalk. All the distraction and noise of Chinatown just blur and disappear as my egg tart and I share a special moment. Oh yea, their beef curry puffs come to you warm and it's heaven in your mouth as well.
author: Char L.

description: Review only for egg tarts -- they are a MUST try. Eat it warm, when you first get it... the egg custard part is amazing. I'm not even a fan of egg tarts. BUT this is an exception.
author: Vera W.

description: These egg tarts are so good, the first bite takes you into a dreamy egg tart heaven where your taste buds prance around in a cloud of egg tart joy. You flail your arms like Steven Seagal running because your mind has just been blown. There are no rules here in egg tart heaven, just a place with unadulterated flavor. Clothing optional. Best egg tarts in town. Try some. I dare you.
author: Tri N.

description:
No line at 11am on a weekday! I grabbed a dozen for a company potluck and they were a hit. The egg custards are nice where the egg isn't too rich and the custard is kinda fluffy.

I also got a red-bean filled sesame ball for my walk back to the office that was delish.
author: Kat H.

description:
This is in Chinatown, not Nob Hill.
