The egg custard was way too eggy; tasted like slightly sweetened eggs. Maybe next time I go here I'll give it a chance to congeal; although it seems like they cater to tourists by wanting to serve everything "hot out of the oven" even if it might be served better a little cooled.

Other stuff looked good, thought
author: Mark A.

description: Just had to wait in this huuuuge line, not for the egg tarts but for their BBQ pork buns. If I can wait in a 30 min line for a sale at a store, then this is nothing! I initially ordered 4 buns, but after thinking about it some more I had to get more and boy am I glad I did! I also tried those coconut macaroon things and wish I had some BEFORE I ordered and paid for the buns. Those things are really good! It tastes waaay better than it looks. I will definitely go back.. again and again.
author: Sandra T.

description:
This place is crazy - I stopped by just to try out the egg custard tarts (dan tat) that everyone raves about. It's just egg tarts; what's so special???  When I got there, I knew it was going to be good since so many people were waiting in line.

Pros
- Tasty hot egg custard tarts - hot right out of the oven. They have such great turnover! I asked my wife how many we should get & she said no more than 6. Good thing I read the reviews & ordered a dozen - I had 4 in the car & 2 when I got home (oh my stomach).

Cons
- Street parking - right in downtown Chinatown
- Long lines - don't people work?
- EXPENSIVE egg tarts - $1.15 each!!!!!
- ordered some other items & they were not so tasty (fresh).

Return Visit
- unfortunately yes.
author: X L.

description: Best egg tarts that I have ever had! its super fresh! yummy! all the good stuff! mmmmmm....... mmmmm... good!
author: Andrew F.

description:
A friend of mine brought me to this place when I visited from Seattle.  When I lived here a couple of years ago, I used to make my own treks to Golden Gate Bakery to pick up their awesome egg tarts.  They have the best egg tarts I've ever tasted.  It's really nice if you can get them fresh out of the oven.  The custard is warm and the crust is so flaky.  I don't think I've ever had had an egg tart with a flaky crust anywhere else.

The lines are always long here but the service is pretty prompt.
author: Rowena D.

description:
This place use to be it in the 90s. Now it's just overpriced and overrated. You can find egg tarts for alot cheaper elsewhere. I ain't lining up or looking for parking out there for chinese pastries.

This place use to be well known for their mooncakes. Their mooncakes have gone down in quality considerably. Doesn't stop them from charging ridiculous prices though. I remember when their freshly made mooncakes were the brand to buy and gift to other chinese people. Other chinese people would be like oh damn 'gum moon yut beng' thank you! The last time I had a mooncake from here, I was shocked to find a chicken egg in the center. It's suppose to be a duck egg. fail. Now whenever mooncake season comes along, most will just choose from a wide assortment of mooncakes imported from hongkong.
author: Wes C.

description: I heard so much about this place, especially their egg tarts. I took one bite, and it was delicious. This was the first egg tart that I can actually taste the egg. Luckily, we didn't encounter a queue (the next morning there was a line around the block).
author: Tif L.

description:
Best Asian bakery in San Francisco. Longest lines for baked goods you have possibly ever seen. A multi-ethnic customer base. 

Get the egg tarts or the pineapple cakes!
author: Michelle G.

description:
Tips on looking for Golden Gate Bakery 
- it's on Grant Ave
- it has a long line outside
- the stuff are more expensive than any other Chinese bakeries
- the staff are mean
the above are told by me from a friend's relative who works at golden gate. 
That being said, the egg custards here are good, but they have the flaky, puff pastry crust, which is not really my favorite. I prefer the type with the "pie crust" more. But I am addicted to the coconut tart here, the dense coconut contrast well with the flaky base, eaten when fresh, it's heaven on a tart (just don't think about the weight gain until after!)
One note: all their sponge cake items have orange flavor in it, I love sponge cake but i hate orange flavor, so everytime i get the sponge cake here I get disappointed. So if you have similar taste as me, do not get the sponge cake!
author: Mika J.

description: This is a little hole-in-the-wall Chinese bakery in SF Chinatown. They make the best dan tat (egg custard tarts) I have ever had, even compared to places in Hong Kong! The pastry shell is buttery and flaky while the custard is creamy perfection. There is typically a long line, but it moves quickly. The demand is so high for these tasty treats that they are often sold to you still warm, straight out of the oven.
author: August C.

description: I'm a big fan of this little bakery place!! There are so many bakeries in the Chinatown area and I've tried most of them.  This is definitely one of the best ones!!
author: Karen Z.

description:
The best bakery in Chinatown Period!  I've been coming here for over 30 years.  I don't know how they keep the quality so high after so many years.  The best egg custard tart in the U.S..  I've been to NY, Chicago, L.A...no one comes close.  They also have the best cake rolls, banana rolls, coconut buns, and baked pork buns...yum!
Also, get use to the lines especially on weekends and holidays but it's worth the wait!
author: g s.

description:
Originally five stars because they are one of the best Chinese bakery around.

-1 star for the price of the dan tats - egg tarts.  95 cents for ONE.  I remember when it was a quarter for one of those yummy egg tarts.  I use to able to get 8 of those oh so good silky egg custards tarts that melts in my mouth.....now I can only get measly two.  Not enough to satisfy my cravings. Can you sense my bitterness here?

-1 star for always closing 1.5 - 2 months of the year.   That means I don't get to satisfy my craving for the egg tarts while they take their expensive vacation to god know where relaxing in the sun with all the profits they make off their 95 cents egg tarts.   Yes sense my bitterness again.  Because guess what?  THEY ARE ON VACATION RIGHT NOW!!! ARRGGGGGH!!!!
author: Chris C.

description:
Why do they call them custard tarts and not egg tarts? Anyways, each custard tart is $1.10 or you can get a dozen for $12.20. 

And they still taste great the next day! You can even heat them up in the mircowave so they seem fresh. hehe.
author: Jenn S.

description: I like the egg tarts, but the one hour wait is definitely not worth it. I'll only come back if there isn't a wait.
author: Trang B.

description:
Since my last visit, I've been horribly disappointed in the apparent decline in the quality of the signature egg tarts. No longer is there a nice golden hue to the custard; it was a pale white-ish color, and lacked in flavor. They've apparently skimped on the eggs and cream, yet still price hiked.

I've always told friends that Golden Gate Bakery had the best egg tarts followed by Ruby King in the Bay Area, but I may need to rethink that now.

The service is a bit curt, but I suppose it's just a cultural thing.
author: Janice L.

description: I was astonished that the line was a block long.  Finally I got there to buy an egg custard.  It costs $1.15 for one which is damn expensive.  It used to cost 35 cents back in the day from what my  cousin told me.  The egg custard tasted flakey, warm, and deliciously sweet but not tooo sweet.  I do not remember having a great egg custard in NYC chinatown.  This tops it.  I must do my egg custard research in NYC when I return.
author: Steve W.

description:
The egg tarts here are to die for. I know people have complained about the high prices including myself, but they're good at what they do and it's all business! However, I do noticed the slight adjustments of their recipe, they are a bit lighter nowadays. I'm assuming a little less egg yolk and a little more of the other ingredients.

Regardless, Golden Gate Bakery is one of the best Chinese bakery out there. They're good for what they do and it's as good as it can get in Chinatown; I give them 5 stars.
author: Ray W.

description:
I really like this place because their buns, and tarts are amazingly good, but PRETTY EXPENSIVE! But you get what you pay for i guess. The only thing that makes this place not get 5 stars is how many vacations they take in a year! They seem to be open every other month because of the amount of vacation these people take! 
I know they make a shit load of money selling 1 dollar egg tarts, but is it necessary to take 1 month vacations at a time 4 times a year?
author: Q W.

description: This place is always on vacation. I often ask myself where they went and when they will be back so I can get my egg tarts since they never state a duration of time on their "vacation" sign. *sigh*
author: Tina C.

description:
I am one of those strange creatures who dislikes chocolate in my baked goods and also don't like cakes that are incredibly rich.  So when it came time to buy a wedding cake I turned to these guys.  Chinese cakes tend to be light, not-too-sweet, and layered with fresh fruit and whipped cream.  The cake was delivered without a hitch, tasted great, and was waaaayyyy cheaper than wedding cakes made by western bakeries.  They have a picture book with some of the cakes that they've made and admittedly, most are on the hideous side - they conform to the overly-ornate style of cake often seen at Chinese weddings.  To avoid this, I ordered the cake with plain icing then had my florist decorate it with fresh flowers.  

Aside from the cakes, if  you want a good Chinese bakery with a large selection, this place is great.  Moon cakes, egg tarts, sesame balls, cookies, etc can all be found here.
author: Kaman C.

description: There's a long line, but they are efficient.  Egg tarts here are very good, as is the cream puff pastry, the white-sugar jelly, and the little coconut-flaked mounds.
author: Niniane W.

description: Oh yea baby!  20 minute wait for the delicious little egg custards and it was worth every minute of it!  Honestly, being a tourist in the city, if you see a line in front of a food establishment, you know it's good and every time I've driven by GGB, there's a line.  Get some!
author: Dave L.

description: Simply the best in Bay area!!! Their Egg Tarts are to die for...HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Mabel Y.

description:
All I ever here is "you HAVE to go Golden Gate Bakery for the egg tarts they are the best I have EVER had!!!!!"

After doing the Climb Califnornia event at the Bank of America Building and lunch we headed here to finially try these tarts that my co-workers seems to rave about.

okay so these are good but I would not say they are the best and would not go out of my way to come here.  There is always a line but good thing they really keep this line moving which is a plus in my book. I hate waiting in lines. 

I have not had anything else so I may have found something else that I would adore but not really my thing.

if you love egg tarts you have to give it a try since everyone love these it seems. My only recommendation is eat them when they are fresh and hot.
author: Robert S.

description: I've lived in SF all my life, but I don't remember if I've ever had the egg tarts before, but I figured since I was in Chinatown I might as well go see what all the hype is about. I went at about 3pm on a weekday so there was no line =) this really has to be the best egg tart I've ever had, the egg was sooo soft, I normally don't like the pastry part of the egg tart but I actually like it here.  If I lived closer to Chinatown I'd definitely get it more often, but since I don't and I don't know when's the next time I'll actually be in Chinatown, we will meet again someday, delicious egg tarts....
author: Stephanie T.

description: They were closed today with a sign that says "vacation". They got an extra star (two) because of all the other yummy reviews. No message of closing on their website or phone number.  Wasn't surprised.  This is the second time I came here and they weren't open.  And I don't exactly live in the area at 540 miles away.  I'll give them another shot next time but three strikes you're out.
author: Darius L.

description:
Worth the wait;  worth the extra cost... 
Airy and delicious. From the East coast to the West, from North America to Asia = definitely one of the best in the West. 
1) fragrant coconut tarts = deadly. 
2) boh loh bao = buns with a crispy sweet topping = how can bread melt in your mouth? 
3) Loe poh bang = "Wife biscuits" = loose, flaky, with a nice filling, not too sweet. 
4) Egg custard tarts = the criterion which all rave about and others are judged against.

*The women who work there: New York chutzpah in San Francisco from Cantonese ladies.
author: T P.

description:
BEST EGG CUSTARD TARTS EVER. At least in California haha :) Soooo good for only $1.13 each! Yum...everytime I get them they are still warm from the oven. Mmmmm

Moon cakes are pretty good too...haven't tried anything else.
author: Lauretta L.

description: This is a must-go-to place whenever I'm anywhere near Chinatown. The long line for their egg tarts is well worth the wait. They are best when eaten warm... which means devouring one right after you come out of the store.
author: Eva T.

description: I come here whenever I am in Chinatown to pickup several dozen for my grand/children/grand.  They love this place.  -1 star for Long lines in a very crowded sidewalk.
author: Lai L.

description:
I bought 5 egg custard tarts and 5 pork buns for $9.50. Their pork buns aren't as big as some of the bakeries in Chinatown but they're still pretty good. While some of the bigger buns are sometimes a bit dry, these are moist on the inside and out.

Just remember: dan-tat.
author: Amy D.

description:
Their egg tarts are sooooo tasty!! smooth and pipping hot... Earlier last week, I decided to also try the other items at their bakery... their "wife" cake was really good.. definitely would try that again.. also the banana roll (not sure if that's what they call it... but itz crepe-like) was very refreshing, not too sweet and I love the soft chewy texture... 

This bakery is usually closed for a long period of time at certain times of the year... think around the New Year when they visit their families in HK.. also.. the lines are usually long during the weekends.. so be patient.. coz the wait is soo worth it!
author: Kym L.

description:
Dahn Tats.....Little cups of Heaven... MmMmMMmMmm....
It's best eaten fresh when the crust is still flaky & the custard is still jiggly and steaming....

I totally agree with Michelle W's review.....all worth it, all worth it... : )

Wait...they have other stuff here other than the egg custards!??! 
(j/k! The other stuff is good too!)
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Egg Custard Tarts! Egg Custard Tarts!  and more Egg Custard Tarts!  This bakery has been in SF Chinatown for over 35 years.  Business is great, there's always a line out the door - CA$H only.  Best time to stop by is after 10AM.  The egg custards are not available when they open @ 8AM.  

Their egg custard tarts are famous, delicious - and pricey @ $1.10/each.  So you gotta live - get a dozen (they are fine the next day - if you got a toaster oven).  Try it and you'll be hooked.... :)
author: Rich W.

description:
Famous egg custard tarts! This is the place to get it. It's always hot and fresh (since they burn through their batches VERY quickly b/c of the ridiculous long line that is always there whenever they are open). But it'll cost you an arm and an leg!

J/K. But it's like $1.25 a pop (last time I checked). That's ridiculously expensive for an egg custard tart. But it's very good though. Is it worth it? I think it's worth it to try it and worth it to eat it once in a while. Other times, just go to another Chinatown bakery to get your egg custard tarts.

Get a dozen (or half-dozen) and it does make a nice snack-gift. But you better give that gift fast, b/c their egg custard tarts are best enjoyed HOT!
author: Sam W.

description:
This is a Chinese bakery on Grant street in the part of Chinatown closest to North Beach. 
Best egg tart in the city. That's why all the people are waiting in line.  They make them fresh so you can always get one hot out of the oven. Don't burn your tongue (easy for me to say).   Get more than one.
The other stuff is good too. Prices are much higher than the other Chinese bakeries in the area, but it's worth it.
author: Meredith G.

description: This is the best place to get egg tarts. If they are fresh out of the oven, it is so worth burning your mouth to have it fresh. Line can pile up at times, but moves pretty quick. And the workers english may be so so, but they can churn out these goodies all wrapped up in a box in no time. Definitely worth the trek into chinatown.
author: Henry T.

description:
I agree with mankind that Golden Gate Bakery's got the best egg custard tarts in town!

Other goodies from this place are pineapple buns (where the frosting stuff remains intact even after you bite into it) and cocktail buns. Yes, the lines are sometimes long but moves fast. It's definitely worth the wait.

I have no idea why Golden Gate is listed under Nob Hill when it's in Chinatown though.

Golden Gate Bakery
author: Tommy T.

description:
Yummmmmmmmmmmmmmmm!! it's the best when it first comes out of the oven.

the best flakey crust ever. the best egg custard ever!!

the only downside: it's a bit pricy for an egg tart. but high demands = $$$

Edit: I retract my note on the price. If you think about it, the only reason why it seems a bit pricy is because all the other egg tarts are cheaper. But if you compare this to desserts like flan or creme brulee-- this is a pretty good deal. So excuse me on that note! Please, by all means, visit this little bakery and see for yourself how yummy this place is! Hope you enjoy all the super flakey custardy goodness!!
author: J T.

description:
Five stars for dan tats alone.

I have never been to this place, but I did get the chance to eat their dan tats this past weekend.  I'm not a huge fan of these, but will pick up a threesome off the cart at dim sum every once in awhile.  Few things have changed my mind in one taste, but these did so very convincingly.

Thank goodness I did not have to find parking, wait in line, or pay the high prices (they're not that bad).  I will in the future though.
author: Curtis C.

description:
So my best friend kept telling me about this bakery so when I finally had a chance to make a trip up north, we decided to go here.  There was a line out there (but in general the bakery is very tiny and can fit maybe 5-6 people in the entire store.

He said to get a dozen of the egg custards.  The great part is they only make so much so that when you order it.. it is freshy OUT OF THE OVEN. We did have to wait a few minutes but it well worth it.  The crust was so flaky and crispy I can just taste the sticks and globs of butter that went into it.

I never had an egg custard like that anywhere.  Normally when you eat dim sum, the egg custard has an ultra egg taste to it..but it didn't.. it had this creamy almost flan like texture but it was just incredible. I'm not a big fan of sweets but it almost gave me the ABTS (Almost Better Than Sex Feeling.) 

I don't give too many places 5 stars..but seriously.. everyone needs to go here before they die and eat an egg custard!

I had some of there other bread but it was just tasty but not excellent like the egg custard.  

Damn just another reason to hit up the bay area more. AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH! =D
author: K D.

description: The queue gets ridiculous sometimes, but their *fresh* moon cakes are awesome, and their egg tarts too! Did I mention it was cheap. Highly recommended.
author: Laurent T.

description: Just another review confirming how wonderful and delicious their egg tart is. It was the absolute best egg tart I have every had. I just wished it wasn't 8 hrs away.
author: Amy S.

description:
Want a taste of heaven but aren't eligible to go yet?

Then try one of GGB's egg tarts!
author: Observe R.

description: After seeing all the positive reviews of this place on yelp, i made sure to put this place high on my list of places to go to on my visit to the bay area.  I was not disappointed.  The egg custard tart was really really good.  Didnt try anything else, but im sure the other baked items are delicious as well.  High recommendation.
author: Anthony R.

description:
All my friends in the bay area rave about the egg tarts from golden gate bakery, so I took my family here and we got some macaroons and egg tarts.  The egg tarts have very fluffy and flaky shells.  Very messy to eat, but pretty delicious, especially when it's straight from the oven!  

These egg tarts are EXPENSIVE!  More expensive than some of the famous egg tart spots in NYC.  However, it seems like this is the best spot to go in SF - so try it if you like egg tarts!
author: Diana N.

description: liked the egg custard, coconut covered mochi balls and the coconut macaroons.  the macaroons are really crispy on the outside and soft inside just how i like them.   mochi balls:  red dot = red bean green dot = chuncky peanut and both = lotus...all yummy.  tried the lemon napoleon and it was alright.  just like the regular sponge cake with lemon.  wanted to try the custard bun and coconut tarts but werent ready.
author: she q.

description:
I come here about 2 or 3 times a year and I swear each time I return, the price of the egg tarts increases by 5 cents.  
The egg tarts here are awesome!  I almost always get at least a dozen to share with friends and family.  The best way to eat them is to pop them in the toaster oven until the crust begins to brown.....yummmm.  There's always a line out the front door so be prepared to wait.  But the line moves quickly and you get a little time to decide what to buy.  But remember...your in Chinatown so cash only, and if you don't speak Cantonese then use your fingers.
author: Smokey G.

description:
very, very, very rude owner/salespeople   I've lost appetite eating their pastries.  you can try Garden bakery, located at Jackson.  I do know how popular they are but that doesn't give them the authority to be so rude.  I've ordered from other bakeries located at Mission street for our office parties and they have entertained my inquiries in a very courteous, helpful and businesslike manner.  
No matter how good their egg tarts, there are other bakeries that do better and cheaper.
author: sfbutterfly l.

description:
best egg tarts i have ever had!!!
the crust is amazing and the filling is perfect when its right out of the oven. they also have other very good baked goods, but all i can remember wer the AMAZING egg tarts.  the place is a little tiny whole in the wall, and the line can get amazingly long, but its worth every second waiting there for some delicious treats... 

i recommend getting in bulk since the wait will probably be up to an hour any given day.
author: Luis V.

description: TWO WORDS: EGG TARTS. The best egg tarts I have ever bitten into. The moon cakes are pretty good too. BUT THE EGG TARTS
author: Lin H.

description:
okay. effin amazing.

you should expect the BEST EGG TARTS in the world to be in the tiniest store in chinatown.  this place is so cramped it's crazy!

i only took away one star because although you get your egg tarts boxed to you freshly BAKED and HOT... later on the steam just takes over the box and the box starts to deform. but hey you cannot hate one a bakery that gives you freshly baked anything.
author: Dominique L.

description:
Very good egg tarts, lotus cakes were good too. 

I just don't understand the wait. They're tarts, not pots of gold. 

Be aware, though that if want to start snacking your tart outside, some tourists people are going to start snapping your photo. 

Maybe if was just my experience, but I prefer it  when people do not take my picture while I'm snacking. I think they thought it was cute that an ethnic couple snacking tarts in front of a bakery in Chinatown, would be a precious postcard. Blahhhhh!
author: Erika D.

description:
BEST EGG TARTS EVER!  PERIOD.

Can't handle the lines though! Call ahead and get it fresh!  So worth it.
author: Moni L.

description: Growing up in Hong kong, I had eaten thousands of egg tarts in my life time.  Did any of the reviewers ever had a decent egg tart in Hong Kong?  If Golden Gate Bakery open in Hong Kong, they will fold in less than 3 months.  Why?  First, the crust is way too oily.  I brought a half dozen of the egg tart home.  They put it in a to go paper box for me.  By the time I was home, the excess oil from the crust managed to soak through the paper cup and the paper box and stain my car seating surface!!!  Not to mention when you finished eating them, your mouth and hand were so oily you felt like you had been munching on a block of warm lard!  A good crust is very tricky to make.  It has to be flaky, rich tasting, and not oily.  To make it flaky and rich is easy,  all you have to do is dumping butter or lard in it.  But to make the crust not oily is where the skill comes in.  In Hong Kong,  the good egg tart's crust is always dry to touch,   On Youtube there are actually some video about what authentic, good tasting egg tarts should look like.  You would not even see much oil on the paper cup that's holding the tart!  And by the way, they are way over price.  The altitude toward their customers should be improved.   The A-1 bakery on Ocean Avenue is way better.
author: Frank W.

description:
Stopped in for one of the egg tarts on a recent visit after reading so many positive reviews on Yelp. True to their word, the tart was great: warm and flakey as described. Even better was the fact that I didn't have a line to wait in! 

I've never had an egg tart before, so I don't know what to compare it to. However, if you want an authentic snack to write home about, this would be it.
author: J T.

description:
GO FOR THE EGG CUSTARD TARTS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I highly recommend getting those yummy egg custard tarts. Eat them while it's warm from the oven. The crust is so flakey with warm egg custard in the middle. 

The bad thing is that you have stand and wait in this long ass line to get into the bakery. Another thing is the ladies who work there will yell at you if you take a long time to order something. So make sure you know what you want or else be prepared to be yelled at in Cantonese!
author: Alysha L.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery has forever ruined egg tarts for me.  Ever since I first had their egg tarts x number of years ago (back when they only cost $0.65 each), I have not been able to eat another egg tart without comparing them to Golden Gate's.  But nothing compares to their perfectly flaky crust and their smooth custardy center *sigh*  So yea...each piece of eggy goodness now sets me back $1.15 (the equivalent of two egg tarts at other bakeries!) and I am still a sucker for them.  It must be the crack in them...why else is there always such a crazy long line even though the stuff is twice as expensive?!

They also have very good Wife Cakes (Lo Pau Bang) and Curry Beef Puffs.  I'm not sure what they put in their pastry dough but everything is just so perfect and flaky.  So delicious!  So addicting!
author: Katelynn L.

description:
This is what the egg tarts here have done to me.

I would actually contemplate sacrificing my big toe for one of these little pieces of heaven. PURE EUPHORIA.

btw, parking sucks. go at night when parking is easier and there isn't a huge line.
author: Jennifer L.

description: My parents come here every single time they're in San Francisco. At one point, it seemed like it was every weekend. That's how good it was! It's a shame they are almost always on vacation though, or at least that's what it seems like. But when they are opened, the line stretches past the door. They carry a variety of pastries. The egg tarts, coconut buns, and macaroons are all delicious, especially those egg tarts! If you haven't had one yet, definitely do. Now. Before they go on vacation again.
author: Jason Dak W.

description: REALLY rude service.  I tried to ask if they used lard in a certain item, so I'd know if it was OK to give a vegetarian friend.  In person, my question was completely ignored, and over the phone, I was hung up on and told the didn't have time to waste on that!  :(  Very bad experience.   Also, I have had much better quality (esp. mooncakes)  before-- this place seems to just have a lot of tourists/hype, and the quality and prices reflect that.
author: Elle C.

description: Yes yes, egg tarts, but the Lotus seed cakes are also very good. The atmosphere is a hoot. Back of the store looks like an out of control CPA firm from the 50's. Papers folders books newspapers you name it. If they actually bakel in this store I would really worry about burning the place down, anyway...Service was fast efficient a little abrupt, not rude however so it's all good. A San Francisco treat.
author: michael d.

description: So, I've been TRYING to try this place for over a year now! 5-6 I've been here, they were always closed for the day or closed for vacation. This place does so well that they can close for half a year just for vacation. It's crazy. So I finally got to come here last week cause I decided to make a SF trip for my birthday. Luckily when we came, there was no line. We ordered 3 egg tarts. The guy after me order 4 dozens! Made me realize their popularity! The crust is so flaky and the inside texture is like pudding. It was pretty darn good and probably the best egg tart I've had. It's pretty big for an egg tart. You can buy it by each or by dozens.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I've been going here since I was a kid and Egg Tarts were only 75 cents.  now they're like 1.50 i think.  True, they are quite expensive as far as a chinese bakery goes, but they are the BOMBest.  The egg tarts are a true winner with the delightly sweet egg custard center and a crispy flaky skin.  The only place that can beat that is the actual Portugese Egg Tart in Macau! 

During the moon festival, around August, they also sell the moon cakes which are also a hot buy!  But be careful going there since they end up closing for vacation for about 4-6 months after that since they all ballers by then from da moon cake sales.  

Their "wife pastries" filled with lotus seeds are good as well.  If you get a chance on the weekends, they have this soft spongy bun that has a little sugary topping on top that looks like a fluffy muffin called a "fa goh bao" (French Bun) and that has always been my favorite.  

I guess it does suck that over the years, they've become so much more popular and they've raised their prices.  Nowadays, I only go there as a treat, but not like my past younger days when my mom would buy a box of stuff from there weekly.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Anyone who gives this place less than 5 stars (or 4, I will give you some breathing room) is a fool. A FOOL! A GODDAMN FOOL, I say!

Seriously, what's wrong with you? Did your mama drop you on your head as a child and you bit off your tongue, thus lost all your taste senses? 

As if other bakeries can top Golden Gate's! And if price is your problem, good! Go eat your flourescent yellow custard tarts and I'll take the horde at GG. 

I'm not even a huge fan of custard tarts! BUT these are the bomb because they're usually at least warm, the crust is never burnt, and they are just perfect little cups of custardy-ness. And the pineapple buns! OH MY GOD, the pineapple buns! They are always way to hard and lack taste at other bakeries. These are sweet in just the right way. 

And the buns with the sugar / coconut on the inside! (Anyone know the English word for these? I know in Chinese it's pretty close to GAI MAY BOW... yeah that's right, I busted out the Cantonese. I must be serious about those buns). 

Seriously, what's wrong wit you! Stuff a bun in your face.
author: Salina Z.

description: Just like they do in Hong Kong! This all business, no frills place gets it right. Those darling Chinese ladies - same faces every time I go. My favorites are (of course) the egg tarts (so warm, so fresh) and the coconut tarts (with the cute red cherry on top). I used to live in the Bay and would always bring friends/family here. Just great.
author: Suzan L.

description:
My search for the perfect Chinese bakery has ended...too bad it had to be in San Francisco and not Oakland, but I'm taking what I can get. Friends can expect detours here every time we're in the city, heavy shopping bags be damned. 

I stumbled upon this bakery by accident, and apparently (by "apparently", I mean, "what Yelp seems to be saying"), egg tarts are the primary attraction. The dan ta is quite tasty, but my excitement centered around their beef/chicken/bbq pork pastry puffs. The pastries are absolutely perfect on the outside -- deliciously flaky, buttery, and savory. The meat is good, too, but not as exceptional. 

I'm sure this isn't saying very much, but I find this bakery to be relatively cleaner/brighter than other Chinese bakeries (especially compared to a certain one on Waverly). It's also nice that they have a decent seating area. I've never experienced a line that was too excessive..maybe you should take that with a grain of salt; after all, this is coming from someone who has willingly waited 45 minutes for Pinkberry in LA.
author: Ada T.

description:
Meal: Afternoon Snack
Date: March 3, 2009

It was pouring rain. There was no line. I forgot what it was that everyone raved about. I was staring stupidly at the choices. The ladies behind the counter were looking at me expectantly so I ordered a custard cake. It was the egg custard tart that everyone raved about. I walked back to my hotel in the pouring rain protecting my precious snack as best I could. I got soaked but the custard cake was intact when I opened the bag 20 minutes later. It was tasty, very good but not the out-of-body experience I was hoping for. Then again, I'm not big on sweets so maybe I was hoping for too much.Maybe it would have tasted better after a meal. I'd be happy to try some of their other goodies next time I am in town.
author: Dave L.

description:
I had my first encounter of the real egg-custard-tart by happenstance. Years ago we (me & sis & some friends) were walking up-down Grant when we saw a long line of (asian/chinese) people in front of this hole in the wall place.  No offense people, but I don't trust places that claim authenticity of their food if the people lining up are not the native eater of the particular cuisine. 
Anyway, I mean, that place was so small, with a flock of people like that, it gotta be good, right? And right I was. 

30 minute of waiting, shoving, and pushing inside the short counter in a small space to grab boxes (yes, people buying them custards by the dozens!!! ... just remember to take your cholesterol pills ^_^) of egg custard tart was not in vain. 

The warm, flaky crust buttery but not greasy, with the soft eggy-creamy filling, rich but not thick, soft and smooth, it's like melting in your mouth! Even when you eat it cold or warm temperature it is still heavenly. (drooling yet? .. hehehehe...)

Of course we got to try other pastries while we at it. I like the mochi (rice cake) with peanuts filling and the macaroons.

Oh yeah, go there around 4-5pm and line up for the fresh batch of the egg-tart.
author: Kat S.

description:
Perhaps the best egg tart I've ever had! Perfect flavor, crust flakiness, warmth, and consistency. I was a bit skeptical as this place was located on Grant (= touristy).  Being in Chinatown I was expecting dirt cheap tarts, so when they rang up at $1.20 a piece I was kind of disappointed and surprised.....until I bit into my first one.  OH MY GOODNESS!   

Oh, I didn't see any egg tarts in the display but asked for them anyway and I guess they have them stored in the back or something.
author: Steve Y.

description:
There is a reason why there's a line out the door.

Egg custard tarts. Vanilla cream rolls. Mochi ball things. Banana long things. Mochi flat things with yellow bean centers. I wish they told me what they were called...I just point and nod.

They take random month long vacations. So stock up when you can.
author: Jacinta H.

description:
One Trick Pony.

Ok, so I succumbed to all the hoopla over the dan tan.  I've never been into these but I grew up always purveying various dan tan because my grandma loved them so we always got them.  I've had my fair share of them in NY, L.A., Sydney, Hong Kong and Golden Gate Bakery's dan tan is among one of the best I've had in recent years.  Not too sweet, fresh, flaky crust, custard the right firmness.  

Their cha siu bao was fairly good.  Meat was not your usual gooey mix.  

Now the absolute ugly --- someone on Yelp mentioned they liked the sa chi ma here.  Now, sa chi ma is what I used to do anything for as a kid.  I was crazy for this pure fat treat.  For those of you who don't know sa chi ma, it's this wonderful chinese version of rice crispy treats but so much better if I say so myself.  We used to get some in the 70's in downtown L.A. chinatown that came in a pink box with red string tied to it and I'd sneak piece after piece, trying to rearrange the pre-cut squares in the box so that my parents and brother couldn't tell I had too much. So, I was thrilled to read an endorsement of some good sa chi ma.  I don't eat the processed, packaged kind commonly sold in chinese markets.  I don't know if it's because it was dinner time when I stopped by Golden Gate Bakery and the sa chi ma was old, in which case the store should not have sold it to me, but the sa chi ma here was tooth-chipping hard.  I mean, it was like biting into a square rock.  Just ridiculous this was sold to me.  Greedy me, in a moment of glee at the sight of them, got four of them and I had to toss all of them.  Shame on them for selling these like this.  Negative stars for the sa chi ma if there are such things.

I didn't see anything else that looked appetizing enough in the display to try.  My assessment - Go here for dan tan if that floats your boat.  Otherwise, don't bother with this place.  Plenty of better dim sum places.  This place should be more aptly called Golden Gate Dan Tan Bakery.

Cash-only...duh.
author: Liz K.

description:
I'm giving this place 5 stars.....

only for their egg tarts!

I mean come on.....do you really get anything else from here?  I've heard they serve other chinese pastries here too...but i don't know...I think they're lying.  My eyes have always gone straight for the egg tarts.  What other pastries...you crazy?? LOCO???!?!  It's hypnotizing, watching tray after tray of delicious baked gold in front of your eyes.

You can't just order 1 after waiting in line for 15 min.  Noooo!!  For this amount of time...you gotta order like......50!!!  for who??  who cares....take it and run!!
author: Tadd L.

description:
I'm not going to lie, I was slightly disappointed to wait in line for 10 minutes only to hear they don't sell hot dog buns. And the pork bun gave me a stomach ache.

The egg custard tart is yummy, but word of warning - trying to eat this while walking down the busy streets of chinatown is a feat in itself. Get a napkin or wear a bib.
author: Betsy V.

description:
seeing the long line of chinese folks...something must be good.

after waiting in line for 30mins...the egg tart was good!

$1.15 per egg tart. CASH ONLY.
author: Elliot Y.

description:
Alright, I'm going to have eggs thrown at me for saying this.

A friend of mine kept raving about this place, so I made a point of trying it there when I was in San Fran. What a big disappointment. First of all, I thought there were WAAAAAAAY too much egg. The tart was so deep, why not call it a quiche? ha. Yes, the crust was very flaky, that's why I got it all over me too. Anyways...I don't know what the hype is. Ok, I confess, I'm not a fan of eggs, but I'm not a fan of rice pudding either, until I tried Rice to Riches! (and I liked it!)
author: Lala L.

description:
Come here for the egg custard treats and nothing else and you will leave earth in a nirvana state like of mind.

For starters if you don't know what an egg custard (don-tat) treat is, you can always start with a wikipedia search. From there I would go to Golden Gate Bakery - usually 8:30-9:00AM are good times (if you work nearby like I do); any other time of day say like a weekend at 1pm would mean standing in a really long line for about 20 minutes to get your delicious egg custard treat.

Beware of sneaky Chinese ladies like my grandmother who don't speak much English who will attempt to cut into your line while you are people watching or not paying attention to get her delicious egg custard treat.

Pros: Delicious egg custard treats only; not really anything else I'd recommend

Cons: Prices have gone up since I was eight years old from $.35 custard to treats each to now a whopping $1.00 each! You do also know that they use LARD to make these custard treats right?
author: Will C.

description:
I waited in line, for maybe 10minutes... the line only moved because people ahead left the line. Otherwise, the line didn't move.

Whispers of  "its really good here", "there's always a line" throughout.

Do they spike the food here to make people return for more?

This line wrapped around the sidewalk, and a sidewalk in Chinatown is already crowded.

Sadly, the line wasn't moving, unhappy faces galore.
author: qirk z.

description:
They have delicious egg tarts but I don't know if it's the best Ive ever had but it's good. 

The BBQ pork pastry is delicious, flaky and crunchy. 

It's extremely cramped inside and it's like the usual Chinese bakery where you see and hear Chinese ladies yelling out in Chinese haha but it's expected. 

Although I wouldn't really stand in line just to get some pastries here, I would make a pit stop if there is no line and if im in chinatown.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Good egg tarts (obviously) but not sure I'd wait more than 10 min in line again...
author: Leily P.

description:
A friend of mine told me of this place and how she wanted to try it out when she came to the Bay Area.  So I went here to get some Mooncakes and custards for her and stood in line for over 3 hours.  The Autumn Moon Festival obviously didn't help the length of the line.  It's not that the line was long, it was that the line moved really slowly.  

While some were pre-orders or just large orders, people were jumping in front of the line and they didn't really do anything to police it.  Well, it's Chinatown where the little old ladies run you over to get a seat on the Stockton 30 (or the Chinatown bus as a friend once called it) - so deal with it.

Maybe it's because of the sheer number of large orders that came through or maybe I'm picky, but the custards were just good and not what I was led to expect.  Or maybe standing in line for three hours listening to some cantekerous folks in the line impacted my taste buds.  But it definitely was not worth 3 hours.  Maybe 10-15 minutes.

And eat them hot - we got a dozen and had some left overs that we let sit for a few hours.  They got rather mushy.  There were lots of people who bought like a hundred of the tarts and I'm still wondering what they were going to do with them.  Must have lots of friends.
author: Dave L.

description:
Excellent custard tarts! Sooo soft and fresh even at around 4 PM on a Saturday and as I expected, there was a bit of a line but it moved quickly enough.

The tarts had a crispy pastry shell but the custard was almost too soft. It had just enough substance to stay intact and may benefit from setting a bit at room temperature before being devoured.

They also sell sponge cakes, so rather than hunting across the area for a good sponge cake, you can just make one stop and get everything you want (well... almost).

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description: Yea the egg tarts are HUMONGO!!! And yea I think they are pretty tasty..., but man does the line for this place become HUMUNGO just to get some egg tarts. It is hard enough to get or find parking in china town, but I think I waited over 1/2 an hour to try these golden flaky treats. If you are a fan of the egg tart, it's like waiting for an Ike's sandwich... Long and painful, but mmm mmm good once you get to take a bite :)
author: Minh V.

description: I was told that this was perhaps one of the best places in SF chinatown to get egg tarts to while on vacation in SF, I had to stop by and get one. The first thing I noticed was that the egg tarts was bigger than most and instead of buying 3 at a time like usual at a dim sum restaurant, you buy them one by one. It is kind of pricey for egg tarts and in all honesty, it didn't taste like anything special. Therefore I give it 3 stars, it wasn't bad but I don't think it was really worth the money in terms of egg tarts.
author: sherry w.

description:
I went to GGB yesterday, and I was afraid it would be closed because of the Moon Festival, but thankfully it wasn't. I've visited before and missed it because they were on those vacations!!

It's true, the prices are a little inflated - $1.25 for a dan ta. But they really are fantastic!! I bought another dan ta from another bakery and even comparing them hours later, GGB dan ta reign supreme. They're egg-y, creamy, and the crust is flaky. 

The ladies are quite nice, though! Maybe because I arrived right when they opened, around 9, but their understanding of English was pretty good, too. GO GGB.
author: Alice L.

description: Very tasty egg tarts, but don't know if it's worth the wait (~20 min late saturday afternoon). However, it's much, much better than the grocery stuff in the south bay. $1.15 each. Would come back if I was in the area and it was a weekday (smaller line maybe?).
author: Joyce C.

description:
whenever i come here and the line is super long and i look in the window, i always think to myself 'really? is it really worth standing in this line? they don't even have that big of a selection.' but then, i sink my teeth into one of their infamous dahn taht's, and all of my questions and doubts quickly fade away. 

the line is definitely worth the wait, despite what others may say.

fyi: this place accepts cash only, peeps,which is generally the norm at most restaurants/ shops/ bakeries in chinatown... so bring your dollar bills, or go home sad, hungry and jealous.
author: Erin M.

description: Yeah, this place is good. I just get the normal ones and skip the trendy flavors. Prepare to eat dessert instead of lunch when you pick these up. Super yummy!
author: Sarah T.

description:
EGG CUSTARD TARTS FTW!  

Creamy, flaky, fresh, and sweet...Golden Gate Bakery's Egg Custard Tarts are good to eat!  

I have heard nothing but good things about Golden Gate Bakery.  The line can be a bit long, and parking can be an issue; however, the wait and hassle is definitely worth what lies inside of the bakery.  

The Egg Custard Tarts are most popular.  Not only do I conclude that through what clients say, but through my own personal experience.  I have not had an Egg Custard Tart as good as one from Golden Gate Bakery.  I witnessed a customer ordering Golden Gate Bakery's Egg Custard Tarts...in BULK.  Share the wealth.  An Egg Custard Tart will surely brighten anyone's day. 

The location is convenient considering Golden Gate Bakery is in Chinatown.  Have delicious baked goods from Golden Gate Bakery while strolling around Chinatown!  :D
author: H. C.

description: I stood in line for a short while just to buy some egg tarts since so many people were watiting for the same thing, I finally bought some, it was okay, I think they are just over rated, there are a few places in SF is just as good and better, not worth my time to stand in line for this.
author: Tiff K.

description: My sis made me try the egg custard tarts here.  They're amazing.  Only $1 and you get a huge egg custard tart.  Definitely get them while they're hot cuz cold egg custard tarts just don't taste the same.  I got a bunch of crumbs on my shirt but it was well worth eating while strolling through the city on a beautiful day.  Yum Yum Yum.
author: Amy J.

description:
The egg tarts are indeed fantastic - large, always fresh, not too sweet or rich.  I always come meaning to try something else, but invariably settle on their speciality.

Be prepared for long lines and/or an unexpected vacation closure.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Waited about 20 mins for these famous egg tarts. Got them fresh and it was just okay. A little to eggy for my taste, but buddy who eats egg tarts all the time said it's the best he has ever had.
author: . V.

description:
I just bought two Custard Egg Tarts from them at about 9:30 a.m.  They had a small line and I waited till it was down to nothing.  I loved paying only $1.15 each for these lovely tarts.  They were fresh and warm.  Yummmmy.  Best ever.  Not to greasy and not to eggy.  

The place is so tiny (order up and leave kind of place)...you just go up and order, but you better know what you want because the signs and menu is in Chinese.  

The lady that waited on me was very nice and explained to me the various prices for the Moon Cakes (I'll go back later for them when I can afford the calories.)

Bring a hard  box or tupper wear with you to put small orders of goodies in them so they wont get crushed.  They only give boxes for larger orders.
author: Vanilla C.

description: I LOVE DAN TAT! Not the tiny ones you would get at Dim Sum with all crust and sunken in custard in the middle, but the thin crusts with lots of custard! Ones you can literally get a few spoonfuls out. I remember when it used to be dimes each... now it's $1.15ea and if you buy a dozen it's not any cheaper! Luckily, most of the times i've been, the line was no longer than 15mins. Once, this little chinese lady started ordering behind me and the lady at the counter actually looked past me. YOU HAVE TO SPEAK UP or else those rude little ladies step all over you. The lady at the counter said "Oh, SHE (me) said it's her turn." How rude!! Such Ageists in chinatown!  If it wasn't that good I would never come back! Anyway... I've seen people order dozens and dozens for weddings. Dan Tat at weddings? Forreal? I'm there!
author: Wendy L.

description: The Egg Tarts are really, really good!!! Every time I just went there for that stuff!
author: Daisy L.

description:
All you need to know is that this is the only dun tat (egg custard) you should be eating. No place will ever compare no matter how hard you look. This IS the real deal!

The only problem is that I don't have control over when I can have it. Chinatown is too far away and I always have a hard time finding parking. I only get it when my friend brings it over for my family (thank you Kevina M!) or my mom asks her friends in the area to pick some up. 

I say I probably only get to enjoy this treat two or three times a year. Sigh. AND they are such ballers because of the booming business that they go on vacation A LOT! So they may be closed for weeks at a time to reward themselves.
author: Allan M.

description: These awesome egg tarts are about a buck each and they are worth it! Order a dozen they are worth it!
author: Joy C.

description:
This rating due to their customer service.

I agree this place is NEVER open! Also the people here are so rude! 
There is a long line out the door, people wait and yet they can't seem to understand how to service customers who come first.

I agree that their egg tarts are yummy, but with the prices they charge and their terrible customer service, I'd rather go to other bakeries in SF that service egg tarts just as good with great customer service.
author: lily l.

description: I always wondered if this place was worth the hype. Unfortunately, the last time I tried checking it out, they were closed for vacation. This time, the line wasn't that bad, so my wife waited in line to buy some goodies. All I have to say is, HOLY COW!!! Their dan tat is noticeably better!! The secret is in their light and flaky crust. Everyone else seems to make theirs doughy like a regular pie crust, but not Golden Gate Bakery. Another highlight is it seems like all their items are super-sized.  Big portions are A-OK in my book! Overall, this is a place finally worth the hype (and the wait)!
author: Randy C.

description: Golden Gate Bakery has been around for years. I remember when they first opened, they had a little seating area you can order coffee/milk tea and eat your pasteries while reading your daily newspaper. Now, they got rid of that section, the prices went up, and they're always on vacation. Yeah, their pasteries are overpriced but after eating their flaky, delicious eggtarts, no other eggtarts taste the same or can even compare.
author: Lily W.

description:
ugh~ why is this bakery ALWAYS closed for vacation???!!! this' already my 4th attempts, even called to confirm, someone did pick up, but said they aren't open. guess in this case, it was only a misconception about chinese being one of the hardest working people in the world~

may be one day i'll get to try this "mystical" egg custard....
author: Catherine W.

description: Very tasty treats....Nuomici (rice balls with coconut filling - doesnt sound awesome but is)...moon cakes..cream rolls and of course the egg tarts...wish we bought more :(.
author: B P.

description: Egg tarts fresh and hot. 'nuff said.
author: Edward C.

description: Best egg tarts here (long line for these goodies). I literally can eat 10 these yummy pastry;)
author: Christine T.

description:
Yes we all know this place has the best egg custard tarts in the world. You can read other reviews on the texture, taste etc... There is always a line out the door and everyone wants one. I can never find parking here so I usually park on the side of the road and put my blinkers on, run in and get my tarts. If you go at night, there is usually no line so in and out in less than a minute.  Make sure you ask them get the hot tarts out of the oven. Some of he tarts sit there for a while (rare) and gets cold. 
Oh I also tried the chinese moon cake. Those are awesome! They aint cheap especially if you want your 4 yolk and nuts. I think that cost like $15 each. But well worth it. Cash only. oh yea, it helps if you speak cantonese and be nice. The woman usually slips you an extra tart if you buy enough
author: Tony W.

description: I have never had egg tart that has so much eggy flavors.  They were warm and very soft, and it tasted as if there were a couple (or even more) good eggs in it.  It was so soft it even felt like eating pudding, tofu etc..   It is definitely worth a try.
author: Durif M.

description: OK...seriously this place is without a doubt the best bakery place in SF for chinese pastries.  I've been here so many times, and yes it's a few coins more expensive than other places but it's so good and well worth it.  The lines are ridiculous and half the time it's all tourists.  The egg tarts, the wife bao, and OMG their bbq pork buns are super delish. :)  Can't wait to go again!
author: Amy A.

description: yeah, freshest egg tart this side of hong kong..
author: Jeff N.

description: ah yes, another gem in the city especially for die-hard egg tart fans.. the secret is to arrive by 8:30..hot and fresh the eggy-trans-fat just melts in your mouth. so satisfying...
author: Jen C.

description:
Best. Daan Taats.  Ever.

What's a daan taat?  It's an "egg custard tart."  See wikipedia.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egg_tart

To expand on Diana L's comments "daah" is Cantonese for "dozen" you can also say:

"Yat daah daan taat, mmmg goi."

Which means.

"One dozen daan taats, please."

Every time I find myself in SF Chinatown during daylight hours I always find the means to bring at least dozen of these bad boys back to the suburbs.  Whenever I have family in town, I always bring them here.  Even my relatives from Hong Kong say that the daan taats here are legit.

Who cares if there's a long line.  The line is there for a reason, they're that good.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Us Chinese like things cheap. 
So it speaks volumes when we're willing to not only fork over almost $1/egg tart, but also stand in a line for it from GG Bakery. 
(No worries though, the line moves rather quickly.)

The egg tarts are amazing- almost always fresh from the oven as the demand is truly just that high- piping hot, flaky crust, smooth egg/custard filling. What more can you ask for?

I usually buy a dozen whenever I stop by and sneak one out of the box before I get back to my car. It's that irresistible.
I hear the melon cakes are great as well.
author: Lily L.

description:
I'd stand in line for the whole day for an egg tart. I can't describe it, but the custard is perfect! Its light yet creamy and not too sweet! The crust is flaky and buttery. MmMmM!! 

Go on a weekday to avoid long lines.
author: Jenny K.

description: Mike and I were walking through Chinatown and saw a long line coming out of the Golden Gate Bakery as we were walking by so we jumped into the line because it's gotta be good if this many Asian ppl are willing to wait in line for it. It appeared like others followed our example and before we knew it, the line wound around like a snake outside the store. They were out of the char siu baos so I just pointed and chose a bunch of buns with different fillings (red bean, lotus paste) and we also got a long pastry with bbq pork in it. The pastry was so flaky and the filling was perfectly sweet and satisfying. Mike wished we had gotten more - he said that he could eat 40 of them - they were that good! The prices were a little higher than other random Chinese bakeries in China town, but the quality is definitely better.
author: Mel C.

description: I don't care if it's filled with lard! This place is sooooooooooooo gooooooooood! Imagine how sad I was when I left a whole box of eggtarts at the boyfriend's place...AND HE LET THEM ROT.
author: Kay P.

description: I was looking for a lunch spot and stumbled on some yelp reviews for this bakery and their egg custard tarts. I passed by itnon my walk and stopped in. Best decision ever. My tarts were still warm and were heavenly with wonderful crust. I also got a nameless lemon/fruit layered bar that was fantastic as well. I'll be back tomorrow. And very cheap, as a bonus.
author: Katie W.

description:
There's a reason for the line--delicious, straight from the oven don tots (egg custard tarts).  Yummy!

Also be warned...every summer (usually August, I think) for about 2 weeks, the shop is closed...gone back to China to visit, I assume.
author: mandy f.

description:
What is the freakin' big deal about this place? The prices are ridiculous and the food is average. If it tasted spectacular, yes, I would pay a little extra but the prices here are not justified.

95 cents for an egg custard. It tasted okay but honestly, I've had better tasting egg custards in numerous places in the city for half the price.

I also tried the "lo paul baing." Alright, forgive I'm trying to spell out phonetically what you would call it in Chinese. The literal translation is wife's cookie, I think. What the heck is it called in English?

The "lo paul baing" was again subpar and expensive at $2.50 each. Yes, it was pretty big but still overpriced and as usual with anything I've tried at this bakery,  I've tasted better elsewhere.

Save your money. Pick any Chinese bakery in SF and the odds are in your favor that it will taste better than Golden Gate Bakery.

They may stay busy but I wonder how many of them are actually repeat customers.

EDIT: 9/28/07 It is now $1.10 for one egg custard. And is it me, or have they shrunk in size?
author: Wendy L.

description:
Of course I'll stand in line for Dahn Taat! No, really, I wasn't being sarcastic. I haven't run into too many lines (I come during off-peak hours I guess). When there is a line I will stand in it. But, minus a whole star for pulling the shit where they unexpectedly go on vacation for a few weeks without notice! This has happened a few times and it has to stop. I don't live in Chinatown and my cravings for that buttery flaky custard tart crust don't have any particular schedule. Could you at least leave the one or two people behind to man the ship on limited hours. Don't just up and leave. 

Good luck parking, unless you rock a hardcore Asian style and double park it on Grant. The Chinese half of me rates double parking as 5 stars for pure humor.
author: Alia D.

description: Nothing more needs to be said about this place. When it's open, it's without a doubt the best egg tarts you'll find.
author: Ngoc N.

description: Yup, best egg custard tarts I've ever had. I can't go to Chinatown without picking up a dozen to bring home to the fam. When I get them they're always fresh and hot. I live 40 minutes away in Vallejo, and when I get home they're still as good as when they're first put in the box.
author: Zherr-Anne A.

description: Yay! They make all the wonderful goodies that Mom used to make. Except they still aren't as good as Mom's. They have some great bake goods that a lot of other chinese bakeries won't have. They lost a star cause they are so frickin EXPENSIVE. But I guess with lines always out their door sometimes(the whole day). They've gotten used to charging whatever they want, because they know WE"LL be BACK!!
author: Ms. T.

description: I do not know what all the hype is about the egg tarts.  Waited at least 30 minutes for 4 of them but didn't like them at all.  Ended up throwing them out.
author: G B.

description: Have you ever had a piping hot egg tart with a flaky crispy crust? Golden Gate Bakery has the best egg tarts in town. I used to walk here from downtown during my lunch to pick up a dozen. They always have a line and sell out quick. They have a hard time keeping up with the demand sometimes, but it's worth the wait. It's pricier than most egg tarts, but it's the best one I've ever had.
author: Adelina W.

description: Yes, them egg tarts is damn good and so worth it to go back.....IF this place is open..so call first.
author: Hoover A.

description:
Egg Custards - Delicious!  Not too sweet with a flaky crust.
Moon Cakes - Heavy bean cakes are so good.  They have them all the time, not just during the Moon Festival, and you can get them with no, one, or two yolks for good luck!  They have several varieties and sizes with different beans.
Macaroons - Yummy and not too rich so you can eat a lot of them!
Fried crispy things - Served during Chinese New Year and sold by the bag, the little crispy fried things have a sweet, nutty chewy coated interior (hollow inside) and a crunchy, won ton outside.
Jelly things - I love the while jelly things.  I really like the long banana ones and the round coconut covered ones with macadamia nuts in the middle.  Again, like most Chinese deserts, not too sweet and so good!
Rice Crispy Thing - sweet and gooey.

As you can tell, I am not Asian and I only say hello and thank you in Mandarin.  Luckily my boyfriend can speak Chinese and got $30 worth of goods in a big pink box.  We waited in line out the door and got roughed up just trying to get everyone once we were inside the tiny store.  They don't really display what things are and how much they cost, and I thought it was kind of pricey.  The store is really small, yet 3/4 of the room is sectioned off and full of stacks of junk.  Kind of dirty!  The service was okay, hurried.  It varies what is available, they are not consistent.  I liked the taste of all the treats we tried, but everything else about the bakery was not good.
author: Julie R.

description:
Yes, Darren, no need to say mo'....

HANDS DOWN, BEST DAN TA (in Mandarin accent) EVER!!  

The first time I had it, I thought it was pretty good. The previous time I had egg custard tarts was in Taiwan, so of course I only thought the ones from Golden Gate was alright, not like how crazily-good people described.  And the bakery is just too far away from San Mateo, where I am, and it's a pain in the arse to park, so I never made a trip there just for some egg custard.

The next time when I had egg custard tart was from Sheng Kee, and I thought it wasn't bad either. One day I just had the urge (actually I was jobless and bored) and thought to go to China Town and get egg custard at Golden Gate.

Again, I thought it was pretty good, and I engraved my memory of how good it was in my head.

Couple weeks ago I had egg custard again from Sheng Kee, and I almost puked. There wasn't eggs! It was God-knows-what and tons of sugar on pie crust!  Dang, and I'm going to Golden Gate Bakery tomorrow!
author: HsuMeow L.

description:
This is the best  bakery in SF Chinatown that serves Chinese pastries. Their egg custard tarts are their best seller (the crust is super crispy)!! 

Pretty much everything they make here tastes delicious and all their items are freshly baked from the oven everyday. Normally when you go on the weekends, you will see a long line outside their bakery, but it's worth the long wait. GGB has been in business for a long time. 

I will always frequent this place once or twice a month when i was younger.

Note: they also make their own moon cakes, which they sell during the Autumn Moon Festival..
author: Jenny K.

description:
I don't like the egg custard tart here, AT ALL. Maybe it was an off day when I went, but it was just REALLY BAD!! The shell was soooooo soggy, almost mushy, and the filling tasted like raw egg, it was undercooked! I'm sorry but it was absolutely disgusting.

There are 2 kinds of egg custard tarts that you can usually get in a chinese bakery, the traditional chinese, and portugese. The traditional chinese egg custard has a shell that looks and tastes very similar to the western tart shell. Te filling should be a little firmer than pudding or custard, but less firm than jell-o. The fine balance of the crunchy shell and soft (not creamy) is the key.

The portugese egg custard was once such a hit a couple years ago in Taiwan that everyone cued for hours in front of stores. Why? Because it's so different from the traditional one and so amazingly good. The shell is flaky  and crunchy, like a Tartine croissant and the filling is creamy, like pudding (firmer but not as firm as the chinese egg custard tart), and, a slightly browned top that's formed by the egg and cream in the custard while baking.

I couldn't tell which kind they make here, but it was just, really really disgusting. Was it because it was a random afternoon on a Tuesday?
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Holy Molly!

The line moved ridiculously slow, but the egg custard tarts were well worth it! Not just the egg custard tarts, but we also tried the sesame balls, which are pretty good, and this amazing custard cake roll sandwich. It was delicious. I don't think that I have had a cake that good before. It was a roll of sponge cake with custard in the center and dusted with coconut on the outside, then sandwiched in between two pieces of pastry like thin lemon cookie dusted with powder sugar. Don't know what it is called but Oh My God, I am going back to get that for sure.

5 star! No doubt!
author: WS P.

description:
Egg custards should not be this good, It has eggs and a pie crust.........but holy shit this egg custard taste good. I am convinced they put cocaine in their egg custard. This would explain why they are always on vacation. Vacation to Columbia to buy more cocaine so they can put it in their egg custards.

On the serious note, if you plan to try this joint anytime soon, seek anger management therapy first or take alot of sleeping meds because the lines are long and people will just cut in front of you.  
I almost busted a cap on a 80 year old grandmother on a wheelchair because she ran over my foot and then proceeded to cut in front of me. I would've hurt her but she was actually my grandmother.  Sorry grandma. 
.
author: Rong K.

description:
It was my 3rd or 4th time here and the first time I had to stand in a line. Don't be intimated by the line that snakes around the front of the store. The line moves fast. $1.15 for their famous egg tarts is steep, but they are served warm not too egg-y. They are so warm that the women cut holes in the corners of the pink pastry box for the egg tarts to breathe.

This is a must try if you LOVE Chinese egg tarts.
author: Mary R.

description: Not bad, but definitely overrated, and NOT the best tarts I've ever had.  I'm not sure this is where actual Chinese people go for good egg tarts.  Po Taats are better and creamier.
author: Josephine C.

description: The best egg tart I've ever had. We ordered a dozen but it took forever to get. The older Chinese customers tend to push and skip ahead of you, so you'll have to stand your ground. I would give this place 5 stars but the lady behind the counter gave me an attitude, even though I was being polite. The wait is long, so be prepared. Also, know what you want before you get up to the counter, they don't like waiting around cause it's crowded in there.
author: Lily T.

description: My wife and were in Chinatown just to check it out, as I noticed that the place was indeed Open! Only shop on Grant that had a line of Chinese people out the door...you know this place has to be good!  We waited for about 10 mins and fortunately they brought out a new tray of egg tarts from the oven...we bought two for desert....yes had the will power not to tear in to them as we walked away.  Definitely best egg tarts we've had any where...nice and buttery / flacky crust, generous amounts of egg custard, but best of all these things are huge! They are the size of my palm.  Worth the wait, especially if they are open...we got lucky they just reopened the day we showed up.
author: Mike C.

description: Amazing choices, be ready to order quickly or Asians will cut in line. Not sure why they do this but they do. Serve is curt but food is amazing.
author: Dionne C.

description:
EGG CUSTARD TART.

flaky warm crust that screams sweet sweet unhealthy treat that's well worth losing a couple of years off your life. While many have posted that the egg tart is overrated, it is certainly a matter of preference. If you enjoy fresh baked egg custard tarts that are literally so soft and fragile they collapse and melt in your mouth, then this is the place!
Along with the infamous egg custard tart, the other baked items were served to delight the sweet tooth as well. coconut and cream filled buns along with others were a delight to devour. :]
author: Angeline L.

description:
I'm not a fan of sweet food, no idea why, I just am. I used to love egg tarts when I was younger, but I guess as I got older, they became too sweet for my taste.

The last time I actually had an egg tart was literally years ago, until I tried Golden Gate's egg tarts during September of this year. The crust is really flaky, almost to the point it just literally crumbles as you eat it. The custard isn't too sweet, while being soft and fluffy.  

The wait is long at times, but for some, the wait is worth it. It's amusing watching a bunch of tourists ask the people waiting in the line what they're waiting for and then to see them join the line.

The price of the egg tarts are probably a tad on the expensive side compared to other bakeries out there, but in my opinion, it's worth it.

I will say, this bakery's eggs tarts are probably the only egg tarts I will eat without *much* hesitation.
author: Nikki H.

description: FYI: If you are thinking about going to Golden Gate Bakery, they are currently on vacation. I stopped by today, May 30th and I saw their sign up :(
author: H B.

description: Their egg custard is the absolute best in the entire Bay Area!! The only reason not 5 stars is they are in vacation almost half of the time I visit them. I get a feeling that they are so good on business that they are on vacation 1/3 of the year.
author: Lindy C.

description:
Their Egg Custard is the best in town.

However, that's all they have going for them. Tourists come here left and right, literally. I go elsewhere for my other Chinese baked goods from the BBQ pork buns to the veggie buns! 

But still a good Egg Custard!
author: Michael C.

description:
As stated, the place is expensive and the lines can be outrageous.  If you want to go and not wait too long, go on a weekday and arrive around 11:30.  There seems to be less people at that time.

Egg Custard (daan tat) has a flaky crust and the custard is consistent and flavorful, with a good balance and not too eggy.  This what people come for at this place (but I don't think it is the absolute best...problem is, I can't remember where is the best place anymore, so this is a great default).  I use this as my standard for what most other Bakeries should strive for.
author: Kapeli M.

description:
Disclaimer
I'm not a pro on Chinese pastry. I've only had their Don Tots (SP?) aka their Egg Custard pastries.

Positive

The lines outside this bakery can get uncontrollable. And its usually filled with traditional Chinese people from Chinatown (ok, I know, it's IN Chinatown, but still...). Get their Egg Custards. Buy a dozen. You'll eat them in 2 nights. And if you don't they go bad, but that's what you pay for when you want freshness.

Negatives

Long lines. They run out of the Egg Custards fast, and it takes about 10-15 minutes for them to get a new batch from their mysterious kitchen (where the heck is it?! downstairs?! I bet you there are elves somewhere in their magical kitchen producing these things...). Also the service isn't really service, there are a ton of screaming people there all trying to get their order in, and it has the feelings of a 'gimme your order, gimme your money, now git da hell outta da way.' But hey, it's a pastry, I'm not there for the service, or the ambiance, or a conversation. I'm there to 'give yah mah order, give you mah money, and git da hell outta da way.' So it works out.

Can't give it the famous 5 stars, since I haven't had everything there. And of course, only the best of the best get the legendary 5 from me.
author: Seiji N.

description:
Oh what am I going to do?

I went here because all the Yelpers keep hyping on the egg tart. But it was the banana rice roll that did it. I bought one and took it outside with me. It's white, cylindrical, with some flour to keep it from sticking to the paper... really unassuming. It had a curious, slight jiggliness to it, kinda like Jell-O. But when I bit into it, the taste hit me immediately and I was astounded by how good it was. It almost brought me to tears.

I also bought a baked pork bun fresh from the oven. The filling is unremarkable, but the texture and taste of the dough was pure craftsmanship. The woman pulled it out of the heat at that instant time and energy stood still.

Now the legendary egg tart I also tried... and I wasn't impressed. Yes, it certainly had a taste that somehow, I can't describe, but tells me this one is different from all the others. But maybe the trick is to buy it fresh and hot, and only then will the secret of Golden Gate Bakery finally unfold for me. But I actually fear this moment.

My loyalty has been to Eastern Bakery just down the street. Their own Coffee Crunch Cake is a formidable, fearsome and godlike experience. To taste a piece is to realize just how small in the universe you are. Plus their prices are a little better. But here, the women understand English, they SMILE, they're helpful with the item descriptions... and the place is CLEAN! And the food... oh the food...

Oh what am I going to do??
author: Clar L.

description:
The lines are ridiculous.  The prices are ridiculous.  The old Chinese ladies and men can be pushy.  But the $1 egg custard tart is worth ALL of it.  

They always close for 2-3 weeks sometime in the year for their extended vacation so beware!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Best Egg Custard Tarts EVER. I always send out-of-towners to wait in the appalling long line, and not one has ever been disappointed.  It's the Krispy Kreme of Egg Custard Tarts. I kid you not.

They do go on vacation unannounced and close up to an entire month from time to time. I suppose they believe that "absence will make the heart grow fonder."
author: Glory W.

description:
If you're visiting SF, go here for the egg custard tarts, just like everyone else. On your way to the bakery, you better get an SF poncho cuz you'll be waiting in line with the locals who are already dressed appropriately for the weather.

If you're an SF local, screw the egg custard tarts! Go here for the macaroons. PHENOMENAL!
author: dj z.

description:
LOVE the egg custart tarts!!! absolutely the best, esp when fresh out of the oven and warm but also good the next day too. the line can get long at times, but it is so worth it in my opinion. 
I remember visiting with my parents a few years back and standing in line for the tarts without really knowing why, but after I had my first bite - oh, it was sooo good. Kinda wish I had some right now...
author: A W.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! ... Whenever my aunt from Los Angeles comes up to visit she takes home 4 boxes packed full of egg custard tarts from this bakery. I swear!!! It's that good .. and that says a lot especially since Southern California is like the place to be for an assortment of Asian foods. I had to stand in line one time for 30 minutes just to buy ONE tart. I was pretty pissed by the time I got to the counter but after I got my egg custard tart and bit into it.. -big sigh- heavenly -dreamy- yummmmmmmmmmmmm! Seriously so good ... ~_~ 

O yah .. their Chinese cupcake is delicious .. so soft and spongy and o so good. I grew up eating those and no other place makes it quite like them. VISIT THEM ASAP!!!
author: Linda X.

description:
Reason: two words, Egg tarts!

Simply yummy warm (may I add, fresh!) goodness, deliciously melted in your mouth.

There is always a line and it is a bit pricer than other Chinatown bakeries but overall, just the egg tarts are well worth the wait. And the line move pretty quickly. Don't forget all the other huge selection of pastries! They are all good quality and made fresh!
author: NK M.

description:
Walking up and down Chinatown, I had to get away from the WESTFIELD SF CENTRE's food court, where you can buy a small bowl of soup at BRISTOL FARMS for about $5. 

But guess what? For $5, you can have a light crusted egg tart, a flaky chicken pie and a pastry (i didn't know wat it was) with a tasty filling!! Is that amazing? And it was enough to make me full! 

Be warned though, since this place is so popular, there is a line that goes outside into the street. Many of the customers order two or three boxes of pastries at a time. But it is worth the wait!! So come here for something to eat!! :)
author: herm p.

description:
The egg tar is really good. Just like the ones I got in HK but about like 3 times of the price. That's why i give it a 4 star. If it's a little cheaper, then i will definitely give it 5 star. 

The pound cake is also phenomenal. It's dense but still soft and you can taste the rich butter in it.
