Another drawback about this place is the loooooong line, especially during the weekends. Damn tourists... 

Overall, highly recommended if you have the time and money.
author: Hinling Y.

description:
I guess it's safe to assume any business that can afford to just take 3-4 week long vacations annually HAS to be doing something right! Everything is delicious here!! and when I say everything, I mean E-V-E-R-Y-T-H-I-N-G. They are best known for their egg tarts. Do take in mind that I am chinese and have eaten egg tarts my whole life; even the ones in Asia are not this good.

Though the pastries here lean towards the pricey side and the wait in the freezing San Franciscan air on a sidewalk is not exactly how you'd like to spend an hour of your life, once you take a bite into any one of these pastries, you will find yourself doubting whether or not you had bought enough and already scheming ways to go back for more. 

So worth clogging your arteries for!!
author: Leslie H.

description:
When people told me these were the best egg custard tarts, I was kind of skeptical. I like egg custard tarts, but tend to prefer other Chinese sweet foods like mango pudding. How good could Golden Gate Bakery's egg custard tarts be?

Pretty damn good! Combine still warm egg custard with the flakiest, crisply layered crust, and you're in for a treat. Bought one before dinner and somehow, magically, it was still warm after dinner and the crust lost none of its integrity.

1 star off because you never know when they'll be closed for vacation.
author: Amy N.

description:
My first visit to the Golden Gate Bakery was by accident.

After seeing a relatively long line into the store, I crossed the street and walked by. After seeing that people were purchasing sweets, I decided to stand in line. The person in front of me purchased four egg tarts.

After considering my options -- and because I could not decide over all the bakery goods -- I opted to try the egg tarts as well; I purchased two.

The egg tarts are excellent.

An egg tart is about $1 each.

I will return.
author: A B.

description: The egg custard tart here is DIVINE. Well worth the wait in the line that stretches down the block. The egg custard is silky smooth and subtly sweet, while the tart shell is perfectly buttery and flaky. SOOOO GOOD. Another reason why these tarts are so delicious is that they are almost always fresh out of the oven. It is impossible to hold one of these warm babies in your hand without the immediate and instantaneous urge to wolf it down.
author: Susanna W.

description:
Omigosh!  This place is simply awesome!!!  I've always heard people talking about this place but never really understood why until today.  G and I have been talking about their egg custard tarts for a while and I promised that I'll get him some since he broke his collarbone this past weekend while boarding.  So today with it being such a pretty day, I walked over to Golden Gate bakery and was super glad that it's only a short 5 minute walk from my work. :)  There wasn't really a line when I got there (I've heard horror stories of how long the lines could be!!) but there were definitely people there just to order the egg tarts.  

At $1.15 a pop, I was thinking to myself that these egg tarts better be made with some golden chicken egg or something..haha...but after I took the first bite into it, i was in heaven!! *ahhhhh*  The egg custard wasn't super sweet but it had the right consistency kinda like the boiled egg custard you can get for dessert in Hong Kong.  The crust was flakey and didn't fall apart like some of the other inexpensive bakeries. 

Overall, this is a place to go if you want yummy egg tarts!  Never just buy one, because you'll regret not getting another one.  This will be one of my other pick-me-uppers whenever I have a bad day at work. :)
author: Mina L.

description: whoot hoo! the best egg tarts ever. ever. i haven't had any like these. ever. !!!!
author: MB M.

description:
In one word:  Overhyped.

The best egg tart I've ever had was in Shanghai!

We waited about 45 minutes - 1 hour on a week day.  Granted, it was during Moon Cake Festival time so that might have been a reason we waited longer.  The line didn't seem very long but it still took 45 minutes!  I wonder how long it would have been if it had been a weekend!

The egg tart was ok but I was disappointed after reading the reviews that this was the best egg tart.  Their moon cakes are expensive, too!  I thought I got ripped off since I don't speak any Chinese but I found out mooncakes in general are expensive!
author: Joyce Y.

description: I sorta have this love and hate relationship with them. Hands down, they have the BEST, and i mean BESTEST egg tarts EVER!!! I really LOVE them for that. There's something in those egg tarts that's so delicious it's unexplainable! I don't know what they put in it but it's OFF THE EFFIN HOOK CRAZY GOOD!!! However...I do hate one thing about them...and I am sure there are others out there that feels the same way is that they are always on freakin vacation!!! For reals, how often do ppl there go on vacay is countless!!! It seems like they are only open 50% of the time in the entire year, if so! I have been tricked more than once paying parking in the Portsmouth Square just for a visit to them and they ended up being closed. BUT, as I had said before, we have this ongoing love & hate thing...so I will continue to put up with it b/c it's totally worth it!!! A tip next time for anyone thinking of going there is to roll by first to make sure they're open before looking for metered parking in the ever-busy Chinatown or paid parking.
author: Winnie L.

description: MmMm, those egg tarts are so good.  Gotta get them while their warm, and make sure you get two. One to satsify your intial craving, and the second cracing you get after you finish your first one.  This place has long lines depending on what time of the day, but its worth it.  Save yourself an extra trip and make sure to get a dozen to go.  My mom tells me the owners are from South America and makes their tarts with a portugual influence. Dunno if thats true but an Urban legend to why their so tasty
author: J Y.

description: I've hated egg tarts ever since I was a kid, but this bakery has me coming back time after time to buy dozens at a time! I hate those dense pie crust-y shells but theirs is flaky and chewy. The egg custard center also practically melts in your mouth. The best part is... five days later, when you try re-heating the egg tarts in your oven, it comes out the SAME HEAVENLY GOODNESS!!! Now that's magic.
author: Hannah S.

description: This is the only place in Chinatown with the line out the door, and there is good reason. One can imagine making a pilgrimage to this place solely for the perfect egg tarts. The crisp layers that constitute the crust are delicate and ethereal, while the egg custard filling is well balanced, between the sweet and rich, melded together in a perfect consistency. Best of all, they come warm from the oven, and with the busy turnover, probably just made not too long ago. I've had many many egg tarts, and these are nothing short of spectacular. The other items are also tasty, such as the sesame mochi. The egg tarts are the best by far. Be ware that this place will take weeks on end for vacation, so you may be greeted with a vacation sign.
author: Horace L.

description: This bakery, despite its lack of fanciness or pastel colors, makes the best egg tarts ("dan tat" in Chinese) EVER!!!!!!!!!!! Being a good Chinese girl, I've eaten my way through many throughout my lifetime and these are by far the best: creamy, soft egg custard center with flaky and slightly crunchy crust.  PERFECTION.  Be prepared to wait in line though; these $1.15/ea babies are popular!
author: Grace M.

description: All I see are photos of egg tarts... where are the freaking macaroons! These things deserve praise as they are on my "Must Have" list whenever I'm in the 'hood. Chewy on the inside and crispy on the outside, these coconuty treats are the bomb. I almost ate all dozen of them before arriving home to share with my boyfriend!
author: Nikki B.

description:
Best egg tart I've ever had.  It comes out of the oven still hot, moist, and flaky.  Even a few days later, it still tastest good.

I've never experienced a short line at this bakery.  The last time I was here, from the time I stood in line to the time I got my goodies, was at least an hour. The line is very long, but it's all worth it.
author: Anna T.

description: I don't like the line but their yummy egg custard tarts are the best in the world.  Can't find them that good anywhere else (I tried even in Hong Kong).  Will continue to put up with them.
author: Wing Y.

description: Excellent egg tarts and chicken pies. But prices are higher compare to most bakery (the size of the tart are bigger than the average tart) and be prepare to stand in line for half an hr. Workers doesn't speak much English and depending on who help you, it could go from good service to - I don't care if I loose you as a customer, there's a line waiting outside. But from what I remember, they usually say "thank you".
author: Phuong D.

description:
I say this place makes my most favorite egg tart. A lot of other places either: 
- add coloring to egg tarts making it orangy or neon yellow.
- have crust to filling ratio of 2:1, i.e. almost 1 inch thick crust all around
- add corn starch to the filling making it hard and gelatinous
This bakery does none of those, and has been _consistent_ at making authentic egg tarts for many years. The crust is thin and crispy; the filling is not too sweet and the right consistency. I am a happy customer every time I stop by. Their coconut macaroons, walnut pound cake, bbq pork puff pastry, and curry beef puff pastry are mighty delicious as well. Sure their prices are a tad more expensive, but they are worth it...you can taste the quality ingredients they put into their stuff.
The only reason I subtracted a star is that service isn't very efficient (hence the line out the door), and they are closed for MONTHS AT A TIME at least 2 times a year! Been disappointed sometimes when I have a craving, and then find they are on vacation. So go get 'em egg tarts when they're open!
author: V C.

description:
Lines ... always have a line.

Best egg tarts ....

they also make wonderful moon cakes during the autumn festival. I especially like the plain white lotus paste.
author: JayJay L.

description:
During a trip to SF, we were walking through Chinatown and we saw a line.  We decided to get behind it no matter what they were selling.  We asked a couple people in-line what the line was for and they mentioned that Golden Gate Bakery has the best Egg Custard in town.  

After a 45 minute wait, we bought the Egg Custard.  There are NO words to describe how good it was.  Delicious is an understatement.  It had a flaky crust with a soft not-too-sweet custard.  It was definitely worth the wait.  

*NOTE: While in line, you get to experience the recorder man.  While we were standing in line, I thought I was hearing things or maybe a band was playing.  After were enjoyed our Egg Custard, we walked past the ONE man making all that noise with his recorder..
author: Z C.

description:
The warm freshly baked egg custard tarts! I can scarf down two in a few seconds and my craving is statisfied. 

You can't miss this place when walking down grant street. there is always a decent sized line that filters into the small bakery. You'll find the asian customers and the tourists alike - all craving the same thing - egg custard tarts. 

other things are tasty, too. but the egg custards are what they are famous for... they are quite expensive - about $1.00 each, but so worth it... one thing - you must eat it right after you buy it... HOT! once it cools down it's really not the same!
author: kiko v.

description:
Egg custard has just the right amount of sweetness, and their coconut tart is probably the best I've ever had. 
I tried to stop by this evening to satisfy my craving for custard tart, but sadly they are in vacation until 8/23.
author: Lai T.

description:
So I'm the kind of person who sees a crowd of people in line and wonder, what's going on? Let me get in line too. Must be that Asia countries' consumer thing I learned where people get in line for something that's good. 

So I stumbled upon Golden Gate Bakery and sees a line. Ofcourse, I get into it. After checking out what everyone else is ordering, I get the egg tarts. It did taste pretty good but..a bit pricey. Oh well, you know what they, getting there is half the fun.
author: T H.

description: Really good egg tarts to die for! Like everyone says...they close whenever they want to....worst of all, they are too snobby and won't let me buy more than 1 dozen..even after I haggle with them over and over again! Left in frustration with just 1 dozen and couldn't even eat them myself b/c I promised to give them to coworkers =(
author: Mary T.

description: I heart Don Tots (egg custard in cantonese).  Who wouldn't love these perfectly made sweet egg custard treats in a flaky pastry crust?  These are to me, the chinese version of creme broule's!  I used to come here all the time when I was younger and hanging out in Chinatown with my cousins..  I used to buy these piping hot and use a spoon to scoop out the custard and not eat the crust.  As one grows up and tastes mature, I have learned to enjoy the crust as well haha.  Do yourself a favor the next time your in C-Town and treat yourself to one of these Don Tots.  You can't miss this place.. there's always a fat line of tourists and the storefront window has a chef boyardee on it.
author: Alan N.

description: Over rated. You can have the same quality of bakery elsewhere. Bad customer service. Not worth the long wait.
author: Sydney Y.

description: This place is AWESOME.  Typical hole in the wall Chinese bakery with long lines and half the store is the display case...but the egg tarts are sooooo good.  Warm flaky crust and perfect sweetness to the egg custard in the middle...I personally think it tastes just as good cold and trust me I have eaten many cold because whenever my roommate goes she gets a dozen and we eat it for a couple of days.  I love this place...but I'm sad they go on vacation for weeks...because when I get excited I want instant egg tart gratification!
author: Leah H.

description:
Their egg custard is THE BEST I've ever tasted!!  The didn't know about this place but passed by and saw the long line and realized there was something special, as there are so may other bakeries in Chinatown.  Got in line and figured out what everyone was ordering. The ladies in front of us spent close to $90 in bakery goods and I was pretty much in disbelief.  Only after the first taste did I understand the treasure I'd found!!
 
 I just went to Hong Kong 2 months ago and even their most famous dan tat place wasn't as good. 

We're headed up to Napa the end of the month and I purposely made reservations to stay one night in S.F. to pick up some more egg custard tarts from here...no joke!!  Besides the egg custard (best to eat them when they are fresh & warm), I also love the Old Wives Cake.  By the way, I really won't eat these two things....ONLY from this place!
author: OCgirl H.

description: Must have in San Francisco Chinatown.  Could be considered the best chinese bakery in the city.  Ive been to this place all my life, i even remember when my parents took me here after pre-school to eat and drink vitasoy.  The portions are small, they are a bit pricey, and there is a long line.  BUT it is all worth it when you order the egg tarts.  Simply the best.
author: Derek L.

description: I love this place! The egg tarts are most likely the best in the world. I'm not a big fan of egg tarts, but these are just too delicious! They taste best out of the oven but are usually served warm. The flaky and buttery crust and the creamy and firm consistency of the custard is unmatched elsewhere. Skip the 50 cent egg tarts from other bakeries; they are all a disappointment compared to the ones they serve here for albeit, triple the price. I also found the beef curry pastries to be very good if you are looking for something savory. Service here is relatively quick for the constant stream of customers.  I found the people who work there to be friendly. Bring cash.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Egg Custard hot out of the oven is the reason to stand in line. Listening to the busy counter ladies yelling at customers in Cantonese is just good fun. The macaroons are also worth trying, they are smaller than most places make them; but they are good - always crispy on the outside and gooey in the middle. 

They sometimes close the whole shop for a month for vacation at odd times of the year.
author: Brian C.

description:
5 star for egg tarts
0 star for horrible service (service with no smile).  Closed every year for several months

Here's a secret nobody wants to know.  I know the people who lived in the apartment above the bakery.  They hate it when the bakery is closed.....not because they missed the food but because the rats (as big as kittens) would scale the walls and enter the apartments looking for food.   

They only have one good item here and it's their egg tart.  There are alway a long line at this place and everything else here is ordinary and over-priced.  Skip everything else!
author: L C.

description:
WOW! These egg custard tarts are delicious! I had it while it was cold and it was still super delicious! I can't wait to try it when it comes straight out of the oven. 

I took off one star because it is a bit pricey for just an egg custard tart.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Good G-d!

Tell you the truth, I never knew that chineeze can bake that good.
That's a dont-miss place when you at the Grant St.. Red and yellow bean cakes are bombing! Egg custard are smashing and moon cake is a big yum!
Never dissapointed.

TIP: if you take out their pork or bean buns, warm those up in microwave to the fullest joy.
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: Let me tell you - that long ass walk on a hot ass day up to Golden Gate Bakery for those egg tarts was worth it. I was tempted to stop at the many other bakeries along the away instead, but this place was delicious.
author: Susan K.

description: Five stars because this place has hands down, the BEST EGG TARTS EVER!!! I ate four in a day because they were so darn good and I'm still thinking about it two days later. Previously, the best egg tart I've ever had is at the KFC in Taiwan, now it's at the Golden Gate Bakery. The tarts are pretty big, super soft and soooooooooo tasty! *droooooooool* can't wait to go back.
author: Susan L.

description: Stumbled on this place while wondering around on a rainy night. We went around 4pm so it was not super crowded. Amazing everything! We had a BBQ pork bun, coconut tart and lemon roll slice. I highly recommend stopping here for a mid day snack. :)  Also, it would be a great place to pick up some treats to bring to a dinner party.
author: Laurie A.

description: 4.5 Stars. Good egg tarts, Probably would've been better If i had them straight away but even after a day they were probably the best egg tarts I had in my time in the US. Line was relatively short when I was there and I was in and out pretty quickly. Good for the price but not the best I've had.
author: Kevin T.

description: this is the best place ever to buy egg custard tarts. If you ever come here you will always notice theirs a line out the door. It's the best one i ever tasted. Even though the price is high it is well worth the wait.
author: TC C.

description: Sometimes there is a reason a place has a line out the door all day long. This is flat out the best bakery in Chinatown. The crust on the custard tarts is flaky and the custard melts in your mouth. Red bean cakes are awesome. It's worth the wait, just have your mind made up when you get to the counter or they will pass you by.
author: Gary W.

description: This is my new "crack" and the top of the mountain for egg-custard  tarts (tan tat). I have never been here without a line out the door. The custard is the perfect combination of richness and sweetness. The pastry is buttery and flaky. An absolute masterpece! They come straight out from the oven piping hot. When I go, I order a dozen and eat 4 before I get back to the chinatown underground parking lot. This place actually ruined it for other egg custard tarts for me because nothing even comes close. A definte must go!
author: C C.

description:
The absolute, very best egg custard tarts in the SF Bay Area. Once you take a bite, you'll forget about the long line that you had to wait in, the hand-to-hand combat with the little old Chinese ladies who want to cut in front of you, and the surly mean people working there. :)

--W
author: Warren T.

description: Good lord the egg tarts are yumdidly! The other baked goods are yummy as well, of course. The oddest thing though, the ladies have a tendency to speak to me in Mandarin. I wouldn't think this odd, but I'm quite certain they speak Cantonese, Toisan, and English as well. I've been here 10+ times, and about 7 out of 10 times, the ladies respond to me in Mandarin, all the while speaking English to the fool behind me....interesting.
author: Judy H.

description:
I'm very picky about egg custards. I grew up eating egg custards, and my mom makes it every other weekend at home.

But I'd have to say, these egg custards are really not bad, and how its warm when you buy it - it tastes like you're eating it straight from the oven.  The other pastries are mediocre though. Minus one star.

ALSO, the lines are just RIDICULOUSLY LONG. Hence, another minus star.
author: Daphne L.

description: this place has been in business for years. and i get the same thing every single time i'm in chinatown.. the egg custart tart (dan tat) and their coconut tart( Yeh tat) are my two favs! i have to admit, it's about the crisp to the egg custard.. it's so flaky and true it is oily but as long as you don't eat it all the time, you'll be fine, just drink a cup a tea afterwards. i take all my non chinese friends here and they love it.. their wife cakes are good too but they are semi expensive compared to other chinese bakeries.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Ok, it's the egg tarts that everyone is talking about. Yes they are good, very, very buttery and flaky.  Personally, I think they're too rich and would prefer smaller ones.  It's expensive -- gotta shell out $1 a pop.  I actually prefer the small egg tarts at Flower Loundge.

An even better item is the French bun that they only make on weekend. It was unbelievable, light airy and I was sorry that I only bought two of them.  The coconut milk bun is ok--not enough filling, I think.  Best time to go is late in the afternoon--lines are shorter then.

So, is this place mind-blowing enough for me to shell out the dough, stand in line and get it...not quite for me.  But it's stilll good.
author: Nancy H.

description:
This is the best Chinese bakery that I know of.  Everything here is great.  The egg custards are to die for.  You have to eat them when they are hot so you can take the crispy flakes and the warm, sweet custard.  You should also order the cocktail bun.  It is your typical bun with yellow bean inside.  A great morning snack.

Be warned, you will be waiting in line if you come on the weekends.  Also, there are periods during the year in which they close for a month (my guess is that they make so much business they can afford to close for a month/twice in a year).  My guess is they close after Chinese New Years and after the Moon Festival. 

Oh yeah, CASH ONLY!!!  And if you are like me who is non-Chinese, please have patiences...  The custards are worth it!
author: Mike D.

description:
The warm egg custard tarts are delicious. At $1.10, they are quite expensive, compared to the other bakeries in the area. But there is always a line, no matter what time of the day. 

The other baked goods are.... ok. I would just stick with the warm egg custard tarts.
author: R H.

description:
Howzit!?
The Egg Custard Tart is excellent. No one in California can make it better. Very flaky crust with good aroma. The consistency of the custard is perfect, not too hard, not too watery, just right. No wonder there is always a line. I would highly recommend eating it while it's hot (Just don't burn yourself). If you have to take it home, preheat the toaster oven 275 degrees and heat it for 10 min. Its taste is like 90% of the freshly baked ones. Well worth the wait. Other baked goods are just average, nothing special. Also, prepare a lot of quarters for parking on the street. A must visit in SF Chinatown.
author: Keola C.

description:
The lines were out the door so we had to check it out. Most of the labels were in Chinese so we just did a lot of pointing and imagining what things were. After much looking and listening to what other people were buying, it seemed that the egg custard and/or the mooncakes were the way to go. 

We ended up getting both the custard and the lotus bean mooncake...It was so good.. All I can say that the lines are there for a reason.

Will be back for more egg custard (and will try not to think about all the butter that goes into that flaky crust) and to try the other stuff. There were some sesame balls that were looking really good...
author: Tom L.

description:
so if there's one thing that i feel knowledgeable about, it's freakin' egg tarts. i grew up eating and loving eggs (in the forms of fried eggs, hard boiled, steamed egg, egg w/ tomato, egg w/ spam, etc), and egg tarts are my go-to item in any chinese bakery. definitely got wrapped up in the egg custard king cafe craze (i'm talking about them egg white and flavored kinds) in new york city, and i'm glad golden gate bakery rivals some of that deliciousness on the west coast.

the price is higher than most in new york city, but the egg tarts are also bigger. the custard is a bit runny, which is exactly how i like them!!! sometimes i think they could be sweeter, but they still hit the spot.

only nuisance: you really gotta call them up before you head over b/c they are closed at hella random times. i've made multiple trips to the bakery only to find out it's closed :( i really wanted to show my mom what this is about when she visited!!! i guess waiting on line can be a nuisance too, but i'm okay w/ that. i'm not mad that so many people love egg tarts. :D

i haven't been around that long but this is the most promising egg tarts i've seen around the bay area :)
author: Toby W.

description: These ARE the best egg tarts.  If you're willing to put up with a line (it's like the 'Sprinkles Cupcakes' of egg tart bakeries), it's worth the wait.
author: Maile T.

description: I've been coming here since I was a child and my mom has become friends with the ladies who work here. I know everyone gives mad props for their Dan Tat (egg tarts), but I am also a huge fan of their moon cakes and almond cookies. I always crave their almond cookies-- I wish I could always have a pack to snack on. Their moon cakes are highly coveted by my parents as well. I particularly like the lotus been filling in their moon cakes. I wish the line weren't so long, but I guess that just proves how delicious everything is!
author: Angela L.

description: The best egg tarts in the city, hands down.  Go and expect a line because that is just how good they are!
author: C L.

description: They say the best things in life are worth waiting for!!! I just discovered one of them. :-) It's the best egg tart my mouth has ever tasted!!! The mile long line is worth the wait...I have even been as far as to hong kong and this still beats them all! Thinking about the egg tart is making me drool.
author: Haiyun P.

description: Hands down the best egg custard I've ever tasted in my life.  There is no way anywhere else has them beat!  I can't stand too eggy of an egg custard and they do a perfect job with making it just right.  The flaky crust is so yummy!  Make sure it is fresh out of the oven because it's not nearly as good when it's not warm.  If it means waiting a little longer, do it.  My coworker and I stop by here at least once a week to get the custard.  Mmmhh!
author: Jessica T.

description: no doubt about it, best egg custards ever!!!!!! their white sugar cake is pretty good as well, there's always a line, but def worth the wait
author: Jason L.

description: I wish I lived closer to Golden Gate Bakery just so I could have their egg tarts all the time.  Their egg tarts are Portugese style and have a flaky puff pastry tart crust that just makes you all sorts of happy.  Get them when they're fresh out, and your taste buds will thank you.  I was hoping to bring family from out-of-town to the bakery, but sadly they were on vacation that weekend.  Sometimes, it's hard to believe the world still goes on while egg tarts are vacationing.  ...Next time?
author: Alice Y.

description: The fresh egg tarts are amazing, particularly when eaten right away. Minus one star because of the frequent vacations. The sign on the door simply says "Vacation." They could at least specify the dates that they'll be closed!  I tried going today and they were on vacation. My last attempt (2 months ago) also ended the same way. =(
author: Paul I.

description:
DON TAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 

Oh yea...
Some of the yelpers has been complaining about the mean people that work there... They are super nice to me, it must be because I'm a sexy Chinese boy. I think they are only mean to ugly people, sorry.
author: Mojo L.

description: Never got anything else but the dan tat!  And you HAVE to eat it fresh! It is delicious and flaky and waarrrmmmm!  I only had to wait about 30 seconds on a weekday afternoon.  30-seconds to egg custard tart heaven :)
author: Valerie Y.

description: love this place although they are closed a lot due to vacation. the egg tart literally melts in your mouth. the sesame balls are crispy too. its delicous and reasonabley priced.
author: Tao Tao W.

description: They are my favorite egg tarts. I also don't like eggs, but I will eat an egg tart.  I'm not sure what they do to it?  The crust is awesome, the custard isn't too sweet, doesn't taste too artificial, isn't too watered down and the texture was perfect!  I don't need to review this place to let you know that it's good.  The ratings and number of reviews can stand on it's own
author: Deanna L.

description: The best...ever!! I burned my tongue eating their egg custard because I couldn't wait any longer...but it was worth it!!
author: Jonathan T.

description:
WARNING -- THE EGG CUSTARD NAZI WORKS HERE!!!!

I'm not trying to deny the fact that they have good egg custard.  In fact, that's the only reason why this place gets a 2-star instead of a 1-star.  I would have given this place a 4-star if it weren't for the fact that I literally got yelled at for asking for something other than their freakin egg custards.  

Here was the situation: Friday morning at 9:08AM, I just walked into the store and since it was early, there wasn't the usual 30 min line outside their door.
Me: Do you guys have banana cake?
Nazi: It's too early, we don't make it this early
Me thinking: ??? 9AM is early for bakery???
Me: oh, ok, do you guys have pineapple buns then?
Nazi: No! It's too early! We only have egg custards now! (she was saying this in a very Nazi way.  If you have limited imagination, refer to the Soup Nazi episode of Seinfiled)
Me: oh..? Only egg custard?
Nazi, irritated and glaring at me at this time: ONLY EGG CUSTARDS?!?! You should be very lucky we have egg custards this early! I don't know what you're complaining about....(she turns away from me and mumbles to the other Nazis in the store, mostly about how ungracious and unappreciative I was because I asked for something other than the custards)

I'm a 100% full bred Chinese, born and raised in China.  Naturally, I do not expect service from restaurants, bakeries, etc.  However, to be yelled at for asking for more than a custard at a freakin bakery?!?!?  For god sake you're a bakery!!!  Now I know you're a lazy one too!!!  Yelpers, if you're willing to put up with the verbal abuse from the Nazis here, you'll get your overpriced egg custards in the usual 30 min wait.  Try Washington Bakery, it's on Kearny and Washington.
author: CalBear H.

description:
See the long lines going out the door?  That should be enough of a statement in itself about the Golden Gate Bakery. 
No other bakery can match up-- and don't get me started on the dan tat (egg custard)! The other stuff is good, too.
author: Solomon C.

description:
Yummerz!
* The best egg tarts in town
* Fresh out of the oven steaming hot
* Make sure to buy one to eat soon and one for tomorrow
* Definitely worth the wait (take turns with friends in line and chat with Kenny or John as they pour samples of tea at the shop across the way next door to WaMu)
author: susan f.

description:
As everyone says, the EGG TARTS are the best  not only in the Bay Area but also in the multiple other Chinatowns we have had egg tarts. Mom always stands in line to get a box when in Chinatown.

I like it that the crust is flaky and rich and the right ratio to the not-too-rich custard. A too-rich custard would throw off the balance. 

Only place to beat is in Hong Kong.................where I have fond memories of standing in line at *2 AM* for fresh-out-of-the-oven egg tarts.  Yes, people in Hong Kong take their food seriously.
author: L C.

description:
Yep, the custard tarts are pretty damn fine. I am eating one right now, and even after sitting around for a day and being zapped in the micro, it is excellent. The fine flakey crust is the best part. Also had a White Lotus Paste Moon Cake which was great - and pretty to look at for the few minutes it lasted. Tastes like peanut butter inside!

I was less impressed with the BBQ pork roll and curry beef bun I had. Just kind of "eh" and I've had bigger and better at other dim sum places. I was kind of craving the big round fluffy pork bun, but this place has weird little rolls with the orange crustiness on top. Not as good.

I'd say, if you are looking for savory dum sum this is not the place to go - they definitely seem to have more and better sweets than savories. And it's a little pricey by dim sum standards too - around $10 for the 4 items named above. I like paying for my dimsum in money that jingles.

So, my ultimate judgement is that I would return for the custard tarts and moon cakes as a treat, but would probably keep looking for cheaper and more satisfying lunch tidbits.

(PS - Hardly a line at noon on a Friday. And service was pleasant.)
author: Caitlin H.

description:
As most of you already know, Golden Gate Bakery has the best egg custard tarts. The custard tarts have a yummy flakey crust so you know they don't skimp on their ingredients. I've had some of the other baked goods here. My mom loves the baked buns that they have on the weekends. I don't know the English name for them but they're only available on the weekends. The almonds cookies and macaroons are great.

We made a trip to Chinatown to get some egg tarts today but sadly they were closed for vacation. They're probably preparing mooncakes. Did I also mention their mooncakes are pretty good too?

There's usually a line on the weekends but they're definitely worth the wait. Check out all the goodies while you're in line.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Best egg tarts?  Yes.  Most unfriendly, unwelcoming and scary attitude of any restaurant I've been to?  Unfortunately, yes.  Don't try to strike any small talk with them especially if you're kiddingly saying that their egg tarts are expensive (they are not really).  They take this the wrong way, throw the bag of egg tarts at you and tell you that you have the option of purchasing them.  (They could have said instead nicely that their egg tarts are really delicious and that the price of ingredients have increased.)

I suppose when you're the queens of the egg tarts in Chinatown, you can pretty much be that defensive about your product.  Good for them.

Well, I guess most people don't go their for their smiling faces, so this may not matter all that much.

Good luck.
author: Rosa R.

description: Outstanding egg tarts, the lines are long but worth the wait because of the quality you're getting.  This place knocks it out of the ballpark.  But if you are a tourist and planning to go make sure you call ahead for business hours, there have been a few times where the store has closed without much explanation on the sign as to when they will reopen after their vacation.  As you can see though, it hasn't stopped me from going back there again and again.
author: Peachie Y.

description: The egg custards are among the best I've ever had. I'll give them that. Just one complaint... when the f*ck is this place ever open?!?! My friend and I are seriously 1 for 10 at this place... I can't even tell you how many times our hearts have sanked after treking thru chinatown to hit up golden gate bakery only to find the lights dimmed and the doors locked... I even got yelled at by an old lady inside after I tried knocking on their door.. post a "be back in..." sign or something....
author: Grant L.

description:
Golden gate bakery has the best egg tarts in the city. 
The egg tarts have a light, flaky crust
The egg filling is fresh, lightly sweetened, and whipped perfectly.
When warm, it's simply heavenly. 

Expect to...
1.) wait in line
2.) pay almost double the price for an egg tart at other chinatown bakeries
3.) be extremely satisfied
4.) experience intense cravings for more 
5.) return soon
author: Kelsie L.

description: After living in SF for 13 years, I tried this famous egg tart for the first time today. I'm not too sure if the product stands up to the hype that is created around this place. It really wasn't THAT great. The custard was mediocre, I found it lacking in flavor. And although I read reviews from other yelpers that say the crust was flaky, mine wasn't that day.....it was hard. Maybe I got a bad one in the batch. But it has failed to impress me. However, I will say that the price reflects the size rather than quality. It is a bigger egg tart than they give at most places I've tried. It was average just in taste and presentation. I believe this place is really a tourist trap since it's on Grant where all the other tourist shops are.
author: Crystal C.

description:
4.5 to 5 stars for their egg tart, but 0 for their horrendous service!  Their egg tart consists of crispy wafers and the egg custard is so soft and fresh that it's almost like eating cream.  

As for the bad service, they will decide one day to close for 2 months without giving any heads up!  What kind of bakery does that??!!!  The kind that doesn't care about their customers who would go out of their way to get egg tarts, only to find out they're closed for 2 months!  You might think I'm don't like the egg tart enough to give them another chance, but here's the thing - I've given them 3 chances.  This actually happened to me 3 times!  

So even though they have the best egg tart in San Francisco or bay area (I've tried more than 20 places, the 2nd one doesn't even come close to Golden Gate Bakery), I will not go back there again, at least not for a very very long time (it's been more than 1.5 to 2 years since the last time I went there).  Just for their service alone is enough to remind me to keep protesting them.
author: Tom S.

description: the place looks good but i never get service here because i don't speak their language. i was in line but they skipped right over from the person in front of me to the person behind me. very disappointing service.
author: Kristine D.

description:
It is closed again for vacation with no reference as to when they will reopen... they sure take a lot of vacations here... and months at a time.  I guess the lines out the door when they are open is helping fund the vacation.

Very greasy egg custards as evidenced by the spots left on the bakery box... only good if eaten hot.  The other bakery items are also very good... but most people only get the egg tarts.
author: Eleanor C.

description: YUMMY! Came here and got a dozen! I love how creamy they are.. probably the best egg tarts I've ever had. You can tell a good egg tart by its color (it should be a very light yellow).
author: Alison L.

description:
This place is famous for their egg custard tarts. Although I do think they are very good, above average in fact, they are just not worth the price and waiting the line. I waited 20 minutes for them and they are charging $1.10 each, which I personally don't think it is worth it. I can go elsewhere in Chinatown that's cheaper and no line that's pretty damn good.

I don't like they are closed almost half of the year; they probably make so money that they don't care.
author: Kimberly N.

description: Need I say more?????  The best egg tart known to man kind.  Lines get long, and place is very small.  Eat it hot and fresh cuz it's not the same when cooled down.  I got greedy and left with 3 dozen on the drive back.  Although we finished it all we couldn't help that the cooler it gets the less tasty it gets.
author: Scott B.

description: I really heart Portuguese-style egg tarts, as found in Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan.  From all that I'd heard about this place, I thought I'd be coming face to face with the delicious burnt-top egg tarts of my youth in Asia.  Sadly, not the case.  Delicious egg tart, but not the best I've ever had (by a long shot!).  My recommendation: the next time you're at dimsum and see a fresh batch (a really fresh batch!) of egg tarts rolling by, grab one of those.  Really, the same thing.
author: Cathy H.

description: I've lived in SF my entire life and I think my dad has been buying me Golden Gate Bakery egg tart since i can remember, but I don' t think I've ever had one that was fresh out of the oven till this past weekend. The egg tart gave me the melt in your mouth kind of feeling.
author: Angela T.

description: Yes, the egg tarts are great. But even better than the egg tarts are the coconut tarts! In fact, the combination of the two made for a great dinner! Yum yum!
author: Oxworth C.

description: Oh sweet eggy deliciousness! So warm, sweet and with a flaky crust! If you are strolling around Chinatown, and have a mid day craving for a snack, go here! It is worth the wait in line! Trust me, if you see locals lining up you know it has got to be good!
author: Ella V.

description: Visiting SF, heard that Golden Gate Bakery has the best egg custard tarts.  Went on a Tuesday morning and there were no lines.  Although the tarts were warm and fresh, I was not impressed. They are too big, and the crust is not the actual  "flaky" crust you would see in a Hong Kong egg tart. The filling has a good texture and moderately sweet flavor. Definitely not worth waiting in line for more than 10 minutes.
author: Winnie Y.

description: I didn't think I could find egg tarts in the US that could compare to the ones I've had in Hong Kong, but GG Bakery proved me wrong. Their egg tarts are SO ridiculously delicious! The perfect amount of flakiness to the crust, fluffiness to the filling, and well, egg-iness to the egg. I also ordered the wife cake (another favorite Chinese pastry of mine). Honestly, GG Bakery has excellent egg tarts but everything else is overpriced and so-so on the yumminess scale. Save the money and the wait, buy the wife cakes, sponge cakes, etc elsewhere.
author: Carrie W.

description:
"They're over a dollar each!" my mom exclaims.
"So?" I retort.
"That's EXPENSIVE!"
"So?  They're the best ones out there!"

And by golly the egg tarts (don tats as I'll lovingly refer to them) are.  So what that they're $1.15 each and we're currently in a recession?  So what that you have to trek all the way into the middle of Chinatown for one?  So what that you may find yourself crammed into very tight quarters for God knows how long, waiting for a fresh batch?  So what if they're not the healthiest thing for one to nosh on?  (Or, like the bf, eat for breakfast...especially more than one.  Just because they're made primarily of eggs does not constitute them as a breakfast staple).  I know I've said I'm a sucker for service, but we're talking about Chinatown here, so let's cut these workers some slack.  And in any case, WHO CARES?  As long as I am able to walk out of Golden Gate Bakery with one, two, or six don tats, I am one happy camper.  And I mean happy.

Yes, at $1.15 a pop, one of these bad boys is pretty steep (you can probably get one from any other bakery in Chinatown for fifty cents, but don't be fooled by other bakeries' low prices!  Save up your pocket change!  Scrounge around for all those coins you find in between your sofa cushions!), but well worth it.  "How good could a don tat be?" you ask?  There's not much for me to tell you except to TRY one, and you'll be instantly converted into a Golden Gate Bakery don tat lover.  Sorry.  I know that doesn't really help, but TRUST me.  The crust is so flakey and buttery, and the egg is so...delicious, I can't even describe it.  Splurge a little, people.  Fork over the $1.15 and you surely will not be disappointed (ironically, I have yet to try anything else from this joint, so I cannot speak for the other goods.  But then again, who cares?  All you need is a don tat!..or two or six...).
author: Mel T.

description:
yes, i stood in line.  and yes, it was worth it. 

buy more than you could possibly consume in a timely manner, because your husband/brother/mother/father/friend/cousin/neighbor/etc will nom nom nom the rest and then love you forever.

and don't just get the egg tarts, get the crunchy coconut tart too!
author: Shirley W.

description: Like everyone else has said they make the best egg custard tarts. The crust is light and flaky, while the custard is creamy and delicious. We spent our twenty minutes in line feverishly counting out how much cash we had between us and debating just which goodies and how many of them we planned on ordering. Ordering the egg custard tarts was a given, but we also bought a dozen macaroons which were crunchy on the outside and filled with tender sweet coconut on the inside, the apple roll which was delicious and sweet, and a loaf of walnut bread. If you haven't been to GG Bakery before go, their goodies are definitely worth the wait.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Best egg tarts here in Cali!  But if you ever go to Asia..you must try the Portuguese Egg Tarts from KFC in Asia!
author: Ames L.

description: This will be one of the reasons why I would drive to San Francisco, drive in crazy Chinatown, and pay for parking at the garage.  They have a product no one can deny!!   They sell the best Egg/Custard Tarlets ever!!  Yes the Chinese "don tas"  You know you made it when you have line of customers out the door of all different ethnicity's waiting to buy the tarlets by the dozens. I have seen lines of people waiting in the rain for them.  No one comes out of there without a box of these sweet, flaky, buttery, eggy, creamy, soft goodies.  They are always freshly made and everyone can not wait to dig into them.  You might need someone who speaks Cantonese to help place your order after all it is Chinatown and little Chinese ladies run the counter.  I come here when I have a craving for them and have not found a dim sum place to rival there egg/custard tarlets.  I love them!!
author: Donna Y.
Linda L.

description:
Delicious egg tarts - perfect texture on the inside, smooth, and not too sweet!  Not as big of a fan of the crust though, have had egg tarts from other places where the crusts were more flaky and light.  

Decided to try their mooncakes - white lotus with 1 egg yolk.  It was the first time I tried fresh baked mooncakes and I have to say that I will never buy the packaged mooncakes at the stores ever again!  

Tip:  Go there EARLY to avoid long lines especially on the weekends.  I stopped by on a Sunday morning around 9:30am and only had to wait  15 minutes!
author: foodcrazy d.

description: YES, agreed!  BEST egg custard tarts EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  The line is worth standing in.
author: Yi-Tzu K.

description:
All my life, I've lived about... fifty steps away from this place but I've never dared to step into this place because of the line (lines are terrifying) and how it kinda looks shady on the inside with all the boxes and stuff.

Today, my friend dragged me here and got some napoleon stuff. I was like, sure, gotta try the egg custard thing, I've had it about a million times, I bet the million-and-oneth time will be to die for. But being stereotypical and all, when I saw that an individual egg custard tart was over a dollar (you can get three for one dollar at other places) I kinda backed off. The ladies behind the counter and the other ladies pushing towards the counter kind of intimidated me too. In the end, I had one of those small, flute-like, white, doughy banana things.

One day I will gather all my courage and strike down the other people waiting in line with a bolt of lightning and buy the egg custard tart that I've been waiting all my life for.
author: Peyton L.

description: their egg custards are one of the best i've had. i've been here several times and there is always a line, but it isn't that bad. make sure you call them before you go there because they are on vacation like 3 months out of the year. my last time i tried coming i waited in line for over an hour because they kept running out of egg tarts so people were waiting for them to bake more. when i finally got inside the bakery, the person in front of me ordered 5 boxes full of egg tarts and he took the last batch. so they said it will take another 20 minutes to bake, i had to leave because i had to catch a flight in san jose in 45 min, i ended up missing my flight anyways so i should have just waited...
author: Gilbert G.

description: This shop used to be good.   But now its customers are switching to other bakery shops in SF because of two reasons: 1. it is often closed for multiple weeks.  2. it is very pricy.
author: K Z.

description:
update: there are no lines on the weekdays, and boo that they don't make everything they usually do on the weekends, so if you're looking for something in particular (ie. sponge cake!), hold out till the weekend.

the dan tahts are still FABULOUS any day of the week. YUM.

---------------------------------------------------------------------
only one thing to say - the egg tarts are FABULOUS.
sweet-tooth-craving-and-i-won't-stop-till-i-have-it FABULOUS. 

just kidding on the only one thing to say part though. :)

okay. so in order to make this really useful for y'all - i need to first and foremost teach you how to count in cantonese.

1 - Yat
2 - Yi
3 - Sam
4 - Sei
5 - Mm
6 - Look
7 - Chat
8 - Baat
9 - Gau
10 - Sap
11 - Sap Yat
12 - Sap Yi 

moving on - to get yourself some of these custards from heaven, this is what you say: 

"bey ngo sap yi dan taht!" - give me 12 egg tarts!

you can practice saying that while you wait in line staring at the very efficient service women inside. it's no bouchon bakery or tartine - this is chinatown people! expect speedy, curt, and loud service, and receive the MOST DELIGHTFUL egg tarts ever. 

ps. i am also a fan of the sponge cakes and coconut tarts. mmMmm.
author: Diana L.

description: Their famous egg custards are absolutely delectable. Tourists and locals often come here to get a taste of variety pastries. Especially chinese new year, people flocking all over the city to stock up their egg custard tarts. Dont buy a dozen, but 2 dozens. You'd get a red square box that they put together. if the ladies over the counter rush you to pay, make sure they dont charge you extra money. Take your time ask them to list out all items and prices. They often make mistakes and overcharge customers. It's hard to find parking anywhere around chinatown. Best thing to do is walk or take a bus. Also, there is a long waiting line to get your pastries. Be aware sum cantonese ppl try to cut in line. They think they could speak cantonese and get away with the long waiting line. Stop them!
author: Michael K.

description: There egg tarts are soo big and yummy! They are like the only thing that makes my family come to San Francisco. The last time we went here the line was super super long all the way out to the sidewalk and it was freezing, but no one minded because of how delicious it is. I think the best thing here are the egg tarts! The best, especially when they just make it, yummmy!
author: Cindy T.

description:
I was randomly wandering the streets of Chinatown one day (I work about 20 minutes away walking distance) when I saw a long line coming out of a small doorway. Curious, I gravitated towards the crowd, and found myself amidst a bunch of chinese people clamoring around a window display full of baked goods. I stood in line too (because I had a lot of time to kill and nothing to do). 
When I finally got to the front of the store, I found a display case full of almond cookies, egg tarts, mooncakes, and other yummy treats (which I didn't have much time to look at because the woman at the counter barked at me to order). I bought a few of the famous egg tarts (I heard an elderly couple in line discussing them) and some almond cookies for my mom (her fav). My treats was wrapped nicely and I was rushed out of the store by the hungry crowd behind me. 
When I finally got around to sampling my purchase, the cookies were still crisp and fresh, and the egg tart shell was perfectly flaky. I will definitely be back. The only minus about this place is that there is absolutely no English labels, so tourists may have a bit of a problem. But then again, you can always use your eyes and salivating mouth to help you decide.
author: Chang L.

description: You've got to be kidding me to give this place a bad review.  Everything is AMAZING.  I won't attempt to spell the Chinese names for things so I'll just say that the pork buns and egg custard tarts are my favorites-- especially when they're warm.  If Chinatown wasn't such a headache to navigate, I'd go here everyday and weigh 800 pounds.  And the women who run the store are perfectly nice, they're just busy and don't want you wasting their time with your "ums" and "what's thats?"  I'd advise you to figure out what you want before its your turn and then get out of the way and enjoy the deliciousness.
author: Kristin P.

description: Usually I won't ask for a bag for the egg tart, rather ask the staff to put it on a piece of wax paper...  it'll usually be gone within one minute before I finish walking a block!
author: Bkwm J.

description: I remember coming to this bakery when I was only 10 years old. At the time, egg custards were really popular for me. I had tried egg custards from the conventional dim sum trays that would come by from mayflower and dynasty. These ones were big, well balanced, and very crispy. It was very fine, and I remember we bought maybe 30 and it lasted us the whole week. They have hacao here too and it's not too bad. I remember when this place was still starting out the old lady kept yelling out HACAO HACAO like some dim sum vendor. Man good memories. Egg custard.
author: Su T.

description: EGG TART HEAVEN!! MUST TRY!! eat one then buy a dozen. Would of been 5 stars if there was no line  =)
author: Stanley T.

description: this is one of the occasions i thank the blackberry gods for blessing me with the yelp app that allowed me to find this place while i was wandering around confused in chinatown. otherwise i would have just walked by this place like i walked past all the other rundown looking stores in the area. this place is TINY and can get PACKED. but it's totally worth it. they are known for their egg tarts/custard/dan ta...whatever you want to call it...and they know it too so they are constantly popping them out. they sell mooncake even when it is not around mid autumn festival which you don't see very often. they have a few other things too, but you definitely go for the egg tarts!
author: Veronica L.

description: Great bakery. Been here for years and you can't buy consistency like this these days. Powering through that mindset. Please, for the love of whatever deity you believe in, STOP POSTING PICTURES OF THE GODDAMN EGG TARTS!!!!. The first picture entices you, the second compels you, the third one burns the image in my head of (insert Asian ethnicity here) ogling, taking pictures like they just discovered fire. At the very least take a picture of you enjoying it. I question the choices your parents made raising someone who would post a picture of something identical to what, according to this site, at least 400 OTHER PEOPLE POSTED. Are yours magic? Did they get retaliation on the 80 lbs Chinese woman who shoulder checked you as you took picture 601 of the egg tart? Cure cancer? If no, order your egg tart, eat your egg tart then move on with your life. Golden Gate Bakery your baking sorcery knows no bounds.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
Best Dan Ta in Bay Area?  Yes.

Significantly better than competition?  yes/no depending on the length of the line.

That sums it up.
author: Eric L.

description: What can I say that hasn't been said before? GO HERE FOR THE DAN TAT. NY, HK, LA....no other city has ones like these. Brave the lines. Get aggressive. You will not regret it!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I know my "dan tat" because frankly I've been eating them since I was 3.  Lived 5 minutes from Chinatown LA growing up and believe me I've eaten tons.  Tried all sorts and sizes of them.  In US, I would say this is one of the better places for egg custards.  

The long line that wraps around the door and along the wall is not there because the egg custards cost a ridiculous 5cents each.  You'll see why when you take your first bite of these egg custards.

My friend accidently left her bag of pastries and I drove home with them from SF to LA.  SCORE, I automatically told myself.  Boy, too bad for her because I was left with some GOODIES!  Tried the spongecake and some other pineapple flaky pastry.  Similiar to a napolean but with pineapple taste.  Thanks to her I got to try more than custards and discovered how wonderful they tasted even after 6 hours in my car.

Try going right before they close for a shorter line. You can call in first and ask if the batch is fresh and they will let you know prior.
author: Vivan K.

description: Delicious don-tot, fresh from the oven. The crust is perfect!
author: Ali A.

description: This is the best place to get egg custard tarts! You can see why by the long lines they have everyday....yesss EVERYDAY! except when they go on their LONG vacation in the summer. Wow closing the store for 1+ month ....imagine how well their business goes for them in order to have such a long break!
author: Tracy A.

description: Banana Rolls.  This is the only place I've seen them.  And lots of my friends never ate them because they are so preoccupied with the egg tarts.  I don't need to review the egg tarts...they are tried and true.  Banana Rolls, really.  Buy extras, bring them home and refrigerate them and eat them day old....even better because they harden a little.
author: Jenny K.

description: I LOVE their egg tarts!  I think they bake them fresh around 4 ish.  Usually there's a line in front of the bakery, so you can't really miss it.  There were times where they had to limit 1 - 2 egg tarts per person (that's how good they are!).  Not necessarily the cheapest - but definitely the best i've ever had.
author: MissJ J.

description: A friend of mine brought us up a dozen egg tarts for us.  Ahhh, the soft and tender, creme brulee like filling is heaven!!  it goes so well with the flaky shell.  just as good as fresh from the bakery after being toasted in the toaster oven.
author: Wendy L.

description: this the place to be if you want your hot and fresh egg tarts, i still remember back when it was little and used to live in chinatown... $1 you get 5... man those were the days then price went up to $1 for 3... now its like $1.25 each... just remember once you buy it, eat one right there... its hot and flaky...  i could eat 2-3 of them no problem, its never too sweet or bland... just perfect the way i wanted it... if you ever have extra to bring up, its going get cold... pop them in the oven 350 for few minutes and its good as it came out of the store...
author: JessePanda C.

description: Someone once mentioned this mysterious bakery that made the best egg custards, but had no clue what the name of the bakery was, or where it was generally located, except that it was in Chinatown. After hours of aimless walking through the small alleys of Chinatown, just as I was about to give up hope...i see a crowd of people standing outside a small store front. To my glee and excitement...there is was!!! Almost as a light shone down onto it, Golden Gate Bakery!! As I stood in line, my mouth watered. I got my dan-ta and bit in, I was too anxious, I burned my tongue a little, but oh it was worth it. So fresh and juicy with just the perfect amount of flavoring. I'm typically very picky about my egg custards, the consistency has to be perfect, not too hard or smooshy, the crust can't be too flaky or powdery.  I took another bite of the egg custard...it was heaven.
author: Kristina L.

description: Egg tarts and baked BBQ pork buns. Line up before I do because it is worth every penny.
author: Sean T.

description: Though I can't claim to be an expert on Chinese desserts and pastries, I did live in China for awhile and can vouch on "good" moon pies/cakes and treats. People who knew Chinatown well enough talked this place us as if it were the sun and the moon. Sure, it had a nice little selection and the food tasted OK, but at the end of the day, it is still a hole-in-the-wall with a long line, dirty glass displays, and slightly pricey items. I only ever recommend it when people ask where they can find Chinese desserts because it's easy to find (look for the line). Also, the usually close early on week nights.
author: Christyn K.

description: Game over. This is as good as it gets for Dan Tats (Egg Custards). Yes, there is a line. Yes, there is a wait. Yes, it's worth the wait. Buy some to go, but before you do, make sure you buy some to eat while it's fresh and hot!
author: Drew Y.

description: Line is always out the door but that never stopped me from getting my egg tart plus more. They've raised they price bu the tarts are still as as delicious. Flaky.. custardy..... (is that even a word?) yummy goodness. Damn I want one right now.
author: Juliane N.

description: I grew up driving about 1 hour to come here to get Egg Tarts and it is still the shizz compared to all the other bakeries and dim sum places in the bay. Always a line, but it goes by quickly b/c those old ladies that work there have been workin' it there as long as I can remember. Their wifey cookies (English translation of the Chinese word for these) are delicious with the flakey outer layer and just the right amount of crunch from almonds and winter melon pieces, but a little on the oily side. Make sure they are open, because I've made trips here during the summer and these people can take vacations for weeks. Yup, THAT ballin' from just their egg tarts!!
author: Tracy T.

description:
fresh warm egg tarts... i ONLY eat egg tarts from this bakery

also try the "wife cookies" filled with warm lotus paste. 

if i lived closer to this place i'd be so freakin' fat and poor because it's so expensive. about 95cents for an egg tart and $2.50 for a wife cookie. it's allllll so worth it though. beware of the long lines
author: Mei N.

description: Oh the warmth of the creamy, giggly, ooey gooey center, the golden, buttery, flaky crust... I just want to dive into the egg custard and swim in its goodness!!!
author: Havana H.

description: i'm not a big fan of egg tarts, but over here got me.. it was warm, custard-y goodness in my mouth. drool. ;P
author: Jenn L.

description: By far the best egg tarts in San Francisco, if not California. Getting one of these is definitely worth the wait. Dim sum restaurants don't eve come close to the quality compared to here.
author: Wesley C.

description: walked in here on a saturday, mid morning. two custard tarts, 1 black bean moon cake, 1 sesame black bean ball. All were freakin tasty. the crust on the tarts were super flaky and the filling was peeeerfect. more please..... pretty please....
author: Kahau M.

description: Don't get discouraged if there is a line, it moves fast and well worth it. Super delicious egg custard. I'll be back most definitely.
author: Nick Z.

description: Best egg tarts ever! They're very close to the ones I've had in hk. I always try to make a stop here whenever i'm in town. Supposely they're always a huge line, but if you go later in the afternoon you don't have to deal with the line.  They're always popping these babies out throughout the day, so you don't have to worry about getting the end of the day batch.  It's def a must eat!  Trust me, you'll thank me.
author: eileen h.

description: Long lines for super good egg tarts!! Reminds me of HK.
author: Michelle C.

description:
its crazy how people line up just for the pastries here and its insane how ppl pay close to a $1 an egg tart!!!!! yes i agree the egg tarts here are delicious piping hot from the stove but a bit over priced no?  i know other places like napoleon bakery who has the same qualities and cost a bit less than golden gate!   other than that, i know some of the pastries here are pretty good like the banana roll and the sponge cake etc.  i only come here when im ready to splurge. 

the long lines are way too inconvenient, and the fact that they close down the store 3 times a year for vacation is ridiculous!  be warned, call before you go other wise you might catch them when they're on vacation!
author: Shirley H.

description:
Yes.. most likely if you go here, the wait will be insane or they are most likely closed  (they have an odd scheduling for their days that they are open....usually just an odd sign on the door with a weird reason why they are not there). This isn't like every other Chinese establishment - always open.

HOWEVER, it still is the best DAN TA (egg tart) hands down..subtlely sweet egg custard filling inside a flaky crust of goodness (just don't tell me how much lard is in it and I'll be happy).
author: Jeannette L.

description: mini custard pies excellent....that's what they are known for....thick dense egg custard....sweet crusty delicous....custard puffs...custard tarts....baked goods behind a glass display....goods covered above...in plastic containers....treats along the side......baked goods madness.....
author: Hen A.

description: Yummy egg tarts!  I don't think $1.10 is too expensive, considering I've paid more for cupcakes!  One time after dim sum in the Sunset, my friend and I skipped dessert at the restaurant because we wanted to hold out for GGB egg tarts.  Imagine our dismay when we got there and the place was closed because they were on vacation!  I still get sad when I think about that day....
author: Lynnie P.

description: One of the best egg custard tarts around. Surpasses even the ones baked in Hong Kong. Delicious creamy custard blended with a  perfect flaky crust.  Best to eat when hot.
author: Isabella L.

description:
Just came here with a friend today and sometimes I heard that you need to wait for them to bake the egg custard, so before paying I politely ask if I need to wait.  In return the lady (bit chubby w/short hair) replied me in a rude attitude.  Well never buy from here again (PERIOD)

This place is overrated.  Many said their egg custard are way too excellent.  To me it's fine and good, but think of the long wait of the line.  Well I think most of the people who inline are not SF local resident.  Other than their egg custard those cookies aren't anything special.  Why everyone is overrating this place?  Plus their egg custard is over priced.
author: YELP U.

description: The best egg tarts (dan tat) in town are found in this little bakery.  They go for $1 here, while other places sell them for 50 - 60 cents.  But it's worth it...the crust is flaky and the egg custard the creamiest.  Usually, there's a line outside this place!  Be prepare to wait your turn.
author: Mick S.

description: The customer service here SUCKS/REEKS/HORRIBLE/RUDE. We came here and waited in line and the girl in front of us asked for a box for her egg tarts and not a bag. The lady who works there (probably the owner) yelled at her and then spoke in cantonese to her coworkers about her infront of her face. talk about rudeee and bad customer service! I felt so bad for the girl but i don't think they care because the shop does so well for their egg tarts. The line is always out of the door here. Anyways, I was helped by this old lady and she was so rude too. She asked me what I wanted and i told her my order and she shushed me before i could finish. =/ I was extremely turned off by her and the owner. I understand why people say this place is overated. They give such a bad ambience, vibe to their store and it makes their egg tarts less appetizing. however, based on the egg tarts, they are DELICIOUS and FLAKY. But, I don't think i would come back here for awhile, its just rude and unappreciative of their customers.
author: Julie Z.

description:
The #1 Place in San Francisco Chinatown for Egg Tarts or Egg Custards, otherwise known as "Dan Tat" in Chinese/Cantonese.  Both the locals from Chinatown and tourists from all over gather at this bakery to taste their delicious egg tarts.  Of course, if the locals come here, then you know there is something good about this establishment.

I recently was in San Francisco and decided to venture into another bakery that sold egg tarts (since most bakeries do), which was cheaper than Golden Gate Bakery.  It was about $.75 each, compared to Golden Gate Bakery's $1.25 price tag for each egg tart.  Unfortunately, their egg tart had a thick flaky crust, which made the warm to cold egg tart less than desirable.

I've then realized the secret to what makes Golden Gate Bakery the top place to go for egg tarts, and why people pay a premium for them:

1) Their Flaky Crust is thin (so you get more egg custard in each egg tart)
2) The Egg custard is cooked just right, and not overly sweet
3) Usually they are warm/hot since they sell them so fast they always have a fresh batch ready to sell

The combination of the 3 factors above, make for a wonderful experience when you first bite into the hot "just out of the oven" egg tart, causing it to melt in your mouth.  Hence, people eat their egg tart right away when they step outside of the Bakery, to enjoy the aforementioned experience.

Now you know why whenever you walk by Golden Gate Bakery, there is usually a line of people waiting to get in and people outside eating their just purchased egg tarts!
author: Edmund Y.

description: Egg tarts are like no other, very good.  Mochi weren't that good.
author: J W.

description: Simply the best egg custard EVER!  MMM mmm MMMMPH!!!  Just make sure you eat it as soon as possibly but not before it cools downs!  Or else you'll burn your mouth...take it from somebody who has no patience!
author: Lily L.

description: I have been coming here since 1996 and even though it's been 12 years, the recipe hasn't changed.  The bakery items are piping hot, the walkway is absurdly narrow, and because I am a white guy they typically don't understand a word I'm saying (we make it work)...but I leave with the most delectable egg tarts and sweet buns available in Chinatown.  Let me be clear -- you *will not* find a better Chinese bakery in Chinatown.
author: Jared W.

description: Best egg tart I've ever had.  All I need to say.  Lucky we went one night when there wasn't a line and got some fresh out of the oven.  Next day, there was a line out the door!
author: Cindy W.

description:
ahhhhh egg tarts holy crap 

soo goooood
author: M J.

description:
the best Dan Tat ever on this side of the Pacific Ocean.  they always come out piping hot from the oven due to the high turnover of Dan Tat sales this place has and never ever sits under a heat lamp or anything.  the crust is a lot flakier and less dry than other ordinary dan tats i've had and they're just pure magic in your mouth.  a little pricier than other dan tat places but well worth the premium

the only other egg tarts i feel that match up to GG Bakery's is probably the Po Tat(Portuguese Egg Tarts) i used to get on the streets of Macau.  but all other Dan Tats and Po Tats outside of these two places dont even compare
author: Tony L.

description:
Awesome bakery with really great baked goods

Would have given them a solid 4.5/5, except the server was a little irritated by my no knowing the items they have available - not everything is on display

Otherwise an awesome bakery - great Egg tarts and sesame balls with red bean paste inside
author: C Y.

description: zomg stop going on vacation every time i have a family gathering and need ~3 dozen egg tarts!
author: Alias A.

description: Small & sparse, but well-known for their egg tarts so I had to try 'em even if I don't normally eat 'em. People were bying them by the boxful. Tasted like typical egg tarts to me. I wanted to try some of their other stuff, but there was nothing left. The place was all emptied out!
author: Laurie c.

description: The best Egg Tarts in the whole entire universe!!! Eat them while they are still warm...once you eat the delicious flaky crust with yummy eggy custard, you will never forget!  Must love egg though...the egg flavor is very apparent; there has to be at least 2 eggs in each one!  You can get a dozen for less than 20$.  I always bring this back home to Mom whenever i get a chance.  Great little place in the middle of china town (cash only),  at least one of the workers speaks english...Long lines also form for Moon cakes around the holiday time...havent tried those in years though...but worth the wait, I'm sure!
author: j h.

description: Service is rushed and unfriendly but the little baked treasures that they serve are delicious!
author: Matt G.

description: As fellow yelpers have described, they're fans of the egg custard...  Luckily I just tried one.  At $1.15 for one or a dozen just above $13, it is good.  I got there at around 10am and there was no one in line surprisingly.  I usually walk through China Town and there is always a line.  Anyways, I got an egg custard and it was light, delicious, flaky and hot.  Pretty good!
author: Limzer L.

description:
The Dan Ta is okay because there aren't too many good ones around the bay area. Last time I went there, the service was horrible. I just want to know if the dan ta were hot or not. If they are hot(fresh), I would buy more. Otherwise, I would buy less. The Chinese lady(should be the boss) said she couldn't answer my question because there was no standard to estimate the temperature. It depends on different people. She told me to make up mind and then decide how many I wanted to buy. It doesn't matter if I was not going to buy any. I was extremely mad about her attitude. I left without buying anything.
I know a lot of people go for this bakery, so the boss doesn' t care about the customers. I would NEVER go to Golden Gate Bakery AGAIN.
author: Shao S.

description: Wow!!!!  I bow down to these dahn tots!!!  As an out of towner It was my first experience eating the dahn dots fresh from the oven.  The only other times I have tried the dahn tots were when my friend would bring these babies back to Chicago while she was visiting Cali.  And I must say even after a day they were still oh so tasty.  But the experience of waiting in line and eating them the minute we walked out of the bakery was fantastic.  We waited in line for about 45 minutes and then we made our way to the cramped little bakery.  You need to know what you are ordering since it is pure chaos once you get inside.  You can't blame them for trying to move the line as fast as they can.
author: Jane C.

description:
did you know that for the price of one egg custard tart here you can get THREE of them at another chinese bakery? oh well.

this place is crazy expensive and pretty damn good, so just go, mmkay? just be forewarned: there's almost always some sort of line outside. mooncakes are amazing. very tasty. & yes, the egg custard tarts are amazing too.
author: Betty T.

description:
Everyone writes about the egg tarts.   They're right.  Get them.

BUT

don't forget the sesame balls.   or the macaroons.  Stunning.

Baked pork buns are OK, but ideally skip the savory and head one block over to stockton street to the walk up dim sum places with the steamed ones.

Then do like the locals do.  We grab some Jasmine tea, then walk down to Jackson Square and sit quietly munching in the park.    Best. Sunday. ever.
author: Mel B.

description:
EGG TARTS! Toasty and light tasting on the outside, warm, rich, melt-in-your-mouth at the inside. Get the egg tarts, Thats all you need to get and know! We live in San Jose and my husband and I drive all the way purposely JUST to buy egg tarts and go home. Crazy right? Yet we do it all the time. We buy 2-3 dozens at a time because of the long drive. You can keep it in the fridge up to about 3 days. Just take out and put in toaster over to make it all fresh again.

However, you must try these fresh!! IOn busy weekends be prepared to stand in line for 45+ minutes. We usually drive up on weekdays to avoid that. I know they keep raising the price every year but think about it people, you pay so much more for American pastry. Even at the Anderson's bakery at the mall, you're pay triple+ . You have to try it for yourself. There are reasons why this place has so many review.

Keep in mind, service is bad. What service? there isn't any. You order your tarts and they shoo you away. Hey they are rude and people still come back. What does that tell you?

Other pastries here are just like anywhere else to me. But maybe some are a bit tastier? But overall the egg tarts stands out here. you can get your other pastries elsewhere if you want them cheaper but egg tarts must be from here. You'll never want an egg tart any where else again.

*oh yeah their mooncakes are good here too, made fresh.
author: Ailin N.

description: stopped by here for some mooncakes for the moonfestival! very friendly service, very yummy mooncakes!! i thought it was kind of expensive, but i've never bought mooncakes before either so i don't know whats normal.
author: Melody L.

description: This place is so good, the owners go on vacation for about 3-4 months out of the year.  Now, that is UNHEARD of in Chinese business management.  We open all days of the year...Christmas, Easter, Thanksgiving, and even Chinese New Year's.  We open when we're sick.  If our kids are sent home early from school, they're gittin' home by themselves cuz mommy and daddy aren't going to close up shop just to pick them up!  So the owners of Golden Gate Bakery MUST be making serious bank if they can afford to close for a few months in the year.
author: Liz C.
