description: Simply the BEST egg custard tarts in the city! Usually has a long line out the door and be careful of people who cut while you patiently wait in line. A bit expensive compared to other places, but they are soooo good. No other place compares to this one.
author: Linda C.

description: Visiting San Francisco, I spotted this 4.5 star shop with a long line of customers outside.  I had to try it!  First, their very famous egg tarts were beautiful and full of finely baked egg custard, however the crust could have been more flaky with extra layers. Next, the mooncakes had a beautiful mold and the saleslady said how "beautiful" or good quality they were. So my friend and I both got a box of four with the white lotus seed, two with one egg yolk, two without. They were on the expensive side, about $30 a box. But hey, when can I get fresh moon cakes from San Francisco? After arriving back home that night, we gave them a try.  We cut into the white lotus seed with one egg and saw specks ... of lotus seed? Then I bit into one and found a ginger slice, hmm, new creation? And the egg yolk was very tiny and salty, more like the ones used for jong instead of moon cakes. Overall, a bit disappointing. However, I tried again this morning, on a clean palate, and noticed some nuttiness, but it didn't taste like the delicate white lotus seed I have come to expect.  Overall, good for dim sum, but I think there's too much hype about their mooncakes.
author: Linda W.

description: Want to have the best custard tart EVER? Well, I'm not sure best ever, but it's pretty darn close! I just sampled this custard tart that had a flaky crust and filled with creamy custard. The line was long, but I don't mind waiting for great food! And GGB didn't disappoint.
author: K. F.

description: This is THE place to go for egg tarts. Best ever, hands down. You might have to wait like 30 minutes outside in line to get it but it's worth it. They also make mooncakes for Autumn Festival. I usually hate mooncakes but I like these. We always get the kinds with a bunch of random nuts in it. I'm taking off 1 star because you'll always wait, no matter what time of day it is.
author: Jenny T.

description:
yummy.. their egg tarts are the best... i came around moon festival and man, i was in line for about 30 mins next to all the grammys.. all 4 times before that when i came to this bakery they were out on vacation so no matter how long the wait i wanted myself some egg tarts

they are better than most bakeries.. its a lighter custard than most i've tasted.. just getting these made my day :D
author: KK M.

description: Egg tarts - totally worth it. The sponge cake has a hint of lemon which was also yummy. The bag of oatmeal cookies were good but nothing special.
author: Mary P.

description: This place has the best egg custard in San Francisco, especially when they're nice and warm out of the oven... yummm. The crust is perfectly flaky and the custard is just out of this world. The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is because the workers do not seem friendly and they charged me for a box because I didn't order 6... how the hell are you going to charge me for a box when a egg custard cost $1.15? I guess when you have the best egg custard, you can charge however much you like.
author: Michael T.

description: During my visit in San Francisco, my sister refrained me from ordering egg tarts at the Dim Sum restaurant we were eating at and volunteered to bring me to Golden Gate Bakery in China Town. We went there on a Saturday afternoon and the line was long. We got Egg Tarts, Coconut Macaroons and Mochi with Lotus Seed filling. Their Egg Tarts were ones of the best I've ever tasted: the crust was flaky and the filling was light and tasteful. The Macaroons were also yummy but the Mochis I could do without. Now I know why the bakery is also crowded with customers! It's worth a try if you haven't tried their pastries yet.
author: Jackie T.

description: Their famous egg custard tart and french bread is the best in town.  There's normally a line and they take vacation months at a time.  Don't pay attention to their store hours because they don't abide by it.  Their prices are way more expensive than any bakeries in the city.  The worst thing about this place is their service.  The worst I have experienced.
author: Mary L.

description:
$1.35 per egg tart.  get a dozen while you are here to share with your friends.  if you don't, then you are a bad friend.

the custard is the right consistency, and the crust is just flaky enough.  its everything you have dreamed of in an egg tart.  so dont fool yourself and be chinese and go elsewhere b/c its cheaper.  b/c yes it is cheaper, but you get what you pay for.

come to think of it, i havent ever gotten anything else here.  ever.  and my parents are from chinatown.
author: Jason J.

description: Best egg tarts in the city...hands down. Also, most expensive egg tarts in the city. If you want fresh, warm baked goods, here's the place to go. The highlight, of course, are egg tarts, so sweet and melt in your mouth. One thing to watch out for is that they do tend to close during popular tourist months just because they make so much money. You can't really beat this place though.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I heart egg tarts and get them everytime I have dimsum or find myself in a bakery that sells them.  These are not special.  Waiting in line for them makes them less special.  Waiting in line and then paying over a dollar each for them makes them even less special.  

To be fair, they are better than some restaurants but not so much better that I'd dish out the cash or the time to stand in line for.  They are also the big ones so the custard to crust ratio is just right.
author: Angie C.

description: This place gets 5 stars because of their egg custards.  Expensive for an egg custard, but definitely worth every penny.
author: Nancy L.

description:
It's so funny... I click to see the pictures for GGB, but most of them are pictures of the daan tats! but of course, what else is GGB all about?!

The line is no joke!!!!!!!!! but it is definitely worth the wait.  The Daan tats (egg tarts) has a warm, smushy, yummmmmmyyy filling, with a warm, crispy crust.  mMMmmMmmmmmmmmmmmmm 


*DROOLING*
author: Beck S.

description: With the Autumn Moon Festival just around the corner, its time to eat moon cakes again. I LOVE moon cakes!! And, Golden Gate Bakery makes the best moon cakes in San Francisco. I make a trip out there yearly for my moon cake fix. I stopped by today to pick up my box of pineapple & yolk, red bean paste & yolk, green tea & yolk, and lotus seed paste (2 yolks). Luckily the line was not too long. I had to wait about 1/2 hour but it was worth it. I would have also picked up one of their famous egg tarts today but they were waiting for a new batch to come out of the oven and I didn't want to wait any longer. I will go back some other time for an egg tart.
author: Lisa M.

description: The best "don tats" egg custard tarts, EVER. Eat them as soon as you get them and they're delicious. There's always a long line, but it's soooo worth it. They keep raising their prices, but I'll still pay.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
I've been here several times.  In my opinion, they have by far the best custard egg tarts.  The custard tastes good, but it's the flaky crust that sets it apart from others.  If you get them fresh from the oven, you'll understand why this place gets such great reviews.  Even reheating later (not recommended), the crust is still flaky.

I've had other items here, but the egg tarts are the only thing that I really go for.

Food: great
Service: good
Price: great

Overall, I would highly recommend this to anyone who likes dessert items.  A must-try for out of town visitors.
author: Bay Area T.

description:
wow what a line... 

so my friend had raved about these egg tarts and how I should just wait in line or just cut... cut? geeze hell no.. I don't speak chinese.. there is no way!!! so I waited.. the line went by really fast and it was great.. 

my order 
- sponge cake.. moist, yummy, the best!!
- egg tarts. I don't really like egg tarts but my friend and my ex liked it.
- chicken bun.. yummy yummy
- bbq pork bun - really good
- moon cake.. really good

I don't really like sweet things but it was pretty tasty.... the two I was with loved the desserts there, and I thought they were pretty good.. so they were hooked.. I just don't get hooked that easy......
author: Nina M.

description: Nothing like a warm dan tat from here on a rainy day. Yum! I remember the moon cakes from here tasting really good as well, though I don't know if that's the case anymore since I haven't had moon cakes in a long, long time. But wow, the dan tat, DEELISH! And follow that with a nice, piping hot cup of milk tea. Heavenly!
author: Audrey T.

description: Service is iffy. Depends on the auntie that's taking ur order. Prices are high relative to the other bakeries in Chinatown. Go during the wrong time and the bakery might be closed. Other than that, prepare to eat ur egg custard while waiting in line. Cuz it's the best when it's still hot. Try the macaroons. Better than any I've had in the past. This place is still a five star in my book. Always gotta help the mom n pop businesses especially when the stuff they make is that good.
author: Tsfo E.

description: My kindergarten teacher's family owns this bakery. Their egg tarts are good! Crust is really flaky, I always see a line of people lining up for them!   I wished they could be cheaper, but I guess it is worth it.
author: Janet Z.

description: Best egg tarts and cha-siu-bao.  They also make this cake with yellow cream filling, not sure what it's called but it taste hella good.  Some ppl said sometimes they over charge if you don't pay attention to how they calculate ( they do it by paper and pen).  Just kinda make a mental note on how much the total would be if you are buying a lot.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
It's almost criminal!! 

Here's why: 

1) We got to Golden Gate Bakery and there was NO LINE!!!!  
2) Got the egg tarts aka "Dan Tats" fresh from the oven!!
3) Tasted heavenly, warm crispy, flaky dough with the perfect egg, sweetness custard.

Mmm..Mmm...Good!!!
author: Ruby F.

description:
i'm not a big fan of their egg tarts (i actually despise flaky-crusted stuff), but i AM in love with this sponge cake with egg custard filling, that only they have (as far as i know).  i don't know what it's called in chinese, so i just point to it when i order and gesture with my hands.  try it!

everything is quality, but a little pricey.  their pineapple buns are amazingly small but tasty.  Napoleon's Bakery on Stockton is a better deal, huge portions, but not quite as yummy.
author: Jolene T.

description: This place is awesome! But since they are so awesome, they can choose when they close and were on vacation til 8/11. But no worries, I recall what the egg custards taste like so I am going to write my review. They are expensive in the world of Chinatown egg custards but for good reason! They are $2 but the size of them are much larger than the typical egg custard and they are served piping hot from the oven. People line up outside this store and come out with boxes and boxes of these custards. Hopefully they will be open when you want to go but do go try them, they are divine!
author: Vivian L.

description:
dan tats at $1.10 a piece, the line is still heading around the block. and yes, they are worth it.  i had to get some for chinese new year after dinner dessert.  30 minutes and $40 dollars later, i've gotten a couple boxes of happiness to share with the family.  

but i wish they'd hire a couple more ladies to help speed up the line. they know there are tons of people eyeing their food since its the day before chinese new year.  just a thought.

love this place and their 10000000 calorie dan tats.
author: Ames K.

description:
I'm basing this on my one day where we tried to get some famous egg tarts from this little shop of Chinese pastries, so take it for what you will.

On a Saturday, some friends and friend of friends were in town and heard about this famous Chinatown shop.  I've never heard of it to tell you the truth, but it's a tourist attraction from what I've heard.  And what they're famous for is their fresh baked egg tarts and I do love a good egg tart.  So we get there after lunch from Koi Palace (which some of us waited for about an hour already just for that) and there's a line going out the door from this place.  Probably no more than a shop length's line down the street, so it looked pretty manageable.  We were running short on time to make it to the Chihuly Exhibit at the DeYoung, so I left with others to try to score some tickets.  And unfortunately, we scored only disappointment, but we at least we had a consolation on getting some hot egg tarts.  About 30-45 minutes pass and our friends who were waiting at Golden Gate Bakery come empty handed.  They said it was ridiculous as they waited 30 minutes and the line didn't move one person... not ONE person according to them.

And that's not the end of the story.

They were persistent and determined that day, so they went back to the place before we went to eat dinner.  We ended up deciding to go to R&G Lounge since it was nearby and my friend and I went to get reservations as the others were waiting in line for at least an hour at Golden Gate Bakery.  Good thing, R&G had a bar, because I was drinking the time away as we waited another good hour there sipping my alcohol before I can't stand straight.  And finally, they make it with the goods.

I was starving and ripped the egg tart out of my friend's hand and ate the warm, flaky, custardy pastry.  It's definitely good and fresh (and it better be for that wait), but for 2 1/2 freaking hours for this... I don't know about that.  It's good, but not 2 1/2 hours good.  I was expecting to enter nirvana after eating this, but it did not quite happen that way.

I did hear the reason why it was so fraggin heck slow was that they had half their ovens making mooncakes that day and that slowed down their process, but from what I had, I don't see the huge hype that this place was given.  Maybe I'll try it again on a better day.
author: David Y.

description: Without a doubt the best asian bakery in Chinatown, or for that matter all of California.  Egg Tarts are amazing, but my favorite is the Wife's Cake, with little bits of winter melon and a flaky buttery crust.  The lines out the door are justified, so make sure to get there early and get them hot out of the oven.
author: Henry L.

description: Five stars for their egg tarts! I love gum moon dan tat!!!!
author: P C.

description: I've been coming here since I was little and the line has always been out the door. They have a large variety of yummy chinese pastries and baked goods - and by far the most delicious egg custard tarts fresh out of the oven!! But beware, I believe the egg custards contain lard. Haha. Aside from that, they are to die for!! They also have really good macaroons and other sweet treats. It's worth the trip, the standing in line, the money, and even the waiting!! YUMMMM!!
author: Rochelle F.

description: Tasted great... it's pretty much what you would expect from a slightly above average chinese bakery. Can't give it more than three stars because my partner found a giant staple in his pork roll. I know this should dissuade me from ever going back... but I would probably try it again. Honestly, as gross as it may be, it could happen in a lot of places.
author: Andrea S.

description: After trying several SF establishments, the best coconut buns ever to exist are baked at the Golden Gate Bakery.  And because the bakery does such a bumping business, nothing stands around for very long and you are guaranteed totally fresh if not warm from the oven treats.
author: Sharon R.

description: Yummy breads and pastries.  Just hate the long line.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
They do have the best egg tarts you will ever find in SF, but I do have to say that their customer service sucks! They tend to be pretty rude over the phone, which is why I'm giving this place 4 out of 5 stars. 

But I do love their egg tarts!
author: Cecilia L.

description: I really like the cha siu bao here.  It's a little salty, but the meat has more of the cha siu flavor to it.  The crust also has a light glaze on it.  Not to mention, I always run into other people from Hawaii here.
author: Kelvin K.

description: I love you! :D You're the best thing that ever came into my life yesterday. My boyfriend and I got a dozen like fattys we are! Theres still one lingering in my kitchen after my boyfriend and I ate some.... SOME. WE'RE NOT THAT FAT! It's expensive but who cares. When we were here, NO LINE ^__^ But the pass few times we tried going there was TWO lines.
author: Carolyn Y.

description: You have not eaten egg tarts until you've tried Golden Gate Bakery's egg tarts!  The line is always out the door so I rarely get the chance to drop by.  However, on this beautiful Saturday afternoon, the line was only one-store-over long.  How could I not wait??  I bought two egg tarts for $2.30.  Pretty overpriced for egg tarts but so worth it.  I bit into mine right away and no joke...there was still steam coming from it. The crust was still flaky and the egg part was perfectly made.  Also, try their sponge cake!  It's a nice treat if you don't like egg tarts.
author: Helen V.

description: Wait in line, no matter how long, as long as you come out with a hot custard tart.  Pay someone in the front of the line to buy you one that you can eat in line while you wait.
author: Diana R.

description: The egg tarts really are yummy...next time i'll try the other pastry but a dozen of egg tarts is a bit much for me to finish by myself!  they close at 8pm on fridays...dont bother calling, they never answer their phones, at least all the times i tried calling.  get the egg tarts, they delish!
author: Michael Y.

description: My only regret was not buying more when I had the chance! The best egg tart you're going to get anywhere! All the reviews here about the egg tarts being perfect are all true! My mate and I got here after our dimsum and we ate them right away by the street and despite the cold rain outside, the hot-out-of-oven tarts were such a bliss!! The egg custard was so smooth, fresh and satisfying omg i'm salivating just thinking about it - try you must!
author: BY S.

description: 5 stars for their portuguese egg tart. It is the only baked good item I think of when I think of Golden Gate Bakery.
author: quan q.

description: Why can't anyone replicate their egg tarts and lotus moon cakes?
author: Suz K.

description: I'll give Golden Gate Bakery 3 1/2 stars.  I'm a big egg tart fan, especially anything with egg.  I was really excited to try the best egg tarts in town.  We had to wait in line for 20 minutes.  When I finally got hold of my egg tart, I took a big bite, and it seemed like it was falling apart because it was so jiggly.  The mixture of the egg custard wasn't too sweet and had just enough milk.  But it was just too jiggly and soft.  I would like it to be more settled.  I did like the thin flaky crust though.  I've eaten a better egg tart, but too bad I can't remember where it was from.  That egg tart had a very buttery, flaky crust and a perfectly settled custard.
author: Cindy H.

description: Best Chinese bakery in town! I used to go there every year in September around the Mid-Autumn festival to fill up on mooncakes: they make the freshest and the best you will find in San Francisco. Be ready to fight the lines, and the chaos inside the bakery, but it's all worth it! They have a huge variety of mooncakes, but I tend to stick to the basics: I really like the lotus filling, as well as the red bean filling, but the pineapple and the nut mooncakes are also worth a try. All the mooncakes are available with one, two, or no egg yolks in the center (no a huge fan of the egg yolk version myself). They're not exactly cheap, but it's good to indulge once a year. Oh, and you should see all the Chinese grandmas' faces when I order there in mandarin... just precious!
author: David S.

description: WOW. Now this is what an egg tart is supposed to be like! The best egg tart I've ever had, and I don't even like egg tarts. The pastry crust is crisp and soft, the custard is sweet with a taste of egg. Awesome. It's kinda scary going into Chinatown, but this place is definitely worth going in to. You'll find it by the long line going out the door.
author: Jeanie C.

description: i was curious why there was a line with this bakery each time I went to chinatown in Sf, so i decided to try it out.  I ordered some egg tarts, some mochi like desserts, and some cocktail buns.  Well...I didn't find anything real special about the eggtarts or mochi, but the cocktail buns were absolutely the best.  I'll return to this bakery in the future, not for the raved eggtarts, but for the cocktail buns.  It is worth the wait in line.
author: Sweep J.

description:
best dan taats in chinatown, hands down. coconut tarts are also delicious and have the same flaky crust... yum...

they're open to 8pm most every day, so if you're roaming around chinatown late at night, it's worth a try. i've gone close to closing time and still managed to snag some warm, fresh baked dan taats, if you can believe that!
author: Andrey C.

description: This is one of the best egg custard tarts I had in the bay. there's usually a big line for this, but if you go a little late they still have it fresh and hot out of the oven. I love it! it's worth the wait if you are a huge fan for them. They are quite pricey but it's worth it for the taste. But I think there is too much egg sometimes because these are the size of your cupcakes. If I could, I would have these every other day!
author: Ann L.

description: Came here after eating some dim sum, got some egg custard.... nom nom nom
author: Tony D.

description:
i'm really not an egg tart fan.

most of the time, they just taste like...hrm.  if pure cholesterol had a taste, it'd taste like egg tart, just with sugar.

but golden gate bakery, their egg tarts are served with a warm, gooey filling, crispy and flaky crust.  think homemade cookies right out of the oven.  or beard papa's cream puffs.  or fresh creme brule.

i'm not an egg tart fan, but these are worth waiting in line for.

(oh, and their other treats are yummy too. try the sponge bread and the coconut pastry.)

dropped to 3 stars only because you have to stand next to the fake sunglasses hawker guy the whole time while you wait.  no, i don't want fake sunglasses.  no, i don't want the fake LV wallet.
author: brian w.

description: Good eggtart joint. I tell all the tourists that I know to come here to add to the 10 minute line. It's probably the best place I know off for eggtarts in the city. The kiosk selling fake sunglasses and louis vutton bag has some douchebag owners who think the bakery is affecting their business... anyhow, good eggtarts... Get 'em while they are hot.
author: Wil M.

description: Best custard tarts on the planet!  We also enjoy the moon cakes.
author: Debbie T.

description: I stopped by before flying back to Chicago. Luckily the line was not long. I picked up 6 tarts at $1.15 each. They were freshly baked making them so warm and flaky. I also bought 2 triangular layered sponge cakes for my brother. Less than 48 hours layer they are growing mold! I would advise against those.
author: Tina L.

description: The warm, just-out-of-the-oven egg custard tarts here can't be beat. It's worth dealing with the hassle of parking around Chinatown and getting past the throngs of tourists and feisty Chinese ladies (who, as many below noted, do try to cut in line). I should really branch out and try their pork buns and moon cakes, but as soon as I step in the door, I have eyes only for you, oh tasty egg custard tart.
author: Jen R.

description: I've been patronizing this bakery for awhile and been able to withstand their rush-rush service but after today, I will not patronize this bakery. I usually order their melon cake (which is the best in town) and was gonna order some. I asked the lady nicely to not give me the one that looked imperfect. I guess she was a little offended by my comment but she has no right to yell at me. Disgruntlely, she asked me which one I prefer so I pointed out the ones I wanted. When she got me the one I didn't ask for and I informed her, she started yelling at me. I told her that you asked which one I wanted so I told you. I also told her to learn to be polite as I am a customer! That naturally shut her up. Although this place has good pastries (pricey too), rude service will only ruin the taste!
author: Cuisine N.

description: The Dan-Tat is amazing here. I've been here on a number of occasions with friends and family. I've never been let down. The egg-custard tart (which is what they're most famous for) seems to be perfect everytime. Even their other pastry items seem to be made by high-quality pastry chefs in the back (that we never see...).
author: Jj H.

description: My absolute favorite chinese bakery in Chinatown.  This place has great egg custard tarts, coconut cream buns, and almond cookies.  I pretty much like everything here and it reminds me of my childhood. During peak  times this place does get busy and a queue starts outside the door.  Although I have never waited for more than 10 minutes.  I suppose it depends when you go.
author: Dbear T.

description:
I'm giving GG a five star only for the egg custard tart.  I think the mooncake from Eastern Bakery is much better than GG's, and GG's staff needs an attitude adjustment at times.

I grew up in SF, and the GG tart has not changed in over twenty years. I  live in NY now, and have not found a tart that even comes near to GG's.  The Portugese tart from NY's Egg Custard King is really good, but of a different style.

Back to GG's tart.  The tart's crust is always flaky, and for me, preferrable to the cookie crust. What really sets the GG tart apart from others is the filling. The custard is silky and just sweet and eggy enough.  Other custard tarts have fillings that are: so sweet that make my fillings tingle; taste of artificial flavors like honeydew; or have a mealy consistency.  The GG tart is expensive, but I willing to pay for it as it is what a tart should be: egg custard in flaky pastry.
author: Jeff H.

description: They have one of the best Egg Tarts (Dan Tat) that I have ever tasted in the Bay Area.  They even beat the best Dim Sum restaurants.  But for $1.10, the price is a little steep, but is well worth it.  Whenever you are in Chinatown, make sure you stop by this bakery, but make sure you have 20 minutes because you would need to stand in a long line that wraps around the corner sometimes.
author: Andrew N.

description: This place is well known for their egg custards. Everytime I come here, there's always a line with people waiting for the egg custard. If I'm lucky that day, then it's a short line. The egg custard taste very different from the ones that I've eaten. You just have to try one for yourself.
author: Linh N.

description: The best egg custards I've ever had!  They are to die for, especially when it's freshly made and still hot!  Definitely worth the wait in line!
author: Stacey L.

description: Wow! I absolutely love this place for the tasty bbq rolls. It was so good and flaky and the char siew was so aromatic. I love how you can taste the lil pieces of meat and not the mushed up goo that some places stuff their charsiew rols with. Their egg tarts were excellent too...the custard was nicely baked and soft and the vanilla essence made it so delish. This is definitely to be eaten right when it gets out of the oven and we were fortunate enough to get there when their fresh trays were just done. DING!
author: Topazskye L.

description:
Golden Gate Bakery is good, but not great like many people have reported. Take away the "best egg tart in the world" slogan and you've got yourself a regular Chinese bakery. It offers generally above average baked goods, but there isn't anything that is really exceptional about this place. 

I've had egg tarts, bbq pork buns, moon cakes, etc. from tons of places: Chinese farmer's markets, restaurants, bakeries and stores all over the place. This was just on par with everything else, so I can't quite grasp the fanaticism that surrounds this place.

Egg tarts: great crust, exactly how I like it: flaky, chewy and crispy all at the same time. The filling itself was a bit too pudding-like, but still good.

BBQ pork buns: they make the kind that have a hint of sherry or alcohol in it - the kind I don't like - so it wasn't my cup of tea. The filling is less dependent on sweet, thick and red bbq sauce, so I did enjoy that.

Moon cakes: This is one item that I absolutely love. Moon cakes can be too dry or too sweet when not properly prepared. This was fantastic. 

Service: It's a Chinese establishment, so it's efficiency over quality. I understand that so I had no qualms. I did love how all the old ladies started yelling, "no pictures!," and waving their arms in the air when some tourists tried to take a picture of the bakery. Hiding something?  ;)

Overall, above average but not the best in the world.
author: Farm S.

description: a line at a chinese bakery?  unheard of.  this place has the best egg tarts i've ever had.  i've been to nyc many times but no one compares to this place.  we were lucky and got them right when they came out of the oven.  FABULOUS!  it melts in your mouth and the crust was so crisp and flaky.  usually many places skimp out on the egg custard part but this place doesn't!
author: Andreal W.

description: Not much to say here about their egg custard.  But I do have to agree that they are quite expensive but with all these reviews and customers going, there's no reason the business doesn't charge more.  However, this time I also tried their banana cake (not too sure what it's called), but they're not up to par with those you find in HK. It doesn't have enough of the banana flavor.  Other than that, I was lucky to go in at round 1:30 on a weekday and find no lines.
author: Crystal L.

description:
three stars only?  but why??

1.  there is always a line.  once, i waited up to 30 minutes.
2.  this place has good egg tarts, yes.  but they sell them for $1.10 whereas at other places, they are $0.70.  that means they cost 57% more than other egg tarts, but they're not 57% better.  there are other places (with no lines) that are nearly as good.  (i just think their egg tarts are a tad over rated).
3.  have you tried anything else at this place??  the "pineapple buns" at al?  i can say one of the worst.  how can you run a place with only good egg tarts?
4.  everything in here is more expensive than everywhere else in chinatown.  i think this place is made to cater to white people (ie: let's rip them off for all they've got).  i bought 35$ worth of food here, and i could have gotten (better) baked goods for 15$ elsewhere.
author: H. L.

description: not really sure what the fuss is about with these daan taat. 1.15 for one? that's a bit pricey. the custard was really rich and not too sweet, which was good, but the crust was a bit too thin. flaky, yes, but really too thin to hold this thing together. you can get very similar quality stuff all around ctown, and for less $ and less of a wait. i guess it's good for tourists who don't really get much chinese cuisine, but really nothing to write home about.
author: Danny C.

description: This is the only place i get "dan tats" I refuse to eat them anywhere else! Especially when they come right out of the oven.. the crust is flakey and the custard is warm and gooey.. haha.. I also love the melon cakes? is that what you call them in english? I know the chinese name is "wife cookie."  Reason why I'm giving them 4 stars instead of 5 is because of their soaring prices!  95 cents for one dan tat and 2.50 for the melon cake! its crazy, i know but i still buy them.. beware of the long line, some chinese folks like to cut .. haha
author: JUDY L.

description: The Egg Tarts are Great, but the wait is pretty long!!  The place is pretty small and I have never been there when there was no line or very busy.  Overall a great bakery if you have the patience.
author: Rommel M.

description: What a great place to meet a couple of friends.  Even if ou are picky you can find something here.
author: John B.

description: I was lucky enough to buy fresh egg tarts from the oven this evening and they were absolutely heavenly!  It's a little pricey for an egg tart ($1.10 a pop) but the tarts are extremely large and tasty.
author: Helen B.

description: BEST fluffy Egg Tarts and crispy Sesame Balls in the Bay Area! Can't escape the long line but it goes fast, which also means be ready with your order. The ladies inside won't wait for you to dottle. $1.10 for an egg tart seems overpriced until you see that Beard Papa is charging $2.25 for a cream puff (@ Westfield's Shopping Center below Bloomingdale's). Golden Gate Bakery is only a block & a half to Columbus so walk on over to North Beach afterwards for your favorite coffee drink (may I suggest Caffe Puccini?)!
author: Sabi M.

description:
Well worth the 45-minute wait and another 45 minutes to get served inside the store for a dozen egg tarts.  Be prepared to fight hard to get the salespeople's attention.  There is no first come first served.  Be especially cautious of the little old Asian ladies who cut the line and demand immediate service.  It's true that the prices have gone up.  However, I think it went from $0.95 to $1.10 per pie.  Nothing to freak out about.

During mooncake season, it's crazy.  My favorites are mixed nuts and winter melon.  So worth the wait.
author: T. N.

description: If you're in chinatown and don't mind the long line. GGB has the best egg custard.  Especially, when it's fresh from the oven.
author: Nancy T.

description: I can never understand why this place has such a long line. Even with the kind of pathetic service that you get. Almost anyone I know agrees that the service sucks. It used to be the only place to find the best egg tart. But not anymore. Many other places sell egg tarts that are just as good. Furthermore I started liking portugese egg tart instead which they do not have.
author: Elaine T.

description: Long lines ALMOST make this place a joke, however, when the rude ladies hand you an egg tart fresh from the oven and your burn your tongue on it I'll ask you who's laughing now?
author: Po L.

description: My wife and I went there to check out what all the fuss was about. We waited in line for a good 45-50 minutes to place our order. Once actually inside the bakery we waited at least another 15 minutes before anyone helped us. People were coming in the store to "pick up" their orders and walked straight in rather than waiting in line like the rest of us. This normally wouldn't be a big deal to me but it seemed like all the people coming into the store to just "quickly pick up" their orders were taking longer than the actual customers waiting in line. My wife and I almost walked out after waiting for well over an hour and then to not have anyone help us. It seemed like if you weren't Chinese you weren't going to get helped. Finally, after having three orders jump ahead of me, I said something and one of the older women helped us out. We got a couple coconut macaroons and a few egg tarts. The macaroons were pretty good but the egg tarts were nothing spectacular. Certainly not worth waiting over an hour for.....I will not be going back here again.
author: Matt R.

description: egg custards the size they used to make them in the good ole days at dim sum restaurants.  it's good to have a freshly made one on a brisk SF day. the sesame pastry is good and big as well too.
author: NY Y.

description: Everyone in line was ordering 5 of this, 4 of this, and a dozen of that but all I ordered was one egg custard and it was GOOD.
author: Debbie Y.

description: As I run through Chinatown with my running group - I catch a whiff of some baked goods. Hence, where is that wonder aroma coming from? It's the Golden Gate Bakery, home of the perfect egg custard tart. Kiss my healthy eating and fitness regime good-bye when I see these custard tarts. Let's do the math: light flakey crust - made with tons of butter = lots of calories + custard - made with eggs and sugar = even more calories. Grand total: Another 5 miles of running to burn these calories. I don't care, it's totally worth it. I better switch to another route.
author: Candace F.

description: Best custard cake I ever had. When I approached this place, I saw ropes lined up for a pending crowd but being that there was no crowd, I was a lil taken back. However, literally secomds later there was a line formed behind me and when I took my first bite into the cake (its not on display but in a heated spot so it comes out warm and succulent when you get it) I could understand the need to anticipate the crowd. At $1.15 for what tastes gourmet, its a steal. Some desserts that cost $5 don't even taste that good! I dream about it all the time since I left. I should have bought more for the road...::sigh::
author: D N.

description:
Their dan tat is really really good...

their service...not too good...

and either i have really bad timing, but everytime i drop by san francisco chinatown...it's ALWAYS closed. and then i go on the day it's supposed to reopen but then they just happen to extend their vacation for another two weeks. 

will i come here again? most definitely...
am i really disapointed? HELLS YEAH I AM!
will i be disapointed again? PROBABLY!!!!
author: Jtina K.

description:
this place has so many great reviews already that it really doesnt need another one but i just want to put in my two cents. what everyone says is true, the egg tarts here are amazing. even more amazing if your lucky and are able to score a fresh batch which is just what i did. my only regret was that i only bought two of them when i really should of gotten a dozen and shared the wealth with my friends. 

yes the line is crazy but if you go during off hours its not so bad and its kind of fun to people watch while you wait. besides the egg tarts, i also bought myself a vanilla/chocolate swirl cake thing with cream in the middle, red bean moon cake and this white spongy looking dessert. apparently i dont know what any of these things are called but thats the beauty of this place, i can just point at whatever i want and no one can laugh at my terrible chinese. and as if i even need to say it but yes, everything was delicious.

added bonus of walking around chinatown afterwards with the red plastic bag which made me feel very authentic. in fact, in thinking about it i need to go back and soon.
author: georgette y.

description: this place is off the hook. I have tried several Chinese bakeries and this one buy far is the best. the egg tarts, moon cake and buns with coconut filling are all awesome. I loveeeeeee this place. I really miss them when they go to china as they close there business. This place is the winner when it comes to quality and price. Avg cost of items is  less than $1
author: Hasham Y.

description: There are only a few places I've memorized the location of in Chinatown and this is one. I LOVE WARM BUNS. :D I also enjoy the flakiness of the egg tarts, which my friend got me hooked on. The line is frequently out the door and trickling to the other stores. I didn't say always because there was one time they were closed on vacation--good for them! The women seem to work pretty hard in here and everything is so fresh and yummy.
author: Kim G.

description:
best eggtart ANYWHERE!

refer to below reviews.. always a long line... but is so worth the wait!

flaky, pastry shell filled with piping hot egg custard...melts in your mouth with a perfect consistency.  best to eat right on the spot!
author: J C.

description: The line at this place is always out the door.  People come here mainly for their egg custards - which are really good.  I used to come here to buy egg custards to snack on after I finished for the day student teaching down in Chinatown 3 years ago.  Not everyday or I'd be freakin' huge, but every once in a while.  And only on the days when I'd have to trek over to SFSU after a day of student teaching for class.  There were lines even back then so that's gotta tell you something.  Anyway, my aunt brought over some egg custards and mooncakes from GG Bakery yesterday.  The egg custards were good as usual, but I didn't like the mooncakes so much.  Then again, I am NOT a big fan of mooncakes.
author: Kris L.

description: Don Tat... how many ways can you spell that out in English?  Well I went there for the first time because the hubby tried it and insisted that we go.  $13.20 for some don tats in chinatown?!?!  Outrageous!  Call me cheap, but I can get 3 don tats for $1.20 anywhere else.  ok ok they really are good, they really are flaky, warm, delicious.  but that's so expensive for a don tat!  Everytime a good chinese bakery or restaurant hits it "big" aka put on Zagat or whatever those other tour books are, they jack up the prices.  Anyway, we didn't wait in line at all.  Nobody was there.  however, i came home and to my unpleasant surprise, they jipped us!  There were 11 don tats in the box and not 12!  so we got ripped off.  you can't complain to those chinese places cuz they'll probably spit in your next order.  so just beware - always count before they seal the box on you!
author: Stacey C.

description: egg tarts. all I can say is after a ridiculous mad dash to this bakery is that it was well worth it. after living in Shanghai and looking for something to compare to the authentic standards, this place is it.
author: Paulina T.

description: Oh wow, the egg tarts are to die for!  The crust is really flaky and warm, the custard is the perfect consistency and melts in your mouth.  The line is long but you can get a boba tea nearby to make the wait shorter.  Gosh, I really want to go there right now.
author: Tabatha Y.

description: Yummy, yummy--I've really nothing new to add...but I was just thinking how I'd love a warm , flaky egg custard tart right now.  Four stars only b/c it's always crowded, you have to be pushy, and they're seemingly often on vacation!
author: Joyce L.

description: Well looks like it's already been said: egg tarts. So worth the line up. Keep in mind they close for a pretty long holiday over the summer.
author: Vanessa A.

description: Okay I admit - the custard egg tarts are the freakin' best in the city. As much as I dislike going to Chinatown and standing in line for half an hour  just to order overpriced food, they DO make nice gifts for your neighbor.. and family.. simply because EVERYONE loves their egg tarts. That's pretty much the only thing I order here because I can get everything else for half the price and equally as good from other Chinatown bakeries.
author: Judy L.

description: THE BESTEST EGG TART EVERRRRRRRR....  just be careful they make it fresh and can BURNNNN ur tongue.. but the BESTEST EVERRR.... soo flaky.. so creamy... so heavenly =P
author: Ryan M.

description: Best egg tarts outside of Hong Kong.  You have to eat them while they're still hot though.  The crust is flaky, not dense and hard like the ones in most bakery in SJ.  I like that there is a good amount of custard to each tart and the custard is not overtly sweet.  The wait is definitely worth it!
author: lani h.

description: I love this place ! Everything here is good . I esp. love the egg tart , lemon pastry (?) , and sponge cake ! I don't know what they put in in their batter but it's mm mm good and addicting ! Kind of expensive pastries but it's worth every penny . This place is usually very busy .. you can see a whole line of people waiting to purchase everyday .
author: Eileen L.

description: everything's delicious! *period*  and I don't care how much I have to pay for the Don Tot!  It's SO worth it!
author: Leisheung P.

description:
some 8 years ago when i first moved here, i was consulting on a project.
one of the other consultants had mentioned that SF houses 'the best egg tart EVER'. when questioned, the said person could not give me the name of the place or contact info... except that it was in chinatown.

i've been on this holy grail search for egg tarts on and off for 7 years. i've done the random search online for 'best egg tart in san francisco' and the results are always vague and random. last year i finally remembered to search yelp, and lo and behold, "Golden Gate Bakery" came on top of search results...

this little place is hidden in the midst of Chinatown. if you weren't informed, this would look like just another chinese bakery in chinatown. however, the long lines that winds onto half the pavement reminds you that this isn't a place to ignore.

the bakery front is a small shop with a counter and some display cases and that's it - you get real cozy with everyoone else. be prepared to stand in line - anywhere from 10 to 25minutes depending on when you go... i've only gone on weekends. my first visit i was a bit surprised by the brisk short answers, but to their credit they try to serve as many people as quickly as they can.

the egg tart is served piping hot, sometimes they run out and you wait a few minutes for the downstairs to supply more right out of the oven. it is flaky, it is full of butter or lard, it is perfectly sweetened - when enjoyed fresh, the custard part is smooth and glides over your tongue and melt, mingling the sweet egg flavor into your taste buds.

i also love the curry beef puff here... the lady in front of me recommended it, and this is also usually steaming hot inside, and oh so tasty - slightly spicy, but very good....


*i have heard there's another bakery in chinatown that rivals this place, and is even cheaper, with no line-ups. but i wasn't told the name of the bakery so that will be the next chapter in my continued search to find the best egg tarts*

this is on the must-have list to hit if you're visiting San Francisco.
author: amy c.

description: The don tats or egg tarts for you non fatties are amazing here.  Probably one of the best in SF.  Its greasier than the back of my thighs but I like greasy thighs.  The apple roll is also good here.  The egg tarts are over $1 a piece.  Thats pretty expensive.  But if you are a true fat ass you will eat 12 of these.
author: Fatty A.

description: I love egg tarts and by far this is the "Eggtart King". I have heard so much about this place and finally got my way around to here so I ordered pretty much everything that was in my site. I ordered 12 eggtarts, 2 coconut thingys, pineapple bun, fluffy pound cake in a cup ? and some  coconut macaroons. All the items listed above were very average and is definitely something you can find in the market, random bakeries, or even make better ones at home, but the eggtarts are to die for. I never had an eggtart that is so creamy in the inside and soft on the outside like that. The custard itself melts in your mouth and the crush is super soft. Honestly, the service sucks big time and there's always a line of people in the very small shop, but even if I have to wait an hour for these eggtarts they are super worth it.
author: T Is For Tom N.

description: ah...i love the dan-tats here. this is probably as close to Hong Kong dan-tats as I can get here in San Francisco. The crust is always flaky and the custard is always sweetened to just the right amount. yummy...
author: Carolyn F.

description: Just to let you guys know, I called and their hours are 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., I'm assuming 7 days a week, but wasn't able to squeeze an answer from them on it.
author: Curtis W.

description: I stopped by yesterday early in the a.m. to get a dozen egg tarts. So early that there was no one in line! Woot!! These babies are now 1.15 each! EACH!! And I didn't hesitate getting these at that price tag. I must be rich! Ha.
author: cyndi L.

description: I'm from San Francisco and I go back about once a year.  Every time I go to SF I must get at least a dozen of their egg tarts.  They are THAT good.  Trust me, I've had egg tarts in HK, Macau, SF, LA, Seattle, etc and these are the BEST!   The only downside is there is always a long line making the wait quite long.
author: Melissa C.

description: Yes they make the best egg custard. Instead of just sweet filling, it's fresh and so EGG-y :) But 3 out of 5 visits ended up with "no more egg custard" for today.. ahh I should go earlier next time.
author: Marlis T.

description: definitely tasty, fresh egg custard.  pretty much described accurately already -- bigger size, flaky crust, soft custard.  warm when right out of the oven.  long line.
author: Rob C.

description: Best eggtarts in the city, although your average eggtart anywhere else is half the price..I use to live in South San Francisco and my bf and I use to drive to chinatown just to visit this place..thats how good it is!
author: M W.

description: Ok.. they are good? But... are they THAT GOOD? I mean, I see some crazy ass lines for their famous this famous that. But I've had their stuff and I don't recall it being out of this world or anything. And YES, they cost a lot more than other dim sum/bakery places. So no, I will not line up for whatever they have here. But YES, I'll be glad to eat it if someone offers it.
author: Elaine H.

description: do yourself a flavor and order AT LEAST half a dozen of their egg tarts any time you are even remotely close to the chinatown area.  i try not to be huge a huge piggy and always only order two egg tarts at first, but then after i finish those in a fury, i have to make the walk of shame back to the long line and order more.  i will no longer make this same mistake!
author: Irene W.

description:
The egg custard tarts are excellent as many yelpers have written BUT the price is exorbitant. However, if you feel their price is worth it, then more power to you. 

I think the egg custard tarts that are on those dim sum carts at the Y Ben House on Pacific Ave are much tastier, albeit smaller in size. Problem is, I think they are only available during an eat-in dim sum.

Note - this rating only applies to their egg tarts; I haven't tried anything else.
author: John C.

description: Everytime I come home from college, we make a couple pit stops here so I can bring some buns back to school.  Their egg tarts are too oily for me but I love these other buns they sell.  I have no idea what they're called in English but in Chinese they're called "Ji-Wei-Bao."  They're kinda long looking, have a yummy crusty thing on top, and this really good eggy coconutty amazing orgasmic filling inside.  Tourists started to discover this place so there usually is a huge line but sometimes, you can get the very nice, loud ladies who work there to set aside an order for you so you can pick it up later.  Their curry pockets are really good too! Definitely worth the wait and the prices are reasonable.
author: Joanne L.

description: The egg custard tarts are amazing. The custard is perfect, not too hard, not too mushy..and the crust is nice and flakey. YUM! The best is to eat them fresh and right after you buy them. The cocktail buns and pork buns are decent there too. This place closes down at random times for extended periods of times, so I've been disappointed a bunch of times. Beware of the long lines...my eyes tend to be bigger than my stomach and I end up buying way too much each time I'm there because I've been in line too long staring at the pastries.
author: Vanessa W.

description: One place I forgot to review during my last trip to SF...oh, how I miss those cheap egg tarts that taste larger than life....on the weekends, they have dinner rolls that just yummers!!!!!!!! It's a bit of a walk from Union Square to Chinatown but well worth it!!!!
author: Jenny L.

description: We were walking around Chinatown and saw this from across the street and thought, OMG, this place was crazy busy, it must be good!  So off we go.  30 minutes and $15 later, i am walking around with a red plastic bag (must-have if you go to chinatown) full of treats.  The don tot was my favorite, but everything else was sooo good.  Can't go wrong with this place, that's for sure!!!
author: Toni Y.

description: Go first thing in the morning when the round doughnuts are warm from the oven. They are greasy, sweet, filled with bean curd or lotus, rolled in sesame, and addictive! Also great for moon cakes. Don't be afraid to ask questions. Definitely a place to take out-of-town friends.
author: Jude M.

description: If you ever need to get a gift for Chinese New Year, this bakery's Moon Cakes (minus egg yolks) are the best gift you can offer. They also have some other unusual pastries that you won't find in your traditional bakery. My favorite is the curry beef puff(?) Service is terrible unless you speak Cantonese.
author: Babs P.

description: I'm now quite sure what most of the stuff in here is called, let alone whats in it.  I don't think I'll ask, it's too cheap and to good.  Just point to something and pay 75 cents for it.  More than enough for me, just don't tell me about the ground crickets in it.
author: Herbert S.

description: i gotta say, this is the best egg tart place in San Francisco. Even people that i know from other cities who come here say it's better. the place may be dirty because it's located in chinatown. but heck., the egg tart is something that you can't get. i say it is even better then some of those in hong kong
author: Eric Y.

description: the best egg custard tarts around. crust is so flakey and yummy.. had to take the cousins out to get some after the giants losing to the padres on saturday. Since the giants did lose, which was a bummer, i cheered them all up with this delightful treat. They also had fresh pork buns which were also delicious. Everytime i goto the city my mom makes me stop by this place to atleast get a dozen for the family.
author: Johnny G.

description: 6/14/08: It took a couple passes by this place until the line was short enough to bear - any visit to SF's chinatown isn't complete until you fill yourself with a couple egg custards from this place. I could only handle one this afternoon and boy was it delicious! I pretty much burned the roof of my mouth since it just came out of the oven - nothing beats this...
author: Jesse W.

description: Love the Coconut pastries they have....staff really doesn't speak english so you know its authentic, lol!
author: Amit S.

description: I don't like flaky crust egg tarts.  I like GGB's flaky crust egg tart.  I'm conflicted now.  Worth the line-up, worth the parking, worth the price.
author: H C.

description: I've only had one thing here: the egg custard tarts. They are the best frickin' egg custard tarts I've had. That's all you really need to know. It's a bit on the pricey side, considering it's Chinatown, but it's worth it.
author: Bernie L.

description: One of the best warm freshly baked custard tarts in town! I prefer the baked goods/Chinese BBQ pork buns or sweet pastries in other bakeries but when it comes to custard tarts, this is the place to pick up a dozen. I've seen others packing 100s to go! Insanely long lines esp on weekends. The bakery is closed 2-3 months during the summer.
author: Yan M.

description: Returning home from dinner, a friend recommended Golden Gate Bakery for Moon Cake.  Line was long and I had the pineapple moon cake.  Good but not amazing.  So the lesson to be learned is that long line doesn't necessarily equate to amazing.
author: ITesh J.

description: Just thinking about this place makes me want a dan tat. The best anywhere! Definitely worth the slightly higher price, as well as the wait. I like strolling around Chinatown with one of these in my hand.
author: lindsay w.

description:
i drive all the way out from union city and wait in that line for their egg tarts....



enough said.
author: Leon C.

description:
wow...their egg tarts are f--king good when it's fresh out of the oven, it's crispy and taste perfect.  but what the hell is up with the price?? used to be 80 cents, then 90 cents...then 1.00, now it's like 1.15 each!!! YOUCHHHHHH...

i tried their other stuff such as the walnut cup cake and sticky rice ball...they are alright....i only crave for their egg tarts...

everytime i go, there is a long line...people dont care, they just wait....and lots of time i go to chinatown only to be disappointed because they are on vacation. hell-for selling an egg tart for that price, they can go on vacation monthly.....
OH also you must be prepared to stand in long line only to hear they ran out of egg tarts when it's your turn..
That happened to me once, I almost had a cow but then I heard the next batch will be ready in another 10 minutes....but then someone who ordered 2 dozens had their orders packed twice so i was able to buy some before the 10 minutes...yay
author: sonya h.

description: i love egg tarts.. it's one of my favorite chinese desserts.. and this place does it justice.. i stood in line for about about 30 minutes waiting for these suckers.. and they were worth it.. i also saw people buy boxes of moon cake.. and apparently that's quite popular here too..
author: Stan L.

description: These egg tarts are noticably bigger then your average and the custard is less egg yolk tasting and more like custard.  They are amazing, even the next day!  These are hands down the best egg tarts ive ever eaten.  They are a little pricer then your avg egg tart as well, but well worth it.
author: Cacula J.

description: These are my brother-in-laws favorite egg tarts. I don't eat egg, but my in-laws were all ooh-ing and ahh-ing, so they must be pretty good. I did try 2 things that I don't know the names of (including one of those coconut-rolled dumplings with sugary peanut filling), though, and they were very good. So, 5 stars for quality, but perhaps only 4 stars overall, because of the major inconveniences of lack of parking and waiting in a pushy-shove-y line. We'll be back, though.
author: Ramon E.

description: I don't like egg tarts in general, so I will not comment on those. However, bought a few other items from the bakery like the curry pastry, rice cake/coconut with a peanut in a middle item, and another lotus seed bun. All were extremely tasty and piping hot, straight from the oven.
author: Glaciala A.

description:
Need to say more with so many reviews on Yelp?! - THE place for Egg Tart in SF!!!

My office is moving from the Financial District to SOMA... I know I will miss one thing - walking to Golden Gate Bakery for a dozen of Egg Tarts on Fridays.  

The store closes 3 times a year for 3-7 weeks vacation.  So, plan ahead :-)
author: Sophia X.

description:
so this was my first egg tart and i'm glad i tried it.
didn't know what to expect, i read all these reviews about "egg tart" and got confused when their menu only read "custard tart"
as for service, the ladies who run the place are really pushy and try to hurry you up, which i expect in Chinatown, but it kept me from looking at all my options and getting more pastries which i had planned on.
i'll definitely visit this place again next time i'm downtown and see what other stuff they have to offer.
the only problem is that $1.15 is a bit steep for a tiny little tart. 
oh well, the quality is good, i just don't plan on buying a dozen any time soon
author: Grace M.

description: I went on a Sunday afternoon and stood in the line down the sidewalk. I was pretty stoked to try their famous egg tart! I have never had an egg tart so didn't know what to expect taste wise. I suppose I was expecting it to be more of a dessertish taste - like more vanillaish - less total egg flavor. Nope, i was wrong. I took a bit and it tasted like biting into an egg mcmuffin (ok that's an exageration, but you get the emphasis on the EGG not tart or dessertis at all). Man, my excitement fell. And i had bought 5 of them to share with the roomate and hubby and have some extra for myself assuming i would be in love with them. Luckily i also picked up a vanilla cream filled pastry with coconut on top - that was delish and totally hit the spot for the sweet item I'd been envisioning. The little ladies behind the counter and over and super efficient and good at pointing out what's 'good' and what's 'really good'.  I might come back, but not for the egg tart.
author: Audrey V.

description: Yummy! The egg tarts here are amazing. This place is a must. Another awesome thing about this place is it's a few doors down from Red Blossom Tea Company, which is a great place to get really great quality Chinese tea.
author: Joyce G.

description: You cant find better egg custard tarts. I know friends that travel miles for these babies and actually pack them special to take home on planes.
author: Ikeb I.

description: I'm sure their other pastries are good, but people come here (and wait in long lines) for their fresh egg tarts.  There's nothing like eating a hot, just out of the oven egg tart right on the streets of Chinatown.
author: Kit E.

description: You ever seen the soup Nazi's on Seinfeld? Well these old lady's are the egg tart Nazi's.  I mean just like the soup Nazi's they are rude as hell and they close for months at a time, when they feel like it, and people wait in line because nobody makes a big, rich, flaky, egg tart like the mean old lady's at Golden Gate Bakery.
author: sonia m.

description:
This is a MUST stop destination place.  
This place is reknown for it's egg tarts and egg tarts ONLY.  The crust is light and flaky when they first come out from the oven.  The custard is nice and filling (unlike a lot of places where they don't have much custard!).  Eventhough their prices are twice as expensive ($0.95 each) as other places, I still prefer these over anywhere else.  These are better than a lot of places even in Hong Kong!...I know cuz I've been there.  
Be prepare for a LOOOONNNG line though on the weekends.  I would try to go there either early in the morning (8:30 am) or 6:30 pm.
author: Gary Y.

description: Legendary egg custards... simply phenomenal. You must try them... perfectly set, flaky crust... oh so good.
author: Joy C.

description: OMG... melt in your mouth egg custard... The best in S.F..
author: Doris M.

description:
definitely the best egg tarts are from golden gate bakery~!  

i always try to get my bf to drive me here so i can get my hands on one of these...  *of course i end up eating more than one ( = *  before i leave for the airport to fly out to the bay area, my mom always ask if i'm going to golden gate bakery.  why?  of course my whole family wants the egg tarts, so i always come home with at least a dozen of them.  they're not as crunchy and flaky by the time i get to socal, but a few minutes in the toaster oven and they're all good again.  ( =   $1.10 each?  yea, a lil' pricey...  oh well, they are sooo... worth it.  i just have to remind myself to the need to spend a lil' more time at the gym after i enjoy these goodies.  = /  

i've tried a few of their other goodies...  although they were good, some of them just weren't my thing.  but i do like the coconut tart *not sure if that's the real name* and another big, round, flaky pastry with wintermelon in it...   wife pasty? o.O  sorry, i really don't know what they're called.  = /   but yes...  yummy, yummy, yummy...  ( =

i love you but i hate how you are a few hundred  miles away from me... = /  and i get even sadder when i show up only to be greeted by a sign on your door telling me that you won't be open till *certain date*  i came back a few days after the posted date... only to find that you've extended the date.  then i fly back home without any goodies.  boo..  but still, i can't find myself to give you less than 5 stars for the delicious egg tarts you make...
author: karina o.

description: If you've been searching for old skool egg custards that you've had when you were little...then this is the place to be.  We've heard rumors of SF having the best dahn tat but we never found one until we yelped it.  So this past president's day, we took a jet plane up to SF to search for these golden gems and after a few stops for directions and a long wait in line, we found our golden treasures.  Sure enough, all the rumors are true...these are the best dahn tat that we've ever tasted.  One bite and you'll relive your childhood of sitting with your family for dim sum and your grandma handing you a dahn tat as big as your hand.  Even if you are not in the neighborhood, you should go and experience this for yourself.  I promise you that after one dahn tat here, all the egg custards you will ever have will not measure up to these!
author: Mei L.

description: This places makes the best egg / custard tarts I've ever had.  Nothing else I've had comes close.  The filling is great and the flaky shell is just ridiculously good.
author: Piggy S.

description: Warm egg custard tarts! So good... I always try to get one when I'm in Chinatown.  Unfortunately I have been foiled by their vacation!
author: Joann C.

description: egg tarts are freaking bomb!  i almost want to find out who's single in their family so I can marry them off to a relative of mines...so i can get the recipe for the dan tats.
author: Cindy B.

description: Recommended by my relatives from the Bay area, and worth the wait in line! Yes, the egg tarts are a bit pricey, but they are delicious. I was lucky enough to get them right out of the oven. The crust was nice and flaky, the custard filling was light, and not too sweet. Delish!!!
author: Carolyn S.

description: My husband loves their egg custards and we always come here to get the hot and fresh ones. They are the best! The line can be very long sometimes, and I've seem people cut in line. Wish they have a "to-go" window.
author: Amada S. W.

description: Definitely Worth the wait. . . . . .I love the egg tart, and the best is eating one right there on the spot when they are warm, the crust is flaky and the custard is the perfect consistency and sweetness. I know this place probably doesn't need more reviews, but the egg tart is so awesome that I had to.
author: TANYA V.

description:
The egg custard tarts are insanely good.  We waited 20 minutes in line to get some.  I had recently been underwhelmed waiting in line for baked goods at a cupcake place (reviewed) and was skeptical about the line here.  But boy howdy, was I glad I waited. 

I bought a tart to eat on the spot and a box to take home, since we waited so long.  Standing outside I dug into the steaming hot, fresh out of the oven, jiggly goodness and experienced sheer bliss.  The warm custard was as smooth as silk and the crust was perfectly flaky.  These are baked goods risen to an art form.  If you think you've had a good egg custard tart, maybe at your local dim sum place or pearl tea shop, you probably haven't.  These are unlike any custard tart I have had previously.  The tarts we took home were great even after they had cooled, and still good the next day after a night in the fridge.

Incidentally, we had a good time waiting in line.  We chatted with the guy behind us and when we got to the front of the line we chatted with the lady behind the counter.  Standing outside stuffing our gobs we talked to the people at the back of the line.  A good time was had by all.  Get in line and have fun!
author: Dave P.

description:
We drove from OC to SF and this was our first stop.

Five stars for the Dan Tat (Egg Custard).  
Hot, just cooked in the middle.  
Crust is flaky.

I also tried the BBQ Pork bun.  It was ok.  I wouldn't get it again.  Just go there for the custard.
author: Anon y.

description: The egg tarts are delicious. The moon cakes are a little pricey and they don't tell you the price ahead of time. The price is never mentioned until you are actually about to pay. There is always a long line during lunch. If you have trouble finding the place, just remember it's across the street from WAMU, and it's the place with the long line of people outside.
author: Pika C.

description: This can easily be the best egg custard tart I've tried in the WORLD - including Hong Kong, China, and Singapore.  Their custard tarts are so fresh and perfect -- crust is flaky and the custard is soft and hot (when you eat it as soon as you get it!). The long lines are well worth it! Their coconut tart is pretty good too. But if I had to choose it, it'd be the Egg Custard Tart, hands down!
author: Elaine B.

description: I think I was pretty lucky cos I went straight into the store without the sign of the 'long line'. Don't get me wrong, I wasn't cutting in the line or anything cos there was no such thing but the min I got in there... OMG there were tons of people waiting outside! Man, the egg custard tart is so good! It's the best in the SF and LA! I can tell where the line is coming from now! The crust is neither the traditional flaky layers one nor the western cookie one. It's more like the Portuguese one you can have in Macau! And the egg custard filling is so darn good! It's full with egg and vanilla odor. It still taste very good the other day.
author: Ms Piggy W.

description: I must have caught them on a slow day.  I only waited in line for about 10 minutes.  I had a red bean sesame ball.  Delicious.  I also ordered 3 egg custards but I forgot about them and was scared to eat them after they had sat in the car for so long, I'm a wuss like that.
author: Josh V.

description: I have no idea why people would line up for this place. I normally love egg tarts but the egg tarts from this place are just made of grease. Some people swear the old school bakery has to use tons of pork oil to make good pastries. May be this is what they're trying to accomplish but I would rather get flaky buttery egg tart without tons of grease from other bakeries such as Napoleon and New Hwong Kok. Their napoleon was also greasy, too chunky, and chalky.
author: Jen C.

description: Hands down the best chinese egg custard pastry thing ever.  The pastry part is sooo flaky and buttery while the egg part is just so....eggy.  There is always a line out the door and down the street a little but it's worth it.  It's on the pricey side for Chinatown but these things are big and good.  Can't complain about the service because it is a takeout bakery place and you ARE in Chinatown.  We Chinese aren't known for service, eat and get out lol.  It's all a part of the experience.
author: Anna H.

description:
i know it's a good day when my parents bring home some good ol', warm egg custard tarts. and then it all gets better when i bite into the melts-in-your-mouth custard filling and flaky perfect crust. 

and then there's the banana thing that is just so good that i do not know the english words to describe it. heck, i don't even know what this thing is called in english. i just know that if they have it, and i got it, it's all good in the hood. not to mention the soft sponge cakes that are wrapped in the paper....ooh, spongey goodness....

and then there's the other many yummy things that i have no clue what the hell they are called in english, but seriously, this place makes everything the best. you just can't go anywhere else.

it's a small place that appears to have no order in how it is run. i felt claustrophobic and as if i was in everybody's way, but i kept my eye on the prize (or make-me-fatter goodies). luckily, when i went, i didn't have to wait in a long line. but from what mother tells me, this place doesn't have dependable hours, so it's always a guess whether it's open or not. one star off for that, but four stars and a hundred pounds for some good chinese baked goods. hell yeeeah.
author: Veggie J.

description: Yes, everyone craves their egg tarts. Light, flakey, buttery goodness. They're pricey for an egg tart, or custard tart as they call it, but it's worth it. Their buns are good too. Their items are always FRESH!
author: Katherine C.

description: The egg custard tarts are the best dessert/breakfast/whatever  I've ever eaten.  Every time I visit San Francisco (about once every couple of months) I always stop in to pick up some of these delicious, addictive tarts.  Last time I bought a box of them and the woman who sold them to me told me to be sure to keep the box level so they wouldn't smash together.  Couldn't even wait to get back to the car before I gobbled a couple of them.  YUMMY YUMMY!!!!
author: W. H.

description: get the egg custard tarts. and the chicken pot pie. yum. i want some now.
author: L M.

description: The best egg tarts in the city...the ONLY reason i didn't give them 5 stars: very pricey.  But certainly worth the 1.15 per tart.  and try the mooncakes during autumn moon festival.  delish.  remember - bring wads of cash.
author: Sonia C.

description: Worth the wait in line. These egg custard tarts are the closest to the ones that i've had in Macau!
author: michael l.

description: Best dan tats in the city!  Period.  Oh yeah, worth the wait.
author: Ryan C.

description: This Chinatown institution is here for a good reason: the best egg tarts outside of Hong Kong. The long lines of patient egg tart lovers are a testament to the famous Chinese pastry that put Golden Gate Bakery on the map. Get a dozen tarts straight out of the oven, so tasty and warm...yum.
author: Tami Y.

description: Read on,  they aint lyin.  The best egg custard tart ive ever had,  and Im very picky, Im a baker.  Thank you warren and mary.
author: Hen A.

description:
i always see a long a** line in front of this place so i figured it must be good for something. so one day b4 they closed we took advantage that there was no line & decided to spoil ourselves with a late night snack. 

had no idea what to get but ended ordering some things we didn't know how to pronounce. lol. the only thing i can really tell you was that we ordered a muffin-like pastry made of coconut. now that was REALLY good. it's the only thing there made of coconut so you shouldn't have a problem. the other thing we ordered was this flat , circular pastry made of melon. that was definitely different & not your ordinary pastry...give those 2 things a shot if you're ever in the area!
author: yummycupcake o.

description:
Best egg custard tart.  Not just the best in SF, it is the best among all the places I've tried in SF, LA, Vancouver, Toronto, Hong Kong, and Macau.

Their other bakery goods are decent but the egg custard tart totally shines. 10 stars for the egg custard tarts - 5 stars for anything else, it's still a 5-star.
author: E H.

description: The egg tarts are delicious and overpriced but everyone is a sheep. "Baaaah Baaaah"
author: SF N.

description: If you want some real yummy Chinese egg custards come to this place in Chinatown!  It's a tiny bakery but all of the pastries are really good!  The egg custards are so popular sometimes there would be a line just for that!  If you're in Chinatown do stop by and try it out!
author: JenJen W.

description: The delicious dan tat (egg custard tart) is considered the best in the city, and it's sheer perfection with a delicate, buttery, flakey crust, and often warm. But my personal favorite is the coconut-covered mochi ball with a macadamia nut tucked inside surrounded by finely chopped peanuts (AKA "sweet rice with peanut"), and these guys somehow manage to make them incredibly light, whereas others literally weigh much more -- talk about a little ball of heaven! The mooncakes are also spectacular.
author: Sharman G.

description:
The egg tarts here are truly to die for.  Some of the best I've had anywhere.  I make special trips to C-town just to pick up a dozen of these babies, then try to gobble them all up before my apartment-mate sees the box.

Yeah the line is usually going out the door, but it moves fast.  Persevere young one, for it is definitely worth the wait!
author: Chris C.

description: Best custard tarts anywhere ever. Love the sound system that lets you hear what's going on downstairs. Many fond childhood excursions associated with this place. Incredibly consistent quality. Unfortunately, too many wannabes have found GGB, but that's life.
author: Bibi R. R.

description: Although their Egg Tarts aren't as perfect as I remember them to be, I'd say they're still the best in the Bay. And their Moon Cakes were some of the best I've ever had!
author: Donald F.

description:
One of our favorite bakeries.   Prices are high, lines are long, parking is a myth.  And yet we go out of our way to stop by here for some treats.

Get the egg custard tarts.  You have to.  Try everything, but, get the custard tarts.
author: Al V.

description:
4 stars is for their Egg tart.

The eggs are perfectly cooked, to the right texture and taste. The pastry is flaky and fresh.

But the waiting line was too too long. They need more staff and bigger store. Considering how much they charge, I would expect better service.
author: Nancy Z.

description: it's true, they have the best egg-tarts in town. it's also true that there's *always* a line. they also have some tasty moon cakes as well, get 'em for moon festival!
author: grant l.

description: what can i say thats not already said,after eating these egg tarts,its hard to eat them from other places,(theyre on vacation till first week of sept)
author: Soupnazi B.

description: Went by yesterday (Sat).  Sign on the door says "vacation"....no return date.  I'm giving up on this place.  They are closed more often than open.
author: Julie H.

description: The king of egg tarts!  If you like egg tarts, I don't care what versions of it.  If you're Chinese you know what I mean.  You have to give this place a try if you're in Chinatown.  There's usually a long line in front of this place so be patience and you will be rewarded.
author: Goose C.

description:
What's the big deal about the supposed line? The  longest I've had to wait is a couple of minutes, less than Starbucks on average. So, don't let that detour you.

Now everyone talks about the egg or custard tarts., and for good reason. I mean,  WOW!!, they are awesome. They must be eaten warm, but no worry - they microwave just fine. Also, if you want a little something different - try the coconut buns. They are light rolls with a suburb coconut filling. Either way, you can't lose. Absolutely yummy.
author: merle s.

description:
Love, Love, Love 'Tan Tarts' from Golden Gate Bakery.
Hubby and I find every excuse possible to detour to Chinatown to get some egg tarts and their BBQ pork rolls. Though it has been awhile... sigh.
 
Their mooncakes are very good as well. I would recommend getting the White Lotus Paste ones, cause IMHO they taste better than the ones with red paste. I just noticed last Mooncake festival that they have a special mooncake, which I aim to try this year.

The only thing that annoys me that their business is so good that they close for a good chunk of time to go on vacation. Argh!! To go all the way there to find out they are closed does not make me a happy camper. Oh, and of course the wait.

But we love them anyway :-)
author: eileen y.

description:
