voted as one of the best bakeries in chinatown.. i dont see what all the fuss is about.. i meannn 95 cents for an egg tart?! outrageous! i have had it a couple times and they are good.... but is it to die for? nope.... i can live without it.. i mean its filled with butter anyways :[....but its not a bad place to go to if you are rich.... IF...

-x3 shells!
author: Lily X.

description: You gotta love the dan-tas but the lines are insane!  Did you know that if you speak English, they will treat you nicer?  The most upsetting is when you make a mouth-watering trek to Chinatown and the shop is closed!  Otherwise beware of the sa chi mahs, they're out on display even during vacation times!
author: Big e.

description: Omg!!! We were in Chinatown with family and saw the gianormous line on our way to lunch and decided to try it out on our way back. Waited forever it seems and got a little of everything. Custard tart was sooo good. It's deeper and holds more custard. We waited and came back for the fresh out of the oven sesame balls! Sooo good and did I mention big!?? Huge balls of yummy red bean goodness!!! Every woman's dream...ok maybe just this woman. We went during Chinese new year do they had their new year cake? It's not really cake but more of a gooey tapioca laffy taffy pie? Hard to explain. It comes in 3 flavors but I don't care for the consistency. My favorite and also the kids' is the BBQ pork rolls!! They are SO good!!! Perfect size and oh so tasty! I could eat a million of those. So you're probably wondering why only 4 stars?! Well...I hate waiting in line that long and I'm sure my 1 yr old along with everyone else in my group disliked waiting that long for me as well. Suffer enough for food don't you think?
author: Christie M.

description: This place rocks. i recommend this to all my non-asian friend that tell me they are heading doen to Chinatown. Even thought the lines are ridcously long they haave the best egg tarts and france butter bread. THey have the  france butter bread obly on weekends and people buy dozens. Than they run out. But if you are down by SF Chinatown it is well worth the line waiting. Bring it back home tomom and she love you for it!!
author: jacqueline c.

description: best egg tarts ever! i will come to san francisco just to get these egg tarts... they are THAT good! (:
author: Nani L.

description:
Overpriced, disgusting hygiene WITH VISIBLE RODENTS and extremely rude staff.  I've eaten in Chinatown all my life and have grown up with "dan tat", and theirs are twice the price and no better than the other Chinatown bakeries, though the lines seem to convince people otherwise.  I gave one a try, and the tart was okay, but tasted too greasy, and I noticed bits of dirt in the crust, probably from the pans they never wash.

Right about then i saw a RAT RUNNING ALONG THE FLOOR, heading right into the kitchen area!  I also noticed the flies hanging around inside the glass pastry display, and a dead one (no kidding!!) lying on its back on one of their unclaimed coconut tarts.

Okay, I know Chinatown can be a little dirty, but this is disgusting, especially if i just paid double the price!  You gotta be kidding me.  

My tip: explore Chinatown a bit more, and try some of the other less known bakeries.  This place is hyped by word of mouth because people haven't ventured elsewhere.  But the other bakeries are seriously just as good.  I'm sure that rat is enjoying egg tarts in their kitchen area though, along with all his family and friends.  GROSS.  For your own good, try someplace new.
author: Irina L.

description: i dont believe that i have been loving egg tart that i really hated before cuz i think it is nasty, but now i changed my mind because its egg tart. all friends like it as well. i will buy more in the future.
author: Ivan C.

description: I got to say I never cared too much for egg tarts but after checking out GG bakery, it seems impossible to find a suitable replacement outside of SF. Their pork buns are actually pretty good also. They are closed quite often so be sure to call ahead.
author: Ed C.

description: The best egg custard tart I've ever had hands down, their other stuff is not bad either, but the custard tarts are a must try for those who haven't yet.  I can't even eat ones from other places because I compare them to Golden Gate's and no other one comes close.  Lines are almost always out the door, but it's worth it and the custard tarts are constantly coming out fresh.
author: Eric T.

description: Wow.. i never lined up before for egg tart, but would see the line everything i go Chinatown. On Memorial Day, the line was super short, so I finally got in line (only 5 deep) and it was super fast. After i got mine and was leaving, the line was super long. This was definitely worth the wait and the higher price. The big box was shared with everyone and they loved it also.
author: H C.

description: Why the hell is this place listed as being in Nob Hill when it's right smack in the middle of Chinatown?
author: Ken L.

description: I totally agree with the Yelp egg custard fans.  We arrived today around 1 ish and there was no line.  I just walked in and order.  The lady behind the counter speaks English and was nice enough.  We ordered a dozen since we don't come here often.  I love the brown and crusty crush.  The custard is soft and warm.  However, I think it is a bit sweet for me.  We had to eat one right outside the door.  I would definitely come here again.
author: lovefoods S.

description: Most people that come to GGB come for dantat, but I come here for the macaroons!!!! OMG! THIS PLACE AS THE BEST macaroons I have ever had! I usually go to italian pastry shops that make delightful macaroons, but for some reason GGB took that away from all my favorite places! Even the place in boston does not compare!! ahhhh I LOVE YOU MACAROONS!
author: Mai H.

description: Incredibly good egg tarts... always fresh, warm and perfectly sweetened. 4 stars because the long line out the door.
author: Ryan O.

description: Another overrated place on Yelp.  Yes, they have the best egg custard tarts in town but nothing else.  Their pineapple buns are stale and the BBQ pork buns taste like they're left-over from the night before.  I would still come here for the egg tarts if it weren't for the long lines.  Honestly, it's not worth it anymore if you have to fight your way through a bunch of rude Chinese ladies to make an order every time.  If you're not aggressive enough, people who work there will just ignore you...typical of any Chinatown business.  Anyway, I just don't think this place is that special because anyone who's been to Asia before knows that any random bakery can make egg tarts equal to or better than Golden Gate.
author: Eric L.

description: Yum! Yum! Yum!!! This was probably the highlight of our SF trip, the custard tarts were awesome, the coconut tart was good also, and white lotus seed moon cake with salted egg yolk ($7--pricey!) was great too. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Iihae S.

description: The egg tarts melt in your mouth. Flaky, little warm. Heavenly awesome.
author: warakant j.

description: the old asian people in my family swear by this place. pricey, but worth it. only waited 15-20 minutes on the Saturday before Chinese New Year. $1.25 for one, $15 for a dozen. open 8am everyday.  even the day before Chinese New Year.  typical Chinese work ethic.
author: F S.

description: after a long break, the egg tart is still great.  but the cost is even higher.  so it's more of a treat then an every day snack.  also tried their cream puff.  it's gigantic, but where's the cream?!
author: Food Is L.

description: This place brings back memories. As a child I still remember eating egg custard tarts when going for dim sum with my parents and getting the crust all over my chubby cheeks.  Yes, there is usually a wait to get your order but that just means they are freshly baking those flaky, sweet, egg custard tarts!
author: Diana B.

description: No question about it - this is the place to go if you are willing to splurge on golden, flaky, "perfect", fresh, piping hot out of the oven egg tarts.  The line can be outrageously long for a simple dessert item, but well worth it.  Moon cakes from this place are also really good, and during the moon cake season add many to the already long line waiting for the egg tarts.  I have friends who buy a dozen and finish all in one afternoon, by themselves.  Delicious, inexpensive, and wonderful way to treat one's self!  Bring a friend if you are driving - parking is tough, but not impossible.
author: Antonio E.

description: i stock up on 2 items from them - the egg tarts and the "fought gawk bow" - cantonese pronunciation of french bread.  the "fought gawk bow" is only available on the weekends.  it's this yummy bread with a sugary crust.  try it and you will be converted!!
author: Dorothy L.

description: You know precisely what you are there for. Yes, your cholesterol level will shoot up instantly because of that, but life is too short to not indulge on good dan tat.
author: kenneth y.

description: yes,... i like this place too.... got here by mistake also... bread & sweet lover have definitely have to stop by in here....
author: jdyn l.

description: Everyone raves about how this little Chinese bakery makes the best egg tarts and mooncakes. Well I'm going to rave about their chocolate roll cake. The egg tarts are not especially tasty, they're just really big. The mooncakes are just mooncakes. They make the traditional kinds with the lotus fillings, egg yolk, and nuts. Older Chinese generations love it but I think for young people, it's just a lot of calories and fat. Now when someone can get haagen daaz to make ice cream mooncakes in America, I will Yelp about that. Now back to chocolate cake. It's not the sweet w/ a little hint of chocolatey bitterness like the ones you find in Western bakeries. The chocolate roll cakes here are moist, light, not too sweet, and come in the perfect size. Well you can buy them slice by slice or in one big roll. I go for the slice. They spread just a little bit of whip cream in the center so you don't get it all over your hands like the ones you buy in Western bakeries. Now... I'm not a big fan of cake. I won't even eat my own birthday cake, but I still can't resist buying a slice of chocolate cake from this bakery every time I pass buy.
author: Rennie C.

description: Have you ever tried the egg custards there?  The best I have ever had, hot out of the oven and only $1.15 each.  We ordered two dozen!  Omg, we waited nearly two hours on Sun night b/c they had been on vacation for almost a month.  I wouldn't wait that long again, but it's definitely worth a 30 minute wait.  And to top that, the moon cakes were very good.
author: Brian L.

description: hands down... best don tauts (egg custard tarts) ever!
author: Darren W.

description: being lucky enough to spend once a week in Chinatown teaching a class at the Y, i stumbled on to Golden Gate for a pre-class snack. i had heard of these famous egg custards and have also seen the lines during the daytime. fortunately for me, my class is in the evening so no lines! the night i finally tried my first ever Golden Gate egg custard was like a delicious dream: warm, steaming, not too overly sweet and fresh egg custard surrounded by perfectly flaky crust in a $1 miracle. ahhhhh... life, sometimes the simple things remind you of just how good it is....
author: ray e.

description: best egg tarts EVER! and i waited in the pouring rain for those suckers!
author: Nancy L.

description: best damn egg custard tarts in san francisco!!
author: rosemarie l.

description: i love so many of their pastries! whenever i go or my parents go, we usually buy 2 boxes worth of pastries unless they run out of something. too bad that i live outside of SF, otherwise, i would be here every week, restocking my kitchen with their yummy pastries! woohoo!
author: A C.

description: i never understood the big fuss about egg tarts. i thought, ok, egg custard in a pastry shell. big deal. but my brother brought these home while they were still warm, and they were by far the best egg tarts i've ever had. i heard that there's a long ass line tho so i don't think i'll ever be eating these unless someone buys them for me.
author: ML N.

description: Baked Cha Siu Bao and dan tat are the things to get here. It takes a while, because its freshly made. Its funny to hear the lady screaming cha siu bao into the microphone to the bakers downstairs. Buy a whole bunch and freeze them. Nuo mo zi (mochi) dumplings are really good too.
author: kirin r.

description: 45 minutes in line for an egg custard I can eat in under 45 seconds? c'mon now..
author: Derek C.

description: don't just eat the warm and flaky egg custard. eat EVERYTHING.
author: Shirley D.

description: This place is overated. The lines are long and the baked goods are overpriced.  it's true...they are famous for their egg tarts with the rich custard filling and the flaky crust (ok...i'm salivating all over my keyboard now) but the egg tarts at Wa Li on Stockton are just as good and they're cheaper.  With their fame in the egg tart business I can see why they can charge $1 each but what irks me is that they are also overcharging everything else they have to offer.  come on...sponge cake is a standard in every chinese bakery. it typically goes for ~$0.65 elsewhere but you have the nerves to charge a buck?
author: Justin Y.

description: i heart this place! been getting cakes & pastries from here since i was a fetus. yes, the egg custard tarts are great, but the french rolls are above & beyond the best, simple, fluffy deliciousness with just enough sugar on top vs ANYwhere else, & i've been around. it's such a shame they only make them on weekends until early afternoon. & a further shame they take (toooo long) vacations after moon day.
author: mel c.

description: Tasty and cheap but you will have to wait in a long line on the weekend.  I like the egg tarts and the triangle cake.  The macaroon things are good too.  Good ol' Chinese pastry.  Not worth it to go to any other bakery in Chinatown if you can wait in line for this stuff.
author: Priscilla P.

description: The custard tarts are good, and really good if you eat them when they're still warm.  Just not sure if it's worth waiting in a long line.  But if there's a no line or a short line, GO FOR IT.  I don't speak a lick of Chinese, I just point and say how many.  That's how I usually order food anyway.
author: gummy j.

description: the best egg tarts hands down in the Bay Area..dare i say California since I am an LA native.......totally worth the wait (I have been in line for about 40 minutes once due to the Mooncake Festival time).  If they are freshly baked you may want to wait awhile before inhaling them, unless you like a burnt tongue (trust me, that smarts)......
author: Andrew G.

description: Love the egg tarts here!  I live up in Seattle and I remember as a kid how my uncle up there would always ask people to bring him egg tarts from this place.  I never really appreciated them back then but now as an adult... haven eaten egg tarts all over the world... I've come to appreciate just how great these really are.  The custard is rich and silky smooth matched with a crust that's every bit as sinful.
author: Corey C.

description: I can't give this place more than two stars because of their bag services and attitude. I do agree with the last reviewer that this place needs a refresher course on good customer service. I do like their eggs tarts but it's not worth the hassle to deal with those people in the store just to get a couple eggs tarts to eat. Skip this place and move on to the bakery down the street. It's cheaper and friendlier.
author: jop h.

description: One sentence summary:  Overrated and only fools would stand in that long line.
author: Gina R.

description: Golden Gate Bakery is Chinese pastry heaven, let alone egg custard tart nervana.  It is definitely worth the wait at this Chinatown institution for those flaky, buttery, smooth egg custard tarts that are made to order in small, medium, and large; the curry beef turnovers are flaky with a tender filling of mildly spicy curry beef and vegetables, and the moon cakes popular around Chinese Newyear and the autumn moon fest are sinful with just the right amount of dough and smooth and sweet fillings of black bean, yellow bean, red bean, and lotus paste, the lotus root adding a salty eliment to these decident treats.  Get here early or else expect to wait; no credit cards.  The service, though rushed, is very friendly and the women behind the counter will answer any questions you may have.  So, for sublime Chinese pastries at rock bottom prices with friendly but rushed service in a clean but barebones atmosphere, Golden Gate Bakery cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!  Note: they close at least once a year for vacation which is needless to say well deserved.
author: Brian S.

description: awesome egg tarts and pastries. curry beef pastry was good! the chicken roll was alright. awesome Pineapple bun with crunchy top. but prob waited  in line for around half hour :(
author: j s.

description: Guess there's no need to add to the numerous "omg egg tart" reviews, but they truly are awesome. I went during my lunch break today and was craving some Chinese bakery treats...after wandering for a while I stopped into Golden Gate Bakery because there was a huge line. The huge line was full of Chinese people, not tourists, so I figured this place was good/authentic. After standing around for 10 min like an idiot while people around me were ordering in Chinese, one nice woman took pity on me and asked what I wanted. I didn't yelp this place beforehand, but all other customers were getting the egg tarts, so I decided to get a couple along with some moon cakes. I haven't tried the moon cakes yet, but the egg tarts are wonderful. They're so fresh (still warm after the 10 min walk back to the office) and not too sweet. I wish they had more of the prices advertised in English because I emptied all my change paying for the mooncakes, which were kinda pricey (about 5 bucks for the ones I got). They are very large though.
author: Rekha S.
